f.d: @#/ /gdams ngag mdzod/ bka' brgyud pod dang po/
Volume 7: Marpa Kagyu, Part 1

(ja) @#/ /sgrub brgyud shing rta chen po bzhi pa dgyes mdzad mar pa lo tsA chen po'i bka' brgyud la rtsa ba dang yan lag gi bka' brgyud gnyis las/ dang po gangs can grub thob rgya mtsho'i chu 'go 'phags yul bka' bab bzhi yi paN grub rnams kyi rgyud dang man ngag gi brgyud srol shin tu zab cing rgya che bar bzhugs pa tshad dang mu mtha' med pa'i gtso bo phyag chen rgya gzhung / rngog dkyil bdun la sogs pa'i sgrubs thabs dang / dbang / rdzogs rim khrid yig thabs grol gyi man ngag gi yig cha rnams mdzod chen rnam pa lnga yi ya gyal bka' brgyud sngags mdzod chen po rgyab rten dang bcas pa sogs la bzhugs su gsol la/
The fourth chariot practice lineage is the Kagyu tradition of the master Marpa, the great lotsāwa, who was an emanation of Hevajra and the grandfather of the teachings of the practice lineages.[1]
'dir man ngag gnad kyi nying khu zab mo gdams ngag mdzod du ji ltar bzhugs pa'i mtshan tho la/ gzhung rtsa 'grel gyi skor dang / gdams ngag khrid kyi rim pa gnyis las/
Its instructions are divided into two parts: the cycle of root texts and commentaries and the instructions.
dang po [gzhung rtsa 'grel gyi skor]
I. The Cycle of Root Texts and Commentaries
['di] la / thun mong phyag chen gyi skor dang / thun min chos drug gi skor gnyis las/
dang po thun mong phyag chen gyi skor
A. The Shared Mahāmudrā Cycle
['di] la/ …
@#/ /zab lam phyag rgya chen po dang nA ro chos drug gi gzhung gces par btus pa nges don rin po che'i mdzod ces bya ba bzhugs so// // (1)
[rgyud kyi rgyal po rnyog pa med pa]
1. The Unsullied State, A Monarch of Tantras[1]
(2)@#/ /rgya gar skad du/ a nA ni la tan+t+ra rA dza na ma/
In the language of India: Anāvilatantrarājānāma.[7]
bod skad du/ rgyud kyi rgyal po rnyog pa med pa zhes bya ba/
In the language of Tibet: rGyud kyi rgyal po rnyog pa med pa zhes bya ba.
rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to Vajraḍākinī.
sems can rnams la phan 'dod pas/ / rnyog med rab tu bshad par bya/ ! /
With the wish to benefit sentient beings I will explain the unsullied. (1–2)
snang ba med cing dpe med pa/ / tshig gi yul las rnam par 'das/ /
Nonappearing and without example, it transcends the reach of words. (3–4)
zhi zhing bdag med dag pa nyid/ / mtshan med mtshan gzhi rnam par spangs/ / ngang gi sangs rgyas 'di nyid tshul/ / mtshan med mtshan gzhi rnam par spangs/ /

It is peace, an absence of self, purity itself—an absence of characteristics, devoid of a basis of characteristics. The natural buddha is this way:[8] an absence of characteristics, devoid of a basis of characteristics.[9] (5–8)
khyad par du yang mdor bsdus pas/ / bdag gis gsal bar bshad pa yin/ / rmongs pa rnams la phan 'dod pas/ / snying rjes 'di ni bstan pa yin/ ! /
I will clearly explain this by summarizing its distinctions.[10] I will present this with compassion, wishing to benefit the dull-witted. (9–12)
kha cig stong par 'dod pa dang / / kha cig thig le'i gzugs can dang / / kha cig khyab 'jug tshul gyis ni/ / blo dman dang ni 'jog par byed/ /
Some posit emptiness, some the forms of bindus, others follow the way of Viṣṇu. Such are the approaches of inferior minds. (13–16)
de nyid nges par yang dag par/ / rgyu yi gnas kyi spyod yul nyid/ / rgyu dang 'bras (3)bu ma grub na/ / bsgom pa med cing byang chub med/ /
Suchness, certainly and truly, is the domain of the causal state. {3} If causes and their results are not existent, there is no meditation and no awakening. (17–20)
rgyu yi yid ches spangs pa 'di/ / thog ma tha ma med pa'i bdag / sgyu ma'i ye shes las byung ba/ / rnam pa sna tshogs ston par byed/ /
The abandonment of conviction about causes is the beginningless and endless self. Various manifestations are displayed from the wisdom of illusions. (21–24)
kha cig drag po'i rang bzhin du/ / kha cig zhi ba chen po che/ / kha cig phyag rgya'i rang bzhin gzugs/ / kha cig 'dar zhing g.yo ba dang / /
Some are of a wrathful nature, others are very peaceful, some have forms of the nature of mudrās. Some shake and move. (25–28)
glu gar de bzhin sil snyan dang / / lha yi sngags ni brjod pa nyid/ / kha cig sngags ni yang dag 'god/ / kha cig dkyil 'khor bri ba dang / /
There are expressions of songs, dance, cymbals, and the mantras of deities. Some arrange mantras, others draw maṇḍalas. (29–32)
dbang la sogs pa brtag pa dang / / 'byung dang 'byung las gyur pa'i lus/ / de ltar la sogs mtha' yas mchog / sangs rgyas la sogs rdo rje brtags/ ! /

Designations, such as abhiṣekas, and bodies,[11] which are of the elements and the element derivatives— those and the like, the infinite and supreme— are vajra designations of buddhas and others. (33–36)
gang tshe sems ni legs gnas pa/ / de bzhin nyid kyi spyod yul nyid/ / dkyil 'khor de bzhin 'gyur ba ni/ / phan 'dod rnams ni shes par bya/ /
When the mind rests well, that is the sphere of suchness. Those who wish for benefit should know that to be like a maṇḍala. (37–40) {4}
phung po la sogs (4) tshogs rnams kyis/ / gang zhig khyad par gyis bcos pa/ / lus ngag yid gsum bcos pa'i phyir/ / rdul tshon dkyil 'khor zhes byar gsungs/ /
What are fabricated through what is special, by the collections, such as the skandhas,[12] are called “colored-powders maṇḍalas,” because body, speech, and mind are fabricated. (41–44)
phung sogs gzhan bogs mthong ba'i phyir/ / tshogs kyi dkyil 'khor zhes byar gsungs/ / sems kyi dkyil 'khor dag pa ste/ / rang bzhin med par bsgom par bya/ /
Because the skandhas and the like[13] are seen as other and so on, they are called “the maṇḍalas that are collections.” Meditate on the pure maṇḍala of mind as lacking any nature. (45–48)
me long lta bu gcig nyid de/ / dang po grwar ni rtogs par bya/ / so sor rtog pa zhes gsungs pas/ / shar gyi grwar ni rnam par brgyan/ /
What is mirrorlike is to be realized on the first side. What is called “discriminating” adorns the southern side.[14] (49–52)
bya ba nan tan khyad 'phags pa/ / byang gi grwar ni rnam par spros/ / mnyam nyid ye shes chen po ni/ / bag chag med grwa rjes rtogs byed/ /
The special assiduous application[*2] radiates on the northern side. The great wisdom of equality is realized on the side of no latent tendencies. (53–56)
gzhan du'ang dkyil 'khor gru bzhi ba/ / grwa yi dbus ni thams cad du/ / de nyid 'di ni rab 'jug pas/ / ye shes spyod yul du ni brtag /
Furthermore, the center of the square maṇḍala, on its sides and throughout, is designated as the sphere of wisdom, since it is the engagement with suchness. (57–60)
sgo bzhir yang dag brjod pa ni/ / de bzhin dran pa bzhir byung ba/ / de bzhin grwa bzhir gsungs pa ni/ / sbyin pa bzhi ni rnam dag pa/ /
The correct description of the four doors is that they are where the four mindfulnesses[*3] arise. Similarly, the four sides are taught to be four pure generosities.[*4] (61–64)
dbus su dkyil 'khor gzugs su ni/ / mi bskyod pa yis rnam par brgyan/ / zhi dang chos don brgyan pa las/ / de dag thams cad dkyil 'khor 'grub/ /
The center is ornamented by Akṣobhya, the form of the maṇḍala. The maṇḍala is formed from the ornaments of peace, dharma, and benefits. (65–68)
drwa ba drwa phyed zla ba sogs/ / dkyil 'khor du ni bris pa dang / / rta babs la sogs thams cad ni/ / ting 'dzin yan lag rta babs nyid/ /
The garlands and pendants, the moon, and the rest, what are drawn on the maṇḍala, and everything, such as the torans, are the branches of samādhi. (69–72)
sems kyi mthar thug brjod pa ste/ / de nyid rang bzhin las ni gsungs/ / gang zhig sems kyi rab 'phel ba/ / ting 'dzin yan lag rnam par gnas/ /
The torans themselves are said to be the final state of mind, being of the nature of suchness. What develops the mind is the branches of samādhis. (73–76)
de nyid drwa ba zhes su gsungs/ / drwa ba phyed pa phyed du ste/ / dril bu do shal brtag pa ni/ / rang gi btsun mo rtogs par byed/ /
Suchness is called “garlands.” The hanging pendants are designated as bells and mid-length necklaces, which bring realization of your queen. (77–80)
sgra brnyan rnam pa lta bur ni/ / chos rnams thams cad so sor rtogs/ / chos rnams ma skyes mthong ba'i phyir/ / de nyid rgyal mtshan phreng bar gsungs/ /
All phenomena are realized to be like echoes. Because phenomena are seen to be unborn, suchness is said to be the victory banners and mālās. (81–84)
bla re la sogs gang phres pa/ / dngos po la sogs dang por nges/ / sems ni bla re zhes byar bshad/ / dam pa'i (5)don las gsungs pa'o/ /
Whatever is hung,[15] canopies and the like, are first ascertained as entities and so on. Mind is explained to be what are called “canopies,” when taught in terms of the ultimate point. (85–88) {5}
gos phreng de dag thams cad ni/ / rnam pa sna tshogs snang ba nyid/ / gang zhig rdo rje rnam pa'i sems/ / dga' ba'i ye shes kyis ni mtshan/ /
All the clothes and mālās are appearances of various manifestations. Mind in the manifestation of vajra is marked by the wisdom of joy. (89–92)
de yi 'og tu rtag tu gsungs/ / grwa yi mtshams ni thams cad du/ / rdo rje rin chen rtogs pa'i phyir/ / rdo rje rin po che yis sbus/ /
Following that, it is constantly taught: all edges of the sides are decorated[16] with vajra jewels, since the vajra jewel is realized. (93–96)
zla ba nyi ma gang gsungs pa/ / thabs dang shes rab don mthong phyir/ / thabs dang shes rab bdag nyid sems/ / ye shes 'dis ni rnam par brgyan/ /
Because what are said to be the moon and sun are seen to be method and prajñā, the mind, the embodiment of method and prajñā, is adorned with this wisdom. (97–100)
sku gsung thugs kyi rdo rje skyes/ / de nyid dkyil 'khor du ni gsungs/ ! /
The arising of the vajras of body, speech, and mind is taught to be the maṇḍala of suchness. (101–2)
sku gsung thugs ni nye ba'i phyir/ / rnam pa gcig tu mtshan nyid med/ / bla ma slob ma rnam gsal bar/ / rab tu 'jug pa de nyid gsungs/ !
Since body, speech, and mind are close, as a single manifestation, they have no characteristics. It is taught that the guru and students entering the clear manifestation is suchness. (103–6)
sbyin sreg yang ni bshad pa yang / / lha rnams tshim pa nga yis brjod/ / rnam rtog med pa'i sems gang ni/ / thab khung sgra yis mtshon pa nyid/ /
In the explanation of homa I will describe how to satisfy the deities. The nonconceptual mind is symbolized by the term “firepit.” (107–10)
bye brag phyed pas me nang du/ / gzugs kyi phung sogs lnga po rnams/ / sems las byung ba'i yam shing nyid/ / thams cad kyis ni sreg blugs bya/ /
Specifically, into the fire, the five—the skandha of forms and the others— the firewood arising from mind, are poured and burned.[17] (111–14)
gzugs la sogs pa gang byung ba/ / yam shing zhes ni rab tu grags/ / de ltar sbyin sreg bshad nas ni/ !
Forms and so forth, which arise, are well known to be what is called “firewood.” Thus, that is the explanation of homa. (115–17)
rab tu gnas pa brjod par bya/ / sku gsung thugs la rtag tu ni/ / gang zhig sems ni brtan gyur pa/ / de nyid rab tu gnas par brjod/ / phung po rnams kyi dngos po ci/ ! /
I will describe consecration. The constant stabilization of mind within body, speech, and mind is said to be the consecration of suchness. It is the entities of the skandhas.[18] (118–22)
gang zhig sngags kyi mtshan nyid ni/ / de ni gsal bar brjod par bya/ / yid rnams kyis ni skad du yang / / gang zhig gsang ba bdag gis brjod/ /
I will clearly describe the characteristic of mantras. I state that it is what is secret, including what is expressed in language by minds. (123–26)
skye ba med cing snang med pa/ / mtshan gzhi mtshan nyid rnam par spangs/ / gsang ba'i don ni rtogs pa'i phyir/ / 'di ni nga yi sngags su gsungs/ !
They are unborn, nonappearing, devoid of characteristics and a basis of characteristics. Since the secret point is realized, I[19] declare this to be mantras. (127–30)
sngags ni gsal bar bshad nas ni/ / lha rnams yang ni brjod par bya/ / phung po khams dang skye mched kyi/ / rang bzhin gyi ni legs gnas gang / (6)
Having clearly explained mantras, I will discuss the deities. They are present as the natures of the skandhas, dhātus, and āyatanas. (131–34) {6}
yang dag byang chub thar pa nyid/ / de kun yang dag rab brtags shing / / gal te sems kyis nyer brtags gang / / lha zhes bya bar yang dag bshad/ /
True awakening and liberation, when correctly discerned and determined by the mind,[20] are correctly explained as what are called “deities.” (136–38)
sku gsung thugs kyi phyag rgya las/ / de nyid du ni yang dag gsungs/ ! /
Being mudrās of body, speech, and mind, they are truly taught to be suchness. (139–40)
lha la gsol btab rnal 'byor ni/ / gsal bar nga yis brjod par bya/ / de nas skyil krung bcas nas ni/ / sna yi rtse mor bltas nas kyang / /
I will clearly explain the yoga of supplicating the deities. Seated cross-legged,[21] gaze at the tip of your nose. (141–44)
rang gi rang bzhin rnal 'byor gyis/ / de nyid mthong ba gzhag par bya/ / snying ga'i gnas su lag pa gnyis/ / 'bad pas mnyam par sbyar nas su/ /
With the yoga of your own nature, rest in seeing suchness. Press your hands together deliberately at your heart. (145–48)
mi rtog pa yi rang bzhin du/ / gang tshe sems ni rab rgyu ba/ / sangs rgyas thams cad 'dus pa'i bdag / de tshe de la skye bar 'gyur/ /
When mind moves in the nature of nonconceptuality, the lord embodying all buddhas arises there in that moment.[22] (149–52)
sangs rgyas thams cad 'dus pa'i bdag / myur bar byin gyis rlobs par 'gyur/ ! /
The lord embodying all buddhas quickly bestows blessings. (153–54)
sangs rgyas thams cad 'dus pa'i bdag / sangs rgyas kun gyi sdom pa'i bdag / thugs kyi rdo rjes gsungs pa bzhin/ / rnal 'byor sangs rgyas thams cad 'gyur/ /
The lord embodying all buddhas is the lord binding all buddhas. As taught by Vajra Mind, this is all buddhas of yoga.[23] (155–58)
nga yis gsal bar brjod pa ni/ / sku gsung thugs kyi grub sbyin pa/ / sangs rgyas kun mchog gsang ba'i don/ / thabs dang shes rab spyod yul don/ /
I explain clearly that the bestowing of the attainments of body, speech, and mind is the secret point of the buddha jewel, the point of the sphere of method and prajñā. (159–62)
sems can don du snying rje che/ / sangs rgyas byang chub rab sgrub pa/ /
For the sake of beings, with great compassion,[24] cultivate the awakening of the buddhas. (163–64)
sna rtse'i dkyil 'khor nga yis gsungs/ / de dag thams cad dbyibs tsam du/ / mdor bsdus thams cad ma byas so/ ! /
I teach the maṇḍala of the tip of the nose. All that has just a shape, all that is summarized, is not made. (165–67)
res 'ga' dam tshig 'khor lo yang / / de nyid ces bya ma gsungs so/ / rtogs pa cung zad tsam gyis ni/ / gang 'grub de ni res 'ga' yang / / gsung gi 'khor lor gsungs pa yin/ /
Sometimes, even the cakra of samaya is not said to be suchness. Even what is accomplished by the slightest realization is sometimes said to be the cakra of speech.[25] (168–72)
rnam rtog med par lhag mos pas/ / sgrub po dam pas bsgrub par bya/ /
Through being highly dedicated to nonconceptuality, the genuine practitioner will practice. (173–74)

khrag dang khu ba de bzhin sha/ / bshang ba dang ni gci ba nyid/ / dam tshig zhes bya rab 'bad par/ / gang zhig bdag gis tshig gsungs pa/ de rnams kun la de bzhin (7) gshegs/ / de rnams tha snyad tsam gyis gnas/ /
Menses, semen, flesh, feces, and urine I have spoken of in words, deliberately calling them “samayas.” There the tathāgatas {7} abide merely as conventional expressions. (175–79)
gang tshe dam tshig 'dod chags sems/ / des ni de nyid rab tu spyod/ / gang tshe sems ni chags gyur pa/ / de ni sems can yod ma yin/ /
When the samaya is the mind of passion, that is enjoying suchness. When the mind is [without] passion, there are no existent sentient beings.[26] (180–84)
de la kun tu rtog pa yis/ / khrag ni za bar 'gyur ba'o/ / khrag ni chen po zos nas ni/ / 'od dpag med pa'ang bza' bar bya/ /
Menses, which[27] is understood as that, is to be eaten. Having eaten that great menses, you have eaten Amitābha. (185–88)
gang zhig chos rnams las skyes pa/ / khu ba'i sgrar ni bsgrag par bya/ / de tshe ma skyes rtogs pa'i phyir/ / bza' bar yang dag gsungs pa nyid/ /
What is born from phenomena is known to be semen. In order to realize the unborn at that time, it is correctly said to be food. (189–92)
dngos po kun gyi mnyam pa nyid/ / sha chen du ni rab tu dbye/ / mi dmigs pa yi rnal 'byor gyis/ / bza' ba zhes byar mngon par brjod/ /
The equality of all things is determined to be great flesh. With the yoga of nonobservance, that is said to be what is called “food.” (193–96)
gang zhig rab tu 'dzag pa'i sems/ / nus pa'i rjes su sbyong ba las/ / phyag rgya las kyi sbyor ba yis/ / de yang gci ba'i sgra yis brjod/ /
The mind that leaks, through being in union with the potential and the union of action with a mudrā, is referred to as urine. (197–200)
chos dang chos min nges pa'i sems/ / sbas pa'i char ni gnas pa 'di/ / chos rnams thams cad rab rtogs pa'o/ / bshang ba za bar yang dag brjod/ /
This hidden aspect, mind ascertaining what is dharma and what is not, realizes all phenomena. It is said correctly to consume feces.[28] (201–4)
dam tshig nyid kyi mtshan nyid ni/ / 'di rnams thams cad gsal bar bshad/ ! /
The characteristics of samaya are clearly taught as these. (205–6)
'di rnams don ni rtogs pa yis/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi bdag nyid 'gyur/ /
Those who realize these points become the embodiment of all buddhas. (207–8)

dpal bde ba dam pa rtogs par byed pa dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i rgyud byin gyis brlabs pa'i rim pa chen po mkha' 'gro ma drwa ba sdom pa'i brtags pa rnyogs pa med pa zhes bya ba rdzogs so/ / rgya gar gyi mkhan po paN+Di ta ga ya d+ha ra dang / / bod kyi lo tsA ba dge slong shAkya ye shes kyis bsgyur ba'o/ /

This completes The Unsullied State: The Section of the Bond of the Net of Ḍākinīs, the Great Process of Blessings, [from the Monarch of] Tantras[29] Called “Endowed with the Means to Realize Glorious Sacred Bliss.” It was translated [into Tibetan] by the Indian scholar Paṇḍita Gayadhara and the Tibetan lotsāwa Gelong Śākya Yeshe.[*5]

'di ni spros pa dang bcas pa'i spyod pa thams cad spros med de kho na nyid phyag rgya chen po la sbyar ba'i nges pa don gyi rgyud de khyad par 'phags pa ste/ paN+Di ta gzhon nu zla bas mdzad pa'i 'grel ba rgya gar phyag na dang / mtshur lo tsA ba ye shes 'byung gnas kyis bsgyur ba'ang yod/ / mchan/ !

[*5] Interlinear note: This is an exceptional tantra of the definitive meaning that connects all conducts [or practices] involving elaborations (spros bcas pa’i spyod pa) to mahāmudrā, unelaborate suchness (spros med de kho na nyid). There is a commentary written by Paṇḍita Kumāracandra translated [into Tibetan] by the Bhārata-pāṇi [Indian Vajrapāṇi] and Tsur Lotsāwa Yeshe Jungne.
do ha mdzod kyi glu
2. Dohā for the People. Song That Is a Treasury of Dohās[1]
rgya gar skad du/ /do ha ko Sha grA ti/ /
In the language of India: Dohakoṣagīti.[13]
bod skad du/ /do ha mdzod kyi glu/ /
In the language of Tibet: Do ha mdzod kyi glu.
'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to youthful Mañjuśrī. {8}
dug (8)sbrul lta bu'i skal med ni/ / nges par skye bo dam pa la/ / skyon gyi dri mas dgod pa'i phyir/ / mthong ba tsam gyis 'jigs par byos/ ! /
Viperous ones lacking in fortune, with their problematic flaws, make truly holy beings laugh. Be afraid to even see them.[14] (1–4)
de nyid mi shed bram ze ni/ / gyi na rigs byed bzhi dag 'dod/ / sa chu ku sha dag byed dang / / khyim na gnas shing me la bsregs/ / don med sbyin sreg byed pa ni/ / du bas mig la gnod par bas/ ! /

Brahmans, unaware of suchness, recite the lowly four Vedas.[15] Purifying with earth, water,[16] and kuśa, they sit at home, burning the fires. Their eyes sting with the smoke of their meaningless performance of burnt-offering rituals. (5–10)
dbyu gu dbyug gsum legs ldan gzugs/ / tha dad pa dang dad pas bsten pa dag / chos dang chos min shes par mi mnyam zhing / / 'gro ba rnams ni brdzun pa nyid du gol/ ! /

Those of the Staff, with three staffs, adopt the form of the Lord, either relying on separate [forms] or the geese.[*2][17] The same as those who don’t know dharma from nondharma,[18] they lead beings to stray into falsehood. (11–14)

e ra'i thal bas lus la byugs nas su/ / mgo la ral pa'i khur bu khur bar byed/ / khyim du mar me btang nas gnas/ / mtshams su 'dug nas dril bu 'khrol/ / skyil krung bcas nas mig btsums te/ / rna bar shub shub skye bo slu bar byed/ / khyo med skra med 'di 'dra gzhan la ston/ / dbang rnams bskur zhing bla ma'i yon rnams len/ ! /

Smearing their bodies with the ashes of eras,[*3] piling masses of hair on their heads, lighting fires in their homes, they sit on the side and tinkle their bells. Cross-legged, eyes closed, whispering in people’s ears, they deceive them. They teach others what resembles the husbandless and the hairless.[*4] And, after giving abhiṣekas, they take the guru fee. (15–22)
sen mo rings zhing lus la dri mas g.yogs/ / gos dang bral zhing skra ni 'bal bar byed/ / nam mkha'i yid can gnod byed lam gyi gzugs/ / thar pa'i ched du bdag nyid grol byed slu/ ! /

Long-nailed and covered with filth, without clothes and with their hair ripped out, Kṣapaṇakas[*5] adopt a form of the path that harms. They are deceived [in thinking] they are heading toward liberation.[19] (23–26)

gcer bus gal te grol 'gyur na/ / khyi dang wa sogs cis mi grol/ / spu btogs bas ni grol 'gyur na/ / bud med spu btogs grol bar 'gyur/ / 'jug spu bslang bas grol 'gyur na/ / rma bya g.yag sogs grol bar 'gyur/ / langs te za bas grol 'gyur na/ / rta dang glang po ci phyir min/ ! /

If nakedness brings liberation, why are dogs and foxes not liberated? If plucking hair brings liberation, women who remove their hairs will be liberated. If swishing a tail about brings liberation, peacocks and yaks will be liberated. If eating while standing up brings liberation, why isn’t that so for horses and elephants? (27–34)
mda' bsnun na re nam mkha'i yid can la/ / thar pa nam yang yod pa ma yin zer/ ! /
Saraha says, “Kṣapaṇakas will never be liberated.” (35–36)

bde ba'i de nyid dang ni bral gyur zhing / / lus kyi dka' thub 'ba' zhig tsam ldan pas/ / dge tshul dge slong gnas brtan zhes bya bas/ / ban+de rnams ni de ltar rab byung nas/ / kha cig mdo sde 'chad par byed cing 'jug / la la ro gcig sems kyi tshul 'dzin mthong / / kha cig theg chen de la rgyug byed cing / / (9) de ni gzhung lugs tshad ma'i bstan bcos min/ ! /

Lacking blissful suchness and only enduring physical asceticism, bandes, called “śrāmaṇeras,” “bhikṣus,” and “sthaviras,” are, accordingly, monastics. Some set out to teach the sūtras. Some regard one taste as the mode of the mind. Others run after the Mahāyāna. {9} Theirs are not śāstras of authentic scriptural traditions.[20] (37–44)

gzhan yang dkyil 'khor 'khor lo ma lus bsgom/ / kha cig bzhi pa'i don 'chad pa la zhugs/ / la la nam mkha'i khams la rtog par snang / / gzhan yang stong nyid ldan par byed pa de/ / phal cher mi mthun phyogs la zhugs pa yin/ /

Others meditate on all the maṇḍala cakras. A few expound the meaning of the fourth. Some conceptualize the dhātu of space. Still others make emptiness into a view.[21] Mostly they engage the opposite [of what they seek]. (45–49)

lhan cig skyes bral gzhan gang gis/ / mya ngan 'das gang sgom byed pa/ / de dag 'gas kyang don dam ni/ / cig shos 'grub par mi 'gyur ro/ / gang zhig gang la mos par gyur pa des/ / bsam gtan gnas pas thar pa thob bam ci/ /

Those divorced from the connate state may take nirvāṇa as their meditation, but they won’t achieve the ultimate in isolation.[*6] How can those who believe in something achieve liberation by resting in meditative concentration? (50–55)
mar me ci dgos lha bshos de ci dgos/ / de la ci bya gsang sngags bstan pa ci zhig dgos/ / 'bab stegs 'gro dang dka' thub mi dgos te/ / chu la zhugs pas thar pa thob bam ci/ /

Why do you need candles? Why offering cakes? What will such things do? What’s the use of teaching Secret Mantra? Visiting bathing places and being ascetic aren’t necessary. How can dunking yourself in water achieve liberation? (56–59)
snying rje dang bral stong pa nyid zhugs gang / / des ni lam mchog rnyed pa ma yin no/ / 'on te snying rje 'ba' zhig bsgoms na yang / / 'khor ba 'dir gnas thar pa thob mi 'gyur/ /
Those who remain in emptiness without any compassion do not discover the sublime path. Yet those who only meditate on compassion remain here in saṃsāra, never attaining liberation. (60–63)
gang yang gnyis po sbyor bar nus pa des/ / 'khor bar mi gnas mya ngan 'das mi gnas/ ! /
Whoever can unite the two abides in neither saṃsāra nor nirvāṇa. (64–65)
kye lags gang smras brdzun zhing log pa de bor la/ / gang la zhen pa yod na de yang thongs/ ! /
Kye la. What gets said is a lie and wrong—reject it. If you have an attachment, let it go. (66–67)
rtogs par gyur na thams cad de yin te/ / de las gzhan pa sus kyang shes mi 'gyur/ / klog pa de yin 'dzin dang sgom pa de yin te/ / bstan bcos snying la 'chang pa'ang de yin no/ ! /

When you’ve become realized, everything is that. No one knows anything other than that. Reading is that, retaining and meditating are that too. Explaining the śāstras and purāṇas is that as well.[22] (68–71)
de yis mtshon pa'i lta ba yod min te/ / 'on kyang gcig tu bla ma'i zhal la ltos pa yin/ ! /
There’s no view that doesn’t reveal that[23]— and yet it is solely reliant upon the gurus’ words. (72–73)
bla mas smras pa gang gi snying zhugs pa/ / lag pa'i mthil du gnas pa'i gter mthong 'dra/ ! /
When the guru’s speech has entered your heart, it’s like seeing a treasure in the palm of your hand. (74–75)
gnyug ma'i rang bzhin byis pas ma mthong bar/ / 'khrul pas byis pa bslus zhes mda' bsnun smra/ /
Saraha says, “The childish do not see the intrinsic nature and, being confused, they deceive the childish.”[24] (76–77)

bsam gtan med cing rab tu 'byung ba med/ / khyim na gnas shing chung ma dag dang lhan cig tu/ / gang zhig yul gyi dga' bas (10)bcings las mi grol na/ / mda' bsnun nang ni de nyid shes pa yin zhes smra/ ! /

If you have no meditative concentration and no renunciation and, sitting at home together with your spouse, aren’t liberated from your entanglements with pleasure, {10} I, Saraha, say, “You do not know suchness.”[25] (78–81)

gal te mngon du gyur na bsam gtan ci/ / gal te lkog tu gyur na mun pa 'jal/ / lhan cig skyes pa'i rang bzhin de nyid ni/ / dngos dang dngos po med pa ma yin te/ / mda' bsnun 'o dod rtag tu 'bod par byed/ ! /
If it is manifest, why practice meditative concentration? If it’s hidden, you’re trying to weigh darkness. Saraha constantly shouts, “The connate nature is neither an entity nor a nonentity.” (82–86)
gang zhig blangs nas skye shi gnas gyur pa/ / de nyid blangs nas bde chen mchog grub ces/ / skad gsang mthon pos mda' bsnun smra byed kyang / / byol song 'jig rten mi go ji ltar bya/ ! /

“What is taken up is born, abides, and dies, and what is taken up creates the sublime great bliss.”[*7] Although Saraha shares these lofty secret words, the bestial worldly don’t get it—what to do? (87–90)
bsam gtan bral bas ci zhig bsam byar yod/ / brjod du med gang ji ltar bshad du yod/ / srid pa'i phyag rgyas 'gro ba ma lus bsdus/ ! /
Being free from meditative concentration, what can be contemplated? How can the ineffable be explained? Beings are deceived by the mudrā of existence. (91–93)
rang bzhin gnyug ma sus kyang blangs pa med/ / rgyud med sngags med bsam bya bsam gtan med/ / de kun rang yid 'khrul bar byed pa'i rgyu/ /
No one can adopt the intrinsic nature. No tantra, no mantra, no object of contemplation or meditative concentration. Those just create confusion in your minds. (94–96)
rang bzhin dag pa'i sems la bsam gtan dag gis mi bslad de/ / bdag gi de nyid bde la gnas shing gdung bar ma byed cig ! /
Don’t adulterate the naturally pure mind with meditative concentrations. Your nature rests in bliss—don’t torment yourself.[26] (97–98)

za zhing 'thung la gnyis sprod kyis dga' zhing / / rtag tu yang dang yang du 'khor lo 'geng / / chos 'di lta bus 'jig rten pha rol 'grub 'gyur te/ / rmongs pa 'jig rten mgon po rdog pas mnan nas song / /

With eating, drinking, and enjoying sex constantly filling the cakras, again and again, this dharma achieves what’s beyond the world. Crushing the heads of ignorant worldly ones, I move on.[27] (99–102)
gang dur rlung dang sems ni mi rgyu zhing / / nyi ma zla ba 'jug pa med gyur pa/ / mi shes pa dag gnas der dbugs phyung zhig / mda' bsnun gyis ni man ngag thams cad bstan nas song / ! /
When the winds and mind don’t move and the sun and moon don’t engage, those who are unaware, take respite by resting there. Saraha gave all the instructions and went away. (103–6)
gnyis su mi bya gcig tu bya ba ste/ / rigs la bye brag dag tu ma 'byed par/ / khams gsum ma lus 'di dag thams cad ni/ / 'dod chags chen po gcig tu kha dog sgyur cig dang / /
Don’t create dualities: let there be unity. Don’t divide the potential into categories. Transform these three realms, in their entirety, into the single color of great passion. (107–10)
der ni thog ma dbus mtha' med/ / ji srid mya ngan 'das pa min/ / bde ba chen po mchog 'di la/ / bdag dang gzhan du yod ma yin/ /
There, there’s no beginning, no middle, no end, no existence, no nirvāṇa. Sublime great bliss has neither self nor other.[28] (111–14)
mdun dang rgyab dang phyogs bcu ru/ / gang gang mthong ba de de nyid/ / de ring nyid du mgon po nga ltar 'khrul pa chad/ / (11) da ni su la'ang dri bar mi bya'o/ ! /
In front, behind, and in all ten directions, whatever you see is suchness. Today, one like me, the protector, severs confusion.[29] {11} Now there’s no need to ask anyone anything. (115–18)
dbang po gang du nub gyur cing / / rang gi ngo bo mnyam par 'gyur/ / grogs dag de ni lhan cig skyes pa'i lus/ / bla ma'i zhal las gsal bar dris/ ! /
Where the sense faculties subside, your essence does the same. Friends, that is the body of connateness. Ask the guru for clarification. (119–22)

yid ni gar 'ching rlung gar dengs/ / sa steng 'di na yan lag gnas/ / de ni rmongs pas mtshams su yongs shes bya/ / gti mug rgya mtsho 'chad pa gang shes pa/ / 'di ni bde chen mchog yin te/ / sa ra ha yis bstan nas 'gro/ /

Where mentation dies and the winds dissipate,[30] on this ground, the branches rest. Know that to be the border of ignorance.[31] Recognizing the ocean of bewilderment has been cut off is the sublime great bliss. Saraha taught this and departed. (123–28)
kye ho 'di ni rang rig yin pa ste/ / 'di la 'khrul pa ma byed cig ! /
Kye ho. This is reflexive awareness. Don’t be mistaken about it. (129–30)
dngos dang dngos med bde bar gshegs pa'i 'ching ba ste/ / srid dang mnyam nyid tha dad ma 'byed par/ / gnyug ma'i yid ni gcig tu gtod dang rnal 'byor pa/ / chu la chu bzhag bzhin du shes par byos/ /

Existence and nonexistence are bonds for sugatas. Not separating existence and equality, yogins and yoginīs, rest as one with the intrinsic mind.[32] Know this to be like water that’s been poured into water. (131–34)
bsam gtan brdzun pas thar pa rnyed min no/ / sgyu lus drwa bas ji ltar pang du 'khyud/ ! /
False meditative concentration won’t bring liberation. It’s like being held in a lap [created] in a web of magical illusions.[33] (135–36)
bla ma dam pa'i bka' yis bde bar yid ches par/ / nga yis brjod du yod min zhes ni mnga' bsnun smra/ ! /
Having confidence in the truth through the genuine guru’s words,[34] Saraha says, “I have nothing to say.” (137–38)
gdod nas dag pa nam mkha'i rang bzhin la/ / bltas shing bltas shing mthong ba 'gag par 'gyur/ / de lta bu nyid dus su 'gog par 'gyur/ ! /
Look and look at the primordially pure nature of space, and seeing ceases. At such time there is cessation. (139–41)
gnyug ma nyid la skyon gyis byas pa bslus/ / skye bo ma lus lhag par sun 'byin cing / / nga rgyal skyon gyis de nyid mtshon mi nus/ ! /
The childish with their flaws are deceived about the intrinsic state. They then criticize others excessively. Marred by their pride, they’re unable to reveal suchness. (142–44)
'jig rten ma lus bsam gtan gyis rmongs 'gyur/ ! /
All worldly meditative concentrations result in confusion. (145)

gnyug ma'i rang bzhin sus kyang mtshon du med/ / sems kyi rtsa ba min mtshon te/ / lhan cig skyes pa rnam gsum gyi/ / gang las de skyes gang du nub/ / gang du gnas 'gyur gsal bar mi shes so/ / rtsa ba bral ba'i de nyid gang sems pa/ / bla ma'i man ngag mthong ba de yis mchog ! /

No one can show the intrinsic nature. The root of mind isn’t revealed. It’s not clearly known where threefold connateness[*8] arises, abides, and subsides. For those who contemplate suchness free from a root, receiving the guru’s instructions is sufficient.[35] (146–52)

'khor ba'i rang bzhin sems kyi ngo bo nyid yin zhes/ / rmongs rnams mda' bsnun gyis smra co ne shes par byos/ / gnyug ma'i rang bzhin tshig gis mi brjod kyang / / slob dpon man ngag mig gis mthong bar 'gyur/ / chos dang chos min mnyes nas bros (12) pa yis/ / 'di la nyes pa rdul tsam yod ma lags/ ! /

“The nature of saṃsāra is the essence of mind.” Know clearly that’s what Saraha says to the ignorant. The intrinsic nature can’t be spoken of in words, but with the ācārya’s instructions, the eyes can see it. Dharma and non-dharma: consume them with delight. {12} Here there isn’t a trace of a flaw. (153–58)
gnyug ma'i yid ni gang tshe sbyangs gyur pa/ / de tshe bla ma'i yon tan sting la 'dug par 'gyur/ / 'di ltar rtogs nas mda' bsnun glu len te/ / sngags dang rgyud rnams gcig kyang ma mthong ngo / ! /
Once the intrinsic mind is purified, the guru’s excellent qualities enter your heart.[36] With this realization, Saraha sings this song though not having seen a single mantra or tantra. (159–62)
'gro rnams las kyis so sor bcings gyur te/ / las las grol na yid ni thar pa yin/ / rang rgyud grol na nges yang gzhan med do/ / mchog gi mya ngan 'das pa thob par 'gyur/ ! /
All beings are bound by their own karma. When freed from karma, their minds are liberated. If your mindstream is freed, there’s definitely nothing else: you’ve achieved the sublime nirvāṇa. (163–66)
sems nyid gcig pu kun gyi sa bon te/ / gang la srid dang mya ngan 'das 'phro ba/ / 'dod pa'i 'bras bu ster bar byed pa yin/ / yid bzhin nor 'dra'i sems la phyag 'tshal lo/ ! /
Mind-itself alone is the seed of everything: it radiates existence and nirvāṇa and bestows the desired fruits. Homage to the mind, like a wish-fulfilling gem. (167–70)
sems bcings pas ni 'chings gyur te/ / de nyid grol na the tshom med/ / blun po gang gis 'chings 'gyur ba/ / mkhas rnams de yis myur du grol/ ! /
When mind is fettered, you are bound. It can be liberated—have no doubts. What binds fools swiftly sets the wise free. (171–74)
sems ni nam mkha' 'dra bar gzung bya ste/ / nam mkha'i rang bzhin nyid du sems gzung bya/ ! /
Regard the mind as being like space. Take the mind to be of the nature of space. (175–76)

yid de yid ma yin par byed 'gyur na/ / des ni bla med byang chub thob par 'gyur/ / mkha' 'drar byas na rlung ni rnam par 'ching / / mnyam nyid yongs su shes pas rab tu zim/ / mda' bsnun gyis smras nam zhig nus ldan na/ / mi rtogs yo ba myur du sprod par 'gyur/ ! /

When mentation is no longer mentation, unsurpassable awakening is attained. When [mind] is taken to be like space, the winds are bound.[37] When you recognize equality, they dissolve.[38] Saraha says, “When you have this ability, you can quickly abandon the impermanent and the moving.”[39] (177–82)

rlung dang me dang dbang chen 'gag pa na/ / bdud rtsi rgyu ba'i dus su rlung ni sems la 'jug / nam zhig sbyor ba zhi gnas gcig la ni zhugs pa ni/ / bde chen mchog ni nam mkha'i khams su mi shong ngo / ! /

When wind, fire, and the mighty[*9] cease and amṛta moves, wind enters mind. When the four yogic techniques converge in the one state, sublime great bliss doesn’t fit into the realm of space. (183–86)
khyim dang khyim na de yis gtam smra yang / / bde chen gnas ni yongs su shes pa med/ / 'gro kun bsam pas su 'byin mda' bsnun smra/ / bsam gyis mi khyab grub pa 'ga' yang med/ ! /
In house after house, tales of this are told, yet the state of great bliss isn’t fully known. Saraha says, “With their ideas, beings dismiss it.”[40] None accomplish the inconceivable. (187–90)
srog chags thams cad kun la yang / / de nyid yod de rtogs pa med/ ! /
Suchness is present in all living beings, and yet they don’t realize that. (191–92)
thams cad ro mnyam rang bzhin pas/ / bsam pas ye shes bla med pa'o/ ! /
Since everything is of the nature of equal taste, there is nothing higher than inconceivable wisdom.[41] (193–94) {13}
kha sang (13)de ring de bzhin sang dang gzhan/ / don rnams phun sum tshogs par skye bo 'dod/ / kye ho bzhin bzang snyim pa chus bkang ba/ / 'dzag pa bzhin du nyams pa ma tshor ro/ ! /
Yesterday, today, tomorrow, and beyond, people like to believe things are prospering. Kye ho. Beautiful people, like water seeping from your cupped hands, you don’t feel your loss. (195–98)
bya ba byed dang bya ba min byed pa/ / nges par rtogs na 'ching dang grol ba med/ ! /
When you’re definitely realized, what you do or don’t do neither binds you nor frees you. (199–200)
yi ge med las 'chad par yod 'dod pa/ / gang zhig rnal 'byor brgya la 'ga' yis mtshon/ ! /
Among the hundreds of yogins and yoginīs claiming to explain what’s beyond letters, only a few can reveal it. (201–2)
'jur bus bcings pa'i sems 'di ni/ / glod na grol bar the tshom med/ / dngos po gang gis rmongs pa 'chings/ / mkhas rnams de yis rnam par grol/ /
If the mind twisted into knots is relaxed, it’s free—there is no doubt. Things bind the ignorant, but they set the wise free. (203–6)
bcings pa dag ni phyogs bcur 'gro ba rtsom/ / mthong bar gyur na mi g.yo brtan par gnas/ / go bzlog rnga mo lta bur bdag gis rtogs/ / bu khyod rnams kyang rang la cher te ltos/ /
What is bound wants to run in the ten directions. When let go, it stays still and motionless.[42] I understand these camel-like perversities. Children, look directly at your [mind].[43] (207–10)
kye lags dbang po ltos shig dang / / 'di las ngas ni ma gtogs so/ ! /
Kye la. Look with your faculties. Apart from this, I haven’t realized anything.[44] (211–12)
las zin pa yi skyes bu yi/ / drung du sems thag bcad par byos/ /
In the presence of a being who’s finished with karma, be conclusive about mind. (213–14)
rlung bcings pa la rang nyid me sems skye/ / shing gi rnal 'byor sna rtser ma 'du gcig / e ma 'o ma yin lhan cig skyes pa mchog chags byos/ / srid pa'i sna rtser 'ching ba yang dag spangs/ /

Kye. When binding the winds, don’t think about yourself. Wooden yogin or yoginī, don’t stay on the tip of your nose. E ma ho—that’s not it: long for the sublime connate.[45] Give up being bound to the tip of the nose of existence. (215–18)
'di ni yid 'dus pa la rlung gi rlabs/ / g.yo zhing 'phyar la shin tu mi srun 'gyur/ / lhan cig skyes pa'i rang bzhin rtogs gyur na/ / de yis bdag nyid brtan par gyur pa yin/ ! /
When mentation is gathered, the coursing of winds moves and surges, causing wildness. When you realize the connate nature, you become the epitome of stability. (219–22)
gang tshe yid ni nyer bar 'gags gyur na/ / lus kyi 'ching ba rnam par 'chad par 'gyur/ / gang tshe lhan cig skyes dang ro mnyam pa/ / de tshe dman pa'i rigs dang bram ze med/ ! /
Once mentation ceases, the bonds of the body are severed. Once all has become of one taste with the connate, there are neither brahmans nor outcastes. (223–26)
'di ni zla ba rgya mtsho nyid dang ni/ / 'di ni gang+gA'i rgya mtsho nyid dang ni/ / pa ra NA si pra ya g+ha ya ti/ / 'di ni zla ba gsal byed nyid/ ! /
This is the Candra Ocean. This is the Ganges Ocean, Varanasi, Prayag, and Ghayati too. This is illuminated by the moon.[*10][46] (227–30)
zhing kun gnas dang nye ba'i gnas sogs pa/ / phyin te bltas pa'i rtogs pa gang smra ba/ / lus dang 'dra ba'i mu gnas gzhan na med/ ! /
Some go to the sacred fields, abodes, nearby abodes, and all, claiming realization through seeing.[47] There are no sacred abodes like the body. (231–33)

dge ba de yis nges par yang dag mthong / / 'dab ldan pad+ma'i sdong po ge sar gyi dbus na/ / (14)shin tu phra ba'i snal ma dri dang kha dog ldan/ / bye brag 'ongs shing rmongs pa mya ngan gyis/ / gdung pa 'bras bu med par ma byed cig /

I have truly and definitively seen virtue.[48] A lotus with its stem and petals, its center of pistils and stamens, {14} is a subtle natural thing[49] with scent and color. Variations arise and the ignorant are distressed. Don’t let that pain eliminate the results.[50] (234–38)
gang tshe tshangs pa khyab 'jug mig gsum dang / / 'jig rten ma lus thams cad gzhir gyur pa/ / rigs med de la mchod na las kyi yang / / mtha' yi tshogs ni yang dag zad par 'gyur/ ! /

For some, Brahmā, Viṣṇu, and the Three-Eyed [Shiva][51] are the foundations of the entire world. If you offer to the one without family,[*11] all your amassed extremes of karma will be completely exhausted. (239–42)
kye ho bu nyon rtsod pa'i ro ni dag par yang dag gnas shes pa/ 'gro ba 'chad cing 'don la sogs pas de ni shes par nus ma yin/ /
Kye ho. Listen, children: delighting in the taste of debate, recognizing the true state,[52] then explaining about beings, reciting, and so on, doesn’t enable you to know this. (243–44)
kye ho bu nyon de nyid sna tshogs kyis/ ro 'di bstan par nus pa ma yin te/ / bde ba'i gnas mchog rtog spangs te/ / 'gro ba nye bar skye ba nyid bzhin no/ ! /
Kye ho. Listen, children: those various ways can’t show you this taste. The sublime state of bliss abandons thoughts, like those arising within beings. (245–48)
blo ni rnam 'gags yid ni pham gyur pa/ / gang du mngon pa'i nga rgyal chad pa'o/ / de nyid sgyu ma'i rang bzhin mchog tu rtog pa ste/ / de la bsam gtan 'ching ba des ni ci byar yod/ ! /

Intellect ceases, mentation is overcome, and there, overt pride is cut. Those are fully realized to be of the nature of illusions. With that, what can the bonds of meditative concentration do? (249–52)
dngos por skyes pa mkha' ltar rang bzhin na/ / dngos po rnam sangs phyi nas ci zhig skye/ / gdod nas skye med rang bzhin yin pa la/ / de ring dpal ldan bla ma bsten pas rtogs/ ! /
If the nature of arising things is like space,[53] when they are abandoned, what could arise next? Today, through the glorious guru’s teachings, I realize the primordial, unborn nature. (253–56)
mthong dang thos dang reg dang dran pa dang / / za snom 'khyams dang 'gro dang 'dug pa dang / / cal col gtam dang lan smra gyur pa la/ / sems so zhe na gcig gi rnam pa la mi bskyon/ ! /

If you recognize that seeing, hearing, touching, recollecting, eating, smelling, wandering, going, staying, talking idly, and speaking in reply are mind, you won’t waver from the expressions of the one [mind].[54] (257–60)
gang zhig bla ma'i man ngag bdud rtsi'i chu/ / gdung sel bsil ba ngom par mi 'thung bar/ / de ni bstan bcos don mang mya ngam gyi/ / thang la skom pas gdung te 'chi bar zad/ !

Those who don’t drink to satiety the cooling amṛta of their guru’s instructions—the dispeller of pain— will simply die of tormenting thirst on a desolate desert,[55] despite [knowing] the meaning of many śāstras. (261–64)
bla mas bstan pa brjod min na/ / slob mas go ba ma yin te/ / lhan cig skyes pa bdud rtsi'i ro/ / gang gis ji ltar bsten par bya/ /
If a guru doesn’t speak the teachings, the disciple can’t understand. How can anyone explain[56] the taste of the amṛta of connateness? (265–68)
tshad mar 'dzin pa'i dbang gis su/ / blun pos bye brag rnyed pa ste/ / de tshe gdol pa'i khyim du rol/ / 'on kyang dri mas mi gos so/ ! /
Fueled by recognizing what’s authentic, even fools are able to discover the distinctions. Then, enjoying the homes of caṇḍālas won’t taint you with filth. (269–72) {15}
gang tshe slong na (15)srong kha'i kham bor gyis spyod de/ / bdag ni rgyal po yin na slar yang ci byar yod/ ! /
When begging, we use a bowl from the street.[57] If I were a king, what would that add? (273–74)

dbye ba rnam par spangs nas de nyid gnas pa la/ / rang bzhin mi g.yo btang snyoms lhun gyis grub/ / mya ngan 'das pa la gnas srid par mdzes/ / nad gzhan dag la sman gzhan gtong mi bya/ / bsam dang bsam bya rab tu spangs nas su/ / ji ltar bu chung tshul du gnas par bya/ ! /

Having abandoned distinctions, rest in suchness, naturally motionless, with equanimity, innately present. Abide in nirvāṇa and beautify existence. Don’t treat one disease with medicine for another. Cast away thinking and what is thought, and you’ll rest like a small child. (275–80)
bla ma'i lung la bsgrims te rab 'bad na/ / lhan cig skyes pa 'byung bar the tshom med/
If you hold to the guru’s words and apply yourself, the connate will arise—there’s no doubt. (281–82)
kha dog yon tan yi ge dang bral ba/ / smra ru mi btub de ni bdag gis gyi na mtshon/ / gzhon nu ma yi bde ba snying la zhen pa bzhin/ / dbang phyug dam pa de ni su la bstan nus sam/ ! /

Though it’s without color, qualities, and words,[58] still I try to roughly demonstrate what can’t be described. Being like the bliss a youth cherishes, can the genuine īśvara be taught to another? (283–86)
dngos dang dngos med yongs su bcad pa dang / / der ni 'gro ba ma lus rab tu thim par 'gyur/ /
Cut through existence and nonexistence. There all beings dissolve. (287–88)
gang tshe yid ni mi g.yo rang gnas brtan pa ste/ / de tshe 'khor ba'i dngos po las ni rang grol 'gyur/ / gang tshe bdag gzhan yongs su shes med na/ / de tshe bla med lus ni thob par 'gyur/ ! /
When your mind is unmoving, stable in its own place, it’s self-liberated from the things of saṃsāra. When you don’t recognize either self or other, you attain the unsurpassable body. (289–92)

de ltar bstan pa nyid las nges par ma 'khrul par/ / rang gis rang la legs par byas nas ni/ / rdul med rdul bral ma yin sems kyang min/ / dngos po de dag gdod nas zhen pa med/ / mda' bsnun gyis smras de tsam zhig tu zad/ / kye ho ma lus dri med don dam shes par byos/ ! /

Once you’re definitely not mistaken about that teaching, you know well your own [nature]. It’s not a particle, not free from particles, and not just mind. Such things could never have been fixated upon. That’s all Saraha has to say. Kye ho. Know that everything is the stainless ultimate. (293–98)
khyim na gnas pa phyi rol song nas tshol/ / khyim bdag mthong nas khyim mtshes dag la dri/ / mda' bsnun gyis smras bdag nyid shes par byos/ /
[What you seek] is in the house but you go outside to look for it. You see the owner but you question the neighbors. Saraha says, “Know yourself.” (299–301)
blun pos bsam gtan bsam bya bzlas brjod min/ / gang tshe bla mas bstan cing thams cad shes byas kyang / / bdag gis yongs su brtags pas thar pa thob bam ci/ ! /
This is not the meditative concentration, object of thought, or recitation of fools. Even when the guru teaches and everything is understood, how can you achieve liberation through analysis? (302–4)
yul rnams bgrod cing gdung bas mnyes byas kyang / / lhan cig skyes pa mi rnyed sdig pas 'dzin/ /
You may encounter objects and though afflicted with pain,[59] you won’t discover the connate, you’ll be gripped by evildoing. (305–6)
yul rnams bsten pas yul gyis mi gos so/ / u ta pa la 'dab ma chu yis ma gos bzhin/ /
Availing yourself of objects, you are not sullied by objects, {16} like utpālas are untouched by muddy water. (307–8)
(16)gang ltar rtsa ba rnal 'byor skyabs su 'gro/ / dug gi sngags can dug gis ga la tshugs/ ! /
Yogins and yoginīs take refuge in what is the root. How can poison harm the one with the mantra for poison? (309–10)
lha la mchod pa khri phrag byin nas kyang / / bdag nyid de yis 'ching 'gyur ci zhig bya/ / de 'dras 'khor ba 'di ni 'chad min te/ / gnyug ma'i rang bzhin ma rtogs brgal mi nus/ !
You may make ten thousand offerings to the gods and yet those bind you—so what’s the use? Such things don’t cut through saṃsāra. Without realizing the intrinsic nature, you can’t cross over. (311–14)
mig ni mi 'dzum pa sems kyang mi 'gog dang / / rlung 'gog pa ni dpal ldan bla mas rtogs/ / gang tshe rlung rgyu de ni mi g.yo ste/ / 'ching ba'i tshe na rnal 'byor pas ci bya/ ! /

Eyes not closed, mind stopped,[60] and winds stopped: this is realized through the glorious guru. When the winds move, [now] there’s no wavering. At death, what’s there for a yogin or yoginī to do?[61] (315–18)
ji srid dbang po yul gyi grong la lhung / / de srid rang nyid las med rab tu rgyas/ / khyed cag da ltar ci byed som dang kye/ / de ni shin tu dka' ba'i dgongs pa 'jug ! /

As long as the faculties wallow in the city of objects, they increase—despite not existing apart from you. All of you, consider: kye, what do you do right now?[62] Engage that state, difficult to fathom. (319–22)
gang zhig gang la gnas pa ni/ / de ni de ru mi mthong ste/ / mkhas pa thams cad bstan bcos 'chad pa yis/ / lus la sangs rgyas yod par ma rtogs so/ /
What abides in someone isn’t seen as such. Scholars explaining the śāstras don’t realize the presence of the buddha in the body. (323–26)
glang chen lobs nas sems chags tshud pas na/ / der ni 'gro 'ong chad nas ngal ba ste/ / 'di ltar rtogs na gang du'ang dri sa med/ / mkhas pa ngo tsha med pas de ma rtogs/ ! /

When elephants have been trained and their minds are workable, in that case, coming and going are severed and there’s gentleness.[63] When you have that realization, there’s no one to question, but scholars, lacking integrity, don’t realize that. (327–30)
gson pa gang zhig rnam par ma gyur pa/ / de ni rgas shing 'ching bar 'gyur ram ci/ ! /
Some living beings don’t change. Do they age or die?[64] (331–32)
bla mas bstan pa dri med blo gros ni/ / de nyid gter yin gzhan pa gang zhig la/ ! /
The stainless intelligence taught by the guru is the treasure—nothing else.[65] (333–34)
yul nyid rnam par dag ste bstan bya min/ / stong pa 'ba' zhig gis ni spyad par bya/ / ji ltar gzings las 'phur ba'i bya rog bzhin/ / skor zhing skor zhing slar yang de ru 'bab/ ! /

Objects themselves are pure and aren’t supports.[66] Being only emptiness, that’s what’s to be practiced. This is like a crow who flies from a ship, circles and circles, and lands there again. (335–38)
thag pa nag po'i dug sbrul bzhin/ / mthong ba tsam gyis sdang bar 'gyur/ ! /
A rope masquerading as a black poisonous snake creates terror upon sight. (339–40)
grogs dag skye bo dam pa ni/ / yul gnyis skyon gyis bcings par 'gyur/ /
Friends, holy beings, the flaws of the two objects bind you.[*12] (341–342)
yul la zhen pas 'ching bar ma byed cig / kye ho rmongs pa mda' bsnun gyis smras pa/ / nya dang phye leb glang chen bung ba dang / / 'di ni ri dwags bzhin du bya bar byos/ ! /
Don’t be caught by fixating on objects. Kye ho. Ignorant ones, Saraha says, “[Look] what happens to fish, moths, elephants, bees, and deer.” (343–46) {17}
gang zhig sems las (17) rnam 'phros pa/ / de srid mgon po'i rang bzhin te/ / chu dang rlabs dag gzhan yin nam/ ! /
Whatever radiates from mind is necessarily of the nature of the protector. Are water and waves different? (347–49)
srid dang mnyam zhing nam mkha'i rang bzhin na/ ! /
Existence and equality are of the nature of space.[67] (350)
gang zhig bstan te gang thos pa/ / dgongs pa gang yin dam pa skyol ba na/ / nyi zer lkugs pa sa yi rdul bzhin brlag / snying ga nyid du nub par gyur pa yin/ ! /

Someone hears what someone teaches. When that someone arrives at the sacred—what’s intended— then, like dust [disappearing when] the sun’s rays are blocked,[*13] [thoughts] flatten: they subside within the heart.[68] (351–54)
ji ltar chu la chu bzhag na/ / de snyed chu ru ro mnyam 'gyur/ / skyon dang yon tan mnyam ldan sems/ / mgon po sus kyang mthong mi 'gyur/ /
When water is poured into water, it becomes of the same taste as that water. The mind with the sameness of faults and virtues is the protector, not seen by anyone. (355–58)
rmongs pa dag la gnyen po gang yang med/ / nags la mched pa'i me lce bzhin/ / gdong du bab pa'i 'di ltar snang ba kun/ / sems kyi rtsa ba stong pa nyid du lhan cig byos/ ! /
There are no remedies for the ignorant. Like flames spreading through a forest, know that all that appears before you is connate with emptiness, the root of mind. (359–62)
gal te yid du 'ong ngam snyam pa'i sems/ / snying la bab pa gces par byas na ni/ / til gyi shun pa tsam gyi zug rngus kyang / / nam yang sdug bsngal 'ba' zhig byed par zad/ ! /
If the mind that thinks, “This is attractive,” takes that to heart and cherishes it, even pain the size of a sesame seed husk will cause constant affliction. (363–66)
de ltar yin te de ltar ma yin no/ / grogs po phag dang glang chen ltos/ ! /
There is similarity and yet there isn’t similarity. Friends, look at pigs and elephants. (367–68)
ji ltar yid bzhin nor bu'i dgos pa bzhin/ / 'khrul ba zhig pa'i mkhas pa ngo mtshar che/ / rang la rang rig bde ba chen po'i bag chags gzugs/ / thams cad de tshe mkha' mnyam byed par 'gyur/ ! /

Just like the benefits of a wish-fulfilling gem, the wise, for whom delusion has perished, are amazing. With the form of the latent tendencies of great bliss—when awareness [knows] itself— everything is then the same as space. (369–72)
kA wa kU Ta smos su ci rung ste/ / rang bzhin mkha' mnyam yid kyis 'dzin pa yin/ / yid de yid ma yin par byed 'gyur na/ / rang bzhin lhan cig skyes pa mchog tu mdzes/ ! /
Speaking of kālakūṭa isn’t useful[69]— mentation will grasp at the space-like nature. When mentation is no longer mentation, natural connateness is supremely beautiful.[*14] (373–76)
khyim dang khyim na de ni brjod min te/ / bde chen gnas ni yongs su shes pa min/ / 'gro kun sems khral khur pa bda' bsnun 'dra/ / de ni bsam med sus kyang rtogs ma yin/ ! /

In house after house, that is discussed,[70] yet the state of great bliss isn’t fully known. Saraha says, “All beings are burdened by worries. That, which isn’t conceivable, isn’t realized by anyone.” (377–80)
bde gsang yan lag yongs su spangs pa na/ / bsgom dang mi bsgom dbyer med bdag gis mthong / ! /
When you give up the offshoots of bliss and secrecy, you see the inseparability of meditation and nonmeditation. (381–82)
yul gyis mtshon pas gzhan dag bsam par byed/ / de nyid bsam pas ma rtogs rang bzhin 'gags par 'gyur/ /
For others, objects are used to create understanding. With that understanding, thoughts naturally cease.[*15][71] (383–84)
gal te sems kyis sems ni mtshon du 'gro/ / (18)rnam rtogs dang ni mi g.yo brtan par gnas/ / ji ltar lan tshwa chu la thim pa ltar/ / de ltar sems ni rang bzhin la thim 'gyur/ /
When mind reveals mind, {18} thoughts do not stir, and it remains firm. Just as salt dissolves in water, so mind dissolves into its nature. (385–88)
de tshe bdag dang gzhan ni mnyam par mthong / / 'bad de bsam gtan byas pas ci byar yod/ ! /
At that point, you see self and other as the same. What would practicing meditative concentration with effort do? (389–90)
lhan cig pa ni lung rnams ma lus mthong / / rang gi 'dod pa mang po gsal bar snang / / mgon po bdag nyid gcig pu gzhan rnams 'gal/ / khyim dang khyim na grub mtha' de grub bo/ /

Within the connate, all scriptures are seen.[72] Your individual assertions cause the many to appear clearly. I, the protector, alone contradict all others. In house after house, tenets are established. (391–94)
gcig zos pas ni thams cad tshig / phyi rol song nas khyim bdag tshol/ / 'ongs kyang ma mthong phyin chad med/ / 'phag par gyur kyang ngo ma shes/ ! /

Consume one and all are burned.[73] [And yet] you search for the homeowner by going outside. You don’t see what comes [to you] and don’t get [anywhere]. Even what’s sitting right here, you don’t recognize.[74] (395–98)
rba rlabs med pa'i dbang phyug mchog / rnyog pa med pa'i bsam gtan 'gyur/ / chu dang mar me rang gsal gcig tu zhog / 'gro 'ong nga yis mi len mi 'dor ro/ ! /

Supreme īśvara free from waves becomes unsullied meditative concentration. Leave [mind] alone to be self-illuminating, like water and candle flames.[75] I don’t accept or reject comings or goings. (399–402)
gang yang snga na med pa'i sgeg mo dang phrad nas/ / nyal ba'i sems ni gzhi med pa la brten/ / rang gi gzugs dang tha dad ma lta zhig / de ltar sangs rgyas lag tu gtod pa yin/ ! /

What you encounter as an attractive person, one previously not [experienced], is your sleeping mind relating to something groundless. Don’t see that as separate from your [mind’s] own form, and buddhahood is placed in the palm of your hand. (403–6)
gang tshe lus dang ngag yid dbyer med pa/ / lhan cig skyes pa'i rang bzhin de tshe mdzes/ / khyim bdag zos nas khyim bdag mo longs spyod/ / yul ni gang zag mthong ste spyad par bya/ ! /

When body, speech, and mind are inseparable, of the nature of the connate, [all is] resplendent. Once the householder is consumed, the housemistress is enjoyed. Whatever objects are seen are to be enjoyed.[76] (407–10)
nga yis rtsed mo byas pa la/ / bus pa rnams ni a thang chad/ / a ma bzhag nas bu de skye mi 'gyur/ / des ni rnal 'byor spyod pa dpe dang bral/ ! /
I provide the entertainment. The children are exhausted. Those children aren’t born from any other mother.[77] Therefore, yogic practice is beyond analogy.[78] (411–14)
bdag po za zhing rang bzhin mdzes/ / chags pa'i spyod des gang ba'i sems de nyid/ / chags dang chags bral spangs nas dbu mar zhugs/ / sems nyams pas na rnal 'byor ngas ma mthong / /

Consume the owner, and the nature is resplendent. The mind filled with objects of passion[79] gives up passion and passionlessness and rests in the middle.[80] As mind declines, I see the yoginī.[81] (415–18)
za zhing 'thung la bsam du med par gyur/ / grogs mo 'di ni sems la gang snang ba/ / phyi rol sems la mtshon med bdag gis 'dzin/ ! /
Eating and drinking aren’t conceptualized. My lady friend, I see that what appears to mind can’t be shown to be external to mind.[82] (419–21)
sgyu ma'i rnal 'byor pa ni dpe dang bral ba ste/ /
The illusory yoginī is beyond analogy.[83] (422)
sa gsum du yang dri med mi gnas mi 'byung ste/ / me ni spra ba nyid la rkyen gyis 'bar/ / zla ba chu 'dzag nor bu rang dbang med/ /
thabs kyis (19) rgyal srid kun la dbang bsgyur ba/ / sems nyid de nyid grub pa'i rnal 'byor ma'o/ / lhan cig skyes pa'i sdom par shes par bya/ ! /
Methods rule the kingdom. Mind-itself is the yoginī of accomplishment.[84] Know the bond of connateness. (426–28)
yi ge 'gro ba ma lus pa/ / yi ge med pa gcig kyang med/ / ji srid yi ge med gyur ba/ / de srid yi ge rab tu shes/ / snag tsha mnyes pa bklag tu med/ / rig byed don med 'don pas nyams/ ! /

All beings [using] letters don’t have what’s without letters—not even one of them. As long as there are no letters, there is understanding of letters. Rubbing ink is not reading. Reciting the meaningless Vedas brings ruin. (429–34)
dam pa sems dang gcig shos mi shes na/ / gang nas shar cing gang du nub/ / ji ltar phyi rol de bzhin nang / / bcu bzhi pa yi sa la rgyun du gnas/ ! /

Holy ones, think: if you don’t know the other one,[85] from where is there arising and to where does subsiding occur? As without, so within: the fourteenth bhūmi is present continuously.[*16] (435–38)
lus med lus la sbas pa med/ / de shes de yis grol bar 'gyur/ ! /
The formless is hidden in the body.[86] Those who know that are liberated. (439–40)
sgrub yig bzhi las dang po bdag gis ston/ / khu ba 'thungs pas nga ni brjed par gyur/ /
With the four words of accomplishment,[*17] first I teach. Drinking the elixir, then I forget.
gang gis yi ge gcig shes pa/ / de yi ming ni mi shes so/ /
Whoever knows the one letter doesn’t know its name. (441–44)
rkyen bral gsum ni yi ge gcig / zag med gsum gyi dbus na lha/ / gang zhig gsum po zag pa ni/ / gdol pa rigs byed de bzhin no/ ! /

What is free from the three conditions is the single letter. In the middle of threefold nondegeneration is the deity. Those with the three degenerations are like caṇḍālas [impersonating] Vedic [teachers].[*18][87] (445–48)
ma lus rang bzhin mi shes pas/ / kun tu ru yi skabs su bde chen sgrub pa ni/ / ji ltar sgom pas smig rgyu'i chu snyegs bzhin/ / skom nas 'chi yang nam mkha'i chu rnyed dam/ /

Those who don’t know the nature of all and yet try to produce great bliss during kunduru[*19] are like the thirsty pursuing the water of a mirage.[88] They’ll die from their thirst—how can they find water in the sky? (449–52)
rdo rje pad+ma gnyis kyi bar gnas pa/ / bde ba gang gis rnam par rol pa yin/ / ci ste de bden nus pa med pas na/ / sa gsum re ba gang gis rdzogs par 'gyur/ /
What use is it to revel in the bliss dwelling between the vajra and lotus? Since that has no capacity for truth, how can the hopes of the three planes be fulfilled? (453–56)
yang na thabs kyi bde ba skad cig ma/ / yang na de nyid gnyis su 'gyur ba ste/ / bla ma'i drin gyis slar yang ni/ / brgya la 'ga' yis shes par 'gyur/ /
Although the bliss of method is momentary, it can become both.[*20] Through the guru’s kindness, within a hundred, a few will know it. (457–60)
grogs dag zab pa dang ni rgya che ba/ / gzhan med bdag nyid ma yin no/ / lhan cig skyes dga' bzhi ba'i dus/ / gnyug ma nyams su myong bar shes/ ! /
Friends, what is profound and vast is devoid of other and is not self. Know the time of the fourth, connate joy, to be the experience of the intrinsic state. (461–64)
mun nag chen po zla ba nor bu ni/ / ji ltar 'chad par byed pa bzhin/ / mchog tu bde chen skad gcig gcig la ni/ / bsams pa'i sdig pa ma lus phan par byed pa'o/ ! /
Just as a moon jewel can light[89] up dense darkness, in a single instant of sublime great bliss, all evil deeds of thought are conquered.[90] (465–68)
sdug bsngal snang byed nub pa na/ / skar ma'i bdag po gza' dang mnyam (20) du shar/ / 'di ltar gnas pas sprul par sprul/ / de ni dkyil 'khor 'khor lo dam pa'o/ /
When the illuminator of suffering sets, the lord of the stars arises with the planets.[*21] {20} Thus abiding, emanations issue forth. They are the genuine maṇḍala cakras. (469–72)
kye ho rmongs pa'i sems kyis sems la brtags na ni/ / lta ba ngan pa thams cad las ni rang grol 'gyur/ / mchog tu bde ba chen po'i dbang gis ni/ / de la gnas na dngos grub dam pa'o/ ! /
Kye ho. When the confused mind is realized to be mind,[91] it is self-liberated from all evil views. To remain in sublime great bliss under its power is the genuine siddhi. (473–76)
sems kyi glang po yan du chug / de ni bdag nyid dris la gcig / nam mkha'i ri bo chu 'thung dang / / de yi 'gram du zhog cig rang dga' bar/ /
Let your elephant-mind go free. Ask yourself about it. Drink the sky-mountain water. Rest on its bank and enjoy yourself. (477–80)
yul gyi glang po'i dbang po lag pas blangs nas su/ / ji ltar gsod par rang dbang snang bar 'gyur/ / rnal 'byor pa ni glang po skyong ba bzhin/ / de nyid nas ni ldog par 'gyur ba yin/ ! /
The master of the elephants of objects takes them in hand— they even have the power to kill them. For yogins and yoginīs, like the trained elephants, [mind] returns to itself. (481–84)
gang zhig 'khor ba de ni mya ngan 'das pa nges/ / dbye ba gzhan du sems pa ma yin te/ / rang bzhin gcig gis dbye ba rnam par spangs/ / dri ma med pa nga yis rab tu rtogs/ ! /
Whatever is saṃsāra is definitely nirvāṇa. They aren’t to be thought of as separate divisions. The one nature eliminates divisions. I have realized the stainless. (485–88)
yid kyis de nyid dmigs dang bcas/ / dmigs pa stong pa nyid yin la/ / gnyis la skyon ni yod pa ste/ / rnal 'byor gang gis sgom pa min/ /
The suchness of mentation can involve reference points.[92] The absence of reference points is emptiness.[93] Both are flawed. That is not meditation for yogins and yoginīs. (489–92)
sgom pa dmigs bcas dmigs med de/ / sgom dang mi sgom tha snyad med/ / bde ba'i rnam pa'i rang bzhin no/ ! /
Meditation lacks reference points and the absence of reference points. It lacks the conventions of meditating and not meditating.[94] It is of the nature of bliss. (493–95)
rab tu bla med rang 'byung ba/ / bla ma'i dus thabs bsten pas shes/ ! /
What is supreme, unsurpassed, and self-arising is known by attending to the guru’s timing and methods. (496–97)
nags su ma 'gro khyim du ma 'dug par/ / gang yang de ru yid kyis yongs shes na/ / ma lus rgyun du byang chub brtag par gnas/ / 'khor ba gang yin mya ngan 'das pa gang / /
Don’t go the forest, don’t sit at home. If you know fully what there is, you will abide in the realization of awakening, continuously with all.[95] Whatever is saṃsāra, that is nirvāṇa. (498–501)
yid kyi dri med ga la lhan cig skyes pa ste/ / de tshe mi mthun phyogs kyis 'jug pa med/ ! /
When the stains of mentation are purified, there is the connate state.[96] At that time, you don’t encounter anything discordant. (502–3)
ji ltar rgya mtsho dwang bar gyur ba la/ / chu bur chu nyid yin te de nyid thim par 'gyur/ / nags dang khyim na byang chub gnas pa med/ ! /
In the pure, clean ocean water bubbles are just water and that’s where they subside. Awakening doesn’t reside in forests and homes. (504–6)
de ltar byed pa yongs su shes nas su/ / dri ma med pa'i sems kyi rang bzhin gyis/ / ma lus mi rtog pa ru brten par 'os/ / de ni bdag yin gzhan yang de bzhin no/ /
Once you fully know the distinctions,[97] then, with the nature of the stainless mind, rely on not conceptualizing anything.[98] That is self and also other.[99] (507–10)
gang bsgom yongs su bsgom pa gang / / dbye ba de nyid 'ching dang bral (21) bar bya/ / 'on kyang bdag nyid rnam par grol ba'o/ ! /
bdag dang gzhan du 'khrul pa ma byed dang / / ma lus rgyun du gnas pa'i sangs rgyas te/ / sems ni ngo bo nyid kyis dag pa na/ / de nyid dri med mchog gi go 'phang ngo / ! /
Don’t be mistaken about self and others. Everyone is the continuously present buddha. When mind is completely pure in its essence, it is stainless and the sublime achievement. (514–17)
gnyis med sems kyi sdong po dam pa ni/ / khams gsum ma lus kun tu khyab par song / / snying rje'i me tog gzhan phan 'bras bu 'dzin/ / ming ni mchog tu gzhan la phan pa'o/ /
The sacred tree of nondual mind spreads throughout the three realms. Its flowers of compassion yield the fruit of benefit for others. Its name is “sublime altruism.” (518–21)
stong pa'i sdong po dam pa me tog rgyas/ / snying rje dam pa sna tshogs du mar ldan/ / lhun gyis grub pa phyi ma'i 'bras bu ste/ / bde ba 'di ni gzhan pa'i sems min no/ ! /
On the sacred tree of emptiness, flowers bloom, infused with compassion in all its many forms.[100] Innately present, there’s the final fruit, bliss, which is not a different mind. (522–25)
stong pa'i sdong po dam pa'i snying rje min/ / gang la slar yang rtsa ba me tog lo 'dab med/ / de la dmigs par byed par gang yin pa/ / der ltung bas ni yan lag med par 'gyur/ ! /
The sacred tree of emptiness without compassion[101] has no root, no flowers, no leaves. Those who take that as their focus will fall and have no offshoots. (526–29)
sa bon gcig la sdong po gnyis/ / rgyu mtshan de las 'bras bu gcig / de yang dbyer med gang sems pa/ / de ni 'khor dang mya ngan 'das rnams grol/ /
One seed grows two trunks, and, for that reason, the fruit is the same. Whoever understands inseparability is free from saṃsāra and nirvāṇa. (530–33)
gang zhig 'dod pa can gyi skye bo 'ongs pa'i tshe/ / de ni re ba med na gal te 'gro ba ni/ / phyi sgor bor ba'i kham phor blangs nas su/ / de bas khyim thabs bor nas bsdad pa rung / /
If someone comes [to you] in need but leaves with dashed hopes, you’re better off taking a bowl discarded outside the door, leaving behind your household, and staying like that. (534–37)
gzhan la phan pa'i don ni mi byed pa/ / 'dod pa po la sbyin pa mi ster ba/ / 'di ni 'khor ba'i 'bras bu gang yin lo/ / de bas bdag nyid bor bar byas na rung / /
If you don’t work for the welfare of others and don’t give to those in need, what will be the results in saṃsāra? Tsk tsk. You’re better off leaving yourself behind. (538–42)
rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug chen po dpal sa ra ha chen po'i zhal snga nas mdzad pa do ha mdzod ces bya ba de kho nyid rnal du mtshon pa don dam pa'i yi ge rdzogs so/ /
This concludes the Treasury of Dohās composed orally by the great lord of yogins, the glorious great Saraha, whose ultimate words reveal suchness, the natural state.[*22]

phyag rgya chen po snying po'i don gyi gdams pa'i shing rta chen po 'phags yul gyi grub pa'i dbang phyug mtha' dag gi gtsug gi nor bu bram ze chen po dpal sa ra ha zhes pa 'jig rten na nyi zla ltar grags pa gang de'i dpal gyi mgur las stsal ba'i phyag rgya chen po do ha mdzod kyi rdo rje'i glu mang zhig bzhugs pa las/ dmang do har grags pa 'di ni 'phags bod kun tu bram ze chen po'i gsung rtsod med du grags shing / (22) rgya bod kyi 'grel pa dang man ngag gi yi ge'ang mang du bzhugs so/ / mchan/ ! /

[*22] Interlinear note: The great chariot of instructions on mahāmudrā, the ultimate essence (snying po don), is found in the many vajra songs of the treasuries of mahāmudrā dohās that were bestowed through the glorious songs of the Great Brahman, the crown jewel of all the siddha-lords in the Noble Land [India], the one known as the glorious Saraha, famous throughout the world like the sun and moon. Among those vajra songs, this one known as the People’s Dohā is undisputedly famous in both the Noble Land and Tibet as the speech of the Great Brahman. {22} It has many Indian and Tibetan commentaries and associated texts of esoteric instructions.
