IV. The concluding summary: The results of achieving both [emptiness and compassion][22]
sgrub pa'i rten rang bzhin rnam {bdag dang} dag dang / de yongs su grub pa'i 'bras bu dang / zhen pa spang ba skabs kyi don {gang zhig} bsdu ba'o/ /
A. The pure nature of the support for practice (self and) (514–17) B. The result achieved C. Summary of the section: Abandoning attachments (someone) (534–42)
gnyis pa la gsum/
B.
snying rje'i 'bras bu gzhan don 'byung ba'i tshul {gnyis med} dang /
1. The way the result of compassion brings benefit for others (nondual) (518–25)
snying rje dang bral bas gzhan don mi 'byung ba'i tshul {stong pa'i} dang /
2. The way benefit for others does not occur when compassion is absent (emptiness) (526–29)
stong pa dang snying rje zung 'jug gis 'khor 'das kyi mtha' las {sa bon} grol ba'o/ /
3. The unification of emptiness and compassion liberates us from the extremes of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa (seed) (530–33)
snying rje bral ba'i stong pa des/ / theg pa dman pa ltung ba yin/ /
Emptiness devoid of compassion falls into the Hīnayāna.
nyams dang bral ba'i rtogs pa de/ / chos nyid lkog du gyur pa yin/
Realization with no experiences makes dharmatā something hidden.
ma rtogs nyams la zhen pa de/ / gong ma'i khams su 'ching ba yin/ /
Fixating on experiences without realization binds us to the higher realms.
stong dang snying rje dbyer med cing / / nyams rtogs ro gcig ma nor lam/ /
The inseparability of emptiness and compassion and the one taste of experience and realization are the unmistaken path.
rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug dpal sa ra ha'i glu'i don bsdus pa/ /dge slong blo gros seng ges sbyar ba'o/ /
The summary topics for the song of the glorious Saraha, lord of yogins, were arranged by Gelong Lodrö Senge.[*1] {28}
dpal phag mo grub pa'i slob ma shes (28) rab mthar phyin spar bu zhes yongs su grags pa de'o/ /
[*1] Interlinear note: This is the one renowned as Sherap Tarjin Parbuwa [sic], a student of the glorious Pakmo Drupa.
do ha mdzod ces bya ba phyag rgya chen po'i man ngag
4. Treasury of Dohās. Esoteric Instructions on Mahāmudrā[1]
rgya gar skad du/ /do ha ko Sha nA ma ma hA mu dra u pa de sha/ / bod skad du/ /do ha mdzod ces bya ba phyag rgya chen po'i man ngag /
In the language of India: Dohakoṣanāmamahāmudropadeśa. In the language of Tibet: Do ha mdzod ces bya ba phyag rgya chen po’i man ngag.
lhan cig skyes pa'i ye shes kyi sku bde ba chen po la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to great bliss, the kāya of connate wisdom.[4]
[The topics of the text are presented in three parts:
I.
I. The Presentation of Mahāmudrā, the Abiding State
A.
A. The Explanation of How Things Are]
ji ltar dngos dang dngos med snang stong dang / / rgyu dang mi rgyu g.yo dang mi g.yo ba/ / thams cad ma lus nam mkha'i rang bzhin las/ / dus rnams kun tu nam yang g.yos pa med/ /

Without exception, everything— entities, nonentities, appearances, and emptiness, what moves and doesn’t move, what wavers and does not— never, at any moment or time, moves beyond being of the nature of space. (1–4)
nam mkha' nam mkha' zhes ni rab brjod kyang / / nam mkha'i ngo bo cir yang grub pa med/ / yod dang med dang yod min med min dang / / de las gzhan du mtshon pa'i yul las 'das/ /

Though we say, “space, space,” the essence of space doesn’t exist in any way. It transcends being an object that can be shown to exist, not exist, to be not existent and not nonexistent, or anything other than those.[5] (5–8)
de ltar mkha' dang sems kyi chos nyid la/ / tha dad cung zad yod pa ma yin te/ / tha dad ming ni blo bur btags pa tsam/ / de la don med brdzun gyi tshig tu zad/ /
Thus, there isn’t the slightest distinction between the dharmatā of mind and space. The different words are simply temporary labels: unreal, nothing more than false terms.[6] (9–12)
chos rnams thams cad rang gi sems yin te/ / sems las ma gtogs chos gzhan rdul tsam med/ / gang gis gdod nas sems med rtogs pa yis/ / dus gsum rgyal ba'i dgongs pa dam pa rnyed/ /

All phenomena are your own mind. Apart from mind, there’s not even an atom of some phenomenon. Those who realize there’s been no mind from the start have found the genuine realization of the buddhas of the three times. (13–16)

chos kyi za ma tog ces yongs su btags/ / de yang log pa'i chos gzhan ma yin te/ / gdod nas lhan cig skyes pa'i rang bzhin no/ / de yis de nyid bstan du yod min te/ / brjod du med pa sus kyang go ba med/ /

This is labeled “the basket of dharma.” It is not any other wrong dharma:[7] it is the primordial connate nature.[8] Its suchness is not demonstrable.[9] No one understands what is inexpressible. (17–21)
gal te bdag po yod na nor yod de/ / ye nas bdag med de la ci zhig yod/ / sems yod gyur na chos kun yod rigs te/ / sems med pa la chos shig su yis rtogs/ /
If an owner exists, possessions would exist. What could the primordial absence of self have? If mind exists, it follows that phenomena exist. In the absence of mind, who knows phenomena? (22–25)

sems dang chos su snang ba thams cad ni/ / btsal na mi rnyed 'tshol mkhan gang na'ang med/ / med pa dus gsum ma skyes ma 'gags pa/ / de nyid gzhan du 'gyur ba med pa ni/ / rang bzhin bde ba chen po'i gnas lugs yin/ /

When we search for mind and what appear as phenomena, nothing is found—there isn’t even a searcher.[10] What is nonexistent neither arises nor ceases in the three times. Suchness, which doesn’t become something else, is the abiding state of natural great bliss. (26–30)
de phyir snang ba thams cad chos kyi sku/ / 'gro ba sems can rnams ni sangs rgyas nyid/ / 'du byed las kun ye nas chos kyi dbyings/ / (29) btags pa'i chos kun ri bong rwa dang mtshungs/ ! /

All appearances, therefore, are the dharmakāya. All beings are buddhas. All karmic formations are primordially the dharmadhātu. {29} All imputed phenomena are the same as the horns of a rabbit. (31–34)
B.
[B. The Presentation That Sentient Beings Are Confused Due to Not Realizing Suchness]

kye ho/ nyi ma sprin bral 'od zer kun khyab kyang / / mig med rnams la mun pa nyid du snang / / lhan cig skyes pa kun la khyab gyur kyang / / rmongs pa dag la de nyid shin tu ring / / 'gro ba rnams kyis sems med ma rtogs pas/ / btags pa'i sems kyis sems nyid rab tu bcings/ /

Kye ho. The sun free from clouds shines its light everywhere, yet the blind always perceive darkness. Connateness pervades all but the deluded are far from suchness. Beings do not realize the absence of mind. The labeling mind binds mind-itself. (35–40)
ji ltar gdon gyis brlabs pa'i smyon pa dag / dbang med don med sdug bsngal byed pa ltar/ / dngos 'dzin rnam rtog gdon gyis zin pa yis/ / kye ma don med sdug bsngal 'ba' zhig byed/

Those who are insane have been blessed by demons[11] and helplessly fabricate useless suffering. Similarly, those gripped by the demon of reifying thoughts[12] create only senseless suffering—kye ma.[13] (41–44)

kha cig blo yi dbye bas rmongs rnams bcings/ / bdag po khyim du bzhag nas gzhan du tshol/ kha cig gzugs brnyan dag la don du 'dzin/ kha cig rtsa ba bor nas lo 'dab 'breg / ji ltar byas kyang bslus pa ma tshor ro/ ! /

Some are enmeshed in ignorance by their mind’s divisions. While the owner remains in the house, the search takes place elsewhere. Some take reflections to be the actual thing. Others leave the root intact and just cut off the leaves and petals. Whatever they do, they aren’t aware of the deception. (45–49)
C.
[C. The Presentation of the Way the Śavara Realizes]
kye ho/ /byis pa rnams kyis de nyid ma rig kyang / / de nyid rang la g.yo med nga yis rtogs/ / nga yis thog mtha' med par shes gyur pas/ / nga yis nga mthong nga nyid gcig pur lus/ /
Kye ho. The childish don’t know suchness, but I, not wavering from it, realize suchness.[14] I know what has no beginning or end.[15] I see myself: I alone remain.[16] (50–54)
gcig po nyid la bltas pas gcig ma mthong / / mthong bya mthong byed bral bas brjod du med/ / brjod du med pa su yis go bar 'gyur/ /
When I look at that alone, I don’t see a single thing. With nothing to see and no seer, there’s nothing to describe. Who could understand what’s inexpressible? (55–57)
gnyug ma'i yid la gang tshe byang gyur pa/ / de tshe ri khrod nga yis rtog pa 'jug / seng ge'i 'o ma snod ngan phal par min/ /
Whenever the intrinsic mind is purified, I, the Śavara, enter realization.[17] Lion’s milk is not for common, inferior bowls. (58–60)

ji ltar nags na seng ge'i nga ro yis/ / ri dwags phra mo thams cad skrag gyur kyang / / seng phrug rnams ni dga' bas rgyug pa ltar/ / gdod nas ma skyes bde chen 'di bstan pas/ / rmongs pa log rtog can rnams skrag 'gyur kyang / / skal ldan rab tu dga' bas spu zing byed/ ! /

A lion’s roar in the forest terrifies the small animals but brings the lion’s cubs running with joy. Similarly, teaching this great bliss—what’s primordial and unborn— terrifies the ignorant who hold wrong notions but causes the fortunate to tingle with goose bumps of joy. (61–66)
II.
[II. The Practice of Path Mahāmudrā
A.
A. Determining the View
1. The Presentation of the Abiding Mode of the View]
kye ho/ /ma yengs sems kyis rang gis rang la ltos/ / rang gi de nyid rang gis rtogs gyur na/ / yengs pa'i sems kyang phyag rgya chen por 'char/ / (30) mtshan ma rang grol bde ba chen po'i ngang / /
Kye ho. The undistracted mind looks at itself. When you realize your own suchness, even the distracted mind is mahāmudrā, {30} a state of great bliss, self-liberated ideas. (67–70)
rmi lam dag gi bde dang sdug bsngal kun/ / sad pa'i dus na rang bzhin med pa'i phyir/ / re dang dogs pa'i bsam pa kun spangs nas/ / dgag dang sgrub pa'i bsam pa su zhig byed/ /
Pleasure and pain in dreams have no reality when you awake. Once you’ve abandoned all notions of hopes and fears,[18] who is there to act on thoughts of blocking or encouraging anything? (71–74)
'khor dang mya ngan 'das pa'i chos rnams kun/ / nga nyid mthong bas rang bzhin med pa'i phyir/ / re dang dogs pa'i blo ni zad gyur pas/ / spang dang blang ba'i 'bad rtsol ci byar yod/ /
Seeing the suchness of the phenomena of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa,[19] thoughts with hopes or fears collapse— they’re devoid of nature. What’s the use of striving to adopt or reject? (75–78)
snang grags thams cad sgyu ma smig rgyu dang / / gzugs brnyan dang mtshungs dngos po'i mtshan ma med/ / sgyu mar snang mkhan sems nyid nam mkha' ste/ / mtha' bral dbus med sus kyang shes mi 'gyur/ /

All appearances and sounds are like illusions, mirages, and reflections: they have no real characteristics. The perceiver of illusions is mind-itself, space, without end or middle: no one can know this. (79–82)
gang+gA la sogs chu klung sna tshogs pa/ / ba tshwa can gyi rgya mtshor ro gcig ltar/ / brtags pa'i sems dang sems byung sna tshogs dag / chos kyi dbyings su ro gcig shes par byos/ /
In the same way all rivers, the Ganges and others, become of one taste in the salt ocean, know that all analyzing minds and mental events[20] are of one taste in the dharmadhātu. (83–86)
[2. The Presentation of the Way to Realize]

gang zhig nam mkha'i khams kun yongs btsal yang / / mtha' dang dbus med mthong ba yongs su 'gags/ / de bzhin sems dang chos nyid yongs btsal bas/ / snying po rdul tsam yod par ma gyur te/ / yongs su tshol ba'i sems kyang mi dmigs pa/ / ci yang ma mthong ba de de mthong yin/ /

Although we thoroughly investigate the realm of space, it has no edge and no center—and our seeing stops. Similarly, by thoroughly investigating mind and phenomena, we do not find even a particle’s worth of an essence. Since the thoroughly investigated mind is not observed,[21] that not seeing of anything is seeing. (87–92)
[3. Not Changing from That Realization]

ji ltar gzings las 'phur ba'i bya rog ni/ / phyogs rnams bskor zhing slar yang de ru 'bab/ / 'dod pa'i sems kyis bstan pa'i rjes spyod kyang / / dang po'i sems nyid gnyug ma nyid du 'bab/ / rkyen gyis mi 'gul re ba'i yid chad pa/ / dogs pa'i lkugs pa gzhig pa rdo rje sems/ /

Just like a crow flying from a ship circles in many directions yet returns, though the mind of desire pursues thoughts,[22] it returns to the intrinsic, original mind. What’s not disturbed by circumstances, what severs the mind of hope,[23] and destroys the muteness of fears is vajra mind.[24] (93–98)
B.
[B. The Presentation of Meditation
1. The Presentation That Mahāmudrā Is Without Meditation]
rtsa ba chod pa'i sems nyid nam mkha' 'dra/ ! / kye ho/ /bsgom du med pas yid la mi bya ste/ / tha mal shes pa rang lugs gnyug ma la/ / bcos pa'i dmigs pa dag gis mi bslad do/ /

The mind whose root has been cut is just like space. Kye ho. Since there’s nothing to meditate upon, don’t engage mentation. Ordinary mind in its own intrinsic state is not spoiled by contrived focuses. (99–102)
rang bzhin dag pa'i sems la bcos mi dgos/ / ma gzung ma gtang rang ga nyid du zhogs/ / gal te ma rtogs (31)blo la bsgom rgyu med/ / rtogs pa can la bsgom bya sgom byed med/ /

The naturally pure mind needs no contrivance. Don’t grasp at it, don’t release it: leave it as it is.[25] Unrealized minds have nothing to meditate upon. {31} Realized on es have neither an object of meditation nor a meditator. (103–6)
ji ltar nam mkhas nam mkha' dmigs su med/ / de ltar stong pas stong pa bsgom du med/ / gnyis med shes pa chu dang 'o ma ltar/ / sna tshogs ro gcig bde chen rgyun chad med/ /

Just as space cannot observe space, what is empty does not meditate on emptiness. The nondual mind is like water [mixed] with milk: continuous great bliss in which diversities are of one taste. (107–10)
[2. The Presentation That Not Being Separated from the State of Nonmeditation Is the Supreme Meditation]
'di ltar dus gsum rnam pa thams cad du/ / yid byer med sing ma bral gnyug ma'i ngang / / de nyid skyong la sgom zhes tha snyad btags/ /
Thus it is that throughout the three times the intrinsic state, free from extremes, is without mental activity.[26] Sustaining this is labeled with the term “meditating.” (111–13)
rlung ni ma bzung yid ni ma bcings pas/ / ma bcos shes pa bu chung lta bur zhog / dran rtog byung na de nyid rang la ltos/ / chu dang rlabs gnyis tha dad ma rtog cig /

Don’t hold your breath, don’t bind your mind. Let your uncontrived mind be like that of a small child. When a memory or thought arises, look directly at it. Don’t think that water and waves are different. (114–17)
[3. An Example Showing That Ordinary Mind, Free from the Three Spheres and Without Identification, Is Path Mahāmudrā]
yid la mi phyed phyag rgya chen po la/ / bsgom rgyu rdul tsam med pas mi bsgom ste/ / sgom med don la 'bral med sgom pa'i mchog /

With mahāmudrā, where mind doesn’t do anything,[27] there’s not even an atom’s worth of something to meditate on, so don’t meditate. Never being separated from the state of nonmeditation is the sublime meditation. (118–20)
gnyis med lhan skyes bde ba chen po'i ro/ / ji ltar chu la chu bzhag ro gcig ltar/ / ji bzhin ngang du de bzhin gnas pa'i tshe/ / dmigs 'dzin yid ni rab tu zhi bar 'gyur/ ! /

The taste of nondual, connate great bliss is like the single taste of water poured into water. When you remain in that state in just that way, the mind holding onto reference points is pacified. (121–24)
C.
[C. The Presentation of Conduct[28]
1. The Presentation That Mahāmudrā Conduct Is Not Definite]
kye ho/ /gnyis med gnyug ma'i rang bzhin gang de la/ / spang dang blang ba'i dngos po ci zhig yod/ / ngas ni chos kun ma bzung ma btang bas/ / bu khyod 'di gyis bya ba mi smra'o/ /
Kye ho. In the nature of the nondual intrinsic state[29] what things could there be to adopt or reject? I don’t hold on to phenomena or reject them. I don’t say, “Child, you must do this.” (125–28)
ji ltar nor bu de dngos med pa ltar/ / rnal 'byor shes pa de ni nges med ltar/ / 'du byed sna tshogs cal col gang smras kyang / / rnal 'byor blo ni gcig las mi dga' 'o/ /
Just as a gem is not real, the mind of a yogin or yoginī is not real.[30] No matter what kind of things they blather on about, the mind of the yogin or yoginī never goes beyond the one.[31] (129–32)
gcig nyid na ni gcig nyid yod min pas/ / rnam pa sna tshogs rtsa ba bral gyur te/ / smyon pa bzhin du rtsis med yan pa la/ / byar med spyod pa bu chung bzhin du gnas/ /

Since within the oneness, oneness itself does not exist, the myriad manifestations are free from a root. Like a madman, be carefree without judgments. Remain in the conduct of doing nothing, like a child. (133–36)
[2. The Presentation That Those Who Conduct Themselves That Way Will Not Be Tainted by Any Situation]

srid pa'i 'dam skyes pad+ma bung ba'i sems/ / nyes pa gang la gang gis gos pa med/ / za zhing 'thung la gnyis sprod bde ba dang / / gal te lus sems rab tu gdung 'gyur dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs gang la spyod gyur pa/ / gang gis ma bcings ma grol gos pa med/ /

The mind, like a lotus growing in the mud of existence,[32] isn’t tainted by any faults at all. No matter what you experience when eating or drinking, enjoying the pleasures of sex, and no matter what your physical or mental distress may be, none of it can bind you, free you, or taint you. (137–42) {32}
[3. The Presentation That Compassion Without Clinging Benefiting Others Arises Naturally]
rtogs pa'i (32) ngang spyod rtsis med ngang de nas/ / rmongs pa'i 'gro ba nyid dag mngon gyur tshe/ / mi bzod snying rje'i shugs kyis mchi ma 'byung / / bdag gzhan 'dog nas phan pa nyid la 'jug /

In the nonjudgmental sphere of realization,[33] tears flow naturally from overwhelming compassion[34] when the misery of ignorant beings is so clear. Switch places with others and do what is useful. (143–46)
don la brtags na dmigs pa gsum bral bas/ / yang dag ma yin rmi lam sgyu ma 'dra/ / chags thogs bral bas dga' zhing skyon med pas/ / sgyu ma mkhas pas sgyu ma'i don byed mtshungs/ ! /

When you examine objects, since they are devoid of the three reference points,[*3] like dreams and illusions, you see they are not real. When you’re free from attachments, [they bring] joy, not sadness,[35] just like the illusory objects created by a magician. (147–50)
III.
[III. The Breakthrough into Mahāmudrā[36]
A.
A. The Presentation of the Certainty of Attaining the Result]
kye ho/ /gdod nas dag pa nam mkha'i rang bzhin la/ / spang dang thob pa'i dngos po gang yang med/ / yid la byar med phyag rgya chen po ni/ / 'bras bu gang du'ang re bar ma byed cig /
Kye ho. The nature of space, primordially pure, has nothing to be abandoned or attained. With mahāmudrā, where the mind doesn’t do anything, don’t manufacture hopes about results. (151–54)
re ba'i sems ni gdod nas ma skyes pas/ / spang dang thob pa'i dngos po ci zhig yod/ / gal te gang gis thob pa'i dngos yod na/ / dran pa'i phyag rgya rnam bzhis ci zhig byed/ /

A mind with hope has never come into being. What could there be to abandon or attain? If there were something to be attained by someone,[*4] what would the four mudrās that are taught do?[*5] (155–58)
B.
[B. The Presentation That Desiring the Attainment of the Unattainable Is Deluded]
ji ltar ri dwags skom pas gdungs pa yis/ / smig rgyu'i chu la rab tu rgyug pa ltar/ / rmongs pa gang zhig 'dod pas rab gdungs ba/ / ji ltar 'bad kyang slar ni ring bar 'gyur/ /
Like a deer suffering from thirst[37] racing toward the water of a mirage, the ignorant suffering from desire get further and further away—despite their efforts. (159–62)
C.
[C. What Is Absolutely Unattainable Is Given the Name “Vajradhara”]
ye nas ma skyes rang bzhin rnam dag pas/ / de las khyad par cung zad yod min te/ / brtags pa'i yid ni dbyings su dag gyur pas/ / de la rdo rje 'chang zhes btags pa tsam/ /
Since the primordially unborn nature is pure, nothing differs from that at all. When the conceptualizing mind becomes pure in the expanse, that’s simply labeled “Vajradhara.” (163–65)
ji ltar bye thang skam po'i smig rgyu ni/ / chur snang chu ni gnyis su med pa ltar/ / bzod nas dag pa btags pa'i yid spangs pa/ / de la rtag chad gnyis su brjod du med/ /

Mirages on a dry sandy plain[38] do not exist as [either of] the two: an appearance of water or water. Similarly, what’s pure from the start, devoid of imagined mentation,[39] cannot be described as [either of] the two: permanence or annihilation. (166–70)
yid bzhin nor bu dpag bsam shing bzhin du/ / smon lam dbang gis re ba yongs skong ba/ / de yang 'jig rten tha snyad kun rdzob ste/ / dam pa'i don la 'ga' yang yod ma yin/ /
Like wish-fulfilling gems and wish-granting trees, the power of aspiration prayers fulfills all hopes. That too is a worldly convention, the relative, with no existence in the ultimate. (171–74)

do ha mdzod ces bya ba phyag rgya chen po snying po don gyi man ngag /dpal ri khrod dbang phyug sha ba ri'i zhal snga nas mdzad pa rdzogs so// // rgya gar gyi mkhan po shrI bai ro tsa nas rang 'gyur du mdzad pa'o/ /

This completes the instructions on the ultimate essence, mahāmudrā, called the Treasury of Dohās, composed orally by the glorious lord of śavaras, the Śavari [Saraha]. The Indian scholar Śrīvairocana[rakṣita] translated it himself.[*6][40] {33}

rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug dpal sha ba ri'i phyag rgya chen po snying po don gyi man ngag 'di nyid ras chung snyan (33) brgyud 'dzin pa'i dam pa gong ma rnams kyis thugs nyams su bzhes shing 'grel pa dang bsdus don la sogs pa'ang ci rigs pa mdzad snang ngo / ! /

[*6] Interlinear note: These instructions on the ultimate essence, mahāmudrā, of the glorious Śavari, lord of yogins, have been practiced by the earlier holy masters who held the Rechung Aural Transmission. They composed various commentaries, summaries of the topics, and so forth.
grub chen tai lo pa'i phyag rgya chen po gang+gA ma'i gzhung sa bcad 'grel pa dang bcas pa bzhugs so//
5. Ganges Mahāmudrā. Esoteric Instructions on Mahāmudrā[1]
rgya gar skad du/ ma hA mu dra u pa de sha/ bod skad du/ /phyag rgya chen po'i man ngag ! /
In the language of India: Mahāmudropadeśa. In the language of Tibet: Phyag rgya chen po’i man ngag.
dpal rdo rje mkha' 'gro la phyag 'tshal lo/ ! /
Homage to the glorious Vajraḍākinī.[6]
dka' ba spyad cing bla ma la gus pa/ / sdug bsngal bzod ldan blo ldan nA ro pa/ / skal ldan khyod kyis blo la 'di ltar byos/ ! /
Nāropa, you endured hardships, are devoted to your guru, are intelligent and patient with pain. Worthy person, keep this in mind.[7] (1–3)
phyag rgya chen po bstan du med kyis kyang / / dper na nam mkha' gang gis gang la brten/ / rang sems phyag rgya che la brten yul med/ / ma bcos gnyug ma'i ngang du glod la zhog ! /
Mahāmudrā cannot be shown.[8] For example, with space, what supports what? Your mind, mahāmudrā, has no supported objects. Be relaxed in the uncontrived intrinsic state.[9] (4–7)
bcings pa klod na grol bar the tshom med/ / dper na nam mkha'i dkyil bltas mthong ba 'gag par 'gyur/ / de bzhin sems kyis sems la bltas byas na/ / rnam rtog tshogs 'gag bla med byang chub 'thob/ ! /

Let your bonds go and there’s no doubt: you will be liberated. For instance, when you look into the middle of space, seeing stops. Similarly, when mind looks at mind, the masses of thoughts cease and unexcelled awakening is attained.[10] (8–11)

dper na sa rlangs sprin ni nam mkha'i dbyings su dengs/ / gar yang song ba med cing gar yang gnas pa med/ / de bzhin sems las byung ba'i rtog tshogs kyang / / rang sems mthong bas rtog pa'i rba rlabs dwangs/ ! /

For example, clouds of ground mist vanish into the expanse of space. They go nowhere and reside nowhere. Similarly, when the masses of thoughts rising up in the mind are seen to be mind itself, the waves of thoughts vanish.[11] (12–15)

dper na nam mkha'i rang bzhin kha dog dbyibs las 'das/ / dkar nag dag gis gos shing 'gyur ba med/ / de bzhin rang sems snying po kha dog dbyibs las 'das/ / dge sdig dkar nag chos kyis gos mi 'gyur/ ! /

For example, space in its nature transcends color and shape. It’s untainted and unchanged by anything virtuous or unvirtuous. Similarly, mind in its essence transcends color and shape. It’s untainted by the virtuous and unvirtuous phenomena of good and evil.[12] (16–19)
dper na gsal dwang nyi ma'i snying po de/ / bskal pa stong gi mun pas sgrib mi 'gyur/ / de bzhin rang sems snying po 'od gsal de/ / bskal pa'i 'khor bas sgrib par mi nus so/ ! /

For example, the brilliant clarity of the sun in its essence can’t be obscured by thousands of eons of darkness. Similarly, your mind in its essence, luminosity, can’t be obscured by eons of saṃsāra.[13] (20–23)

dper na nam mkha' stong par tha snyad rab brtags kyang / / nam mkha' la ni 'di 'drar brjod du med/ / de bzhin rang (34) sems 'od gsal brjod gyur kyang / / brjod pas 'dir 'drar grub ces tha snyad gdags gzhi med/ ! /

For example, we use the term “empty” to refer to space, but space cannot be described as being “like this.” {34} Similarly, your mind is said to be luminous, yet there is no basis to which the expression “it exists like this” applies.[14] (24–27)

de ltar sems kyi rang bzhin gdod nas nam mkha' 'dra/ / chos rnams thams cad de ru ma 'dus med/ / lus kyi bya ba yongs thongs rnal 'byor dal bar sdong / / ngag gi smra brjod med de grags stong brag cha 'dra/ / yid la ci yang mi bsam la bzla'i chos la ltos/ /

In that way, the nature of mind is primordially like space. No phenomenon is not included within it. Give up physical activities: be at ease in union with the natural state. Don’t talk: that sound-emptiness is just echoes. Don’t think at all: behold the phenomenon of the breakthrough.[15] (28–32)
lus la snying po med pa smyugs ma'i sdong po 'dra/ / sems ni nam mkha'i dkyil ltar bsam pa'i yul las 'das/ / de yi ngang la btang bzhag med par glod la zhog ! /
Body has no essence, like a stalk of bamboo. Mind, like the center of space, transcends being an object of reflection. Remain relaxed in that state, not discarding or keeping anything.[16] (33–35)
sems pa gtad so med na phyag rgya chen po yin/ / de la goms shing 'dris na bla med byang chub 'thob/ ! /
When mind is without reference point, that is mahāmudrā. When you are accustomed to and familiar with this, you achieve unsurpassable awakening.[17] (36–37)

sngags su smra dang pha rol phyin pa dang / / 'dul ba mdo sde sde snod la sogs pa/ / rang rang gzhung dang grub pa'i mtha' yis na/ / 'od gsal phyag rgya chen po mthong mi 'gyur/ / zhe 'dod byung bas 'od gsal ma mthong bsgribs/ ! /

The specific texts and philosophies of those who expound Mantra, of the pāramitās, vinaya, sūtras, and the various piṭakas will not bring you to see luminosity-mahāmudrā. Your expectations obscure and you don’t see luminosity.[18] (38–42)

rtog pa'i srung sdom dam tshig don las nyams/ / yid la mi byed zhi 'dod kun dang bral/ / rang byung rang zhi chu yi pa tra 'dra/ / mi gnas mi dmigs don las mi 'da' na/ / dam tshig mi 'da' mun pa'i sgron me yin/ ! /

Vows guarded conceptually impair the true state of samaya. Don’t do anything with your mind—be free from expectations. What is self-arisen is self-pacified, like ripples on the water. If you don’t pass beyond the true state in which there’s no dwelling and no observing, you don’t pass beyond samaya and are a lamp in darkness.[19] (43–47)
zhe 'dod kun bral mtha' la mi gnas na/ / sde snod chos rnams ma lus mthong bar 'gyur/ ! /
If you’re free from expectations and don’t abide in extremes, you will see all the dharma of the piṭakas without exception.[20] (48–49)
don 'dir gzhol na 'khor ba'i btson las thar/ / don 'dir mnyam bzhag sdig sgrib thams cad sreg / bstan pa'i sgron me zhes su bshad pa yin/ /

If you immerse yourself in this true state, you’ll be liberated from saṃsāra’s prison. Resting evenly in this true state burns up all wrongdoings and obscurations. This explanation is called “the lamp of the teachings.”[21] (50–52)

don 'dir mi mos skye bo blun po rnams/ / 'khor ba'i chu bos rtag tu khyer bar zad/ / ngan song sdug bsngal mi bzad blun po snying re rje/ / mi bzad thar 'dod bla ma mkhas la bsten/ / byin rlabs snying la zhugs na rang sems grol bar 'gyur/ ! /

The foolish, uninterested in this true state, are always swept up in saṃsāra’s rivers. Alas, how sad: these fools suffer unbearably in the lower states. If you desire liberation from what’s endless, attend upon skillful gurus. Once their blessings enter your heart, your mind is free.[22] (53–57)
kye ho 'khor ba'i chos 'di don med sdug bsngal rgyu/ / byas pa'i chos la snying po med pas don ldan snying po ltos/ /
Kye ho. The phenomena of saṃsāra are meaningless, the causes of suffering. Since all created phenomena have no essence, look at the essence of what’s meaningful.[23] (58–59) {35}
gzung 'dzin kun las (35)'das na lta ba'i rgyal po yin/ / yengs pa med na bsgom pa'i rgyal po yin/ / bya btsal med na spyod pa'i rgyal po yin/ / re dogs med na 'bras bu mngon du 'gyur/ ! /

Transcending percepts and perceivers is the sovereign of view. Being without distraction is the sovereign of meditation. Being without striving is the sovereign of conduct. Being without hopes and fears reveals the result.[24] (60–63)
dmigs pa'i yul 'das sems kyi rang bzhin gsal/ / bgrod pa'i lam med sangs rgyas lam sna zin/ / bsgom pa'i yul med goms na bla med byang chub 'thob/ ! /

Beyond any object of focus, the nature of mind is clear. Having no path to travel is the start of the path to buddhahood. Once you are familiar with the absence of an object of meditation, you attain unsurpassable awakening.[25] (64–66)
kye ma 'jig rten chos la legs rtogs dang / / rtag mi thub ste rmi lam sgyu ma 'dra/ / rmi lam sgyu ma don la yod ma yin/ / des na skyo ba skyed la 'jig rten bya ba thongs/ /

Kye ma. Contemplate worldly phenomena well. They do not endure, being like dreams and illusions. Dreams and illusions in fact don’t exist. Become disenchanted and cast aside worldly activities.[26] (67–70)
'khor yul chags sdang 'brel pa kun gcod nas/ / gcig pur nags 'dabs ri khrod gnas par bsgom/ / bsgom du med pa'i ngang la gnas par gyis/ / thob med thob na phyag rgya chen po 'thob/ /

Sever your love-hate ties with those around you and your land. Meditate alone in hermitages, in the mountains or forests. Remain in a state of nonmeditation, and when you attain the unattainable, you have attained mahāmudrā.[27] (71–74)
dper na ljon shing sdong po yal ga lo 'dab rgyas/ / rtsa ba gcig bcad yal ga khri 'bum skam/ / de bzhin sems kyi rtsa ba bcad na 'khor ba'i lo 'dab skam/ ! /

For example, if you sever the one root of a tree with spreading branches full of leaves, all those many branches will wither. Likewise, when you sever the root of mind, the leaves of saṃsāra wither.[28] (75–77)
dper na skal stong bsags pa'i mun pa yang / / sgron me gcig gis mun pa'i tshogs rnams sel/ / de bzhin rang sems 'od gsal skad cig gis/ / bskal par bsags pa'i ma rig sdig sgrib sel/ ! /

For example, darkness may persist for thousands of eons, but a single lamp will dispel that gloom. Similarly, an instant of your own mind’s luminosity will dispel the ignorance, evil deeds, and obscurations that have endured for eons.[29] (78–81)
kye ho/ /blo yi chos kyis blo 'das don mi mthong / / byas pa'i chos kyis byar med don mi rtogs/ / blo 'das byar med don de thob 'dod na/ / rang sems rtsad chod rig pa gcer bur zhog /

Kye ho. The true state beyond the intellect isn’t seen by means of intellectual dharma. The true state of nonaction isn’t realized through fabricated dharma. If you wish to attain the true state of nonaction beyond the intellect, investigate your mind and remain in naked awareness.[30] (82–85)
rtog pa dri ma'i chu de dwangs su chug / snang ba dgag sgrub mi bya rang sar zhog / spang len med par snang srid phyag rgyar grol/ /

Let the murky water of thoughts clear. Leave appearances to be in themselves—don’t stop or create anything. When there’s no rejection or acceptance, all possible appearances are liberated as mudrā.[31] (86–88)
kun gzhi skye ba med par bag chags sdig sgrib spong / / snyem byed rtsis gdab mi bya skye med snying por zhog / snang ba rab snang blo yi chos rnams zad du chug /

The ālaya, being unborn, is devoid of latent tendencies, wrongdoings, and obscurations. Don’t inflate or judge: remain in the unborn essence. Appearances are self-appearances: let mental phenomena collapse.[32] (89–91)
mu mtha' yongs grol lta ba'i rgyal po mchog / mu med gting yangs sgom pa'i rgyal po mchog / mtha' chod phyogs bral spyod pa'i rgyal po mchog / (36) re med rang grol 'bras bu'i mchog yin no/ ! /

The full release from extremes is the supreme sovereign of view. Boundless, spacious depth is the supreme sovereign of meditation. Severing extremes and being without partiality is the supreme sovereign of conduct. {36} Self-liberated, free from hopes, is the supreme of results.[33] (92–95)
las ni dang po gcong rong chu dang 'dra/ / bar du chu bo gang+gA dal zhing g.yo/ / tha ma chu rnams ma bu 'phrad pa 'dra/ /

For beginners, it feels like water cascading over a cliff. In the middle, it’s the gentle flow of the Ganges River. At last, all waters become like the reuniting of a mother with her children.[34] (96–98)
blo dman skyes bu'i ngang la mi gnas na/ / rlung gi gnad bzung rig pa bcud la bor/ / lta stangs sems 'dzin yan lag du ma yis/ / rig pa dang la mi gnas bar du gcun/ ! /

If those of normal intelligence can’t rest in that state, they should use breath techniques and extract the elixir of awareness. Using various kinds of methods—gazes and ways of concentrating— hold [mind] until it is still within awareness.[35] (99–102)

las rgya bsten na bde stong ye shes 'char/ / thabs dang shes rab byin rlabs snyoms par 'jug / dal bar dbab cing bskyil bzlog drangs pa dang / / gnas su bskyal dang lus la khyab par bya/ / de la chags zhen med na bde stong ye shes 'char/ ! /

Practicing with a karmamudrā gives rise to the wisdom of bliss-emptiness. Bless the upāya and prajñā, and enter union. Allow [the bindus] to slowly descend, retain them, reverse them, draw them up, and spread them to all places, allowing them to pervade your body. If you have no attachment or fixation toward that, the wisdom of bliss-emptiness will arise.[36] (103–7)
tshe ring skra dkar med cing zla ltar rgyas par 'gyur/ / bkrag mdangs gsal la stobs kyang seng ge 'dra/ / thun mong dngos grub myur thong mchog la gzhol bar 'gyur/ ! /

You will live long, have no gray hairs, [your vitality] increasing like the [waxing] moon. Your complexion will be radiant and your strength like that of a lion. You will quickly attain the common siddhis and reach what is supreme.[37] (108–10)
phyag rgya chen po gnad kyi man ngag 'di/ / 'gro ba skal ldan snying la gnas par shog /
May these instructions on the key points of mahāmudrā remain in the hearts of all worthy beings.[38] (111–12)

phyag rgya chen po grub pa'i dpal tai lo pa chen po'i zhal snga nas mdzad pa kha che'i paN+Di ta mkhas la grub pa'i nA ro pas dka' ba bcu gnyis mdzad pa'i rting la chu bo gang+gA'i 'gram du tai lo pas gsungs pa phyag rgya chen po rdo rje'i tshig rkang nyi shu rtsa dgu pa rdzogs so// //

This completes the twenty-nine[*1] vajra verses on mahāmudrā composed orally by the great, glorious Tilopa, one who achieved [the realization of] mahāmudrā. Tilopa spoke these on the bank of the Ganges River to the Kashmiri paṇḍita, the scholar-siddha Nāropa, upon his fulfillment of twelve hardships.

It was translated, checked, and finalized by the great Nāropa and the great Tibetan lotsāwa, the king of translators, Marpa Chökyi Lodrö, at Pullahari in the north [of India].[*2][39] ithi.

II. The Text
{root} phyag rgya chen po bstan du med kyis kyang zhes pa nas/ ma bcos gnyug ma'i ngang du glod la zhog ces pa'i bar gyis/ {/root}
{root} Mahāmudrā cannot be shown. [For example, with space, what supports what? Your mind, mahāmudrā, has no supported objects.] Be relaxed in the uncontrived intrinsic state. (4–7) {/root}

phyag rgya chen po spros pa'i mtha' thams cad dang (38) bral ba de nyid kyi ngo bo stong zhing dngos po gzung ba'i yul du ma grub pa'i phyir bstan du med cing dpe ni nam mkha' lta bu yin te/ nam mkha' ni ngo bo stong pa/ rang bzhin gsal ba/ mtshan nyid 'gag pa med pa/ dbyings kun la khyab pa ste/

{38} Mahāmudrā, which is free from all extremes of elaborations, is in its very essence empty and does not exist as an object that can be grasped as a thing. Therefore, it cannot be shown, and the example used for that is space. Space is in its essence empty, its nature is clarity, its characteristic is that it is unimpeded, and it pervades all of the expanse.

de yang bram ze chen po'i zhal nas kyang / / phyag rgya chen po skad pa de/ / nam mkha'i rang bzhin lta ba 'dra/ / bsgom yang phar la mi bsgom zhing / / yengs kyang tshur la mi yengs par/ / ma bcos gnyug ma'i ngang nyid do/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

The Great Brahman [Saraha] says: What is called “mahāmudrā” is like looking at the nature of space. Even when you meditate, you’re not meditating on something “over there.” Even when you’re distracted, you’re not distracted with something “over here.” It’s the uncontrived intrinsic state.[3]
{root} bcings pa klod na grol bar the tshom med ces pa nas/ / rnam rtog tshogs 'gag bla med byang chub 'thob ces pa'i bar gyis ni/ {/root}

{root} Let your bonds go and there’s no doubt: you will be liberated. [For instance, when you look into the middle of space, seeing stops. Similarly, when mind looks at mind,] the masses of thoughts cease and unexcelled awakening is attained. (8–11) {/root}

dper na mi nyes pa can sdug bsngal de las thar ba bzhin du/ gang zag tha mal pa zhig gis phyag rgya chen po'i mtshan nyid go ba tsam du gyur na yang dga' ba chen po dang ldan te/ de bas kyang spros pa dang bral ba'i mtshan nyid dga' ba dang mi dga' ba dang / bde ba dang sdug bsngal ba la sogs pa gang gis kyang mi gnod pa'i don de nyid shes na/ 'khor ba dang mya ngan las 'das pa'i chos thams cad rtsa ba rang gi sems nyid yin par gsungs te/

For example, when someone who is suffering due to having done wrong is freed [from their sufferings, they experience joy]. Similarly, when ordinary individuals simply understand the characteristics of mahāmudrā, they become very joyful. Moreover, it is taught that when we recognize that very state, which cannot be undermined by anything—joy or despair, happiness or suffering—and has the characteristic of being beyond elaborations, that is our own mind-itself, the root of all the phenomena of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa.

sa ra ha'i zhal nas/ sems nyid gcig bu kun gyi sa bon te/ / gang la srid dang mya ngan 'das 'phro zhing / / 'dod pa'i 'bras bu thams cad ster mdzad pa/ / yid bzhin nor 'dra'i sems la phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
Saraha states: Mind-itself alone is the seed of everything: it radiates existence and nirvāṇa and bestows the desired fruits. Homage to the mind, like a wish-fulfilling gem.[4]
{root} dper na sa rlangs sprin ni nam mkha'i dbyings su dengs zhes pa nas/ rang sems mthong bas rtog pa'i rba rlabs dwangs zhes pa'i bar gyis ni/ / {/root}

{root} For example, clouds of ground mist vanish into the expanse of space. [They go nowhere and reside nowhere. Similarly, when the masses of thoughts rising up in the mind] are seen to be mind itself, the waves of thoughts vanish. (12–15) {/root}

rnam par rtog pa gang nas kyang ma 'ongs pa/ gang du yang mi 'gro ba snga phyi med pa/ de lta bu'i rig pa de sa rlangs kyi sprin dang 'dra bar 'byung ba yin/ / de yang sa rlangs kyi sprin de yang / dang po char pa babs pa las byung yang / sa rlangs med pa'i sngon du char ba ma grub cing / /(39) gcig dang gcig dus mnyam yin pa'i phyir na/ de bzhin du rang gi sems las byung ba'i rtogs pa'i tshogs kyang / phyag rgya chen po dang dus mnyam du byung ba yin par shes par gyis/ de yang phyag rgya chen po de sems can rnams kyis ngo ma shes pas 'khor bar 'khyams pa yin no/ /

Thoughts do not come from anywhere and they do not go anywhere. There is nothing that precedes or follows. Such awareness arises like clouds of ground mist. Clouds of ground mist appear right with the falling rain. The rain didn’t exist prior to the ground mist. {39} Both occur at the same time. Similarly, recognize that the masses of thoughts that arise within the mind occur at the same time as mahāmudrā. Since sentient beings do not recognize that mahāmudrā, they wander in saṃsāra.
rang gi sems nyid de nyid mthong na ni/ /rtog pa'i rba rlabs thams cad dwangs nas gnyis med bde ba chen po'i gnas su rang rig pa'i ye shes sems nyid phyag rgya chen po rtogs pa'o/ /
When we see our own mind-itself, the waves of thoughts vanish and we realize mahāmudrā, mind-itself, reflexively aware wisdom within a state of nondual great bliss.
{root} dper na nam mkha'i rang bzhin kha dog dbyibs las 'das zhes pa nas/ / dge sdig dkar nag chos kyis gos mi 'gyur/ zhes pa'i bar gyis ni/ {/root}

{root} For example, space in its nature transcends color and shape. [It’s untainted and unchanged by anything virtuous or unvirtuous. Similarly, mind in its essence transcends color and shape.] It’s untainted by the virtuous and unvirtuous phenomena of good and evil. (16–19) {/root}

nam mkha'i rang bzhin zhes ming du btags pa dkar ba dang / nag pa dang / ser ba dang / ljang ba dang / gang du yang ma grub pa yin/ de bzhin rang gi sems kyi snying po de nyid kyang sems zhes brjod kyang / dngos po zlum po dang / 'jong mo dang / gru bzhi dang sog ka la sogs pa rnams kyi rnam pa ma grub cing / kha dog kyang gong dang mtshungs pa dang / thams cad ma grub pa yin zhing / nam mkha' la dbyibs dang dkar nag ma grub zhes pa ni gong du bstan/ de bzhin du rang gi sems nyid de mthong na dge ba dang sdig pa gang gis kyang gnod pa ma bskyal/ phan ma btags mi 'dogs/ / 'dogs par mi 'gyur ba yin/ de yang rang gi sems ma gtogs pa/ sangs rgyas gzhan na yod par ma gsungs/

“Space in its nature” does not exist as any thing for which a descriptor might be used, such as white, black, yellow, or green. Similarly, the essence of your own mind itself is referred to as “mind,” but it does not exist as something round, oval, square, axe-shaped, and so on. And it is the same with colors: it does not exist as any of those. The statement, “Space does not exist as a shape or as something virtuous or unvirtuous” is taught above. Similarly, when you see your own mind-itself, evil does not cause harm and virtue has not brought benefit, does not benefit, and will not benefit. Furthermore, it is not taught that there is a buddha that is other than your own mind.
de yang mdo las/ / sems rtogs na sangs rgyas yin pas sangs rgyas gzhan du mi btsal ba'i 'du shes rab tu bsgom par bya'o/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
A sūtra says: When the mind is realized, that is buddha. Therefore, meditate with the awareness that buddhahood is not to be sought anywhere else.[5]
{root} dper na gsal dwangs nyi ma'i snying po de zhes pa nas/ / bskal pa'i 'khor bas sgrib par mi nus so zhes pa'i bar gyis ni/ {/root}

{root} For example, the brilliant clarity of the sun in its essence [can’t be obscured by thousands of eons of darkness. Similarly, your mind in its essence, luminosity,] can’t be obscured by eons of saṃsāra. (20–23) {/root}

dper na nyi ma de nyid gdod ma nas gsal ba'i rang bzhin (40) can yin pas/ mun pa shin tu gnag pa'i rang bzhin can de nyid bskal pa'i bar du bsags par gyur kyang / nyi ma'i 'od gsal ba skad cig ma nyid kyis mun pa'i tshogs bcom zhing gsal bar gyur pa de bzhin du rang gi sems kyi ngo bo 'od gsal ba de nyid skad cig ma nyid la rtogs na/ bskal par bsags pa'i sdig pa dang sgrib pa ma lus pa thams cad skad cig nyid la sel bar 'gyur zhing / byang ste dag par 'gyur ba'i phyir na/ 'khor bas bsgrib bar mi nus zhes bya ba'i don no/ /

For example, right from the start the sun has the nature of light. {40} Even though a place may have the nature of being very dark persistently for eons, an instant of the sun’s light will destroy that mass of darkness and light it up. Similarly, once we realize an instant of luminosity, the essence of mind, all the evil and obscurations persisting for eons are dispelled in that instant. They are cleansed and purified. Therefore, that is the meaning of “can’t be obscured by eons of saṃsāra.”
{root} dper na nam mkha' stong par tha snyad rab brtags kyang / /zhes pa nas/ / brjod pas 'di 'drar grub ces tha snyad 'gags gzhi med ces pa'i bar gyis ni/ {/root}

{root} For example, we use the term “empty” to refer to space, [but space cannot be described as being “like this.” Similarly, your mind is said to be luminous,] yet there is no basis to which the expression “it exists like this” applies. (24–27) {/root}

nam mkha' stong pa zhes brjod kyang / nam mkha' la dbyibs gru bzhi dang / zlum po dang 'jong mo la sogs pa gang du'ang ma grub cing / brjod du med pa dang mtshungs par/ sems kyi ngo bo la yang / ming tsam du sems zhes brjod kyang / dbyibs dang ngo bo 'di lta bu zhes brjod du med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Although we say, “space is empty,” space does not exist as anything with a shape, such as something square, round, oval, and so forth. It is similar to being inexpressible. The essence of mind is nominally referred to as “mind,” but it cannot be described as being something with a shape or essence that can be said to be “like this.”
{root} de ltar sems kyi rang bzhin gdod nas nam mkha' 'dra zhes pa nas/ de yi ngang la btang bzhag med par glod la zhog ces pa'i bar gyis ni/ {/root}

{root} In that way, the nature of mind is primordially like space. [No phenomenon is not included within it. Give up physical activities: be at ease in union with the natural state. Don’t talk: that sound-emptiness is just echoes. Don’t think at all: behold the phenomenon of the breakthrough. Body has no essence, like a stalk of bamboo. Mind, like the center of space, transcends being an object of reflection.] Remain relaxed in that state, not discarding or keeping anything. (28–35) {/root}

rang gi sems nyid gong du ji ltar brjod pa dang 'dra bar/ dbyibs dang ngo bo gang yang ma grub pa de nyid/ chos thams cad kyi ngo bo yin pa ste/ de rtogs par byed pa'i thabs la ri khrod dgon pa la sogs par gcig pur smra brjod med pa'i ngang las sgra thams cad chos kyi dbyings brag ca lta bu'i ngang la mnyam par bzhag cing / yid la ci yang mi bsam pa de nyid don gyi ngo bo nyid yin te/ bsam pa'i yul las 'das pa'i chos thams cad kyi ngo bo gong du brjod pa lta bu'i don de nyid ma rtogs na/ smyug ma'i dong bu lta bur snying po med pas te/ de yang snying po med ces brjod kyang don gyi ngo bo la (41) yod pa dang med pa'i tha snyad ma grub pa yin pa'i phyir na/ spros pa'i mtha' dang bral ba'i ngang la 'jog pa'o/ /

Your own mind, as stated above, doesn’t exist with any shape or essence. That is the essence of all phenomena. The means for realizing that is as follows: Remain alone in the wilderness, in mountain hermitages, and the like, keeping silent. Rest evenly in the state where sounds are like echoes of the dharmadhātu. Do not think at all. That is the actual essential nature [of this instruction]. If you have not realized that the essence of phenomena, which is beyond being an object of reflection, is this true state, as described above, [there is the following instruction: the body] has no essence, like a stalk of bamboo. Although it says, “has no essence,” in terms of the true essence, the conventional expressions “existent” or “nonexistent” are not established. {41} Therefore, remain in a state free from the extremes of elaborations.
{root} sems la gtad po med na phyag rgya chen po yin/ / de la goms shing 'dris na bla med byang chub 'thob/ / {/root}
{root} When mind is without reference point, that is mahāmudrā. When you are accustomed to and familiar with this, you achieve unsurpassable awakening. (36–37) {/root}

ces bya ba'i don ni/ sems nyid spros pa'i mtha' thams cad dang bral ba de nyid/ 'dus byas kyi chos gang la chags kyang / phyag rgya chen po de nyid mi rtogs shing / 'khrul pa'i rgyu yin/ 'dus byas dang 'dus ma byas kyi chos gang la yang ma chags shing / don de nyid klong du gyur na/ phyag rgya chen po zhes bya ba yin zhing / de nyid goms shing 'dris na byang chub thob ces bya ba'i don yin no/ /

Mind-itself is free from the extremes of elaborations. Nevertheless, being attached to conditioned phenomena, we do not realize mahāmudrā. That is the cause of our delusion. Whenever we are not attached to phenomena, conditioned or unconditioned, and we have mastery of the true state, that is called “mahāmudrā.” That is the meaning of saying, “When you are accustomed to and familiar with this, you achieve awakening.”

{root} The specific texts and philosophies [of those who expound Mantra, of the pāramitās, vinaya, sūtras, and the various piṭakas will not bring you to seeing luminosity-mahāmudrā.] Your expectations obscure and you don’t see luminosity. (38–42) {/root}

bka' bstan bcos gsang sngags gsar rnying / theg pa che chung la sogs pa rnams kyi don dam pa'i de nyid khong du ma chud cing / de nyid la chags pa yis 'khor ba'i rgyu ma gtogs pa phyag rgya chen po rtogs pa'i grogs su mi 'gyur ba yin te/

Not comprehending deeply what is ultimate in the [Buddha’s] teachings, the śāstras, Secret Mantra, the new and old [translations],[*1] the Hīnayāna, Mahāyāna, and so forth, and being attached to those are causes of saṃsāra and do not assist us in realizing mahāmudrā.

de yang rgyud kyi rgyal po chen po gsang ba snying po de nyid las/ ma rtogs pa dang logs par rtog / dgongs pa 'dul ba gsang ba dang / / phyogs rtogs yang dag nyid ma rtogs/ / don dam 'di la the tshom za/ zhes gsungs pa'i don 'di lta bu la dgongs pa yin te/

The following statement in the Guhyagarbha, Great Monarch of Tantras expresses this point: Lack of realization, wrong understanding, [not realizing] the intent, the taming, and the secret, partial realization, and not realizing what is true are all doubts about the ultimate.[6]

de yang grub mtha' so so la zhen cing ma rtogs pas 'khrul zhing / rigs drug gi sa bon ma gtogs pa phyag rgya chen po rtogs pa la spu tsam yang mi phan pa ste/ de'i phyir na so so rang rang gi grub mtha' la chags pa dang zhen pa ma byas na/ phyag rgya chen po rtogs shing / chos thams cad kyi de kho na nyid rtogs shing khong du chud par 'gyur ro/ /

Fixating on specific philosophical tenets and not realizing them cause delusion. That will only be a seed for the six kinds of beings and isn’t even a hair’s tip worth of benefit for realizing mahāmudrā. Therefore, if we are not attached to and do not fixate upon our own specific philosophical tenets, we will realize mahāmudrā and will realize and comprehend deeply the suchness of all phenomena.
rtog pa'i bsrung sdom dam tshig don las nyams/ /zhes pa nas/ / dam tshig mi 'da' mun pa'i sgron ma yin/ /zhes pa'i (42) bar gyis ni/

Vows guarded conceptually impair the true state of samaya. [Do not do anything with your mind—be free from expectations. What is self-arisen is self-pacified, like ripples on the water. If you don’t pass beyond the true state in which there’s no dwelling and no observing,] you don’t pass beyond samaya and are a lamp in darkness. (43–47) {42}

gong dang mtshungs pa lta bur 'jig rten pa'i snang ngo la bsod nams kyi tshogs gsog pa'i rten 'ba' zhig bsgrub cing 'di yis sangs rgya bar byed zer yang / snying po'i don yid la ma byed pa/ dge bas phan pa spu tsam ma byas/ /sdig pas gnod pa spu tsam yang ma bskyal zhing / zhen pa dang 'dod pa kun dang bral ba'i 'od gsal ba de nyid khong du chud cing rtogs na ni/ 'khor ba dang mya ngan las 'das pa'i chos thams cad mnyam pa nyid du ma ro gcig par 'gyur zhing rang gi yid la byung ba'i rtogs pa'i tshogs thams cad ni/ mnyam pa nyid chos kyi sku'i grogs su 'gyur ba ma gtogs pa gnod par mi 'gyur ba yin te/

As above, in the context of appearances for worldly beings, it is said that only the supports for the amassing of merit should be practiced and that brings buddhahood. However, [in the context of] the ultimate essence, there is no engaging of the mind. Virtue doesn’t create any advantages at all. Negative actions don’t cause any harm at all. When we deeply comprehend and realize luminosity (which is free from fixation and desires), all phenomena of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa are equal: the many are of one taste. The masses of thoughts[7] occurring in our minds are aids for the dharmakāya, the state of equalness—they never cause harm.

de yang rang gi sems la rnam par rtog pa gang byung yang / dper na mtsho chen po rlung gis bskyod na pa tra dag 'byung zhing yal ba'i dpe dang mtshungs pa bzhin du/ sems kyi rnam par rtog pa yang gcig gi rting la gcig 'byung zhing / phyi ma skye zhing snga ma 'gag kyang / rtsa ba rang gi sems ma gtogs pa/ /gzhan gang yang ma yin pa'i phyir na/ /de nyid kyi ngang las ma g.yos pa mi dmigs par mnyam par bzhag cing / /don de nyid las ma 'das na/ chos thams cad kyi sgron me don dam pa nyid khong du chud par 'gyur zhing / dper na mun pa la sgron me btegs pa bzhin du 'gyur ro/ /

No matter what thoughts arise in our minds, they are, for example, like the ripples that appear on a lake when the wind blows and then vanish. Similarly, thoughts in the mind arise one right after another. When a subsequent one arises, the previous one has ceased. Nevertheless, the root is only your mind—there’s nothing else. Therefore, rest evenly in that state without moving and without observing. Not passing beyond that true state, we comprehend deeply the ultimate, the lamp of all dharmas. This is like setting up a lamp in darkness.
{root} zhe 'dod kun bral mtha' la mi gnas na/ / sde snod chos rnams ma lus mthong bar 'gyur/ {/root}
{root} If you’re free from expectations and don’t abide in extremes, you will see all the dharma of the piṭakas without exception. (48–49) {/root}

zhes pa'i don ni zhen pa ces bya ba ni/ 'khor ba dang mya ngan las 'das pa dang / lha dang bla ma la sogs pa gang la yang chags pa dang zhen pa'i sems kun dang bral zhing mtha' rnam pa gnyis la ma gnas na/ sde snod kyi ches ma lus pa mthong bar 'gyur ro/ /

The meaning of that relates to what are called “fixations.” When we are completely free from a mind involved with attachments and fixations to saṃsāra and nirvāṇa, deities and gurus, and so forth, and don’t abide in the two extremes, we see all the dharma of the piṭakas without exception.
don 'dir gzhol na 'khor ba'i btson las thar/ (43) zhes pa nas/ / byin rlabs snying la zhugs na rang sems grol bar 'gyur/ zhes pa'i bar gyis ni

If you immerse yourself in this true state, you’ll be liberated from saṃsāra’s prison. {43} [Resting evenly in this true state burns up all wrongdoings and obscurations. This explanation is called “the lamp of the teachings.” The foolish, uninterested in this true state, are always swept up in saṃsāra’s rivers. Alas, how sad: these fools suffer unbearably in the lower states. If you desire liberation from what’s endless, attend upon skillful gurus.] Once their blessings enter your heart, your mind is free. (50–57)

sems kyi gnas lugs phyag rgya chen po'i don de nyid la mos shing nyams su blangs na 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal gyi rgya mtsho las thar zhing / / sdig sgrib zhes bya ba thams cad kyang sreg par byed pas na bstan pa'i sgron me zhes bya bar yang bshad pa yin zhing / phyag rgya chen po'i don de nyid la mi mos pa'i blun po rnams ni/ 'khor ba'i chu bo chen po las rtag tu mi thar zhing ngan song gi gnas na sdug bsngal bsam gyis mi khyab pa nyams su myong bar 'gyur zhing / snying rje ba'i gnas dang ldan pa yin pas na/ 'gro ba thams cad kyis de dag las thon par bya ba'i ched du/ mi lus thob pa'i dus su/ bla ma mkhas pa byin rlabs dang ldan pa la bsnyen zhing / de nyid kyi byin rlabs rang nyid la zhugs na phyag rgya chen po'i don de nyid rtogs par 'gyur zhes bya ba'i don no/ /

If we have conviction in and practice the true state of mahāmudrā, the abiding state of mind, we will be liberated from the ocean of suffering that is saṃsāra, and what are called “wrongdoings and obscurations” will be burned up. This is the explanation called “the lamp of the teachings.” Fools who have no interest in the true state of mahāmudrā will never be liberated from the great rivers of saṃsāra, and they will continue to experience unimaginable suffering in the lower states. They are objects of our compassion. For the sake of bringing all beings out of that [saṃsāra], now that we have a human existence, we should attend upon wise gurus endowed with blessings. When their blessings have entered us, we will realize the true state: mahāmudrā.

{root} kye ho 'khor ba'i chos 'di don med sdug bsngal rgyu/ / byas pa'i chos la snying po med pas don ldan snying po ltos/ / ces pa nas/ / re dogs med na 'bras bu mngon du gyur zhes pa'i bar gyis {/root}

{root} Kye ho. The phenomena of saṃsāra are meaningless, the causes of suffering. Since all created phenomena have no essence, look at the essence of what’s meaningful. (58–59) [Transcending percepts and perceivers is the sovereign of view. Being without distraction is the sovereign of meditation. Being without striving is the sovereign of conduct.] Being without hopes and fears reveals the result. (60–63) {/root}

'khor ba'i chos can zhes bya ba ni/ bsod nams kyi tshogs la brten pa'i 'dus byas kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba rnams la zer ba yin te/ de nyid kyi sa phyag rgya chen po'i don gsal ba stong pa'i mtshan nyid can de nyid mi rtogs pa yin pas na/ / don dang ldan pa'i snying po de nyid la ltos/ / zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

What are called “the phenomena of saṃsāra” refer to the roots of conditioned virtues, which are the basis for the accumulation of merit. Through those we do not realize the true state of mahāmudrā, what is characterized by clarity-emptiness. Therefore, it is said “look at the essence of what’s meaningful.”

de lta bu'i don de nyid nyams su myong ba ni gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i yul kun las 'das pa de nyid rtogs na ni lta ba'i rgyal po yin zhing / /de ma yengs par spyod pa gang gis kyang mi gnod cing / don de nyid bsgoms na bsgom pa'i rgyal po chen po yin zhing / de gnyis ka'i bya ba dang rtsol sgrub las 'das pa de nyid ni spyod pa'i rgyal po chen po yin zhing / de rnams thams cad la re dogs (44)med pa de ni 'bras bu mngon du gyur pa'o/ /

The practice of that true state transcends all objects involving something perceived and a perceiver. When we realize that, that is the sovereign of view. Not being distracted from that, no conduct can cause harm. When we meditate on that true state, that is the great sovereign of meditation. Transcending striving related to those two is the great sovereign of conduct. The absence of hopes and fears with regard all of those reveals the result. {44}
{root} dmigs pa'i yul 'das sems kyi rang bzhin gsal/ /zhes pa nas/ / bsgom pa'i yul med goms na bla med byang chub 'thob/ /ces pa'i bar gyis ni/ {/root}

dmigs pa'i yul zhes bya ba ni/ lha bsgom pa dang sngag bgrang pa la sogs pa dmigs pa'i yul de dag thams las 'das na/ sems kyi rang bzhin dmigs pa med pa de nyid don gsal bas bgrod pa'i lam theg pa chung ngu la sogs pa thams cad med par sangs rgyas pa zhes bya ba'i lam zin cing bsgom du med pas yul med pa de nyid goms na bla na med pa'i byang chub ces bya ba thob par 'gyur ro/ /

“Any object of focus” refers to all objects of focus, such as view, meditation, or counting mantras. When such objects of focus are transcended, since it is clear that the nature of the mind has no reference point, there are no paths to travel, such as that of the Hīnayāna. That initiates the path toward what is called “buddhahood.” Since there is no meditation, once we are familiar with the absence of an object, we attain what is called “unsurpassable awakening.”
{root} kye ma 'jig rten chos la legs rtog dang zhes pa nas/ / de bzhin sems kyi rtsa ba bcad na 'khor ba'i lo 'dab skam/ /ces pa'i bar gyis/ {/root}

{root} Kye ma. Contemplate worldly phenomena well. [They do not endure, being like dreams and illusions. Dreams and illusions in fact don’t exist. Become disenchanted and cast aside worldly activities. Sever your love-hate ties with those around you and your land. Meditate alone in hermitages, in the mountains or forests. Remain in a state of nonmeditation, and when you attain the unattainable, you have attained mahāmudrā. For example, if you sever the one root of a tree with spreading branches full of leaves, all those many branches will wither.] Likewise, when you sever the root of mind, the leaves of saṃsāra wither. (67–77) {/root}

'jig rten zhes bya ba ni bsam gyis mi khyab na yang / 'di ni 'khor ba'i 'jig rten bya ba la 'jug pa yin te/ de yang 'jig rten pa'i chos 'di rnams thams cad brtag mi thub pa yin te/ sgyu ma'i dpe brgyad dang 'dra ba lta bur snang yang / rmi lam la sogs pa sgyu ma'i dpe rnams kyang don ngo bo chos kyi dbyings la yod pa ma yin pas/

What is called “the world” is inconceivable, but here it refers to the worldly activities within saṃsāra. Furthermore, worldly phenomena cannot withstand analysis. They appear like the eight examples of illusions. Using the examples of illusions, dreams, and so forth does not mean that [worldly phenomena] exist ultimately within the dharmadhātu.

de'i phyir na/ 'khor ba'i chos thams cad la skyo ba chen po bskyed la/ 'jig rten gyi bya ba thams cad dang / 'khor dang yul dang / chags pa dang sdang ba la sogs pa'i sems spangs la gcig pur nags kyi 'dab la sogs pa dang / ri khrod dgon pa shin tu dben zhing nyams dga' bar de lta bur bsgom zhing / bsgom du med pa'i ngang las ma g.yos par byas na 'khor ba dang mya ngan las 'das pa'i rtog pa dang / gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i yul thams cad spangs nas/ phyag rgya chen po'i don ngo bo nyid chos kyi dbyings thob par 'gyur ba yin te/

Thus, we should arouse weariness for saṃsāric phenomena and abandon all states of mind involving attachment or aversion to worldly endeavors, those around us, and our lands. We should meditate alone in very isolated hermitages, in mountains, forests, and the like, with a sense of joy. Not moving from a state of nonmeditation, we give up ideas about saṃsāra and nirvāṇa and about objects involving percepts and perceivers, thereby attaining the true state of mahāmudrā, the essential nature, the dharmadhātu.

de yang dper na ljon shing sdong po yal ga dang / lo ma dang / 'dab ma dang / me tog dang / 'bras bu (45) ldan pa chen po gcig gi rtsa ba bcad par 'gyur na/ yal ga khri dang 'bum la sogs pa skam par 'gyur ba yin pas na/ dpe de bzhin du sems kyi rtsa ba bcad na/ 'khor ba dang mya ngan las 'das pa dang rnam par rtog pa'i tshogs rnams kyi lo 'dab skam par 'gyur ro/ /

For example, when the root of one massive tree, with its trunk, branches, leaves, petals, flowers, and fruits, is severed, all its tens of thousands and hundreds of thousands of branches will dry up. {45} Similarly, when the root of mind is cut, the leaves and petals of saṃsāra, nirvāṇa, and the masses of thoughts will dry up.
{root} dper na bskal pa stong du bsags pa'i mun pa yang / zhes pa nas/ / bskal par bsags pa'i sdig sgrib thams cad sel/ zhes pa'i bar la/ {/root}

{root} For example, darkness may persist for thousands of eons, [but a single lamp will dispel that gloom. Similarly, an instant of your own mind’s luminosity] will dispel the ignorance, evil deeds, and obscurations that have endured for eons. (78–81) {/root}

dpe ni mun pa shin tu gnag pa'i mtshan nyid can de nyid/ /bskal pa stong du bsags par gyur na'ang sgron me gcig gis mun pa'i tshogs thams cad bsal ba bzhin du/ tshe 'khor ba thog ma med pa nas tha ma da lta la thug gi bar du/ sdig pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa byas kyang / rang gi sems la shar ba'i 'od gsal phyag rgya chen po skad cig gis/ bskal par bsags pa'i sdig pa dang sgrib pa'i tshogs thams cad sel ba'o/ /

A place may have been very dark for thousands of eons, but a single lamp can dispel all its darkness. Similarly, from beginningless saṃsāra until the present moment we may have done unimaginable evil deeds. Nevertheless, a single instant of luminosity-mahāmudrā arising in our own minds will dispel the masses of evil deeds and obscurations we have accumulated for eons.
{root} kye ho blo yi chos kyis blo 'das don mi mthong / zhes pa nas/ re med rang grol 'bras bu'i mchog yin no/ /zhes pa'i bar gyis/ {/root}

{root} Kye ho. The true state beyond the intellect isn’t seen by means of intellectual dharma. [The true state of nonaction isn’t realized through fabricated dharma. If you wish to attain the true state of nonaction beyond the intellect, investigate your mind and remain in naked awareness. Let the murky water of thoughts clear. Leave appearances to be in themselves—don’t stop or create anything. When there’s no rejection or acceptance, all possible appearances are liberated as mudrā. The ālaya, being unborn, is devoid of latent tendencies, wrongdoings, and obscurations. Don’t inflate or judge: remain in the unborn essence. Appearances are self-appearances: let mental phenomena collapse. The full release from extremes is the supreme sovereign of view. Boundless, spacious depth is the supreme sovereign of meditation. Severing extremes and being without partiality is the supreme sovereign of conduct.] Self-liberated, free from hopes, is the supreme of results. (82–95) {/root}

blo yi chos zhes bya ba ni/ theg pa chung ngu'i chos rnams la zer ba yin te/ de yang byas pa'i chos yin pas na/ byar med pa'i don phyag rgya chen po de nyid mi rtogs pas na/ blo las 'das pa bya ru med pa de nyid thob par 'dod na/ rang gi sems nyid kyi ngang las ma g.yos na/ rtog pa'i tshogs thams cad 'gags nas/ bla na med pa thams cad chos kyi phyag rgyar rtogs shing / kun gyi gzhi sems nyid skye ba med pa klong du 'gyur zhing rang gi snang ba las byung ba'i blo'i chos thams cad phyag rgya chen por rtogs pa yin te/ mu mtha' med pa de nyid nyams su myong na lta ba'i rgyal po yin te/ mu med cing ma yengs pa ni bsgom pa'i rgyal po yin no/ / mtha' dang bral zhing dgag sgrub med pa ni spyod pa'i rgyal po chen po yin no/ / re ba dogs pa med par (46)thams cad klong du gyur pa ni 'bras bu'i mchog yin no/ / yang / /

“Intellectual dharma” refers to the dharma of the Hīnayāna. Since that is a fabricated dharma, it is not [the way] to realize mahāmudrā, the true state of nonaction. If we wish to achieve nonaction beyond the intellect, we must not waver from our own mind-itself. Once the masses of thoughts cease, we realize everything to be the dharmamudrā, the unexcelled. We master the ālaya, unborn mind-itself. We realize all intellectual dharma, which arises from reflexive appearances, to be mahāmudrā. When we experience the absence of extremes, that is the sovereign of view. Being boundless and without distraction are the sovereign of meditation. Being free from extremes and not rejecting or affirming are the great sovereign of conduct. {46} Being without hopes or fears and mastering everything are the supreme of results.
{root} las ni dang po gcong rong chu dang 'dra/ zhes pa nas/ / rig pa ngang la mi gnas bar du gcun zhes pa'i bar ni/ {/root}

{root} For beginners, it feels like water cascading over a cliff. [In the middle, it’s the gentle flow of the Ganges River. At last, all waters become like the reuniting of a mother with her children. If those of normal intelligence can’t rest in that state, they should use breath techniques and extract the elixir of awareness. Using various kinds of methods—gazes and ways of concentrating—] hold [mind] until it is still within awareness. (96–102) {/root}

las dang po pa ni/ theg pa chung ngu nas rim gyis 'dzegs dgos shing / / las dang po gcong rong gi chu dang 'dra zhing / tshogs bsags pas dge bar lta zhing / gnod pa dang log pa'i sems skyes na sdig par lta ba ste/ de rnams kyi 'dzin pa grol nas gsang sngags kyi lam la zhugs pa'i dus su/ dper na chu bo chen po gang+gA la sogs pa dang / chu bo chen po rnams dal zhing g.yo ba bzhin du tshegs chung ngus dge ba dang sdig pa gang gis kyang phan ma btags gnod pa mi bskyel ba'o/ / de nas de lta bu kun mi dmigs pa'i klong du gyur ba ni/ / chu thams cad 'dres pa'i rgya mtsho dang 'dra ba'o/ / blo dman pa'i skyes bu 'ga' zhig gis de lta bu'i don ma rtogs kyang / rlung gi gnad bzung zhing bsgom pa'i thabs du ma yis/ phyag rgya chen po'i don ma rtogs kyi bar du/ rig pa gnad du gcun zhing rtogs pa'i dus su phyag rgya bzhi la gnas shing nyams su len dgos pa'o/ /

We must ascend gradually starting with the Hīnayāna. As beginners, we will [experience our minds] as being like water cascading over a cliff. Amassing the accumulations [of merit and wisdom] is seen as virtuous, and the arising of harmful and incorrect mental states is seen as wrongdoing. Once we are free from those fixations and have entered the path of Secret Mantra, [our mental experience] will be like the gentle flow of a major river, such as the great Ganges River. With little strain, whatever virtue or wrongdoing we do will cause neither benefit nor harm. Then, we will gain the mastery of nonobservance. That is like an ocean in which all waters have mixed. Those of us of normal intelligence have not realized that true state. Therefore, using the many methods for holding the vital points of breath and meditating, we should home in on the vital points of awareness until we realize mahāmudrā. When we have realization, we should rest in and practice with the four mudrās.[*2]

(103–7) {/root}

8. Summary Verses on Mahāmudrā[1]
rgya gar skad du/ ma hA mu dra pA da me tha/ bod skad du/ phyag rgya chen po'i tshig bsdus pa/ /
In the language of India: Mahāmudrapādamitha.[8] In the language of Tibet: Phyag rgya chen po’i tshig bsdus pa.
bde chen ngang la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the state of great bliss.
[lta ba phyag rgya chen po la gsum gyi]
[Three Points for View in the Context of Mahāmudrā]

First, Appearances in the Context of Mahāmudrā
phyag rgya chen po brjod bya ba/ chos rnams thams cad rang gi sems/ / phyi rol don mthong 'khrul pa'i blo/ / rmi lam bzhin te dngos po stong / /
What’s called “mahāmudrā” is that all phenomena are your own mind. External referents and the deluded mind that sees them are empty of reality, like dreams.[9] (1–4)
gnyis pa rig pa phyag rgya chen po'i don gsungs pa/
Second, Awareness in the Context of Mahāmudrā
sems kyang dran rig 'gyu ba tsam/ / rang bzhin med de rlung gi rtsal/ / ngo bos stong pa nam mkha' 'dra/ / chos kun mkha' 'dra mnyam gnas pa'o/ /
Mind is simply the movements of cognition. With no nature, those are the expressive power of wind. Empty of essence, [mind] is like the sky. All phenomena remain equal, like space. (5–8)
gsum pa zung 'jug phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa
Third, Unification in the Context of Mahāmudrā
phyag rgya chen zhes brjod pa ni/ rang gi ngo bos bstan du med/ / de phyir sems kyi de bzhin nyid/ / phyag rgya chen po'i ngang nyid do/ /
What’s called “mahāmudrā” can’t be shown with an essence of its own. Therefore, the thusness of mind is itself the state of mahāmudrā. (9–12)
de ltar snang ba rig pa zung 'jug gsum gyis lta ba phyag rgya chen po bstan la/
In that way, view in the context of Mahāmudrā is taught through appearances, awareness, and unification.

de la bcos shing bsgyur du med/ gang gis de nyid mthong rtogs na/ / snang srid thams cad phyag rgya che/ / chos sku khyab bdal chen po bas/ /
It’s not to be altered or transformed. Once suchness is seen and realized, all that can possibly appear is mahāmudrā: the great all-pervasive dharmakāya.[10] (13–16)
gnyis pa rtogs tshul phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/
Second, the Process of Realization in the Context of Mahāmudrā[11]
rang bzhin ma bcos lhug par bzhag / bsam du med pa chos kyi sku/ / ma btsal bzhag na bsgom pa ste/ / btsal zhing bsgom pa 'khrul pa'i blo/ /
Rest loosely, without altering your nature.[12] What can’t be conceived is the dharmakāya. Remain without seeking and meditate. To meditate while seeking is a confused state of mind. (17–20)
gsum pa dbyer med phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/
Third, Inseparability in the Context of Mahāmudrā
mkha' dang cho 'phrul ji lta ba/ / bsgom dang mi bsgoms gnyis med pa/ / bral dang ma bral ga la yod/ / rnal 'byor pas ni de ltar rtogs/ /
Like space and its magical displays, there’s neither meditating nor not meditating. How can there be separating or no separating? Yogins and yoginīs realize thus. (21–24)
slar yang spyod pa phyag rgya chen po la gsum gyis
Three Points for Conduct in the Context of Mahāmudrā
dang po rang grol phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/
First, Self-Liberation in the Context of Mahāmudrā
dge dang sdig pa'i las rnams kun/ / de nyid shes pas grol bar 'gyur/ / nyon mongs ye shes chen po ste/ / nags la me bzhin rnal 'byor grogs/ /
Knowing the suchness of virtue and evil, you are free. Mental afflictions are great wisdom: like a forest feeds a fire, they aid yogins and yoginīs. (25–28)
gnyis pa ro snyoms phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa
Second, Equal Taste in the Context of Mahāmudrā
'gro dang 'dug tu ga la yod/ (48) dgon par phyin nas bsam gtan ci/ / de nyid ma rtogs gang gis kyang / / gnas skabs tsam las grol mi 'gyur/ /

How can there be going or remaining? {48} What’s the use of going to a hermitage for meditative concentration? If suchness isn’t realized, other [approaches] won’t yield freedom except temporarily. (29–32)
gsum pa dbyer med phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/
Third, Inseparability in the Context of Mahāmudrā
de nyid rtogs na gang gis 'chi/ / ngang la ma yengs gnas pa las/ / mnyam par bzhag dang ma bzhag ces/ / gnyen pos bcos shing bsgom du med/ /

Once suchness is realized, what could bind?[13] Just rest in that state without distraction. What are called resting or not resting in equipoise can’t be cultivated or contrived through remedies. (33–36)
slar yang 'bras bu phyag chen la gsum gyi

dang po snang srid phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa
First, All Possible Appearances in the Context of Mahāmudrā
'di la gang yang ma grub ste/ snang ba rang grol chos kyi dbyings/ / rtog pa rang grol ye shes che/ / gnyis med mnyam pa chos sku'o/ /
This doesn’t exist as anything. Appearances, free in themselves, are the dharmadhātu. Thoughts, free in themselves, are great wisdom. Nondual equality is the dharmakāya. (37–40)
gnyis pa 'khor 'das phyag rgya chen po don du gsungs/
Second, Saṃsāra and Nirvāṇa in the Context of Mahāmudrā
chu bo chen po'i rgyun 'bab ltar/ / ji ltar spyad kyang don dang ldan/ / 'di ni rtag tu sangs rgyas nyid/ / 'khor ba yul med bde ba che'o/ /
Like the flowing current of a great river, whatever you do is meaningful. This is always buddhahood: baseless saṃsāra, great bliss. (41–44)
gsum pa mthar thug phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa
Third, the Ultimate in the Context of Mahāmudrā
chos rnams rang rang ngo bos stong / / stong par 'dzin blo rang sar dag / blo bral yid la mi byed pa/ / 'di ni sangs rgyas kun gyi lam/ /
Phenomena are empty of any essence of their own. The intellect grasping emptiness is pure right where it is. Nonattention free from the intellect is the path of all buddhas. (45–48)
mthar gdams shing bsngo ba gsungs pa/

skal pa rab tu gyur pa la/ / bdag gis snying gtam tshig tu bsdus/ / 'di yis 'gro ba ma lus pa/ / phyag rgya che la gnas par shog /
For those of great fortune, I’ve summed up my heart advice in verse. May it enable all beings to abide in mahāmudrā. (49–52)
mkhas pa chen po nA ro pa'i zhal snga nas/ /mar pa chos kyi blo gros la phul+la ha rir gnang ba'o/ /
The great scholar Nāropa bestowed this orally on Marpa Chökyi Lodrö at Pullahari.

This teaching, which summarizes mahāmudrā in its entirety in thirteen verses, has been divided into [topical] sections in accordance with their meaning. The details should be learned from oral teachings.
'khrugs pa rnams la yid brtan mi bya la 'di dpe rnying dag pa rnams ltar bris pa yin pas bcos par mi bsam mo/
Do not trust the [corrupt] variations [found in other editions]. Since this has been copied from accurate old manuscripts, I do not think it needs altering.[*1] {49}

9. A Short, Lucid Commentary on the “Summary Verses on Mahāmudrā,” Emphasizing the Esoteric Instructions with Relevant Citations from the Tantras[1]
na mo gu ru b+h+yaH /
namo gurubhyaḥ
dpal nA ro pa'i phyag rgya chen po tshig bsdus 'di la gsum/ klad dang / gzhung dang / mjug go /
This commentary on the Summary Verses on Mahāmudrā by the glorious Nāropa is divided into three parts: (1) the introduction, (2) the text, and (3) the conclusion.
dang po [klad]
I. The Introduction
['di] la gnyis/ mtshan bstan pa dang / mchod par brjod pa'o/ /
This has two parts: (1) the presentation of the title and (2) the homage.
dang po [mtshan bstan pa] ni/
A. The Presentation of the Title
rgya gar skad du/ ma hA mu dra ba dA mi thA/ bod skad du/ /phyag rgya chen po tshig bsdus pa/
In the language of India: Mahāmudrapadāmithā. In the language of Tibet: Phyag rgya chen po’i tshig bsdus pa.

ji skad du/ /phyag chen thig le'i rgyud las/ / nyon cig lha mo phyag rgya che/ / phyag rgya chen po gsang ba che/ / brjod med mi zad ma skyes pa/ / thams cad gzugs can gzugs dang bral/ / gzugs med gzugs kyi dam pa mchog / sbom phra la sogs dang bral ba/ / gzhal du med pa'i rang bzhin no/ /

It is said in the Mahāmudrātilaka: Listen Goddess Mahāmudrā, mahāmudrā is the great secret. It is inexpressible, inexhaustible, unborn. It has the form of all and yet has no form. It is formless and the sublime, sacred form. Beyond subtle or grand, its nature is immeasurable.[2]
mtshan brjod las/ / a ni yig 'bru kun gyi mchog / don chen yi ge dam pa nyid/ / khongs nas 'byung ba skye ba med/ / tshig tu brjod pa spangs pa ste/ / brjod pa kun gyi rgyu yi mchog /

The Name-Chanting of Mañjuśrī states: a is the supreme of all syllables: the sacred letter of great meaning. Arising from within, it is unborn. Not something expressed in words, it is the sublime cause of all expressions.[3]
bde mchog rtsa rgyud las/ / de nas gsang chen bshad bya ba/ / mdor bsdus pa ste rgyas pa min/ /
The Saṃvara Root Tantra begins: Now I will explain the great secret in brief, not in detail.[4]

zhes pa ltar phyag rgya chen po ni gzhi lam 'bras gsum thams cad la khyab pa/ blo'i spyod yul mtha' dag las 'das pa/ phyag rgya gsum las chos khyad par du gyur pas bla na med pa ste brjod bya'o/ / tshig ni brjod byed de/ don dam par brjod du med kyang / kun rdzob tu dngos po thams cad kyi de kho na mtshon pa'o/ / bsdus pa ni/ don gyi gnad mdor bsdus par ston pa'o/ /

“Mahāmudrā” pervades everything: ground, path, and result. It is entirely beyond the scope of the intellect. Since its qualities are superior to those of the other three mudrās, it is unsurpassable. This is the subject of discussion. “Verses” are its means of discussion. Although ultimately inexpressible, on a conventional level it signifies the suchness of all entities. “Summary” means this teaches the ultimate key point succinctly.
gnyis pa [mchod par brjod pa] ni/
B. The Homage
{root} bde chen ngang la phyag 'tshal lo/ / {/root}
{root} Homage to the state of great bliss. {/root}
ji skad du/ dgyes rdor brtag gnyis las/ / de la thog ma dbus mtha' med/ / sred med mya ngan 'das pa'ang med/ / 'di ni mchog tu bde chen nyid/ / bdag med gzhan yang med pa'o/ /
It is said in the Two-Part Hevajra Tantra: This has no beginning, middle, or end. It is without existence and without nirvāṇa. It is sublime great bliss, with no self and no other.[5]
zhes dang / / rang rig bde ba chen po nyid/ / rang rig nas ni byang chub 'gyur/
And: Reflexive awareness is great bliss. Reflexive awareness becomes awakening.[6]
rnal 'byor ma kun spyod las/ / gang du (50) bde chen zhes bya gcig pu nyid/ / gcig pu'i nyams kyis du ma'i gar mdzad do/ /
rim lnga las/ / ji ltar chu la chu bzhag dang / / ji ltar mar la mar bzhag ltar/ / rang gi rang rig ye shes na/ / legs mthong gang yin 'dir phyag yin/ / zhes pas/ /
The Five Processes says: Like water poured into water, or butter poured into butter, we pay homage to what’s seen by wisdom that’s reflexively aware.[8]
bde ba chen po ni/ /rang gi sems nyid 'gyur ba med pa'i ye shes bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i gnas lugs te/ de'i ngang du mnyam par bzhag pa ni don dam pa'i phyag 'tshal ba'o/ /
Great bliss is the abiding state of unfathomable, unchanging wisdom, your own mind-itself. Resting evenly within that state is the ultimate homage.
gnyis pa gzhung gi don
II. The Text
['di] la bzhi/ lta ba/ bsgom pa/ spyod pa/ 'bras bu'o/ /
