This has four parts: (1) view, (2) meditation, (3) conduct, and (4) result.
dang po [lta ba]
A. View in the Context of Mahāmudrā
['di] la gsum las/
This has three parts.
dang po snang ba phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/ /
1. Appearances in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} phyag rgya chen po brjod bya ba/ / chos rnams thams cad rang gi sems/ / phyi rol don mthong 'khrul pa'i blo/ / rmi lam bzhin te dngos pos stong / / {/root}
{root} What’s called “mahāmudrā” is that all phenomena are your own mind. External referents and the deluded mind that sees them are empty of reality, like dreams. (1–4) {/root}
ji skad du/ rdo rje gur las/ / rin chen sems las phyir gyur pa'i/ / sangs rgyas med cing sems can med/ / rnam par shes pa'i gnas don du/ / phyi rol gyur pa gang yang med/
It is said in the Vajrapañjarā: Outside of the precious mind there are no buddhas or sentient beings. The places and objects of consciousness are not external things.[9]
he badzra las/ / rmongs phyir 'khor ba'i gzugs can te/ / rmongs med 'khor ba dag pa nyid/ ces dang / /
It is said in the Hevajra Tantra: When there is confusion, there are the forms of saṃsāra. When there is no confusion, saṃsāra is pure.[10]
'jig rten khams ni gang du yang / / sangs rgyas gzhan du rnyed mi 'gyur/ / sems ni rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas nyid/ / sangs rgyas gzhan tu bstan du med/ ces dang /
It is also said there: Nowhere else in the world is the buddha to be found: the mind is the perfect buddha. No other buddha is taught.[11]

dus 'khor las/ / sems can rnams ni sangs rgyas yin te sangs rgyas chen po gzhan 'dir 'jig rten khams na yod ma yin/ / de rnams mnyes par byas nas dpag med srid pa gcod par byed de rnam par mi rtog pa las so/ /

It is stated in the Kālacakra Tantra: Sentient beings are buddhas. No greater buddha exists in the realms of this world. Pleasing them severs the boundless existence because that is without conceptuality.[12]
gsang 'dus las/ / chos rnams rmi lam lta bu ste/ / ngo bo nyid kyis ma skyes shing / / rang bzhin dag pa de nyid la/ / 'khrul pa'i rdo rje rab tu gsungs/ zhes te/
It is said in the Guhyasamāja: All phenomena are like dreams: they don’t inherently come into being. That pure nature is taught to be vajra delusion.[13]

de'i don ni/ phyag rgya chen po'i don brjod par bya ba ni/ 'di ltar chos thams cad ni rang gi sems kyis btags pa tsam du (51) zad pas/ phyi rol gyi don dang / de mthong ba'i 'khrul pa'i blo ni/ rmi lam gyi gnas skabs nyams su myong ba'i shes pa bzhin/ don dam par yul yul can gnyis ka rang bzhin gyis ma grub ste dngos pos stong pa'o/ /

The meaning. The meaning of what is called “mahāmudrā” is as follows: {51} Your mind simply imagines phenomena, and therefore external referents and the deluded mind that sees them are like the mental states experienced during dreams. Ultimately, both objects and their perceivers do not inherently exist—they are empty of reality.
gnyis pa rig pa phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa ni/ /
2. Awareness in the Context of Mahāmudrā
sems kyang dran rig 'gyu ba tsam/ / rang bzhin med de rlung gi rtsal/ / ngo bos stong pa nam mkha' 'dra/ / chos kun mkha' 'dra mnyam gnas pa'o/ /
Mind is simply the movements of cognition. With no nature, those are the expressive power of wind. Empty of essence, [mind] is like the sky. All phenomena remain equal, like space. (5–8)

ji skad du/ rdor phreng las/ / ji ltar mes bsreg dngos po med/ / rgyu med par ni thim nas 'gro/ / slar yang srog gi rlung shar nas/ / las kyi rlung ni sna tshogs pa/ / de ni lhan cig rnam shes dang / / slar yang 'jig rten gsum du gnas/ / de las las dang de bzhin skyes/ / de las chags sogs bag chags dang / / de las slar yang 'chi dang skye/ / de ltar 'khor lo bskor ba 'dra/ / zhes dang /

It is said in the Vajramālā: Just as what’s burned by fire becomes nonexistent, what doesn’t move dissolves. Again, the life-force wind arises, and the karmic winds together with the consciousness continue to reside in the three worlds. From that comes karma, and from that birth; from that, the latent tendencies for attachment and the rest. And again there is death, then birth. Thus, it is like a wheel turning.[14]
dgongs pa lung ston las/ / 'gro ba yul sogs las byed pa/ / 'dir ni de la brten pa yin/
The Tantra Prophesying the Intent teaches: The creator of beings, objects, and so on, here is supported on that.[15]
zhes dang rlung rnams phra ba'i gzugs kyis su/ / shes dang yang dag 'dres gyur nas/ / dbang po'i sgo nas byung nas ni/ / yul rnams la ni 'jug par 'gyur/
It also says: Once winds, being subtle forms, mix with consciousness, they manifest through the doors of the senses and engage objects.[16]
dpal mchog dang po las/ / thams cad nam mkha'i mtshan nyid te/ / nam mkha' la ni mtshan nyid med/ / mkha' dang mnyam par sbyor ba yis/ / kun mchog mnyam pa nyid du gsal/
The Glorious Paramādya says: Everything is of the characteristic of space. Space has no characteristics. Uniting evenly with space, [everything] is clear as all-supreme equality.[17]
gsang 'dus las/ / chos rnams ngo bo med pa las/ / chos kyi de nyid kun bshad pa/ / e ma ho ngo mtshar las byung ba/ / nam mkha' la ni nam mkha' bsgom/
It is said in the Guhyasamāja: Although phenomena lack an essence, the suchness of phenomena is taught. E ma ho, most wondrous is meditation on space within space.[18]

don ni/ nang gi sems dran rig 'gyu ba gsal tsam 'di ni/ rang bzhin med de/ las rlung gi gzhan dbang can gyi rtsal las byung ba'i phyir/ ngo bos stong pa nam mkha' dang 'dra bas na/ gzung 'dzin gyi (52)chos kun gdod nas ma byung zhing ma skyes pa mkha' dang 'dra zhing mnyam pa nyid du gnas pa'o/ /

The meaning. The internal mind is simply clarity: the movements of cognition. It has no nature because it manifests due to the expressive power of karmic winds, which are dependent. It is empty of essence, like the sky. {52} Thus, all phenomena (percepts and perceivers), from the outset, do not manifest and do not arise. They are like space and remain equal.
gsum pa zung 'jug phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/ /
3. Unification in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} phyag rgya che zhes brjod pa ni/ / rang gi ngo bos bstan du med/ / de phyir sems kyi de bzhin nyid/ / phyag rgya chen po'i ngang nyid do/ / {/root}
{root} What’s called “mahāmudrā” can’t be shown with an essence of its own. Therefore, the thusness of mind is itself the state of mahāmudrā. (9–12) {/root}
ji skad du/ phyag chen thig le las/ / bdag gi ngo bo brjod mi nus/ / sangs rgyas kun gyis kyang rnyed dka'/ /
It is said in the Mahāmudrātilaka: My essence can’t be described. It’s difficult even for buddhas to find.[19]

brtag gnyis las/ / ngo bos gzugs med mthong ba po yang med/ / sgra med thos pa po yang med/ / dri med snom pa po yang med/ / ro med myong ba po yang med/ / rig med rig pa po yang med/ / sems med sems las byung ba med/

It is said in the Two-Part [Hevajra Tantra]: In essence, there are neither forms nor those who see them. There are no sounds and also no hearers, no smells or anyone to smell them, no tastes and not a single taster, no tangible objects or anyone to feel them, no minds and nothing to arise from mind.[20]
don ni/ de bas phyag rgya che zhes tshig tu brjod pa ni/ don dam par rang gi ngo bos 'di zhes bstan du med do/ /
The meaning. Therefore, what is termed “mahāmudrā” is not something that ultimately can be shown with an essence of its own, such that you could say, “It’s this.”

phyi don dang / rang rig gnyis ka la gzung 'dzin gyi bden grub ma dmigs pa'i phyir/ blo las 'das shing yid la byar med pa/ gdod ma nas zung 'jug mnyug ma sems kyi de bzhin nyid ni/ gzhi phyag rgya chen po'i ngang las nam yang ma g.yos pa nyid do/ /

Both external referents and reflexive awareness are not observed to be truly existent percepts and perceivers. Therefore, mahāmudrā transcends the intellect and is the absence of doing something with the mind. The thusness of the intrinsic mind, primordial unification, is itself never moving from the state of ground mahāmudrā.
de ltar snang ba bden med/ rig pa skye med/ zung 'jug blo 'das gsum gyis lta ba phyag rgya chen po khas len dang bral bar gtan la phabs nas/

In that way, through these three points—appearances are not real, awareness is unborn, and unification transcends the intellect—we determine that view in the context of mahāmudrā is free from any assertions.
gnyis pa bsgom pa phyag rgya chen po bstan pa
B. Meditation in the Context of Mahāmudrā
['di] la gsum las
This has three parts.
dang po gnas lugs phyag rgya chen po'i don tu gsungs pa/ /
1. The Abiding State in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} de la bcos shing bsgyur du med/ / gang gis de nyid mthong rtogs na/ / snang srid thams cad phyag rgya che/ / chos sku khyab gdal chen po pas/ {/root}
{root} It’s not to be altered or transformed. Once suchness is seen and realized, all that can possibly appear is mahāmudrā: the great all-pervasive dharmakāya. (13–16) {/root}

ji skad du/ /gsang 'dus las/ / dngos po thams cad dang bral ba/ / phung po khams dang skye mched dang / / gzung dang 'dzin pa rnam spangs pa/ / chos bdag med pa mnyam pa nyid/ / rang sems gdod nas ma skyes pa/ / stong pa nyid kyi rang bzhin no/ /

It is said in the Guhyasamāja: Without materiality, free from the skandhas, dhātus, āyatanas, and percepts and perceivers, and the same as the lack of self of phenomena, your own mind is primordially unborn and of the nature of emptiness.[21]
sdom 'byung las/ de (53) bzhin sems de sems med la/ / gcig dang sna tshogs rtog par byed/ / dngos po dngos med bya brag dag / rnam spangs gang na gang nyid ni/ / lhan cig skyes dga'i rang bzhin gsal/

It is stated in the Saṃvarodaya: {53} Thus, mind is devoid of mind. For those who have abandoned sameness and the varieties conceived, as well as the particulars of entities and nonentities, that itself illuminates the nature of connate joy.[22]

phyag chen thig le las/ / gzhan yang chos kyi dbyings su grags/ / de nyid nyon cig bdag gis bshad/ / nam mkha' chos kyi dbyings yin te/ / dbyings ni sa bon zhes su bstan/ / chos rnams kun gyi nang na yod/ / rgyu dang mchog gi gnas yin no/ / ji ltar til nang mar yod bzhin/ / ji ltar shing rnams me yod pas/ / de bzhin chos rnams kun la yod/

It is said in the Mahāmudrātilaka: As for what’s renowned as the dharmadhātu, listen as I explain. Space is the dharmadhātu. Dhātu is explained to mean “seed,” what is within all phenomena. It is the cause and the supreme source. Like oil is present within sesame seeds, and [the potential for] fire is within wood, it is present within all phenomena.[23]
gsang 'dus las/ / dngos po 'di rnams ma skyes pas/ / chos dang chos nyid med pa ste/ / nam mkha' lta bur bdag nyid las/ / byang chub tshul 'di brten pa'o/ /
It is said in the Guhyasamāja: These entities do not arise, and thus there are no phenomena or dharmatā. The way of awakening rests within the principal that is like space.[24]
phyag chen thig le las/ / yang dag rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyis/ / gal te kun rdzob gzugs su rnyes/ / 'jig rten khams ni grangs med la/ / gzhan ni ma yin bdag gis khyab/
It is said in the Mahāmudrātilaka: If the true, perfect buddhas were to find it as a conventional form, I, and nothing else, would be pervading the countless realms of the worlds.[25]

don ni/ gnas lugs phyag rgya chen po de la lam gyis bcos shing bsgyur bas blang ba dang dor bar bya ba med do/ gang gis gzung 'dzin gyi spros pa thams cad las 'das pa'i de kho na nyid mthong ba med pa'i tshul gyis rtogs shing khong du chud par gyur na/ / snang srid thams cad phyag rgya chen po chos sku khyab bdal chen po las don gzhan logs su grub pa med pa'i phyir/ /

The meaning. Abiding-state mahāmudrā is not something to be taken up or rejected through being altered or transformed by the path. Once you realize and comprehend deeply—in a nonseeing way—the suchness that transcends all the elaborations of percepts and perceivers, all possible appearances are nothing other than mahāmudrā: the great all-pervasive dharmakāya.
de bas na lam dang 'bras bu'i gnas skabs su btags pa thams cad kyang gzhi rang byung gi ye shes las ma g.yos par shes par bya'o/ /
Therefore, you should know that despite any and all imputations related to the processes of the path and result, [mahāmudrā] does not move from the ground, self-arising wisdom.
gnyis pa rtogs tshul phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/ /
2. The Process of Realization in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} rang bzhin ma bcos lhug par bzhag / bsam du med pa chos kyi sku/ / ma btsal bzhag na bsgom pa ste/ / btsal zhing bsgom pa 'khrul pa'i blo/ / (54) {/root}

{root} Rest loosely, without altering your nature. What can’t be conceived is the dharmakāya. Remain without seeking and meditate. To meditate while seeking is a confused state of mind. (17–20) {54} {/root}
ji skad du/ dpal rnyog pa med pa'i rgyud las/ /
The Glorious Unsullied State Tantra says:
de nas skyil krung bcas nas ni/ / sna yi rtse mor bltas nas kyang / / rang gi rang bzhin rnal 'byor gyis/ / de nyid mthong bar mnyam par bzhag /
Seated cross-legged, gaze at the tip of your nose. With the yoga of your own nature you rest in seeing suchness.[26]
rdo rje snying po rgyun gyi rgyud las/ / de ltar bzhugs par gyur nas kyang / / ji srid sems ni mi skyo'i bar/ / mnyam bzhag yid ni bzang po'i ngang / / de la 'bad de bsgom par bya/
It is said in the Ornament of the Vajra Heart: Once you rest in that way, as long as your mind doesn’t tire, meditate—exerting yourself in an excellent mental state of meditative equipoise.[27]
sdom 'byung las/ gang tshe de nyid la reg pas/ / bsam pa thams cad bsam du med/ / gang tshe bsam du med sems pa/ / de tsho bsam mi khyab par 'gyur/
It is stated in the Saṃvarodaya: When you contact thusness, thoughts are not conceived. When you think of what can’t be conceived, that’s the inconceivable.[28]

don ni/ gnas lugs phyag rgya chen po'i don mthong ba'i rnal 'byor pas/ de kho na nyid kyi rang bzhin las ma bcos par lhugs par bzhag pas/ bsam du med pa'i don so so rang rig pas nyams su myong ba ni lam dus kyi chos sku yin la/ des na rang gi sems las gzhan du ma btsal bar sems rang lugs su bzhag nas bsgom par bya ste/ gzhan du btsal zhing bcos nas bsgom pa na gzung 'dzin 'khrul pa'i blo las ma 'das pa nyid do/ /

The meaning. Yogins and yoginīs who see abiding-state mahāmudrā rest loosely without altering the nature of suchness. What can’t be conceived is experienced by intuitive reflexive awareness. That is the dharmakāya during the path. Therefore, without seeking your mind somewhere else, leave it in its natural condition and meditate. If you meditate by looking somewhere else and contriving, you will not get beyond the confused mind involved with percepts and perceivers.
gsum pa dbyer med phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/
3. Inseparability in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} mkha' dang cho 'phrul ji lta ba/ / sgom dang mi bsgoms gnyis med pa/ / bral dang ma bral ga la yod/ / rnal 'byor pas ni de ltar rtogs/ {/root}
{root} Like space and its magical displays, there’s neither meditating nor not meditating. How can there be separating or no separating? Yogins and yoginīs realize thus. (21–24) {/root}
ji skad du/ gsang 'dus las/ dngos po med la bsgom pa med/ / bsgom par bya ba sgom pa min/ / de ltar dngos po dngos med pas/ / sgom pa dmigs su med pa'o/
It is stated in the Guhyasamāja Tantra: There are no entities and no meditation. To meditate is not meditation. Thus, since entities are nonentities, meditation is not observed.[29]
bde mchog las/ dngos po med pa'i chos nyid chos/ / nam mkha' lta bur dri ma med/ / stong pa'i ye shes rdo rje yi/ / stong pa nyid du rnam par bsgom/
It is said in the Saṃvara: Phenomena, whose nature is not existent, are stainless, like space. Meditate on emptiness: the vajra wisdom of emptiness.[30]
rdo rje gur las/ sngags med bzlas pa'ang yod ma yin/ / 'gro ba gsum po thams cad med/ / chos kyi dbyings kyi rang bzhin gyis/ / sgom pa dang ni bsgom bya med/
It is said in the Vajrapañjarā: There are no mantras and no repetitions. All three beings don’t exist. In the nature of the dharmadhātu there is neither meditation nor object of meditation.[31] {55}

don ni/ /(55) nam mkha' dag pa las cho 'phrul sprin dang 'ja' tshon sogs snang ba'i dus nas snang ba med pa ji ltar bar/ sgom pa'i dus na gzung 'dzin du bsgom pa med la/ rang gi ngo bo las ma g.yos pas mi sgom pa'ang med pa ste/ / de ltar bsgoms pas nyon mongs pa'i bag chags rang bzhin med pas bral ba med la sems kyi chos nyid dang lhan cig tu mi gnas pas ma bral ba'ang ga la yod/ de bas na don dam pa'i bden pa phyag rgya chen po'i ye shes la yid mnyam par sbyar ba'i rnal 'byor pa rnams kyis de ltar rtogs par bya'o/ /

The meaning. Within clear space, its magical displays—clouds, rainbows, and the like—appear, [and yet] there are no [“real”] appearances. Similarly, when meditating, there is no meditation on percepts and perceivers, and yet, since you do not move from your own essence, there is no not meditating either. By meditating in that way, there is no separating since the latent tendencies of the mental afflictions are without any nature. And yet, since those do not abide with the dharmatā of mind, how could there be no separating? Thus, yogins and yoginīs whose minds are joined evenly with the wisdom of mahāmudrā, the ultimate truth, should realize in this way.
de rnams kyis gnas lugs ma bcos pa/ /rtogs tshul bsam du med pa/ /dbyer med mtha' dang bral ba gsum gyis sgom pa phyag rgya chen po yid phyed dang bral bar gtan la phabs nas/

Through these three points—the abiding state is not contrived, the process of realization is not conceived, and inseparability is free from extremes—we determine that meditation in the context of mahāmudrā is free from mental activities.[32]
gsum pa spyod pa phyag rgya chen po
C. Conduct in the Context of Mahāmudrā
['di] la gsum las/
This has three parts.
dang po rang grol phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/ /
1. Self-Liberation in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} dge dang sdig pa'i las rnams kun/ / de nyid shes pas grol bar 'gyur/ / nyon mongs ye shes chen po ste/ / nags la me bzhin rnal 'byor grogs/ {/root}
{root} Knowing the suchness of virtue and evil, you are free. Mental afflictions are great wisdom: like a forest feeds a fire, they aid yogins and yoginīs. (25–28) {/root}

ji skad du/ sam+bu Ti las/ / kun rtog mang po'i mun pas khyab gyur pa'i/ / rab tu 'joms pas smyo zhing glog 'gyu ba/ / chags sogs dgag dka'i dri mas gos gyur pa'i/ / sems ni rdo rje can gyis 'khor bar gsungs/ / rang bzhin 'od gsal rtog las rnam par grol/

It is said in the Sampuṭa: Those crazed and electrified by the overwhelming pervasiveness of the darkness of their many imaginations have minds that the Vajrin described as “saṃsāra,” tainted by the stains of desire and the like, so difficult to stop. Natural luminosity is free from thought.[33]
ces dang / / de yi sdig dang bsod nams kyi/ / cha gnyis rnam par rtog pa ste/ / 'di ltar chos ni rang bzhin dag / ma skyes pa dang gnas pa med/
And: Thoughts involving the pair of merit and wrongdoing are phenomena pure by nature, unborn and nonabiding.[34]
rdo rje gur las/ / gzugs brnyan rang bzhin ji lta bar/ / de ltar dngos po bsgom par bya/ / stong nyid dri med mchog gi gnas/ / der ni bsod nams sdig pa med/
It is said in the Vajrapañjarā: Meditate that all things are just like the nature of reflections: the sublime abode of stainless emptiness. That has neither merit nor wrongdoing.[35]
bde mchog 'byung ba las/ / dngos po med pa'i chos rnams la/ / blang dang dor ba ga la zhig / blang dang dor (56) bar bya ba yi/ / chos kun rmi lam ji bzhin no/ /
It is said in the Saṃvarodaya: How can phenomena, which lack existence, be adopted or rejected? {56} All phenomena to be adopted or rejected are just like dreams.[36]

brtag gnyis las/ skye bo mi zad pa yi las/ / gang dang gang gis 'ching 'gyur ba/ / thabs dang bcas na de nyid kyis/ / srid pa'i 'ching ba las grol 'gyur/ / chags pas 'jig rten 'ching 'gyur zhing / / 'dod chags nyid kyis rnam grol 'gyur/

It is said in the Two-Part [Hevajra Tantra]: The incorrigible actions of people, whatever they are, will cause bondage. But with methods, those very actions will free beings from the bonds of saṃsāra. Passion binds the whole world; passion itself liberates.[37]

don ni/ /'khor ba ni las las byung zhing / las ni blang bya dge ba dang dor bya sdig pa'i las te/ de rnams kun kyang rnam par rtog pa'i gzugs brnyan tsam las rang bzhin gyis ma grub pa'i de kho na nyid shes na grol bar 'gyur ro/ /

The meaning. Saṃsāra arises from karma. Karma is acts of virtue (what are to be adopted) and acts of wrongdoing (what are to be rejected). When you know the suchness of all of those—that they are only the reflections of your thoughts and do not inherently exist—you are free.

las de'ang nyon mongs pa las byung zhing / nyon mongs pa'i rang bzhin shes na ye shes phyag rgya chen por 'char bar 'gyur te/ nags tshal mes tshig pa la rlung grogs su 'gyur ba bzhin/ /rang bzhin shes pa'i rnal 'byor pa rnams nyon mongs pa ye shes kyi grogs su 'gyur ro/ /

Karma arises from mental afflictions. When you know the nature of mental afflictions, they arise as wisdom, mahāmudrā. In the same way that wind fans a fire burning through a forest, mental afflictions assist wisdom for yogins and yoginīs who know their nature.
gnyis pa ro snyoms phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/ /
2. Equal Taste in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} 'gro dang 'dug tu ga la yod/ / dgon par phyin nas bsam gtan ci/ / de nyid ma rtogs gang gis kyang / / gnas skabs tsam las grol mi 'gyur/ {/root}

{root} How can there be going or remaining? What’s the use of going to a hermitage for meditative concentration? If suchness isn’t realized, other [approaches] won’t yield freedom except temporarily. (29–32) {/root}
ji skad du/ gsang 'dus las/ / chos rnams rang bzhin 'od gsal ba/ / gdod nas dag pa nam mkha' bzhin/ / byang chub med cing mngon rtogs med/ / byang chub tshul 'di bstan pa'o/ /
It is said in the Guhyasamāja: The nature of all phenomena is luminosity, pure from the start, like space. There is no awakening and no realization. This is how awakening is taught.[38]

brtags gnyis las/ gzugs la sogs pa yul rnams dang / / gzhan yang rnal 'byor pas mthong ba/ / dngos po de kun dag pa ste/ / 'di ltar 'gro ba sangs rgyas bdag / rang rig bdag nyid dag pa nyid/ / dag pa gzhan gyi rnam grol min/

It is said in the Two-Part [Hevajra Tantra]: Objects, such as forms, and, moreover, all the entities that yogins and yoginīs see are pure. In this way, beings are buddhas. The character of reflexive awareness is purity. Other purities do not liberate.[39]

don ni/ phyag rgya chen po'i gnas lugs mngon du gyur pa'i rnal 'byor pas/ 'gro ba ste rjes thob dang / 'dug pa ste mnyam bzhag gnyis tha dad du 'dzin pa ga la yod de/ thams cad (57)chos nyid kyi rol pa las ma 'das pa'i phyir/ des na dgon pa ste gnas dben par phyin nas bsam gtan bsgoms pas ci zhig bya ste/ mnyam bzhag dang rjes thob ro mnyam par phyag rgya chen po'i ye shes las ma g.yos pa'i de kho na nyid ma rtogs na/ gzhan gang gis kyang gnas skabs nyon mongs pa mgo mnan pa tsam las srid pa'i sa bon drung nas 'byin mi nus pas/ mthar thug gi grol ba thob pa mi 'gyur ro/ /

The meaning. How could yogins and yoginīs who have actualized the abiding state of mahāmudrā cling to going (postmeditative attainment) and remaining (meditative equipoise) as separate? {57} Nothing is ever anything but the play of dharmatā. Thus, what would be the point of going to a hermitage, a secluded place, and cultivating meditative concentration? If, within the equal taste of meditative equipoise and postmeditative attainment, you don’t realize the suchness that never moves from the wisdom of mahāmudrā, nothing else will be able to eradicate the seeds of cyclic existence, even though such other [means] may temporarily suppress your mental afflictions. And, therefore, you won’t achieve ultimate freedom.
gsum pa dbyer med phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/ /
3. Inseparability in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} de nyid rtogs na gang gis 'ching / / ngang la ma yengs gnas pa las/ / mnyam par bzhag dang ma bzhag ces/ / gnyen pos bcos shing bsgom du med/ {/root}

{root} Once suchness is realized, what could bind? Just rest in that state without distraction. What are called resting or not resting in equipoise can’t be cultivated or contrived through remedies. (33–36) {/root}
ji skad du/ brtag gnyis las/ / chu bo'i rgyun ni rab 'babs dang / / mar me'i rtse mo rab bcings ltar/ / rtag tu de nyid rnal 'byor gyis/ / nyin dang mtshan du mnyam par bzhag /
It is said in the Two-Part [Hevajra Tantra]: Like the way a river flows or a candle flame burns on, yogins and yoginīs remain continually in the yoga of suchness, day and night.[40]
sa m+bu Ti las/ / dbang po gang dang gang lam nyid/ / de dang de yi rang bzhin las/ / mnyam par ma bzhag rnal 'byor gyi/ / rtag par shin tu mnyam bzhag nyid/
It is said in the Sampuṭa: All the sense faculties and their paths are of their own nature. The yoga of nonequipoise is the continuous true equipoise.[41]
gur las/ / sems pa med cing bsgom pa med/ / sngags med lha yang med pa ste/ / kye yi rdo rje las byung ba/ / 'di ni byang chub rim bstan pa'o/ /
It is said in the Vajrapañjarā: There is no mind, no meditation, no mantra, no deity. What arises from Hevajra is taught to be the process of awakening.[42]

don ni/ ji skad bshad pa ltar de kho na nyid rtogs na gzung 'dzin las grol bas yul yul can gang gis kyang 'chi bar mi 'gyur bas/ / de kho na nyid kyi ngang las ma yengs par gnas pa las/ mnyam par bzhag pa dang ma bzhag pa zhes gnyen pos bcos shing bsgom du med de/ mnyam par ma bzhag pa med pa'i ye shes chu bo rgyun gyi rnal 'byor la gnas pa ni spyod pa thams cad kyi mchog tu gsungs so/ /

The meaning. As just explained, when you realize suchness, you are free from percepts and perceivers, and therefore no objects or perceiving subjects will bind you.[43] Just rest undistracted within the state of suchness. What are called resting or not resting in equipoise can’t be cultivated or contrived through remedies. Remaining in the yoga of the flowing river of wisdom, which is the absence of “not resting in equipoise,” is taught to be the most sublime of all kinds of conduct.
de ltar ngo bo rang grol/ mtshan nyid ro mnyam/ mthar thug dbyer med pa gsum gyis spyod pa phyag rgya chen po rang shar rang grol du gtan la phab (58)nas/ /

Through these three points—the essence is self-liberated, the characteristic is equal taste, and the ultimate is inseparability—we determine that conduct in the context of mahāmudrā is self-arising, self-liberating. {58}
bzhi pa 'bras bu phyag rgya chen po
D. Result in the Context of Mahāmudrā
['di] la gsum/
This has three parts.
dang po snang srid rang grol phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/ /
1. All Possible Appearances Are Self-Liberating in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} 'di la gang yang ma grub ste/ / snang ba rang grol chos kyi dbyings/ / rtog pa rang grol ye shes che/ / gnyis med mnyam pa chos sku'o/ / {/root}
{root} This doesn’t exist as anything. Appearances, free in themselves, are the dharmadhātu. Thoughts, free in themselves, are great wisdom. Nondual equality is the dharmakāya. (37–40) {/root}

ji skad du/ phag mo mngon 'byung las/ / snang ba med pa'i gnas la gnas/ / snang ba med pa yang dag brten/ / spyod pa med pa'i chos rnams la/ / chos can med cing chos nyid med/ / rten 'brel mkha' dang mnyam pa'i chos/ / dngos med mtshan ma med pa'o/ /

It is said in the Vārāhyabhibodhana: Rest in the abode of no appearances. The absence of appearances is the true support. The phenomena of nonconduct are the absence of phenomena and the absence of dharmatā. The interdependence of phenomena equaling space is an absence of things and characteristics.[44]
gur las/ / ma skyes pa dang mi dmigs pa/ / mi phyed nam mkha' lta bu ste/ / zab cing zhi ba'i rang bzhin ni/ / 'di ni byang chub rim bstan pa'o/ /
It is said in the Vajrapañjarā: There is no birth, no observation, and no division—it’s like space. The nature of the profound and peaceful is taught to be the process of awakening.[45]

de lta bu'i phyag rgya chen po'i gnas lugs 'di la ni don dam par spros pa'i mtshan ma gang yang ma grub pa ste/ phyi rol gyi don ma skyes pas snang ba rang grol chos dbyings su shar/ nang shes pa mi dmigs pas rtog pa rang grol ye shes chen por dag /

[The meaning.] This abiding state of mahāmudrā, ultimately, does not exist as any characteristics involving elaborations. Since external referents do not arise, appearances, free in and of themselves, manifest as the dharmadhātu. Since the internal consciousness is not observed, thoughts, free in and of themselves, are pure as great wisdom.
gsang ba gzung 'dzin gnyis med blo 'das mnyam pa chen por brdal bas zab zhi spros pa dang bral ba'i chos kyi sku mngon du gyur ba'o/ /

Since the secret nonduality of percepts and perceivers, beyond the intellect, is omnipresent as the great equality, the dharmakāya—which is profound, peace, and free from elaborations—manifests fully.
gnyis pa 'khor 'das dbyer med phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/ /
2. The Inseparability of Saṃsāra and Nirvāṇa in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} chu bo chen po'i rgyun 'bab ltar/ / ji ltar spyad kyang don dang ldan/ / 'di ni rtag tu sangs rgyas nyid/ / 'khor ba yul med bde ba che'o/ / {/root}
{root} Like the flowing current of a great river, whatever you do is meaningful. This is always buddhahood: baseless saṃsāra, great bliss. (41–44) {/root}
ji skad du/ brtag gnyis las/ / 'di ni 'khor ba zhes bya ste/ / 'di nyid mya ngan 'das pa nyid/ / 'khor ba spangs nas gzhan du ni/ / mya ngan 'das pa rtogs mi 'gyur/
In the Two-Part [Hevajra Tantra] it is said: This is called “saṃsāra.” This is called “nirvāṇa.” You will not realize nirvāṇa somewhere else by abandoning saṃsāra.[46]
kha sbyor las/ / bdag dang gzhan du 'dzin spangs shing / / rang gi rig pa'i ye shes de/ / dngos dang dngos med bdag nyid mchog / mkha' mnyam sbyor ba rdul dang bral/ /
It is said in the Sampuṭa: This reflexively aware wisdom, which precludes grasping at self or other, is the supreme principle, neither entity nor nonentity. Equaling space, it’s beyond particles.
'dod chags chags bral 'dres pa ste/ / thabs (59) dang shes rab shin tu 'dres/ / de nyid srogs chags rnams kyi srog / de nyid mi 'gyur dam pa ste/ /
It mixes passion and passionlessness. {59} It blends method and prajñā. It’s the life force of all living beings. It’s the sacred unchanging state.
de nyid kyis ni thams cad khyab/ / de 'di sangs rgyas ye shes te/ / dpal ldan he ru ka zhes bya/ / 'di dang de dang gzhan yang rung / / dngos dang dngos med 'di las byung /
It pervades all. This is the buddhas’ wisdom. It’s called the glorious Heruka and this and that as well. Entities and nonentities arise from this.[47]
zhes dang / / sdug bsngal phung po du ma'i mtshan gyur pa/ / 'di las gzhan du cung zad yod ma yin/ / bde ba mtha' yas 'byung ba'i rgyur gyur pa/ / de las gzhan du 'gro ba yod ma yin/ /
And: The cause for the myriad heaps of suffering is nothing other than this. The cause from which limitless bliss will arise will also be nothing other than that.
sdug bsngal ma lus zad par 'dod pa dang / / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyi bde mchog thob 'dod pas/ / sems ni brtan par byas nas 'bad pas spyad/ / de yi rang bzhin dngos po med par bya/ /
With the wish to exhaust all suffering and the wish to attain the sublime bliss of perfect buddhahood, stabilize your mind and apply yourself. Its nature is not existent.

ji srid rtog pa'i mun pa'i yol stug pos/ / skye dgu'i yid bsgribs de srid sdug mtha' yas/ / ji srid de nas de ni bral yin pas/ / de srid bde ba rgya chen tha dad min/ / mnyam pa kun gyi mthar thug 'phags dgyes pa'i/ / de yi zad phyir rang gi bya ba yang / / rgyas pa de yis rang gi 'gro ba blta/

As long as beings’ minds are obscured by thick, dark veils of thoughts, their suffering will be endless. When they are separated from those, their bliss will be vast and unbroken. The ultimate equality of all pleases the noble ones. In order to exhaust [the veils of thoughts,] increase your application. You will see your progress through that.[48]

don ni/ de kho na nyid phyag rgya chen po rtogs pa'i rnal 'byor pa ni chu bo chen po rgyun chad pa med par 'bab pa ltar/ dus rtag tu mnyam par bzhag pa las ma 'das pas ji ltar spyad kyang don dang ldan pa nyid de/ /'di ni rtag tu sangs rgyas kun dang dgongs pa dbyer mi phyed pa nyid kyi phyir/ /'khor ba yul med mya ngan las 'das pa'i bde ba chen po 'khor 'das dbyer med kyi 'bras bu mngon tu gyur pa'o/ /

The meaning. Yogins and yoginīs who realize suchness-mahāmudrā always dwell in equipoise, like the uninterrupted flow of a great river. Therefore, whatever they do is meaningful because they are always inseparable from all buddhas and their realization. They actualize the result, the inseparability of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa: baseless saṃsāra and the great bliss of nirvāṇa.
gsum pa mthar thug phyag rgya chen po'i don du gsungs pa/ /
3. The Ultimate in the Context of Mahāmudrā
{root} chos rnams rang rang ngo bos stong / / stong par 'dzin blo rang sar dag / blo bral yid la mi byed pas/ / 'di ni sangs rgyas kun gyi lam/ / {/root}
{root} Phenomena are empty of any essence of their own. The intellect grasping emptiness is pure right where it is. Nonattention free from the intellect is the path of all buddhas. (45–48) {/root}

ji skad du/ kha sbyor las/ stong pa bsgom par mi bya ste/ / stong (60)min bsgom par mi bya'o/ / stong pa mi spangs rnal 'byor pas/ / stong min yongs su mi spang ngo / / stong dang stong min gzung ba las/ / rnam rtog nyung min skye bar 'gyur/

It is said in the Sampuṭa: Don’t meditate on emptiness. {60} Don’t meditate on not empty. Yogins and yoginīs who don’t abandon emptiness don’t abandon not empty. Through grasping at emptiness and not empty, thoughts do not lessen.[49]

sdom 'byung las/ / yid med yid ni byas nas su/ / cung zad tsam yang bsam mi bya/ / stan la gnas bcas bla ma yi/ / drin gyis yang dag sbyar bar bya/ / mkha' dang nam mkha' mnyam de bzhin/ / sems ni ro mnyam bsgom bya ste/ / bsam gtan 'dzin pas nges par grol/ / rtog ge'i sbyor ba rnam par spangs/ /

In the Saṃvarodaya it is stated: Don’t contemplate the absence of mentation as a mental activity—even slightly. While abiding on your seat, practice truly through the kindness of the guru. Meditate on the equal taste of mind, like space equaling space. Adhering to meditative concentration, there’s definite liberation. Give up the pursuits of logicians.[50]
ces dang / de bzhin sems des sems med la/ / gcig dang tha dad ji ltar rtog / dngos dang dngos med shes rab dag / rnam spangs gang na rang nyid ni/ / lhan cig skyes dga'i rang bzhin gsal/

And: Thus, mind is devoid of mind. For intelligent ones who have abandoned sameness and differences as they are conceived, as well as entities and nonentities, that itself illuminates the nature of connate joy.[51]

don ni/ 'di ltar snang ba'i gzung 'dzin gyi chos rnams ni/ rang rang gi ngo bos stong zhing / stong par 'dzin mkhan gyi shes bya'i blo'i sgrib pa'ang rang sar dag pas blo bral yid la mi byed pa 'di ni dus gsum du gshegs shing bzhugs la 'byon par 'gyur ba'i sangs rgyas kun gyi gsang ba'i lam rmad du byung ba ste/ rtogs bya'i gzhi dang / /thob bya'i 'bras bu'ang de las logs su ma dmigs pas na gzhi lam 'bras gsum dbyer med pas ni mthar thug don gyi phyag rgya chen por shes par bya'o/ /

The meaning. The phenomena of percepts and perceivers, which appear as such, are empty of any essence of their own, and the obscurations of the intellect [directed] toward objects of knowledge—the one grasping at emptiness—are pure right where they are. Thus, nonattention, free from the intellect, is the marvelous secret path of all buddhas of the three times: those who have gone, those who are present, and those who will come. No other ground (what is to be realized) and no other result (what is to be attained) are observed. We should know the inseparability of ground, path, and result to be the actual ultimate mahāmudrā.
de ltar na snang srid rang grol/ 'khor 'das dbyer med/ mthar thug blo 'das gsum gyis 'bras bu'i phyag rgya chen po rang bzhin lhun grub du gtan la phabs nas/

Through these three points—all possible appearances are self-liberating, saṃsāra and nirvāṇa are inseparable, and the ultimate is free of the intellect—we determine that the result in the context of mahāmudrā is innately present by nature.
gsum pa mjug gi don
III. The Conclusion
['di] la gsum/ /skal ldan la gdams pa/ smon lam gyis mtshams sbyar ba/ /mdzad byang gis mtha' brgyan pa'o/ /
This has three parts: (1) advice for the fortunate, (2) making connections through aspirations, and (3) the concluding ornament of the colophon.
dang po [gdams pa] ni/ /
A. Advice
{root} skal pa rab tu gyur pa la/ / bdag gi snying gtam tshig tu bsdus/ {/root}
{root} For those of great fortune, I’ve summed up my heart advice in verse. (49–50) {/root}
ji skad du/ dpal rnyog pa med pa'i rgyud las/ / khyad par du yang mdor bsdus pa/ / bdag gis gsal (61)bar bshad pa ni/ / rmongs pa rnams la phan 'dod pas/ / snying rjes 'dir ni bstan pa yin/
The Glorious Unsullied State Tantra says: I will clearly explain this {61} by summarizing its distinctions. I will present this with compassion, wishing to benefit the dull-witted.[52]

don ni/ rdo rje theg pa snying po don gyi gsang lam du dkrir rung pas dad pa dang skal pa rab tu gyur pa la/ nA ro paN+Di ta bdag gis snying phyung nas lag mthil du bzhag pa lta bu'i phyag rgya chen po yid la mi byed pa'i gtam/ nyung ngu'i tshig tu bsdus te bstan pa yin la/ de ltar bstan pa'i rgyu mtshan kyang / dang po'i las can zab pa dang rgya che ba'i gzhung bslab par mi nus pa'i blo dman pa rnams la snying brtse bas 'o ma las mar phyungs pa bzhin gdams ngag gnad du bsdus te ngo sprod kyi tshul du brjod pa yin no/ /

The meaning. For those of the great faith and fortune, who are able to be guided[53] along the secret path of the ultimate essence, Vajrayāna, Nāro Paṇḍita summarized into short verses and presented his advice on nonattention in the context of mahāmudrā, as if he were placing what arose from his heart in the palm of our hands. The reason for this type of presentation is that those with beginners’ karma who are of normal intelligence are unable to train with the profound and vast treatises. Out of affection for them, Nāropa extracted the key points of instruction, like extracting butter from milk, and presented them as pointing-out instructions.
gnyis pa [smon lam] ni/ /
B. Aspiration
{root} 'di yis 'gro ba ma lus pa/ / phyag rgya che la gnas par shog / {/root}
{root} May this enable all beings to abide in mahāmudrā. (51–52) {/root}
ji skad du/ brtag gnyis las/ / stong nyid snying rje dbyer med pas/ / byang chub sems zhes rab tu brjod/
It is said in the Two-Part [Hevajra Tantra]: The inseparability of emptiness and compassion is called “bodhicitta.”[54]
bshad rgyud las/ / sems can thams cad bde gyur cig / sems can thams cad skyon med pa/ / gang gis lam gyis 'gro 'gyur ba/ / des ni sangs rgyas myur thob shog /
The explanatory tantra [Sampuṭa] says: May all beings be happy. May all beings be without troubles. Through whatever path they go along may they swiftly attain buddhahood.[55]

don ni/ ngo bo stong nyid phyag rgya chen po las ma g.yos bzhin du/ gdangs dmigs pa med pa'i snying rje chen pos gzhung 'di brtsams pas 'gro ba ma lus pa gnas skabs bde ba dang / mthar thug phan pa bla na med pa stong nyid dang snying rje dbyer med pa'i phyag rgya chen po'i lam gyi gzhon pas bgrod de sku bzhi'i 'bras bu la gnas nas don gnyis lhun gyis grub par shog cig ces pa'o/ /

The meaning. While not moving from mahāmudrā—the essence, emptiness—[Nāropa] composed this text out of his great nonreferential compassion, the radiance [of mahāmudrā]. May every single being, on a temporal level, achieve happiness and, in the end, traverse the path of mahāmudrā, the inseparability of emptiness and compassion, which is the highest benefit. May they abide in the result of the four kāyas and naturally achieve the two benefits.
gsum pa [mdzad byang] ni/
C. Colophon
{root} mkhas pa chen po na ro pa'i zhal snga nas/ mar pa chos kyi blo gros la phul+la ha rir gnang ba'o/ / {/root}
{root} The great scholar Nāropa bestowed this orally on Marpa Chökyi Lodrö at Pullahari. {/root}
zhes pa ste go sla'o/ /
That is easy to understand.

zhes pa'ang dpal mkha' spyod dbang po'i sa bcad dang / rje bdun pa chos grags rgya mtsho'i lung sbyor sogs phyogs gcig tu sbyar te/ ngag don mdor bsdus pa'i tshul gyis (62)bya bral ba many+dzu g+ho Shas bsdebs pa su shre yo b+ha ba tu/ ! /

Combining the outline of the glorious Khachö Wangpo, the scriptural citations of the seventh lord, Chödrak Gyatso, and more, this has been arranged in the form of a summary recitation text by the renunciate Mañjughoṣa. suśreyo bhavatu
[de kho na nyid bcu pa]
10. Ten Stanzas on Suchness[1]
rgya gar skad du/ tat+tA da sha ka nA ma/ bod skad du/ de kho na nyid bcu pa zhes bya ba/ /
In the language of India: Tattvadaśakanāma. In the language of Tibet: De kho na nyid bcu pa zhes bya ba.
'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to youthful Mañjuśrī.
gang zhig yod med sbyor ba spangs/ / de bzhin nyid la phyag 'tshal 'dud/ ! /
I bow down and pay homage to thusness, what precludes involvement with existence and nonexistence.
gang la rnyogs pa med rang bzhin/ / byang chub rtogs pa'i rang bzhin can/ /
Being of unsullied nature, this is of the nature of awakening, realization.[10] (1)
de bzhin nyid ni shes 'dod pas/ / rnam bcas ma yin rnam med min/ / bla ma'i ngag gis ma brgyan pa'i/ / dbu ma'ang 'bring po tsam nyid do/ /
Those desiring to know thusness do not do so with images or nonexistent images.[11] Even the Madhyamaka not adorned with the guru’s instructions is itself just intermediate. (2)
dngos po 'di ni byang chub 'gyur/ / chags pa spangs pa'i rang bzhin nyid/ / chags pa las ni 'khrul bar 'gyur/ / 'khrul pa gnas ni med par 'dod/ /
This entity is awakening: it is the nature devoid of attachment. Delusion comes from attachment. It is asserted that delusion has no base.[12] (3)
de nyid ci na dngos rang bzhin/ / dngos po dngos med gang yin pa'o/ / dngos po med pa'ang dngos por 'gyur/ / rgyud dang 'bras bu'i rang bzhin gyis/ /
What is suchness? It is the nature of entities. Entities are nonentities and nonentities are entities[13] in terms of the nature of the cause and the result. (4)
de ltar chos rnams ro gcig ste/ / thog pa med cing gnas med par/ / ji ltar 'byung ba'i ting 'dzin gyis/ / 'di dag thams cad 'od gsal te/ ! /
Thus, phenomena are of one taste, are unobstructed and nonabiding. With the samādhi of [realizing suchness] as it is, all are luminosity.[14] (5)
ji ltar 'byung ba'i ting 'dzin yang / / rab tu 'jig pa'i sems kyis 'gyur/ / gang phyir de yi gnas rig pas/ / de nyid rgyun mi 'chad las skye/ /
The samādhi of [realizing suchness] as it is comes from engaged [bodhi]citta, since suchness arises uninterruptedly by being aware of its base.[15] (6)
shes dang shes bya rnam bral ba/ / 'gro ba nyid ni gnyis med 'dod/ / gnyis dang bral bar rloms pa yang / / gang phyir de ni 'od gsal 'dod/ ! /
Being free from cognition and objects of cognition, beings are said to be nondual. Even the presumption of being free from duality is said, therefore, to be luminosity.[16] (7)
de lta'i de nyid nges rtogs na/ / ji lta de ltar gang de na/ / rnal 'byor mig ni rgyas 'gyur bas/ / kun tu seng ge de bzhin rgyu/ /
Once they definitely realize that suchness, yogins and yoginīs with wide-open eyes wander everywhere like lions, doing whatever however.[17] (8)
'jig rten chos las rnam log 'dis/ / smyon pa'i brtul zhugs la brten nas/ / dmigs pa med pas thams cad byed/ / rang byin rlabs pas rnam brgyan pa'o/ ! /
They have turned away from worldly values and turned toward crazy [yogic] discipline. Without reference point, they do everything, adorned with self-blessing.[*1][18] (9)
rnyogs med de nyid gang bstan cing / / gnyis su med pas gang smras pa/ / mnyam dang mi mnyam spangs pa'o/ / blo gter rnams kyis shes byar rigs/ /
Suchness, taught to be unsullied and described by nonduality,[*2] precludes equality and nonequality. Those with gifted minds are worthy of knowing it.[19] (10) {63}
de kho na nyid (63) brtub/ slob dpon gnyis su med pa'i rdo rjes mdzad pa rdzogs so/ /
This completes the Ten Stanzas on Suchness composed by the ācārya Advayavajra.

gzhung 'di/ bla ma phyag na dang / mtshur gyis bsgyur zhing / phyis lo tsA tshul khrims rgyal bas bcos par snang zhing 'di ni slob dpon lhan cig skyes pa'i rdo rje'i 'grel pa dang mthun par bris pa'o/

This text was translated by the guru [Vajra]pāṇi and Tsur [Yeshe Jungne]. Later it seems to have been altered by Lotsāwa Tsultrim Gyalwa. This [Tibetan translation] is in keeping with the commentary by Sahajavajra.[*3][20]

rje mar pa lo tsA'i lta bas spros pa gcod pa'i bla ma mnga' bdag mai tri pa'i gsung phyag rgya chen po yid la mi byed pa'i chos nyer bzhi sogs mang du bzhugs pa rnams kyi nang nas/ lta ba ston pa'i gzhung gtso bor gyur pa ste/ rgya bod kyi 'grel pa'ang ci rigs pa snang ngo / ! /

[*3] Interlinear note: The exalted Marpa Lotsāwa’s view is that among the many teachings of the lord Maitrīpa, the guru who severs elaborations—such as the twenty-four [texts] in the Dharma Cycle on Amanasikāra (Nonattention), Mahāmudrā—this is the primary one that presents the view. There are various Indian and Tibetan commentaries on this text.
[mar pa'i thugs bcud phyag rgya chen po yi ge bzhi pa]
11. Vajra Song on the Meaning of the Four Points
mnga' bdag mar ba lo tsA bas dpal sa ra ha las gsan pa'i phyag rgya chen po yid la mi byed pa snying po don gyi gdams ngag yi ge bzhi pa'i don rdo rje'i mgur du bzhengs pa ni/ ! /
Instructions on the Ultimate Essence, the Mahāmudrā of Nonattention Heard by the Lord Marpa Lotsāwa from the Glorious Saraha[1]

dpal de ring bkra shis yar gyi ngo / / dus khyad par can gyi tshes bcu la/ / dpa' bo dga' ston gyi tshogs gral du/ / bu 'gyur ba med pa'i dam tshig can/ / khyod klog skya jo sras zhu 'bul ba/ / sngar ma thos pa'i glu long skad/ /

Today, a glorious, auspicious waxing moon, a special occasion of the tenth day, in the assembled gathering of this feast of heroes, you, the prince of Lokya, a son with unchanging samaya, said, “Sing a song never heard before.”[5] (1–6)

nga shul ring lam la gshar ba des/ / lus ngal dub dbang du song ba'i phyir/ / glu yid 'phrog snyan po ma mchis shing / / tshig sdeb sbyor mkhas po mi shes kyang / / grogs khyed bas ngo che med pa'i phyir/ / ngo che ba'i dpral ba mi ldog pas/ / don sngar ma mthong ba'i ya mtshan can/ / rje bram ze'i bzhed dgongs glur len pas/ / khyed gdan gang bzhugs pa'i mdo sngags rnams/ / snyan lhan ne gsan la thugs dgongs 'tshal/ ! /

I’ve been on the road a long time and am feeling physically exhausted, so my song won’t be melodious or captivating. And though I’m no expert in composition, since there’s no one more worthy than you, my friend— and I can’t refuse such a worthy person— I will sing something wondrous, with a meaning never before heard: a song of the instructions of the exalted Brahman. All you followers of sūtra and mantra sitting here, listen carefully and consider this well.[6] (7–16)

dus kha sang dpyid zla tha chung la/ / gzhi bal po'i mthil nas 'phags pa yi/ / gdugs dro lam mtshes kyi shul kha na/ / bal bo ling gi sho gam ri/ / gdol ba can gyi grong khyer du/ / mi brdal mi 'jal gyi shongs ma pas/ / mgron kha zhan po yi bod rnams bskyil/ / mi ngas kyang dbang med zhag 'ga' bsdad/ /

Recently, during the last month of spring, I traveled up from central Nepal. After being on the road for the morning, I arrived at a Nepali customs station in a town of low-caste people, where incoherent tax collectors round up hapless Tibetan travelers. Even I was stuck there for a few days.[7] (17–24)

dgung nub gcig tham thum rmi lam na/ / rigs kyi mtshan ldan tshangs skud can/ / bram ze'i bu mo (64) mdzes ma gnyis/ / cung zad 'dzum zhing zur mig blta/ / mi kho bo'i drung du 'ongs nas kyang / / lho dpal gyi ri la 'gro dgos skad/ /

One night in a light dreaming state, two beautiful brahman girls, true to their caste, wearing brahman threads, {64} smiling coyly, and glancing from the corners of their eyes, appeared before me and said, “Go to Śrī Parvata in the south.”[8] (25–30)
kho bos sngon chad phyin ma myong / / rgyus med lam yang mi shes smras/ / bu mo gnyis kyi zhal na re/ / khyed ming pos dka' ba spyad mi dgos/ / nged kyi phrag la khur gyis zer/ /

I replied, “I’ve never been there. I’ve no knowledge of it—I don’t even know the way.” The two girls countered, “Brother, you won’t need to do anything arduous. We’ll carry you on our shoulders.”[9] (31–35)
'do li dar gyi lding khrir bcug / gdugs bzhin mkha' la btags nas kyang / / glog 'gyu skad cig yud tsam la/ / lho dpal gyi ri la phyin pa rmis/ /
They placed me in a silk palanquin and raised it to the sky like a parasol. In a single instant, in a flash of lightning, I dreamt I arrived in Śrī Parvata in the south.[10] (36–39)

shing p+laka sha ljon pa'i bsil grib la/ / ti ra ro yi gdan steng na/ / rje bram ze chen po sa ra ha/ / zhal sngar ma mthong ba'i gzi mdangs can/ / btsun mo gnyis kyis mtha' brten nas/ / sku la dur khrod chas kyis brgyan/ / dges pa'i zhal ras 'dzum mdangs can/ /

In the cool shade of a grove of plakṣa [ficus] trees, on a tira corpse seat, sat the exalted Great Brahman, Saraha, his face radiating in a way I’d never seen before. With two queens by his side, he was adorned with the attire of charnel grounds. His joyous face beamed with a smile.[11] (40–46)
bu bde bar 'ongs sam zhes kyang gsungs/ / rje mthong ba dga' bas ma bzod par/ / lus kyi spu g.yos mchi ma 'khrugs/ /
He said, “Welcome, son.” I was filled with unbearable joy upon seeing the exalted one— the hairs on my body quivered and I shook with tears.[12] (47–49)
lan bdun bskor zhing brkyang phyag 'tshal/ / zhabs mthil spyi bor blangs nas kyang / / pha thugs rjes zung zhes gsol btab pas/ / lus la sku yi byin rlabs pa/ /
I circumambulated him seven times and offered a full prostration. Placing my head at his feet, I supplicated, “Father, hold me in your compassion.”[13] (50–53) He blessed my body with his body.
phyag dbang spyi bor reg tsam gyis/ / lus zag med bde bas ra ro ba/ / glang chen chang gis myos pa bzhin/ / g.yo 'gul med pa'i nyams shig shar/ /
By just touching the top of my head with his hand to bless me, I was drunk with undefiled bliss. Like an elephant intoxicated by beer, I had an experience of being without movement.[14] (54–58)
ngag la gsungs gis byin brlabs pa/ / stong nyid seng ge'i nga ro yis/ / yi ge bzhi pa'i don gsungs pa/ / lhug pas rmi lam rmis pa bzhin/ / brjod du med pa'i nyams shig shar/ /

He blessed my speech with his speech. With the lion’s roar of emptiness, he taught the meaning of the four points.[*1] Like the dream of a mute, I had an experience that can’t be described.[15] (59–63)
yid la thugs kyis byin brlabs pa/ / lhan cig skyes pa chos kyi sku/ / 'gro 'ong med pa'i don rtogs pas/ / dur khrod gnas pa'i mi ro bzhin/ / bsam du med pa'i nyams shig shar/ /

He blessed my mind with his mind. I realized connate dharmakāya, the reality beyond coming or going. Like a human corpse lying in a charnel ground, I had an experience that can’t be imagined.[16] (64–68)

rdo rjes bde chen dag pa'i gsungs/ / rin chen mgur gyi bum pa nas/ / tshangs pa'i dbyangs kyi brda skad kyis/ / sprin bral nam mkha' stong pa'i don/ / gnas lugs mtshon (65)pa rdo rje'i mgur/ / skye med rang sgra 'di skad thos/ ! /

Then, his speech of pure great bliss rose in the vase of his precious throat, and, in symbolic language with the melody of Brahmā, he sang this vajra song revealing the abiding state, the reality of emptiness, space free from clouds. {65} These are the unborn self-sounds I heard.[17] (69–74)
na mo/ /stong nyid snying rje dbyer med pa/ / rgyun chad med pa gnyug ma'i sems/ / gdod nas dag pa de bzhin nyid/ / nam mkhas nam mkha' sbyor ba mthong / /
Namo. Indivisible emptiness and compassion is intrinsic mind, without interruption. See this thusness, pure from the start: space united with space.[18] (75–78)
rtsa ba khyim na gnas pa'i phyir/ / yid kyi rnam shes btson du bzung / / sgom pa shes pa phyi ma yis/ / sems la lhan pa gdab tu med/ /
Because the root abides at home, imprison the mental consciousness. Meditation is not placing a patch on the mind[19] with the next consciousness. (79–82)
snang srid sems kyi rang bzhin shes/ / gnyen pos bcos te sgom du med/ / sems kyi gnas lug dran du med/ / de yang ma bcos ngang la bzhag /

Know all possible appearances to be of the nature of mind. It can’t be contrived through remedies and meditated upon. The abiding state of mind can’t be recollected. Leave it in an uncontrived state.[20] (83–86)
de don mthong na grol ba'i phyir/ / bu chung gdol pa'i spyod pa ltos/ / sha za smyon pa gang dgar mthong / /
Because, if you see that reality, you are free, look at the conduct of outcastes and small children. Be a crazy piśāca, doing what you please.[21] (87–89)
snyems dang bral ba'i seng ge bzhin/ / sems kyi glang po yan du chug / bung ba me tog rgyu ba ltos/ / 'khor ba skyon du mi lta zhing / / mya ngan 'das pa thob byar med/ /
Like a fearless lion, release your elephant mind. Watch bees moving among flowers. Don’t see saṃsāra as a problem. Nirvāṇa isn’t something to be attained.[22] (90–94)
tha mal shes pa rang lugs de/ / ma bcos so ma nyid du bzhag / bya ba rnams la khyod ma rtog / phyogs dang cha la mi gnas shing / / spros bral nam mkha'i dkyil du ltos/ ! /

Leave ordinary mind in its natural condition: uncontrived, fresh. Don’t conceptualize your actions. Don’t dwell in a position or part. Look into the center of space free from elaborations.[23] (95–99)
chos zad sar 'khyol ba snying po'i don/ / lta ba'i yang rtse phyag rgya che/ / sems gnad du bsnun pa'i brda don zhig / bram ze chen po'i zhal nas thos/ ! /

Reaching the state of exhaustion of phenomena is the ultimate essence. It’s mahāmudrā, the pinnacle of view. This symbolic meaning striking the vital points of mind is what I heard the Great Brahman say.[24] (100–103)

skad cig de la gnyid kyang sad/ / de ma brjed dran pa'i lcags kyus zin/ / ma rig gnyid kyi mun khung du/ / rig pa ye shes mthong phye nas/ / sprin med mkha' la nyi shar ltar/ / 'khrul pa'i mun nag sangs nas thal/ /

At that moment, I awoke and held that with the iron hook of recollection, not forgetting it. In the dark cell of unawareness, a vision of the wisdom of awareness unfolded, and, like the sun shining in a cloudless sky, the darkness of my confusion simply vanished.[25] (104–9)
dus gsum sangs rgyas zhal mjal kyang / / phyin chad dri rgyu med do snyam/ / sems kho thag chod pa'i nyams shig skyes/ / yid 'gyu ba zad pa ngo mtshar che/ ! /

I thought, “Now, even if I were to meet the buddhas of the three times, I would have nothing to ask them.” I had an experience of absolute certainty about mind. The movements of mentation collapsed—how wondrous.[26] (110–13)

e ma/ /yi dam mkha' 'gro'i lung bstan dang / / bla mas gsungs pa zab mo'i don/ / ngag smra ru mi btub gsung na yang / / dgung do nub mi smra'i thabs ma byung / / dus da res tsam zhig ma gtogs pa/ / sngon chad ngag du brjod ma myong / / da phyin chad bzlas sam rna bar nyon/ /

E ma. Though it’s said that we shouldn’t speak of the prophecies of the yidams and ḍākinīs or the profound meaning taught by our gurus, tonight I could not resist doing so. This is the only occasion— previously I have never spoken of this. Listen well so later you can repeat it.[27] (114–20)

nga sngon chad shul ri brgyang (66) gi mi/ / mdza' bshes gnyen med grogs kyang med/ / lus ngal dub bkres par gyur pa'i tshe/ / bu khyod kyis gang byas sems la yod/ / de ma brjed sems la shin tu gcags/ / drin 'khor bar thal lo snying gi grogs/ /

I’m someone who has traveled a long way, {66} with no companionship, close friends, or relatives along. What you, son, have done for me when I was tired and hungry, I’ve kept in mind. I didn’t forget, it touched me deeply. Now, my dear friend, your kindness has been repaid.[28] (121–26)

rje gong na bzhugs pa'i bla ma dang / / dngos grub ster ba'i yi dam lha/ / bar chad sel ba'i chos skyong rnams/ / mi bdag la bka' bkyon mi gnang 'tshal/ / don 'khrul par gda' na bzod par gsol/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Gurus, exalted ones dwelling on high, yidam deities, who bestow siddhis, and dharma protectors, who dispel obstacles, please do not scold me— be patient if I have muddled the meaning.[*2][29] (127–31)

'di'i don ni/ / yi ge dang po chos kyi sku/ / gnyis pa longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sku/ / yi ge gsum pa sprul pa'i sku/ / bzhi pa ngo bo nyid kyi sku/ zhes ma hA mu dra'i phyag rgya chen po ces pa 'di nyid la gzhi lam 'bras bu'i chos bzhi bzhi bshad nas lam gyi skabs su/ / dang po sems kyi gzhi rtsa bcad/ / gnyis pa sems kyi bzhag thabs bstan/ / gsum pa sems kyi go las spong / / bzhi pa sems kyi lam khyer bstan/ / ces mar pa'i thugs bcud phyag rgya chen po yi ge bzhi pa grags pa de yin no/ ! /

[*2] Interlinear note: The meaning of this is as follows. It is said that the first point relates to the dharmakāya; the second, to the saṃbhogakāya; the third, to the nirmāṇakāya; and the fourth, to the svabhāvakāya. What is called “mahāmudrā” (phyag rgya chen po) is explained in terms of four dharmas for the ground, path, and result. In the context of the path, the four dharmas are as follows. First, become absolutely clear about a base or root of mind. Second, teach the ways of resting the mind. Third, eliminate the mind’s strayings. Fourth, teach the ways to integrate [experiences] into the mind’s path. Thus it is said. That is the heart-elixir of Marpa, known as the “Four-Line Mahāmudrā.”
rje btsun mi la'i phyag rgya chen po ye shes gsal byed kyi rtsa ba bzhugs so/ /
12. The Root Text for Mahāmudrā. The Illumination of Wisdom[1]
bla ma grub thob rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the siddha-gurus.
bla ma brgyud pa'i rim pa ni/ / slob dpon chen po ti lo pas/ / mkhas pa chen po nA ro pa la/ / des lho brag mar pa la'o/ /
The successive transmission of my gurus is as follows: The great ācārya Tilopa [taught] the great paṇḍita Nāropa, who [taught] Marpa of Lhodrak. (1–4)
gung thang pa'i rnal 'byor bdag / lho brag gi rje btsun la/ / dad cing ni mos gyur nas/ / zhabs drung du 'khor yun ring / / thugs rjes ni dgongs nas gnang / /
I, the yogin of Gungtang, had faith and belief in the Jetsun of Lhodrak. I spent a long time in his presence. He bestowed [teachings upon me] through his compassion. (5–9)
gdams ngag ni dang du blangs/ / rtsol sgrub kyis drag tu bsgoms/ / bsgom pas yi byin rlabs kyis/ / lus la ni gtum mo 'bar/ / ras gos ni rkyang res dros/ / sems la ni 'od gsal shar/ /

I enthusiastically took up these instructions and meditated upon them with perseverance. Meditating, blessings [came]. Caṇḍālī blazed in my body— I was warm with only cotton clothing— and luminosity shone in my mind. (8–14)

rgyud lung ni mang gis kyang / / 'di dag dang gzhan mi mnyam/ / khyad par gyi bye brag ltos/ / nyams su ni len pa'i dus/ / dngos po'i gnas lugs lam dang ni/ / 'bras bu skye ba'i rim pa'o/ / zhes pa'o/ /

Although there are many tantras and scriptures, none equal this [transmission]. Behold its special features! In the context of practice, it is said: There are the abiding state of entities, the path, and the process that gives rise to the result.[7]

de la 'dir sems nyid dngos po'i gnas lugs ni phyag rgya chen po yin te/ / 'di la phyag rgya chen po'i mtshan nyid bstan pa la gsum ste/ / gzhi phyag rgya (67) chen po/ /lam phyag rgya chen po/ 'bras bu phyag rgya chen po'o/ /
Here the abiding state of the entity of mind-itself is mahāmudrā. The explanation of the characteristics of mahāmudrā is threefold: ground mahāmudrā, path mahāmudrā, and resultant mahāmudrā. {67}
[gzhi phyag rgya chen po]
[Ground Mahāmudrā]

dang po dngos po gshis kyi gnas lugs/ sangs rgyas kyi dgongs pa/ sems can gyi sems nyid/ kha dog dang dbyibs su ma grub pa/ mtha' dang dbus su ma grub/ rgya chad phyogs lhung dang bral ba/ yod ma myong / / med ma myong / ma 'khrul/ ma grol/ rgyus ma bskyed/ rkyen gyi ma bsgyur/ sangs rgyas mkhas te ma bcos/ sems can blun te ma bslad/ rtogs pas bzang du ma song / 'khrul pas ngan du ma song / de ni gzhi kun la gnas pas gzhi phyag rgya chen po'o/ /

First, the abiding state, the basic state of entities, is the mind of buddhas and the mind-itself of sentient beings. It does not exist with a color or shape. It does not exist with an edge or center. It is neither limited nor partial. It has never existed and never not existed. It is neither confused nor free. It is not produced from causes and is not changed by conditions. The wise buddhas don’t alter it, and foolish sentient beings don’t adulterate it. Realization doesn’t make it excellent, and confusion doesn’t make it bad. Since it is the ground present in everything, it is ground mahāmudrā.
lam phyag rgya chen po ni/
Path Mahāmudrā

gzhi de'i steng du nyams su blangs pa'i chos 'jog dus dmigs med du 'jog / gnas na yengs med du gnas/ khyer dus 'dzin med du khyer/ 'char na chos nyid du 'char/ grol dus rang grol du 'gro ba gcig nyams su len pa'o/ / de ni lam phyag rgya chen po'o/ /

When resting with phenomena, which are taken for practice right with that ground, rest without reference point. When still, be still without distraction. When integrating [experiences into the path], integrate them without grasping. When things arise, they arise as dharmatā. When things liberate, they liberate in and of themselves. That is the practice. That is path mahāmudrā.
'bras bu phyag rgya chen po ni/ /
Resultant Mahāmudrā
grol bya grol byed dang bral ba/ / re dogs dang bral ba/ blo zad chos zad 'dzin med zhes pa blo las 'das pas brjod pa dang bral ba'o/ / de ni 'bras bu phyag rgya chen po'o/ /

It is without something to be liberated and a means of liberation. It is without hopes and fear. It is said to be “the exhaustion of mind, the exhaustion of phenomena, the absence of grasping.” Since it transcends the intellect, it is beyond expression. That is resultant mahāmudrā.
'dir gzhi lam 'bras gsum dbyer med du nyams su len pa'o/ /
Here, ground, path, and result are to be practiced as inseparable.
phyag rgya chen po ye shes gsal byed kyi gdams pa/ rje btsun mi la rnal 'byor gyis mdzad pa'o// / ! /
These instructions, Mahāmudrā: The Illumination of Wisdom, were composed by Jetsun Mila Yogin. ithi
rje sgam po pa'i phyag rgya chen po lam gcig chod bzhugs so/ /
13. Mahāmudrā. Path of a Single Stride[1]
bla ma dam pa rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the genuine gurus.
rje btsun sgam po pa'i phyag rgya chen po lam gcig chod 'di la gsum ste/ gnas lugs kyi kho thag bcad pa dang / yin lugs kyi ngo sprad pa dang / de kho na nyid la lam sbyangs pa'o/ /
Mahāmudrā: Path of a Single Stride by Gampopa has three parts: (1) definitiveness about the abiding state, (2) pointing out the way it is, and (3) training in suchness as the path.
dang po [gnas lugs kyi kho thag bcad pa]
I. Definitiveness about the Abiding State
['di] la lnga ste/
This has five points:
phyag rgya chen po la rgyu med/ / phyag rgya chen po la rkyen med/ / phyag rgya chen po la thabs med/ / phyag rgya chen po la lam med/ / phyag rgya chen po la 'bras bu med do/ /
1. Mahāmudrā has no causes. 2. Mahāmudrā has no conditions. 3. Mahāmudrā has no methods. 4. Mahāmudrā has no path. 5. Mahāmudrā has no result.
gnyis pa yin lugs ngo sprad pa
II. Pointing Out the Way It Is
['di] la lnga ste/
This has five points: {68}
phyag rgya chen (68) po la rgyu med do/ dad pa dang mos gus phyag rgya chen po'i rgyu yin/
1. Mahāmudrā has no causes, and yet faith and devotion are the causes of mahāmudrā.
phyag rgya chen po la rkyen med do/ bla ma dam pa phyag rgya chen po'i rkyen yin/
2. Mahāmudrā has no conditions, and yet genuine gurus are the conditions for mahāmudrā.
phyag rgya chen po la thabs med do/ blo ma bcos pa 'di phyag rgya chen po'i thabs yin/
3. Mahāmudrā has no methods, and yet the uncontrived mind is the method of mahāmudrā.
phyag rgya chen po la lam med de/ yid ma yengs pa 'di phyag rgya chen po'i lam yin/
4. Mahāmudrā has no path, and yet the undistracted mind is the path of mahāmudrā.
phyag rgya chen po la 'bras bu med de/ blo chos nyid du grol ba 'di phyag rgya chen po'i 'bras bu yin no/ /
5. Mahāmudrā has no result, and yet mind freed in its dharmatā is the result of mahāmudrā.[5]
gsum pa de kho na nyid la lam sbyangs pa
III. Training in Suchness as the Path
['di] la bzhi ste/
This has four points:
sngon 'gro dad pa dang / mos pa/ gus pa gsum gyis nyin lan gsum mtshan lan gsum du bla ma'i rnal 'byor bsgom/ /
1. The preliminary practice is to meditate on guru yoga with faith, devotion, and respect three times during the day and three times at night.
dngos gzhir sems ma bcos pa'i ngang la ma yengs pa'i rtsis bzung la bzhag /
2. The main practice is to rest—with the light touch of nondistraction—in a state of uncontrived mind.
rjes la cir snang thams cad rang gi sems su shes par byas la rig pa rtsal sbyangs/ /
3. The concluding practice is to know that whatever appears is your own mind and refine your awareness.
nyams myong gi 'char lugs la brten nas blo ma zad bar du sgom sgrub la nan tan bya'o/ /
4. Relying on the way experiences arise, apply yourself to practicing meditation until you reach the exhaustion of mind.
de la nyams myong gi 'char lugs la gnyis te/ mi mthun pa'i nyams dang / mthun pa'i nyams so/ /
There are two ways experiences arise: as unfavorable experiences and as favorable experiences.
dang po [mi mthun pa'i nyams] ni/
First, [unfavorable experiences].

bying rgod dang / /na tsha dang / 'jigs bred dang / the tshom la sogs pa mi mthun pa'i nyams ci byung yang / de thams cad bsgoms pa las byung ba yin pas de thams cad nyams su shes par byas la/ mi spang bar de kho na nyid la lta sgom gyi bab byas nas bsgom pas/ mthun pa'i nyams shugs la 'char ro/ /

All unfavorable experiences—whatever they are, such as dullness, agitation, illness, fear, fright, or doubt—arise from your meditation. Therefore, recognize them to be experiences. Without abandoning them, take those very experiences as the objects of your view and meditation, and meditate. They will naturally become favorable experiences.
mthun pa'i nyams ni/
Favorable experiences.

dang po sems gnas pa'i nyams 'char/ de la brten nas ngo bo stong pa'i nyams 'char/ / de la brten nas rtogs pa thob pa'i nyams 'char/ / de la brten nas zhen pa log pa'i nyams 'char ro/ / de ltar nyams myong gi 'char lugs la brten nas/ / sgrub pa la chog shes med par nan tan bya ba ni/ /

First, experiences of the still mind arise. Based on that, experiences of its essence, emptiness, manifest. That is followed by experiences of attaining realization. Next, experiences of turning away from attachments occur. During that sequential arising of experiences, apply yourself without becoming complacent about your practice.
dang po sems gnas pa tsam gyis mi chog / ngo bo mthong mthong du bsgom dgos/ /
▶ To begin with, simply resting your mind is not sufficient. You must cultivate seeing the essence.
ngo bo mthong ba tsam gyis mi chog / rtog pa thob thob tu bsgom dgos/ (69)
▶ Merely seeing the essence is not sufficient. You must cultivate achieving realization.[6] {69}
rtogs pa thob pa tsam gyis mi chog / zhen pa log log tu bsgom dgos/ /
▶ Merely attaining realization is not sufficient. You must cultivate turning away from attachments.
zhen pa log pa tsam gyis mi chog / rang blo chos nyid du grol nas blo zad chos zad du sangs rgyas rgyas su bsgom dgos/
▶ Merely turning away from attachments is not sufficient. Having freed your mind in its dharmatā, you must cultivate the exhaustion of mind and the exhaustion of phenomena and cultivate awakening.
phyag rgya chen po lam gcig chod thugs kyi nying khu zhes bya ba rdzogs so// //
This completes Mahāmudrā: Path of a Single Stride, the Heart Essence. ithi
[thun min chos drug gi skor]
B. The Unshared Six Dharmas Cycle
bka' yang dag pa'i tshad ma zhes bya ba mkha' 'gro ma'i man ngag bzhugs so/ /
14. Truly Valid Words. The Esoteric Instructions of the Ḍākinī[1]
rgya gar skad du/ /A ha pra maN saM mya k+nA ma DA ki nI u pa de sha/ / bod skad du/ bka' yang dag pa'i tshad ma zhes bya ba mkha' 'gro ma'i man ngag /
In the language of India: Āhapramāṇasaṃyaknāmaḍākinupadeśa.[8] In the language of Tibet: bKa’ yang dag pa’i tshad ma zhes bya ba mkha ’gro’i man ngag.
dpal rdo rje 'chang chen po la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the glorious, great Vajradhara.
gang zag blo yi khyad par gyis/ / rim gyis pa dang gcig car ba/ / rim gyis pa yi sman chen 'di/ / gcig car ba yi dug tu 'gyur/ /

Given the differences in individuals’ intellectual capacities, there are the gradual type and the instantaneous type. A powerful medicine for the gradual type is poison for the instantaneous type. (1–4)
gcig car ba yi sman chen 'di/ / rim gyis pa yi dug tu 'gyur/ / des na sbyangs pa'i 'phro can la/ / gcig car ba ni bstan par bya/ /
A powerful medicine for the instantaneous type is poison for the gradual type. Those possessing the continuity of training should be taught as the instantaneous type. (5–8)
dngos po'i gnas lugs lam dang ni/ / 'bras bu skye ba'i rim pa'o/ /
There are the abiding state of entities, the path, and the process that gives rise to the result. (9–10)
dang po'i gnas lugs gnyis yin te/ / lus dang sems kyi gnas lugs so/ /
The first abiding state is twofold: the abiding state of the body and of the mind. (11–12)
lus kyi gnas lugs bstan pa ni/ / rags dang phra dang shin tu phra/ / thun mong dbyer med rim shes bya/ /
The presentation of the abiding state of the body is as follows: It is coarse, subtle, and very subtle. Know the processes are shared and inseparable. (13–15)
'od gsal pa las stong pa che/ / de las thabs shes sna tshogs 'byung / / mngon par byang chub rnam lnga dang / / rtsa dang rlung dang byang chub sems/ /
From luminosity arises great emptiness. From that, the varieties of method and prajñā: the fivefold awakening, the channels, winds, and bodhicittas. (16–19)
sems kyi gnas lugs bstan pa ni/ / thabs dang shes rab bdag nyid can/ / e waM lus kyi lte bar gnas/ / de nyid lus gnas ye shes che/ / rnam rtog kun spangs de nyid 'grub/ /

The presentation of the abiding state of the mind is as follows: It is the essential nature of method and prajñā. E vaṃ abides in the navel of the body. That is the great wisdom present in the body. It is what precludes all thought. (20–24)
dkyil 'khor 'khor lo las dang ni/ / ye shes phyag rgya'i rnam rtog bral/ / mi mno mi bsam mi dpyad cing / / mi bsgoms mi sems rang babs gzhag /
Be free from thoughts of maṇḍalas, retinues, karmamudrās, and wisdom mudrās. Don’t reflect, don’t think, don’t analyze. Don’t meditate, don’t speculate—rest naturally settled. (25–28)
ji ltar sa bon de bzhin shing / / shing ji lta ba de bzhin 'bras/ / 'jig rten kun la 'di mthong bas/ / 'di nyid rten cing (70)'brel 'byung ngo / /
A plant corresponds to its seed, and a fruit corresponds to its plant. This is seen in the whole world. {70} It is dependent origination. (29–32)
lam ni smin grol gnyis su bshad/ / bla mas bstan pa'i lam gyis ni/ / slob ma yongs su smin par bya/ /
The path is explained as twofold: maturation and liberation. The path taught by the guru fully matures the disciples. (33–35)

rdo rje 'chang gis chos bstan pa/ / rim pa gnyis la yang dag bsten/ / bskyed pa yi ni rim pa dang / / de bzhin rdzogs pa'i rim pa'o/ / rim gnyis mnyam par gnas nas ni/ / rdo rje can gyis chos 'chad do/ /

The dharma taught by Vajradhara is the correct practice of the two processes: the process of generation and the process of perfection. Resting equally in the two processes, the Vajrin explained the dharma. (36–41)
dang po bzhi ste yang na drug / mngon byang lnga ste bsdus pa'i don/ /
The first includes the four-, the six-, and the fivefold awakening.[*3] (42–43)
lus dben sngags dang sems gsum gyi/ / sgyu ma mngon par byang chub pas/ / zung 'jug rim pa shes par 'gyur/ /
Through body isolation, mantra, mind, illusion, and mastery, you will recognize the process of unification.[*4][9] (44–46)
las dang ye shes phyag rgya che/ / dam tshig ces bya 'od gsal nyid/ / rgyu dang sgom pa thob bya dang / / de bzhin bzhi pa lhun gyis grub/ /
Karma, wisdom, mahāmudrā, and the one called samaya—luminosity— are cause, meditation, and attainment, with the fourth being innately present. (47–50)
bsnyen pa nyer sgrub bsgrub pa dang / / sgrub chen ngo bo khyad par du // so sor sdud dang bsam gtan dang / / srog rtsol de bzhin 'dzin pa dang / / rjes su dran dang ting nge 'dzin/ /
Approach, close practice, practice, and great practice are, in essence, specifically, withdrawal, meditative concentration, prāṇāyāma, retention, recollection, and samādhi. (51–55)
rim gnyis brgyad du bstan pa ste/ / gtum mo las kyi phyag rgya dang / / sgyu ma rmi lam 'od gsal dang / / bar do 'pho ba grong 'jug go /
The second process is taught through eight: caṇḍālī, karmamudrā, illusions, dreams, luminosity, bardo, transference, and entering a body. (56–59)
sku gsung thugs kyi dbye ba yis/ / phyis nas rnam pa gsum du 'gyur/ /
Given the divisions of body, speech, and mind, there are also three modes.[*5] (60–61)
gtum mo'i rnal 'byor rgyu yin te/ / 'di la gnad ni rnam pa lnga/ / lus rlung rtsa dus yul lnga'o/ /
Caṇḍālī yoga is the cause. It has five vital points: the body, winds, channels, time, and object. (62–64)
lus ni rdo rje skyil mo krung / / sgal tshigs rin chen rtsar la rgyus/ / mthongs kha rgyun du yangs pa dang / / steng sgo shin tu spa bar bya/ /
For the body, sit in the vajra posture. Your spine should be like jewels strung on a reed. Your chest should always be spacious, and your upper door very concealed.[10]
lce ni yar rkan nyid du gtad/ / mnyam bzhag phyag rgya lte 'og brtsir/ / mig dang shes pa ma 'gyur bar/ / rlung sems dril la drag tu gcun/ / rdo rje skyil krung rdzogs sangs rgyas/ /

Your tongue should be directed toward your upper palate. With the mudrā of equipoise, press below your navel.[11] Not changing your eyes or consciousness, your winds and mind are concentrated and forcefully held. The vajra posture is complete buddhahood. (65–73)
yang na lus ni tsog pur bsdad/ / re'u mig bzhin bsnol bar bya/ /
Alternatively, sit with your body in a squatting posture. Cross [your legs] like lattice.[12] (74–75)
rlung la sbyor ba bzhi ldan te/ / rngub dang dgang dang gzhil ba dang / / 'phang bar bya dang rnam pa bzhi/ /
There are four yogic techniques for the breath: inhaling, filling, dispersing, and releasing. (76–78)
lcags kyu bzhin du dgug par bya/ / bum pa bzhin du dgang ba dang / / rgya mdud bzhin du bsams nas su/ / mda' ltar (71) gyen du 'phang bar bya/ /
Draw in like an iron hook. Be full like a vase. Be bound like knots.[13] Release upward like an arrow. (79–82) {71}
sbyor ba bzhi ldan ma shes na/ / yon tan skyon du 'gyur ba'i nyin/ /
If you do not know the four yogic techniques, there is the danger that good qualities will become problems.[14] (83–84)
re tsa ka yis lhung bar byed/ / kum+b+ha ka yis dbang du byed/ / pU ra ka yis kun nas 'gugs/ / zhi ba yis ni rengs par byed/ /
Recaka causes descent. Kumbhaka controls. Pūraka attracts. Pacifying paralyzes. [15] (85–88)
gtsug tor las ni thig le nyid/ / me yis zhu ba nyid kyis ltung / / bde ba chen po'i ting 'dzin gnas/ / stong nyid lta stangs ltung bar bya/ /
From the uṣṇīṣa, bindus descend due to being melted by fire. Abiding in the samādhi of great bliss and gazing at emptiness, they descend. (89–92)
bum pa can gyi 'khor lor son/ / dpal ba zhes byar rab tu bsgrags/ / rdo rje pad+mar ting 'dzin brtan/ / khams gsum po ni dbang du byed/ /
They reach the cakra of the vase, called the “forehead.”[16] Stabilize the samādhi of the vajra in the lotus, and the three realms are controlled. (93–96)
snying ga phyogs su dag pas 'gugs/ / ma rungs las can de rnams kun/ / he ru ka dpal rang bzhin phyir/ / rtag tu lta ngan gzhom bar bya/ /
They are attracted to the area of the heart through purification. Those who have done reprehensible acts, because they are of the nature of the glorious heruka, destroy wrong views. (97–100)
zhi pas rengs pa nor bu'i mtha'/ / rgyal ba'i gzugs brnyan rnam par bsgom/ / mchog tu mi 'gyur rtogs gyur pa/ / de ni mnyam nyid mi g.yor gsungs/ /
Paralyzed by pacifying, at the end of the jewel, meditate on an image of the victors. Realization, completely unchanging, will occur. That is taught to be unwavering equality. (101–4)
rngub pa yis ni dbang du byed/ / dgangs pa ris ni rengs pa dang / / zhi ba yis ni zhi bar 'gyur/ / mnyam par ma rungs dpral ba can/ /
Inhaling controls. Filling paralyzes.[17] Pacifying pacifies. Equalized, the reprehensible [are paralyzed at] the forehead.[18] (105–8)
d+hU tIr tshud na rgyun mi 'bab/ / dgang ba yis ni lus bkang nas/ / dug dang rims kyi tsha ba 'phrog /
Once [bodhicitta] enters the avadhūti, its stream does not fall.[19] Filling fills the body and vanquishes the pain of poisons and disease. (109–11)
bum pa can gyis sgo bcings na/ / sgo yi bu ga dag par 'gyur/ / 'thor ba sna tshogs rdul du bya/ / rab tu zhi bas zhi bar 'gyur/ /
When the doors are bound within a vase,[20] the openings of the doors are purified. The various scatterings are made into dust. Fully pacified, there is peace. (112–15)
yang na og kos ol mdud mnan/ / yang na mjing pa ltag pa mnan/ / g.yas nas rgyu na g.yas rtsa mnan/ / g.yon nas rgyu na g.yon rtsa mnan/ / don la nu ma bcud la bor/ /

Press your chin toward your larynx.[21] Or press your neck toward its nape. If movement is on the right, press down on the right channel. If movement is on the left, press down on the left channel. In practice, zero in on your breast.[22] (116–20)
seng ge rnam rol phyag rgya ni/ / rnal 'byor pa yis bcings nas su/ / rtag tu srog dang rtsol ba bya/ /
The mudrā of the manifestation of a lion is when, through binding, yogins and yoginīs do prāṇāyāma continuously. (121–23)
pho rlung 'dul zhing mo rlung sbyangs/ / ma ning rlung la rgyun du bzla/ / brjod dang dmigs par bcas pa dang / / brdar gyur dang ni don dam mo/ /
Tame the male winds, train the female winds, and with the neuter winds, do the repetitions continuously. These are verbal expressions, objects of meditation, symbols, and the ultimate. (124–27)
tshig gi brjod pa thun mong ste/ / dmigs par bcas pa sangs rgyas dngos/ / (72)
Verbal expressions using words are shared. Those with objects of meditation are the actual buddha. {72}
sngags kyi de nyid brda ru bshad/ / don dam de bzhin nyid yin no/ / srog ni rgyun mi chad gyur spro/ / a wa d+hU tI'i gnas son bzla/ /
The suchness of mantras is explained as the symbols. The ultimate is thusness. The life force, continuous and radiating, goes to the places of the avadhūti with the repetitions. (128–33)
rtsa yig nang ni 'di lta ste/ / skad cig tsam gyis yi dam lha/ / rgyu ma lta bu'i lus bsgoms te/ /
The vital points of the channels are thus:[23] instantly meditate on the yidam deity as an illusion-like body. (134–36)
dus me sgra gcan de nas nyi/ / ri bong can mas mtshan pa'i dbus/ / phug nas gtsug tor du son pa/ / de ni a ba d+hU tI'i rtsa/ /
In the middle of Kālāgni, Rāhu, the sun, and the rabbit-bearer,[*6] extending from the depths to the uṣṇīṣa, is the avadhūti channel. (137–40)
rkyang ma ro ma dang sbyar ba/ / gdugs dang shing rta ltar gnas pa'i/ / 'khor lo bzhi dang bcas pa bsgom/ /
It joins with the lalanā and rasanā. Meditate that it has four cakras, which abide like umbrellas or chariots. (141–43)
de la dus kyi gnad bshad pa/ / gnyid dang rmi lam snyoms 'jug pa/ / tha mal dus dang rnam pa bzhir/ / sems ni 'khor los sgyur rgyal 'dra/ /
I will explain the vital points of time. During the four periods— sleep, dreams, sexual union, and the ordinary state— the mind is like a cakravartin ruler. (144–47)
