yul gyi gnad ni gsum yin te/ / phyi rol dkar dmar rnam pa can/ / rig ma mtshan ldan grogs su gces/ /
The vital points of the objects are three with the external white and red manifestations. Embrace an authentic vidyā as an aid. (148–50)
gtum mo a thung yul gyi gnad/ / nang gi 'khor lo bzhir gtad de/ / srog rtsol sbyar ba'i sbyor ba yis/ / lte ba'i a las me sbar te/ / 'khor lo bzhi bsreg rtsa kha 'byed/ /

Short a caṇḍālī is the vital point of the object. Focus on the four internal cakras. Through the practice of applying prāṇāyāma, fire blazes from a at the navel, the four cakras are burned, and the channels open. (151–55)
me lce haM las reg pa yis/ / nam mkha'i ba ni rim bzhin bzho/ / byang chub sems kyis rtsa rnams 'gengs/ /
When the flames touch the haṃ, space is gradually milked and bodhicittas fill the channels. (156–58)
a la babs shing thigs ma chad/ / bde stong dbyer med don la gzung / / 'byung ba ro snyoms ma shes na/ / bsgoms kyang rtogs pa mi 'byung ngo / /
They descend and drip to a continuously.[24] Inseparable bliss-emptiness is held. If you don’t recognize the equal taste of the elements, even though you meditate, realization won’t arise. (159–62)
bcos thabs bgrang gis mi longs kyang / / stong ba'i go cha rtsis su che/ / lus ni 'grub par gyur ba na/ / rtags ni rnam pa sna tshogs 'byung / /
Although there are countless remedial methods, the armor of emptiness is of greatest value. When the body has become accomplished, myriad signs occur. (163–66)
lte bar gtum mo sbar ba yis/ / de bzhin gshegs pa lnga sreg cing / / spyan la sogs pa yang sreg ste/ / bsregs pas ri bong can haM 'dzag /
Caṇḍālī blazes at the navel, scorching the five tathāgatas, consuming Locanā and the others. Its burning causes the haṃ of the rabbit-bearer to drip.[25] (167–70)
e waM bzhi yi bsam gtan bya/ / lte ba sprul skur dga' bzhi bskyed/ /
Cultivate the meditative concentrations of the four [related to] e vaṃ. Arouse the four joys at the navel nirmāṇakāya. (171–72)

lha yi rnal 'byor dus su ni/ / skra yi rtse mo'i khyon tsam gyis/ / 'od zer glog stong 'khyug pa bzhin/ / ba spu'i khung bu'i phyogs mtshams nas/ / byung ste phyogs bcur gnas pa yis/ / lha dang lha min bsdigs par mdzad/ / (73)

During deity yoga, slivers of light rays—just hair tips’ worth,[26] flashing like thousands of lightning bolts— arise in all directions in your pores. They threaten the gods and asuras.[27] (173–78) {73}
lus sems srog gi dbyug pa la/ / sbyor ba drug gi man ngag gnas/ / thabs dang bcas na shin tu 'bar/ /
The esoteric instructions for the six-branched yoga reside in the body, mind, and the life-force staff.[28] When combined with method, there is great blazing. (179–81)

lte bar chu shing snying po gnas/ / snying gar yang ni bsgrengs te gnas/ / rtag tu stong ba'i sgo yin te/ / mkhas pas rgyun du bzlog par bya/ / sgom dang bzlas pa'i khyad par gyis/ / ngag gi lam nas zhugs gyur na/ / 'grub 'gyur 'di la the tshom med/ /

The heart of a plantain tree rests at the navel and extends to the heart, where it abides. It is always the door of emptiness. Those with skill reverse this.[29] When, with the special features of meditation and recitation, you enter through the path of speech, you will become accomplished—there is no doubt.[30] (182–88)
stong pa'i snying po mtshon pa las/ / chu shing snye ma'i bdud rtsi bzhin/ /
This is shown through the heart of emptiness, which is like the amṛta of the fruits of a plantain tree. (189–90)

lte ba chu bo mtshams 'khor lo/ / gru gsum dkar zhing dmar ba la/ / thig le kha dog lnga bsam te/ / sangs rgyas lnga ru mtshon par bya/ / srog 'gog pa dang ldan byas pas/ / skad cig nyid la 'bar 'gyur te/ / 'jig rten khams rnams mchod pa'i gnas/ / rdo rje 'dzin pa nyid du 'gyur/ /

In the navel, there is a cakra at the edge of the bladder,[31] triangular, white, and red. Imagine bindus of five colors, symbolizing the five buddhas. With the cessation of the life force, instantly they blaze. The worldly realms are sources of offerings. You become Vajradhara.[32] (191–98)
de las 'bras bu 'char ba la/ / thun mong dang ni khyad par dang / / mchog dang rnam pa gsum yin no/ /
With that, the result develops in three modes: common, special, and supreme. (199–201)
thun mong rim pa bstan pa ni/ / rlung ni zin par gyur pa yis/ / dang po dro ba lta bu 'byung / / gnyis pa bde ba 'char ba dang / / gsum pa mi rtog skye bar 'gyur/ /
de nas rnam rtog shugs kyis 'gag / du ba smig rgyu me khyer dang / / skya rengs shar ba ji bzhin dang / / nam mkha' sprin dag lta bu 'byung / /
Then, thoughts naturally stop. Smoke, mirages, fireflies, what is like dawn, and what resembles a cloudless sky arise. (207–10)

dul zhing brtan pa sa yi rlung / / 'khor gzhong nang du chu blug bzhin/ / 'jam nyal byed na chu yi rlung / / tsha zhing 'thibs pa me yi rlung / / rtsen zhing mgyogs pa rlung gi rlung / / gsal zhing yang ba nam mkha'i rlung / / las su rung ba'i rtags lnga'o/ /

The earth winds tame and stabilize. The water winds soften, like water poured into a basin.[33] The fire winds heat and thicken. The wind winds cause play and speed. The space winds clarify and lighten. Those are the five signs of flexibility. (211–17)
srog rtsol gnad du tshud pa yis/ / g.yas g.yon 'pho dang bye brag phyed/ / tshor ba bde dang rang 'dod du/ / bsdam dang phyi nang bsre bar nus/ /
By striking the vital points of prāṇāyāma, there is movement left and right and distinctions are made. Sensations are blissful, and you can hold as you wish and blend inner and outer. (218–21)
nang gi tsha grang 'dres pa'i rtags/ / 'du ba rnam bzhis gnod mi tshugs/ / mi snang sa 'og nam mkhar rgyu/ / rkang mgyogs de bzhin bcud kyis len/ /

The signs of mixing internal heat and cold are that the four gatherings do not cause harm, that you can disappear, move below the earth and through space, are swift-footed, and can practice rasāyana. (222–25)
mkha' 'gro ma rnams khyad par du/ / (74) skad cig de la sbyor bskyed de/ /
With the ḍākinīs in particular, {74} in an instant, you can generate conjunctures. (226–27)
'byung bzhi gcig la gcig thim nas/ / tsaN+DA li ni shugs kyis 'bar/ / chu shel nges par 'beb pa gang / / gsang ba'i 'khor lo de nas bgrod/ / 'di ni phyugs chen du gsungs so/ /
Once the four elements dissolve one by one, caṇḍālī blazes naturally and the water crystal falls and fills. Reaching the secret cakra, that becomes mahāpaśu. (228–32)
khyad par rim pa bstan pa ni/ / de yi rkyen gyis d+hU tI ru/ / rlung rnams tshud par gyur pa yis/ / srog thur gong bur gyur pa'i mes/ / thig le'i tshogs pa gsang bar 'gog /

I will explain the special process. Through those conditions, the winds enter the avadhūti, and the life-force and downward-expelling become a sphere whose fire [causes] a gathering of bindus to block the secret place. (233–37)
thig le'i gzugs kyis 'dzag pa yis/ / bdud rtsi khu ba'i gzugs can ni/ / thig le'i rnal 'byor zhes bshad do/ /
The dripping of the forms of bindus becomes the forms of amṛta śukra. That is explained as the bindu yoga. (238–40)
bcu drug phyed phyed thig le can/ / cha med cha las 'das pa ste/ / bsam gtan bzhi ba'i mthar 'chang ba/ / nA da'i rnal 'byor zhes byar dran/ /
The bindus are sixteen divided in half and divided in half again. They are partless and beyond parts. Hold the end of the fourth meditative concentration.[34] Be aware that is the nāda yoga. (241–44)
'dis ni nad 'phrog tshe spel ba/ / khyad par rtags lnga yon tan brgyad/ / mkha' la spyod dang phra sogs ster/ /
That overwhelms illnesses and increases longevity.[35] In particular, it bestows the five signs, eight excellent qualities, the celestial realms, and what is subtle and the others. (245–47)
mchog gi rim pa bstan pa ni/ / nyi ma dang ni zla ba'i rlung / / 'pho med d+hU tI'i khyim du thim/ / yid kyi g.yo ba gzung 'dzin gnyis/ / spros dang bral bar rab tu zhi/ /

I will teach the supreme process. The sun and moon winds dissolve into the house of the avadhūti, devoid of movement.[36] The stirrings of mind, the duality of percepts and perceivers, are fully pacified, free from elaborations. (248–52)
ma bcos gnyug ma lhan cig skyes/ / zag pa med pa'i ting 'dzin gnas/ / phyi rol yul gyis rtag ma thub/ / snang ba had bor 'char bar nges/ /
This is the uncontrived, intrinsic state: connateness. It abides as nondegenerative samādhi. Outer objects are not eternal. It is certain that appearances arise in a flash. (253–56)
skad cig gcig gis bye brag phyed/ / skad cig gcig gis rdzogs sangs rgyas/ /
An instant makes the difference: in an instant there is complete buddhahood.[37] (257–58)
kun tu 'od ni sa chen po/ / de nyid nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor 'dra/ / bdud rtsi'i 'od ni gnyis pa ste/ / shin tu 'od gsal zla ba 'dra/ /
nam mkha'i 'od ni gsum pa ste/ / nam mkha' ji bzhin rab tu gnas/ / rdo rje'i 'od ni bzhi ba ste/ / sa de'i 'od ni yid dga' ba/ / lhag pa'i bsam pa brtan sbyor bas/ / rdo rje zhes ni yongs su btags/ /
lnga pa rin chen 'od ces bya/ / dbang bskur ba la rab tu gnas/ / pad+ma'i 'od ni drug pa ste/ / pad+ma bzhin du rab tu skye/ / rang bzhin dag pa'i sems nyid kyis/ / dri ma med pa yongs su 'dzin/ /
bdun pa las kyi 'od ces pa/ / sangs rgyas phrin las (75)byed par 'dod/ / brgyad pa dpe med ces bya ba/ / de la dpe ni yod ma yin/ /
dpe ldan zhes pa dgu pa ste/ / thams cad dpe ni so sor rtogs/ / bcu pa shes rab 'od ces pa/ / sangs rgyas pa ni bla na med/ /
bcu gcig thams cad mkhyen pa nyid/ / sa chen rab tu 'od gsal ba/ / bcu gnyis so so bdag nyid rig / rnal 'byor ye shes rab tu rdzogs/ /
des kyang bsgom skyod ma byung zhing / / ting 'dzin brtan par ma gyur na/ / las kyi phyag rgya mtshan ldan las/ / lam lnga 'bras bu thob par bya/ /
If, through that meditation, development does not occur[39] and samādhi is not stabilized, you will achieve the five paths and the results with a qualified karmamudrā. (287–90)
sbyor thabs mi shes rnal 'byor dang / / stan yang gcig la mi bsdad de/ / gal te brgya la bsdad gyur na/ / shi nas mnar med dmyal bar skye/ /
Those who do not understand the methods of union should not abide even on one seat with [this] yoga. If they sit with a mudrā,[40] they will be born in the Avīci hell once they die.
'dod chags la sogs sha ma li/ / yar la bshal zhing mar la 'dud/ / de phyir sbyor thabs mkhas pas bsten/ / bstan pa smod pas 'jigs pa na/ / rang sems tsam la mos pa bya/ /

Desire and the rest will cause them to crawl up and down through Shalmali trees.[*7][41] Therefore, practice the methods of union with skill. (291–97) Those who fear being a disgrace to the teachings should simply imagine this in their minds. (298–99)

pad+ma can dang dung can ma/ / ri mo can dang ri dwags can/ / bram ze rgyal rigs rje rigs dang / / dmangs rigs gdol pa la sogs dang / / ma dang sring mo bu mo yang / / khyad par can gyis bsten gyur na/ / yon tan 'byung gi skyon du min/ /

If you can practice with special ones— such as padminīs, śaṅkhinīs, citriṇis, mṛgīs, brahmans, kṣatriyas, vaiśyas, śūdras, and caṇḍālas, and also with mothers, sisters, and daughters— excellent qualities will arise, faults will not. (300–306)
bcu gcig ma dang bcu gnyis ma/ / bcu drug ma dang nyi shu ma/ / nyi shu bzhi lon bar du bsten/ / sgyu ma dag ni thams cad las/ / bud med sgyu ma khyad par 'phags/ /
Practice with those who are eleven, twelve, sixteen, twenty, and up to twenty-four. Among all the illusions, women are the finest illusions. (307–11)
me tog rab song sbas pa yis/ / de 'og rdul gyi sbyor bas ni/ / rgyal po dang ni blon po dang / / gzhon nu ma yang dbang du 'gyur/ /
A compound of dust below which a departed flower is hidden will magnetize kings, ministers, and the young. (312–15)
mi snang ba yi las bya ste/ / byi la nag mo'i sha ma ni/ / kham phor kha sbyar nang du skams/ / bgegs bskrad pa yi cho ga bya/ /
For the activity of invisibility, do as follows: In [two] earthenware bowls joined “mouth-to-mouth,” dry the afterbirth of a black cat. Perform the ritual for expelling obstructors.
de ltar grib skam byas pa'i rdzas/ / phye mar btags te rang nyid kyi/ / mi bskyod pa dang rab sbyar nas/ / sran ma tsam gyi ril bu bya/ /
Grind into a powder substances that have been dried in the shade, mix in your Akṣobhya, and make a ball the size of a bean.
ril bu lcags gsum gyis dkris nas/ / kha yi nang du gzhug par bya/ /
Wrapping the ball in the three metals, place it in your mouth. (316–25)
kun tu ru yi skabs su ni/ / bus pa'i sman yang lag (76) tu bcang / /
During kunduru, hold in your hand the medicinal herb of a child. (326–27) {76}
rang gis dbang bskur snying rje can/ / de dang dben pa'i gnas nyid du/ / nyam nga med pa'i spyod pa bya/ /
Bestow the abhiṣekas yourself, compassionate ones. In an isolated place, engage in the conduct without intimidation. (328–30)
dbab pa sgrub pa'i bye brag gis/ / gsang la sbyor ba'i dus tsa na/ / blta dang 'dzum dang 'khyud dang rgod/ / de la rtsed mo sna tshogs bya/ / de ni tshogs kyi lam du 'dod/ /
With the specifics for practicing descent, during the secret conduct, gaze, smile, embrace, and laugh— do all kinds of flirtatious things. That is said to be the path of accumulation. (331–35)
e waM gcig tu sbyar byas pas/ / rnam pa sna tshogs sbyor ba'i lam/ / rtse mo yun ring drud pa las/ / rnam par smin pa mthong ba'i lam/ /
Joining e and vaṃ is the manifold, the path of preparation. Drawing from the tips for a long time is the maturing, the path of seeing. (336–39)
gnyis shor gnyis mnyam dbus dag tu/ / de la ma yengs sgom pa'i lam/ / dgag bsgrub med par ngo 'phrod pas/ / mthar thug lam du 'dod pa yin/ /
Releasing both and being undistracted in the pure middle, the equality of the two, is the path of meditation. Recognition, with no blocking or confirming, is said to be the consummate path.
bsgoms na sangs rgyas kun kyang rgya/ / ma bsgoms rgya na rgya ba yin/ /
If they meditate, everyone becomes awakened, but if they awaken without meditating, that is awakening. (340–345)
gzung ba 'khrul 'khor man ngag dang / / zangs tshags can dang ting 'dzin no/ / zlog pa dud 'gro'i 'gyur bzhi la/ / sbyor pa drug dang bzhi ldan sbyar/ /
Retaining involves trulkhors, esoteric instructions, the “copper strainer,”[*8] and samādhi. Reversing involves the four movements of animals with six and four yogic techniques.
'grems pa rnam rol phyag rgya dang / / gzer chen dag gi man ngag go /
Spreading involves the manifestations, mudrās, and the esoteric instructions of the great nails. (346–51)
de nas rtsa yi nang nyid du/ / g.yon pa'i srin lag sa la ni/ / drag tu btsugs nas lus lcid phab/ / yang na lag pa gnyis kyang rung / /
Right on the channels, forcefully press your ring finger on the spots and relax your body’s weight. Or do that with two hands. (352–55)
rlung dang bsre ba'i man ngag ni/ / steng rlung mnan zhing 'og rlung bsdam/ / dper na nor bu rin chen dag / ma phug pas ni sbyor bral 'gyur/ / phug pas dga' ba sbyin pa'o/ /

The esoteric instructions for mixing the winds are to press down the upper winds and bind the lower winds. This is like, for example, a gem and its value. When there is no penetration, there is no union. When there is penetration, joy is bestowed. (356–60)
shel dang mtshungs pa'i sems la ni/ / sbyor bas yul la 'jug pa ste/ / 'khor ba'i skyon gyis gos pa yin/ / skyon dang yon tan sems la med/ /
The crystal-like mind, engaging with objects through union, is sullied by the flaws of saṃsāra, [even though] mind has neither flaws nor virtues. (361–64)
'di la spang ba gnyis yod de/ / yon tan med na spang ba dang / / khyad par 'phags nas spang ba'o/ /
There are two [instances when] this is to be dispensed with: it is to be dispensed with by those without the qualities and is to be dispensed with by the especially noble ones.[*9] (365–67)
khyad par yon tan can gyis kyang / / shes pa skyon pa bsten kyang rung / / 'ga' dang 'ga' yi spyod yul las/ / kun gyi spyod yul 'di ma yin/ /
In particular, those with excellent qualities may practice despite having a flawed mind. It is a sphere of practice for a few—not a sphere of practice for all. (368–71)
phyi dang nang du rnam bye ba/ / thams cad sgyu ma las gzhan min/ / de bas 'di ltar 'gro ba kun/ / sgyu ma lta bur 'dir bshad de/ /
All the various things, outer and inner,[42] are nothing other than illusions. Thus, I will explain here: all beings are like illusions. (372–75)
rnam par smin pa'i sgyu lus dang / / (77) dag pa lha yi sgyu lus dang / / sgyu ma lta bu'i ting 'dzin gnas/ / thams cad de dang 'dra bar mthong / /
The illusory body of full maturation, {77} the illusory body of the pure deity, and the illusion-like-samādhi states[*10] are all seen to be that way. (376–79)
me long lta bu'i gzugs brnyan gyis/ / sgyu ma'i lus 'di shes par bya/ / kha dog rnams ni 'ja' lta bu/ / khyab pa chu yi zla bas so/ /
Through [seeing] an image reflected in a mirror, recognize this illusory body. Its colors are like rainbows. It is omnipresent like moons reflected in water. (380–83)

mig yor glog dang smig rgyu dang / / brag cha dri za'i grong khyer dang / / rmi lam sgyu ma chu sbur dang / / mig 'phrul mtshungs par gang gis mthong / / sgyu mar bstan pa'i mtshan nyid kyis/ / 'gro ba sgyu ma ji bzhin brtags/ /

Whoever sees [that all things] are similar to visual distortions, lightning, mirages, echoes, cities of gandharvas, dreams, illusions, water bubbles, and optical illusions understands beings to be like illusions through their characteristics, which demonstrate illusions. (384–89)
me long dri ma med pa las/ / rdo rje sems dpa' legs bris pa'i/ / gzugs brnyan gsal bar snang mtshungs pas/ / rnam pa kun gyi mchog ldan pa'i/ / sku ni rjes su dran par bya/ /

Through [meditating on] a stainless mirror in which the well-drawn reflection of Vajrasattva is similar to a clear appearance, recollect that it is a form with the most sublime of manifestations. (390–94)
'ja' tshon lta bu'i lus ngag ni/ / de nyid bsgoms pas thob par 'gyur/ / yan lag drug sgom de la ni/ / slar yang byin gyis brlab bya yin/ /
By meditating on the suchness of the rainbowlike body and speech, you become accomplished. Cultivate the six branches. Next is the consecration.[43]
rjes mthun cho ga'i rim pa 'dis/ / phyis nas mtshan ma mtshon par bya/ /
This process of concordant practices will then reveal the signs. (395–400)
dang po sprin gyi rnam pa ste/ / gnyis pa du ba lta bu'o/ / gsum pa srin bu me khyer dngos/ / bzhi pa mar me gsal 'bar ba/ /
The first is the manifestation of clouds. The second is like smoke. The third is the actual fireflies. The fourth is clearly blazing flames.
lnga pa rtag tu snang ba ste/ / sprin med nam mkha' lta bu'o/ /
The fifth is continual illumination, like a cloud-free sky. (401–6)
thams cad mkhyen pa'i rgyu de de/ / dngos grub nges 'jug nye ba yin/ / rnal 'byor las ni gang gang dmigs/ / de de sgyu ma bzhin du brtag /
Those are causes for omniscience, and close to the definite engagement of siddhi. Whatever yogins and yoginīs observe is understood to be an illusion. (407–10)
gzugs dang sgra dang de bzhin dri/ / ro dang reg bya nyid dag la/ / mig la sogs pa 'jug gyur pa/ / sgyu ma lta bur nye bar brtag /
What engage—that is, the eyes and so forth— with forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tangible objects are understood to be illusion-like. (411–14)
gang gang dbang po'i lam gyur nyid/ / de de'i rang bzhin nyid las grol/ / don dam nyid phyir sbyar ba yis/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi ngo bo 'gyur/ /
The paths of the sense faculties, whatever they are, are free from being [only] of that nature.[*11] United with the ultimate, they are of the natures of all buddhas. (415–18)
phyis nas sgyu ma'i rnam pa ltar/ / rmi lam rnam par skad cig 'gyur/ /
Then, those illusion-like manifestations instantly become dream manifestations. (419–20)
'jig rten khams ni thams cad du/ / ji srid rdo rje'i lus dang ldan/ / khams gsum rgyu dang mi rgyu ba/ / ma lus lus pa med par 'grub/ /
In all the realms of the world, all of the animate and inanimate of the three realms, with their vajra bodies, become accomplished.[44] (421–24)
dmigs med kun rdzob dag tu ni/ / sgyu ma lta bur rab tu (78) bshad/ /
The inapprehensible and the conventional are said to be illusion-like. {78} (425–26)
kun nas phyag dang kun nas zhabs/ / kun nas spyan dang dbu dang zhal/ / kun nas snyan ldan 'jig rten na/ / kun tu thams cad g.yogs nas bzhugs/ /
The hands and feet [of awakened ones] are everywhere; their eyes, heads, and faces are everywhere, in the world, everywhere with renown, everywhere covering all.[45] (427–30)
rdo rje theg pa 'di nyid du/ / mang du bshad pas smos ci dgos/ /
Since there are many explanations of this in the Vajrayāna, there is no need to discuss it. (431–32)
chos rnams rmi lam lta bu ste/ / ngo bo nyid kyis ma skyes shing / / rang bzhin dag pa'i sems nyid la/ / 'khrul pa log pa rab tu gsungs/ /
Phenomena are said to be like dreams: they do not inherently come into being, and delusion is reversed in the naturally pure mind. (433–36)
don bzhis nyams su blang bar bya/ / dang po rmi lam gzung ba dang / / de nas sbyang zhing sgyu mar bslab/ / de tshe ya nga spang ba dang / / kho na nyid don sgom pa'o/ /
This is practiced through four points. First recognize [dreams to be dreams]. Then practice, and train with their illusoriness. At that time, abandon your fears and cultivate suchness. (437–41)

dang po gzung ba'i man ngag ni/ / dran dang 'dun pas mtshams sbyar te/ / rnam shes srog ni 'du ba'i rten/ / mgrin par sngags kyi 'khor lo bsgom/ / slar yang rlung dang shes sbyar nas/ / thig le bting dang bgo bar bya/ /

First, the esoteric instructions for recognizing are as follows: Join mindfulness with intention, and meditate on the mantra cakra at your throat, the support for the gathering of the consciousness and the life-force [wind]. Again, join the winds and mind, and spread out and put on the bindus. (442–47)

de nas sbyangs pa'i man ngag ni/ / ngo mtshar can gyi rmi lam gang / / rmi bar bya'o snyams pa'i blos/ / dper na rmi lam bud med snang / / sad nas bud med mang por spro/ / der shes pa yis dbang gis su/ / cir yang bsgyur du btub pa yin/ /

Next, the esoteric instructions for practicing are as follows: Whatever amazing dream you have, think, “I am dreaming.” If you dream of a man or woman, recognize [your dream] and multiply them.[46] The force of that recognition enables you to transform them however you wish. (448–54)

gsum pa sgyu mar bslab pa ni/ / bdag med ma yi rnam par bsgom/ / de yi sprul pa rnam mang pos/ / nam mkha'i khams kyi mthar thug pa/ / khengs par gyur pa rab bltas na/ / de bzhin du ni 'gyur ba yin/ /

Third, training with their illusoriness is as follows: Meditate on the form of Nairātmyā. Her many emanations reach the limits of the realm of space, filling it—when you see that, that is how it is. (455–60)

chos rnams rmi lam ltar shes nas/ / sems can don du rab tu 'jug / / sgyu ma lta bur lam khyer bas/ / sgyu ma lta bur 'tshang yang rgya/ / de dag 'chi ba'i dus byung yang / / bar do ngo ni shes par 'gyur/ /

When you know that all phenomena are like dreams, you can fully engage for the welfare of sentient beings. By integrating [all experiences] with the illusion-like path, you will attain illusion-like awakening. Then, when death arrives, you will recognize the bardo. (461–66)

kho na nyid don sgom pa ni/ / rdo rje las byung sna tshogs pa'i/ / rmi lam de ma med mthong na/ / rmi lam sgyu ma gcig tu sbyangs/ / sku gsung thugs kyi rdo rje las/ / skyes pa bla med 'grub par 'gyur/ /

Cultivating the suchness [of dreams] is as follows: When you see stainless dreams, which are the varieties that arise from the vajra, you practice dreams and illusions together.[*12][47] Arising from the vajras of body, speech, and mind, the unsurpassable is achieved. (467–72)
'od gsal ngos 'dzin man ngag 'dir/ / gzhi lam 'bras bu rab shes bya/ / rang bzhin sprin dang 'od gsal ba/ / gdod nas dag pa nam mkha' (79) bzhin/ /
The esoteric instructions for recognizing luminosity here should be known in terms of ground, path, and fruition. Naturally, clouds and luminosity are pure from the start, like space. (473–76) {79}
ji ltar sprin ni sna tshogs shing / / mdog dang dbyibs ni tha dad pa/ / nam mkha'i dbyings nas byung nas ni/ / de nyid du ni thim par 'gyur/ /
Clouds, in all their varieties, with their different colors and shapes, arise from the expanse of space and dissolve there too. (477–80)
de bzhin rang bzhin thams cad ni/ / snang ba gsum gyi rgyu can te/ / ma lus yul la zhugs nas ni/ / 'od gsal bar ni 'jug par 'gyur/ /
Similarly, all the intrinsic natures come with the causes—the three illuminations— and, having engaged objects, they enter luminosity.[*13] (481–84)
de nyid 'char ba'i dus lnga ste/ / 'chi ba'i dus dang gnyid log dang / / mnyam par bzhag dang dbu mar gnas/ / mnyam rjes ro gcig gyur pa yin/ /

There are five occasions when that occurs: at death, when falling asleep, in meditative equipoise, when abiding in the madhyamā, and when meditative equipoise and postmeditative attainment are of one taste. (485–88)
ji ltar mar me bum nang gnas/ / phyi rol du ni snang mi 'gyur/ / bum pa de nyid bcag gyur na/ / de 'og mar me'i 'od snang 'gyur/ /
When a butter lamp is inside a vase, it doesn’t illuminate outside that. Once the vase is broken, the butter lamp’s light can illuminate. (489–92)
de bzhin bum pa rang lus nyid/ / 'od gsal mar me lta bu yin/ / bla ma'i zhal gyis legs bcag na/ / sangs rgyas ye shes gsal bar 'gyur/ /
Similarly, your body is like a vase, and luminosity like a butter lamp. When the guru’s oral instructions break that, buddha wisdom can shine. (493–96)
stong nyid shin tu stong pa dang / / gsum pa stong pa chen po dang / / bzhi pa thams cad stong pa ni/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu'i bye brag go /
Emptiness, extreme emptiness, the third, great emptiness, and the fourth, total emptiness, are instances of causes and results. (497–500)
stong pa che la mnyam par gzhag / bsam gtan 'di ni rnam dag min/ / de nyid rig la gang gis gnas/ / ye shes gsum ni rnam dag des/ / mngon par byang chub shes par 'gyur/ /
Resting evenly in great emptiness is not pure meditative concentration. Whoever, recognizing that, abides in suchness purely ascertains the three wisdoms and knows mastery. (501–5)
stong pa ma yin mi stong min/ / dbu mar yang ni mi dmigs so/ /
This is not emptiness and it is not nonemptiness. It is not observed to be a middle either. (506–7)

'od gsal bar ni gnyid log na/ / zhag ni du mar mtshams bcad nas/ / gnyid mi nyal bar sems kyi sang / / de nas khrus dang byug pa dang / / dku mnye'i sbyor ba la 'bad cing / / mthun pa'i zas dag bsten par bya/ /

To fall asleep in luminosity, remain in retreat for a few days. Then don’t lie down to sleep, and refresh your mind.[48] Next, apply yourself to the activities of bathing, anointing, and massage. Also consume agreeable foods. (508–13)
de nas nyal bar gyur ba na/ / snying gi pad+mo kha phye ste/ / 'dab bzhi dbus kyi lte ba la/ / a nu ta ra hU~M bsgoms nas/ /
Then, when you lie down, visualize at your heart an open lotus with four petals and in its center a nu ta ra hūṃ. (514–17)

dbugs kyi rlung ni me long la/ / ji ltar kun tu thim gyur pa/ / de bzhin rnal 'byor yang dag mthar/ / yang dang yang du 'jug par byed/ / ril por 'dzin pa'i rim pa dang / / de bzhin rjes su gzhig pas so/ /
Just as your breath fades on a mirror, so should yogins and yoginīs, again and again, enter the true end. Do this by grasping the whole and successive destruction. (518–23)
'od gsal mngon du gyur pa na/ / song bzhi gcig tu gyur pa'i (80) shes/ / sgyu ma'i rlung ldan zung 'jug 'char/ /

ji ltar dwangs pa'i chu klung las/ / nya dag myur du 'phar ba ltar/ / de bzhin thams cad stong gsal las/ / sgyu 'phrul drwa ba 'byung bar 'gyur/ / mthong ba'i chos la mya ngan 'da'/ / bya ba byas pa'ang de nyid yin/ /
Like a fish leaping from a clear river, from clear total emptiness comes a web of magical illusion. The present life is nirvāṇa. This is what is to be done. (527–32)
'chi ba stong pa chos sku la/ / bar ma do ni longs spyod rdzogs/ / srid par skye ba sprul pa'i sku/ / skye ba'i cha ni thabs yin la/ / 'gags pa shes rab srid mthar byed/ /
Death is the dharmakāya, emptiness. Bardo is the saṃbhogakāya. Taking birth in existence is the nirmāṇakāya. Birth is method. Cessation is prajñā, which brings an end to existence. (533–37)

dang po snang ba gsum gyis ni/ / thim pa'i 'od gsal ngos bzung ba/ / gnyis pa dag dang ma dag pas/ / sgyu ma lta bu'i sgo nas ni/ / bar ma dor ni 'tshang rgya'i thabs/ / gsum pa mngal sgo dgag pa dang / / gang 'dod mngal sgo gdam pa'o/ /

The first is to recognize luminosity, the dissolution of the three illuminations. The second is the method to awaken in the bardo by means of the illusion-like process involving the impure and the pure. The third is to block the entrance to the womb and choose a womb you wish.[50] (538–44)
de la skye shi bar do ru/ / bsgom ste sangs rgyas gtum mo dang / / sgyu ma'i lus la bslab par bya/ / de la goms par gyur pa dang / / rmi lam sgyu lus gnyis bsres la/ /
For that, during the bardo of birth-to-death, meditate and train in buddha caṇḍālī and illusory forms. Become habituated to those, and mix dreams and illusory forms. (545–49)
rmi lam bar do sbyang bar bya/ / rmi lam sgyu lus 'byongs pa dang / / 'chi ka dus kyi bar do ru/ / 'od gsal pa dang 'dres pa las/ /
Practice with the bardo of dreams. Be skilled with dreams and illusory forms. Mix the bardo of the moment of death with luminosity. (550–53)
sgyu lus ril 'dzin rjes gzhig gi / bag chags thams cad bsreg pa'i phyir/ / 'od gsal me yis sbyangs nas ni/ / zung du 'jug pa'i skur sangs rgyas/ /
Using illusory body, grasping the whole, and successive destruction, practice with the fire of luminosity in order to burn up all latent tendencies, and awaken into the kāya of unification. (554–57)

rim gyis 'jug pa'i gang zag gi / shes pa skye lugs 'di lta ste/ / snang ba thim dang rags pa thim/ / rtog pa thim dang phra ba thim/ / thim pa'i rjes la goms pa dang / / rang bzhin gyi ni 'od gsal 'char/ /

For individuals who enter [death] gradually[51] the sequence of the mental processes is as follows: Illumination dissolves, the coarse dissolves. Thoughts dissolve, the subtle dissolves.[52] Be familiar with what follows dissolution: natural luminosity dawns.[53] (558–63)
de yi rjes la zung 'jug gi / sku ni rnam pa gnyis 'byung ste/ / slob pa dang ni mi slob gnyis/ / mi slob pa ni gyur tsa na/ / 'bras bu thob ces bstan pa yin/ /
After that, the two kāyas of unification arise: one of training and one beyond training. When beyond training occurs,[54] that is taught to be “attaining the result.” (564–68)
gang du bstan pa de dag kyang / / rgyas par bshad na 'di lta ste/ / dang po lung rigs man ngag gis/ / rgyud la rtogs pa shar tsa na/ / snang ba 'gag lugs bstan pa ni/ /

All that is taught above[55] is explained in detail as follows:[56] First, when through scriptures, reasonings, and esoteric instructions, realization dawns in your continuum, the process of the cessation of illumination is explained.[57] (569–73)
gzugs ni sgra la thim par 'gyur/ / (81) sgra yang dri la dri yang ro/ / reg bya'i bar du rim gyis thim/ / sa dang chu dang me dang rlung / / de rnams rim gyis rnam shes la/ /

Forms dissolve into sounds, {81} and then sounds into smells, smells into tastes, sequentially up to the dissolution of tangible objects.[58] Earth, water, fire, and wind all [dissolve] sequentially into consciousness.[59] (574–78)

rnam shes snang ba la thim tshe/ / phyi rtags zla shar lta bu la/ / nang rtags du ba lta bu 'byung / / snang ba de nyid mched pa la/ / thim tshe phyi rtags nyi shar 'dra/ / shes pa me khyer lta bur 'byung / /

When consciousness dissolves into illumination, the outer sign is like the moon rising and the inner sign is like smoke. When illumination dissolves into radiance, the outer sign is the sun appearing and cognition is like fireflies.[60] (579–84)
mched pa thob pa la thim pas/ / phyi rtags mun pa lta bu 'byung / / shes pa mar me lta bur 'char/ /
When radiance dissolves into attainment, the outer sign is like darkness[61] and cognition is like candle flames.[62] (585–87)
thob pa 'od gsal la thim pas/ / phyi rtags tho rangs dus tshod kyi/ / skya rings shar ba lta bu 'byung / / nang gi shes pa nam mkha' ni/ / sprin dag 'dra ba 'char ba'o/ /
When attainment dissolves into luminosity,[63] the outer sign is like dawn, the time of first light,[64] and the inner cognition is like the sky free from clouds.[65] (588–92)
'od gsal de las langs pa yi/ / zung 'jug ngos ni gzung bya ste/ / mngon par byang chub 'od gsal mes/ / bag chags thams cad sbyong dus su/ / slob pa'i zung 'jug ces bya'o/ /
Unification, arising from luminosity, is recognized.[66] When the fire of luminosity, mastery, has purified all latent tendencies, that is called the unification of training.[67] (593–97)
sbyang gzhi sbyong byed med tsa na/ / goms pa mthar phyin gyur ba ste/ / mi slob zung 'jug ces bya'o/ / 'bras bu thob par gyur pa yin/ /
When there is no basis to be purified or means of purification, that is the perfection of familiarization. It is called unification beyond training and is the attainment of the result.[68] (598–601)
de las srid pa'i bar ma dor/ / sgyu lus zung 'jug skur gyur te/ / longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sku thob bo/ / de la goms pas mngal sgo khegs/ /
Next, in the bardo of becoming, be an illusory kāya of unification. That is the attainment of the saṃbhogakāya. Familiarizing yourself with that blocks entering a womb. (602–5)

gal te zung 'jug ma shes na/ / srid pa'i skye ba mi khegs pas/ / chags sdang snang ba kun spangs la/ / dran pa'i spyan pas mtshams sbyar te/ / mngal sgo gdam pa'i sbyor ba pa/ / mngon dga'i 'pho ba byas pa yis/ / gang 'dod gnas su skye bar 'gyur/ /

If you do not recognize that unification, block birth in existence and reject appearances of attachment and aversion. With the eye of mindfulness, form the link: link with choosing an entry to a womb.[69] Using the transference to Abhirati, you will be born in the place you wish. (606–12)

'pho ba'i bye brag shin tu mang / / sbyangs te 'pho dang ting 'dzin dang / / srog dang rtsol bas 'pho ba dang / / rnam shes bla mar 'pho ba dang / / btsan thabs dag tu 'pho ba dang / / spros med chos sku'i 'pho ba dang / / spros bcas gzugs sku'i 'pho ba dang / / longs spyod rdzogs sku'i 'pho ba dang / / sprul pa sku yi 'pho ba dang / / yid 'ong DA ki'i 'pho ba'o/ /

There are many types of transference: transference through training, through samādhi, transference through prāṇāyāma, transferring your consciousness to the guru, transference using forceful means, the unelaborate dharmakāya transference, the elaborate form kāya transference, the saṃbhogakāya transference, the nirmāṇakāya transference, and the pleasing ḍākinī transference. (613–22)
de dag thams cad ro gcig (82) par/ / sngon 'gro dngos gzhi rjes gsum las/ / pus mo skor zhing sa gol brdab/ / brgya dang rtsa brgyad zin pa'i mod/ /

All of those, as one taste, {82} have preliminaries, a main practice, and a conclusion. Circle your knees and snap your fingers. Doing that one hundred and eight times is the measure of retention.[70] (623–26)
snying gar zin nas lkod mar gzung / / dbugs ni ngal bar gyur pa na/ / sna sgor cha mnyam ngal gso bya/ / rang 'dod dbu mar zin pa na/ / bde ba'i 'khor lo drang bya ste/ /

After retaining it at your heart, hold it at your throat. When your breath feels tired, rest it at your nostrils in equal amounts. When you can hold it in the madhyamā as you wish, draw it to the cakra of bliss. (627–31)

bum pa sngon du brtsams nas ni/ / nyi shu rtsa gcig dbugs dag gis/ / gnas nas drag tu drangs nas su/ / gzhung tshigs nang yar pad+ma yi/ / 'khor lo nyi shu rtsa gcig bsam/ / tshigs gcig nas ni tshigs gcig go /
Start with vase breathing. Abide for twenty-one breaths, then draw up forcefully. In the spinal joints, imagine twenty-one cakras of lotuses, one joint after another. (632–37)
yar bzlog mar bzlog sa bon gyi/ / sbyang ba yi ge phyed dang gnyis/ / nga ro drag tu brjod pa yis/ / shes pa bde ba can du gtad/ /
Traversing up and down, train with the seed syllables, one and a half letters.[*14] With a forceful shout, direct your mind to Sukhāvatī. (638–41)
dus la bab na 'pho bya ste/ / dus min lha rnams gsod par 'gyur/ / rims la sogs pa ma phog par/ / 'pho ba'i sbyor ba mchog yin pas/ /

When the time comes, do transference. If it is not the time, you will kill the deities. [When] you are not afflicted by disease or the like, that is the best [time] to prepare for transference. (642–45)
'chi ba'i dus la bab pa na/ / mtshan ma shes par bya ba ste/ / lam bzang po la yid 'ongs gnas/ / lam ngan gyis ni srid pa skyon/ /
When the time of death arrives, you must know the signs. Excellent paths are abodes of mental ease. Inferior paths involve the flaws of existence. (646–49)
thig le lte ba steng dang ni/ / mig sna srid sgo rna ba dang / / chu dang chu min sgo mtshan nyid/ /
There are the characteristics of the bindu, the navel, the top, the eyes, the nostrils, the path of existence, the ears, and the doors for fluids and nonfluids. (650–52)
lte ba las ni 'dod khams lha/ / thig le'i gzugs can mtho ris te/ / steng nas 'gro ba steng gi ni/ / 'gro ba dag tu rab tu brtag /

[Going] from the navel [leads to] the desire-realm gods. [Going from] what has the form of a bindu [leads to] the higher states. Going from the top is understood to [lead to becoming] a being who is on top. (653–56)
sna nas gnod sbyin gnas su ste/ / rna ba dag gis grub pa'i lha/ / gal te mig las ye shes 'phos/ / mi rnams kyi ni bdag por 'gyur/ /

[Going] through the nostrils [leads] to the land of yakṣas. The ears [lead to becoming] a deity of accomplishment. If your wisdom transfers through the eyes, you will become a leader of humans. (657–60)

srid pa'i sgo las yi dwags dang / / de bzhin chu las dud 'gro ste/ / chu min gyis ni dmyal ba brgyad/ / 'di lta'i sgo yi khyad par las/ / 'khor ba'i bye brag tu 'gyur bas/ / tshangs pa'i gnas nas 'pho bar bya/ /

The door of existence [leads to becoming] a hungry ghost. Likewise, [the door for] fluids [leads to becoming] an animal, and [the door for] nonfluids [leads to] the eight hells. Since the particulars of these doors result in the specific instances of saṃsāra, transfer through the location of Brahmā. (661–66)
nyin re bram ze gsod pa dang / / mtshams med lnga yi byed pa dang / / rku dang 'dod pas log spyod rnams/ / 'di yis lam gyis khegs par 'gyur/ /
Those who have killed a brahman every day, committed the five acts of immediate consequence, stolen, or acted wrongly due to desire will have [those results] stopped by this path.[71]
sdig gis gos par mi 'gyur te/ / srid pa'i dngos po ring bar 'gyur/ /
Evil deeds will not sully, and the things of existence will become distant. (667–72) {83}
ji ltar (83)'dam nas skyes pa yi/ / pad+ma'i 'dab ni mdzes par 'gyur/ / de bzhin 'dam 'dra'i lus dag las/ / ye shes sku ni rang dgar 'byung / /
Although they grow out of mud, lotus petals are beautiful. Similarly, although it comes from the mud-like body, the pure wisdom body arises just on its own. (673–76)
rdo rje dril bu mi ldan pa'i/ / rdo rje'i bsgrub par ring bar 'gyur/ / rdo rje dril bu phyag rgya yang / / sbyangs nas pha rol brgal bar 'gyur/ /
Without vajra and ghaṇṭā, vajra accomplishment is something distant.[*15] By practicing with the vajra and ghaṇṭā mudrās[72] you will cross to the other side.
mtshan mo zla ba med pa yi/ / nyin mo zla ba ji ltar snang / /
How can the moon appear on a day when the moon has not appeared at night? (677–82)

rnal 'byor pa rnams 'pho ba'i tshe/ / khrag 'thung dpal sogs rnal 'byor ma/ / lag na me tog sna tshogs thogs/ / rgyal mtshan ba dan sna tshogs dang / / rol mo'i sgra ni sna tshogs dang / / sna tshogs glu yis mchod pa yis/ / 'chi ba zhes bya rnam rtog ste/ / mkha' spyod gnas su khrid par byed/ /

When yogins and yoginīs are transferring, the notion of what is called “death” will be that they are led to the celestial states [accompanied] by the glorious Heruka, yoginīs, and others holding many types of flowers in their hands, along with offering victory banners and flags, musical instruments of all kinds, and a medley of songs.[73] (683–90)
grong du 'jug pa bshad par bya/ / bskyed pa'i rim pa'i 'pho ba las/ / bye brag gsal bar bstan pa ste/ /
I will explain entering a body. This is clearly taught as a type of generation-process transference. (691–93)
dang po sngon 'gro sbyangs nas su/ / dngos gzhi dmigs pa gsal ba'i tshe/ / sems can rma med dag la yang / / rlung sems rtsal ni sbyang bar bya/ /
First, train in the preliminaries. When clarifying the object for the main practice, develop proficiency of winds and mind with a pure sentient being free from wounds. (694–97)
dang po khru gang bar khru gsum/ / tha ma khru bdun sa yin te/ / dmigs pa rno la ngar ldan pas/ / steng 'og sbo bar nus pa yis/ / rnal 'byor pas ni 'grub par gsungs/ /

First, a cubit and then three cubits. In the end, it will be seven cubits. Through a sharp, keen focus and the ability to move the upper and lower [winds], it is said that yogins and yoginīs will become accomplished. (698–702)
las la sbyar ba'i dus tshod du/ / dam tshig ldan pa'i grogs mchog gces/ / rgan po ma yin rma med cing / / mdze dang shu can la sogs spang / /
When the time to act comes, an excellent friend with samaya is essential. [The receptacle] should not be elderly or wounded; discard those with leprosy or boils. (703–6)
shin tu mnyam par bzhag pa yis/ / 'byung po'i nyi ma la bsgrub bya/ / bdud rtsi lnga yi khyad par dang / / lha yi chu yis bkru bar byed/ /
With strong meditative equipoise, practice on the day of the bhūtas.[*16] Wash [the corpse] with special five amṛtas and water of the gods. (707–10)
maN+Dal gru bzhi byas nas ni/ / de dbus 'bad pas gru gsum bya/ / dkyil 'khor steng du thod pa ni/ / mtshan ldan gcig la hU~M bris te/ /
Create a square maṇḍala. In its center, with effort, make a triangle. On top of the maṇḍala, place a skull cup, an authentic one, and inscribe hūṃ on it. (711–14)
de la shes pa gtad pa dang / / gsal zhing dwangs la yang ba yi/ / rig pa bde ba skye bar 'gyur/ /
Focus your mind on that. Awareness and bliss— clear, lucid, and light—will arise. (715–17)
rlung dang rnam par shes pa dang / / phyi rol lha dang rang nyid bsre/ / lus brjes sems can don bya'o/ /
'bras (84)bu skye ba'i rim pa ni/ / 'khor ba dang ni mya ngan 'das/ / rtog pa gnyis po spangs nas ni/ / gang du dngos po gcig gyur pa/ / zung du 'jug ces de la bshad/ /
The process of the development of the result is as follows: Giving up notions about both saṃsāra and nirvāṇa, there is one entity. That is explained to be “unification.”[74] (721–25)
kun nas nyon mongs dang rnam byang / / don dam nyid du shes nas su/ / gang gis gcig tu spyod gyur pa/ / de yis zung 'jug shes pa'o/ /
Those who know that afflictive phenomena and purified phenomena are the ultimate itself experience their unity. They know unification. (726–29)
dngos po rnam bcas kun rtog dang / / dngos po med par rtog pa dang / / gzung ba dang ni 'dzin pa zhes/ / rnam gnyis blo ni yod min gyi/ /
What are called thoughts with manifestations, those involving entities, thoughts involving nonentities, percepts, and perceivers are a mind [with] two manifestations that does not exist.
gang du mi phyed blo yod pa/ / de ni zung 'jug ces byar bshad/ /
However, there is mind that does not delineate existence and nonexistence. That is explained to be unification. (730–35)
bskyed pa'i rim pa 'di gcig yin/ / gzhan yang rdzogs pa'i rim pa dag / gnyis po gang du gcig gyur pa/ / de ni zung du 'jug par bshad/ /
The generation process is one. The other is the process of perfection. Both become one. That is explained as unification. (736–39)
ril bor 'dzin dang rjes gzhig dang / / 'jug dang de bzhin gnas pa dang / / de nas gang du ldang gyur pa/ / mnyam gyur zung du 'jug pa'o/ /
Grasping the whole, subsequent destruction, entering, abiding, and arising from that bring equality: unification. (740–43)
de nyid shes pa'i rim shes nas/ / bdag byin rlabs dang 'od gsal ba/ / de nyid la ni 'dus pa gang / / zung du 'jug pa'i rim pa'o/ /
Through knowing the process of recognizing thusness, combining self-blessing and luminosity in suchness is the process of unification. (744–47)
chags dang chags bral las grol zhing / / mchog tu dga' ba'i lus ba ldan/ / 'khor ba srid du gnas byed pa/ / zung du 'jug par bsgom pa'o/ /
Free from passion and passionlessness, and with a body of supreme joy, remain in saṃsāric existence and cultivate unification. (748–51)
thabs dang shes rab snyoms 'jug pas/ / thams cad bsdus nas shes gyur pa/ / rnal 'byor chen po gang du gnas/ / de ni zung du 'jug par 'gyur/ /
Uniting method and prajñā gathers everything and brings knowledge. Rest in the great yoga. That becomes unification. (752–55)
stong nyid snying rje gcig pa ni/ / shes nas gang du spyod gyur pa/ / zung 'jug ces byar bshad pa ste/ / rim 'di sangs rgyas spyod yul lo/ /
Knowing the unity of emptiness and compassion, whatever conduct occurs is explained to be unification. This stage is the province of buddhas. (756–59)
gang du lhag mar bcas pa dang / / de bzhin lhag ma med pa zhes/ / 'di lta'i rtog pa med gyur na/ / de ni zung du 'jug pa'o/ /
There is what is called with remainder and without remainder. When there is no such conceptuality, that is unification. (760–63)
gang du gang zag bdag med pa/ / chos la bdag med pa dag gi / rtog pa gnyis las rnam grol ba/ / zung du 'jug ces de la bshad/ /
Being free from the concepts of a lack of self of persons and the lack of self-entity of phenomena is explained to be unification. (764–67)
rtag dang chad pa'i blo dang ni/ / gang zhig spangs nas rab gnas pa'i/ / zung (85) du 'jug pa'i rim pa ni/ / de nyid shes na mkhas pa yin/ /
Once the mind of permanence and annihilation is given up entirely {85} and you know the process of unification that fully abides, you are wise. (768–71)
kun rdzob dang ni don dam dag / so so 'char ni shes nas su/ / gang du yang dag nges gyur pa/ / zung du 'jug ces de la bshad/ /
Knowing the arising of the conventional and the ultimate individually yields true certainty.[75] That is explained to be unification. (772–75)
dran dang dran min las grol zhing / / rtags 'byung ba yi mtshan nyid can/ / rnal 'byor pa ni 'di bzhin spyod/ / zung 'jug rim pa gnas pa'o/ /
Free from being mindful and not mindful, with the authenticity that arises from signs, yogins and yoginīs thus train. They abide in the process of unification. (776–79)
gzugs phra reg na yang ba dang / / khyab dang yang dag thob pa dang / / rab tu snang dang brtan pa dang / / dbang sgyur 'dod dgur sgyur ba ste/ / dbang phyug brgyad ces de la bshad/ /

Having a subtle physical body, being light to the touch, being pervasive, having perfect attainments, [the ability] to illuminate, having stability, dominance, and [the ability] to fulfill wishes are explained to be the eight types of might. (780–84)
drug ni lam yin gnyis po ni/ / gzhan don shugs las 'byung ba yin/ /
Six are the path and two arise naturally to benefit others. (785–86)
gnyid log pa dang sad pa ste/ / gnas skabs gnyis po spangs pa ni/ / gnyid log pa dang rnam bral ba / zung 'jug yin bar ston pas gsungs/ /
The relinquishment of the two states, sleep and being awake, is taught by the Teacher to be unification without sleep or its absence. (787–90)
bya ba dang ni byed pa dag / mi phyed pa yi ngo bo nyid/ / gnas nas rnal 'byor pas shes pa/ / zung du 'jug pa de bshad do/ /
Resting in the essential nature, not divided into action and actor, yogins and yoginīs recognize that. It is explained to be unification. (791–94)
mnyam par bzhag dang ma bzhag dang / / gang la 'di dag thams cad med/ / dngos dang dngos med rnam spangs pa/ / rnal 'byor pa ni zung 'jug gnas/ /
Resting in equipoise and not resting in equipoise— there is none of that anywhere. Having given up entities and nonentities, yogins and yoginīs abide in unification. (795–98)
sku dang gsung gi dbang phyug dang / / thugs dang rdzul 'phrul kun 'gro gnas/ / ci 'dod skyed dang yon tan rgyan/ / 'di ni 'bras bu'i dbang phyug brgyad/ /

The might of body and speech, of mind, miraculous powers, being omnipresent, providing all that is desired, and being adorned with excellent qualities are the eight types of might of the result. (799–802)
sems can dang po'i las can la/ / rim gyis pa 'di bstan par bya/ /
Sentient beings with beginners’ karma should be taught as the gradual type. (803–4)
dang po nyon mongs 'dul ba ni/ khams kyis rab tu dbye bar bya/ / phung po'i zhig ral bsgom par bya/ /
First, for taming the mental afflictions, classify the dhātus. Meditate on the destruction of the skandhas.[76] (805–7)
bskyed rim gzhung las shes par bya/ /
Learn the generation process from treatises.[77] (808)
ngag dben pa dang rlung sgom pa/ / bla ma'i zhal las shes par bya/ /
Learn how to cultivate the isolation of speech and the winds[78] from the guru’s oral instructions. (809–10)
sems la dmigs pa'i man ngag ni/ / bde ba chen po'i man ngag go / bla ma'i zhal gyis rtogs par bya/ /
The esoteric instructions for observing the mind are esoteric instructions on great bliss. They should be understood through the guru’s oral instructions. (811–13)
phyag rgya chen po'i man ngag ni/ / man ngag tshig bsdus dag las shes/ / gtum mo 'od gsal sbyang ba la/ /
Learn the esoteric instructions on mahāmudrā from the summary verses of esoteric instructions. Train in caṇḍālī and luminosity. (814–16)
sgyu ma lta bu'i lus bsgom pa/ / slob pa dang ni mi slob gnyis/ /
Cultivating the illusion-like body is twofold: for those in training and those beyond training. {86}
slob pa la yang (86)gnyis yin te/ / mngon par rtogs pa'i rim pa dang / / rang nyid lhag par gnas pa'o/ /
For those in training, it is also twofold: the process of realization and self-consecration. [79] (817–21)
mngon par rtogs pa'i rim pa la/ / gsang ba'i dbang gi dus dag tu/ / me long dri ma med pa la/ / rdo rje sems dpa' legs bris te/ / de yi gzugs brnyan snang dang mtshungs/ /
The process of realization is like the well-drawn image of Vajrasattva appearing reflected in a stainless mirror during the secret abhiṣeka. (822–26)

rang nyid lhag par gnas pa la/ / 'pho dang grong du 'jug pa dang / / rmi lam bar do rnam pa bzhi/ / gong du 'pho ba rnam gsum ste/ / bskyed pa'i rim pa'i tshul dang ni/ / sgyu ma dngos dang 'od gsal lo/ /

Self-consecration is fourfold:[80] entering a body, transference, dream, and bardo. Transference to somewhere higher is threefold:[81] using the mode of the generation process, the actual illusion, and luminosity. (827–32)

bskyed pa'i rim pa'i tshul la ni/ / k+ShuM la sogs pa'i yi ge yis/ / bu ga dag kyang dgag bya ste/ / rang gi sems ni lha yi sku/ / 'ja' tshon lta bur bsgom pa'ang / / yang na hU~M la bsdu bya ste/ / tshangs pa'i bu ga dag tu 'don/ / 'og min gnas su yang dang yang / / rgyun mi 'chad par gnas par bya/ /

The mode of the generation process is as follows: Block your orifices with syllables, such as kṣum. Meditate on your mind as being the form of a deity, like a rainbow, or dissolve it into hūṃ. Send it out through the opening of Brahmā.[82] It should abide continuously, again and again, in the state of Akaniṣṭha. (833–41)
de ltar goms pa brtan gyur na/ / dus kyi rtags rnams shes bya ste/ / 'pho kar shes pa gnas su bskyal/ / de ltar byas pas 'pho bar 'gyur/ /

Stabilize such familiarization, and recognize the signs of timing.[83] At the moment of transference, your consciousness will be escorted to the place. By doing that, transference will occur.[84] (842–45)
sgyu ma dngos kyi 'pho ba ni/ / 'og nas 'byung ba'i rmi lam la/ / goms par bya ste sum cu ni/ / rtsa gsum gnas su 'pho bar bya/ /
The transference of the actual illusion is as follows: Become familiar with dreams, which appear below.[85] Transfer to the place of the Thirty-Three. (846–49)

de ru sngar ni gang bsgoms par/ / goms pas khrid de bsgoms gyur na/ / bde stong skye ba'i gnad yin pas/ / mi rtog ye shes thob nas ni/ / tshe 'di nyid la sangs rgyas nyid/ / thob 'gyur 'di la the tshom med/ / sngags pa'i 'gro sa mchog yin te/ / mtshan nyid pa ni ltung bar 'gyur/ /

Be guided by your familiarization with your previous habituation to that.[86] Once you are familiar with that, it is the vital point that arouses bliss-emptiness.[87] Thus, having attained nonconceptual wisdom, in this very life buddhahood will be achieved—have no doubt.[88] It is the supreme destination for mantrins. [But] it is a downfall for dialecticians. (850–57)

'od gsal ba yi 'phro ba ni/ / 'pho ba'i dus ni shes byas te/ / mi rtog pa la sems gnas nas/ / lus kyi rtsol ba dag gis ni/ / 'od gsal bar ni gzhug bya ste/ / bar dor mya ngan 'da' ba yin/ / bslabs nas 'pho ba de rnams yin/ /

Transference into luminosity is as follows:[89] Know the time to transfer.[90] When your mind rests in nonconceptuality, through adjustments to your body, you enter luminosity, and the bardo is nirvāṇa.[91] Those are the transferences through training. (858–64)
'od gsal ba la sems gnas na/ / slob bzhin pa yi rnal 'byor che/ / ma bslabs par yang 'pho ba yod/ /
When their minds rest in luminosity, great yogins and yoginīs who are in training[92] transfer to beyond training. (865–67)
zung 'jug ting 'dzin la gnas (87) nas/ / slar ni gang la'ang mi slob ste/ / gnyis med rtogs pa mthar phyin pa/ / sku bzhi ro mnyam 'gyur ba'o/ /
After resting in the samādhi of unification, {87} again, without training in anything, you perfect nondual realization and become the equal taste of the four kāyas. (869–71)
de la grong du 'jug pa ni/ / mdun du dmigs pa gsal byas la/ / dbugs dang shes pa 'thon par gtad/ / de la dmigs pa byang pa dang / / dmigs pa je gsal je gsal 'gyur/ /
Entering a body is as follows: Clarify the object in front. Focus on sending out your breath and mind.[93] Do that with the object, and that object will be increasingly vivid.[94] (872–76)
de la yun du goms byas nas/ / rang gi phung po dor bya ste/ / bsod nams can gyi lus blangs nas/ / sems can don ni ma lus bya/ /
When you have become familiarized with that for some time, discard your own skandhas, [body,] and take the body of someone meritorious.[95] Engage for the welfare of all sentient beings. (877–80)
rmi lam la yang rnam lnga ste/ / dran dang sgyu mar shes pa dang / / spyad dang goms par 'khrid pa dang / / gong du 'pho bar shes par bya/ /
There are five points you should know for dreams: being mindful, recognizing that they are illusions, practicing, being guided to habituation,[96] and transferring to somewhere higher. (881–84)
dran pa shes bya'i sgo la ni/ / gnyid ma log pa'i dus su yang / / 'dun pa dag ni mngon btang nas/ /
As for cultivating what is called mindfulness,[97] when you have not yet fallen asleep, set your motivation. (885–87)
log ka ma yi shes pa ni/ / dran pas yang dang yang dgug la/ / dgug pas log re lan re bzhin/ / rab rib sad dus 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
When you’re on the brink of sleep, summon your mindfulness repeatedly.[98] Summoning it, [recognize] the brink [of sleep] each time.[99] Floaters will arise when you awake.[100] (888–91)
de ltar dran pa brtan gyur nas/ / sgyu ma dag tu shes bya ste/ / ma log pa yi dus su yang / / snang srid sgyu mar shes bya'o/ / sgyu ma dngos ni rmi lam yin/ /

When your mindfulness has been stabilized in that way, recognize [dreams] to be illusions. Even when not asleep, recognize all possible appearances to be illusions. Dreams are the true illusions. (892–96)

sgyu ma lta bur shes bya ste/ / 'di nyid sgyu mar ma shes pas/ / bar do sgyu mar ma shes nas/ / bar do'i srid pas mi khegs pas/ / skye ba yang dang yang blangs te/ / khams gsum 'khor bar 'khyams pa yin/ /

If you don’t recognize what are illusion-like[101] to be illusions, you won’t recognize the bardo to be an illusion. If you don’t stop the existence of the bardo, you will take rebirth again and again, wandering in the three realms of saṃsāra. (897–902)
de ltar rmi lam dngos dag la/ / blo ni 'jug tu ma btub na/ / sngon du 'gro ba dag bya ste/ /
If your mind is unable to engage the actual dream in that way, do the preliminaries. (903–5)
ma log pa yi dus su yang / / snang srid sgyu mar shes par bya/ /
When you are not asleep, recognize that all the appearances of the world are illusions.[102] (906–7)
bskyed pa'i rim pa'i rtags brtan dang / / 'du 'dzi shin tu nyung ba dang / / sngar gyi goms par khrid pa dang / / mos pa shin tu drags pa dang / / dgug pa'i dus dag shes pa'o/ /

Stabilize the signs of the generation process,[103] minimize your busyness, be guided by your previous habituation,[104] have great conviction, and know the time for summoning [recognition of dreams].[105] (908–12)
gnyid ma log pa'i dus su yang / / dran pa de nyid sgyu ma ru/ / shes bya snyam pa sngon btang la/ / nan tan du ni bsgom par bya/ /
When you are not asleep, that mindfulness[106] first sets up the thought for recognizing [dreams to be] illusions.[107] Cultivate that with application.[108] (913–16)

de ltar du ni goms pa dang / / phan tshun dag tu phyin pa dang / / ngal dub dag ni 'ong ba dang / / 'grangs (88) ltog dag ni 'ong ba dang / / cho 'phrul dag ni ston pa dang / / de la sogs pa'i mtshan ma rnams/ / ma log pa yi dus su yang / / goms par byas pa'i bag chags kyis/ / log ka ma yi dus su ni/ / mtshan mo'i dran pa de rnyed la/ / bag mi tsha bar dpyad par bya/ /

Thus, familiarization,[109] going back and forth,[110] becoming tired,[111] {88} becoming satiated or hungry, displaying miracles— those and all such signs— when you are not asleep[112] and, through the latent tendencies of habituation,[113] even at the brink of sleep, [bring] the attainment of mindfulness at night.[114] Train without any fears.[115] (917–27)

de ltar sgyu mar yang dang yang / / nyin mtshan dag tu bsams nas su/ / sgyu mar shes pa'i mtshan ma ni/ / ya nga ba dang bag mi tsha/ / sprul bsgyur nus pa dam dum 'byung / / de ltar goms pa brtan par bya/ /

By considering, repeatedly, throughout the day and night that [dreams] are illusions, the signs of recognizing them to be illusions are that you will be without fear and anxiety.[116] The ability to emanate and transform will develop a bit.[117] Stabilize your familiarization with that.[118] (928–33)
de ltar brtan par gyur nas ni/ / 'pho ba dag ni bya bar bshad/ /
When that has become stable, it is taught that you should do transference. (934–35)
gnyid ma log pa'i dus su yang / / sems ni gang dgar btang ba dang / / 'gro sar sems ni btang byas nas/ / log ka ma yi dus su yang / / de ring bag chags dran byas te/ /
When you are not asleep, let your mind be as it is.[119] By letting your mind go to various destinations, at the brink of sleep you recollect today’s latent tendencies.[120] (936–40)
de ltar rang gi rig pa yis/ / dpyad cing gang ltar bde bar 'pho/ /
Examine with your own awareness and transfer your awareness as you please.[121] (941–42)
'pho bar brtan par gyur nas ni/ / sgyu mar sbyangs pa'i mtshan nyid kyis/ / sngar gyi goms pa bgyid par bya/ /
log kar yang dang yang du bsgom/ / de ltas rmi lam sbyang dus su/ / dam dum bag re 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
Meditate again and again on the edge of sleep. In that way, when training with dreams, there will arise a few fleeting bits [of your daytime practice].[123] (946–48)
de ltas rmi lam sbyong ba la/ / gang yang bzang ngan mi lta ste/ /
In that way, when training with dreams,[124] do not regard anything as good or bad.[125] (949–50)
rtags ma byung bar zin pa yod/ / rang gi rig pas rtogs bya ba/ / ma rtogs pa na 'bad cing brtag / rtsol ba dag ni bskyed byas la/ / nyes pa tshar ni gcad par bya/ /

[Even] without the arising of signs, you will have recognition.[126] Reflexive awareness brings realization.[127] If you don’t have realization, exert yourself and examine. Generate effort and eliminate faults.[128] (951–55)
de ltar yang dang yang byas pas/ / mod du zin pa dag kyang yod/ / longs spyod la sogs rgyud sbyangs pas/ / lo yis zin pa dag kyang yod/ / ye ma zin pa dag kyang yod/ /

By doing that repeatedly, you may have recognition immediately. By training your mindstream in the saṃbhoga and the others,[*17][129] you may have recognition in a year. There are some who will never have recognition.[130] (956–60)
de ltar yang dang yang goms pas/ / rmi lam byin gyis rlob pa yin/ / de yis bar do rlob par 'gyur/ /
By familiarizing yourself repeatedly,[131] your dreams will be blessed. That will be training for the bardo too.[132] (961–63)
gong ma'i rmi lam goms pa yis/ / 'chi ga'i shes pa gsal byas te/ / 'chi ga'i rtags rnams tshang ba dang / / sngar goms pa la sems gzhag ste/ / 'od gsal bar ni 'jug par bya/ /

Your previous familiarization with dreams will illuminate your mind at the moment of death. [When] all the signs of death are complete, rest your mind in your previous habituation and enter luminosity.[133]
'chi gar gnyid mi log pa na/ / (89)
The moment of death [will be like] falling asleep.[134] (964–69) {89}
dran pa dag ni sngon btang nas/ / sa bon skye gnas rim khyab pa/ / gzhi dang khang pa nyid dang ni/ / las la sbyor ba rang nus la/ / rang gi ngo bo thig ler bcas/ / bcu gnyis mtha' yi tshig gi don/ /

Set your mindfulness first.[135] There are the seed, place of birth, the gradual pervader,[136] the ground, and the home. Join with the activities, and [manifest] your own potential:[137] your own essence with its bindu.[138] That is the meaning of the phrase “the end of the twelve.”[*18] (970–75)
rang gis rtag tu goms gyur na/ / des ni dngos grub bde ba yis/ / rdo rje 'dzin par rang nyid 'gyur/ /
Anyone who is continuously habituated[139] will, through the bliss of their siddhi,[140] become Vajradhara themself. (976–78)
skye ba snga ma'i lus bor yang / / sngon byung srid pa'i sha gzugs can/ / las kyi rdzu 'phrul shugs dang ldan/ /
You have discarded the body of your previous birth, and yet you have the fleshly form of your previous existence along with the powers of miraculous actions. (979–81)
bar do de yis mig snga ru/ / thabs dang shes rab mthong ba la/ / bla ma dag tu dmigs byas te/ / gsang ba'i dbang ni dran byas nas/ / mig ser zhe sdang kun spangs te/ /
Within that bardo, at this moment, as you see method and wisdom, visualize your guru and recollect the secret abhiṣeka. Abandon jealousy and aversion. (982–86)
bde gsal mi rtog sgom pa'am/ / yang na sngon du gang bsgoms pa'i/ / goms pa khrid de bsgom par bya/ /
Cultivate bliss, clarity, and nonconceptuality. Alternatively, cultivate what you have become familiar with through your previous meditations. (987–89)

dus su dran par gyur nas ni/ / dang po'i srid pa khegs par 'gyur/ / de nas bdun phrag drug gi bar/ / gong ma bzhin du goms byas pas/ / bzhi bcu rtsa dgu 'das pa dang / / 'khor ba'i srid pa khegs pa yin/ /

Once you have recollection, the first existence is stopped. During the next six weeks, you are habituated to your previous [existence]. Forty-nine days pass, and saṃsāric existence is stopped. (990–95)
de ltar sgyu mar gnas pa la/ / 'od gsal ba yis sbyangs byas te/ / 'od gsal bar ni 'jug par 'gyur/ /
In that way, rest in the illusion, and train with luminosity. You will enter luminosity.[141] (996–98)
dpal rdo rje 'chang nyid kyis gsungs pa gtsigs kyi rgya rim pa bdun gyis btab pa rdzogs so// /
This completes the teaching by the glorious Vajradhara that was placed under seven layers of decreed seals.[*19][142]
bla ma til+li pas 'og min gyi gnas nas spyan drangs pa jo bo nA ro pa dang / mar pa chos kyi blo gros kyis bsgyur cing zhus te gtan la phab pa'o/ /
Guru Tilopa brought it from the place of Akaniṣṭha. The lord Nāropa and Marpa Chökyi Lodrö translated, edited, and finalized it.
shu b+haM mastu sarba dza ga taM/ ! /
śubhaṃ mastu sarvajagataṃ[143]
snyan brgyud rdo rje'i tshig rkang
15. Vajra Verses of the Aural Transmission[1]
rgya gar skad du/ kar+Na tan+t+ra badzra pa dA ki nA ma/ bod skad du/ snyan brgyud rdo rje'i tshig rkang zhes bya ba/ /
In the language of India: Karṇatantravajrapadākināma.[16] In the language of Tibet: sNyan brgyud rdo rje’i tshig rkang zhes bya ba.
bcom ldan 'das dpal rdo rje 'chang la phyag 'tshal lo/ ! /
Homage to the bhagavān, glorious Vajradhara.
gdams pa zab mo'i gleng gzhi/ /
The Opening for the Profound Instructions[17]

e ma ho/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi yang dag gsang ba'i mchog / ye shes rgyal po theg pa mchog gi lam/ / tshig tu brjod pa kun dang bral ba'i (90) don/ / theg chen skye med rang sgra 'di skad thos/ / rdo rje 'chang ngas skal ldan don du bshad/ / gus btud nas ni ye shes mkha' 'gro nyon/ ! /

E ma ho. The most sublime of the true secrets of all buddhas— the sovereign of great bliss, the bindu, the supreme path,[18] the state free from verbal expression[*9]—{90} is the self-sound of the unborn Mahāyāna that, thus heard, I, Vajradhara, expound for the benefit of fortunate ones. Having bowed with respect, now listen, Jñānaḍākinī. (1–6)
gdams pa'i sngon 'gro/ /
The Preliminaries for the Instructions
thog mar brgyud pa yid bzhin nor bu/ /
First, the Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Lineage
bslab gsum rgyan ldan nyams myong bla ma'i mchog / dad brtson shes rab snying rje slob ma'o/ / nyes dmigs dran pas tshe 'di'i bya ba btang / ! /

Supreme gurus are adorned with the three trainings and are experienced. Disciples have faith, exertion, prajñā, and compassion. They have cast aside the activities of this life by remembering its shortcomings. (7–9)
dngos gzhi smin byed dbang / /
The Main Part: The Maturing Abhiṣekas
gnyis pa / smin lam yid bzhin nor bu/ /
Second, the Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Maturing Path
thog mar 'khor lo sdom pa la brten nas/ / drug cu rtsa gnyis dkyil 'khor dbang bzhi bskur/ / lha mo bco lnga dbang bzhi brda yis mtshon/ / smin par byas nas

First, relying on Cakrasaṃvara, the four abhiṣekas of the maṇḍala of the sixty-two are bestowed. The four abhiṣekas of the fifteen goddesses are revealed through symbols.[19] Having been matured, (10–13a)
gsum pa grol lam yid bzhin nor bu/
Third, the Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Liberating Path
thabs shes zung du sbrel/ ! /
join method and prajñā in union. (13b)
bum dbang lam bskyed rim/ /
The Path of the Vase Abhiṣeka: The Generation Processes
rgyal po blon sogs rnal 'byor bdun la 'bad/ ces pa
Exert yourself in the sovereigns, the ministers, and the seven yogas.[*10][20]

rgyal po chos nyid mi 'gyur ba'i gdams ngag yab yum gyi bskyed rim rgyas 'bring bsdus pa/ / blon po rigs gsum las byed (1) bla ma'i rnal 'byor/ (2) dbang blang ba/ (3) rdor sems bsgom bzlas/ dam pa phrin las mthun sbyor/ (1) zas (2) gos (3) gnyid (4) bskong ba (5) smra brjod (6) khrus (7) gtor ma'o/ /

[*10] Interlinear note: The sovereigns, the instructions on unchanging dharmatā, are the extensive, intermediate, and abbreviated generation processes of the male and female consorts. The ministers, three types of actions, are (1) guru yoga, (2) receiving abhiṣekas, and (3) the meditation and recitations of Vajrasattva. The people, the conducive activities, are (1) eating, (2) dressing, (3) sleeping, (4) circumambulating, (5) talking, (6) bathing, and (7) offering tormas.
bsre ba ro snyoms dam tshig gsum la sbyar/ /ces pa
Apply yourself to mixing, equal taste, and the three samayas.[*11] (14–15)

bskyed rim sogs snang ba gdod nas skye med stong pa'i rtsal du shes pas bsre ba/ de ltar shes nas bsgom pa ro snyoms/ 1 sku bum dbang / 2 gsung gsang dbang / 3 thugs sher dbang / bzhi pa'i dam tshig go ! /

[*11] Interlinear note: By recognizing that appearances (such as that of the generation process) are, from the beginning, the expressive power of unborn emptiness, mixing occurs. To meditate with that recognition is equal taste. The [three] samayas are those of (1) the vase abhiṣeka, body; (2) the secret abhiṣeka, speech; and (3) the prajñā abhiṣeka, mind, and the fourth.
gsang dbang lam steng sgo rnam grol chos drug /
The Path of the Secret Abhiṣeka: Liberation through the Upper Door Using the Six Dharmas

gtum mo bde drod rang 'bar lam gyi gzhung / / lus gnad bdun ldan lha sku'i stong ra gnad/ / d+hU tI la la ra sa 'khor lo bzhi/ / a haM 'bar 'dzag srog rtsol thur sel gcud/ / rdo rje bzlas pa rtsa ba'i rlung lnga bsgom/ /

Caṇḍālī—self-blazing bliss and heat—is the main highway of the path. Adopt the seven vital points of body and the vital point of the empty enclosure of the deity’s form. There are the avadhūti, lalanā, rasanā, and four cakras. A and haṃ blaze and drip with prāṇāyāma and work the downward-expelling wind. Do the vajra repetition and meditate on the five root winds. (16–20)

zin dang brtan nas shes rab snyoms par 'jug / dga' bzhi goms pas rtsa rlung thig le 'dres/ / d+hU tIr rlung sems tshud pas mi rtog pa/ / nyon mongs rang zhi bde gsal rgyun mi 'chad/ / ngo bo mthong nas chos sku'i ngang du gnas/ ! /

Having held and stabilized those, unite with prajñā.[21] Through familiarization with the four joys, the channels, winds, and bindus merge. Wind-mind entering the avadhūti [brings] nonconceptuality.[22] Mental afflictions self-pacify, bliss and clarity are unbroken. Seeing the essence, you abide in the dharmakāya. (21–25)

bogs 'don sgyu lus chos brgyad rang grol la/ / 'khor 'das thams cad (91) sgyu mar shes byas te/ / sgyu ma'ang 'ja' tshon chu zla lta bu'o/ / da ltar snang ba dngos po'i chos rnams ni/ / bden cing rtag na 'gyur bar ga la rigs/ /

The enhancement practice of illusory forms self-liberates the eight worldly values. {91} Recognize that all of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa is an illusion. Illusions are like rainbows and the moon reflected in water. If what appears now—phenomena that are entities— were real and permanent, how could they change? (26–30)

'khrul gzugs yin phyir don la grub pa med/ / gzugs rnams snang stong sgra rnams brag car ltos/ / gnyis 'dzin zhig pas chags sdang kun dang bral/ / de ltar shes pas sna tshogs zhen med spyod/ / 'ja' lus chos sku thob par 'gyur ro kye/ ! /

Since they are delusive forms, they do not exist in fact. Regard forms as appearance-emptiness and sounds as echoes. Once dualistic fixation dissolves, you are without attachment and aversion. Knowing that, engage in varieties without fixation. You will attain a rainbow body, the dharmakāya—kye! (31–35)

mtshan dus rmi lam 'khrul ba rang sangs la/ / sgo gsum 'bad pa dran pa'i lcags kyus gzung / / 'dzin sbyang spel bsgyur sprul cing gegs rnams sel/ / nyi zla zhon dang zhing khams mtha' dag bgrod/ / bzang ngan sgyu ma cir snang rang grol ltos/ / mthar phyin sa bcu non nas don chen thob/ ! /

Dreams at night self-clarify delusion. Strive with your three doors, and using the iron hook of mindfulness, recognize [your dreams]. Recognize, train, increase, transform, emanate, and dispel hindrances. Riding the sun and moon, travel throughout the pure realms. See that all illusions, good and bad, are free in and of themselves. In the end, you will master the ten bhūmis and achieve great benefit. (36–41)
khyad par 4 'od gsal ma rig mun bral la/ / lus gnad thabs ldan ting 'dzin bzhi la sbyor/ ces pa/
In particular, luminosity is freedom from the darkness of ignorance. With the technique of the vital points for body, practice the four samādhis.[*12]

snying gar nyi zla'i steng bla ma yi dam rang sems dbyer med dbus su thig le sngo/ phyogs bzhir phyogs mdog ste 1 thig le lnga/ de gnas bsgyur te 2 rim par sa bon hU~M dang a nu ta ra/ 3 phyag mtshan/ 4 rigs lnga'i sku rnams la rim bzhin sems gzung ba'o/ /

[*12] Interlinear note: [Imagine that] in your heart, on top of a sun and moon, as the inseparability of the guru, yidam, and your own mind, (1) there are five bindus: a blue bindu in the middle and [four bindus] in the four directions with the colors of their direction. Transform them and concentrate sequentially on (2) the seed syllables hūṃ and a nu ta ra, (3) the emblems, and (4) the kāyas of the five families.
thig le gus ldan dug gsum 'dzin med ltos/ / gnyid dang rmi lam rnam rtog bar nas bzung / /
With respect for the bindus, look without clinging at the three poisons. Recognize [luminosity] between sleep and dreams and between thoughts. (42–45)
rim pa bzhi dang nyin mtshan bsre zhing goms/ / gsal stong 'dzin bral lhan skyes ye shes de/ /
Become familiar with it, mixing [recognition] with the fourfold process during the day and night. That connate wisdom—clarity-emptiness, free from grasping[*13]—

rim pa bzhin sems la sbyar na/ sems gsal stong du gnas pa las rtsal shar ba snang ba/ de la rtog dpyod zhugs pa mched pa/ dgag sgrub tu shor ba thob pa/ chags sdang rmongs pa'i rtog pa rags pa nyer thob/ de rnams lugs 'byung du shes/ lugs ldog tu thim pas 'od gsal mngon du 'gyur ba'o/ /

[*13] Interlinear note: A correlation of the [fourfold] process [of illumination, radiance, imminent attainment, and luminosity] with the mind is as follows. The arising of the expressive power from mind resting in clarity-emptiness is illumination. Engaging in discernment and analysis of that is radiance. Slipping into negation and affirmation is attainment. The coarse concepts of attachment, aversion, and confusion are imminent attainment. Recognize their forward sequence. When they dissolve in the reverse sequence, luminosity manifests.
brjod du med pa 'od gsal rgyun mi 'chad/ / mi rtogs sbyang zhing phyag rgya chen por blta/ ! /
is uninterrupted, inexpressible luminosity. Purify nonrealization and behold mahāmudrā. (46–49)

5 'pho ba gser 'gyur ma bsgom sangs rgyas ni/ / 'chi ltas shar tshe dga' zhing zhen pa btang / / sgo dgu bgag la rdzas dang smon lam rgyan/ / hU~M dang rlung sems dbyer med d+hU tIr (92) drangs/ / k+Sha yig bsal la tshangs pa'i lam nas 'phang / / chos sku bla ma rgyal ba'i zhing du 'pho/ ! /

Transference is the transformation into gold, buddhahood without meditation. When the signs of death arise, feel delight and cast aside any fixations.[*14] Block your nine doors, and adorn yourself with substances and aspiration prayers. Bring your wind-mind inseparable from hūṃ into the avadhūti. {92} Remove the syllable kṣa and exit through the path of Brahmā.[23] Transfer to the dharmakāya, to the guru, or to the pure lands of the victors. (50–55)

lhag par 6 grong 'jug sbrul lpags 'dor len ni/ / rlung sems dbang thob bskyed rdzogs brtan pa yis/ / skyon med ro la rnam shes yig 'bru 'phang {dgos pa khyad par can gyi} dus {skyon med pa'i phung po} yul {phung po gsar rnying gnyis ka'i tshangs bug bye ba} rdzas {dang grogs nyams can} sogs gnad shes mngon du gyur/ / the tshom bral ba'i skyes bu gzhan don spyod/ ! /

Moreover, entering a body is the shedding and renewal of a snake’s skin. Having mastery of wind-mind and stabilizing the generation and perfection processes, send your consciousness as a seed syllable into a flawless corpse. Manifest your understanding of the vital points of timing {[The vital point of timing] is when there is a special need}, the object {[The vital point of the object] is a flawless body (phung po)}, and substances {[The vital point of substances] is to open the Brahmā apertures on both the old and new bodies. There is also [the vital point] of experienced friends}.[24] As a being free from doubt, engage for the welfare of others. (56–60)
sher dbang lam 'og sgo bde ba chen po/ /
The Path of the Prajñā Abhiṣeka: Great Bliss through the Lower Door

mkha' 'gro'i gsang lam bde ba chen po ni/ / bcu drug nyer lnga'i bar gyi rig ma ni/ / pad+ma ri dwags dung can la sogs pa/ / phyag rgya mtshan ldan rdo rje rnal 'byor ma/ / skal ldan skyes bu he ru ka lta bu/ /

The secret path of the ḍākinīs is great bliss. Vidyās, from sixteen to twenty-five, who are qualified mudrās—padminīs, mṛgīs, śaṅkhinīs, and the others— are seen as Vajrayoginī and the worthy males as Heruka.[25] (61–65)
gnyis med 'khril sbyor zag bcas zag med rol/ / thig le dbab bzung bzlog dgram gnas su spel/ / bya rgod bcud la seng ge glang chen dang / / rma bya stag mo rus sbal la sogs bya/ /

Join in nondual coupling, relish the defiled and undefiled. Bring bindus down, retain them, reverse them, and take them to where they spread.[26] Twist as a vulture and be a lion, elephant,[27] peacock, tigress, turtle, and so on. (66–69)

dga' ba bzhi gsum bcu gnyis don la blta/ / lhan skyes ye shes rang bzhin dbyer med ston/ / snang srid thams cad zag med bde bar 'char/ / gsang dbang phyag rgya bdud rtsi ril bu'i phyir/ / thig le bcu drug phyed phyed bzhi cha sbyin/ / bzhi gsum 'khor lo dag la dgram par bya/ /

Behold twelve joys in three [sets of] four.[*18] Display inseparability with the nature of connate wisdom, and all possible appearances manifest as undefiled bliss. For the sake of a secret abhiṣeka, a mudrā, or amṛta pills, give a fourth, half of half, of the sixteen bindus, and spread three-fourths to the cakras. (70–75)
bag med 'dod sred gzhan dbang chang gis myos/ / don la nyams shing slar yang ngan song ltung / / des na rdo rje'i lus la gnad du bsnun/ / tshe 'dir sangs rgyas ster bar the tshom med/ ! /

Those drunk on the alcohol of being influenced by careless cravings miss the point[*19] and again fall to negative states. Therefore, penetrate the vital points of the vajra body and have no doubts that awakening will be conferred in this lifetime. (76–79)
dbang bzhi pa'i lam phyag rgya chen po ye shes gsal byed/ /
The Path of the Fourth Abhiṣeka: Mahāmudrā, the Illumination of Wisdom

phyag rgya chen po ye shes gsal byed ni/ / sgo gsum g.yo med sgo lnga har dangs gzhag / bltas pas mthong med sems kyi mtshan nyid ltos/ / dmigs su med pas ma bcos rang sor gzhag / gzhan du ma tshol ngo bo rtogs par gyis/ /

Mahāmudrā is the illumination of wisdom.[*20] With your three doors unmoving, your five doors remain in immediate brilliance.[28] Looking, there is nothing to see: behold the characteristic of mind. Since there is nothing to be observed, let it be uncontrived on the spot. Don’t search elsewhere: realize its essence. (80–84)
gzhi nas ma bcos ye nas lhun grub la/ / tha mal rang lugs chen por bzhag pa na/ / 'pho 'gyur med pa nam mkha'i klongs yangs su/ / (93)skye shi med pa chos sku'i lus mthong 'gyur/ /

When what is uncontrived in its ground and innately present from the outset is left in its great ordinary natural condition, then, in the open expanse of unchanging space, {93} you will see the body of the unborn, undying dharmakāya.[29] (85–88)
phyi rol yul sems chos rnams ji snyed pa/ / rang sems yin phyir gzhan na grub pa med/ / 'khrul rtog gnyis 'dzin sna tshogs gang shar rnams/ / cir snang gzhi med rang byung rang brlag ltos/ /

However many phenomena there are, appearing as external objects,[30] since they are your own mind, they don’t exist as anything else. Whatever arises—deluded thoughts and various dualistic perceptions— and however it appears, see that it is without ground, self-arising, self-purifying.[31] (89–92)
sems nyid skye med stong pa chos kyi sku/ / 'gag med gsal dangs gang shar sprul pa'i sku/ / gnas med bde chen zung 'jug longs spyod rdzogs/ /
Mind-itself, unborn and empty, is the dharmakāya. Whatever arises, unceasing clear brilliance, is the nirmāṇakāya. Unification, nonabiding great bliss, is the saṃbhogakāya.[*21] (93–95)
phyag ni gnyis med ye shes ngo yis zin/ / rgya ni 'khor ba'i mdud pa bral bas bde/ / chen po zung 'jug sgron me bltams pa las/ / gzhan gyis ma yin rang grol chos sku'o/ /

Mudrā (phyag) is the identification of nondual wisdom. Mudrā (rgya) is bliss since the knots of saṃsāra are broken. Mahā (chen po) is, born from the lamp of unification, the dharmakāya, free in and of itself—not by anything else.[*22][32] (96–99)

sgrib gnyis rang dag gzung 'dzin mtha' dang bral/ / 'du shes blo dang 'khor 'das chos rnams zad/ / mkhyen tshad yon tan ji snyed rang la rdzogs/ / bsam brjod blo 'das sangs rgyas rang 'khrungs yin/ ! /

The two obscurations are pure in themselves, free from the extremes of percepts and perceivers. The discriminating mind and the phenomena of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa are exhausted. The expanse of knowledge and excellent qualities are complete within yourself. Buddhahood beyond thought, expression, and mind is self-born. (100–103)
lam blo nas gcod par bar do ngo sprod kyi gdams ngag /
Arriving at the End of the Path through Recollection: The Instructions Pointing Out the Bardos
