bar do ngo sprod yang dag zab don bstan/ / skye shi rmi lam sred pa'i bar do gcod/ /
The introduction to the bardos shows the true, profound state and cuts off the bardos of birth-to-death, dreams, and becoming.[*23][33] (104–5)
bltar med bltas pas mthong med mthong ba'i mchog / rang rig gsal stong mi rtog sgrib g.yogs bral/ / bde chen chos dbyings ye shes rnam par dag / rang bzhin dbyer med sku gsum rang shar ltos/ /

By looking at what cannot be looked at, not seeing is the supreme seeing. It is reflexive awareness, clarity, emptiness, nonconceptual, free from obscurations: great bliss, the pure wisdom of the dharmadhātu. Behold its nature: the self-arising inseparable three kāyas.[*24] (106–9)
ma rtogs lus ldan bar do rnam gsum la/ / bskyed rim sgyu lus 'od gsal chos skur 'dre/ /
Corporeal beings without realization should mix the generation process, illusory forms, and dharmakāya-luminosity with the three bardos.[*25] (110–11)

sa chu me rlung 'byung ba rim gyis thim/ / brgyad cu 'gags nas snang ba gsum 'das te/ / dkar dmar sems gsum chu skyes nang du 'joms/ / 'od gsal ngos 'dzin ma bu dbyer med 'dre/ / chos skur sangs rgyas dbang po yang rab bo/ /

The elements of earth, water, fire, and wind dissolve sequentially. Once the eighty [intrinsic thoughts] cease and the three illuminations have passed, the triad of white, red, and mind coalesce within the water-born [lotus]. Recognize luminosity, and mother and child mix inseparably. Buddhahood as the dharmakāya is for those of highest abilities. (112–16)

de ma zin na rlung gsum rkyen gyis 'ching / / 'bring ba chu la nya ltar longs skur 'gyur/ / rtsa {ba'i rlung} lnga {'od} zer lnga dug gsum las kyi dbang / / chags sdang gnyis kyis mngal du 'jug 'gyur bas/ / bsre ba lnga ldan lam khyer phyag rgya bzhi/ /

If you don’t recognize that, you will be bound by the conditions of the three winds.[*26] Those of intermediate abilities become the saṃbhogakāya, like a fish leaping from water. Through the five roots {[the five root] winds}, the five rays {[the five] lights}, the three poisons, the forces of karma,[34] and both attachment and aversion, you will enter a womb. Having [trained in] the five mixings, you integrate [afflictions] into the path using the four mudrās.[*29][35] (117–21) {94}

zhes pas 'dod chags gtum mo/ / (94) zhe sdang sgyu lus/ gti mug 'od gsal/ nga rgyal bskyed rim/ phrag dog dag snang dang bsre ba lnga/ dam rgya thun mong yid bzhin nor bu/ chos rgya steng sgo/ las rgya 'og sgo/ phyag chen ye shes gsal byed de dbang bzhi'i lam mo/ /

[*29] Interlinear note: The five mixings are to mix desire with caṇḍālī, aggression with illusory body, bewilderment with luminosity, pride with the generation process, and jealousy with sacred outlook (dag snang). The paths of the four abhiṣekas are that the samayamudrā is part of the Shared Wish-Fulfilling Gems, dharmamudrā relates to the upper door, karmamudrā relates to the lower door, and mahāmudrā illuminates wisdom.
sngar sbyangs ldan pas bar do rang grol 'gyur/ / tha ma chags sdang grol nas sprul sku thob/ ! /
Those with previous training are self-liberated in the bardo. Those of normal abilities achieve the nirmāṇakāya upon release from attachment and aversion. (122–23)
gdams pa spyi'i gegs sel bogs 'don/ /
Dispelling Hindrances and Enhancement: Universal Instructions
gdams pa spyi la gegs bsal {bar chad kyi} ngos nyid bzung / {zhing sel ba/}
There are universal instructions for dispelling hindrances and identifying māras {[Identify māras,] which are obstacles, and dispel them}.[36]
rtsa ba drug la yan lag so dgu yi/ rdo rje lus kyi 'khrul 'khor gnad du bsnun/ /
Penetrate the vital points [with] the trulkhors for the vajra body: the six roots and the thirty-nine branches.[*31]

{zhes pa'i rtsa ba drug ni/ sing ge bsgyings/ glang chen 'gyings/ rma bya 'phur/ stag mo sgyugs/ ru sbal bskum/ bya rog 'phur ba'i 'khrul 'khor ro/ / yan lag so dgu ni/ rgyal mtshan 'khrud ces yan lag bzhi 'khrud pa ltar byas te lus la byugs pa sogs so/ /}

{[*31] Interlinear note: The six roots are the trulkhors of the pose of a lion (seng ge bsgyings), pose of an elephant (glang chen ’gyings), soaring peacock (rma bya ’phur), vomiting tigress (stag mo sgyug pa), contractions of a tortoise (ru sbal bskum), and soaring crow (bya rog ’phur ba). The thirty-nine branches include the four branches called washing the victory banner (rgyal mtshan ’khrud), which are performed like washing: the body is rubbed and so forth.}
bya spyod thams cad tshogs su bsgyur bar bya/ !
Transform all activities into accumulations. (124–27)
'bras bu ji ltar thob tshul/ /
How the Result Is Attained
go rim ma nor nyams su blangs gyur na/ / skad cig bzhi la dga' ba gsum ston te/ / dwangs ma yas byon 'gyu ba mas brtan pa/ / rtsa mdud rim pas grol nas d+hU tIr 'gyur/ /

If you practice the sequence flawlessly, the three joys are revealed in the four moments. The quintessence comes from above and is stabilized through its ascension, immutable.[37] The channel knots are released sequentially and become the avadhūti.
nyi khri chig stong drug brgya rtsa ba lnga/ / rlung dang nyon mongs 'gags nas ye shes 'gyur/ /
Once the winds and mental afflictions— the twenty-one thousand six hundred and the five roots—cease, they become wisdom.
gnas dang nyi gnas nyi shu bzhi la sogs/ / pUl+li ma ru yan chad gang bar 'gyur/ /
The twenty-four abodes, nearby abodes, and so on are full up to Pullīramalaya.[*32]
sprul sku longs spyod rdzogs pa'i zhal ston cing / / mngon shes yon tan brgyad dang ther 'bum thob/ / dus 'dir sa lam rim par bgrod byed de/ / rdo rje 'dzin pa'i go 'phang thob par 'gyur/ !

The faces of the nirmāṇakāya and saṃbhogakāya are revealed, and you attain hundreds of billions of supercognitions and excellent qualities.[38] At this time, having traversed the bhūmis and paths sequentially, you attain the state of Vajradhara. (128–39)
gdams pa bka' rgyas gdab pa/ /
The Command Seal Placed on the Instructions
bcu gsum bar du chig brgyud rgya yis gdab/ / mdo rgyud kun gyi snying po 'di yin pas/ / skal ldan grol phyir gsang ba'i nges don mdzod/ /

The transmission of these verses is placed under a seal for thirteen [generations]. Since this is the heart of all sūtras and tantras, keep it as the secret definitive meaning for the sake of liberating worthy ones. (140–42)

ces ye shes mkha' 'gro ma la gdams pa/ / snyan brgyud rdo rje'i tshig rkang rdzogs so/ / mkhas pa nA ro paN chen gyi zhal snga dang / lo tsA ba mar pa chos kyi blo gros kyis puSh+pa ha ri'i gnas chen tu bsgyur cing gtan la phab pa'o/ / (95)

This completes the Vajra Verses of the Aural Transmission, the instructions given to the Jñānaḍākinī. The scholar Nāropa Mahāpaṇḍita and the lotsāwa Marpa Chökyi Lodrö translated and finalized this in the great sacred place of Puṣpahari.[*33] {95}

'di ni rje btsun mi la'i thugs bcud bde mchog snyan brgyud du grags pas rgyas 'bring bsdus gsum las/ / rgyas pa ras chung snyan brgyud du grags pa'i gdams ngag gi rtsa ba yin cing / snyan brgyud 'dzin pa'i dam pa snga phyir byon pa rnams kyis spyi don/ sa bcad/ 'grel pa/ khrid yig sogs rgya cher mdzad snang ngo / /

[*33] Interlinear note: Among the extensive, intermediate, and abbreviated [teachings] that are the heart-elixir of Jetsun Milarepa, which are known as the Saṃvara Aural Transmission, this is the root of the extensive instructions that are known as the Rechung Aural Transmission. Earlier and later holy beings who hold the Aural Transmission have written extensive general topics, topical outlines, commentaries, instruction manuals, and so forth.
grub chen na ro pa'i gdams ngag chos drug skor gyi bka' dpe tshigs su bcad pa bzhugs so/ /
16. Authoritative Texts in Verse. Mahāsiddha Nāropa’s Cycle on the Six Dharmas[*1][1]
{zur mang snyan brgyud}
[*1] Interlinear note: This is part of the Zurmang Aural Transmission.
dpal rdo rje sems dpa' la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the glorious Vajrasattva.
rim gyis pa dang gcig car ba khyad par
[The Differences Between the Gradual and Instantaneous Types] (16.1)[7]
rim gyis pa dang gcig car ba/ / rim gyis pa yi sman chen 'di/ / gcig car ba yi dug chen yin/ / gcig car ba yi sman chen de/ / rim gyis pa yi dug tu 'gyur/ /

There are the gradual type and the instantaneous type. A powerful medicine for the gradual type is a strong poison for the instantaneous type. A powerful medicine for the instantaneous type is a strong poison for the gradual type. (1–5)
des na sbyangs pa'i 'phro can la/ / gcig car pa ni bstan par bya/ / sems can dang po'i las can la/ / rim gyis pa ni bstan par bya/ /
Those possessing the continuity of training should be taught as the instantaneous type. Sentient beings with beginners’ karma should be taught as the gradual type. (6–9)
dang po'i nyon mongs 'dul ba ni/ / khams kyis rab tu dbye bar bya/ / phung po gzhig grol bsgom par bya/ / bskyed rim gzhung la sbyar bar bya/ /

First, for taming the mental afflictions, classify the dhātus. Meditate on the disintegration and liberating of the skandhas,[8] and apply yourself to the generation processes in the treatises.[9] (10–13)
ngag dben rlung ni bsgom pa'i thabs/ / bla ma'i zhal las shes par bya/ / phyag rgya chen po'i man ngag ni/ / man ngag tshig bsdus dag las shes/ /

Learn the methods for cultivating the winds, isolation of speech,[10] from the guru’s oral instructions.[11] Learn the esoteric instructions on mahāmudrā from the summary verses of esoteric instructions. (14–17)
sgyu ma lta bu'i lus bsgoms pa/ / slob pa dang ni mi slob gnyis/ / slob pa la yang rnam gnyis te/ / mngon par rtogs pa'i rim pa dang / / rang gis lhag par gnas pa'o/ /

Cultivating the illusion-like body is twofold: for those in training and those beyond training. For those in training, it is also twofold: the process of realization and self-consecration.[12] (18–22)

mngon par rtogs pa'i rim pa la/ / gsang ba'i dbang gi dus dag tu/ / me long dri ma med pa la/ / rdo rje sems dpa' legs bris te/ / de yi gzugs brnyan snang dang mtshungs/ / zhes bya ba sgyu ma'i dpe bcu gnyis la sogs kyis rtogs par bya'o/ /

The process of realization is like the well-drawn image of Vajrasattva appearing reflected in a stainless mirror during the secret abhiṣeka.[13] As is said, realization [occurs] by means of the twelve examples of illusion. (23–28)
da ni lhag par gnas pa la/ / grong du 'jug dang 'pho ba dang / / rmi lam bar do rnam pa bzhi/ /
Now, the consecration is fourfold:[14] entering a body, transference, dream, and bardo. (29–31)
de la grong du 'jug pa ni/ / mdun du dmigs pa gsal byas la/ / dbugs dang sems ni ma yengs par/ / gtad nas yun tu goms byas na/ / shes pa byang nas je gsal 'gyur/ /

Entering a body is as follows: Clarify the object in front. Having focused with undistracted breath and mind, when you have become familiarized for some time, having trained your mind, clarity will increase.[15] (32–36) {96}
de la yun (96)du goms byas na/ / rang gi phung po dor byas nas/ / bsod nams can gyi lus blangs te/ / sems can don ni ma lus byas/ /
When you have become familiarized with that for some time, discard your own skandhas, [body,] and take the body of someone meritorious. Engage for the welfare of all sentient beings. (37–40)
grong du 'pho ba rnam gsum ste/ / bskyed pa'i rim pa'i tshul dang ni/ / sgyu ma dngos dang 'od gsal lo/ /
bskyed pa'i rim pa'i tshul la ni/ / k+ShuM la sogs pa'i yi ge yis/ / bu ga dag kyang dgag byas te/ / rang gi sems ni lha yi sku/ / 'ja' tshon lta bur bsgom pa'am/ / yang na hU~M la bsdu bya ste/ /
The mode of the generation process is as follows: Block your orifices with syllables, such as kṣum. Meditate on your mind as being the form of a deity, like a rainbow, or dissolve it into hūṃ.
tshangs pa'i bu ga nas bton te/ / 'og min gnas su yang dang yang / / rgyun mi 'chad par gnas par bya/ /
Send it out through the opening of Brahmā. It should abide continuously, again and again, in the state of Akaniṣṭha. (44–52)
de ltar goms pa brtan gyur nas/ / dus dang rtags rnams shes bya ste/ / 'pho kar shes pa gnas su bskyal/ / de ltar byas pas thob par 'gyur/ /

Stabilize such familiarization, and recognize the timing and the signs. At the moment of transference, your consciousness will be escorted to the place. By doing that, there will be achievement.[17] (53–56)
sgyu ma dngos kyi 'pho ba ni/ / 'og nas 'byung ba'i rmi lam la/ / goms par bya ste sum cu ni/ / rtsa gsum gnas su 'pho bya ste/ /
The transference of the actual illusion is as follows: Become familiar with dreams, which appear below.[18] Transfer to the place of the Thirty-Three. (57–60)

de ru sngar du gang goms pa'i/ / goms pas khrid de goms gyur na/ / bde ba skyed pa'i gnas yin pas/ / mi rtog ye shes thob nas ni/ / tshe 'di nyid la sangs rgyas na/ / 'thab 'gyur 'di la the tshom med/ / sngags pa'i 'gro sa mchog yin no/ /

Be guided by your familiarization with your previous habituation to that.[19] Once you are familiar with that, it is the place that arouses bliss.[20] Thus, having attained nonconceptual wisdom, in this very life buddhahood will be achieved—have no doubt.[21] It is the supreme destination for mantrins.
mtshan nyid pa ni ltung bar 'gyur/ /
[But] it is a downfall for dialecticians. (61–68)
'od gsal bar ni 'pho ba la/ / 'chi ba'i dus ni shes byas la/ / me tog pa la sems gnas na/ / lus kyi rtsol ba dag gis ni/ / 'od gsal bar ni 'jug pa ste/ / bar dor mya ngan 'das pa yin/ /

Transference into luminosity is as follows: Know the time of death. When your mind rests in nonconceptuality,[22] through adjustments to your body, you enter luminosity, and the bardo is nirvāṇa. (69–74)
bslab nas 'pho ba de rnams yin/ / ma bslabs par yang 'pho ba yod// / ! /
Those are the transferences through training.[23] There is also transference to beyond training. (75–76) ithi
gtum mo'i bka' dpe'o/ /
Authoritative Text on Caḍṇālī (16.2)[24]
bla ma grub thob rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ / bla ma chen po nA ro pas/ / bde mchog 'khor lo'i gsang sngags ni/ / 'bum phrag bdun ni bzlas pa yis/ / sa rnams g.yos shing lung bstan thob/ /
Homage to the siddha-gurus. The great guru Nāropa recited seven hundred thousand times[25] the secret mantra of Cakrasaṃvara. The earth trembled, and he received a prophecy. (2.1–2.4)
shar phyogs ngos kyi te lo pa'i/ / zhal sngar gdams ngag mnos pa ni/ / dngos po'i (97) gnas lugs lam dang ni/ / 'bras bu skye ba'i rim pa'o/ /
The easterner Tilopa[26] orally bestowed the following instructions: {97} There are the abiding state of entities, the path, and the process that gives rise to the result. (2.5–2.8)
de la dngos po'i gnas lugs ni/ / lus ni byang chub rnam lnga dang / / rtsa dang byang chub sems dang ni/ / mi gtsang rdzas dang rnam rtog gis/ / lus kyi chos ni gnas pa yin/ /
Within those, the abiding nature of entities includes the body: the five awakenings, the channels, bodhicitta, unclean substances, and thoughts. Those are the phenomena of the body. (2.9–2.13)
de la gnad ni rnam pa gsum/ / lus dang yul dang dbang po gsum/ /
Its vital points are three: the body, objects, and the faculties.[27] (2.14–2.15)
de la lus kyi gnad bshad pa/ / rin chen rtsar la brgyus pa ltar/ / shin tu bsrang la dgugs par byed/ / li ri bzhin tu khong bsgrim bya/ / rgya mdud lta bu'i tshul du gnas/ /

Now I will explain the vital points for the body. Like jewels strung on a reed,[28] be very straight and [then] bend. Tighten internally as if [making a rope of] liri,[*5] and sit in the knot-like position.
'phel ka shin tu bskyed par bya/ / mnyam bzhag rgya yis btsir bya zhing / / re'u mig ltar ni bsnol bar bya/ /
Pull up to your full potential. Press with the mudrā of equipoise.[29] Cross [your legs] like lattice. (2.16–2.23)
rngub dang dgang dang gzhil ba dang / / mda' ltar 'phang dang rnam bzhi'o/ / sbyor ba bzhi ldan ma shes na/ / yon tan skyon du 'gyur ba'i nyen/ /
If you do not know the four yogic techniques— inhaling, filling, dispersing, and releasing like an arrow— there is the danger that good qualities will become problems.
de ni lus kyi gnad du gsungs/ /
Those are said to be the vital points for the body. (2.24–2.28)
yul gyi gnad ni rnam gnyis te/ / phyi nang gnyis su bshad par bya/ / phyi yi dkar dmar rnam pa can/ / nang du 'khor lo rnam pa bzhi/ /
The vital points of the objects are explained to be two: external and internal. The external is what manifests as the white and red. Internally, there are the four cakras.
de la thabs lam bgrang mi lang / / de ni yul gyi gnad yin no/ /
There are countless paths of methods. Those are the vital points of the objects. (2.29–2.34)
da ni dus kyi gnad bshad pa/ /
Now I will explain the vital points of time.[*6]
{g.yas g.yon 'pho dus zer ba'ang yod/ mchan/}
[*6] Interlinear note: These are the times when the right and left shift.
gnyid dang rmi lam snyoms 'jug dang / / tha mal dus dang rnam pa bzhi/ /
There are four periods: sleep, dreams, sexual union, and the ordinary state. (2.35–2.37)
de la dus bzhi'i nyams len ni/ / bla ma'i zhal las shes par bya/ / de la dus kyi gnad brtag go /
The practices for the four periods are to be learned from the guru’s oral instructions. With those, the vital points of time are to be considered. (2.38–2.40)
thabs lam khyad par 'phags pa ste/ de las 'bras bu rim gyis 'byung / /
This is the special path of methods,[*7][30] from which results arise gradually.
{bla ma tai lo pas bla ma nA ro pa la gnang des mar pa la gnang des gung thar gi mi la thos pa dga' la gnang //}
[*7] Interlinear note: The guru Tilopa bestowed [these teachings] on Nāropa, who bestowed them on Marpa, who bestowed them on Mila Töpaga of Gungtang.
'bras bu 'byung ba'i 'byung tshul ni/ / lus dang man ngag nyams dang gsum/ / rim pa grangs kyis 'byung bar gsungs/ /
As for the way results arise, it is taught that they develop through numerous processes related to the body, esoteric instructions, and experiences. (2.41–2.45)
dper na seng ge'i 'o ma 'di/ / gser snod dngul snod ma yin pa/ / snod ngan phal la byin pa na/ / dam tshig nyams nas dmyal bar 'gro/ /

For example, if this milk of a lioness[31] is poured into a common, inferior container[32]— one that is neither gold nor silver[33]— samaya will be broken and [the recipients] will go to the hells. (2.46–2.49)
des na gsang ba thub par gyis/ / grub thob brgyud pa'i man ngag 'di/ / rang gis nyams su blang bar bya/ / rgya mtsho'i gting gi rdo (98)ba bzhin/ / kha ru dbyung pha ma yin no// / ! /

Therefore, those who are capable of secrecy must put these esoteric instructions transmitted from the siddhas into practice themselves, {98} being like stones in the depths of the ocean, which don’t rise to the surface.[34] (2.50–2.54) ithi
rmi lam bka' dpe'o/ /
Authoritative Text on Dreams (16.3)[35]
na mo gu ru/ / rmi lam la yang rnam lnga ste/ / dran dang sgyu mar shes pa dang / / sbyang dang goms par bya ba dang / / gong du 'pho bar shes par bya/ /

namo guru There are five points you should know for dreams: being mindful, recognizing that they are illusions,[36] practicing, becoming habituated,[37] and transferring to somewhere higher. (3.1–3.4)

dran pa zhes bya bsgom pa ni/ / gnyid ma log pa'i dus su yang / / 'dun pa dag ni sngon btang ste/ / log ka ma yi shes pa ni/ / dran pas sang yang bskul byas la/ / bskul bar log rer lan re 'dzin/ / rab rib yad yud 'byang bar 'gyur/ /

As for cultivating what is called mindfulness, when you have not yet fallen asleep, set your motivation.[38] When you’re on the brink of sleep, arouse your mindfulness repeatedly.[39] Arousing it, recognize the brink [of sleep] each time.[40] Floaters and fuzziness will occur.[41] (3.5–3.11)
de ltar dran pa brtan gyur na/ / sgyu ma dag tu shes byas te/ / ma log pa yi dus su yang / / snang srid sgyu mar shes bya ste/ / sgyu ma dngos ni rmi lam yin/ /

When your mindfulness has been stabilized in that way, recognize [dreams] to be illusions. Even when not asleep, recognize all possible appearances to be illusions. Dreams are the true illusions. (3.12–3.16)
de nyid sgyu mar ma shes pas/ / bar do sgyu mar mi shes nas/ / bar do'i srid pa mi khegs pas/ / skye ba yang dang yang blang ste/ / khams gsum 'khor bar 'khyams pa yin/ /

If you don’t recognize them to be illusions, you won’t recognize the bardo to be an illusion. If you don’t stop the existence of the bardo, you will take rebirth again and again, wandering in the three realms of saṃsāra. (3.17–3.21)
de ltar rmi lam dngos dag las/ / blo ni 'jug tu ma btub na/ / sngon du 'gro ba dag byas te/ /
If your mind is unable to engage the actual dream in that way, do the preliminaries.[42] (3.22–3.24)
bskyed rim bzlas pa'i rtags dag dang / / 'du 'dzi shin tu nyung ba dang / / sngar gyi goms pa dkri ba dang / / mos pa shin tu drags pa dang / / bskul ba'i dus dag shes pa'o/ /

[Stabilize] the signs of the recitations of the generation process,[43] minimize your busyness, strengthen your previous habituation,[44] have great conviction, and know the time for arousing [recognition of dreams].[45] (3.25–3.29)
gnyid ma log pa'i dus su yang / / dran pa de nyid sgyu ma ru/ / shes bya'i bsam pa sngon btang la/ / nan tan du ni sbyang bar bya/ /
When you are not asleep, that mindfulness first sets up the mental state for recognizing [dreams to be] illusions.[46] Train in that with application.[47] (3.30–3.33)

de ltar du ni bsgom pa dang / / phan tshun dag tu phyin pa dang / / ngal dub dag ni ngal dub med/ / 'grangs ltog dag ni 'ong ba dang / / cho 'phrul dag ni bstan pa dang / / de la sogs pa'i mtshan ma rnams/ / gnyid ma log pa'i dus su yang / / goms par bya yi bar chad kyis/ / log ka ma yi dus su yang / / mtshan ma dran pa de rnyed la/ / bag mi tsha bar spyad par bya/ /

Thus, cultivation, going back and forth,[48] tiredness and the absence of tiredness,[49] becoming satiated or hungry, displaying miracles— those and all such signs— when you are not asleep and, through the latent tendencies of habituation,[50] even at the brink of sleep, [bring] the attainment of mindfulness at night.[51] Train without any fears.[52] (3.34–3.44)

de ltar sgyu mar yang dang yang / / nyin mtshan gtan tu bsam nas kyang / / sgyu mar shes pa'i mtshan ma ni/ / ya mi nga dang bag mi tsha/ / dam dum kem keM ya 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de ltar (99) brtan par goms par bya/ /

By considering, repeatedly, throughout the day and night that [dreams] are illusions, the signs of recognizing them to be illusions are that you will be without fear and anxiety,[53] a bit, in an unsteady way.[54] Habituate yourself to stabilizing that. (3.45–3.50) {99}
de ltar brtan par gyur na ni/ / 'pho ba dag ni bya bar bshad/ /
When that has become stable, it is taught that you should do transference. (3.51–3.52)

gnyid ma log pa'i dus su yang / / rang bzhin gang dgar btang bar bya/ / 'gro sar sems ni btang byas nas/ / log ka ma yi dus su yang / / der ni bag chags dran byas te/ / de ltar rang gi rig pa yis/ / dpyad cing gong ltar rig pa 'pho/ /

When you are not asleep, let your nature be as it is.[55] By letting your mind go to various destinations, at the brink of sleep you will be mindful of the latent tendencies for those.[56] Examine with your own awareness and transfer your awareness as above.[57] (3.53–3.59)
'pho ba brtan par gyur nas ni/ / sgyu ma sbyangs pa'i mtshan nyid kyis/ / sngar gyi goms pa dkri bar bya/ /
da ltar snga ma ci bzhin bsgom/ / log kar yang dang yang du bsgom/ / de ltar rmi lam dus su ni/ / dam dum yad yud 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
Now meditate as you did before.[59] Meditate again and again on the edge of sleep. In that way, during dreams, there will arise a few fleeting moments [of your daytime practice].[60] (3.63–3.66)
gang la'ang bzang ngan mi blta ste/ / rmi lam 'od gsal 'pho nus pa/ / rtags ma byung bar 'phyangs pa yod/ /
Do not regard anything as good or bad, and you will be able to transfer dreams into luminosity.[61] [Even] without the arising of signs, you can train.[62] (3.67–3.69)
rang gis rig pas rtogs byas pa/ / ma rtogs na yang 'bad cing brtags/ / rtsol ba dag ni bskyed byas la/ / shes pa tshar ni bcad par bya/ /
Reflexive awareness brings realization.[63] If you don’t have realization, exert yourself and examine. Generate effort and cut off cognition.[64] (3.70–3.73)
de ltar yang dang yang byas pas/ / mod du zin pa dag kyang yod/ / zla bas zin pa dag kyang yod/ / lo yis zin pa dag kyang yod/ /
By doing that repeatedly, you may have recognition immediately, you may have recognition in a month,[65] or you may have recognition in a year.[66] (3.74–3.77)
yang dang yang du goms byas pas/ / rmi lam byin gyis rlobs pa yin/ / de yis bar do bslang bar 'gyur/ /
By familiarizing yourself repeatedly,[67] your dreams will be blessed. That will occur in the bardo too.[68] (3.78–3.80)
gong ma'i rmi lam goms pa yis/ / 'chi kha'i shes pa gsal byas te/ / 'chi ba'i rtags rnams tshang ba dang / / sngar goms pa la'ang sems bzhag ste/ / 'od gsal ba la 'jug pa'am/ /

Your previous familiarization with dreams will illuminate your mind at the moment of death. [When] all the signs of death are complete, rest your mind in your previous habituation and enter luminosity.[69] (3.81–3.85)
yang na gsal ba la mi 'jug / 'chi kar gnyid ni log pa na/ / dran pa dag ni sngon btang nas/ /
Alternatively, if you do not enter luminosity,[70] the moment of death [will be like] falling asleep. Set your mindfulness first.[71] (3.86–3.88)
sa bon skyes nas rim khyab bo/ / gzhi dang khang pa nyid dag dang / / las dang pha rol sbyor ba dang / / rang lus ngo bo thig le bcas/ / bcu gnyis mtha' yi tshig gi don/ /

There are the seed, place of birth, the gradual pervader,[72] the ground, and the home. Join with the activities, and see your own potential:[73] your essence with its bindu, [within] your body.[74] That is the meaning of the phrase “the end of the twelve.”[*8] (3.89–3.93)
gang gis rtag tu bsgom gyur na/ / de yi dngos grub bde ba yi/ / rdo rje 'dzin pa rang nyid 'gyur/
Anyone who meditates continuously will, through the bliss of their siddhi,[75] become Vajradhara themself. (3.94–3.96)
rdzogs so// // (100)! /
That completes [the text].[76] {100}
'od gsal gyi bka' dpe'o/ /
Authoritative Text on Luminosity (16.4)[77]

nA ro pa'i gdams pa la/ / phung po khams dang skye mched dbang po la/ / shes pa gnyis po 'di ltar bsdus byas pas/ / stong chen 'gyur bas gang zhig gnyid log pa/ / rlung gi shugs kyis rmi lam mthong bar 'gyur/ /

In the instructions of Nāropa, the following is taught. The skandhas, dhātus, āyatanas, faculties, and two cognitive states dissolve accordingly. Great emptiness occurs, and then you sleep. The force of the winds causes you to see dreams. (4.1–4.4)
rmi lam sad pas bye brag gzhan med pas/ / kun tu rtog pas rmi lam phral 'dod pas/ / 'gro ba nyin mtshan nye bar gnyid log cing / / sa sdug gyur pas rab tu rang gnyid log /

Not seeing any differences between dreams and waking, with conceptualization, you wish for the results of dreams. Beings sleep during the day and the night. Because earth is dense, they sleep a long time.[*9][78] (4.5–4.8)

sems dang sems las 'byung ba'i rtog tshogs ni/ / rang grol bde ba chen po'i ting 'dzin no/ / de ni sgyu ma'i dpe yis nye bar mtshon te/ / de bas na sangs rgyas kyi zhing gang+gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed/ / de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad ni sgyu ma lta bu dang / / 'ja' tshon lta bu'i lus ngag ni/ / de nyid bsgoms pas 'thob par 'gyur/ /

The masses of thoughts—mind and mental factors— are the samādhi of great bliss, self-liberated.[79] That is illustrated by the examples of illusions. Thus, the illusion-like and rainbowlike body and speech of all tathāgatas in buddha fields as numerous as sands in the Ganges River are attained by meditating on just that.[80] (4.9–4.15)
ma rig pa dang gis 'gags shing / / 'od gsal ba la 'gro'o/ /
Ignorance ceases naturally and you proceed to luminosity.
phyi nas langs nas rlung gis 'khor bar 'gyur ba ste/ des lus grub nas mig la sogs pa'i dbang po yul dmigs pa de srid du/ / de nyid du mi dmigs par mi 'gyur ste/ / thog med dus nas gom phyir ro/ /

Arising again, the winds cause you to cycle. That produces a body, and as long as your faculties (such as the visual one) observe their objects, they will not be without observation due to having been habituated [thus] from beginningless time.[81] (4.16–4.21)
phung po la sogs khams phra ba la gzhug go / khams ni sems phra ba la gzhug go /
The skandhas and the others enter the subtle dhātus. The dhātus enter the subtle mind.
sems yang ma rig pa la gzhug ste/ / de ltar gnyid log par bya'o/ / phyis ni ye shes kyi rang bzhin 'od gsal ba'o/ /
Mind enters ignorance. Thus you fall asleep. Then, there is the nature of wisdom: luminosity.[82] (4.22–4.26)
ma rig pa de lcags kyu dang 'dra/ / rnam par shes pa gang la'ang 'dre bar mi byed do/ / 'od gsal ba'i ngo bo nyid mngon sum du byed do/ /
Ignorance, which is like an iron hook, does not cause a mixing with the consciousnesses at all: the essence of luminosity is made manifest.[83] (4.27–4.29)
skye ba 'dis sangs rgya'o/ / bcas rang gar 'dod pa'i zhing khams khyad par can du 'gro na yang 'gro'o/ /
With this birth, awakening occurs. Thus, if there is a special buddha field to which you wish to go, you will go there.[*10]
tai lo pas gsungs/ des nA ro pa la/ des mar pa la/ des mi la la/ des rin po che la gnang ba'o/ /
[*10] Interlinear note: This was spoken by Tilopa. He bestowed these instructions on Nāropa, who bestowed them on Marpa, who bestowed them on Mila, who bestowed them on Rinpoche.
gnyid dang 'dres pa'i bsam gtan rdzogs so// ! /
This completes [the instructions on] the meditative concentration that mixes with sleep.[84] (4.30–4.32)
bar do'i bka' dpe'o/ /
Authoritative Text on Bardo (16.5)[85]
bla ma grub thob rnams (101) la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the siddha-gurus.[86] {101}

rim gyis 'jug pa'i gang zag ni/ / shes pa'i skye lugs 'di lta ste/ / snang ba thim dang rtog pa thim/ / rags pa thim dang phra ba thim/ / thim rjes la ni goms pa dang / / rang bzhin gyis ni 'od gsal 'byung / /

For individuals who enter [death] gradually,[87] the sequence of the mental processes is as follows: Illumination dissolves, thoughts dissolve.[88] The coarse dissolves, the subtle dissolves.[89] Be familiar with what follows dissolution: natural luminosity dawns.[90] (5.1–5.6)
de yi rjes la zung 'jug gi / sku ni rnam pa gnyis 'byung ste/ / slob pa dang ni mi slob gnyis/ / mi slob pa ru gyur ce na/ / 'bras bu thob ces bstan pa yin/ /
After that, the two kāyas of unification arise: one of training and one beyond training. When beyond training occurs,[91] that is taught to be “attaining the result.” (5.7–5.11)

gong du bstan pa de dag ni/ / zhib tu byas na 'di lta ste/ / dang po lung rigs man ngag gis/ / rgyud la rtog pa shar tsam na/ / snang ba 'gags pa'i 'gags lugs ni/ / gzugs sgra la thim de bzhin du/ / dri dang ro dang reg bya dang / / sa dang chu dang me dang rlung / / de rnams rim gyis snang bar thim/ /

All that is taught above[92] is, in detail, as follows: First, when through scriptures, reasonings, and esoteric instructions, realization dawns in your continuum,[93] the process of cessation for the cessation of illumination is that forms dissolve into sounds, and then smells, tastes, tangible objects, earth, water, fire, and wind all dissolve sequentially into illumination.[94] (5.12–5.20)

snang ba'i dus na phyi rtags zla ba shar ba lta bu/ / nang rtags ni shes pa du ba lta bu'o/ / snang ba mched pa la thim tsam na/ / phyi rtags nyi ma shar ba lta bu/ / nang shes pa srin bu me khyer ba lta bu'o/ /

During illumination, the outer sign is like the moon rising and the inner sign is like a smoky cognition. When illumination dissolves into radiance, the outer sign is the sun appearing[95] and the inner one is that cognition is like fireflies.[96] (5.21–5.25)

mched pa thob pa la thim tsam na/ / phyi rtags mun pa lta bu/ nang shes pa mar me lta bu'o/ / thob pa 'od gsal la thim tsam na/ / phyi rtags skya rengs shar ba lta bu/ nang shes pa nam mkha' sprin dag pa lta bu'o/ / 'od gsal las ldang ba'i zung 'jug gi sku de ngo shes par byas te/ /

When radiance dissolves into attainment, the outer sign is like darkness[97] and the inner one is that cognition is like candle flames.[98] When attainment dissolves into luminosity,[99] the outer sign is like dawn[100] and the inner one is that cognition is like a cloud-free sky.[101] (5.26–5.31)
ngo shes pa ni gsum ste/ rang bzhin gyis 'od gsal ba dang / zung 'jug gi sku dang / mngal gyi skye gnas dgag pa'o/

The kāya of unification that arises from luminosity is recognized.[102] Recognition is threefold: that of natural luminosity, the kāya of unification, and blocking the place of rebirth in a womb.[103] (5.32–5.36)
'od gsal ba de ngos zin nas 'od gsal gyi mes bag chags thams cad sbyong ba'i dus na/ /slob pa'i zung 'jug zhes bya'o/ /
Having recognized that luminosity, when the fire of luminosity has purified all latent tendencies, it is called the unification of training.[104]
de sbyang gzhi dang sbyong byed med par goms pa mthar phyin tsam na/ mi slob pa'i zung 'jug zhes bya ste 'bras bu thob pa'o/ /
When you have perfected familiarization with no basis to be purified or means of purification, that is called unification beyond training and is the attainment of the result.[105] (5.37–5.40)

zung 'jug de ngos zin na bar do sgyu ma'i lus yin te/ /de'i mtshan nyid ni/ /dbang po kun tshangs thogs med ldan/ /la sogs pa gzhan nas bshad pa dang mthun te/ chu las nya ldang ba bzhin byung nas/ skye ba gzhan len pa la sogs pa sdug (102) bsngal gyi rgyur 'gyur ro/ //

If that unification is not recognized,[106] there is the illusory body of the bardo. Its characteristics are in keeping with what is explained elsewhere, such as that its faculties are intact and it is unimpeded. Arising like a fish leaping out of water, it is the cause of suffering, such as craving to take another birth.[107] (5.41–5.46) ithi {102}

bar do lam du byed pa 'chi ka ma'i dus su bslab pa ni 'byung ba bzhi rim gyis thim par shes par byas la/ rang gi sems la bltas shing bar do la bar do ngo shes par bya'o snyam pa'i 'du shes drag tu bya zhing / bar do de nyid kyang sgyu mar shes par byas shing de kho na nyid bsgom ste/

To integrate the bardo into the path, train as follows for the moment of death: Learn the dissolution process of the four elements.[108] Look at your mind and strengthen your recognition, thinking, “I will know the bardo to be the bardo.” Also know that very bardo to be an illusion and meditate on suchness.[109] (5.47–5.49)
skye ba'i rkyen pa ma la chags sdang skye ba yin pas/ de zlog cing 'od gsal du gnas par bya'o/ /
Since attachment and aversion to your father and mother give rise to conditions for taking birth, reverse those and remain in luminosity.[110]
de'i dus su de kho na bsgom par mi nus shing skye ba len na'ang / rang dbang gis bde ba can tu 'gro bar bya ste rang dbang yod par lus len pa'o/ /
At that time, if you are unable to meditate on suchness and you take birth, you will go to Sukhāvatī through your own power.[111] You take a body through your own power. (5.50–5.53)
de ni bar do lam du khyer ba ste/ shes bzhin tu 'jug pa'i gang zag go //
That is [how to] integrate the bardo into the path, the instructions for entering [the bardo] with alertness.[112] (5.54–5.55) ithi[*11]
rdo rje 'chang gis phyag na rdo rje la/ des tai lo pa la/ des nA ro pa la/ des rje btsun mar pa la/ des gung thang gi mi la thos pa dga' ba des rin po che la gnang /

[*11] Interlinear note: Vajradhara bestowed these [instructions] on Vajrapāṇi, who bestowed them on Tilopa, who bestowed them on Nāropa, who bestowed them on the exalted Marpa, who bestowed them on Mila Töpaga of Gungtang, who bestowed them on Rinpoche.
snyan nas snyan/ zhal nas zhal/ thugs nas thugs su brgyud pa'o/ /
[These instructions] were transmitted from ear to ear, mouth to mouth, heart to heart.
kun gyi thun mong ma yin pa'o/ /rin po che'i gdams pa'o/ /rdzogs so/ ! /
They are exceptional among all [instructions]. They are precious instructions. This completes them.[113]
grong 'jug gi bka' dpe'o/ /
Authoritative Text on Entering a Body (16.6)[114]
bla ma dam pa rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the genuine gurus.[115]
de la sems kyi 'pho ba grong khyer la 'jug pa'i man ngag ni/ 'di ltar shes par bya ste/ dang po rnal 'byor pas chos thams cad sgyu ma dang khyad med pa'i don la mos pa drag po bya/

The esoteric instructions for transferring the mind using entering a body are to be known in the following way.[116] First, yogins and yoginīs should have the strong conviction that all phenomena are not different from illusions. (6.1)

de nas rang gi khyim du maN+Dal legs par byugs te/ thod pa'am/ /g.yam pa rtse ni la chang byugs te/ dbus su hU~M dkar po gsal bar bris te maN+Dal gyi thog tu bzhag la/ rang gi shes pa snying gar hU~M la gtad par byas la/ rang gi dbugs dang shes pa hU~M la gtad de drag tu bzung ngo / /

Then in your home, anoint a maṇḍala well.[117] Anoint the top of a skull cup or stone slab with beer.[118] In its center, clearly draw a white hūṃ and place that [skull or stone slab] on top of the maṇḍala. Focus your mind on a hūṃ in your heart. Focus and hold your breath and mind strongly on the hūṃ.[119]
de nas zin pa'i rtags ni thod pa dro ba'am/ 'gul ba'am/ /'phang ba'am/ du ba'i rtags 'ong ste/
Then, the signs that you have done this are that the skull becomes warm, shakes, leaps, or smokes.[120] (6.2–6.4)
de'i rjes la mi shi nas ring po ma lon pa/ ro ma rul ba rma med pa blangs la khrus byas te/ rgyan btags la yid gzhung bar bya ste/ maN+Dal gyi thog tu bzhag /

Following that, take the corpse of a person who has not been dead long, one that is not rotting or wounded, and wash it.[121] Adorn it, and direct your mind to it.[122] Place it on top of the maṇḍala.
ro'i snying gar hU~M bsam la de la shes pa gtad la (103) dbugs thub tshad bzung ngo / /
Imagine a hūṃ in the heart of the corpse. Focus your mind on that and hold your breath as much as you can. (6.5) {103}
de nas rlung dang shes pa ro la zin nas dga' ba skyes shing 'dug tsam na/ shes pa ro'i snying gar hril te gtad de bcug la/ tshur mi drang bar/ de langs la lus snga ma bor ro/ /

Next, holding your breath and mind on the corpse, when joy arises and abides, focus your mind completely on the heart of the corpse and enter there.[123] Not coming back, take that [corpse as your body], and abandon your previous body.[124] (6.6)
grong du 'jug pa slob pa'o// / ! /
That is the training for entering a body.[125] ithi
'pho ba'i bka' dpe'o/ /
Authoritative Text on Transference (16.7)[126]
'pho ba ni de kho na nyid dang / grong khyer du 'pho ba gnyis te/
There are two types of transference: transference into suchness and transference to somewhere higher.[127] (7a.1)

de kho na nyid kyi 'pho ba ni/ rang nyid lhar bsgom pa'i snying ga'am/ lte bar pad+ma dang zla ba dang hU~M bsam ste/ de'i 'od kyis snang srid thams cad rang sku la bsdu/ sku yang hU~M dang zla ba la bsdu/ zla ba yang hU~M la bsdu/ hU~M zhabs kyu nas nA da'i bar bsdus la mthar dbugs chad pa dang dus mnyam du nA da'ang mi dmigs par bya'o/ /

Transference into suchness is as follows: Meditate that you are a deity, and imagine that in either your heart or navel, there are a lotus, moon, and hūṃ. The light from that [syllable] gathers all the appearances of the world into your body. Your body dissolves into the hūṃ and moon. The moon dissolves into the hūṃ. The hūṃ dissolves from its shapkyu to its nāda. Finally, when your breathing has stopped, even the nāda is not observed. (7a.2)
des ni rang gi rlung gtso bor gyur pa dang / mos pa dang rtsol ba drag po dang / snang srid sgyu ma tsam du yid ches pas/ ci ltar yang btub snyams pas 'byung ba yin no// //

Then, your wind becomes the principal one. Through your conviction, strong exertion, and certainty that all appearances are simply illusions, you know anything is possible and thus [transference] occurs.[128] (7a.3) ithi
de la grong du 'pho bar byed na yang / bar do chos thams cad sgyu ma dang 'dra ba la yid ches par bya'o/ /
To transfer somewhere higher, first you must have certainty that all phenomena are like an illusion.[129]
de yang gong du 'pho ba'i man ngag la gsum te/ ting nge 'dzin gyis dang / rtsol ba dang / btsan thabs so/ /
Furthermore, the esoteric instructions for transferring to somewhere higher are threefold: using samādhi, exertion, and forceful means.[130] (7b.1)

de la ting nge 'dzin gyis 'pho ba byed na/ dang po rlung la sbyang ste/ de yang / rang gi snying gar yi ge haM yig zer ba'i thig le yungs 'bru tsam la shes pa gtad yun thub tshad du bzung / dbugs ngal na yang sna rtse la phar la rlung drang ngo/ /

Transference using samādhi is as follows: First train your breath. Next, direct your mind to a bindu the size of a mustard seed that is saying “haṃ” and is located in your heart.[131] Hold it there as long as you can. When your breath feels tired, raise [the bindu] up to the tip of your nose, along with drawing up your breath.[132] (7b.2)

de nas snying gar bzung zhing yang dang yang du nan tan du goms par byas pas ci tsam 'dod par zin cing / rang dbang yod pa snyam byed pa 'ong ngo / / pus mo bskor zhing se gol brdab/ / brgya rtsa brgyad zin pa'i chad ces gsungs so/ /

Then hold it at your heart. By habituating yourself to that again and again with dedication, you will be able to hold as you much as wish and you will think that you have gained mastery. Circle your knees and snap your fingers. [133] It is said that [being able to do that] one hundred and eight times is the measure of retention.[134] (7b.3)

snying gar zin nas lkog mar bzung bar bya'o/ / de ltar dbugs ngal na sna sgor ngal gso/ der ni gang 'dod zin gyur na/ / bde ba'i 'khor lo drangs byas te/ / shes pa bde ba can du gtad la tshangs pa'i sgo nas 'pho (104) bar bya// //

After retaining it at your heart, hold it at your throat. When your breath feels tired, rest [the bindu] at your nostrils. When you can hold it there as long as you wish,[135] draw it to the cakra of bliss. Direct your mind to Sukhāvatī, and transfer through the opening of Brahmā. (7b.4) {104} ithi

rtsol bas 'pho ba 'di ltar bya ste/ dang po 'chi rtags byung nas mi thar par shes nas dang por chos thams cad sgyu ma lta bu la yid ches par byas la/ lus kyi 'khrul 'khor bca' ba'o/ / de yang ngag tu A li bzlas te ngag gi 'khrul 'khor bcas pa'o/ /

Transference through exertion is done as follows: First, once the signs of death occur, knowing that you are not liberated, begin by being certain that all phenomena are like illusions. [That is the trulkhor practiced by the mind. The physical posture of sitting cross-legged and other points] are the trulkhor for the body.[136] Verbally reciting ā li is the trulkhor for speech.[137] (7c.1)

de nas shes pa bde ba can du gtad de bsam pa der btang la rang gi shes pa snying gar hU~M la bsdus te/ lag pa ltad par sprel te pus mo btsugs la/ snying gyen la log par bsams la/ lus dbyug pa la brten te/ ngag tu yang hi ka byas pas kha nas 'pho bar bya/ / 'chi rtags nges na 'pho bya ste/ / 'chi rtags med na sangs rgyas gsod/ 'pho ba bo/ /

Next, direct your mind to Sukhāvatī. Send your thoughts there and gather your mind into the hūṃ at your heart.[138] Interlace your fingers behind the nape of your neck, and plant your knees. Imagine that your heart turns upward. Support your body with a staff. With your voice say hik and transfer through your mouth.[139] When there are definite signs of death, transfer. If there are no signs of death [and you transfer], you are killing a buddha. That is transference.[140] (7c.2)

de la btsan thabs kyi 'pho ba ni/ / rkang pa g.yon pa'i phyi rting gis bshang sgo dgag / long bus rtsa sgo mnan nas de la/ seng ge rnam 'gying gi phyag rgyas rtse'u chung gnyis dang mig la sogs pa mnan/ 'og sgo bsdam zhing rlung bum pa can tu bya'o/ /

Transference through forceful means is as follows: Block your anus with the back of your left heel, and press on your channel door, [that is, your urethra,] with your ankles.[*12] With the mudrā of the majestic lion, press down on your two “minor extremities,” eyes, and other parts.[*13] Close the lower door and do vase breathing.

de nas dbugs ma thub na gru mo gnyis kyis mchan khung 'og gi rtsibs log bsdam la/ sked pa nyeg par byas te/ rlung drag por gyen du drangs te phul nas yar rlung dang shes pa gnyis khrog gis phyur gyis tshangs pa'i bu ga nas 'phos te mkha' spyod du 'gro ba'o/ /

Then, when you cannot hold your breath, press your rib cage below your armpits with your elbows and stretch up from your waist.[141] Drawing up the winds forcefully, with a sudden whoosh, transfer your upper winds and mind through your opening of Brahmā and go to the celestial realm.[142] (7c.3)

'pho ba 'di gar dgar dgar bya mi rung ste/ rang gi lus kyi lha bsad na mtshams med rtsa ltung 'byung nas ngan song du 'gro'o/ / 'chi nges na gong rol du bya'o/ / khyad par du btsan thabs kyi 'pho ba 'di ni sdig po che tshogs ma bsags pas bya'o/ / gzhan tu mi rung ngo // //

This transference should not be used just whenever you want.[143] If you kill the deity of your own body, that will be an act of immediate consequence or a root downfall and you will go to the negative states. If death is certain, do as above. In particular, this transference through forceful means is to be used by great evildoers who have not amassed the accumulations [of merit and wisdom]. It is not suitable for others. (7c.4) ithi[144]

dang po rang nyid skyil mo krung dang mnyam bzhag bcas te/ / mig sna rtser phab la/ skad cig gis yi dam lhar bsgom la/ rlung drag po nang du rngub cing drangs nas bum pa can lta bur bya'o/ / 'og sgo dang steng sgo gnyis char gyis bsdab/ de nas lte ba a snying gar hU~M bsam la/ de nas shes pa snying las zhugs (105) te/ /

First you should sit cross-legged and rest in equipoise.[145] Let your eyes rest on the tip of your nose. Instantly, meditate on yourself as the yidam deity. Inhale your breath forcefully and draw it in, making it like a vase.[146] Bind both the upper and lower doors.[147] Then, visualize a at your navel and hūṃ at your heart. Next, let your mind rest at your heart.[148] {105}

hU~M gyen tu song nas tshangs pa'i srubs 'byed bzhin 'byed par bsam/ / de la dbugs shin tu ma thub na/ / sna g.yon pa nas bag tsam btang zhing de nyid la bsgom/ / de la 'pho bar nus pa'i tshad ni/ / dbugs re la lag pa pus mo'i 'khor gsum bskor zhing se gol lan gsum gsum brdab/ / brgya rtsa brgyad nus na 'pho bar nus so/ /

When the hūṃ goes upward, imagine that it opens up the Brahmā suture.[149] When you really cannot hold your breath, release a bit through your left nostril and meditate on that. The [way to] measure your ability in that transference is as follows: With each breath, circle your knee with your hand three times snapping your fingers three times. If you are able to do this one hundred and eight times, you are able to transfer.[150] (7d.1)
nam thun gtong tsam na/ / yi ge gnyis gnas su song bar bsam 'chi nges na gong rol du 'pho'o/ /
When you are finishing a session, visualize that the two letters return to their locations. When death is certain, transfer to somewhere higher. (7d.2)

de la 'pho ba'i dus su gong du bsgom pa ltar byas te/ / sked pa cung zad nyeg nyeg por byas nas/ / gru mos rtsibs logs gnyis cung zhig mnan te/ / rlung drag po gyen du drangs te/ / tshangs pa'i srub phyes te 'phos pas/ / shes pa rlung dang gnyis khrog ther gyis 'gro'o/ / 'pho ba'i man ngag go /

At the time of transference, meditate as above.[151] Stretch up slightly from your waist.[152] Press your elbows into your rib cage a bit. Draw your winds straight up and open your fissure of Brahmā. Moving through that, with a whoosh, your mind and winds go to the celestial realm.[153] Those are the esoteric instructions on transference. (7d.3)

tai lo pa/ des nA ro pa/ des lho brag mar pa chos kyi blo gros/ / des gung thang gi mi la thos pa dga' la/ / des rin po che sgam po pa la gnang ba'o/ / grub pa nus pa thob pa'i nyams len rgyun ma chad pa yin no/ / rje btsun ras pa ni mkha' 'gro mas kyang byin gyis brlabs pa yin gsungs so/ // ! /

Tilopa bestowed these [instructions] on Nāropa, who bestowed them on Lhodrak Marpa Chökyi Lodrö, who bestowed them on Mila Töpaga of Gungtang, who bestowed them on the precious Gampopa. The practice of those who have attained the ability of siddhis is unbroken. Jetsun Repa said that these instructions are blessed by the ḍākinīs.[154] ithi
gdams ngag gnad kyi bka' dpe'o/ /
Authoritative Text on the Vital Points of Instructions (16.8)[155]
srog rtsol gnad du bsdams byas te/ / rtsa rlung thig le mtshan ldan dang / / 'od gsal rjes su gnang ba bsgom/ /
Bind prāṇāyāma as the vital point. Meditate with authorization on the authentic channels, winds, and bindus, and luminosity. (8.1–8.3)
srog rtsol dag la dbang thob na/ / rlung ni g.yas g.yon 'pho dus dang / / kha dog bye brag tshor ba dang / / bsdam gdod med cing phyi nang bsre/ /

If you attain mastery of prāṇāyāma, you will be able to transfer winds to the left and right,[156] the feelings of the various colors will be blissful,[157] there will be no restraints or harm, and outer and inner will blend.[158] (8.4–8.7)
tsha grang 'dres pa'i rtags byung nas/ / dgos dgu thams cad 'byung bar gsungs/ / bla ma dam pa'i gdams ngag la/ / chu bo'i rgyun bzhin nyams blangs na/ / dam tshig de yis skong bar gsungs/ /

Once the signs of mixing hot and cold arise, it is said that all your desires are fulfilled. When your practice of your genuine guru’s instructions is like the flow of a river,[159] it is said that that fulfills your samaya. (8.8–8.12)
rmi lam mngon sum gang la yang / / cho 'phrul sna tshogs 'byung ba la/ / sgyu mar shes na lam du 'gyur/ / bden par bzung na bar chod yin/ /
Your actual dreams, whatever they are, arise as various miraculous displays. When you know they are illusions, they become the path. If you take them to be real, they are obstacles.[160] (8.13–8.16)

nyin re bram ze brgya gsod dang / / mtshams med lnga dag byed pa dang / / rku dang 'dod pa'i longs spyod rnams/ / (106)'di yi lam gyis 'gags par 'gyur/ / sdig gis gos par mi 'gyur te/ / srid pa'i dngos por rengs par 'gyur/ /

Those who have killed a hundred brahmans a day, committed the five acts of immediate consequence, stolen, or indulged in passion {106} will have [those results] stopped by this path. Evil deeds will not sully, and the things of existence will become distant.[161] (8.17–8.22)
ji ltar 'dam nas skyes pa yi/ / pad+ma'i mdangs ni mdzes par 'gyur/ / de bzhin rgas pa'i lus dag la/ / ye shes sku ni rang dgar 'byung / /
Although it grows out of mud, a lotus’s glow is beautiful. Similarly, within your aging body the pure wisdom body arises just on its own. (8.23–8.26)
rdo rje sbyor ba'i sbyor bas na/ / rdo rje dril bu mi ldan pa'i/ / gsang ba'i 'bras bu ci ltar 'byung / / rdo rje dril bu mi ldan pa'i/ / rdo rje bsgrub pa rengs par 'gyur/ /

Because this involves the practice of vajra union, without vajra and ghaṇṭā, how can the secret result arise?[162] Without vajra and ghaṇṭā, vajra accomplishment is something distant.[163] (8.27–8.31)
rdo rje dril bu'i phyag rgya yang / / sbyangs nas pha rol dga' bar 'gyur/ / mtshan mo zla ba med pa yi/ / nyin mo zla ba ji ltar snang // //
Through training with the vajra and ghaṇṭā mudrās[164] you will enjoy the other side.[165] How can the moon appear on a day when the moon has not appeared at night? (8.32–8.35)
ces nA ro pa'i bka' dpe rnams rdzogs so/ /
ithi This completes the Authoritative Texts of Nāropa.[*14][166]
ka dpe tshig lhug pa gcig kyang yod do/ / tshig bcad 'di gtso bor mdzad do/ /
[*14] Interlinear note: There is also the Authoritative Texts in Prose (ka dpe tshig lhug pa). This verse is taken to be the primary one.
mang+ga laM/ ! //
