17. Esoteric Instructions on the Six Dharmas[1]
rgya gar skad du/ ShaT d+harma u pa de sha nA ma/ /
In the language of India: Ṣaḍdharmupadeśanāma.
bod skad du/ / chos drug gi man ngag ces bya ba/ /
In the language of Tibet: Chos drug gi man ngag ces bya ba.
dpal bde mchog 'khor lo la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the glorious Cakrasaṃvara.
dal 'byor rgyu 'bras las rnams las/ / rnal 'byor don gyi snying po btsal/ /
With your leisures and opportunities, along with the causes and results of your actions, seek the essence of the ultimate yoga. (1–2)
rnal 'byor lus kyi rtse yi tshogs/ / phra rags rlung dang ldan pa ni/ / dbang du byed thabs 'khrul 'khor gyis/ / dbyung rngub dgang dang gzhil ba ste/ /

Yoga practitioners apply, to the collection of channels in the body,[7] subtle and coarse, along with its winds, the methods for controlling: using trulkhor, they exhale, inhale, fill, and disperse. (3–6)
la la nA dang ra sa nA/ / a wa d+hU tI 'khor lo bzhi/ / lte bar tsaN+Da lI yi me/ / phra rab las 'phel haM las ni/ /
There are the lalanā, rasanā, avadhūti, and four cakras. The fire of caṇḍālī at the navel increases from something subtle, and from haṃ
bdud rtsi'i chu rgyun dga' bzhi'i 'gros/ / rgyu mthun la sogs 'bras bu bzhi/ / 'khrul 'khor drug gis rgyas par bya/ /
a stream of amṛta [arouses] the progression of the four joys. There are four results, such as the causally concordant.[*1] The six trulkhors expand those. (7–13)
tsAr+Ya pa'i u pa de sha'o/ /
That is the upadeśa, [instruction,] of Caryāpā. (14)
snod bcud khams gsum ma lus pa/ / sgyu ma rmi lam la sogs dpes/ / 'gro 'dug spyod lam kun tu sbyang / /
With the environment, its inhabitants, and all three realms, apply the examples of illusions, dreams, and so forth, and train when walking, sitting, and in all activities. (15–17)

lha tshogs sgyu ma me long gzugs/ / rdo rje sems dpa' legs bris pa/ / gzugs brnyan gsal bar snang dang mtshungs/ / de nyid sgyu ma'i gzugs bzhin du/ / sgyu dpe bcu gnyis ltar mthong ba/ / rnal 'byor sgyu ma'i don mthong ba'o/ /

Deities are illusions, like images in a mirror. [Take an image of] Vajrasattva, well drawn, [and see that it] is similar to its reflected image appearing clearly. In the same way that is an illusory form, see it to be like the twelve examples of illusion.[*2] Yoga practitioners see illusory reality. (18–23)
na ga rdzu na'i u pa de shi'o/ /
That is the upadeśa of Nāgārjuna. (24)
rmi lam rmi lam don shes shing / / rgyun du zab mo'i don bsgom pa/ /
Know dreams to be dreams in fact, and continuously meditate on the profound reality. {107}
nA da thig le la sogs (107) pa/ / rigs lnga'i sa bon la dmigs nas/ / sangs rgyas zhing dang sangs rgyas blta/ / gnyis dus bde chen sgrub pa'i thabs/ / lwa ba pa'i u pa de sha'o/ /

By focusing on the seeds of the five families— nāda, bindu, and so forth— you will see buddha fields and buddhas. This method for cultivating great bliss during sleep[8] is the upadeśa of Lavapa. (25–31)

rnal 'byor a wa d+hU tI pa/ / a wa d+hU tIr sems gnas pa/ / snying gi thig ler sems brtan pas/ / 'od dang 'od zer 'ja' ris dag / skya rengs nyi 'od zla 'od dang / / nyi ma zla ba shar 'dra gsal/ / lha dang sku yi snang ba sogs/ / sna tshogs zhing khams dag par 'gyur/ /

Avadhūti yoga practitioners rest their minds in the avadhūti. Stabilizing their minds on a bindu at their heart, light, light rays, rainbow patterns, dawn, sunlight, moonlight, clarity like the rising of the sun and moon,[9] appearances of deities and kāyas, and so on, are pure as various pure lands.
rnal 'byor pa yi lam chen te/ / nA gA rdzu na'i u pa de sha'o/ /
This great path for yoga practitioners is the upadeśa of Nāgārjuna. (32–41)
rnal 'byor 'chi ba'i dus kyi tshe/ / dbang po rnams dang 'byung ba sdud/ / zla nyi rlung rnams snying gar 'dus/ / rnal 'byor ting 'dzin sna tshogs 'char/ /
When yoga practitioners arrive at the time of death, their faculties and elements dissolve. The moon, sun, and winds gather at their heart. Various samādhis arise for yoga practitioners. (42–45)
rnam shes phyi rol yul song na/ / rmi lam yul bzhin sna tshogs snang / / bdun bdun dus tshe 'chi snang dang / / de nas skye bar 'gyur ba nyid/ /
When their consciousnesses go out to objects, various things appear like objects in a dream. During seven [intervals of] seven, there are the appearances of death, and then there will be birth.
de tshe lha yi rnal 'byor sgom/ / yang na de nyid ngang la gzhag /
At that time, meditate on deity yoga. Alternatively, remain in a state of suchness. (46–51)
de rjes skye la phyogs pa'i tshe/ / mnga' bdag lha yi rnal 'byor gyis/ / snang srid lha yi rnal 'byor sgom/ / des ni bar do khegs par 'gyur/ /
Next, when departure approaches, meditate on all possible appearances as deity yoga with the sovereign deity yoga. That will stop the bardos. (52–55)
su kha sid+d+hi'i u pa de sha'o/ /
That is the upadeśa of Sukhasiddhi. (56)
de las rnal 'byor 'pho ba'i tshe/ / grong 'jug lha dang sa bon gyis/ / 'gro 'ong ring dang thud pa dang / / lha la bslab cing 'phar ba'i dus/ / gang 'dod grong du 'jug par bya/ /

Then when yoga practitioners [are ready] to transfer, entering a body [is done] with the deity and seeds. Train in coming and going, short and long [distances], and the deity; then when [ready] to elevate, perform entering a body, your desired destination. (57–61)
gong du 'pho na stong rang lha/ / yaM sprod hi ka hU~M dang hU~M/ / lha dang bla ma'i thugs kar 'phang / / des ni 'dod pa'i gnas su 'gro/ /

When [ready] to transfer somewhere higher, [imagine yourself as] the empty enclosure of the deity.[10] Linked with yaṃ, [saying] hi-ka, hūṃ, and hūṃ, shoot to the heart of the deity and guru, then go on to the place you desire.[11] (62–65)
su kha sid+d+hi'i u pa de she'o/ /
That is the upadeśa of Sukhasiddhi. (66)
grub pa'i rnal 'byor dbang phyug til+li pa'i zhabs kyi zhal snga nas mdzad pa rdzogs so/ /
This completes [the instructions] composed orally by the lord of accomplished yogins, Tilopa.
rgya gar gyi mkhas pa na ro paN+Di ta dang / mar pa lho brag chos kyi blo gros kyis kha che'i gnas puSh+pa ha rir bsgyur ba'o/ /
The Indian scholar Paṇḍita Nāropa and Marpa Lhodrak Chökyi Lodrö translated this at Puṣpahari in Kashmir.[*3] {108}

'di ni chos drug gi bka' dpe chung ba'am/ / rnal 'byor dbang phyug til+li pa'i chos drug gi gzhung chung yid bzhin nor bu zhes brgyud pa 'dzin pa rnams kyis gdams ngag gi khungs su mdzad do/ ! / (108)

[*3] Interlinear note: This is called either the Short Authoritative Text on the Six Dharmas (Chos drug gi bka’ dpe chung ba) or the Wish-Fulfilling Gems: A Short Text on the Six Dharmas of the Lord of Yogins Tilopa (rNal ’byor dbang phyug ti+li pa’i chos drug gi gzhung chung yid bzhin nor bu). The lineage holders have taken this as the source of instructions.
mkhas grub chen po nA ro tA pas rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug mar po lo tsA la gdams pa'i chos drug dril ba rdo rje'i mgur/ /
18. Vajra Song Summarizing the Six Dharmas. The Scholar-Mahāsiddha Nāropa’s Instructions to the Lord of Yogins Marpa[1]
rje bka' drin can gyi zhabs la 'dud/ / bod yul gyi mar pa lo tsA khyod/ / dal 'byor lus kyi phung po'i yid/ / dbyar skye tshe na 'di skad lo/ ! /
I bow at the feet of the kind exalted one. You, Marpa Lotsāwa of Tibet, have a body with the leisures and opportunities, and yet your mind this summer is sad: listen.[5] (1–3)
sems kyi gnas thabs lta ba'i gding / / lus kyi gnas thabs sgom pa'i gnad/ / phyi ni sgyu ma lha yi sku/ / nad na rtsa gsum 'khor lo bzhi/ /

The way to rest your mind is to have confidence in the view. The way to rest your body is with the vital points of meditation. Externally, there is the body of the illusory deity. Internally,[6] there are three channels and four cakras. (4–7)

'og na a shad rtsaN+Da yi/ / steng na haM yig rnam pa can/ / steng 'og rlung gi 'khor lo ni/ / srog rtsol bum can nyams len gyis/ / bar na bde stong gsal ba'i nyams/ / ming yang gtum mo'i gdams ngag zer/ / rlung gnad du chud dam lo tsA ba/ ! /

Below is caṇḍālī, the a stroke.[7] Above is what has the form of the letter haṃ. By practicing prāṇāyāma, vase breathing, with the cakras of the upper and lower winds, in between, experiences of bliss, emptiness, and clarity arise. The name for this is the instructions of caṇḍālī. Have you engaged the vital points of winds, Lotsāwa? (8–13)
phyi na snang ba sgyu ma tsam/ / nang na nyams myong smra ma btub/ / nyin mtshan snang ba sprul pa'i sku/ / ming yang sgyu lus kyi gdams ngag zer/ / zhen pa log gam lo tsA ba/ ! /

External appearances are simply illusions. Internal experiences can’t be described. The appearances of the day and night are the nirmāṇakāya. The name for this is the instructions on illusory forms. Do you have revulsion, Lotsāwa? (14–18)

rmi lam nyams kyi 'khrul pa'i dus/ / mgrin par oM yig 'od zer can/ / dran 'dun bag chags kyi mtshams sbyor las/ / skyes pa rmi na pho 'dre zer/ / bud med rmi na mo 'dre zer/ / byol song rmi na klu ru 'dzin/ / dga' ba rmi na sems dpangs bskyed/ / mi dga' rmi na snying mi dga'/ /
'dre sems kyi rtsa bar ma shes na/ / rnam rtog gi 'dre la zad pa med/ / bzang ngan rang grol ston pa'i don/ / ming yang rmi lam gyi gdams ngag zer/ / rang bzhin shes sam lo tsA ba/ ! /

If you don’t recognize that spirits [arise from] the root of mind, you won’t exhaust the spirits of thoughts. The point of this teaching is that good and bad are free in and of themselves. The name for this is the instructions on dreams. Have you recognized the nature, Lotsāwa? (27–31)

gnyid dang rmi lam bar zhig na/ / gti mug chos sku'i ngo bo can/ / brjod med 'od gsal bde ba'i nyams/ / rjes la 'od gsal rgya yis thebs/ / rmi lam 'od gsal 'thug po nyid/ / ming yang 'od gsal gyi gdams ngag zer/ / sems skye med du rtogs sam lo tsA ba/ ! /

The gap between sleep and dreams— bewilderment, which is of the nature of the dharmakāya— is an experience of inexpressible luminosity and bliss. Seal what follows with luminosity, [be it] dreams, luminosity, [or] deep sleep.[8] The name for this is the instructions on luminosity. Have you realized mind to be unborn, Lotsāwa? (32–38)
sgo brgyad 'khor ba'i skar khung can/ / sgo gcig phyag rgya chen po'i lam/ / sgo brgyad bcad nas sgo gcig 'byed/ / (109)
sems kyi mda' la rlung gi gzhu/ / hika gi rgyud kyis rab bskul nas/ / rnam shes tshangs pa'i lam nas 'phen/ / ming yang 'pho ba'i gdams ngag zer/ / rlung dus su khegs sam lo tsA ba/ ! /

On the bow of wind, the arrow of mind is launched by the bowstring of hik, and consciousness is shot through the path of Brahmā. The name for this is the instructions for transference. Can you block your winds on time, Lotsāwa? (39–46)

rang lus dus kyi tshad phebs la/ / gzhan lus mtshan ldan dam pa'i yul/ / bar na yig 'bru rlung gi rta/ / rten 'brel rlung gi 'khor lo yis/ / rang lus khang stong bzhin du bor/ / gzhan lus sprul sku'i ngo bo can/ / ming yang grong 'jug gi gdams ngag zer/ / rlung las su rung ngam lo tsA ba/ ! /

When your body reaches its full measure of time, [find] another body, a qualified, sacred body.[9] In between, there is the seed syllable on the horse of the winds. Through the connections of the cakras of winds, you leave your body like an empty house, and [enter] the other body, which is of the nature of the nirmāṇakāya. The name for this is the instructions for entering a body. Are your winds workable, Lotsāwa? (47–54)

rmi lam dus kyi shes pa de/ / bar do'i sems dang bsre dgos pas/ / longs spyod rdzogs sku'i ngo bo can/ / dag dang ma dag gzugs sku gnyis/ / bar do'i dus su zin yang 'tshal/ / rmi lam bar do bsre 'pho gnad/ / mi yang bar do'i gdams ngag zer/ /

You must mix your mind during dreams with the mind of the bardo, which is of the nature of the saṃbhogakāya. During the bardo, recognize and know purity and impurity to be the form kāyas. These are the vital points for transference and mixing dreams and bardos. The name for this is the instructions on the bardos.
bar do 'byongs sam lo tsA ba/ ! /
Have you mastered the bardos, Lotsāwa? (55–62)
lar phyi nang gi chos la thos pa dgos/ / go bas mtha' gnyis spong ba yin/ / yin min gyi sgro 'dogs chod tsa na/ / gol sa med pa'i lam gcig yin/ / lam de la skyo ba ga la yod/ /

Again, you must listen to the outer and inner dharma teachings. Through understanding, you abandon the two extremes. When you cut through misinterpretations about what is and is not, that is the single path devoid of strayings. How could there be sadness on this path? (63–67)
ces gsungs so/ /
Thus it is said.[*1]

'di rje mar pa'i rnam thar las yongs su grags shing phyis kyi mkhas pa chen po rnams kyis kyang gdams pa'i khungs su drangs shing rtsa ba rdo rje'i tshig lta bur mdzad snang / / 'on kyang tshig mang nyung dang / / go rim mi gcig pa sogs 'dra min cung zad mang du gda' na'ang / / 'dir re zhig yongs grags nyid go bde bar snang bas de ltar bris pa'o/ /

[*1] Interlinear note: This is well known from the biography of the exalted Marpa. Later, great scholars quoted these instructions, and they became like root vajra verses. Nevertheless, there are many slight differences with [some editions] having more lines or less lines, the line order is not consistent, and so on. However, here I have written what is well known, since that seems easy to understand.
mang+ga laM/ ! /
maṅgalam
rje btsun chen po mi la ras pas mdzad pa'i snyan brgyud {zur mang snyan brgyud} gsal ba skor gsum sogs bzhugs so/ /
19. The Three Cycles of Illumination and Other Instructions. Aural Transmissions[*1] {[*1] This is part of the Zurmang Aural Transmission.} Composed by Jetsun Milarepa[1]
rje btsun mi las mdzad pa'i dngos po gsal bar byed pa zhes bya ba/
The Illumination of Entities (19.1)
bla ma dam pa rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the genuine gurus.
bla ma rin chen lta bu yi/ / zhabs kyi pad+ma la btud de/ /
I bow at the lotus feet of the gemlike guru.
lus ngag yid gsum sprin tshogs kyis/ dus gsum du ni mngon phyag 'tshal/ /
I pay homage throughout the three times with billowing clouds of my body, speech, and mind. (1–4)
bla ma dam pa'i drin thob nas/ / gnyis med (110) gsal ba chos kyi dbyings/ / lam mchog de la'ang phyag 'tshal lo/ /
ma rig mun pa sel mdzad pa'i/ / ye shes sgron me la phyag 'tshal/ / 'khor ba rgyun gcod rab bsal ba/ / rab snang de la'ang phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the lamp of wisdom, which dispels the darkness of ignorance. Homage to the best of appearances, the best illuminator for severing the stream of saṃsāra. (8–11)
bla ma tai lo pas nA ro la gnang / / des mar pa la gnang / / de nyid kyi mi la {thos pa dka'/ } la gnang / /
Guru Tilopa bestowed [these teachings] on Nāropa,[6] who bestowed them on Marpa, who bestowed them on Mila.[*3] {[*3] Töpaga.} (12–14)
zhabs drung du 'khor ba yun ring / / dod cing ni thos gyur na/ / thugs rjes ni dgongs nas gnang / /
I spent a long time in [Marpa’s] presence. I longed for and listened [to his teachings], bestowed [upon me] through his compassion. (15–17)
gdams ngag ni dang du blangs/ / rtsol sgrub ni drag tu byas/ / bsgom pas ni yon tan byung / /
I enthusiastically took up these instructions, and practiced them with perseverance. Meditating, excellent qualities arose.
lus la ni gtum mo 'bar/ / ras gos ni rkyang res dros/ / sems la ni 'od gsal shar/ /
Caṇḍālī blazed in my body— I was warm with only cotton clothing— and luminosity shone in my mind. (18–23)
brgyud lugs ni mang gis kyang / / bod yul du brgyud pa la/ / 'di dang ni gzhan mi mnyam/ / khyad par ni bye brag ltos/ /
Although there are many traditions of transmission, of the transmissions in the land of Tibet, none equal this one. Behold its special features! (24–27)
nyams su len pa'i dus tsam na/ / shin tu dben pa'i gnas nyid du/ / dngos po'i gnas lugs lam {gyi rim pa} dang ni/ / 'bras bu skye ba'i rim pa'o/ /

When you are undertaking practice, in a very isolated place, [know the following:] There are the abiding state of entities, {[*4] The process of} the path,[*4] and the process that gives rise to the result.[7] (28–31)
lus ni byang chub rnam lnga dang / / rtsa dang byang chub sems dang ni/ / mi gtsang rdzas dang rnam rtog gis/ / lus ni chos kyi gnas pa yin/ /
As for the body, it is the fivefold awakening, the channels, bodhicittas,[8] unclean substances, and thoughts. Those are the phenomena of the body.[9] (32–35)
de la gnad ni rnam gsum ste/ / lus dang yul dang dus kyang ngo / / dbugs la {dbugs gnad rngub pa dgang ba gzhi yab mda' ltar 'phen pa'o/} bzhir ldan ma shes na/ / gang gi yon tan 'byung bar dka'/ /

Its vital points are three: the body, objects, and timing.[10] If you do not know the four-part breathing,[*5] {[*5] The vital points of breath are inhaling, filling, dispersing, and releasing like an arrow.} it will be difficult to give rise to any good qualities.[11] (36–39)
li ri bzhin du khong sgrim bya/ / rgya mdud bzhin du bsgom par bya/ / lcags kyu bzhin tu dgug par bya/ / re'u mig bzhin tu bsnol bar bya/ /
Tighten internally as if [making a rope of] liri, and meditate in the knot-like [position]. Draw in like an iron hook. Cross [your legs] like lattice.[12] (40–43)
mda' ltar gyen du 'phang bar bya/ / nam mkha'i ba ni {yul gyi gnad} rim gyis bzho/ / 'khor lo bzhi yi bsam gtan bya/ /
a wa d+hU ti'i stong ra 'di/ / stong pa'i nang nas stong pa mchog /
This empty enclosure of the avadhūti is, among emptinesses, the sublime emptiness. (44–48)

gdams ngag khyad par mang gi kyang / / rtsa rlung gdams pa khyad par 'phags/ / nyams su blangs na yon tan 'byung / / des na bla ma dam pa spyi bor bkur/ / mig gi 'bras bu (111) bzhin du bca' bar bya/ /

Although there are many special instructions, the instructions on the channels and winds are especially distinguished. When put into practice, excellent qualities arise. Therefore, venerate the genuine guru on the top of your head. Cherish them as you do your eyes.[14] (49–53) {111}

pho nya'i lam la dga' ba la/ / rig ma bsten pa'i dus tsam na/ / rang gis dbang bskur dad pa can/ / khro sems med cing snying rje che/ / shin tu bzhin bzang mig yangs ma/ / gzugs mdzes lang tshos rnam par brgyan/ /

When, for the joys on the path of the emissaries, you practice with a vidyā, bestow the abhiṣekas yourself [on] ones with faith. They should be without anger, possess great compassion, be lovely with wide-open eyes, and be adorned with beauty and youthfulness.[15] (54–59)

bu srid tshul lam bran mo'i tshul/ / shin tu ngo tsha bsdams par bya/ / rig ma bsten pa'i dus dag tu/ / shin tu dben pa'i {bla ma dang dkon mchog la gsol ba btab nas phyag 'tshal nas shes pa sbyong ba la sogs tshogs lam/ /snyoms 'jug sbyor lam/ skad cig la shes pa mthong lam/} gnas nyid du/ / lam gsum man ngag shes byas te/ /

Join with those who are most wonderful: those [appearing] in the guise of siblings or servants. When practicing with a vidyā, in a very isolated location,[*7] {[*7] From supplicating the guru and jewels and paying homage up to and including training your mind is the path of accumulation. Sexual union is the path of preparation. Recognizing the moment is the path of seeing.} know the esoteric instructions for the three paths. (60–65)
sgo gnyis khegs pa'i rnal 'byor pas/ / rig ma bsten kyang 'gal ba med/ / khyad par rgyud nas spangs pa dang / / yon tan med pa spang ba'o/ /

Yogins and yoginīs who can block the two doors will not contravene anything by practicing with a vidyā. This is to be dispensed with by those without qualities and is to be dispensed with by the especially noble ones.[16] (66–69)
de la log rtog blo ma skye/ / rdo rje 'chang gis sprul pa la/ / rdo rje 'chang gis gsungs pa yin/ /
Wrong thoughts toward that do not arise. Vajradhara said that to the one emanated by Vajradhara. (70–72)
srog dang rtsol ba 'dzin dus su/ / mi rtog don la dmigs kyang rung / / thig le nya gang gcig la dmigs kyang rung / / phyag rgya mtshan ldan zhig la dmigs kyang rung / /

During the retention of prāṇāyāma, a nonconceptual state is suitable as the object of meditation, the single, full-moon bindu is suitable as the object of meditation, a qualified mudrā is suitable as the object of meditation,
gtum mo me khab tsam la dmigs kyang rung / /
or the fine needle of caṇḍālī is suitable as the object of meditation.[17]
yar 'dren mar 'dren bzhu btul byad kyang {dmigs pa yul gyi gnad} rung /
You can also draw up, draw down, melt, and tame.[*8] {[*8] The vital points of the objects of meditation.} (73–78)
shes pa rnam rtog yul la ma 'phros na/ / de rnams gsal ba med kyang ni/ / rnam par rtog pa ngang gis 'gag / yon tan rnams ni rim gyi 'byung / /
If your mind does not scatter to thoughts or objects, although those may not be clear, thoughts will naturally cease. Excellent qualities will gradually arise. (79–82)
thabs lam khyad du 'phags pa'i man ngag 'di/ / slob ma snying dang 'dra ba ma gtogs pa/ / snod ngan gzhan la sbyin pa'i chos ma yin/ / des na gdams ngag snying gi dkyil du spos/ /

These especially distinguished instructions on the path of method are only for disciples for whom they are like their heart. They are not a dharma to be given to others, those who are poor recipients. Therefore, keep these instructions in the middle of your heart. (83–86)
las la brten nas yul de mthong bar nges/ / thabs la brten nas yon tan 'byung bar nges/ / rgyu la brten nas 'bras bu 'byung bar nges/ kha gsag g.yo sgyu can la sbyin mi bya/ /

Based on your actions, it is certain you will see that object. Based on the method, it is certain the excellent qualities will arise. Based on the causes, it is certain that the results will arise. Don’t give these to deceitful sycophants. (87–90)

rgyu dang 'bras bu gdod nas gnyis med kyang / / rnam rtog dbang gi rgyu dang (112) 'bras bur snang / / de ltar rtogs pa med pa'i {phyi rabs kyi/} gang zag rnams/ tshig tsam don du khyed na rang gzhan bslu/ /
de de yin te de nyid min/ / de de mthong yang de ma mthong / / des na gdod nas sangs rgyas khas len pa/ / seng ge g.yang sar mchong ba'i rjes bzhin du/ / bong bu mchong na srog dang bral bar 'gyur/ /

That is so, but that’s not it. That is seeing but it is not the seeing.[18] Thus, asserting they are primordially buddhas, some are like donkeys who, if they try to follow lions jumping across a deep ravine, will part from this life. (95–99)
skal ldan las can rnams kyi bdud rtsi 'di/ / skal med 'byung po rnams kyi dug tu 'gyur/ / mthu rtsal ldan pa stag gi lad mo 'di/ / dur khrod wa spyang rnams kyis spyad par dka'/ /

This amṛta for worthy karmically destined ones is poison for unworthy bhūtas. It is difficult for foxes and wolves of charnel grounds to pull off an imitation of a tiger with its strength and skill. (100–103)
bskos par gyur na sa la chu yang 'byung / / bsrub par gyur na shing la me yang 'byung / / mis ni rtsol sgrub dag ni byas gyur na/ / mi 'grub pa yi chos ni gang yang med/ /
If you dig in it, water appears in the earth. If you rub it, fire arises on wood. If humans apply themselves with exertion, there’s no phenomena they can’t make.[19] (104–7)
des na nyams su blangs pa rab tu gces/ / nyon mongs rnam rtog rim gyis 'gag gyur na/ / rang rig ye shes gsal ba'i ngo bo gsal/ /
Therefore, treasure engaging in practice. When mental afflictions and thoughts gradually cease, the essence of reflexively aware, clear wisdom is illuminated. (108–10)
dge bcu spyad pas thar pa thob pa dka'/ / sdig bcu spangs pas mya ngan 'da' bar dka'/ / spang len gnyis kyis mi rtog 'char ba dka'/ /

It’s difficult to achieve liberation through engaging in the ten virtues. It’s difficult to reach nirvāṇa through abandoning the ten negative actions. It’s difficult to give rise to nonconceptuality through abandoning and adopting. (111–13)
lus can dag ni kun la yang / / snying po don 'di gdod nas gnas/ / des na sems can sangs rgyas rgyu/ /
The ultimate essence abides primordially within corporeal beings, all of them. Thus, sentient beings are the cause of buddhahood. (114–16)

rgyu las 'bras bu btab pa la/ / gdod nas thebs kyis da ltar min/ / da ltar 'debs byed rnam rtog yin/ / rnam rtog don du 'debs byed pa/ / me yis ma bsad ji bzhin du/ / smig rgyu dag la chur 'khrul bzhin/ /

As for planting the cause for the result, it’s primordially sown, not [something you do] now. Any planting done now is [just] thought, [and the idea that] thought could actually plant [this cause] is analogous to [trying to] extinguish fire with fire,[20] or mistaking a mirage for water. (117–22)
lta ba nyams su mi len par/ / thabs kyi khyad par nyams su longs/ / ma mthong yul de blta 'dod na/ / yul de yid la ma byed bar/ / lam gyi khyad par nyams su longs/ /
Do not practice the view— practice the special methods. If you wish to see that unseen object, do not create that object in the mind— practice the special path. (123–27)
thabs la bsten pa'i dus tsam na/ / rgyu yi dus na 'bras bu dngos/ / las can rnams kyis rtogs par rigs/ /
When you practice with the methods, at the time of the cause, the result is evident. The karmically destined are capable of realization. (128–30)
stong pa ma yin {stong pa gang zhe na} mi stong min/ / de nyid su la yod ce na/ / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas nyid la mnga'/
rnal 'byor rig (113) pa'i blo la 'char/ / thun mong {sems can thams cad/ } yod kyang khyad par {rtogs ldan pa/} 'phags/ / de yang thabs la bsten pas 'byung / /

It arises in the mind of awareness for yogins and yoginīs. Although shared by all {[*11] All sentient beings},[*11] for the particularly distinguished {For those with realization},[*12] it arises through practicing with methods. (131–36)
rab kyi yon tan bde stong rgyun par gnas/ / mnyam bzhag rjes thob med pa'o/ /
Those with the highest excellent qualities abide continuously in bliss-emptiness, without [distinction between] meditative equipoise or postmeditative attainment.
'bring gi rjes thob stong par rtogs/ /
Those of intermediate abilities realize postmeditative attainment to be empty.
tha mas rjes thob sgyu mar mthong / /
Those of normal abilities see postmeditative attainment as illusion.
yang dag don la khyad med kyang / / rnam rtog la ni khyad du snang / /
Although there are no distinctions in the true nature, distinctions appear for thoughts. (137–42)
chu bo yi rgyun bzhin du/ / yun ni bsring bar gsungs/ / nam mkha'i sprin bzhin du/ / na bun ni glo bur pa/ / btsan thabs kyis mi dgag par/ / shugs 'byung gi stobs kyis dgag /
Like the flow of a river, it is taught that we must carry on. Like clouds in the sky, thoughts are adventitious. They are not stopped by forceful means— they cease naturally.[22] (141–48)
dngos po gsal bar byed pa zhes bya ba rje btsun mi la nyid kyis mdzad pa rdzogs so/ /
This completes “The Illumination of Entities” composed by Jetsun Milarepa himself.
snyi ba rin po che las brgyud de 'ongs pa/ / lho pa {la yag pa byang chub dngos grub/} rin po che la gnang ba'o/ / des bdag la gnang ba'o/ ! /
This came from the transmission through Nyiwa Rinpoche, who bestowed it upon Lhopa Rinpoche {[*13] Layakpa Jangchup Ngödrup},[*13] who bestowed it upon me {[*14] Dusum Khyenpa}.[*14]
rje btsun mi la'i ma rig gsal byed ces bya ba/ /
The Clarification of Ignorance (19.2)
bla ma grub thob rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the siddha-gurus.
bla ma dam pa'i drin thob nas/ / mthun pa'i gnas dang grub pa'i rdzas/ / 'tsho ba'i {dus gsum mkhyen pa/} yo byed bsags byas la/ / rkyen bzhi ldan pa shin tu gces/ /

Having received the genuine guru’s kindness, you need a conducive location, the substances for accomplishment, and to gather the materials for sustenance. It’s important to possess those four conditions. (2.1–2.4)
bya ba btang ba'i skyes bu yis/ / ji ltar chu dag dwangs pa las/ / nya dag myur du 'phar ba ltar/ / skad cig tsam gyis lha ru bskyed/ /
Beings who have given up activities, like a fish quickly leaping from crystal clear water,[23] in an instant generate the deity. (2.5–2.8)
lam ni rnam pa gnyis gsungs te/ / smin par byed pa nyid dang ni/ / grol bar byed pa nyid yin no/ /
The path is taught to be twofold: one that matures and one that liberates. (2.9–2.11)
smin par byed la lam dang ni/ / dbang ni rnam pa gsum du gsungs/ / smin te grol bar byed pa ni/ / bskyed pa dang ni rdzogs pa'o/ /
The path that matures is said to be the three abhiṣekas. Having been matured, what liberates is generation and perfection. (2.12–2.15)
bskyed pa de yang gnyis yin te/ / bskyed pa dang ni skyes pa'o/ / rdzogs pa la yang gnyis yin te/ / spros dang lhan cig skyes pa'o/ /
Generation is twofold: generation and arising. Perfection is also twofold: [with] elaborations and connate. (2.16–2.19)
spros bcas lus la rtsa dang rlung / / rlung la shes pa thig les brtan/ / de la mi rtog skye bar rigs/ / lus gnas lus la skyes pa'o/ /

With elaborations. In the body, there are channels and winds. The bindus stabilize the mind with the winds. That is able to give rise to nonconceptuality. Present in the body, it arises in the body. {114}
lus (114) la gnas kyang lus skyes min/ / dper na gru dang khang pa bzhin/ /
Though residing in the body, it doesn’t originate from the body,[24] like, for example, [the relationship we have with] boats and houses.[*15] (2.20–2.25)
nges lam 'bras bur bcas pa ni/ / bla ma dam pa'i drin thob nas/ / thabs lam las ni ma gtogs pa/ / yang dag yin no nga mi zer/ /
Having achieved the definitive path with its results through the kindness of the genuine guru, I do not say, “This is authentic,” except when referring to the path of method. (2.26–2.29)
rtogs pa'i khyad par ci byung yang / / ngag gi lam gyi yul las 'das/ / chags lam pa yi grol lam pa/ / tsum+ba ka yi sbyor ba yis/ / rtsol ba drag tu bsgrub par bya/ /

Whatever distinctive realizations arise, they are beyond being objects of the path of speech. Those on the path of liberation, [engaged in] the path of passion, should practice forceful control[25] using the yogic techniques of kumbhaka.[26]
srog rtsol gnas su 'jug par nges/ /
It is certain that prāṇāyāma will enter the locations. (2.30–2.35)
'byung ba gcig la gcig thim 'gyur/ / tsaN+Da lI ni shugs la 'bar/ / byang chub sems ni 'bar bar nges/ /
The elements dissolve one into another, and caṇḍālī blazes naturally.[27] It is certain that bodhicitta will blaze. (2.36–2.38)
nang gis tsha grang 'dres pa'i rtags/ / dang po dro ba lta bu 'byung / / gnyis pa du ba lta bu 'byung / / 'du ba rnam bzhis gnod mi nus/ /
The signs of mixing heat and cold internally are that first something like warmth arises. Second, something like smoke arises. The four gatherings are unable to harm.[28] (2.39–2.42)
de la lus ni bsgrub pa gces/ / lus ni brtan par gyur pa la/ / rtags ni rnam pa sna tshogs 'byung / / dga' ba rnam bzhi rim gyis 'byung / /
That is important practice for the body. When the body is stabilized, myriad signs occur. The four joys arise in sequence. (2.43–2.46)
phyi yi tsha grang bzod pa dang / / lus la srog chags nyung ba dang / / sha bkrag gting nas 'bar ba dang / / lus la dri ma mi chags dang / /
You will be able to tolerate external heat and cold. Your body will have few bugs. Your skin will glow deeply. Your body won’t smell. (2.47–2.50)
shing bal ltar ni yang ba dang / / brkyang bskum gang yang bde ba dang / kha sna'i snabs lud nyung ba dang / / lus la dri zhim 'byung ba dang / /

Like cotton, you will be light. Whether you stretch or contract [your limbs], you will be comfortable. You will have little saliva in your mouth and mucus in your nose. Your body will be fragrant. (2.51–2.54)
zas skom 'du shes chung ba dang / / rna bas sgra snyan thos pa dang / / gnyid kyi rtog pa chung ba dang / /
You will have few thoughts of food and drink. You will hear pleasant sounds with your ears. You will have few thoughts of sleep. (2.55–2.57)
dri ba'i lan la mkhas pa dang / / smra rgu snyan par smra ba dang / / tshig gi sdeb sbyor mkhas pa dang / / rang gi skyon rnams 'chos pa dang / /
You will be skilled in replying to questions. What you say will be said pleasantly. You will be skilled at composition. You will correct your mistakes. (2.58–2.61)
smra ba don dang mthun pa dang / / pha rol skyon rnams 'chos pa dang / / rdzas la chog shes yod pa dang / / 'khor bar skyo ba skyes pa dang / /
Your speech will be in keeping with the facts. You will be able to correct others’ mistakes. You will be content with material things. You will feel weariness for saṃsāra. (2.62–2.65)
dben pa'i gnas la dga' ba dang / / gcig bur sdod snying 'dod pa dang / / yang yang bsgom snying 'dod pa dang / / lus nyid yod du mi tshor dang / /
You will delight in isolated places; your heartfelt desire will be to remain alone. You will repeatedly long in your heart to meditate. You will not sense the presence of your body. (2.66–2.69)
yul la nges pa med pa dang / / gnas gcig ther zug mi gnas dang / / (115) DA ki'i tshogs rnams 'du ba dang / / rmi lam lung bstan thob pa dang / /
chos la byan po thob pa dang / / mngon shes rim gyis 'byung ba dang / / dri lugs la sogs 'byung ba dang / / phyi nang bsre bar nus pa dang / /
You will develop mastery of the dharma. Supercognitive abilities will gradually develop. Pills and so forth will emerge.[29] You will be able to blend outer and inner.[30] (2.74–2.77)
bsdam bya gnod pa med pa dang / / dus la bab na gtong ba dang / / dus min lha ni gsod par byed/ / de la yid ches byar mi rung / / de la yid ches skyes gyur na/ / rnam rtog bdud kyi dbang du 'gro/ /

What [normally] should be avoided will not cause harm. When the time comes, send [your consciousness] off. [If] it is not time, you will kill the deities.[31] It’s not suitable to trust that. If you trust that, your thoughts have come under the power of māras. (2.78–2.83)
de da yin te de nyid min/ / sdong bu yin te 'bras bu min/ / yon tan yin te rtog med min/ /
That is so, but that’s not it. It’s the trunk, not the fruit. It’s a good quality but it’s not nonconceptual. (2.84–2.86)
nyam dang lta ba 'jom pa la/ / bdud bzhi'i dgra yis mi tshugs shing / / snang ba had por 'gro bar nges/ / phyi yi yul ni brtag mi thub/ /

When your experiences meet with the view,[32] the enemies of the four māras can’t take hold. It is certain that appearances arise in a flash.[33] External objects can’t [withstand] examination. (2.87–2.90)
rang gi rang gsal nang na gsal/ / dper na lkugs pa'i rmi lam mam/ / gzhon nu ma yi bde ba bzhin/ /
[Mind] illuminates itself by itself, illuminating within.[34] It’s like the dreams of a mute or the pleasure of a young person. (2.91–2.93)

tha snyad tshig tu brjod tsam na/ / tsha grang 'dres pa'i yon tan gyis/ / 'du ba rnam bzhis gnod mi nus/ / bza' btung la sogs mi dgos pas/ / bshang gci la sogs 'byung mi 'gyur/ / mchog gi dngos grub shugs kyis 'byung / /

To simply state things using conventional expressions, through the excellent qualities of mixing hot and cold, the four gatherings are unable to harm.[35] Since you don’t need food or drink, you won’t produce feces, urine, and the like. The supreme siddhi naturally arises. (2.94–2.99)

lam la brten pa'i tshong pa yis/ / ma bgrod bsam kyang phyin mi 'gyur/ / tshong byas zas nor 'phel ba ltar/ / lam la brten pa'i rnal 'byor gyis/ / nyams myong rim gyis skye bar 'gyur/ / thabs la ma brten chos kyis ni/ / nyams su blangs kyang res 'jog tsam/ /

[If] traders whose [livelihood] depends on being on the road don’t travel, they don’t arrive even though they think about it. [Nevertheless,] their business, food, and wealth does increase. Similarly, yogins and yoginīs who rely on the path gradually develop experiences. Dharma [practitioners] who don’t rely on methods are cultivating experiences but those will be sporadic. (2.100–2.106)
rtogs snyam byed cing bogs mi thon/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis sdem dgongs la/ / sems can rigs spyod bcug pa tsam/ / de nyid yin na de nyid 'gal/ /

That will create the idea of “realization,” and it won’t enhance [your practice]. The buddhas, as [expressions of] indirect intentions,[36] simply engage the conduct belonging to sentient beings. If that were it, it would be a contradiction. (2.107–2.110)
thos bsam mkhas pa'i mi rnams kyang / / tshig la rno la don la brtul/ / gol sgrib gdar sha bcad pa la/ / shugs 'byung snying las ma chod na/ / thos pa mang pos de mi chod/ /

People who are skilled in listening and reflecting may be clever with words but in a fog about the meaning. As for eradicating the obscurations of straying, if they aren’t cut through naturally from the heart, you won’t be able to cut through them with lots of study. (2.111–2.115)

thos pa mang pos chod gyur na/ / mkhas pa dmyal bar ga la 'gyur/ / rang rig rang la shar ba la/ / thos pa mang pos der mi skyob/ / dper na sman dpyad bklag pa yis/ / nad pa'i nad sel ga la nus/ / ma bsgoms chos kyang de bzhin no/ /

If lots of study could cut through them, how could scholars go to hell? Although reflexive awareness arises within ourselves, lots of study won’t protect us there. For example, how can reading about medical treatments clear up the illness of a sick person? The dharma not meditated upon is like that. (2.116–2.122)
shes rab ye shes dbang gi dus/ / (116) kha cig de nyid mthong zhes zer/ / nga ni de la 'thad pa med/ / zla ba yin te bco lnga min/ / shes pa yin te rtog med min/ /

At the time of the prajñājñāna abhiṣeka, {116} some say, “I see suchness.” For me, that is not reasonable. It’s the moon but not the fifteenth, [the full moon]. It is recognition but it’s not nonconceptual. (2.123–2.127)
grib ma yin te lus po min/ / mtshon par bya ba tsam du bas/ / des na thabs lam brten par bya/ /
It is not waning but it’s not full. Since that’s just what is pointed to, you must rely on the path of method. (2.128–2.130)
tshogs lam brgal ba'i gang zag la/ / dngos dang yid la byed pa'o/ / yid la byed pa'i dus tsam na/ / gang 'dod yid kyis blang bar bya/ /
Individuals who have progressed beyond the path of accumulation engage with an actual [vidyā] and bring [a vidyā] to mind. When bringing [a vidyā] to mind, bring to mind one you desire. (2.131–2.134)
de dang lhan cig rol ba na/ / bsam pa ji ltar 'dod par byed/ / de ni yid kyi spyod yul lo/ /
When you frolic with that one, create desire in keeping with your intentions. That is a mental sphere of experience. (2.135–2.137)
rig ma dngos su bsten byed na/ / mtshan ldan rgyud sde kun nas bshad/ / rnal 'byor nga yi 'dod pa ni/ / yid du gang 'ong mtshan ldan yin/ /

When you actually practice with a vidyā, their qualifications are explained in all classes of tantras. The assertion of me, a yogin, is that those who are pleasing have the qualifications. (2.138–2.141)
mang po 'tshogs na spyod lam mdzes/ / gsang spyod byed na khrel dang bral/ / de dang dben pa'i gnas nyid du/ / nyam nga med pa'i spyod pa bya/ /

When gathering with many, your conduct should be agreeable. When performing secret conduct, it should be unhindered by modesty. In an isolated place, engage in the conduct without intimidation.[37] (2.142–2.145)
ma dang bu mo sring mo yang / / khyad par can gyi rten du 'gyur/ / yon tan 'byung gis skyon du min/ / yon tan med pa'i gdams ngag gis/ / de la bsam par mi bya'o/ /
Mothers, daughters, and sisters are special supports. Excellent qualities will arise, faults will not.[38] Individuals lacking the excellent qualities should not consider that.[39] (2.146–2.150)
rgyud sde kun nas bshad pa la/ / ma sring bsten no bshad pa ni/ / sangs rgyas bka' ni sdem dgongs la/ kha cig gis ni med par mthong / /

The explanation in all classes of tantras is “practice with your mother and sisters.” Those words of the Buddha are indirect intentional statements,[40] though some see them as ultimate.[41] (2.151–2.154)

don dang mthun par mi bsgrub par/ / des na gang zag spyod par blang / / sbyor thabs mi shes rnal 'byor dang / / stan yang gcig la bsten gyur na/ / so so skye bo'i spyod pa rnams/ / phan yon mi 'byung skyon du 'gyur/ /

Individuals who do not practice in accordance with the meaning and yet take up the practices, if they do not understand the methods of union and abide even on one seat with [this] yoga,[42] will be practicing the conduct of ordinary beings and won’t get any benefits—faults will ensue. (2.155–2.160)
des na sbyor thabs mkhas pas bsten/ / 'ga' dang 'ga' yi spyod yul las/ / kun gyi spyod yul 'di ma yin/ /
Therefore, practice the methods of union with skill. It is a sphere of practice for a few— not a sphere of practice for all.[43] (2.161–2.163)
des na gsang sngags spyod pa rnams/ / thabs lam ma song tho cor song / / yo tan ma song 'phyas lam song / / des na gsang ba spyad par bya/ /

Thus, all practices of Secret Mantra don’t proceed on the path of method—[some] become coarse. [Some] don’t lead to excellent qualities—they become a reviled path. Thus, practice in secret. (2.164–2.167)
gsang sngags zab mo'i gdams ngag 'di/ / thabs lam tsam las ma gtogs pa/ / lta bas 'phags so da mi zer/ /

ji ltar rna bar chu zhugs pa/ / chu (117) zhan gyis ni 'gugs par byed/ / ji ltar khong du dug zhugs pa/ / slar yang dug gis 'byin par byed/ khye 'us khye'u 'byin pa dang / / dri mas dri ma 'khrud pa bzhin/ / nad rnams 'tsho bar byed 'dod na/ / sman gyi yan lag bsam mi khyab/ /

Just as water in the ear {117} is extracted by more water, just as ingested poison is drawn out by more poison, just as children bring more children, just as scents are cleansed by scents, if you wish to heal all illnesses, there are infinite branches of medicine.
des na thabs kyi lam 'di gces/ /
Therefore, this path of method is important. (2.171–2.179)
gzhan du kha cig 'di skad zer/ / bskyed rim bsgom pa'i yon tan gyis/ / chos sku skye ba med pa las/ / gzugs sku gnyis su ldang nas ni/ / sems can 'gro don byed do zer/ /
Some speak in this way: through the excellent qualities of cultivating the generation process, from the unborn dharmakāya, the two form kāyas arise, benefiting sentient beings. (2.180–2.184)
nga ni de la 'thad pa med/ / chos sku rnam dag med pa la/ / gzugs sku rnam dag 'byung rig sam/ /
For me, that is not reasonable. Is it possible that the nonexistent pure dharmakāya arises as the pure form kāyas?[44] (2.185–2.187)

'o na ji ltar yin zhe na/ / sa la gnas pa'i byang sems dang / / sems can bsam pa dag pa la/ / sngon gyi bsod nams stobs dag dang / / thugs rje chen po'i stobs dag gi / de ltar snang gis dngos su min/ /

In that case, how is it? For bodhisattvas dwelling on the bhūmis and sentient beings with pure intentions, through the strength of previous merit and the strength of great compassion, those [form kāyas] appear as such but they are not actual. (2.188–2.193)
sgyu ma mkhan gyis ci sprul yang / / sgyu ma mkhan nyid der song med/ / rtogs par dka' ba'i don 'di ni/ / gnyis su med pa'i lta ba yin/ /
No matter what a magician conjures up, the magician doesn’t become that. This point, hard to comprehend, is the nondual view. (2.194–2.197)
ma hA mu tra'i dgongs pa la/ / rang gi 'od gsal gyi shes pa/ / cir yang mi rtog don de nyid/ / tshig dang yi ges mtshon nas ni/ / sangs rgyas zhal nas gsungs pa na/ /
As for the realization of mahāmudrā, it is your own luminous mind, a wholly nonconceptual state, taught by the buddhas, using words and letters. (2.198–2.202)
rang la yod de rtogs pa med/ / ce re 'dug kyang long ba/ / dmigs pa med pa'i thabs lam/ / mtshan ma'i sku la slob pa/ /
It is present within you but is not realized. Though your eyes are wide open, you are blind. The path of methods that brings observation is taught to qualified beings.[45] (2.203–2.206)
rnam dag bshur la 'debs pa/ / nyon mongs rim gyis 'gags pa/ / mi rtog shugs las 'byung ba/ / rnal 'byor lam gyi rim pa/ / gzhan la bstan du 'phang ba/ /
Thoughts are dispersed,[46] mental afflictions gradually cease, and nonconceptuality automatically arises. The process of the path of yoga is too precious to show to others.[47] (2.207–2.211)
snod dang ldan la sbyin pa/ / nyams can rnams kyi lta ba/ / nyams su myong na tshim pa/ /
Give it to those who are worthy recipients. Those with experiences will behold it. If they practice, they will be satisfied. (2.212–2.214)
tshig dang yi ge bsdebs pa/ / kun gyi spyod yul min pa/ / spyod pa yangs dogs med pa/ / bla ma'i drin lan sob pa/ /
It is not the sphere of experience of all, of those who stitch together words and letters. Conduct is neither spacious nor confined.[48] Repay the guru’s kindness. (2.215–2.218)
gcig pur dben par sdod pa/ / rang sems gtan la 'bebs/(118)pa/ / 'chi ba rjes su dran pa/ / ngan song gsum gyi 'jigs pa la/ / bla ma brgyud pa'i rim pa bstan/ /
Stay alone in isolation. Determine your own mind. {118} Remember death. Fear the three lower realms. Explain the transmissions of the gurus. (2.219–2.223)
gzhan tu rnal 'byor lus dang gcig / nyams su blangs pa'i chos dang gnyis/ / nyams myong skyes pa'i lus dang gsum/ / 'di gsum shin tu gsang na legs/ /
dad pa can gyi ngor byas pa'o/ /
This was done for those with faith.
drin tu gzo bar gyis shig /
Repay kindness. (2.228–2.229)
rje mi la ras pa'i nyams myong yi ger bkod pa/ / ma rig gsal byed ces bya ba rdzogs so/ /
This completes the record of the exalted Milarepa’s experiences in words called, “The Clarification of Ignorance.”
sa mA staM/ /
samāstaṃ
snyi ba rin po che las brgyud/ !
It was transmitted by Nyiwa Rinpoche.
rje btsun mi la'i rnam rtog dri ma dag byed ces bya ba/ /
The Purification of the Stains of Thoughts (19.3)
dam pa de la phyag 'tshal lo/ / snod du rung bar bya ba'i phyir/ / dbang gi go ba rnam pa gnyis/ / gdod nas rang chas gnas pa dang / / rkyen gyi dbang gis bskur tshul lo/ /

Homage to the holy ones. For those who are suitable recipients, the understanding of the abhiṣekas involves two aspects: what abides as the primordial innate quality and the way the abhiṣekas of conditions are bestowed. (3.1–4)
nyams su blangs pa'i thabs tshul dang / / nyams blangs rtogs pa shar tshul gnyis/ / de ni dbang gis go bar mthong / /
There are two approaches: the methods to be practiced and the arising of the realizations to be practiced. Those are [the ways] to see what was understood through the abhiṣekas. (3.5–3.7)
dam tshig la yang gnyis su 'dod/ / bsrung dang ye bsrung chen po'o/ / bza' bsrung gnyis su 'dod pa ni/ / de ni bsrung ba'i dam tshig go / ye bsrung chen po 'bras bu dngos/ /

Samaya is said to be twofold: what is observed and the great primordial observation. What is observed related to food is said to be twofold. That is the samaya to be observed. The great primordial observation is the actual result. (3.8–3.12)
lta ba yang ni gnyis su 'dod/ / lta ba gtan la 'beb lugs dang / / lta ba gtan la phebs lugs so/ /
The view is also said to be twofold:[49] the view when it is to be determined and the view when it has been determined. (3.13–3.15)
lta ba gtan la 'beb thabs ni/ / rtsa rlung 'khor lo gtsigs su che/ / srog rtsol gnad du ma tshud na/ / dbab thabs 'byung ba rig ma yin/ / des na thabs lam khyad du 'phags/ /

As the methods for determining the view, the channels, winds, and cakras are important. If you do not engage the vital points of prāṇāyāma, you will not determine the view.[50] Thus, the path of method is especially distinguished. (3.16–3.20)

gtan la phebs pa'i lta ba ni/ / nga 'dra rmongs pa ma yin gyi/ / yang dag rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis kyang / / lkugs dang gzhon nu ji bzhin du / mtshon pa tsam las ma gtogs pa/ / ngo bo bstan par nus ma yin/ /

As for the view when it has been determined, it is not for the ignorant like me. Even the complete perfect buddhas are unable to show its essence, except for simply pointing to it, like [using the examples of] a mute or young person. (3.21–3.26)
sgom pa la yang rnam gnyis te/ / bsgom du yod dang med pa gnyis/ / mtshan ma'i sku yi rnal 'byor pas/ / de ni bsgom du yod pa yin/ / ngo bo nyid kyang de la bya/ / (119)

Meditation is also twofold: when there is something to cultivate and when there is nothing to cultivate. There are the two: with characteristics and without characteristics. Śamatha and so forth are when there is something to cultivate.[51] (3.27–3.31) {119}
skyon yon gnyis kyang de 'byung rigs/ / bcos thabs grangs kyis mi long gis/ / stong pa'i go cha gcigs su che/ /
There it is possible that both faults and virtues arise. Although there are countless remedial methods, the armor of emptiness is of greatest value.[52] (3.32–3.34)
nges pa'i shes pa mi skye bar/ / nyams rtogs 'byung bar ga la rig / nges pa'i shes pa skye ba la/ / bla ma dam pa'i drin thob nas/ / gcig pu dben pa'i gnas bsten nas/ /

When certainty has not arisen, how can experiences and realizations manifest?[53] When certainty has arisen, and you have received the kindness of genuine gurus, remain alone in an isolated place. (3.35–3.39)
srog rtsol gnas su tshud gyur na/ / nang gi tsha grang 'dres par nges/ / nges pa'i shes pa skye bar nges/ / rnam par rtog pa rim gyis 'gogs/ /
Once prāṇāyāma enters the locations, it is certain that heat and cold will mix internally. It is definite that certainty will arise. Thoughts will gradually stop. (3.40–3.43)
phyi yi snang ba na bun tsam/ / bla med yul des gnod mi nus/ / yang dag don gyi de nyid la/ / bsgom bya sgom byed gnyis su med/ /
External appearances will be misty. The highest cannot be harmed by objects.[54] In the suchness of the true nature, the duality of an object of meditation and a meditator is absent. (3.44–3.47)
spyod pa la'ang gnyis su 'dod/ / spyod du yod dam med gnyis so/ /
Conduct is said to be twofold: when there is something to engage and when there is nothing to engage.
spyod du yod pa'i dus tsam na/ / lkugs pa smyon pa'i tshul du spyod/ / spyad du med pa'i dus tsam na/ / de nyid spyod pa'i mchog yin no/ /
When there is something to engage, engage in the manner of mutes and the insane. When there is nothing to engage, that is the best conduct. (3.48–3.53)
'bras bu la yang rnam pa gnyis/ / chos sku gzugs sku gnyis su 'dod/ /
The results are said to be twofold: the dharmakāya and the two form kāyas.
chos sku'i rang bzhin ngo bo ni/ / nam mkha'i phyogs cha kha gting med/ / 'di zhes bya bar gdags mi nus/ /
As for the essence, the nature, of the dharmakāya, like the sphere of space with neither top nor bottom, it can’t be designated, saying, “It is this.” (3.54–3.58)
re dogs spang blang dgag sgrub med/ / mdzub mos zla ba ston pa bzhin/ / tshig la brten nas mtshon pa tsam/ /
There is nothing to hope for or fear, reject or adopt, block or establish. Like pointing a finger at the moon, words simply indicate it. (3.59–3.61)
don nyid rang yang ma grub par/ / 'di 'dra bstan du ga la yod/ /
The state itself does not exist. How could something like this be shown?
yod na bstan pas mthong bar rigs/ / smra ba mkhan gyis don ston yang / / tshig phyir blo 'brang snying re rje/ /
If it existed, it would be possible to see it when someone shows it. Eloquent ones teach the meaning— how sad that some minds pursue [just] the words![55] (3.62–3.66)
yod med gnyis las 'das pa'am/ / rtag chad gnyis kyis stong pa la/ / lan cig tshig gis mtshon du bas/ / de lta bu yi mtshan nyid la/ / gzugs sku 'byung bar ga la rigs/ /

It transcends existence and nonexistence, and is empty of permanence and annihilation. [Just] revealing that once with words, [we then ask:] How is it possible that [the dharmakāya with] those characteristics arises as the form kāyas?[56] (3.67–3.71)
sangs rgyas ldem por dgongs pa la/ kha cig de las 'byung ngo zer/ / nga ni de la 'thad pa med/ / 'o na ji ltar 'byung zhe na/ /
As an indirect intentional statement of the buddhas, some say those [form kāyas] arise from it. For me, that is not reasonable. In that case, how do they arise? (3.72–3.75)
gzugs sku gnyis su 'byung ba ni/ / sems can snang ba dag pa la/ / sngon gyi smon lam stobs dag gis/ / ji ltar 'dug bzhin (120)so sor snang / /
The two form kāyas arise as follows: For sentient beings with pure outlook, [the form kāyas] appear distinctly in keeping with the strength of their previous aspiration prayers. (3.76–3.79) {120}
snang ba yin phyir de nyid min/ / phal la smras na skrag par 'gyur/ / sangs rgyas sems can don mi 'chad/ / chos kyang nub par ga la 'gyur/ /

Since they are appearances, they are not suchness. If that is said to ordinary people, they will become afraid. The buddhas don’t stop benefiting sentient beings. How could the dharma vanish? (3.80–3.83)
rnam rtog dri ma dag byed 'di/ / slob ma rnams kyi ngor bshad do/ / tshig tu smras kyis nyams su longs/ / nyams myong smra thabs nga la med/ /
This “Purification of the Stains of Thoughts” has been explained for disciples. Practice with what has been put into words. I have no means of talking about experiences.
rgyas par smra ru sdus shig zer/ / tshig tu go sla smras nas bzhag /
“Condense the details,” you said. I spoke words easy to understand and set them down. (3.84–3.89)
rnam rtog dri ma dag byed ces bya ba rje btsun mi la ras pas mdzad pa rdzogs so// ! /
This completes “The Purification of the Stains of Thoughts” composed by Jetsun Milarepa.
phyag rgya chen po ye shes gsal byed kyi ngo sprod bzhugs so/ /
Mahāmudrā: Pointing-Out Instructions Illuminating Wisdom (19.4)
bla ma dam pa rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the genuine gurus.
phyag rgya chen po ye shes gsal byed kyi man ngag 'di la/ / phyag rgya chen po'i mtshan nyid bstan pa la gsum/ / gzhi phyag rgya chen po/ lam phyag rgya chen po/ / 'bras bu phyag rgya chen po/ /
In these esoteric instructions, Mahāmudrā: The Illumination of Wisdom, the explanation of the characteristics of mahāmudrā is threefold: ground mahāmudrā, path mahāmudrā, and resultant mahāmudrā.
[gzhi phyag rgya chen po]
[Ground Mahāmudrā]

dang po dngos po gshis kyi gnas lugs sangs rgyas kyi dgongs pa/ sems can gyi chos nyid/ kha dog dbyibs su ma grub/ mtha' dang dbus su ma grub pa/ rgya chad phyogs lhung dang bral ba/ yod ma myong / med ma myong / ma 'khrul ma grol/ rgyus ma bskyed/ rkyen gyis ma bsgyur/ sangs rgyas mkhas te ma bcos/ sems can bsgrin te ma bslad/ rtogs pas bzang du ma song / 'khrul pas ngan du ma song / de ni gzhi la gnas pas/ gzhi phyag rgya chen po'o/ /

First, the abiding state, the basic state of entities, is the mind of buddhas and the dharmatā of sentient beings. It does not exist with a color or shape. It does not exist with an edge or center. It is neither limited nor partial. It has never existed and never not existed. It is neither confused nor free. It is not produced from causes and is not changed by conditions. The wise buddhas don’t fabricate it, and obscured[57] sentient beings don’t adulterate it. Realization doesn’t make it excellent, and confusion doesn’t make it bad. Since it is present as the ground, it is ground mahāmudrā.
lam phyag rgya chen po ni/
Path Mahāmudrā

gzhi de'i steng du nyams su blangs pas chog / 'jog dus dmigs med du 'jog / gnas na yengs med du gnas/ khyer dus 'dzin med du khyer/ 'char na chos nyid du 'char/ grol dus na rang grol du 'gro ba gcig nyams su len pa'o/ /

Practicing right with that ground is sufficient. When resting, rest without reference point. When still, be still without distraction. When integrating [experiences into the path], integrate them without grasping. When things arise, they arise as dharmatā. When things liberate, they liberate in and of themselves. That is the practice.
'bras bu phyag rgya chen po ni/
Resultant Mahāmudrā

grol bya dang grol byed dang bral ba/ re dogs dang bral ba/ blo zad chos zad 'dzin med zhen pa dang blo las 'das pas (121)bsam brjod bral ba/ gzhi lam 'bras bu gsum dbyer med du nyams su len pa'o/ / phyag rgya chen po ye shes gsal byed kyi zhal gyi gdams pa rje btsun mi la rnal 'byor gyis mdzad pa'o/ // (122) (123)

It is without something to be liberated and a means of liberation. It is without hopes and fear. It is the exhaustion of mind, the exhaustion of phenomena, the absence of grasping. {121} Since it transcends fixation and the intellect, it is beyond expression and thought. Ground, path, and result are to be practiced as inseparable. These oral instructions, Mahāmudrā: The Illumination of Wisdom, were composed by Jetsun Mila Yogin. ithi

A. The Abhiṣekas for Maturation
@#/ /dpal 'khor lo bde mchog dwags po snyan brgyud lugs kyi sgrub thabs bde chen drwa ba bzhugs so// //
20. Net of Great Bliss. The Sādhana for the Dakpo Aural Transmission Tradition of the Glorious Cakrasaṃvara[1]
(124)@#/ /na mo gu ru shrI tsakra sam+ba ra ya/
namo guru śrīcakrasaṃvaraya

I bow respectfully to the gurus, omnipresent lords, inseparable from the one who binds all phenomena of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa in the net of immutable great bliss and emptiness endowed with the most sublime of manifestations. I will present the sādhana of the Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Aural Transmission.

The contents of this root text are difficult to implement except in the context of specifically doing the practice of the Aural Transmission, [so they are difficult to implement when] bestowing abhiṣekas and doing a general sādhanapūjā. Therefore, I have abbreviated them. In a place that is isolated and in keeping with [what is specified in] the tantras, such as a charnel ground, practitioners who have received the abhiṣekas and have not impaired their samayas should begin on a tenth lunar day of the waxing or waning moon. Gather the necessary items for the sādhana: representations, offerings, amṛta, ḍamaru, ghaṇṭā, and so forth.
nyams len dngos la gsum/ sngon 'gro/ dngos gzhi/ rjes kyi rim pa'o/ /

de'i steng du ka~M gsum las thod pa bum ril gyi sgyed po ltag pa nang du bstan pa gsum gyi

steng du/ yi ge a yongs su gyur pa las/ ka pA la phyi dkar la nang dmar ba dum bu gcig pa/ dpral ba rang la bstan pa/ rgya khyon chos kyi dbyings dang mnyam pa/ /

de'i dbus su baM las dri chu la mU/ shar du lA~M las dri chen la bi/ lhor mA~M` las rak+ta la ra/ nub tu pA~M las byang sems dkar po la shU/ byang du tA~M las klad pa la mA/

rang gi thugs ka nas rlung hU~M gi dbyibs can 'phros/ rlung gi dkyil 'khor la phog / ba dan bskyod/ me sbar/ thod pa dros/ rdzas rnams khol/ nyes pa'i skyon rnams lbu ba'i rnam par phyir lud/ de'i steng du oM AHhU~M gsum las 'od zer 'phros pas/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi thugs ka nas ye shes kyi bdud rtsi bkug ste dam tshig gi bdud rtsi dang gnyis su med pa'i bdud rtsi'i rgya mtsho chen por gyur/

From my heart, wind in the shape of hūṃs streams out. It strikes the wind maṇḍala. The banners flap, the fire blazes, the skull cup heats up, and the substances boil. Above that, from oṃ āḥ hūṃ, light radiates, drawing wisdom amṛta from the hearts of the tathāgatas, creating a great ocean of amṛta that is nondual with samaya amṛta.

A. The Outer Practice: Guru Yoga

rang gi spyi bor pa~M las pad+ma ra~M las nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor gyi steng du bla ma rdo rje sems dpa' bde chen 'khor lo sku mdog gangs ri'i phung po la nyi ma shar ba lta bu zhal gcig phyag gnyis pa/ spyan gsum rab tu dmar zhing g.yo ba/ mche ba bzhi gtsigs pa/ phyag gnyis rdo rje dang dril bu 'dzin pas yum la 'khyud pa/ yum rdo rje snyems ma sku mdog dkar mo gri gug dang thod khrag 'dzin pas yab la 'khyud pa/

On my head, from paṃ, is a lotus, and from raṃ, a sun maṇḍala. Above that is guru Vajrasattva, the mahāsukhacakra, with a color like the sun shining on a massive snow mountain, with one face and two arms. His three eyes are very red and moving. His four fangs are bared. Holding a vajra and ghaṇṭā in his hands, he embraces his consort. His consort Vajragarvā is white. Holding a hooked knife and skull cup of blood, she embraces her consort.

zhabs g.yas brkyangs g.yon bskums pa'i gar gyis bzhengs pa/ ral pa'i thor cog dang rus pa'i rgyan drug / rin po che sna tshogs kyi phreng ba dang / rdo rje phreng ba dang me tog gi phreng ba du mas brgyan pa/ 'od dang 'od zer gyi phung po gar dgu'i nyams dang ldan cing dam tshig ye shes gnyis su med pa/

He stands in a dancing posture with right leg extended and left, bent. His hair is in a topknot, and he is adorned with the six bone ornaments, garlands of various jewels, garlands of vajras, and many garlands of flowers. In a mass of light and light rays, he displays the nine moods of the dramatic arts. He is the nonduality of samaya and wisdom.

de'i 'khor lo lnga la pad+ma dang nyi ma'i gdan gyi steng du spyi bor de bzhin gshegs pa rdo rje sems dpa' yab yum sku mdog dkar po/ mgrin par gar gyi dbang phyug yab yum dmar po/ snying gar he ru ka yab yum sngon po/ lte bar rdo rje nyi ma yab yum ser po/ gsang gnas su rdo rje rgyal po yab yum ljang gu ste yab yum thams cad kyang rgyan dang cha lugs gtso bo lta bur mtshan dang dpe byad yongs su rdzogs pa'i skur gyur/

In his five cakras are lotus and sun seats. At the top of his head is the tathāgata Vajrasattva, white male and female consorts. At his throat is Padmanarteśvara, red male and female consorts. At his heart is Heruka, blue male and female consorts. At his navel is Vajrasūrya, yellow male and female consorts. At his secret place is Vajrarāja, green male and female consorts. All the male and female consorts have ornaments and attributes like the principal ones, and their forms are complete with the major and minor marks.

de'i dpral bar oM dkar po/ mgrin par AHdmar po/ snying gar so so'i mdog gi pad+ma'i steng na nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor/ de dag gi steng du hU~M so so'i mdog can (129) gyi mtha' mar sngags kyi phreng bas bskor bar gyur/

At their foreheads are white oṃs, at their throats are red āḥs, and at their hearts are lotuses of their respective colors, above which are sun maṇḍalas, above which are hūṃs of their respective colors surrounded by mantra garlands. {129}
oM badzra Ar+g+haM pra tIts+tsha swA hA/ sogs kyis
oṃ vajra arghaṃ pratīccha hūṃ svāhā…
mchod nas gsol ba gdab pa ni/
Thus, offer. Next, the supplication.
bcom ldan 'das rdo rje sems dpa' yab yum gyis bdag dang mtha' yas pa'i sems can thams cad kyi sdig sgrib nyes ltung dri ma'i tshogs thams cad byang zhing dag par mdzad du gsol/ ces pas
Bhagavān Vajrasattva, male and female consorts, please cleanse and purify the negative actions, obscurations, flaws, downfalls, and mass of stains of myself and all limitless sentient beings.
lan gsum du gsol ba btab pas/
Supplicate three times.

lha tshogs rnams kyi sku gsung thugs las ye shes kyi bdud rtsi dkar dmar sngon po dpag tu med pa na ra ra tshangs bug tu bab/ lus phyi nang thams cad khyab/ phyi lus kyi sdig sgrib nang sems kyi sdig sgrib nyes ltung dri ma'i tshogs thams cad rkang mthil sor mo rgyud du nag nur gyis don pas/ lus thams cad shel gong dag pa ltar gyur/

From the body, speech, and mind of the assembled deities, an immeasurable stream of white, red, and blue wisdom amṛta falls to my opening of Brahmā. It pervades my body, inside and out. All the negative actions and obscurations of my external body and all the negative actions, obscurations, flaws, downfalls, and mass of stains of my internal mind are expelled as a thick black stream from the soles of my feet and toes. My body becomes like a pure crystal sphere.
oM badzra he ru ka sa ma ya sogs
oṃ vajraheruka samaya…
he ru ka'i yig brgya ci nus bzlas pa'i mthar/
Recite the heruka hundred syllables as much as you can. At the end:

rdor sems rigs bsdus yab yum thams cad kyi sbyor mtshams nas byang sems bdud rtsi dkar dmar na ra ra babs/ spyi bo tshangs pa'i bu ga nas lus gnas rtsa'i pho brang thams cad khyab cing ba spu'i bu gar ngang lhug lhug par gyur/ rang nyid rdo rje sems dpa' rigs bsdus kyi rang bzhin bde stong bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i ye shes dang ldan par gyur/

From the places of union of all the male and female consorts of Vajrasattva, the embodiment of all families, a stream of red and white bodhicitta-amṛta falls. Entering my body through the opening of Brahmā at my head, it pervades the palaces of channels abiding in my body and causes all my hair pores to tingle. I become of the nature of Vajrasattva, the embodiment of all families, endowed with the wisdom of unimaginable bliss-emptiness.
mgon po bdag ni mi shes sogs nas/ byang zhing dag par mdzad du gsol/

Protector, through ignorance and delusion, [I have transgressed and broken my samaya. Guru Vajrasattva, please grant me refuge. Vajradhara, principal one, embodiment of compassion, I take refuge in you, leader of beings. I admit and confess all broken and impaired root and branch samayas of body, speech, and mind. Please cleanse and purify my negative actions,] obscurations, flaws, and downfalls.
oM AHhU~M/
oṃ āḥ hūṃ

rdor sems yab yum 'od du zhu nas rang la thim/ rang nyid bde mchog lhan cig skyes pa yab yum gyi skur gsal ba'i thugs ka'i sa bon gyi 'od kyi snang bas mdun gyi nam mkhar gzhal yas khang gi nang du dpal 'khor lo sdom pa'i dkyil 'khor gyi lha tshogs bde ba chen po'i rang bzhin can/ gtso bo'i mdun gyi nam mkhar seng khri pad+ma nyi ma'i gdan la rtsa ba'i bla ma rdo rje 'chang gi rnam pa can la brgyud pa'i bla ma'i tshogs kyis bskor nas bzhugs par gyur/ ye shes sems dpa'i 'khor lo spyan drangs/

Vajrasattva, male and female consorts, melt into light and dissolve into me. I am clearly Saṃvara Sahaja, male and female consorts. The radiant light from the seed syllable in my heart invites into the sky in front, in a palace, the assembly of deities of the maṇḍala of glorious Cakrasaṃvara, whose nature is great bliss. In the sky in front of the principal one, on a lion throne, lotus, and sun seat, is seated my root guru in the form of Vajradhara, surrounded by the lineage gurus. The assembly of wisdom sattvas are invited.
badzra sa mA dzaH dzaHhU~M ba~M hoH
vajra samājaḥ / jaḥ hūṃ vaṃ hoḥ
sangs rgyas thams cad 'dus pa'i sku sogs dang / dang por me tog phog pa'i lha/ / dkyil 'khor lha tshogs (130) rnams la 'dud/ /

Embodiment of all buddhas [essence of Vajradhara, the root of the three jewels: to the gurus, I pay homage.] I bow to the deity upon whom my flower first fell and to the assembly of deities of the maṇḍala. {130}
ces phyag bya/
Thus, pay homage.
lha mi'i longs spyod phun tshogs thams cad dang / / kun tu bzang po'i mchod sprin chen po dang / / gsang dang rab gsang gsang chen thams cad kyi/ / mchod pa'i sprin chen rgya mtsho dag gis mchod/ /
I offer the abundant enjoyments of gods and humans, the great offering clouds of Samantabhadra, and oceans of clouds of the secret, very secret, and most secret offerings.
oM sarba ta thA ga ta gu ru de ba DA ki nI dzA la sam+ba ra maN+Dal sarba wI ra yo gi nI badzra Ar+g+haM pra tIts+tsha hU~M swA hA/
oṃ sarvatathāgata guru deva ḍākinījāla samvara maṇḍala sarvavīrayoginī vajra arghaṃ pratīccha hūṃ svāhā
de bzhin
Similarly:
pA d+yaM sogs nas shab+da 'i bar gyis
…pādyaṃ…śabda…
phyi mchod 'bul/
Thus, present the outer offerings.
oM AHbadzra wi Ni hU~M hU~M phaT/ sogs
oṃ āḥ vajra viṇi hūṃ hūṃ phaṭ…
rig ma bcu drug dang / pany+tsa a mr-i ta sa nang mchod/ ma taM gi sbyar bas gsang mchod 'bul/ spro na rkang brgyad dang bsdu na/

Thus, present the sixteen offering goddesses. With pañca amṛta, present the inner offering. Adding mataṃgi, present the secret offering. If you wish to elaborate, recite the eight-line [praise],[*1] or, if you wish to abbreviate, say:
sgrib gsum dri med gsang gsum yon tan ldan/ / srid zhi'i 'dren pa rigs bdag bla ma'i sku/ / 'khor lo bde mchog dkyil 'khor lha tshogs la/ / rab tu gus pa'i yid kyis bstod par bgyi/

To the assembly of deities of the maṇḍala of Cakrasaṃvara, who are unstained by the three obscurations, are endowed with the excellent qualities of the three secrets, and are the kāyas of the guru—lord of the family, the guide for existence and peace— with a very devoted mind, I offer praises.
yan lag lhag ma rnams dang dam tshig sdom pa bzung ba ni/ /
The remaining branches and holding the samaya vows.
dkon mchog gsum la bdag skyabs mchi/ / sdig pa mi dge so sor bshags/ / 'gro ba'i dge la rjes yi rangs/ / chos kyi 'khor lo bskor du gsol/ /
I take refuge in the three jewels. I confess each and every negative action and unvirtuous deed. I rejoice in the virtuous actions of all beings. I supplicate you to turn the wheel of dharma.
mya ngan mi 'da' gsol ba 'debs/ / rnal 'byor lam la gnas bgyid cing / / dam tshig thams cad skyong ba dang / / sems can thams cad sdug bsngal las/ / grol ba bdag gis bsgrub par bgyid/ /
I supplicate you not to pass into nirvāṇa. May I abide on the path of yoga. May I guard all samayas. May I achieve the freeing of all sentient beings from suffering.
bstan sogs dge ba 'di dag gi / rnam pa'i mchog rnams kun ldan pa'i/ / sangs rgyas nyid du bdag gyur nas/ / 'gro ba yongs su sgrol byed shog /
May I become a buddha: one endowed with all the most sublime manifestations, the virtues of the teachings, and so on. May I liberate all beings.
lan gsum/ maN+Dal rgyas bsdus gang 'grub 'bul/
Three times. Offer a maṇḍala, whatever you can, either extensive or abbreviated.
gsol ba 'debs pa ni/
Supplication.
na mo gu ru badzra DA ki nI ye/
namo guru vajraḍākinīye
rdo rje 'chang chen dbang phyug tai lo pa/ / nA ro paN chen mar pa lo tsA'i zhabs/ / bzhad pa rdo rje dwags po lha rje'i skur/ / gsol ba 'debs so bdag rgyud byin gyis rlobs/ /
Great Vajradhara, lord Tilopa, great paṇḍita Nāropa, Marpa Lotsāwa, Shepa Dorje, and Physician from Dakpo, I supplicate you, please bless my mindstream.
dus gsum mkhyen pa 'gro mgon ras chen rje/ / spom brag chen po grub chen karma pa/ / o rgyan pa dang rang byung rdo rje'i zhabs/ / gsol ba=
Dusum Khyenpa, the exalted Drogön Rechen, the great Pomdrak, the mahāsiddha Karmapa, Orgyenpa, and Rangjung Dorje: I supplicate you,…{131}
rgyal ba g.yung ston (131) 'dzam gling chos kyi grags/ / mkha' spyod dbang po de bzhin gshegs pa'i zhabs/ / blo gros rin chen chos dpal ye shes la/ / gsol ba=
The victor Yungtön, Dzamling Chökyi Drak, Khachö Wangpo, Dezhin Shekpa, Lodrö Rinchen, and Chöpal Yeshe, I supplicate you,…
bsod nams dbang phyug blo gros grags pa dang / / blo gros rgya mtsho don grub bkra shis dang / / legs bshad sgra dbyangs blo gros rnam rgyal rje/ / gsol ba=
Sönam Wangchuk, Lodrö Drakpa, Lodrö Gyatso, Döndrup Tashi, Lekshe Drayang, and the exalted Lodrö Namgyal, I supplicate you,…
sangs rgyas rin chen kun dga' rnam rgyal dpal/ / karma bstan skyong bsod nams 'gyur med rje/ / dkon mchog bstan 'dzin bstan pa rnam rgyal zhabs/ / gsol ba=
Sangye Rinchen, the glorious Kunga Namgyal, Karma Tenkyong, the exalted Sönam Gyurme, Könchok Tenzin, and Tenpa Namgyal, I supplicate you,…
gsung rab rgya mtsho chos kyi 'byung gnas dpal/ / dge legs rab rgyas 'gyur med bstan 'phel dang / / dge legs nyi ma yon tan rgya mtsho'i zhabs/ / rtsa ba'i bla ma rnams la= / gsol ba= /
Sungrap Gyatso, the glorious Chökyi Jungne, Gelek Rapgye, Gyurme Tenpal, Gelek Nyima, Yönten Gyatso, and my root gurus:… I supplicate you,…

rgyud sde'i mthar thug 'khor lo bde ba'i mchog / sangs rgyas kun yum rdo rje rnal 'byor ma/ / dus gsum rgyal ba'i bstan srung phyag bzhi pa/ / phrin las mnga' bdag dpal ldan lha mo'i tshogs/ / gsol ba= /

The sublime Cakrasaṃvara, the ultimate of the tantras, Vajrayoginī, the mother of all buddhas, the Four-Armed One, the protector of the teachings of the victors of the three times, the assembly of Śrī Devī, the mistress of all activities, I supplicate you,…
sgyu lus sprul skur rtogs par byin gyis rlobs/ / srog rtsol longs skur rtogs par byin gyis rlobs/ / rmi lam chos skur rtogs par byin gyis rlobs/ / 'od gsal ngo bo nyid skur byin gyis rlobs/ /

Grant your blessings that I realize the illusory body to be the nirmāṇakāya. Grant your blessings that I realize prāṇāyāma to be the saṃbhogakāya. Grant your blessings that I realize dreams to be the dharmakāya. Grant your blessings that I realize luminosity to be the svabhāvakāya.
dbang blang ba'i don tu/ bde chen dpal gyi mgon po yis/ / sangs rgyas skyob pa ji lta ba/ / dag pa de nyid ston mdzad pa/ / de ring bdag la mgon dgyes mdzod/ /

To receive the abhiṣekas, supplicate: The Glorious Protector of Great Bliss taught the suchness of purity, just as it is, [as] the refuge for buddhas. Today, may the Protector be pleased [to confer this] on me

ces gsol ba btab pas bla ma brgyud pa rnams kyi sku gsung thugs las byin rlabs kyi chu rgyun dkar dmar sngon po dang / bde mchog yab yum gyi sbyor mtshams nas byang sems dkar dmar gyi rgyun dang na ra ra babs te spyi bo tshangs pa'i bu ga nas zhugs/ lus sems kyi nyes ltung dri ma thams cad dag nas rang nyid 'khor lo sdom pa'i skur gyur/ rtsa 'khor lo bzhir byang sems kyis khyab pas bde stong gi ye shes skyes/ gnas bzhir khyab pas dbang bzhi thob/ sgo (132)gsum tha dad du 'dzin pa'i sgrib pa dag / 'bras bu sku bzhi 'grub pa'i sa bon bzhag /

Having supplicated, from the body, speech, and mind of the gurus and lineage, a stream of blessings—white, red, and blue—flows, and from the place of union of the male and female Saṃvara consorts, a stream of red and white bodhicitta falls. These enter the opening of Brahmā at the top of my head. My mental and physical flaws, downfalls, and stains are all purified. I become the form of Cakrasaṃvara. Bodhicitta pervades my four channel-cakras, giving rise to the wisdom of bliss-emptiness. By pervading my four places, I receive the four abhiṣekas. {132} My obscurations of taking my three doors to be separate are purified. The seeds for achieving the resultant four kāyas are planted. Melting into light, they dissolve into the yidams. The assembly of yidam deities melts into light and dissolves into me. Rest in equipoise.

'od du zhu nas yi dam la thim/ yi dam lha tshogs 'od du zhu nas rang la thim par gyur par bsam la mnyam par bzhag / snyan brgyud nyams su len skabs mtshan bcas kyi rdzogs rim bsgoms nas nang sgrub la mtshams sbyar ba yin kyang skabs 'dir 'dir tsam gyis 'thus so/ /
When practicing the Aural Transmission, after meditating on the perfection process with characteristics, continue on with the inner practice. However, here this much is sufficient.
gnyis pa nang sgrub yi dam gyi dkyil 'khor bsgom pa la/
B. The Inner Practice: Meditating on the Maṇḍala of Yidams
thog mar 'byung rim dang srung 'khor ni/
First, the layers of elements and the protection cakra.
oM kA ya wA ka tsit+ta At+ma ko‘haM/
oṃ kāya vāk citta ātmako ’haṃ

snod bcud thams cad stong par gyur/ stong pa'i ngang las thig le sngon po/ de yongs su gyur pa las rdo rje sngon po rtse lnga ba hU~M gis mtshan pa/ de yongs su gyur pa las chos 'byung sngon po gru gsum pa/ de'i nang du ya~M las rlung gi dkyil 'khor sngon po gzhu'i dbyibs can/ chang bzung la ya~M dang mchog ma gnyis la g.yo ba'i ba dan gyis mtshan pa du ba'i phreng bas bskor ba/ /

The environment and its inhabitants become empty. Within emptiness is a blue bindu. It transforms into a blue five-pointed vajra marked with hūṃ. That transforms into a blue triangular source of dharmas. Within that, from yaṃ, appears a blue wind maṇḍala in the shape of a bow. Its grip is marked with yaṃ, both its tips with fluttering banners, and it is encircled by a garland of smoke.

de'i steng du ra~M las me'i dkyil 'khor dmar po ra~M gyis mtshan pa 'bar ba'i phreng bas bskor ba/ de'i steng du ba~M las chu'i dkyil 'khor zlum po dkar po ba~M gyis mtshan pa 'od kyi phreng bas bskor ba/ de'i steng du la~M las sa'i dkyil 'khor gru bzhi ser po la~M gyis mtshan pa 'od zer gyi phreng bas bskor ba/

Above that, from raṃ, appears a red fire maṇḍala, marked with raṃ and encircled by a garland of flames. Above that, from vaṃ, is a white water maṇḍala, a circle marked by vaṃ and encircled by a garland of light. Above that, from laṃ, is a yellow earth maṇḍala, a square marked by laṃ and encircled by a garland of light rays.

de'i steng du su~M las ri'i rgyal po ri rab gru bzhi pa/ shar shel las grub pa'i dkar ba/ byang in+d+ra nI las grub pa'i ljang ba/ nub pad+ma rA ga las grub pa'i dmar ba/ lho bai DUr+Ya las grub pa'i sngo ba/

Above that, from suṃ, is the king of mountains, Meru, a square. Its eastern side is white, made from crystal. Its northern side is green, derived from indranīla. Its western side is red, made from padmarāga. Its southern side is blue, derived from vaiḍūrya.

de'i dbus su pa~M las sna tshogs pad+ma 'dab ma mtha' yas pa'i lte bar hU~M las sna tshogs rdo rje rtse mo bcu gnyis pa/ shar gyi rwa dkar ba/ byang gi rwa ljang ba/ nub kyi rwa dmar ba/ lho'i rwa ser ba/ lte ba mthing ga yangs shing rgya che ba/

In its center, from paṃ, appears a multicolored lotus with infinite petals. In its center, from hūṃ, is a twelve-pointed viśvavajra. Its eastern prongs are white, its northern prongs are green, its western prongs are red, and its southern prongs are yellow. Its center is deep blue, spacious, and vast.

de'i dbus su hU~M gis mtshan pa/ de las b+h+rU~M ser po las gser gyi 'khor lo rtsibs bye ba phrag du ma dang ldan pa yangs shing rgya che ba gur phub (133) pa lta bu/ hU~M de las hU~M yig sngo ljang dmar ser dkar ba dpag tu med pa 'phros pa las de rnams kyi gur khang kha dog sna lnga pa/ hU~M de las trA~M ser po dpag tu med pa 'phros pa las rin po che'i gur khang ser po/ de las ba~M dmar po dpag tu med pa 'phros pa las pad+ma'i gur khang dmar po/ de las kha~M ljang gu dpag tu med pa 'phros pa las ral gri'i gur khang ljang gu/ de las b+h+rU~M dkar po dpag tu med pa 'phros pa las 'khor lo'i gur khang dkar po/ de las kha~M sngon po dpag tu med pa 'phros pa las dgra sta'i gur khang ser po/ de las hU~M sna tshogs dpag tu med pa 'phros pa las mda'i gur khang kha dog sna tshogs pa/ de thams cad kyang gur bla re ra ba drwa ba sa gzhi dang bcas pa/

Its middle is marked by hūṃ. From that comes a yellow bhrūṃ, from which appears a yellow cakra with millions of spokes, spacious and vast, like a pitched tent. {133} From that hūṃ, innumerable hūṃs—blue, green, red, yellow, and white—stream forth and form a five-colored dome of those [hūṃs]. From that hūṃ, innumerable yellow trāṃs radiate, from which appears a yellow dome of jewels. From it, innumerable red vaṃs radiate, forming a red dome of lotuses. From it, innumerable green khaṃs stream out, forming a green dome of swords. From it, innumerable white bhrūṃs radiate, forming a white dome of cakras. From it, innumerable blue khaṃs spread out, forming a yellow dome of battle-axes. From it, innumerable multicolored hūṃs stream forth, forming a multicolored dome of arrows. Those are [complete] with tents, canopies, fences, nets, and grounds.

de'i phyir rdo rje'i rwa gur/ de'i phyir thod pa bum ril gyi gur khang / de'i phyir me ri kha dog sna tshogs pa'i gur khang / de'i phyir me ri dmar nag gi gur khang g.yon skor du 'khyil zhing 'tshubs pa/ de rnams kyi bar bar du hU~M las he ru ka zhal gcig phyag gnyis pa dang zhal gsum phyag drug pa mtshon cha sna tshogs pa 'dzin pa'i gur khang ste/

Outside of those is a vajra-pronged tent. Outside of that is a dome of whole skulls. Outside of that is a dome of multicolored volcanoes. Outside of that is a dome of dark red volcanoes, coiling and swirling counterclockwise. Interspersed between those, from hūṃs, is a dome of herukas with one face and two arms, and ones with three faces and six arms, holding various weapons.
de rnams kyang don dam stong pa nyid kyi rang bzhin can no/ /
All of those are of the nature of ultimate emptiness.
rten dkyil 'khor bsgom pa ni/
Meditation on the maṇḍala, the support.

srung 'khor gyi nang du hU~M brgyad las dur khrod chen po brgyad/ de'i nang du sna tshogs pad+ma mtha' yas pa'i dbus su sna tshogs rdo rje'i lte bar b+h+rU~M dkar po las/ rin po che sna tshogs las grub pa'i gzhal yas khang gru bzhi sgo bzhi pa/ nang nas rim pa bzhin du sngo ljang dmar ser dkar ba'i rtsig pa rim pa lnga dang ldan pa/ de'i steng du rin po che'i pha gu ser pos bskor ba/ de'i steng du gser gdung las rin po che'i drwa ba dang drwa phyed 'chang ba/ de'i steng gi phyi rol du shar bu dang mda' yab kyis bskor ba/

Within the protection cakra, from eight hūṃs, appear the eight charnel grounds. Within those is a vast multicolored lotus, in whose center is a viśvavajra, in whose center is a white bhrūṃ. From that appears a palace made of various jewels, square with four doors. From within, it has, in order, five-tiered walls of blue, green, red, yellow, and white. Above that circles the yellow jeweled frieze. Above that, jeweled garlands and pendants hang from golden beams. On top of and outside of that is encircled by the fascia and parapet. {134}
