The wisdom ones of the torma guests dissolve into me, and the worldly ones depart for their own places.

de nas spro na chos srung gtor 'bul kyang bya/ de nas lhag gtor la myos byed kyi kha phru gdab la hU~M brjod/ 'bar ba'i rgya dang / pheM/ zhes pas mgon dgug ste/ lhag ma la dbang ba'i mkha' 'gro rnams dang / 'byung po thams cad mdun du spyan drangs/ oM AHhU~M gis snod thod pa dang bcud ye shes kyi bdud rtsir byin gyis brlabs la/

Then, if you wish to elaborate, do a torma offering for the dharma guardians. Next, spit with an intoxicant on the leftover torma saying hūṃ. With the blazing mudrā, say pheṃ and summon the guests. The ḍākinīs and bhūtas who are authorized for the leftovers are invited to the front. With oṃ āḥ hūṃ, the skull-cup container and its contents are consecrated as wisdom amṛta.
a kA ro'am/ oM sarba kha kha khA hi khA hi uts+tshiSh+Ta ba liM uts+tshiSh+Ta b+hak+She b+h+yaHswA hA/
akāro… Or: oṃ sarva kha kha khāhi khāhi ucchiṣṭa baliṃ ucchiṣṭa bhakṣebhyaḥ svāhā
zhes lan gsum mam bdun brjod pas tshim par bsams la lhag gtor phyi rol du bskyal/ theg chen thun mongs ma yin pa'i smon lam rgya cher gdas/
Saying that three or seven times, think that it is satisfying. Take the leftover torma outside. Make a vast, exceptional aspiration of the Mahāyāna.
de nas dkyil 'khor bsdu ba ni/
Dissolving the maṇḍala.
khyed kyi sems can don kun mdzad/ / grub par stsal lam byon pa bzhin/ / sangs rgyas yul du gshegs nas kyang / / slar yang 'byon par mdzad par zhu/ /
You who perform benefit for sentient beings, like bestowing or bringing siddhis, although you depart for the buddha lands, please come again.
rdzogs sangs rgyas dang lha rnams dang / / de sras rnams dang tshangs la sogs/ / 'jig rten skyong rnams cho ga 'di'i/ / ma tshangs pa dag (282)bzod par gsol/ /
Perfect buddhas, deities, your children, Brahmā and others— the worldly protectors—{282} please be patient with any mistakes in this ritual.
zhi dang bkra shis bde legs shog / yon bdag don khyed byas nas su/ / sangs rgyas yul du gshegs nas kyang / / slar yang 'byon par mdzod cig muH
May there be peace, auspiciousness, and goodness. For the sake of the patrons, although you depart for the buddha lands, please again come. muḥ
gtso bo nus pa ma mchis shing / / ma 'tshal ba dang ma rnyed dang / / ma tshangs pa dang lhag gyur pa/ / byas pa de mi bzod par gsol/ /
Principal one, whatever I have not been able to do, whatever has not been sufficient or not acquired, whatever has been incomplete or extra, please be patient with that.
gsang sngags nyams dang bya ba rnams/ / cho ga nyams par gyur pa gang / / de ni lha mos bzod par gsol/ / mnga' bdag ma yis gnang ba zhu/ /
Whatever has been done that impairs the Secret Mantra, whatever impairs the ritual, may the Goddess be patient with that. Mistress, please grant that.
lha mo tshad ma dam tshig tshad ma dang / / des gsung tshig kyang tshad ma'i mchog yin te/ / bden pa de yis lha mo de dag rnams/ / bdag la rjes su 'dzin pa'i rgyur gyur cig
The Goddess is genuine, the samaya is genuine, and the words spoken are supremely genuine. May that truth be the cause for the goddesses to accept me.[16]
zhes brjod de rang bzhin gyi gnas su gshegs pa nongs pa bzod par gsol/
Thus, request them to depart to their natural abodes and ask for their patience with any mistakes.
bdag bskyed bsdu ba ni/
The dissolution of the front visualization.

rang gi thugs ka'i sa bon las 'od zer 'phros pas brtan pa dang g.yo ba thams cad 'od du zhu nas dur khrod brgyad la thim/ de gzhal yas khang la/ de gdan la/ de lha so so la/ lha sgo ma bzhi phyogs ma bzhi la/ mtshams ma bzhi thod pa bzhi la/ phyogs ma bzhi gtso bo'i zhal bzhi la/ thod pa bzhi gtso bo'i thugs kar thim zhing / bdag nyid bcom ldan 'das yab yum du gsal ba'i snying khar rdo rje sems dpa'i ngo bo oM ha dkar po/ dpral bar rnam snang gi ngo bo na ma he ser po/ / tshogs mar rin chen 'byung ldan gyi ngo bo swA hA hu dmar po/ phrag gong gnyis su he ru ka'i ngo bo bau Sha Ta he nag po/ spyan gsum la 'od dpag med kyi ngo bo hU~M hU~M ho mthing ga / yan lag thams cad la rta mchog gi ngo bo phaT haM ljang khu/

From the seed syllable at my heart, light rays radiate, causing everything inanimate and animate to melt into light and dissolve into the eight charnel grounds. Those dissolve into the palace, that into the seats, those into their specific deities. The goddesses of the four doors dissolve into [the yoginīs of] the four directions, and those in the four intermediate directions into the four skull cups. [The yoginīs of] the four directions dissolve into the four faces of the principal one, and the four skull cups into the heart of the principal one. I appear clearly as the Bhagavān, male and female consorts. In my heart is white oṃ ha, the essence of Vajrasattva; at my forehead is yellow nama he, the essence of Vairocana; at my bregma[17] is svāhā hu, the essence of Ratnasambhava; in both my shoulders are black vauṣaṭ hes, the essence of Heruka; in my three eyes are deep blue hūṃ hoḥs, the essence of Amitabhā; and at my limbs are green phaṭ haṃs, the essence of Paramāśva.

yum gyi lte bar phag mo'i ngo bo oM baM dmar mo/ snying gar gshin rje ma'i ngo bo haM yau sngon mo/ khar rmongs byed ma'i ngo bo hrI mi dkar mo/ dpral bar skyod byed ma'i ngo bo hri hriM ser mo/ spyi gtsug tu skrag byed ma'i ngo bo hU~M hU~M ljang khu/ yan lag thams (283)cad la tsaN+Da ka'i ngo bo phaT phaT dud kha/ spyi bor bla ma mi bskyod pa'i gzugs can gyis dbu brgyan pa'i bdag nyid can no/ /

At the navel of the female consort is red oṃ vaṃ, the essence of Vārāhī; in her heart is blue haṃ yauṃ, the essence of Yāminī; in her mouth is white hrīṃ moṃ, the essence of Mohanī; in her forehead is yellow hri hrīṃ, the essence of Saṃcālanī; at the crown of her head is green huṃ hūṃ, the essence of Saṃtrāsanī; and in all her limbs are smoky phaṭ phaṭs, the essence of Caṇḍikā. {283} At the top of my head, the form of the guru Akṣobhya is the embodiment of a crown.
de nas spyod lam brtan pa ni/
Stabilizing conduct.
tshul khrims tsan dan yan lag byugs/ / bsam gtan stod g.yogs kyis dkris pa/ / byang chub yan lag me tog bkram/ / ji ltar bde bar spyod par bya'o/ /
Rub the sandalwood of ethical conduct on your limbs. Wrap yourself in the jacket of meditative concentration. Spread the flowers of the factors for awakening. In that way, engage happily.

zhes don nges pas thun mtshams kyi rnal 'byor la 'jug cing / shis brjod rgyas par byas la me tog gi char dbab bo/ 'di'i 'don chog spros pa rgyas par 'dod na rgyal dbang 'brug pa yab sras kyi gsung las shes dgos shing don gyi snying po 'dir bstan la ma tshang med do/

With those points, engage in the yogas for between sessions. Do an extensive expression of auspiciousness, and a rain of flowers will fall. If you wish for an expanded and elaborate liturgy for that, you should learn that from the writings of the Gyalwang Drukpa and his sons. The essence of the meaning is complete in the teaching here.
dam tshig gtum mos snyigs ma'i phung khams bsregs/ / ye shes me lces bdag 'dzin bud shing bcom/ / bde stong mchog tu mi 'gyur phyag rgya che'i/ / dngos grub tshe 'dir 'grub pa'i rgyur gyur cig

The samaya caṇḍālī burns the dreg skandhas and dhātus. The wisdom flames consume the firewood of belief in a self. May those be causes for achieving, in this lifetime, the siddhi of mahāmudrā, immutable bliss-emptiness.

ces pa'i tshul 'dir yig chas phongs par ma gyur kyang / skal ldan yongs la 'phel zhing rgyas pa'i sgor 'gyur bar re ba'i lhag blos kun nas bslangs te/ karma ngag dbang yon tan rgya mtsho'am blo gros mtha' yas pa'i sdes gong ma'i gsungs las khyer bde ba'i lag len tu rdzong shod bde gshegs 'dus pa'i pho brang chen por bgyis pa

Although there is no shortage of texts in this approach, motivated by the hope of spreading this to all fortunate ones and creating the door to its expansion, [I,] Karma Ngakwang Yönten Gyatso, or Lodrö Taye Paide, [wrote this] in the great palace of Dzongshö Deshek Dupa as procedures easy to implement, [drawn] from the teachings of the earlier masters.
dge legs 'phel// sarba mang+ga laM/ (284) (285)
May virtue and goodness increase. sarva maṅgalam {284}
@#/ /dpal 'khor lo bde mchog ras chung lugs kyi sgrub thabs bde chen ye shes thig le zhes bya ba bzhugs so/ /
24. Bindu of Great Bliss-Wisdom. The Sādhana for the Rechung Tradition of the Glorious Cakrasaṃvara[1]
(286)@#/ / na maHshrI tsakra sam+ba ra gu ra we/
nāmaḥ śrīcakrasamvara gurave
rang byung bde chen lhan cig skyes pa'i sku/ / dngos kun khyab bdag 'khor lo'i dbang phyug dang / / dbyer med he ru ka la gus btud nas/ / sgrub thabs zab pa'i yang snying 'dir dgod bya/ /

I bow with respect to the Heruka, inseparable from the lord of cakras, the omnipresent master of all things, the connate kāya of self-arisen great bliss. I will here present the quintessence of the profound sādhanas.

sgrub pa po'i gang zag dbang gis rgyud smin cing dam tshig la gnas pas sgrub gnas dur khrod sogs rgyud dang mthun pa'am dben cing byin rlabs dang ldan par sgrub rdzas dam tshig gi bris sku sogs sku gsung thugs kyi rten dang phyi nang gi mchod pa'i yo byad rnams nye bar bsdog / dus yar mar gyi tshes bcu sogs la dbu brtsams te stan bde bar 'khod/ mdun du DA ru rdor dril nang mchod rnams bzhag go /

Individuals who are practitioners, who have had their mindstreams matured by abhiṣekas and abide within samaya, [should stay] in practice places in accordance with [what is specified in] the tantras, such as charnel grounds, or in isolated locations that have been blessed. There they should assemble the items for practice: representations of body, speech, and mind, such as drawn forms, and the requisites for the outer and inner offerings, which are all [connected to] samayas. Begin on a tenth lunar day of the waxing or waning moon or a similar occasion. Arrange a comfortable seat, and place a ḍamaru, vajra, ghaṇṭā, and the inner offering in front.
nyams len bya ba la gsum/ sngon 'gro/ dngos gzhi/ rjes kyi rim pa'o/ /
The practice has three parts: (1) the preliminaries, (2) the main practice, and (3) the concluding section.
dang po
I. The Preliminaries
['di] la gnyis/ dkyil 'khor dang 'brel ba dang / sgrub thabs dang 'brel ba'o/ /
This has two sections: (1) the preliminaries connected with the maṇḍala and (2) the preliminaries connected with the sādhana.
dang po ni/
A. The Preliminaries Connected with the Maṇḍala
gtso bo dkyil chog dang 'brel ba yin kyang / sgrub pa ched du 'dzugs pa sogs la sgrub thabs kyi thog mar dgos gal che zhing dkyil chog dang 'brel na'ang sngon du 'gro dgos pas/

These are primarily connected with the maṇḍala ritual, but [because] what is needed at the beginning of a sādhana (such as specifically initiating the practice) is most important and connected with the maṇḍala, they must be preliminaries.
[1. sngon 'gro gtor ma]
1. [The Preliminary Torma]

thog mar sngon 'gro gtor ma btang ba ni dkar bgegs spyi ltar bsham/ oM gyis gtor ma mi dmigs te stong par bsam/ AHyis rin po che'i snod yangs shing rgya che bar bsam/ hU~M gis zad mi shes pa'i 'dod yon lnga ldan tu gyur/

Begin with giving a preliminary torma. Arrange a white obstructors [torma], as is generally done. With oṃ, the torma is unobservable: it is empty. Thus, contemplate. With āḥ, it is a jeweled container, spacious and vast. Thus, contemplate. With hūṃ, it becomes inexhaustible pleasures of the five senses.
ha hoHhrIH lan gsum dang bcas pas byin brlab/
ha hoḥ hrīḥ Saying that three times, consecrate [the torma]. {287}
rang gi snying ga'i (287) hU~M gi 'od zer gyis gtor mgron rnams spyan drangs/
Light rays from the hūṃ in my heart invite the torma guests.
sa ma ya dzaH
samaya jaḥ

oM kha kha khA hi khA hi/ sarba yak+Sha rAk+Sha sa b+hU ta pre ta pi sha tsi un mA da a pa smA ra DA ka DA ki n+yA da yaH i daM ba liM gr-ih+Nan+tu sa ma ya rak+Shan+tu ma ma sarba sid+d+hi m+me pra yats+tshan+tu ya thai paM ya theSh+ThaM b+huny+dza tha dzi g+h+ra tha pi pa tha mA ti kra ma tha/ ma ma sarba kArta yA sat+su khaM bi shud+d+ha ye/ sa hA yi kA b+ha wan+tu hU~M hU~M phaT phaT swA hA/

oṃ kha kha khāhi khāhi / sarvayakṣa rākṣasa bhūta preta piśāci unmāda apasmāra ḍāka ḍākinyādayaḥ / iḍaṃ baliṃ gṛhṇantu samaya rakṣantu mama sarvasiddhimme prayacchantu yathaivaṃ yatheṣṭaṃ bhuñjatha jighratha pibatha mātikramatha / mama sarvakārtayā satsukhaṃ viśuddhaye / sahāyikā bhavantu hūṃ hūṃ phaṭ phaṭ svāhā
lan gsum gyis bsngos la/
Saying that three times, dedicate it.
mchod sbyin gyi gtor ma rgya chen po 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga dang ldan pa 'di nyid yul 'di'i gzhi bdag gis gtso byas pa'i 'byung po'i tshogs rnams la bsngo'o/ / 'bul lo/ / mgron no/ / sbyin no/ /

This offering and gift of a vast torma, endowed with the five sense pleasures, is dedicated to the assembly of bhūtas, lead by the local deities of this place. It is offered to them. They are the guests. It is given to them.
bzhes nas dkar phyogs la dga' zhing skyong ba rnams kyis rnal 'byor pa bdag cag 'khor bcas chos sgrub pa'i grogs mdzod cig /
Thus, may those who take delight in and protect the virtuous side act as assistants to us, yogins and yoginīs, and our retinues in our practice of dharma.

gzhi bdag chen po la sogs pa'i/ / lha klu gnod sbyin srin po dang / / 'byung po yi dwags sha za'i tshogs/ / smyo byed rjed byed mkha' 'gro ma/ / ma mo'i tshogs rnams ma lus pa/ / 'dir gshegs bdag la dgongs su gsol/ /

Gods—the great local deities and others— nāgas, yakṣas, rākṣasas, bhūtas, hungry ghosts, and piśācas, those causing madness, those causing forgetfulness, ḍākinīs, and assemblies of mamos: please come here and consider us.
mchod sbyin gtor ma 'di bzhes la/ sogs nas/

Accept this offering and gift of torma [May we yogins and yoginīs with our retinues be without illness, have long lives, might, glory, fame, excellent fortune, and vast enjoyments. Bestow on us the siddhis of actions: pacifying, enriching, and the others. Samaya holders, protect us. Be our friend and aid for the siddhis. May we not meet with untimely death, illness, spirits, or hindrances. May we not have bad dreams, bad omens, or bad interactions. May there be peace in the world, good harvests, plentiful grains, the flourishing of dharma, and an abundance of goodness.]
'dod pa kun 'grub mdzod/
May all that we desire be accomplished.
bar gyis phrin las bcol/
Thus, entrust them with activity. {288}

nag po'i phyogs la dga' (288) ba rnams kyang gtor ma 'dis tshims par gyis la/ sdig spong dge ba sgrub pa dang / dkar po'i phyogs la dga' bas/ bdag cag 'khor dang bcas pa'i chos sgrub pa'i stong grogs mdzod cig /

May all those who delight in the dark side be satisfied by this torma. May they give up evil and cultivate virtue. May those who delight in the virtuous side aid us and our retinues in our practice of dharma.

gal te de ltar mi byed na sa phyogs 'dir ma 'dug par rang rang so so'i gnas su dengs shig / mi 'gro na ye shes kyi rdo rjes lus ngag thal bar rlog par byed do/ / zhes brjod cing rang lha'i nga rgyal brtan pos bka' bsgo ba ni/

If you do not act in those ways, do not stay here. Go to your own places now. If you do not go, the wisdom vajras will grind your bodies and speech into dust. With stable pride of the deity, give the following command.
hU~M/ nga ni dpal ldan rdo rje 'chang / / sangs rgyas kun gyis dbang bskur zhing / / phrin las kun gyi bdag po ru/ / nga ni rjes su gnang ba ste/ /
hūṃ I am the glorious Vajradhara. As one upon whom all buddhas have bestowed abhiṣekas and as lord of all activities, I issue this mandate:
log 'dren bgegs kyi tshogs rnams kun/ / nga yi bka' las ma 'da' zhig / gal te bka' las 'das gyur na/ / brlag par 'gyur bar gdon mi za/ /
All corrupting influences and gatherings of obstructors, do not transgress my command. If you do, you will be crushed, rest assured.
oM suM b+ha ni suM b+ha hU~M hU~M phaT/ gr-ih+Na gr-ih+Na hU~M hU~M phaT/ gr-ih+NA pa ya gr-ih+NA pa ya hU~M hU~M phaT/ A na ya hoHb+ha ga wAn badzra rA dza hU~M hU~M phaT/
oṃ suṃbha nisuṃbha hūṃ hūṃ phaṭ / gṛhṇa gṛhṇa hūṃ hūṃ phaṭ / gṛhṇāpaya gṛhṇāpaya hūṃ hūṃ phaṭ / ānayahoḥ bhagavān vajra rāja huṃ hūṃ phaṭ
ces drag rol dang bcas pas gtor ma phyir dor/
With wrathful music, throw the torma outside.
gnyis pa nang mchod byin gyis brlab pa ni/
2. Consecration of the Inner Offering
oM khaN+Da ro ha hU~M hU~M phaT/ ces pas bsang /
oṃ khaṇḍaroha huṃ hūṃ phaṭ Thus, cleanse.
oM swa b+hA wa shud+d+ha sarba d+harmaHswa b+hA wa shud+d+ho \u0f85haM/ zhes pas/
oṃ svabhāva śuddhā sarvadharmaḥ svabhāva śuddho ’haṃ And:

stong par sbyangs pa'i ngang las/ ya~M las rlung gi dkyil 'khor ljang sngon gzhu bdungs pa'i dbyibs can chang zung dang mchog ma la ya~M dang ba dan gyis mtshan pa/ de'i steng du ra~M las me'i dkyil 'khor gru gsum dmar po 'bar ba ra~M gyis mtshan pa/ de'i zur rnams su ka~M ka~M ka~M las mi mgo'i sgyed bu ltag pa nang du bstan pa rnams kyi steng du/ A las ye shes kyi ka pA la yangs shing rgya che ba/ phyi dkar la nang dmar ba dpral ba rang la bstan pa/

From a state purified as emptiness, from yaṃ, appears a blue-green wind maṇḍala in the shape of a drawn bow. Its grip and tips are marked with yaṃs and banners. Above that, from raṃ, appears a fire maṇḍala, triangular, blazing red, and marked with raṃ. In its corners, from kaṃ kaṃ kaṃ, arise hearths that are human heads, whose napes face inward. Above those, from ā, is a wisdom kapāla, spacious and vast. It is white on the outside, red on the inside, with its forehead facing me.
de'i nang du a las zla ba'i steng du/ dbus su na las mi'i sha / shar du gau las ba glang gi sha / lhor ku las khyi'i sha / nub tu da las rta'i sha / byang du ha las glang po che'i sha /

Inside of that, from a, is a moon. On top of that, in the middle, from na, is human flesh. In the east, from gau, is cow flesh. In the south, from ku, is dog flesh. In the west, from da, is horse flesh. In the north, from ha, is elephant flesh.

de rnams kyi steng du dbus su mu las dri chu/ shar du bi las dri chen/ lhor ra las rak+ta/ nub tu ma las klad pa/ byang du shu las byang sems te/ sha lnga (289)bdud rtsi lnga'i steng du oM AHhU~M las sku gsung thugs kyi bdud rtsi'i ngo bo kha T+wAM ga yu ba dngul chu lta bu las/ rtse mo dkar dmar mthing gsum 'od kyi rang bzhin can grub par bsam/

Above those, in the middle, from mu, is urine. In the east, from vi, is excrement. In the south, from ra, is rakta. In the west, from ma, is brains. In the north, from śu, is bodhicitta. {289} Above the five meats and five amṛtas, from oṃ āḥ hūṃ, appears a khaṭvāṃga with a mercury-like handle. It is the essence of the amṛtas of body, speech, and mind. Its tip is of the nature of light, white, red, and blue. Thus, contemplate.

bdag gi thugs ka'i sa bon las 'od 'phros/ rlung g.yos me sbar bas thod pa'i nang gi rdzas rnams khol zhing zhu/ kha T+wAM ga'i rtse las 'od 'phros pas/ phyogs bcu'i rgyal ba sras bcas kyi sku gsung thugs las byung ba'i ye shes kyi bdud rtsi 'od zer dkar dmar mthing gsum gyi rnam par spyan drangs kha T+wAM ga la thim zhing / kha T+wAM gas thod pa'i nang gi rdzas rnams dkrugs pas/ zhu zhing dam tshig gi bdud rtsi dang / ye shes kyi bdud rtsi ro gcig tu 'dres par gyur/

From the seed syllable in my heart, light radiates. The wind blows and the fire blazes, causing the substances within the skull cup to boil and melt. From the tip of the khaṭvāṃga, light streams forth, invoking wisdom amṛta from the bodies, speech, and minds of the victors and their children in the ten directions in the form of white, red, and blue light rays. Those dissolve into the khaṭvāṃga. The khaṭvāṃga stirs the substances in the skull cup, which melt. The samaya amṛta and wisdom amṛta blend as one taste.
oM AHhU~M ha hoHhrIH
oṃ āḥ hūṃ ha hoḥ hrīḥ

rgya dang bcas lan gsum/ g.yon pa'i mtheb srin gyis 'thor la/ bla ma yi dam mkha' 'gro chos skyong rdo rje spun rigs drug gzhi bdag dang bcas pa rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ lcer myong la/ rang lus rgyal ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi lha tshogs rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/

Say that three times with the mudrā. Sprinkle [amṛta] with your left thumb and ring finger and say: To the gurus, yidams, ḍākinīs, dharma protectors, vajra siblings, six kinds of beings, and local deities, oṃ āḥ hūṃ. Taste it with your tongue and say: To the assembly of deities in the maṇḍala of the victors within my own body, oṃ āḥ hūṃ.
gsum pa gnas khang dang mchod rdzas byin gyis brlab pa ni/
3. Consecration of the Place and the Offering Substances
sngar ltar bsang sbyang /
Cleanse and purify as before.

stong pa'i ngang las b+h+rU~M las thar pa chen po'i gzhal yas khang gru bzhi sgo bzhi rgyan rta babs mtshan nyid thams cad yongs su rdzogs pa'i phyi nang kun tu oM AHhU~M dkar dmar mthing gsum 'od du zhu ba las byung ba'i lha rdzas las grub pa'i mchod yon/ me tog bdug spos/ snang gsal/ dri chab/ zhal zas/ rol mo la sogs te 'dod yon lnga'i mchod rdzas dwangs shing thogs pa med pa/ yul sa dang nam mkha' bar snang thams cad khyab pa/ dus thams cad 'khor ba ji srid ma stongs kyi bar du gnas pa/ ngo bo bzang zhing rgya che ba/ bkod pa mchog tu gyur pa/ byang chub sems dpa' kun tu bzang po'i rnam par thar pa las byung ba'i mchod pa'i sprin gyi phung po ltar bsam gyis mi khyab par mos la/

Within emptiness, from bhrūṃ, appears a palace of great liberation, square, complete with four doors, ornaments, torans, and all the characteristics. Outside, inside, and everywhere are oṃ āḥ hūṃs, white, red, and blue. They melt into light, from which arise pristine and unobstructed offering substances of the five sense pleasures: offering waters, flowers, incense, lamps, scented waters, food, music, and more, all made from divine substances. They spread throughout the area, space, and everywhere in between. They remain at all times until saṃsāra is emptied. Their nature is excellent and vast. Their arrangement is sublime. They are unimaginable like the masses of offering clouds in the biography of the bodhisattva Samantabhadra. Thus, have that sense and say:
oM badzra ma hA Ar+g+haM pra tIts+tsha swA hA/ oM badzra puSh+pe AHhU~M/
oṃ vajra arghaṃ pratīccha svāhā oṃ vajra puṣpe āḥ hūṃ
de bzhin du/ (290)
Similarly: {290}
d+hU pe/ A lo ke/ gan+d+he/ nai wi d+ye/ shab+da AHhU~M/ gi bar gyis sngags rnams rgya dang bcas pas byin brlab/
…dhūpe…āloke…gandhe…naividye…śabda āḥ hūṃ With the mantras and mudrās, consecrate.
rol mo 'khrol la/ oM badzra d+harmA ra Ni ta sogs nas/ AHkhaM swA hA'i bar brjod /
Play music and say: oṃ vajradharmā raṇita…āḥ khaṃ svāhā[*1]
gnyis pa sgrub thabs kyi sngon 'gro la
B. The Preliminaries Connected with the Sādhana
dang po spyi'i sngon 'gro skyabs 'gro sems bskyed ni/
1. Refuge and Bodhicitta
rgyas pa na spyi ltar skyabs 'gro drug skor ci nus brjod/ bsdu na/

The preliminaries for the sādhana are first the common preliminaries of taking refuge and arousing bodhicitta. To do this extensively, recite a sixfold refuge as is commonly done as much as you can. To abbreviate:
'gro rnams bsgral 'dod bsam pa yis/ / sangs rgyas chos dang dge 'dun la/ / byang chub snying por mchis kyi bar/ / rtag par bdag ni skyabs su mchi/ /
With the intention to free all beings, I will always take refuge in the Buddha, dharma, and saṅgha, until reaching the heart of awakening.
shes rab snying rje dang bcas pas/ / brtson pas sems can don du bdag / sangs rgyas mdun du gnas bcas nas/ / rdzogs pa'i byang chub sems bskyed bgyi'o/ /
With prajñā and compassion, and with exertion, for the sake of sentient beings, I go into the presence of the buddhas and arouse the perfect bodhicitta.

sems can thams cad kyi don du yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi go 'phang rin po che thob par bya/ de'i ched du bdag gis bcom ldan 'das dpal 'khor lo sdom pa'i lam rim pa gnyis kyi rnal 'byor nyams su blang bar bgyi'o/ / lan gsum/

To be of benefit to all sentient beings, I will attain the precious state of true, perfect buddhahood. In order to do that, I will practice the yogas of the two processes on the path of the Bhagavān, the glorious Cakrasaṃvara. Three times.
sems can thams cad bde ba dang sogs tshangs ba'i gnas bzhi sgom/

May all sentient beings have happiness [and the causes of happiness. May all sentient beings be free from suffering and the causes of suffering. May all sentient beings never be separated from the genuine happiness that is free from suffering. May all sentient beings abide in the great equanimity that is free from attachment and aggression to those near and far.] Thus, cultivate the four abodes of Brahmā.
gnyis pa bye brag sa chog gi sngon 'gro
2. The Special, Supreme Preliminaries
blon po rigs gsum las byed la gsum las/
Among the three types of actions of the ministers, the first is the meditation and recitation of Vajrasattva.
dang po rdor sems sgom bzlas ni/
a. Meditation and Recitation of Vajrasattva

rang gi spyi bor pa~M las pad+ma a las zla ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi steng du rdo rje dkar po hU~M gis mtshan pa las 'od zer 'phros/ 'phags pa mchod/ sems can gyi don byas/ tshur 'dus yongs su gyur pa las bla ma rdo rje sems dpa' sku mdog dkar po zhal gcig phyag gnyis rdo rje dang dril bu 'dzin pa/ dar gyi na bza' dang rin po che dang rus pa'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa/ zhabs rdo rje'i skyil krung gis bzhugs pa la yum rdo rje snyems ma dkar mo gri gug dang thod khrag 'dzin cing pad+ma'i skyil mo krung gis 'khyud pa/ gnyis ka'ang mtshan dang dpe byad 'bar zhing 'od zer gyi klong du snang stong sgyu ma'i sku can du gsal ba'i gnas gsum 'bru gsum las 'od zer 'phros pas sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad rdo rje sems dpa' yab yum gyi rnam par spyan drangs/

On top of my head, from paṃ, appears a lotus, and from a appears a moon maṇḍala. Above that is a white vajra marked by hūṃ. From that, light rays stream out, making offerings to the noble ones and benefiting sentient beings. They gather back and the vajra transforms into the guru Vajrasattva. He is white, with one face and two hands, holding a vajra and ghaṇṭā. He is adorned with silks and ornaments of jewels and bones. Sitting in the vajra position, he is embraced by his consort, Vajragarvā, who is white, holding a hooked knife and skull cup with blood, seated in the lotus position. Both blaze with the major and minor marks. They appear clearly in their illusory forms, empty appearances in an expanse of light rays. From the three seed syllables at their three places, light rays radiate, inviting all the buddhas and bodhisattvas in the form of Vajrasattva, male and female consorts. {291}
badzra sa mA dzaH (291) dzaHhU~M ba~M hoH gnyis su med par gyur/
vajra samājaḥ / jaḥ hūṃ vaṃ hoḥ They become nondual.

bcom ldan 'das bdag dang sems can thams cad kyi lus ngag yid gsum gyi sgo nas rtsa ba dang yan lag gi dam tshig nyams chag sdig sgrib nyes ltung dri ma'i tshogs dang bcas pa thams cad byang zhing dag par mdzad du gsol/ zhes gsol ba btab pas rdor sems yab yum gyi sbyor mtshams nas byang sems bdud rtsi'i rgyun babs/ rang gi spyi bo nas zhugs/ lus phyi nang thams cad bkrus pas sdig sgrib nyes ltung thams cad dag cing dri ma med par gyur/

Bhagavān, please cleanse and purify all the impaired and broken root and branch samayas, negative actions, obscurations, flaws, downfalls, and mass of stains that I and all sentient beings have accumulated through our bodies, speech, and minds. Having supplicated in that way, from the place of union of Vajrasattva, male and female consorts, a stream of bodhicitta-amṛta falls. It enters the top of my head. Washing my body, inside and out, all my negative actions, obscurations, flaws, and downfalls are purified and I become stainless.
oM shrI badzra he ru ka sa ma ya sogs he ru ka'i yig brgya dang /
oṃ śrīvajraheruka samaya… Recite the heruka hundred syllables and then:
oM badzra sa twa hU~M/ zhes pa'ang bzla/
oṃ vajrasatva hūṃ
mthar/
At the end:
mgon po bdag ni sogs kyis gsol ba btab pas/

Protector, through ignorance and delusion, [I have transgressed and broken my samaya. Guru Vajrasattva, please grant me refuge. Vajradhara, principal one, embodiment of compassion, I take refuge in you, leader of beings. I admit and confess all broken and impaired root and branch samayas of body, speech, and mind. Please cleanse and purify my negative actions,] obscurations, flaws, and downfalls. Thus, supplicate.
rdor sems yab yum 'od du zhu nas rang la thim par bsams la mnyam par bzhag /
Vajrasattva, male and female consorts, melt into light and dissolve into me. Thus, contemplate, and rest in equipoise.
gnyis pa bla ma'i rnal 'byor ni/
b. Guru Yoga

rang nyid lhag pa'i lhar gsal ba'i mdun gyi nam mkhar seng ges btegs pa'i rin po che'i khri'i steng du pa~M las pad+ma ra~M las nyi ma a las zla ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi gdan la hU~M las rdo rje sngon po hU~M gis mtshan pa las 'od zer phyogs bcur 'phros pas 'phags pa rnams mchod/ sems can gyi don byas/ 'od zer tshur 'dus rdo rje la thim zhing yongs su gyur pa las bla ma rdo rje 'chang sku mdog mthing gzhal gcig zhi zhing 'dzum pa phyag gnyis kyis rdo rje dang dril bu 'dzin pas yum reg bya rdo rje ma sngon mo gri gug dang bdud rtsi'i thod pa 'dzin pa la 'khyud pa/

I am clearly my special deity. In the space in front, on a jeweled throne supported by lions, from paṃ, appears a lotus; from raṃ, a sun; and from a, a moon maṇḍala. On those seats, from hūṃ, is a blue vajra marked by hūṃ. From that, light rays radiate to the ten directions, making offerings to the noble ones and benefiting sentient beings. The light rays gather back and dissolve into the vajra, which transforms into the guru Vajradhara. He is deep blue, with one face, peaceful and smiling, with two hands holding a vajra and ghaṇṭā, embracing his consort Sparśavajrā, who is blue, holding a hooked knife and skull cup with amṛta.

yab rdo rje'i skyil krung dang yum pad+ma'i skyil krung gis bzhugs pa/ gnyis ka'ang mtshan dang dpe byad rdzogs shing dar gyi na bza' dang rin po che dang rus pa'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa/ bkrag mdangs 'od zer gzi brjid rab tu 'bar ba gnas gsum 'bru gsum gyis mtshan pa las 'od zer 'phros pas rang bzhin gyi dag pa'i zhing rab 'byams nas/ dpal 'khor lo sdom pa'i ngo bor gyur pa'i rtsa brgyud bla ma/ yi dam lha tshogs/ mkha' 'gro chos skyong thams cad mdun gyi nam (292) mkhar byon par bsam/

The male consort sits in the vajra position, and the female consort sits in the lotus position. Both are complete with the major and minor marks and are adorned with silks and ornaments of jewels and bones. They blaze with brilliant, dazzling light and majesty. From their three places marked with the three seed syllables, light rays stream forth. From the infinite naturally pure realms, the root and lineage gurus—who are of the essence of the glorious Cakrasaṃvara—the assembly of yidam deities, and all the ḍākinīs and dharma protectors come into the space in front. {292} Thus, contemplate.
oM gu ru maN+Dal de ba DA ki nI sa pa ri wA ra badzra sa ma ya dzaH pad+ma ka ma lA ya s+t+waM/
oṃ guru maṇḍala deva ḍākinī saparivāra vajra samaya jaḥ / padma kamalāyastvaṃ
sngags snga ma'i mthar/ sa pa ri wA ra badzra ma hA Ar+g+haM pra tIts+tsha swA hA/
At the end of the previous mantra: …saparivāra vajra mahā arghaṃ pratīccha svāhā
yab pA d+yaM sbyar ba dang / oM badzra puSh+pe AHhU~M/ nas/ shab+da 'i bar 'gres sbyar/
Next, insert pādyaṃ and then: oṃ vajra puṣpe āḥ hūṃ…śabda… Use the same ending.
gang gi drin gyis bde chen nyid sogs sh+lo ka dang /
Through your kindness, great bliss [arises in an instant. To the lotus feet of the guru, with a precious vajra body, I bow.] Say that śloka and:
sangs rgyas kun gyi rang bzhin sku/ sogs sh+lo ka gcig gis bstod/ sngags snga ma'i mthar/

In you whose body is of the nature of all buddhas, [ācārya, I take refuge. To the cakras of heroes and yoginīs, abiding in yoga, I pay homage.] With that śloka, praise. Say the previous mantra and at the end:
dzaHhU~M ba~M hoH gnyis su med par thim par gyur par mos la/
jaḥ hūṃ vaṃ hoḥ They dissolve to become nondual.
bdun rnam dag 'bul ba ni/
Offering the seven purities.
mchod 'os kun 'dus drin can bla ma la/ / sgo gsum gus pa chen pos phyag 'tshal lo/ / phyi nang gsang gsum mchod pa ma lus 'bul/ / dug gsum dbang gis sdig pa mtha' dag bshags/ /

To the kind gurus, embodying all those worthy of worship, I pay homage with great respect of body, speech, and mind. I present all inner, outer, and secret offerings. I confess all negative actions done under the influence of the three poisons.
dus gsum dge la rjes su yi rang ngo / / theg gsum chos 'khor rtag tu bskor bzhin du/ / khams gsum 'gro ba'i don du bzhugs su gsol/ / dge bas 'gro kun sku gsum myur thob shog /

I rejoice in the virtue of the three times. I request you to remain for the sake of beings in the three realms, always turning the dharma wheel of the three yānas. Through this virtue, may all beings quickly achieve the three kāyas.
ces dang maN+Dal tshogs bcad lhug gis phul/
Offer a maṇḍala with verses and prose.
de nas thun mong gi sdom pa bzung zhing byang chub tu sems bskyed pa ni/
Holding the common vows and arousing bodhicitta.
skyabs gnas mchod 'os kun 'dus pa'i/ / dpal ldan bla ma dgongs su gsol/ / che ge mo zhes bgyi ba bdag / dus 'di nyid nas bzung nas ni/ / ji srid byang chub ma thob bar/ /
Glorious gurus, who embody all those worthy of worship, the sources of refuge, please consider me. I, (insert your name), starting from this time until reaching awakening,
ji ltar dus gsum mgon po rnams/ / byang chub tu ni nges mdzad pa'i/ / byang chub sems ni bla na med/ / dam pa bdag gis bskyed par bgyi/ /
give rise to genuine [bodhicitta], just as the protectors of the three times gave rise to unsurpassable bodhicitta, which definitely brings awakening.
tshul khrims kyi ni bslab pa dang / / dge ba'i chos ni sdud pa dang / / sems can don byed tshul khrims gsum/ / so sor brtan por bzung bar bgyi/ /
I will hold firmly the three modes of ethical conduct: training in ethical conduct, gathering virtuous qualities, and benefiting sentient beings.
sangs rgyas chos dang dge 'dun te/ / bla na med pa'i dkon mchog gsum/ / sangs rgyas rnal 'byor las skyes pa'i/ / sdom pa deng nas brtan por bzung / /
The Buddha, dharma, and saṅgha are the unsurpassable three jewels. From now on, I will hold firmly the vows arising from buddhayoga.
rdo rje'i rigs mchog chen po la/ / rdo rje dril bu'i phyag rgya yang / / yang dag nyid du bzung bar bgyi/ / slob dpon dag kyang bzung bar bgyi/ /
For the great, supreme vajra family, I will hold perfectly the vajra, ghaṇṭā, and mudrās and I will hold the ācārya.
rin chen rigs mchog chen po yi/ / dam tshig yid du 'ong ba la/ / nyin re bzhin (293)yang dus drug tu/ / sbyin pa rnam bzhi rtag tu sbyin/ /
For the great, supreme ratna family, {293} I will always perform the four types of generosity six times each day as the samaya that is pleasing to the mind.
byang chub chen po las byung ba'i/ / pad+ma'i rigs can dag pa la/ / phyi nang gsang ba theg pa gsum/ / dam pa'i chos ni ma lus bzung / /
For the great, supreme padma family, arising from great awakening, I will hold all the genuine dharma of the three yānas, outer, inner, and secret.
las kyi rigs mchog chen po la/ / sdom pa thams cad ldan par ni/ / yang dag nyid du bzung bar bgyi/ / mchod pa'i las kyang ci nus bgyi/ /
For the great, supreme karma family, I will hold perfectly all the vows. I will perform all possible acts of worship.
byang chub sems ni bla med mchog / dam pa bdag gis bskyed bgyis nas/ / sems can kun gyi don gyi phyir/ / bdag gis sdom pa ma lus bzung / /
Having developed genuine, supreme, unsurpassable bodhicitta, I will hold all the vows for the benefit of all sentient beings.
ma bsgral ba rnams bdag gis bsgral/ / ma grol ba rnams bdag gis dgrol/ / dbugs ma phyin pa dbugs dbyung zhing / / sems can mya ngan 'das la 'god/ /
May I release those who have not been released. May I liberate those who have not been liberated. May I provide relief to those who have no relief. May I establish sentient beings in nirvāṇa.
ces lan gsum brjod/
Recite that three times.
gsum pa
c. Samādhi Abhiṣeka
ting nge 'dzin gyi dbang bskur ba'i thog mar brgyud pa'i gsol 'debs 'don par gsungs pas rgyas bsdus gang rung 'don/ bsdu na/
It is taught that a lineage supplication should be recited at the beginning of the samādhi abhiṣeka. Therefore, recite a long or short one, as you prefer. An abbreviated one is as follows:

ma nam mkha' dang mnyam pa'i sems can thams cad bla ma sangs rgyas rin po che la skyabs su mchi'o/ / chos rje sangs rgyas bka' drin can la skyabs su mchi'o/ / bla ma ngo bo nyid kyi sku la= / bla ma kun khyab chos kyi sku la= / bla ma longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sku la= / bla ma thugs rje sprul pa'i sku la skyabs su mchi'o/ / ces gsol ba lan mang du btab/

My mother sentient beings, who equal the extent of space, take refuge in the gurus, the precious buddhas. We take refuge in the dharma lords, the kind buddhas. We take refuge in the gurus, the svabhāvakāya. We take refuge in the gurus, the all-pervasive dharmakāya. We take refuge in the gurus, the saṃbhogakāya. We take refuge in the gurus, the compassionate nirmāṇakāya. Thus, supplicate many times.
dpal ldan bla ma rin po che/ / sku gsung thugs las byung ba yis/ / bdag la dbang bzhi bskur du gsol/ / smin cing grol bar mdzad du gsol/ /
Glorious, precious guru: with your body, speech, and mind, please bestow upon me the four abhiṣekas. Please mature and liberate me.
bla ma'i sku la gsol ba 'debs/ / lus la bde drod 'bar bar byin gyis rlobs/ / bla ma'i gsung la gsol ba= / ngag la nus pa thon par byin= /
I supplicate the body of the guru. Bless my body so that it blazes with bliss and warmth. I supplicate the speech of the guru. Bless my speech that it may be efficacious.
bla ma'i thugs la gsol= / sems la rtogs pa 'char bar byin= / bla ma'i sku gsung thugs la gsol ba= / sgo gsum dbyer med rtogs par byin gyis rlobs/
I supplicate the mind of the guru. Bless my mind so that realization dawns. I supplicate the body, speech, and mind of the guru. Bless me that I may realize the inseparability of my three doors.

zhes gsol ba btab pas/ bla ma'i spyi bo'i oM las 'od zer dkar po 'phros rang gi spyi bor thim/ sku las sku dpag tu med pa byung lus (294) la thim pas lus kyi sdig sgrib dag / bum pa'i dbang thob/ lus sku rdo rje'i rang bzhin tu gyur/ lam bskyed rim sgom pa la dbang / 'bras bu sprul sku thob pa'i skal ldan tu byas/

Having supplicated in that way, from the oṃ at the guru’s head, white light rays stream forth and dissolve into my head. {294} From their body, innumerable forms of their body appear and dissolve into my body. My negative actions and obscurations of body are purified, and I receive the vase abhiṣeka. My body becomes of the nature of vajra body. I am empowered to meditate on the generation process as the path. I become endowed with the fortune of attaining the nirmāṇakāya as the result.

bla ma'i mgrin pa'i AHlas 'od zer dmar po 'phros/ rang gi mgrin par thim/ zhal nas sngags phreng dpag tu med pa byung ngag la thim pas ngag gi sdig sgrib dag gsang ba'i dbang thob/ ngag gsung rdo rje'i rang bzhin tu gyur/ lam gtum mo sgom pa la dbang / 'bras bu chos sku thob pa'i skal ldan tu byas/

From the āḥ at the guru’s throat, red light rays stream forth and dissolve into my throat. From their mouth, innumerable mantra garlands appear and dissolve into my speech. My negative actions and obscurations of speech are purified, and I receive the secret abhiṣeka. My speech becomes of the nature of vajra speech. I am empowered to meditate on caṇḍālī as the path. I become endowed with the fortune of attaining the dharmakāya as the result.

bla ma'i thugs ka'i hU~M las 'od zer sngon po 'phros rang gi snying gar thim/ thugs ka nas phyag mtshan dpag tu med pa byung snying gar thim pas yid kyi sdig sgrib dag / shes rab ye shes kyi dbang thob/ yid thugs rdo rje'i rang bzhin tu gyur/ lam pho nya sgom pa la dbang / 'bras bu longs sku thob pa'i skal ldan tu byas/ de nas bla ma yab yum 'od du zhu nas rang la thim pas rang gi lus ngag yid gsum dang / bla ma'i sku gsung thugs dbyer med du gyur/ lam phyag rgya chen po sgom pa la dbang / 'bras bu ngo bo nyid sku 'grub pa'i skal ldan tu bsams la ci gnas su mnyam par bzhag go /

From the hūṃ at the guru’s head, blue light rays stream forth and dissolve into my heart. From their mind, innumerable emblems appear and dissolve into my heart. My negative actions and obscurations of mind are purified, and I receive the prajñājñāna abhiṣeka. My mind becomes of the nature of vajra mind. I am empowered to meditate on emissaries as the path. I become endowed with the fortune of attaining the saṃbhogakāya as the result. Then, the guru, male and female consorts, melts into light and dissolves into me. My body, speech, and mind and the guru’s body, speech, and mind become inseparable. I am empowered to meditate on mahāmudrā as the path. I become endowed with the fortune of achieving the svabhāvakāya as the result. Thus, contemplate, and rest in equipoise as much as you can.
gnyis pa
II. The Main Practice

dngos gzhi la rgyal po chos nyid mi 'gyur ba'i nyams len bsre 'pho skor gsum bskyed rdzogs zung 'jug gi gdams pa rnams yin pas gzhan tu shes/ dmangs phal pa phrin las mthun sbyor gyi rnal 'byor bdun 'dir bstan par bya ba yin pas/

For the main practice, the practices of the king, unchanging dharmatā, are the instructions on threefold mixing and transference and on unifying the generation and perfection processes. These should be learned from other sources. The seven yogas of the conducive activities of the common people will be taught here.
dang po
A. Supplication
gsol 'debs skabs 'dir mi dgos/
Supplication is not needed in this context.
gnyis pa bskyed rim
B. The Generation Process
['di] la lnga'i
This has five parts.
dang po
1. The External Maṇḍala

phyi dkyil sgom pa'i thog mar bgegs bskrad pa ni/ dbang bzhi pa'i mnyam gzhag gi ngang las/ snying rje chen po'i dbang gis rang gi thugs ka'i hU~M mthing nag las 'od zer lcags kyu'i rnam pa phyogs bcur 'phros/ phyogs bcu'i dgra bgegs gdug pa can rnams bkug cing steng 'og phyogs mtshams rdo rje'i gur dang bla bre sa gzhi rwa ba drwa ba sra zhing brtan pa ye shes kyi me rab tu 'bar bar gyur/

Begin the meditation on the external maṇḍala by expelling obstructors. Within a state of equipoise of the four abhiṣekas, recite: Through the power of great compassion, from a dark-blue hūṃ at my heart, light rays in the form of iron hooks radiate to the ten directions. They summon my enemies, obstructors, and all malevolent ones in the ten directions. Above, below, and in the main and intermediate directions, a vajra tent, canopy, ground, fence, and nets are solid and firm, blazing with wisdom fire.
oM badzra rak+Sha rak+Sha hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/
oṃ vajra rakṣa rakṣa huṃ hūṃ phaṭ svāhā {295}

de'i dbus su b+h+rU~M las (295)mtshon cha'i 'khor lo rtsibs bcu pa/ kha dog ser po cher 'bar ba/ rtse dang dpal shin tu rno zhing khog pa stong pa'i steng 'og gi rtsibs gyen thur du zug cing me rab tu 'bar bar gyur/

In the center of that, from bhrūṃ, appears a ten-spoked cakra of weapons. It is yellow and ablaze. Its tips and points are sharp and hollow. Its upper and lower spokes stick up and down, blazing with fire.
oM badzra tsakra rak+Sha rak+Sha hU~M hU~M phaT/
oṃ vajra cakra rakṣa rakṣa huṃ hūṃ phaṭ

de'i nang gi dbus dang rtsibs bcu'i 'khor lo la ma reg pa'i bar snang rnams su pad nyi dbang phyug pho mo/ phyogs skyong bcu chung mar bcas pa dregs stobs nyams nas gan rkyal du 'gyel te/ rkang pa lcags sgrog gis sbrel zhing lag pa thal mo sbyar ba'i gdan rnams grub par gyur/

Within that, in the center and in the empty spaces of that ten-spoked cakra, not touching it, on lotuses and suns, are the male and female lords, the protectors of the ten directions and their wives, their haughtiness and strength broken, lying on their backs. Their feet are shackled, and their hands are in añjali. They form the seats.

dbus kyi gdan gyi steng du skad cig gis rang nyid rdo rje hU~M mdzad khams gsum las rnam par rgyal ba sku mdog mthing nag bskal pa'i me ltar 'bar ba/ g.yas dkar g.yon dmar dbus mthing ba'i zhal gsum phyag drug pa/ phyag dang po gnyis rdo rje dang dril bu 'dzin pas rang 'dra'i yum la 'khyud pa/ gnyis pa na lcags kyu dang zhags pa/ gsum pa na kha T+wAM ga dang thod pa 'dzin pa/ zhabs g.yas brkyang gi stabs kyis gdug pa can thams cad kyi bdag po 'jigs byed dang dus mtshan mnan pa/

On the center seat, instantly I appear as Vajra Hūṃkāra, victorious over the three realms, dark blue and blazing like the eon-ending fires. I have three faces: the right one is white; the left is red; and the middle, blue. Of my six hands, the first pair are holding a vajra and ghaṇṭā, embracing my consort who is like myself. The second pair holds an iron hook and noose. The third pair holds a khaṭvāṃga and skull cup. My outstretched right leg presses down on Bhairava and Kālarātri, masters of all malevolent ones.

de'i thugs ka'i hU~M las skad cig gis khro bo brgyad spros te/ de yang shar gyi rtsibs su rdo rje drag po sngon po/ byang du rdo rje thabs sbyor ljang gu/ nub tu rdo rje gtsug tor dmar po/ lhor rdo rje nyi ma ser po/ shar lhor rdo rje 'jigs byed dmar po/ lho nub tu rdo rje stobs chen sngon po/ nub byang du rdo rje nag po nag po/ byang shar du rdo rje gnod sbyin dkar po/

From the hūṃ in my heart, instantly eight krodhas emanate. On the eastern spoke is blue Vajrarudra. On the northern spoke is green Vajrakuṇḍalī. On the western spoke is red Vajroṣṇiṣa. On the southern spoke is yellow Vajrasūrya. On the southeastern spoke is red Vajrabhairava. On the southwestern spoke is blue Vajramahābala. On the northwestern spoke is black Vajrakāla. On the northeastern spoke is white Vajrayakṣa.

thams cad kyang rab tu khros pa zhal gsum phyag drug pa/ g.yas dkar g.yon dmar dbus mthing ba la sogs pa g.yas g.yon gyi phyag dang po gnyis na kha T+wAM ga dang thod pa/ de'i 'og ma lcags kyu dang zhags pa/ de'i 'og ma cang te'u dang dril bu 'dzin pas rang 'dra'i yum la 'khyud pa/ g.yas brkyang gi stabs kyis sna tshogs pad+ma dang nyi ma'i gdan la brgya byin la sogs (296)pa mnan pa/

All are ferocious with three faces and six hands. Their right are white; the left are red; the middle, blue; and so on. Their first right and left hands hold khaṭvāṃgas and skull cups. Those below that hold iron hooks and nooses. Those below that hold changteus and ghaṇṭās. They embrace consorts like themselves. Their outstretched right legs press down on Indra and others on multicolored lotus and sun seats. {296}

de nas steng du rdo rje gtsug tor dkar po/ 'og tu rdo rje gnod mdzes sngon po zhal gsum phyag brgyad pa/ dang po gnyis na rdo rje dang dril bu 'dzin pas rang 'dra'i yum la 'khyud pa/ gnyis pa gnyis na lcags kyu dang zhags pa 'dzin pa/ gsum pa gnyis na mdung rtse gsum pa dang 'khor lo/ /bzhi pa gnyis na kha T+wAM ga dang thod pa 'chang ba/ g.yas brkyang bas tshangs pa dang sa bdag pho mo'i gdan la bzhugs pa/

Above them is white Vajroṣṇiṣa and below is blue Vajraśumbha. They have three faces and eight hands. Their first pair, holding vajras and ghaṇṭās, embrace their consorts who are like themselves. Their second pairs hold iron hooks and nooses. Their third pairs hold tridents and cakras. Their fourth pairs hold khaṭvāṃgas and skull cups. Their outstretched right legs stand on seats of Brahmā and male and female earth lords.
de thams cad kyang shin tu khros pa'i gzugs can thod pa dang rus pa'i rgyan drug dang sbrul gyis brgyan pa/ stag lpags kyi sham thabs can ye shes kyi me 'bar ba'i skur gyur/
All have ferocious forms and are adorned with skulls, the six bone ornaments, and snakes. They wear tiger-skin skirts, and their bodies blaze with wisdom fire.
oM badzra ma hA kro d+ha rA dza sa pa ri wA ra badzra sa mA dzaH e h+ye hi/ pad+ma ka ma lA ya s+t+waM/
oṃ vajra mahākrodharāja saparivāra vajra samājaḥ / ehyehi / padma kamalāyastvaṃ
sngags snga ma'i mthar/ Ar+g+haM nas/ shab+da 'i bar gyis mchod/
At the end of the previous mantra, offer from arghaṃ to śabda.
hU~M/ shes rab zag med stong pa'i ngang nyid las/ / snying rje chen pos 'gro don dpag med mdzad/ / log 'dren bgegs tshogs thal bar rlog mdzad pa'i/ / dpal chen khro bo'i tshogs la phyag 'tshal bstod/

hūṃ Within the state of emptiness, undefiled prajñā, your great compassion creates unlimited benefit for beings. To the host of glorious, great krodhas, who grind corrupting influences and obstructors to dust, I pay homage and praise.
ces pas bstod/
Thus, praise.

na mo/ rje btsun rtsa ba dang brgyud par bcas pa'i dpal ldan bla ma dam pa rnams kyi bka' bden pa dang / yi dam dkyil 'khor gyi lha tshogs= ma srin mkha' 'gro= sangs rgyas kyi= chos kyi= dge 'dun gyi= gsang sngags dang / rig sngags dang / gzungs sngags dang / snying po dang / phyag rgya dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / rgyu 'bras bslu ba med pa'i= rig pa'i rgyal po khro bo rnams kyi bka' bden pa dang / bden pa chen po'i byin gyi rlabs kyis/

Namo Through the truth of the words of the glorious, genuine, and exalted root and lineage gurus, the truth of the words of the assembly of yidam deities of the maṇḍalas, the truth of the words of the ḍākinīs, mother and sisters, the truth of the words of the buddhas, the truth of the words of the dharma, the truth of the words of the saṅgha, the truth of the words of the secret mantras, awareness mantras, dhāraṇī mantras, the essence, mudrās, samādhis, and the infallible causes and their results, and the truth of the words of the vidyārājas and krodhas, and through the blessings of great truth—

spyir zhing bcu tshang ba'i dgra dang / khyad par dam pa'i chos bsgrub pa la bar du gcod pa'i bgegs gang yin pa de dag thams cad kyi mthu stobs brlag par gyur cig / nus pa nyams par gyur cig / drag shul dang rdzu 'phrul med par gyur cig / lus ngag rdul phran bzhin du brlag par gyur cig / rnam shes chos kyi (297) dbyings su sangs rgyas par gyur cig /

may the power and strength of the enemies who meet the ten criteria, in general, and, specifically, the power and strength of the obstructors who interrupt the practice of the genuine dharma, whoever they are, be crushed. May their powers be broken. May they have neither ferocity nor magical powers. May their bodies and speech be ground like powder. {297} May their consciousnesses be awakened in the dharmadhātu.
ces thal mo lan lnga brdab/
Clap your hands five times.
khro chen 'bar ba'i tshogs rnams kyis/ sogs/
May the assembly of blazing great krodhas, [grind to dust the bodies and speech of all enemies and obstructors, and liberate their consciousnesses in the dharmadhātu.]
slar yang khro bo'i nga rgyal gyis se gol phyogs bzhir brdab cing / khro bo bcu gcig gi thugs ka nas 'od zer 'phros pas dgra bgegs rnams sgo gsum g.yo 'gul mi nus par gyur/

Again, with the pride of the krodhas, snap your fingers in the four directions. From the hearts of the eleven krodhas, light rays stream forth and render the three doors of all enemies and obstructors immobile.
oM suM b+ha ni lan gsum brjod/
Say oṃ sumbha ni three times.

slar yang thugs ka nas stod khro bo smad phur bu'i rnam pa me 'bar ba dpag tu med pa phyogs bcur 'phros te/ bgegs rnams kyi spyi bor phur bu bkod par gyur/ phur bu tho bas bsdigs pa'i phyag rgya bca'/

Again, from their hearts, innumerable blazing forms of krodhas above and kīlas below radiate to the ten directions. The kīlas are placed on the heads of all obstructors. With the kīla, do the mudrā of threatening with a hammer.

oM b+ha g+ha g+hA ta ya g+hA ta ya sarba duSh+TAM bi g+h+nAn hU~M phaT/ kI la ya kI la ya sarba pA paM hU~M phaT/ hU~M hU~M hU~M badzra kI la ya badzra d+hA ra A dz+nya pa ya ti/ sarba duSh+TAM big+hA na kA ya wA ka tsit+ta badzra kI la ya hU~M phaT/ oM badzra mung+ga ra badzra kI la ya A ko Ta ya hU~M phaT/ ces lan gsum brjod pas/

oṃ gha gha ghātaya ghātaya sarvaduṣṭāṃ vighnān hūṃ phaṭ / kīlaya kīlaya sarvapāpaṃ hūṃ phaṭ / hūṃ hūṃ hūṃ vajrakīlaya vajradhāra ājñāpayati / sarvaduṣṭāṃ vighnān kāya vāk citta vajra kīlaya hūṃ phaṭ / oṃ vajramudgara hūṃ phaṭ Say that three times.

rkang mthil gnyis kyi bar du phug nas/ srog 'od gsal du thim ste bde ba chen po'i rang bzhin du gyur pa dang / phur bu rnams hU~M yig tu gyur nas khro bo rang rang la thim zhing / khro bo rnams las 'od zer 'phros pas dgra bgegs rnams 'khor lo'i rtsibs la bskyon zhing / 'khor lo g.yas phyogs su drag tu mi 'gul ba ltar 'khor bas/ mtshon cha'i char dang / 'khor lo'i rtsibs dang / me rlung gis dgra bgegs rnams rdul du brlag par byas/ rnam shes rnams yi ge a dkar po'i rnam par khro bo'i thugs kar thim pas chos kyi dbyings su sangs rgyas par bsam zhing / rab tu khros pa'i tshig gis/

Being pierced to the soles of their feet, their life forces dissolve into luminosity and they become of the nature of great bliss. The kīlas become hūṃ letters and dissolve into each krodha. Light rays stream forth from the krodhas, causing the enemies and obstructors to mount the spokes of the cakra. The cakra spins so rapidly clockwise, it is as if it were standing still. A rain of weapons, the spokes of the cakra, and fiery winds grind the enemies and obstructors to dust. Their consciousnesses, in the form of white letter a’s, dissolve into the hearts of the krodhas, and they awaken in the dharmadhātu. Thus, contemplate. With fierce words:

oM kha badzra d+h+r-ig badzra hU~M ka ra badzra hU~M phaT/ oM badzra tsaN+Da badzra hU~M phaT/ oM badzra a na lArka badzra hU~M phaT/ oM badzra uSh+Ni Sha badzra hU~M phaT/ oM badzra kuN+Da lI badzra hU~M phaT/ oM badzra yak+Sha badzra hU~M phaT/ oM badzra ma hA bA la badzra hU~M phaT/ oM badzra kA la badzra hU~M phaT/ oM badzra b+hi Sha Na badzra hU~M phaT/ oM badzra uSh+Ni Sha tsakra warti (298)badzra hU~M phaT/ oM badzra pa ta la badzra hU~M phaT/ zhes lan gsum brjod/

oṃ khavajra dhṛga vajrahūṃkara vajra hūṃ phaṭ / oṃ vajracaṇḍa vajra hūṃ phaṭ / oṃ vajra analārka vajra hūṃ phaṭ / oṃ vajra uṣṇiṣa vajra hūṃ phaṭ / oṃ vajrakuṇḍalī vajra hūṃ phaṭ / oṃ vajrayakṣa vajra hūṃ phaṭ / oṃ vajramahābāla vajra hūṃ phaṭ / oṃ vajrakāla vajra hūṃ phaṭ / oṃ vajrabhiṣaṇa vajra hūṃ phaṭ / oṃ vajra uṣṇiṣacakravarti vajra hūṃ phaṭ / {298} oṃ vajrapatala vajra hūṃ phaṭ Three times.
oM badzra ma hA kro d+ha rA dza sa pa ri wA ra Ar+g+haM nas shab+da 'i bar gyis mchod/
oṃ vajramahākrodharāja saparvara arghaṃ…śabda With that, make offerings.

sngar ltar bstod/ slar yang thugs ka'i 'od kyis gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba bskul/ de'i 'od kyis phyogs mtshams kyi khro bo brgyad bskul/ thams cad zhal phyir gzigs shing thugs ka'i 'od zer dang drag sngags kyi sgras dgra bgegs gnod byed rnams bkug nas 'khor lo'i rtsibs la bskyon/ mtshon cha'i char dang me rlung gis thams cad rdul du brlag / rnam shes a dkar po'i rnam pas khro bo'i thugs kar thim pas/ chos kyi dbyings su sangs rgyas par bsams la/

Praise as before. Again, light from their hearts invokes Uṣṇīṣacakravarti. That light invokes the eight krodhas of the main and intermediate directions. All their faces look outward. Light rays from their hearts and the sounds of wrathful mantras summon the enemies, obstructors, and harmful beings to mount the spokes of the cakras. The rain of weapons and the fiery winds grind them all to dust. Their consciousnesses, in the form of white letter a’s, dissolve into the hearts of the krodhas, and they awaken in the dharmadhātu. Thus, contemplate and say:

na maHsa man+ta kA ya wA ka tsit+ta badzra he ru kA nAM/ oM hU~M badzra he ru ka tsakra warti/ sarba lo ki ka lo kot+ta rA Ni yan+t+ra man+t+ra tan+t+ra tsUr+Na pra yo ga dI ni/ ye na ke na tsi ta tA ni sarba ni/ A kaD+D+h+ya A kaD+D+h+ya/ tardza ya tardza ya/ gr-ih+Na gr-ih+Na/ b+hak+Sha ya b+hak+Sha ya/ trA sa ya trA sa ya/ ha na ha na/ da ha da ha/ pa tsa pa tsa/ k+Sh+mAM k+Sh+mAM/ dz+nyau dz+nyau/ ma tha ma tha/ bi d+hAn+sa ya bi d+h+wAn+sa ya/ sha ta sa ha sra/ tsUr+Na ya tsUr+Na ya/ oM phaT/ badzra he ru ka uSh+NI Sha tsakra warti/ ta s+yai baMmu khaM tsak+Shu ban+d+ha ban+d+ha/

namaḥ samanta kāya vāk citta vajraherukā kānāṃ / oṃ hūṃ vajraheruka cakravarti / sarvalokikalo kottrāṇi yantra mantra tantra cūrṇa prayoga dīni / yena kena cita tāni sarvani / ākaḍḍhya ākaḍḍhya / tarjaya tarjaya / gṛhṇa gṛhṇa / bhakṣaya bhakṣaya / trāsaya trāsaya / hana hana / daha daha / paca paca / kṣmāṃ kṣmāṃ / jñauṃ jñauṃ / matha matha / vidhvānsaya vidhvānsaya / śatasahasra / cūrṇa yacūrṇaya / oṃ phaṭ / vajraheruka uṣṇīṣacakravarti / tasyai vaṃ mukhaṃ cakṣu bandha bandha
dgra bgegs byad ma gnod byed thams cad shIn+taM ku ru hU~M hU~M phaT phaT swA hA/ zhes lan gsum brjod rjes/
Enemies, obstructors, sorcerers, and harmful beings: śīntaṃ kuru hūṃ hūṃ phaṭ phaṭ svāhā. Say that three times, and then say:
khro bo rnams thugs zhi bas 'khor lo yang mi 'gul ngar srung / khro bo rten bcas 'od du zhu ste rang la thim/ rang yang 'od du zhu nas chos kyi dbyings kyi ye shes su bsam mo/ /

The krodhas with their peaceful minds protect without the cakra moving. The krodhas with their supports melt into light and dissolve into me. I also melt into light and become the wisdom of the dharmadhātu. Thus, contemplate.
gnyis pa chos thams cad stong par sbyang ba ni/
2. Purifying All Phenomena into Emptiness
oM shU n+ya tA dz+nyA na badzra swa b+ha ba At+ma ko‘haM/
oṃ śūnyatā jñāna vajra svabhāva ātmako ’haṃ
zhes brjod cing / rang gzhan snod bcud kyis bsdus pa'i chos thams cad rang bzhin gyis stong pa nyid du gyur/ stong pa'i ngang las/
And: All phenomena, which includes myself, others, the environment, and its inhabitants, are naturally emptiness. Within the state of emptiness…
gsum pa srung ba'i 'khor lo bsgom pa ni/
3. Meditation on the Protection Cakra

nam mkha'i khams su e e las chos kyi 'byung gnas phyi dkar la nang dmar ba/ gdengs ka che ba gnyis kha sbyar zhing / rtse mo rno ba gnyis steng (299)'og tu phyogs pa'i nang du/ ya~M las rlung gi dkyil 'khor zla gam ljang sngon ya~M gyis mtshan pa/ de'i steng du ra~M las me'i dkyil 'khor gru gsum dmar po ra~M gyis mtshan pa/ de'i steng du ba~M las chu'i dkyil 'khor zlum po dkar po ba~M gyis mtshan pa/ de'i steng du la~M las sa'i dkyil 'khor gru bzhi ser po la~M gyis mtshan pa/ de'i steng du su~M las rin po che sna tshogs las grub pa'i ri rab lhun po/ de'i steng du pa~M las sna tshogs pad+ma 'dab ma sum cu rtsa gnyis pa dang / ra~M las nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor gyi steng du hU~M sna tshogs mdog can 'od du zhu ba las sna tshogs rdo rje rtse mo lnga pa/ shar dkar/ lho ser/ nub dmar/ byang ljang / lte ba mthing nag hU~M gis mtshan pa/ de las 'od zer phyogs bcur 'phros pas/ 'og rdo rje'i sa gzhir grub par bsam/ byin gyis brlab phyir/

In the dhātu of space, from e and e, sources of dharmas appear, white on the outside, red on the inside. Their flat surfaces face each other, and their sharp tips face above and below. {299} Within those, from yaṃ, is a wind maṇḍala, a blue-green half-moon marked by yaṃ. Above that, from raṃ, is a fire maṇḍala, a red triangle marked by raṃ. Above that, from vaṃ, is a water maṇḍala, a white circle marked by vaṃ. Above that, from laṃ, is an earth maṇḍala, a yellow square marked by laṃ. Above that, from suṃ, is Mount Meru made from various jewels. Above that, from paṃ, is a thirty-two-petaled multicolored lotus and, from raṃ, a sun maṇḍala. Above that is a multicolored hūṃ, which melts into light, from which appears a five-pointed viśvavajra. Its east is white; its south, yellow; west, red; and north, green. Its center is dark blue, marked by hūṃ. Light rays stream forth from it to the ten directions, forming a vajra ground below. Thus, contemplate. In order to consecrate it, say:
oM me di nI badzrI b+ha wa badzra ban+d+ha hU~M/ zhes lan gsum brjod/
oṃ medinī vajrībhava vajrabandha hūṃ Say that three times.
de'i steng thams cad rdo rje'i gur gyis bkab par bsams la/
Above that, everywhere is enclosed within a vajra tent. Thus, contemplate and say:
oM badzra pany+dza ra hU~M ba~M hU~M/
oṃ vajrapañjara hūṃ vaṃ hūṃ
gur gyi nang du rdo rje'i bla bre grub par bsams la/
Within the tent, a vajra canopy is formed. Thus, contemplate and say:
oM badzra bi tA na hU~M kha~M hU~M/
oṃ vajravitāna hūṃ khaṃ hūṃ
gur gyi phyi rol du rdo rje rtse dgu pa rwa rab tu gdengs pa rtsig pa'i ra ba grub par bsams la/
Outside the tent, nine-pointed vajras with wide-open prongs form a fence that is the walls. Thus, contemplate and say:
oM badzra prA kA ra hU~M ba~M hU~M/
oṃ vajraprākāra hūṃ vaṃ hūṃ
de'i steng du gnam lcags kyi thog ser la sogs mtshon cha sna tshogs kyi char drag po phyir 'phro ba'i sna tshogs rdo rje'i drwa ba grub par bsams la/
Above that are nets of viśvavajras, projecting a violent rain of various weapons, meteoric iron hail and lightning, and the like. Thus, contemplate and say:
oM badzra sa ra dz+wa la tra~M sa~M tra~M/
oṃ vajrasarajāla traṃ saṃ traṃ

rdo rje'i sa gzhi ra ba drwa ba gur bla re rnams me'i rang bzhin du gyur pa las me 'bar te/ me lce gcig tu gyur pa gyen du rgyug cing thur du 'tshubs pa dang / phyogs mtshams kun tu go 'tshams med par 'phyong bas dgra bgegs rnams sreg par byed pa'i ye shes kyi me drag por bsams la/

The vajra ground, fence, net, tent, and canopy all become of the nature of fire, and from them fire blazes. The flames become one, racing upward, swirling downward, protecting in every direction with no gaps. It becomes a fierce wisdom fire, capable of incinerating enemies and obstructors. Thus, contemplate and say:
oM badzra dz+wa la a na lArka hU~M hU~M hU~M/ oM badzra rak+Sha rak+Sha hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/
oṃ vajrajvāla analārka hūṃ hūṃ hūṃ / oṃ vajra rakṣa rakṣa hūṃ hūṃ hūṃ phaṭ svāhā
zhes srung 'khor gyi sngags thams cad lan gsum brjod cing byin gyis brlab bo/ /
Say all the mantras of the protection cakra three times and consecrate. {300}
de nas bzhi pa rten gzhal (300) yas khang gdan dur khrod dang bcas pa bskyed pa ni/
4. Generating the Palace, Seats, and Charnel Grounds, the Supports

sna tshogs rdo rje'i lte ba'i steng du b+h+rU~M sna tshogs mdog can 'od du zhu zhing yongs su gyur pa las/ rin po che sna tshogs las grub pa'i thar pa chen po'i gzhal yas khang gru bzhi sgo bzhi'i nang nas rim pa bzhin du nag / dkar/ ser/ dmar/ ljang pa'i rtsig pa lnga dang ldan pa/ de'i steng na rin po che'i ba gam ser po'i ngos la chu srin mA ka ra'i kha nas do shal dang do shal phyed pa 'phyang ba/ de'i steng du bai DUr+Ya'i bad kyi ngos la rin po che'i dra ba dang drwa ba phyed pa 'phyang ba/

Above the center of the viśvavajra, a multicolored bhrūṃ melts into light and transforms into a palace of great liberation made from various jewels. It is square with four doors. From the inside, the walls have five layers: black, white, yellow, red, and green. Above those, on the sides of the yellow-jeweled dome are makaras from whose mouths hang necklaces and long necklaces. Above those, on the sides of the vaiḍūrya capping stones hang garlands and pendants of jewels.

de'i steng du rin po che'i mda' yab dang pu shus yongs su bskor ba/ nang rdo rje'i gdung zlum pos khor yug tu bskor ba'i dbus su rdo rje'i gdung bzhis mig mang ris su bris pa'i sna nas ka ba brgyad kyis rim pas bteg cing / dbus phyur bur gyur pa'i thog gi rtse mor rdo rje rin po che'i tog gis mtshan pa/

Above that is the surrounding jeweled parapet and coping. Inside, the round vajra beams completely encircle. In the middle, the ends of four vajra beams, decorated with a checkered pattern, are supported by eight columns. The peak of the domed roof is marked by a precious vajra finial.

sgo rnams kyi thad sor ka ba bzhi bzhis bteg pa'i rta babs 'og nas steng du rim pa bzhin du ser/ sngo/ ljang / dmar/ nag ser/ nag / sngo/ ljang / dmar/ dkar ba'i snam bu bcu gcig dang ldan pa'i rtser/ pad+ma la gnas pa'i chos kyi 'khor lo dang / gdugs dang / ri dwags pho mo dang bcas pa/

Next to the four doors are the torans, which are each supported by four columns. They have eleven friezes, which, from the bottom to the top, are yellow, blue, green, red, black, yellow, black, blue, green, red, and white. On their tops are dharmacakras resting on lotuses, along with parasols and male and female deer.

gzhan yang gos dang 'phan dang me tog gi phreng ba dang / zla ba rlung gis bskyod pa dang rnga yab nor bu'i yu ba can la sogs te rgyan du mas brgyan pa'i phyi 'gram 'dod yon gyi snam bu dmar po'i stegs bu'i steng du lha mo bcu drug gi gdan dang bcas pa'i gzhal yas khang pa'i steng 'og gi lha snam shar sngo/ byang ljang / nub dmar/ lho ser pa'i 'og dbus mthing ga 'phang mar gyur pa'i steng du/ sa 'og skyod sku'i 'khor lo dkar po mu khyud 'khor lo'i phreng bas bskor ba/ de'i steng du sa spyod gsung gi 'khor lo dmar po mu khyud pad+ma'i phreng bas bskor ba/

Furthermore, the palace is adorned with many other ornaments, such as cloths, pendants, garlands of flowers, moons blown by the wind, yak-tail fans with jeweled handles, and so forth. Outside is the red plinth of pleasure, where there are small stands with the seats for the sixteen offering goddesses. The upper and lower deity podiums of the palace are blue in the east, green in the north, red in the west, and yellow in the south. Below those, in the center there is a deep blue dais. Above that is the white cakra of body, ruling below the earth, surrounded by its rim, a garland of cakras. Above that is the red cakra of speech, ruling on the earth, surrounded by its rim, a garland of lotuses.
de'i steng du mkha' spyod thugs kyi 'khor lo mthing ga mu khyud rdo (301) rje'i phreng bas bskor ba ste/
Above that is the deep blue cakra of mind, ruling the sky, surrounded by its rim, a garland of vajras. {301}

thams cad kyang rtsibs brgyad pa kun gyi lte ba ngo bo gcig las/ rnam pa'i kha dog rang rang gi mdog las steng 'og tu lhag par mngon pa sum brtsegs kyi steng ma/ thugs kyi 'khor lo'i lte ba bde chen 'khor lo'i dbus su sna tshogs pad+ma 'dab ma brgyad pa'i steng du zla ba dang / nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor/

All of them have eight spokes that are of one essence at the center. The color of their manifestation is their own respective color. They are three layers clearly manifesting above and below. In the center of the upper one, the mind cakra, in the middle of the mahāsukhacakra, is a multicolored eight-petaled lotus. Above that are moon and sun maṇḍalas.

de'i steng du 'jigs byed nag po mgo bo byang dang / dus mtshan dmar mo mgo bo lhor phyogs pa gan rkyal du 'gyel nas lag pa thal mo sbyar zhing rkang pa lcags sgrog gis sbrel ba'i gdan dang pad+ma'i phyogs bzhir nyi ma ro'i gdan dang / mtshams bzhir bum thod bdud rtsis gang ba'i khar sna tshogs rdo rjes mtshan pa re re/ 'khor lo rnams kyi rtsibs kun gyi nang dang sgo mtshams rnams su pad+ma nyi ma ro'i gdan re re grub par bsam/

Above those are the seats of black Bhairava, whose head is facing north, and red Kālarātri, whose head is facing south. Both are lying on their backs, their hands in añjali, with their legs shackled. In the four main directions of the lotus are sun and corpse seats. In the four intermediate directions are vases with skull cups filled with amṛta, the mouths of which are marked by viśvavajras. On the inside of all the spokes of the cakras and in all the doorways are seats of lotuses, suns, and corpses. Thus, contemplate.

gzhal yas khang pa'i phyi rol du khyams/ de'i phyi rol rdo rje'i gur dang ra ba'i bar du dur khrod chen po brgyad ni/ shar nas g.yon skor du/ gtum drag / tshang tshing drag po/ 'bar ba 'khrigs pa/ keng rus thod pa can/ shar lho nas g.yas skor du/ dpal gyi nags tshal/ mun pa drag po/ kI li kI li'i sgra can/ AT+Ta Te rgod rnams gnas pa/ de rnams su shing chen po brgyad/ sprin chen po brgyad/ ri chen po brgyad/ mchod rten chen po brgyad/ me chen po brgyad/ chu chen po brgyad dang / 'og gi sa gzhi thams cad mi ro dang rta ro dang sha khrag rus pas yongs su gang ba 'jigs shing skyi g.ya' ba'i dur khrod chen po rnams grub par gyur/

Outside the palace is a courtyard. Outside of that and before the vajra tent and fence are the eight great charnel grounds. From the east, counterclockwise are Caṇḍogra, Gahvara, Jvālākula, and Karaṅka Kāpāla. From the southeast, clockwise are *Śrīvana, Ghorāndhakāra, Kilikilārava, and Aṭṭaṭehāsa. In all are eight great trees, eight great clouds, eight great mountains, eight great stūpas, eight great fires, and eight great rivers. The ground below in all of those is filled with human corpses, dead horses, flesh, blood, and bones. Those are the terrifying and dread-inducing great charnel grounds.
lnga pa
5. [Generating the Deities, the Supported][2]
['di] la bzhi'i
This has four parts.
dang po brten pa lha bskyed pa'i yan lag
a. The Branches of Generating the Deities, the Supported
['di] la'ang gsum gyi
This has three parts.
dang po gtso bo yab yum bskyed pa ni/
i. Generating the Principal Male and Female Consorts

dbus kyi gdan gyi steng du/ g.yon skor du dngul chu ltar gsal la 'tsher ba'i oM a A/ i I/ u U/ r-i r-I/ l-i l-I/ e ai/ o au/ aM aH g.yas skor du/ oM a A nas/ aM aH zhes pa'i bar/ phrag gnyis rnams 'od du zhu (302) las byung ba'i zla ba'i dkyil 'khor nya gang ba/ de'i dbus su thod pa rak+tas gang ba'i nang du/ rang gi rnam shes hU~M las rdo rje sngon po rtse lnga pa 'od kyi rang bzhin can/

Above the seat in the middle, counterclockwise are oṃ a ā / i ī / u ū / ṛ ṝ / ḷ ḹ / e ai / o au / aṃ aḥ and clockwise are oṃ a ā /…aṃ aḥ. All are luminescence, like mercury. {302} The two sets melt into light, from which appears a maṇḍala of the full moon. In its center is a skull cup filled with rakta. Within that is my consciousness, hūṃ, from which there is a blue five-pointed vajra of the nature of light.

de'i steng du g.yas skor du rak+ta ltar dmar zhing snum pa'i ka kha ga g+ha nga / tsa tsha dza dz+ha nya/ Ta Tha Da D+ha Na/ ta tha da d+ha na/ pa pha ba b+ha ma/ ya ra la wa/ sha Sha sa ha k+ShaH ya ra la wa Da D+ha/ g.yon skor du/ ka kha ga g+ha nga / nas/ Da D+ha/ zhes pa'i bar

Above that, clockwise are ka kha ga gha ṅa / ca cha ja jha nya / ṭa ṭha ḍa ḍha ṇa / ta tha da dha na / pa pha ba bha ma / ya ra la va / śa ṣa sa ha kṣaḥ / ya ra la va ḍa ḍha and counterclockwise are ka kha ga gha ṅa…ḍa ḍha. All are red and shiny, like rakta.

phrag gnyis rnams 'od du zhu pa las byung ba'i nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor rnams gcig tu 'dres pa las 'od 'phros/ 'phags pa mchod/ sems can gyi don byas/ tshur 'dus yongs su gyur pa las/ rang bcom ldan 'das dpal he ru ka 'khor lo sdom pa'i skur grub cing gsal ba ni/ sku mdog mthing gzhal bzhi las rtsa zhal mthing ga khros shing 'gyur ba/ g.yon zhal ljang gu rngams shing bsdams pa/ rgyab zhal dmar po cung zad zhi zhing chags pa/ g.yas zhal ser po gdangs shing bzhad pa/ zhal re re la'ang dmar la zlum pa'i spyan gsum gsum dang ldan pa/ smin ma dang sma ra ag tshom dmar ser me ltar 'bar ba/ mche ba gtsigs shing khro gnyer g.yo ba'o/ /

The two sets melt into light, from which appears maṇḍalas of the sun. They blend as one and radiate light, making offerings to the noble ones and benefiting sentient beings. It gathers back, and the vajra transforms: I exist and appear in the form the Bhagavān, the glorious Heruka Cakrasaṃvara. I am deep blue in color with four faces. My main face is deep blue, wrathful and changing. My left face is green, wondrous and controlled. My rear face is red, slightly peaceful and passionate. My right face is yellow, brilliant and laughing. Each face has three eyes, red and round. My eyebrows, moustache, and beard are orange, blazing like fire. My fangs are bared, and my furrowed brow quivers.

phyag bcu gnyis dang ldan pa'i dang po gnyis rdo rje dang dril bu 'dzin pas yum la 'khyud pa/ tha ma gnyis zhing chen gyi g.yang gzhi dang / glang chen gyi ko rlon brgyangs te 'dzin pa/ g.yas kyi gnyis pa na DA ma ru/ gsum pa na gri gug / bzhi pa na dgra s+t+wa/ lnga pa na mdung rtse gsum pa/ g.yon gyi gnyis pa na rdo rje kha T+wAM ga/gsum pa na khrag gis gang ba'i thod pa/ bzhi pa na rdo rje'i zhags pa/ lnga pa na tshangs pa'i mgo bo gdong bzhi pa 'dzin pa/ zhabs g.yas brkyangs pas dus mtshan gyi snying ga dang / g.yon cung zad bskums pas 'jigs byed kyi snying gar mnan nas rol pa'i stabs kyis bzhugs pa'i sku la khrag zhag thal chen gyis byugs pa/

Of my twelve hands, my first two, holding a vajra and ghaṇṭā, embrace my consort. My last two hold outstretched a human skin of one meeting the great criteria and a fresh elephant hide. In my second right is a ḍamaru; in my third is a hooked knife; in my fourth, a battle-ax; and in my fifth, a trident. In my second left is a vajra khaṭvāṃga; in my third is a skull cup filled with blood; in my fourth, a vajra noose; and in my fifth, Brahmā’s head with his four faces. Standing in the playful posture with my right leg extended, I press down on the heart of Kālarātri, and with my left slightly bent, I trample on the heart of Bhairava. My body is smeared with blood, fat, and great ashes. {303}

dbu skra ral (303) pa'i cod pan gyi steng na sna tshogs rdo rje nor bu'i phreng ba dang / zla phyed rdo rjes mtshan pa/ thod skam gyi rtse rin chen 'bar bas spras pa lnga lnga'i dbu rgyan dang / rlon pa khrag 'dzag pa lnga bcu'i do shal can/ gcer bu sbrul dang rus pa'i rgyan drug dang ldan pa/ stag lpags rlon pa'i sham thabs lhab lhub tu 'phyang ba la sogs te rgyan dang cha lugs ldan pas sgeg pa/

Above the crown of my topknot of hair is a viśvavajra with a garland of gems and marked by a half moon and a vajra. I have a crown of five dried skulls whose tips are ornamented by blazing jewels, and a necklace of fifty fresh ones dripping blood. Naked, I wear snakes and the six bone ornaments. My fresh tiger-skin skirt sways back and forth. With all those ornaments and attributes and more, I am alluring.

dregs pa pho mo gdan du bting bas dpa' ba/ sku che yan lag rags pas mi sdug pa/ ha hA dang hi hI la sogs te rten 'brel bcu gnyis kyi bzhad sgra gad mor rgod pa/ hU~M phaT kyi nga ros drag shul dang ldan pa/ yan lag drug cu'i gdangs kyis log 'dren rnams spa bkong bar mdzad pas 'jigs pa/ rigs drug thugs rjes 'dzin pas brtse ba/ gdug pa can zhal du gsol bas rngams pa/ chos nyid ngang la bzhugs pas zhi ba ste/ gar dgu'i nyams dang ldan pa'i thugs kar hU~M sngon po dang bcas pa'i bcom ldan 'das he ru ka'o/ /

Trampling on seats of male and female arrogant ones, I am heroic. With a large body and huge limbs, I am revolting. I explode with the laughter of the twelve links of interdependence: ha hā, hi hī, and on and on. With the roar of hūṃ phaṭ, I am fierce. With the tunes of sixty parts, I intimidate all corrupting influences, and thus I am terrifying. Embracing the six realms with compassion, I am loving. Eating malevolent ones, I am amazing. Since I remain within dharmatā, I am peaceful. Thus, I am endowed with the nine moods of the dramatic arts. At my heart is a blue hūṃ. I am the Bhagavān, the Heruka.

de'i pang na bde ba skyed pa'i yum rdo rje phag mo ni/ sku mdog dmar mo zhal gcig phyag gnyis ma/ g.yas sdigs mdzub gri gug dang bcas pas log 'dren rnams la bsdigs shing / g.yon bdud bzhi'i khrag gis bkang ba'i thod pa yab kyi zhal du stob pa/ gzugs dang lang tsho dar la bab cing b+ha ga dang nu ma rab tu rgyas pa/ bde ba chen pos rnam par myos pa'i cha byad can gyi zhabs gnyis pad+ma'i skyil krung gis yab kyi sku la 'khril ba/ khro la 'dzum pa'i zhal mchi ba cung zad gtsigs shing mdzes la yangs pa'i spyan gsum dang ldan pa/ dbu skra sil bu'i stod cha gyen du brdzes pa 'khor lo dang me tog gi phreng bas mdzes shing / lhag ma thur du grol bas rked pa non pa/ mi mgo skam po lnga'i dbu rgyan dang / rlon pa khrag 'dzag pa lnga bcu'i do shal 'phyang zhing / gcer bu rus pa'i rgyan drug dang ldan pa/ thugs kar ba~M (304) dmar po dang bcas pa'i bde ba chen po'i bdag nyid ma ste/

In my lap is my consort who arouses bliss, Vajravārāhī, red, with one face and two hands. Her right holds a hooked knife with the threatening gesture, menacing corrupting influences. Her left serves a skull cup filled with the blood of the four māras to my mouth, as her consort. Her form, splendor, vitality, bhaga, and breasts are radiant. Her two legs, which have the quality of intoxicating with great bliss, are wrapped around me, as her consort, in the lotus posture. Her face is wrathful yet smiling, and she bares her fangs slightly. She is beautiful with three wide-open eyes. The upper part of her loose hair sweeps upward and is adorned with a cakra and flower garland. The remainder is free, reaching to her waist. She has a crown of five dried human heads and a necklace of fifty fresh ones dripping blood and is naked with the six bone ornaments. {304} At her heart is a red vaṃ. She is the embodiment of great bliss.
yab yum gnyis ka'ang ye shes kyi me 'bar ba'i dbus na bzhugs par bsam/
Both [of us, as] the male and female consorts reside in the midst of a raging fire of wisdom. Thus, contemplate.
gnyis pa nang gi 'khor bskyed pa ni/
ii. Generating the Inner Retinue

yab yum snyoms par zhugs pa'i bde ba chen po'i sgra dang / thugs ka'i sa bon gyi 'od kyis phyogs bcu'i sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad spyan drangs/ yab kyi zhal du zhugs/ thugs kar rjes chags kyi mes 'od du zhu/ bde ba chen po'i rang bzhin thig ler gyur pa gsang gnas brgyud de yum gyi mkha' nang du byon pas dpa' bo mkha' 'gro'i skur grub cing rdzogs pa

[We,] the male and female consorts, are seated in union. Light from our private parts of great bliss and from the seed syllables at our hearts invites the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions. They enter the mouth of me, the male consort, and the fire of passion at my heart causes them to melt into light and become a bindu of the nature of great bliss. That flows to my secret place and enters my female consort’s space. It forms into bodies of heroes and ḍākinīs and is complete.

yum gyi mkha' nang nas phyir 'phros te rang rang gi gdan thog tu 'khod pa ni/ bde chen 'khor lo'i phyogs kyi pad 'dab bzhi la/ shar du mkha' 'gro ma sngon mo/ byang du lA ma ljang gu/ nub tu dum skyes ma dmar mo/ lhor gzugs can ma ser mo rnams zhal gcig phyag gnyis ma/ g.yas dang po gri gug / gnyis pa na DA ma ru/ g.yon dang pos thod khrag / gnyis pa na kha T+wAM ga 'dzin pa/

They stream forth from my female consort’s space and arrange themselves on their respective seats. On the four petals of the lotus in the main directions of the mahāsukhacakra, in the east is blue Ḍākinī, in the north is green Lāma, in the west is red Khaṇḍarohā, and in the south is yellow Rūpiṇī. They all have one face and four hands.[3] Their first right ones hold hooked knives, and their second ones ḍamarus. Their first left ones hold skull cups with blood; and their second ones, khaṭvāṃgas.

khro la 'dzum pa'i zhal mche ba cung zad gtsigs shing / mdzes la yangs pa'i spyan gsum dang ldan pa/ dbu skra sil bu'i stod cha gyen du brdzes pa nor bu dang me tog gi phreng bas mdzes shing / lhag ma thur du grol bas rked pa non pa/ thod skam lnga'i dbu rgyan dang rlon pa khrag 'dzag pa lnga bcu'i do shal can/ gcer bu rus pa'i rgyan drug gis brgyan pa/ gzugs dang lang tsho dar la babs shing b+ha ga dang nu ma rab tu rgyas pa/ bde ba chen pos rnam par myos pa'i cha byad can gyi zhabs gnyis g.yas bskum zhing g.yon brkyang pa'i gar stabs kyis pad nyi ro'i gdan la bzhugs pa'o/ /

Their faces are wrathful yet smiling, and they bare their fangs slightly. They are beautiful with three wide-open eyes. The upper part of their loose hair sweeps upward and is adorned with gems and flower garlands. The remainder is free, reaching to their waists. They have crowns of five dried skulls and necklaces of fifty fresh ones dripping blood and are naked with the six bone ornaments. Their forms, splendor, vitality, bhagas, and breasts are radiant. Their two legs, which have the qualities of intoxicating with great bliss, are planted on their seats of lotuses, suns, and corpses in a dancing posture, with their right bent and their left extended.
de'i phyi rol thugs kyi 'khor lo'i shar phyi rtsibs/ pul+lI ra ma la yang khaN+Da ka phA la dang rab tu gtum mo/
Outside of that is the mind cakra. On its eastern spoke, Pullīramalaya, are Khaṇḍakapāla and Pracaṇḍā.
