sangs rgyas bsnyen pa la sogs pa/ / pad+mar bya ba ji bzhin byed/ / bde chen rgyal po rang nyid de/ / 'di nyid du ni rtag tu bzhugs/ /
Approaching the buddhas and more is done just like with the lotus. The sovereigns of great bliss themselves always abide in this.
blun po 'ga' zhig 'di spong ba/ / de la mchog gi dngos grub med/
Some fools reject this. They are without the supreme siddhi.

s+t+waM pad+ma mok+Sha hoH zhes gsungs shing pang du byon pa dang mnyam par sbyor bas dpa' bo thams cad spyan drangs/ zhal du zhugs pas lus la bde ba dang / /sems 'od gsal bar byas/ de'i gtum mo'i mes khams zhu nas lugs 'byung dang lugs ldog gi dga' ba bzhi bskyed par mos/

stvaṃ padma bhañja mokṣa hoḥ Thus, she comes to your lap and unites. This invites all the heroes, who enter your mouth, making your body blissful and your mind luminous. Feel that the fire of that caṇḍālī causes your dhātus to melt, which arouses the four joys of the forward and reverse sequences.
mig dar 'grol/
Remove their blindfolds.
sher dbang thob pas bde stong lhan skyes kyi nyams skyes/ sems kyi dri ma dag 'bras bu chos sku 'grub pa'i skal pa can du byas so/ /
Having received the prajñā abhiṣeka, the experience of connate bliss-emptiness has arisen. Your stains of mind are purified. You are a fortunate one who will achieve the dharmakāya as the result.
dbang bzhi ba tshig dbang rin po che ni/
4. The Fourth Abhiṣeka, the Precious Word Abhiṣeka
gsol 'debs rjes zlos/ skyabs med skyob pa skyabs kyi mchog / dpal ldan 'khor lo bde ba'i mchog / rgyu med par ni thugs rje che/ / mgon med bdag gi mgon mdzod cig / lan gsum/

Repeat the following supplication: The refuge for those without refuge, supreme of refuges, sublime, glorious Cakrasaṃvara, Great Compassionate One without cause, I have no protector—be my protector. Three times.
ngo sprod pa ni/
The pointing-out.
'di ni rang rig mdzes ma ste/ / phyi rol yul ni spangs pa'o/ / rig 'di bor nas de las ni/ / gzhan pa'i thabs kyis sangs rgyas med/ /
This is the beauty, reflexive awareness. Give up external objects. Rejecting this awareness, there will be no buddhahood through other means.
rig ma'i brtul zhugs spyod cig bu/ / brtul zhugs rnams kyi bla ma'i bla/ / ltos shig rang gi sems la ltos/ / bltas pas sems la grub pa med/ /
Vidyā discipline is the only practice. It is the highest of the high for disciplines. Look: look at your own mind. Looking, mind does not exist.
grub pa med pa'i sems nyid la/ / sna tshogs snang ba ngo mtshar che/ / rang sems chos sku'i me long la/ / gnyis med ye shes 'od du shar/ /
This very mind that does not exist appears in myriad ways—how wondrous. In the mirror of your own mind, the dharmakāya, the light of nondual wisdom arises.
shar tsam nyid nas grub pa med/ / bde chen lhan cig skyes pa yin/ /
At the very moment of arising, it does not exist. It is connate great bliss.

dbang gsum pa'i dus su thabs gyi rlung dang rtog pa mngon gyur rtsol bas bkag nas rang gi sems nyid skye 'gag gnas gsum gyi spros pa thams cad dang bral ba/ don gyi rig ma 'di bor na spros pa (461)gzhan gyis sangs rgyas mi thob pas/ brtul zhugs rnams kyi mchog rig ma 'di dang mi 'bral bar gyis shig / de ltar dbang bzhi pa zung 'jug gi nyams skyes/ sgo gsum gyi dri ma'i bag chags dag / gnas lugs phyag rgya chen po bsgom pa la dbang / 'bras bu ngo bo nyid sku thob pa'i skal pa can du byas so/ / des dbang bskur rnams grub nas/ dam tshig khas blang ba/ gtso bos ji ltar sogs dang / gtang rag gi maN+Dal/ lus longs spyod 'bul ba/ dge bsngo rnams spyi ltar byas pas grub bo/

During the third abhiṣeka, the winds of method and manifest thoughts are blocked with effort. Thus, your mind-itself is free from all elaborations of arising, ceasing, or abiding. {461} If you reject the actual vidyā, you will not attain buddhahood through other elaborations. Do not separate from this vidyā, the supreme of all disciplines. In that way, the experience of the fourth abhiṣeka, unification, arises. The latent tendencies of the stains of your three doors are purified. You are empowered to meditate on the abiding-state mahāmudrā. You are a fortunate one who will attain the svabhāvakāya as the result. Having completed the bestowal of the abhiṣekas, commit to the samayas with: Whatever the principal one commands, [all that I will do.] In thanks, offer a maṇḍala, your body, and possessions. Dedicating the virtue, as is customarily done, completes this.
lnga pa rjes kyi bya ba'i rim pa la/
V. The Stages of the Concluding Activities
dang po lag mchod ni/
First, the hand offering.

lag g.yon bsang sbyang / lag mthil du bdud rtsi'i thig le dang me tog gi tshom bu tshig bstun dgod cing / lag pa g.yon pa'i mthil du pad+ma 'dab ma lnga pa'i lte bar oM pa~M/ mdun nas g.yon skor du/ haM yoM/ hrIM moM/ hrIM hrIM/ huM hU~M/ phaT phaT rnams las yum gyi go cha'i lha mo rnams dang / mthe bong sogs lnga dang / sen mo'i ngos la oM taH na ma hi/ swA hA hu/ bau ShaT he/ huM hU~M hoH phaT phaT haM rnams las yab kyi go cha'i lha rnams me long nang gi gzugs brnyan lta bur khams lnga rnam par dag pa'i ngo bor gyur/ gong gi sngags rnams lan gcig brjod pa'i mthar/

Cleanse and purify your left hand. On the palm of your hand, arrange drops of amṛta and bunches of flowers in conjunction with the following words: On the palm of my left hand, in the center of a five-petaled lotus, are oṃ vaṃ. In front, counterclockwise, from haṃ yoṃ, hrīṃ moṃ, hriṃ hriṃ, huṃ hūṃ, and phaṭ phaṭ, are the armor goddesses for the female consort. On my five fingers, the thumb and the others, and my fingernails, from oṃ haḥ, nama hi, svāhā hu, vauṣat he, hūṃ hūṃ hoḥ, and phaṭ phaṭ haṃ, are the armor gods for the male consort. They are the essences of the purities of the five dhātus, appearing like images reflected in a mirror. Recite the above mantras once, and at the end say:

puSh+paM pra tIts+tsha swA hA sogs nyer spyod lngas mchod/ rkang brgyad gnyis kyis bstod/ oM AHhU~M gis bdud rtsi 'thor/ hU~M AHoM zhes lag mthil spyi bor byugs la/ lag pa'i lha rnams rang nyid la thim par gyur/ zhes mos/

puṣpaṃ pratīccha svāhā… Thus, present the five traditional offerings. Praise with the two eight-line verses. With oṃ āḥ hūṃ, sprinkle amṛta. Saying hūṃ āḥ oṃ, rub the palm of your hand on the top of your head and say: The deities of the hand dissolve into me.
de nas gtor ma 'bul ba ni/
The torma offering.
nar mchod ltar byin gyis brlabs la/
Consecrate it according to the inner offering.
oM gu ru maN+Da la de ba DA ki nI d+harma pA la badzra yo ga yo gi nI sa pa ri wA ra ba liM ta kha kha khA hi khA hi/
oṃ guru maṇḍala deva ḍākinī dharmapāla vajra yoga yoginī saparivāra baliṃta kha kha khāhi khāhi
dang / na maHsarba ta thA ga ta sogs nam mkha' mdzod kyi sngags btags pa lan gsum gyis dbul/ mchod bstod 'dod don gsol/ 'jig rten pa la mkha' 'gro spyi gtor gyi cho gas btang ngo/ /

And adding the Gaganagañja mantra, namaḥ sarvatathāgata…, three times, offer it. Offer, praise, and request [the fulfillment of] your desired aims. Give to the worldly ones with the ritual of a general ḍākinī torma.
de nas tshogs mchod ni/
The feast offering.

thabs shes kyi rdzas sogs bza' btung ji ltar 'os par bsham/ bdud rtsi ltar byin brlab/ tshogs kyi yo byad zad mi shes pa'i (462) 'dod yon rnams bzang zhing rgya che ba/ bkod pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa sa dang bar snang thams cad khyab par gyur/ ces brjod cing bsam/

rang gi thugs ka'i sa bon las 'od zer 'phros pas rang bzhin gyi gnas nas rtsa ba'i bla ma dang rdo rje 'chang tha mi dad pa la brgyud pa'i bla ma dam pa rnams dang / yi dam dkyil 'khor gyi lha tshogs dpa' bo mkha' 'gro chos skyong srung ma'i tshogs kyis bskor ba mdun gyi nam mkhar

Light rays stream forth from the seed syllable in my heart inviting, from their natural abodes into the space in front, all the genuine lineage gurus, who are my root gurus and Vajradhara, indistinguishable, and the yidam deities of the maṇḍala, surrounded by the assembly of heroes, ḍākinīs, dharma protectors, and guardians.
oM badzra sa mA dzaH sa tshogs 'gron rnams spyan drangs la/ dzaHhU~M ba~M hoH sa bstim/ pad+ma ka ma lA ya s+t+waM gyis gdan phul/
oṃ vajra samājaḥ With that, invite the guests for the feast. With jaḥ hūṃ vaṃ hoḥ, they dissolve. With padma kamalāyastvaṃ, offer them seats.
bla ma yi dam lha tshogs la/ / sgo gsum gus pas phyag 'tshal lo/ / phyi nang gsang gsum mchod pa 'bul/ / dug gsum dbang gis sdig pa bshags/ /

To the gurus and assembly of yidam deities, I respectfully pay homage with my three doors. I present outer, inner, and secret offerings. I confess negative actions done under the influence of the three poisons.
dus gsum dge la rjes yi rang / / theg gsum chos 'khor bskor bzhin du/ / khams gsum 'gro ba'i don bzhugs gsol/ / dge bas sku gsum myur thob shog /

I rejoice in the virtue of the three times. While turning the dharmacakra of the three yānas, please remain for the sake of beings in the three realms. Through virtue, may the three kāyas be quickly achieved.
ces yan lag bdun pa phul/ spro na rdo rje'i glu blangs pa'i rjes tshogs phud cha gnyis su bsdus te/ phud dang po dkyil 'khor gyi mdun nam gtor ma la bran/ byin rlabs sngar bzhin dang /

With that, offer the sevenfold service. If you wish to elaborate, sing a vajra song. After that, gather the feast into two select portions. Place the first select portion in front of the maṇḍala or the torma, and sprinkle it. Consecrate it as before.
oM gu ru bud+d+ha bo d+hi satwa shrI tsakra sam+ba ra wI ra yo gi nI DA ka DA ki nI sarba d+harma pA la sa pa ri wA ra ga Na tsakra pU dza kha kha khA hi khA hi/
oṃ guru buddha bodhisatva śrīcakrasamvara vīra yoginī ḍāka ḍākinī sarvadharmapāla saparivāra ganacakra pūja kha kha khāhi khāhi

lan gsum mam bdun gyis tshogs gtor 'bul zhing / spros pa la dga' na zhu dbul sogs sngon du 'gro ba dang / gang ltar yang rang he ru ka lus kyi dkyil 'khor dang bcas pa gsal bzhin pas dam tshig gi rdzas la zhen pa med par longs spyad/ phud cha gnyis dang / lhag ma bsdus te slob dpon gyis bya khyung gi phyag rgya dang bcas la dA nas la phu btab la/

Saying that three or seven times, offer the feast torma. If you like elaborations, do a request and so forth first. In either case, with no attachments, enjoy the samaya substances while visualizing yourself as the Heruka with the body maṇḍala. With the second select portion and the collected leftovers, the ācārya makes the garuda mudrā and spits with madana.
oM AHhU~M ha hoHhrIH sa brlab/
oṃ āḥ hūṃ ha hoḥ hrīḥ Thus, consecrate.
oM dz+nya na ma ya lo ka DA ki nI sa pa ri wA ra dz+nyA na sa ma ya karma ba liM ta kha kha khA hi khA hi/
oṃ jñāna samaya lokaḍākinī saparivāra jñāna samaya karma baliṃta kha kha khāhi khāhi
na maHsarba ta thA ga ta sogs nas/ gr-ih+Na daM ba l+yA di swA hA/
namaḥ sarvatathāgata…gṛhṇe daṃ balyādi svāhā
oM a kA ro sogs/
oṃ akāro…
oM AHhU~M phaT swA hA/ oM uts+tshiSh+Ta ba liM ta b+hak+Sha sI swA hA/ zhes sngags tshang ba lan res bsngos la/
oṃ āḥ hūṃ phaṭ svāhā / oṃ ucchiṣṭa baliṃta bhakṣasī svāhā Dedicate with each recitation of mantra.
lhag la dbang ba'i 'byung po'i tshogs/ / ye (463)shes dam tshig 'jig rten gyi/ / dpa' bo mkha' 'gro ma lus kun/ / mchod sbyin gtor ma 'di bzhes la/ /
Assembly of bhūtas entitled to the leftovers, {463} all heroes and ḍākinīs— wisdom, samaya, and worldly— accept this offering and gift of torma.
sogs kyis

[May we yogins and yoginīs with our retinues be without illness, have long lives, might, glory, fame, excellent fortune, and vast enjoyments. Bestow on us the siddhis of actions: pacifying, enriching, and the others. Samaya holders, protect us. Be our friend and aid for the siddhis. May we not meet with untimely death, illness, spirits, or hindrances. May we not have bad dreams, bad omens, or bad interactions. May there be peace in the world, good harvests, plentiful grains, the flourishing of dharma, and an abundance of goodness. May all that we desire be accomplished.]
phrin las bcol lo/ /
Thus, entrust them with activity.
mchod pa kha gsos la 'bru gsum gyis byin brlab/ sgrub thabs ltar mchod bstod mdor bsdus bya/ /
Replenish the offerings and consecrate them with the three seed syllables. Do abbreviated offerings and praises according to the sādhana.
ting nge 'dzin gyi dbang blang ba ni/
Receiving the samādhi abhiṣeka.
dpal ldan bla ma rin po che/ / sku gsung thugs las byung ba yis/ / bdag la dbang bzhi bskur du gsol/ / smin cing grol bar mdzad du gsol/ /
Glorious, precious guru, with your body, speech, and mind, please bestow upon me the four abhiṣekas. Please mature and liberate me.

zhes gsol ba btab pas bla ma dang dbyer med pa'i dkyil 'khor lha tshogs rnams kyi spyi bor oM las 'od zer dkar po 'phros rang gi spyi bor thim/ sku las sku dpag tu med pa byung lus la thim pas lus kyi sdig sgrib dag / bum pa'i dbang thob/ lus sku rdo rje'i rang bzhin tu gyur/ lam bskyed rim bsgom pa la dbang / 'bras bu sprul sku thob pa'i skal ldan tu byas/

Having supplicated in that way, from the white oṃs at the heads of the assembled deities of the maṇḍala who are inseparable from the guru, white light rays stream forth and dissolve into my head. From their bodies, innumerable forms of their bodies appear, and dissolve into my body. My negative actions and obscurations of body are purified, and I receive the vase abhiṣeka. My body becomes of the nature of vajra body. I am empowered to meditate on the generation process as the path. I become endowed with the fortune of attaining the nirmāṇakāya as the result.

bla ma'i mgrin pa'i AHlas 'od zer dmar po 'phros/ rang gi mgrin par thim/ zhal nas sngags phreng dpag tu med pa byung ngag la thim pas ngag gi sdig sgrib dag / gsang ba'i dbang thob/ ngag gsung rdo rje'i rang bzhin du gyur/ lam gtum mo sgom pa la dbang / 'bras bu chos sku thob pa'i skal ldan tu byas/

From the āḥ at the guru’s throat, red light rays stream forth and dissolve into my throat. From their mouth, innumerable mantra garlands appear and dissolve into my speech. My negative actions and obscurations of speech are purified, and I receive the secret abhiṣeka. My speech becomes of the nature of vajra speech. I am empowered to meditate on caṇḍālī as the path. I become endowed with the fortune of attaining the dharmakāya as the result.

bla ma'i thugs ka'i hU~M las 'od zer sngon po 'phros rang gi snying gar thim/ thugs ka nas phyag mtshan dpag tu med pa byung snying gar thim pas yid kyi sdig sgrib dag / shes rab ye shes kyi dbang thob/ yid thugs rdo rje'i rang bzhin tu gyur/ lam pho nya bsgom pa la dbang / 'bras bu longs sku thob pa'i skal ldan tu byas/

From the hūṃ at the guru’s head, blue light rays stream forth and dissolve into my heart. From their mind, innumerable emblems appear and dissolve into my heart. My negative actions and obscurations of mind are purified, and I receive the prajñājñāna abhiṣeka. My mind becomes of the nature of vajra mind. I am empowered to meditate on emissaries as the path. I become endowed with the fortune of attaining the saṃbhogakāya as the result.

de nas bla ma yab yum 'od du zhu nas rang la thim pas rang gi lus ngag yid gsum dang / bla ma'i sku gsung thugs dbyer med du gyur/ sgo gsum cha mnyam gyi sdig sgrib dag / bzhi pa tshig dbang rin po che thob/ / lus ngag yid gsum sku gsung thugs rdo rje'i rang bzhin du gyur/ lam phyag rgya chen po sgom (464) pa la dbang / 'bras bu ngo bo nyid sku 'grub pa'i skal ldan tu bsams la ci gnas su mnyam par bzhag go /

Then, the guru, male and female consorts, melts into light and dissolves into me. My body, speech, and mind and the guru’s body, speech, and mind become inseparable. My negative actions and obscurations of body, speech, and mind equally are purified, and I receive the fourth, the precious word abhiṣeka. My body, speech, and mind become of the natures of vajra body, speech, and mind. {464} I am empowered to meditate on mahāmudrā as the path. I become endowed with the fortune of achieving the svabhāvakāya as the result. Thus, contemplate, and rest in equipoise as much as you can.
bzod par gsol ba ni/
Request for patience.
oM badzra he ru ka sa ma ya sogs/
oṃ vajraheruka samaya…
ma 'byor ba dang nyams pa dang / / gang yang bdag rmongs blo yis ni/ / bgyis pa dang ni bgyid stsal ba/ / de kun mgon pos bzod par gsol/ /
With anything missing or done wrong, or things I did or had others do out of my ignorance, protectors, please be patient.
lhag pa dang ni chad pa dang / / cho ga'i yan lag nyams pa dang / / bdag gis bgyis nongs ci mchis pa/ / de yang mgon pos bzod par gsol/ /
Whatever additions, omissions, and impairments of the sections of the ritual I have done in error, protectors, please be patient.
dkyil 'khor ras bris skabs/
On occasions when there is a cloth-drawn maṇḍala, say:
ye shes pa rnams rten 'di nyid la 'byung ba bzhis gnod pas ma zhig gi bar du brtan par bzhugs nas bstan pa dang sems can gyi don mdzad du gsol/ /
May the wisdom ones reside firmly in this representation as long as it is not destroyed by the damage caused by the four elements. May they be of benefit to the teachings and sentient beings.
oM su pra tiSh+Tha badzrA ya swA hA/ dzaHhU~M ba~M hoHdam tshig gi dkyil 'khor 'od du zhu nas rang la thim par gyur/
oṃ supratiṣṭha vajrāya svāhā / jaḥ hūṃ vaṃ hoḥ The samaya maṇḍala melts into light and dissolves into me.
bsngo ba ni/
Dedication.

bdag gi dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis nye bar mtshon te bdag dang 'khor 'das sems can thams cad kyi dus gsum du bsags pa dang yod pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba la brten nas bdag gzhan nam mkha' dang mnyam pa'i sems can thams cad phyogs bcu dus gsum gyi de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las zhing khams gdul bya sku tshe mdzad pa sogs da lta nyid du mnyam par gyur nas chos kyi dbyings nam mkha'i mthar thug gi sems can thams cad 'khor ba dong nas ma sprugs kyi bar du 'bad rtsol dang thogs thug med par grol ba'i don rgyun chad med pa 'byung bar gyur cig /

On the basis of the roots of virtue that exist and have been accumulated in the three times by myself and all beings of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa, as represented by these roots of virtue of mine, may, right now, I and others—all sentient beings who equal space—become the same as the tathāgatas of the ten directions and three times in terms of body, speech, and mind, excellent qualities, activities, pure realms, disciples, longevity, deeds, and so forth. As long as saṃsāra is not dredged from its depths, may effortless and unobstructed benefit arise continuously for all sentient beings who extend throughout space, the dharmadhātu.
sangs rgyas sku bzhi brnyes pa'i byin rlabs dang / sogs sh+lo ka brjod/

Through the blessings of the buddhas’ attainment of the four kāyas, [through the blessings of the unchanging truth of dharmatā, and through the blessings of the unwavering resolve of the saṅgha, may this dedication and aspiration be achieved just as it is.] Recite that śloka.
shis brjod ni
Expression of auspiciousness.
zhal nas gsungs pas thog drangs rgyas bsdus ji ltar rigs pa bya'o/ /
Since it is said in the oral [tradition to include an expression of auspiciousness], begin with whatever is appropriate, be it extensive or abbreviated.

ngam rdzong ras pa la slob ma gling ka ba sogs grub thob thor bu re byon pa las/ chos brgyud cher ma 'phel stabs snyan brgyud skor yang rgyun ma chad tsam las bka' brgyud spyi la mi snang bas rgyun la bsams nas 'bad pas btsal te smin grol phyogs gcig tu bsdebs pa'o/ /

A few siddhas appeared as disciples for Ngamdzong Repa, such as Ling Kawa, [and although] his dharma transmission did not spread greatly, the cycle of Aural Transmission is unbroken. Since it does not appear within the general Kagyu [traditions], I put effort into seeking it out with the thought to continue it. I arranged the maturation and liberation together. {465}
lhag bsam 'od dkar snang bas bzhad pa yi/ / (465) zab gsang kun+da'i dga' tshal gsar du rgyas/ / smin grol bcud kyis thar pa'i lang tshor rtas/ / bde chen rdo rje'i sku mchog myur 'grub shog /

May the illumination of the white light of higher intentions cause the profound, secret pleasure garden of blooming jasmine to newly flourish. May the elixir of maturation and liberation strengthen the splendor of liberation and the supreme vajra body of great bliss be attained swiftly.

tshul 'di nyid grub dbang bde chen rdo rjes rtsa tho zin bris tsam mdzad pa la kha skong dgos pa rnams rigs mthun gyi gzhung las blangs te karma bka' brgyud kyi gral mthar 'khod pa'i dge sbyong ltar snang ba karma ngag dbang yon tan rgya mtshos rang lo gya bdun par dpal spungs yang khrod de bI ko TA'i sgrub gnas su spel ba'i yi ge pa ni nye bar gnas pa blo gsal gsang sngags bstan 'dzin gyis bgyis pa

Drupwang Dechen Dorje composed only notes on the main points of this approach. The necessary additions are drawn from texts of similar types. [I,] Karma Ngakwang Yönten Gyatso, a pseudospiritual practitioner who sits at the end of the row in the Karma Kagyu, composed this in my eighty-seventh year at the retreat center, Devīkoṭi Tsādra Rinchen Drak, the isolated hermitage of Palpung. The secretary was my attendant Losel Sangak Tenzin.
dge legs 'phel// // mang+ga laM// // (466) (467)
May virtue and excellence increase. maṅgalaṃ {466}
B.
B. The Actual Instruction Texts for Liberation[1]
1. The Texts in the Dharma Cycles of the Root Aural Transmissions[2]
a.
a. The Extensive Rechung Aural Transmission[3]
@#/ /rje btsun ras chung pa'i lugs kyi dpal 'khor lo sdom pa snyan brgyud kyi gzhung chung til+li pas mdzad pa bzhugs so/ /
29. Ilopa's The Short Text. The Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Glorious Cakrasaṃvara Aural Transmission from the Tradition of Jetsun Rechungpa[1]
(468)@#/ /rgya gar skad du/ shrI tsakra sam+ba ro pa de sha mu kha kar+Na pa ram+pa ra tsin+tA ma Ni nA ma/
In the language of India: Śricakrasamvaropadeśamukhakarṇaparamparācintāmaṇināma.[6]
bod skad du/ dpal 'khor lo sdom pa'i man ngag zhal nas snyan du brgyud pa yid bzhin nor bu zhes bya ba/
In the language of Tibet: dPal ’khor lo sdom pa’i man ngag zhal nas snyan du brgyud pa yid bzhin nor bu zhes bya ba.[*3]
dpal rdo rje sems dpa' la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the glorious Vajrasattva.

sku gsum bdag nyid dgos 'byung bla ma dam pa'i zhabs pad ze'u 'bru dri med 'od zer la phyag 'tshal/ / gsang sngags mthar thug snying po'i bcud phyung yid bzhin nor bu mkha' 'gro'i gsung bzhin rtogs pas 'dir gsal bkod/ /

I bow down to the genuine guru, whose lotus feet with stainless anthers [radiate] light, who is the embodiment of the three kāyas and the source fulfilling all needs. Having realized the Wish-Fulfilling Gems—the distillation of the ultimate essence of Secret Mantra—according to the teachings of the Ḍākinī, I will clearly present these here.
bde gshegs thugs la snang ba dri med pany+tsa pa nas rtogs pas ko ri li ru gsang bdag mnyes/ / spyod pas zil mnan lus kyi bkod pas rnal 'byor rjes bzung mdzad pa tha mas 'gro rnams stong par byas/ /

I, Pañcapana, realized the stainless [wisdom] appearing within the minds of the sugatas and, in Kirili, pleased the Lord of Secrets.[7] I overpowered [the ḍākinīs] through my practice, guided yogins with my physical displays, and in the end, made beings vanish.[*4] (1–4)
bslab pa gsum dang brgyud par ldan pa nyams su myong bas 'jug tshul shes pas bla ma dam par shes/ / sen d+ha ba dang rigs cad bran ltar rus sbal spu ste mo gsham bu ltar slob ma skyon lnga bral/ /

Those with the three trainings, [who belong to] a lineage, and who, through their experiences, know how to enter [disciples] are known as genuine gurus. Disciples should be without five flaws: being sendhapas, of the cut-off gotra, like servants, like the hairs of a turtle, or like the child of a barren woman.[*5][8]

mchog gi don 'dod gang gi de bsten thog mar dbang bzhis rgyud smin thabs dang shes rab 'brel ba nyid/ / 'di don rim par brgyud pa rna bar 'pho byed de tshe sangs rgyas bstan gnas gus pas mnyan par gyis/ (469)

Those desiring the supreme state attend such [gurus]; to begin with, their mindstreams are matured by the four abhiṣekas, and they connect method and prajñā.[9] This state is transferred [from ear] to ear in a sequential transmission; on such occasions, those who abide in the Buddha’s teachings should listen with respect. (5–8) {469}
sa yi cho ga lhag par gnas pa rig byed slob dpon rig sbyor sogs kyis bum pa'i dbang bskur bya/ / bslab pas rgyud mdzes thos bsam nor ldan bla mar 'os pa phul ba bla mas gsal stong la sogs bskur/

Bestow the vase abhiṣeka by means of the earth ritual, the consecration, arousing awareness, the ācārya [abhiṣeka], uniting with awareness, and so forth.[*6][10] Offer to a worthy guru, one whose mindstream is beautified by training, who has the gems of listening and reflection; the guru will bestow clarity, emptiness, and so forth.

nyer lnga lhag spangs rigs ldan rgyan spras zag bcas bskul sogs gsum pa byin nas brtul zhugs brtan par bya/ / dga' ba gsum son lhan cig skyes pa rnyogs pa dang bral yul du bya sogs 'bras bur shes par gyis/

Having been given the third—which includes one not more than twenty-five who belongs to a family, wears the ornaments, arouses the defiled, and the like—practice [yogic] discipline.[11] Once the three joys pass, taking the unsullied connate as the object and so forth, recognize the result.[12] (9–12)

dbang bzhi dang 'brel brda yis mtshon pa shes rab bdag nyid sin+d+hU ra la mnyes sogs ston mos brgyan/ / slob dpon bzhi la dbang bzhi dus bzhi byed pa bcu gnyis chos nyid dbang la mtshon du med par byos/ /

Connected to the fourth abhiṣeka, what is revealed through symbols [is given]: the embodiment of prajñā [is bestowed based] on sindhu; please [the guru] and so forth, [and] the female teacher adorns.[13] There are four ācāryas, four abhiṣekas in the four times, [with] the twelve activities; the dharmatā abhiṣeka cannot be revealed.[*7][14]

dbang gis smin nas rim pa gnyis shes rnal 'byor dbang phyug zung du 'jug pa rgyal ba'i sku sgrub phyir/ / dbang po'i rim pas dbye dang bsdu ba'i rim pa shes nas 'du 'ji med par rgyun du 'bad pas spyad/ /

Having been matured by the abhiṣekas, know the two processes; in order to achieve the unification of the lords of yogins and yoginīs, the kāyas of the victors, know the processes of expanding and condensing according to the stages of abilities, and practice with exertion continuously and without busyness. (13–16)

tshangs pa'i gnas bzhi gsol dang khams sogs bslab pa 'khor lo tshogs brten rgyu 'bras nyid dang phra mor brjod/ / go cha ye shes rgyas btab sku gsung mchod dang bzlas pa rdzogs rim phrin las phyogs dang thub pa nyid/ /

There are the four abodes of Brahmā, supplications, consecrating the dhātus and so forth, the [protection] cakra, accumulations, supports, causes, results, what is called the subtle,[15] the armors, [entering] the wisdom ones, sealing, body and speech, offerings and repetitions, the perfection process, and activities; those are directions and munis.[*8][16] {470}

bsdus pa'i sbyor ba tshad (470) med bzhi ldan rdzus te skyes pa skad cig rnal 'byor bzlas pa bcas pa nyid/ / brtan g.yo'i dngos po lhan cig skyes pa snang sems dbyer med rnon po'i spyod yul zung 'jug rdo rje'i sku/ /

The abbreviated practice, accompanied by the four immeasurable aspirations, is the instantaneous yoga and its recitations, [which are related to] spontaneous birth. [17] Animate and inanimate entities are connate, and appearances and mind are inseparable: this is the sphere of experience for the sharp, [resulting in] unification, the vajra body. (17–20)

kun la khyab pa'i ngo bo nyid ston gsal rig mtshan nyid thub pa'i dbang po bde gshegs kun gyi gtso/ / gsum gsal bdag gis mngon sum nyid du legs par rtogs nas bsgom dang bzlas pa gsal por rab tu phye/ /

The essential nature pervading all is taught; the characteristics of clarity-awareness is the principal one of all sugatas, the lord of sages.[18] I realized correctly the three clarities as direct perceptions and, having meditated, recited, and clarified, thus reveal.[*9][19]
chos dbyings skye med rgyal ba'i yum gcig rgyal dang rgyal ba nyid de nam mkha'i ri mo lta/ / brtan dang g.yo brten dang brten pa lha yi rang bzhin rang la bcug nas sna yi rtse mor rdo rje bzlas/ /

The unborn dharmadhātu, [as] the one mother of the victors, the victors, and the victorious ones, is seen as drawings in space.[*10][20] After the supported and the animate—[meditated upon as] the natures of the deities, support and supported—enter yourself, do the vajra repetition at the tip of your nose. (21–24)

gtor ma sbyin nas dbang po 'bring pos 'od gsal bsgoms te dbang sogs lam dang dam tshig 'bras bur bsre/ / bdag 'jug dbang dang bla ma mchod byed nyams chags bskang phyir rdo rje sems dpa' brtan pa'i cho ga bzlas/ /

Having offered torma, those of intermediate abilities should meditate on luminosity; [relying on] the abhiṣekas and so forth, the paths, and the samayas, mix with the result.[21] In order to [take] the self-entering abhiṣeka, to offer to the gurus, and to restore impaired and broken [samayas], recite the ritual that stabilizes Vajrasattva.[22]

rgyal po blon po dmangs kyi byed pas mtshams kyi kun spyod za nyal 'gro dang khrus sogs rnal 'byor bya/ / rnam rtog dang bral zla ba drug tu nges par bsams nas grub pa'i mtshan ma mthong nas rol par gnas/ /

[After the practices of] the sovereigns and the ministers, with the actions of the people, engage in the yogas for all activities of the break: eating, sleeping, walking, washing, and so forth.[23] Free from thoughts, contemplate with certainty for six months; once you see the signs of accomplishment, abide in enjoyment.[*11][24] (25–28)

thub pa'i bstan pa rgyas mdzad dngos grub mthar phyin zab dang rgya che ba dang gnyis med dam tshig kun gyi gzhi/ / bag yod bsgom zhing rten dang gsang ba mi bsag mi 'bral bza' bsrung mchog gyur thub pas rab tu gsungs/ /

Spread the teachings of the Sage and perfect the siddhis; [cultivate] the profound, vast, and nondual samayas, the ground of all.[*12] The Sage taught that those who cultivate conscientiousness, do not amass representations and secret [substances], and are not separate [from samādhi] are supreme in observing [the commitments related to] food.[*13][25]

bslab pa gsum dang rgyu 'bras zhen med dbang sogs 'bras bu rgyud gzhan las gsungs rang sems brtan pas bsrung / / sku gsum la brten ting 'dzin gsum gyis rgya cher rab gsal gzhi lam 'bras bus lta ba mtshon par gyis/

[Safeguard] the three trainings, causes and results, not fixating, and the abhiṣekas and so forth; [for] the result, stabilize [what is] taught in other tantras in your own mind and protect [those].[*14][26] Relying on the three kāyas, the three samādhis clarify the vast; reveal the ground, path, result, and view.[*15][27] (29–32)

rnal 'byor srog rtsol sangs rgyas mnga' bdag g.yon dang g.yas su rim pa ji bzhin rgyu ba nges pa ste/ / mnyam par bzhag pas 'jug pa'i rlung nyid bum pa can du byas nas brtan pa'i go 'phang so sor thob/ (471)

In prāṇāyāma yoga, the buddha masters on the right and left, in keeping with the sequence, move in a definite way.[*16][28] By resting in equipoise and performing vase breathing with the operative winds, you will attain the specific states of stabilization.[29] {471}
rlung gi sbyor ba 'di nyid mi shes las dang las min mi 'grub rlung rig pas ni 'bras bu ster/ gdams pas tshe dang bzlas pa'i rim pa goms pas dge dang mi dge 'chi bzlog rlung rig pas ni shes/ /

[When] the suchness of the yogic techniques of the winds is not known, the activities and nonactivities are not accomplished; knowing the winds, the result is bestowed.[30] Through the instructions, you become familiar with the processes for longevity and the repetitions; thus, through awareness of the winds, you will know virtue, unvirtue, and [how to] avert death.[31] (33–36)

bya dang byed las chos mtshungs rgyu mtshan gdams pa'i sbyor ba bskyed rim goms pas mthun pa'i rkyen dang ldan/ / gsang spyod la gnas sdug bsngal bzod pas lus gnad gsum ldan dmigs pa bzhi las sbyor ba'i skyon bsal te/ /

The reason the categories and functions have similar qualities is that becoming accustomed to the generation process as the preparatory instructions [creates] the conducive conditions.[*17][32] Abiding in the secret conduct [and] enduring suffering, hold the three vital points for body; the four observations dispel the flaws of the yogic techniques.[*18][33]
steng 'og bar du 'bugs pa'i sbyor ba li re'i tshul du sgo gsum sbyang bar bya phyir nges par rol/ / rdo rje bzlas pa yig 'bru gsum la goms shing sangs rgyas lnga la kha dog so sor bslab par bya/ /

[Engage in] the yogic techniques for penetrating above, below, and in between in the manner of [making a rope of] liri; definitely revel in order to purify the three doors.[*19][34] Become habituated to the three syllables of the vajra repetition and train in the five different colors for the five buddhas. (37–40)
'byung ba lnga yi rlung zin pas ni du ba smig rgyu me khyer mar me sprin med nam mkha' 'byung / / brtan pa'i rtags su zla zer nyi zer glog gi zer dang 'ja' tshon nyi zlar bsres pa dngos su mthong / /

By holding the winds of the five elements, smoke, mirages, fireflies, candle flames, and a cloudless sky appear.[35] The signs of stabilization are to see directly moonlight, sunlight, lightning, rainbows, and the mixing of sun and moon.[36]

spyod lam dang ni sbyor ba mkhas pas dug sogs gzhom dang 'chi ba brtag pa la sogs sna tshogs rgyur/ rtsa dang rlung dang thig le 'dres pas bde gsal mi rtog rgyun mi 'chad par rgyal por 'gyur ro kye/ /

[During] the conduct [and] path, those skilled in the practices are able to destroy poison and the like and change the various signs of death and so forth.[*20][37] Mixing the channels, winds, and bindus, there is the sovereign: uninterrupted bliss, clarity, and nonconceptuality—kye.[38] (41–44)
rim pa 'di nyid 'phel bar bya phyir snang dmigs dngos po sgyu mar bsams la dben pa'i gnas su ni/ / rdo rje sems dpa' mtshan dpes spras pa'i gzugs brnyan la ni rab tu dmigs la dngos po chu zla ltar/ /

In order to elevate this process, consider appearing observed entities to be illusions; in an isolated location, focus on the reflection of Vajrasattva adorned with the major and minor marks, and entities are like the moon reflected in water.

bcu gnyis sgyu ma'i dpe yis mtshon te mnyam rjes la ni chos brgyad las 'das mkha' bzhin snyoms par 'jug / de ltar shes pas mi bya ba med sngags zlos bsrung sogs mi dgos dge slong sogs la phyag mi bya/ /

[That] is demonstrated by the twelve examples of illusion; in meditative equipoise and postmeditative attainment, transcend the eight worldly values, equalizing them like space.[39] With such recognition, there is nothing not done; there is no need for mantra repetitions, protection, and so forth, and bhikṣus and others need not be revered.[*21] (45–48)

nyin dang mtshan dus bsre zhing sbyang dang goms pas gyen du 'bangs te bde gshegs bltas la chos sogs mnyan/ / rmi lam med dus gnad dang ldan pas 'dod chags la sogs brgyad cu dgag nas snang ba gsum 'das te/ /

Blending day and night, training and familiarizing elevate; you will see the sugatas and hear the dharma and the like.[*22][40] When there are no dreams, through [the application of] the vital points, the eighty [intrinsic thoughts], such as those associated with desire, cease and the three illuminations pass.[41] {472}

rgyun mi 'chad pa'i 'od (472) gsal chen pos sa bcur gyur pa lam ma bgrod na rnam shes gang du 'pho/ / sna tshogs don chen mthong nas shes pa spong ste rim pa gnyis ldan 'jug phyir gzhan gyi mi 'gyur ro/ /

Continuous great luminosity becomes the ten bhūmis; if you do not progress on the path, transfer your consciousness higher.[42] Seeing the great value in varieties, for the sake of the two processes, the knower does not do any other [practice].[43] (49–52)

chags dang chags bral 'di ma shes par gzhan ni don med dus gsum sangs rgyas bgrod pa gcig pa'i lam/ / ri bong rgyug dang zla ba chu 'dzin dus dang 'brel pa bslab bcas sangs rgyas dgongs pa mi shes phyir/ /

For those who do not know [the paths of] passion and passionlessness, other [paths] will be meaningless; [this path of two processes] is the single path trod by the buddhas of the three times.[44] When the rabbit runs and the moon is linked with the water-bearers, since those [of you] in training do not understand the intention of the buddhas,[*23][45]

sgo gsum gnad kyis sbyang bar bya zhing ngal na snad rtser bltas la nges shes skyes nas chen por blta/ / dang po'i las kyis yid 'ong la brton goms pas sngags las zhing dang lhan cig skyes sogs rtsa bsnyen bya/ /

you should purify your three doors using the vital points; when tired, look at the tip of your nose and give rise to certainty; and look at what is great.[*24][46] First, those with the karma become familiar with practicing with a pleasing one, then approach the channels of the mantra-born, the field[-born], the connate ones, and so forth.[*25][47] (53–56)

gcig car mgon po bsgoms nas mthar gnas rdo rje'i bzlas pa rtsal mkhas pa pad+ma'i skyon bzhi bsal/ / bde ba'i lam drangs ye shes mtshon pa mar la 'du bar rgyu 'bras shes nas zhes bya'i dkyil 'khor blta/ /

The instantaneous, having meditated on the Protector, abide in the end and do vajra repetitions; being skilled in the channels, they dispel the four faults of lotuses.[*26][48] Drawn along the path of bliss, gather [the bindus] below to reveal wisdom; recognizing causes and results, behold the maṇḍala of objects of knowledge.[49]

thur sel gcud nas glang chen seng ge rma bya'i 'dren dang bya rgod stag mos snang dmigs bde bar 'char/ / sbyor bar dwangs mas rlung dang mnyam zhing rig ma'i bde ba lus la spros nas rtsa mdud dgrol bar bya/ /

Work the downward-expelling wind and, [with] the drawings up of the elephant, lion, and peacock, and the vulture and tigress, observed appearances arise as bliss.[50] Through uniting, the quintessences are equalized with the winds; the vidyā’s bliss radiates in your body, releasing the channel knots.[51] (57–60)

bde ba'i nyams skyes tshogs drug kun la ro mnyam lugs las 'byung dang bzlog pas dga' bzhi mtshon par bya/ / dga' ba gsum dang dpe don bsres nas rgyu tshogs gzung 'dzin chos nyid goms nas rtsol med 'bras bu 'char/ /

Experiences of bliss arise and the sixfold collection [of consciousnesses] are of equal taste; through their sequential and reverse orders, the four joys are revealed.[52] Mix the three joys, the exemplified, and the actual; by becoming familiar with the collection of causes, percepts and perceivers, and dharmatā, the result arises effortlessly.
ye shes gsal byed dbang gi 'bras bur rdo rje'i lus la 'khor lor mdud pa spyi bor grol ba'i gnas/ / sgo dgu bgags nas sgo bzhi thim pa gnyis kyi rnam grol ye shes lus can sgra brnyan lta bur bral/ /

The illumination of wisdom: the results of the abhiṣekas [is the release of] the knots in the cakras of the vajra body; the head is the location of liberation.[53] Having blocked nine doors, four doors dissolve; embodied beings with wisdom that is released in the two are like pleasing sounds and are free.[*27][54] (61–64)

mig sogs stong dang btud bzhi grol ba chos nyid la mkhas gsum po gcig gyur ye shes rgyun chad med/ / gzhi lam 'bras bu gcig gyur bde chen dngos po ro mnyam yi ge bzhi don 'bras bu (473) mngon du 'gyur/ /

Assist with your eyes and so forth, be released from the four māras, be skilled in dharmatā; the three become one, and wisdom is uninterrupted.[*28] Ground, path, and result become one, the entities [of] great bliss are of equal taste, and the natures of the four syllables manifest as the results.[*29] {473}
mthar ma skyol na nye bar spyod pa lus lhan bzhi dang ngas shes brtags te ngo sprod shes par bya/ / skye shi bar do shes pa snga phyir nyid du dran mtshams 'chi ba'i dus su phra rags thim nas ni/ /

Those who do not reach the end, with material possessions [and] a body, should understand the four with certainty and recognize what is pointed out.[*30][55] For the birth-to-death bardo consciousness, awareness [makes] the connections [between] the previous [life] and the next; at the time of death, coarse and subtle [thoughts] dissolve.[56] (65–68)
'od gsal chen po de ma rtogs nas bla ma sogs kyi skye la bsu nyid mtshams rlung gsum bcing ba'i phyir/ / yon tan rdzogs pa bar dor longs sku yon tan bdun ldan de ma brtan na dug gsum las gyur pa'i/ /

Those not realizing that great luminosity will be welcomed and sent off by the gurus and others, [making] the next connections; therefore, bind the three winds. If, in the bardo of the complete excellent qualities, the seven excellent qualities of the saṃbhogakāya are not stabilized, there will be [thoughts] that develop from the three poisons.[57]
rtog par bcas la dbang dus nyams dang lha sogs sgyu ma zung du 'jug pa slob dang mi slob pa/ / bdun phrag re la brgyal bar gyur ba de ma khegs na skye ba sna tshogs sprul sku nying mtshams sbyor/ /

With those thoughts, [apply] the experiences of the time of abhiṣeka and unify the illusoriness of the deities and so forth; this will be training or beyond training.[*31][58] Each week, you will pass out; if you cannot stop [taking birth], take it as a nirmāṇakāya in [one of] a variety of births.[*32] (69–72)

bar do gsum la 'dod chags la sogs dug gsum shes pa zag med 'od gsal sgyu mar bsres la sgom/ / 'di don rim pa 'khor ba dang ni mya ngan 'das las rgyal ba gnyis med zung 'jug phyag rgya chen por 'gyur/ /

In the three bardos, recognize the three poisons, desire and the others, and cultivate mixing them with the undefiled, luminosity, and illusions.[*33] This state gradually is victorious over saṃsāra and nirvāṇa; it becomes nondual unification: mahāmudrā.[59]

dbang dang dam tshig 'brel bar shes pa gdod nas dag pa rkyen gyis bskur tshul nyams su blang dang rtogs/ / bum sogs dam tshig mnyam gzhag rjes spyod mi 'bral bza' bsrung spros bcas spros med yan lag bshags bya nyid/ /

Know the connections between the abhiṣekas and the samayas; what is pure from the beginning is to be practiced and realized [according to] the way it is bestowed through conditions.[60] [Preserve] the samayas of the vase and so forth, do not be separate from meditative equipoise and the conduct of post[meditative attainment], observe the food, [cultivate the two processes] with elaborations and without elaborations, and confess [even] the branches.[61] (73–76)

dbang dus lta sogs mtshon par byas la bdud rigs ngos bzung zil gyis mnan nas sgom dang rtags su 'brel/ / tha ma 'bring dang rab dang mchog gyur 'jug sgo shes pas bsgoms la sbyar te gang dang gang la sogs/ /

To reveal the view and so forth [connected to] the abhiṣekas, identify the types of māras, overpower them, and meditate; you will connect with the signs.[62] Know the entryways for normal ones, the intermediate, the best, and the supreme, and apply the meditations; those [individuals should train in that] and so forth.[63]

mchog gi dngos grub tshe 'dir 'dod pa dus dang 'brel par spyod pa byas nas gol sa bcad par bya/ / bya dang spyod sogs tshogs su bsgyur la phrin las byed par rab gnas sbyin sreg rnam bzhis 'dod dgur bsgyur/ /

Those who desire the supreme siddhi in this life should undertake the conduct connected with the timing and cut through strayings.[64] Those included in the assemblies [of deities] of kriyā, caryā, and the others perform the activities, and through the consecrations and the four types of homa, bring about all that is desired.[*34][65] (77–80)

'khor lo bzhi la sku bzhir yan lag bdun ldan rdo rje sems dpa' sgo gsum ngo sprod mtshon dpes spras/ / rgyud rnams snying phyung man ngag bcud bsdus lam gyi rim pa bde (474) gshegs kun thugs yid bzhin nor bu nyid/

Within the four cakras are the four kāyas with the seven branches; Vajrasattva is pointed out to be the three doors, adorned with the major and minor marks.[*35][66] {474} The condensed elixir of esoteric instructions—the heart-essence of the tantras, the processes of the path—is the Wish-Fulfilling Gems, the mind of all sugatas.[67]

mi mthun phyogs las rgyal bar bya phyir 'jug pa'i tshul dang zhugs pa'i 'bras bu gsal ba'i thabs nyid do/ / lus la go gyon ngag gis g.yul sprod sems kyis mtshon bsnun sku gsung khrus bcud rlung dang 'khor lo bskor/

To be victorious over what is discordant, there are the methods that clarify the approach to engage and the result to be engaged. Wear armor on your body, wage war with your speech, thrust the weapons with your mind; cleanse the three kāyas, and turn the cakra with the elixir and winds.[*36][68] (81–84)
rtsa ba drug la yan lag so dgus nad la sman dpyad bar chad srung 'khor gnad bral gegs bsal te/ sa la sogs pa'i ro bzhi ngos bzung 'khor lo bzhi yis ra bzhi mnyam la zhi gnas phyogs la ni/

Like medical treatments for illnesses—the six roots and thirty-nine branches—protection cakras [for] obstacles free you from illnesses and dispel hindrances.[*37][69] Identify the four tastes of earth and the others, and equalize the four tastes in the four cakras; this is associated with śamatha.[*38][70]
thabs dang ldan pa pi wang sgra sogs rtsa rlung la ni shes rab sku gsum mthun sbyor rdzas sogs lnga/ zin dang ma zin legs par shes nas lus kyi gnad la nyi ma zla sogs brdzis nas rdul sprugs byed/

With methods, [sense experiences are like] the sounds of a vina and the like; once the winds [enter] the channel, the three kāyas of prajñā [are achieved]; as for the five, such as the substances, which are concordant practices,[*39][71] by knowing properly if they are retained or not retained, press the sun, moon, and so forth in the vital points of the body, and shake off impurities.[*40][72] (85–88)

'byung bzhi rlung la lte ba la sogs stong ra bcas nas na tsha bogs 'don 'gags 'khyil la sogs bsal/ bcu ba'i rlung shes ting 'dzin rang grol sman pa lta bus brgyad po bsal nas dngul chu ltar sprang bya/

For [illnesses related to] the winds of the four elements, with the empty enclosures, such as the navel, use the enhancements for the illnesses, and dispel blockages, coalescing, and so forth.[73] Knowing the ten winds, they are self-liberated by samādhi; this is like a doctor who, having removed its eight [flaws], applies mercury.[*41][74]

dwangs ma bsrubs nas skyon rnams sel phyir bdag tu lta ba'i bud shing bsregs nas 'od gsal chos skur bsgral/ 'di don rim brgyud bla ma la bsten gus pas blang phyir byin rlabs lam khyer snyan nas snyan du brgyud/

Because churning the quintessences dispels all flaws, the firewood of the belief in a self is consumed and you are released in the dharmakāya, luminosity.[75] The sequential transmission of the meaning [of] these [instructions] is received through attending a guru with devotion; therefore, with blessings, [the instructions for] practice will be transmitted from ear to ear.[76] (89–92)

mchog gi blo can brtse ba chen pos theg gzhan spangs pa smin dang grol ba rim pa gnyis la 'bad/ snod bcud la sogs gzhal yas khang dang phung po khams sogs lha ru dag pas rgyal ba thams cad bsdu ba'o/ /

Those of supreme intelligence and great kindness abandon the other yānas and exert themselves in the two processes, which mature and liberate.[77] The environment, its inhabitants, and so on are pure as the palace, and the skandhas, dhātus, and the rest are pure as the deities; thus, all the victors are gathered.
rdo rje'i lus la bde chen gnas pas pho nya la sogs spros dang spros med 'khor lo zung du 'jug / rim pa 'di la mos pa brtan pas sprul pa mthong zhing skyon yon dang bcas chung ngu yin phyir tshogs/

With great bliss residing in the vajra body, through the elaborate, such as the emissaries, and the unelaborate, unification [occurs] in the cakras. By stabilizing your conviction about these two processes, you see the nirmāṇa[kāya]; because, with faults and virtues, this is the lesser [path of accumulation], it is [called the path of] accumulation.[78] (93–96)

skad cig bzhi yis dga' ba gsum son 'bring po'i drod de lhan cig skyes pa d+hU tI'i lam zhugs nas/ 'jig rten las 'das brgya phrag bdun (475) po yon tan gyis spras gnas dang nye gnas nyi shu bzhi la sogs/ /

With the four moments and the occurrence of three joys, the intermediate [level of] heat [is attained]; connateness [is achieved] and the path of the avadhūti is entered.[*42][79] {475} [Now you are] adorned by transmundane excellent qualities, hundreds [or] seven; in the twenty-four abodes, nearby abodes, and the others,

dwangs ma yas byon pUl+li sogs khyab rgyu ba mas brtan bde chen brtol nas ma chags pad+ma'i sa/ / rab bkram chen po phrag bdun yon tan ye shes gsal/ /byed chos sku bdag nyid rdo rje 'dzin par 'gyur/ /

the quintessences come from above and pervade Pullī[ramalaya] and the others; the moving [bindus] are stabilized in their ascension and reach the mahāsukha[cakra], becoming the bhūmi of the Unattached Lotus,[*43][80] with its excellent qualities, mahāprasuta[*44] [or] seven: this is illuminating wisdom, the embodiment of the dharmakāya, Vajradhara.[81] (97–100)

'khor lo sdom pa'i bskyed rdzogs la sogs gting dpag dka' ba gsal por rab phye snyan brgyud mkha' 'gro'i gsang / / dri med bsags pa'i dge ba des ni sa gsum gnas pa rdo rje 'dzin pa'i go 'phang thob par shog /

The processes of generation, perfection, and so on of Cakrasaṃvara—which are difficult to fathom—are clearly revealed in the Aural Transmission, the secret of the Ḍākinī. Through the stainless virtue accumulated here, may those dwelling on the three planes achieve the state of Vajradhara. (101–2)

yid bzhin nor bu zhes bya ba mkha' 'gro ma'i gsang tshig til+li pas bkod pa rdzogs so/ / gtsigs kyi rgya mdud dang bcas pa nA ro paN+Di ta'i zhal snga nas dang / / lo tsA ba mar pa chos kyi blo gros kyis puSh+pa ha ri'i gnas su bsgyur ba'o// ! /

This completes The Wish-Fulfilling Gems, the secret verses of the Ḍākinī arranged by Tilopa.[82] This has the knot of cherishment. It was translated by Nāropa Paṇḍita and Lotsāwa Marpa Chökyi Lodrö at Puṣpahari.[83]
snyan brgyud yid bzhin nor bu'i gzhung gi bsdus don rnam par {zur mang snyan brgyud las so} bshad pa bzhugs so/ /
30. The Presentation of the Summary of Topics for “The Short Text: The Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Aural Transmission”[*1]{[*1] From the Zurmang Aural Transmission}[1]
dus gsum sangs rgyas kun gyi gsang ba yi/ / gnas 'gyur bde chen mkha' 'gro ma yi gsung / / snyan brgyud snying po gsal ba'i sgron me 'di/ / ston pa'i bla ma yi dam lha la 'dud/

I bow to the gurus and yidam deities, expounders of this lamp illuminating the essence of the Aural Transmission, the speech of the Ḍākinī, great bliss, the transformation that is the secret of the buddhas of the three times.
yid bzhin nor bu zhes bya ba'i gzhung chung rdo rje'i tshig le'ur byas pa 'di 'chad pa la/ brjod bya ni gang / dgos pa ni ci/ 'brel po ni du zhe na/
In this explanation of The Short Text of Vajra Verses, Called the Wish-Fulfilling Gems, what are the subject of discussion, the purpose, and the connections?
dang po ni/ rdo rje theg pa'i lam phyin ci ma log par ston pa'o/ /
The first is the correct exposition of the Vajrayāna path.[4]
gnyis pa ni/ dbang po rnon po tshe 'di nyid la mchog thob par byed pa'o/ /
The second is to enable those of sharpest abilities to achieve what is supreme in this lifetime.
gsum pa ni/ don de nyid mtshon pa dbang bzhi dang 'brel pa rgyun chags su ston pa gzhung chung gsal bar byed pa la/ /
The third are that that state [or aim]—which is continuously taught in connection with the four abhiṣekas, which reveal it—is clarified in The Short Text.

31. The Instruction Manual for the Shared Wish-Fulfilling Gems. The Practices Connected with the Vase Abhiṣeka from the Glorious Saṃvara Aural Transmission[1]
(480)@#/ /na mo gu ru de ba DA ki nI/ /
namo guru deva ḍākinī

dus gsum sangs rgyas kun gyi mchod 'os yon tan gter/ / yid bzhin nor bu gdung ba kun sel 'gran zla bral/ / dri med nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor sems can kun kyi dpal/ / bde chen bde mchog bla ma gsum la gus pas 'dud/ /

To the treasury of excellent qualities, worthy of the honor of all buddhas of the three times, the Wish-Fulfilling Gems, unrivaled dispellers of suffering, to the stainless maṇḍala of the sun, the glory of all sentient beings, Saṃvara, great bliss, and the gurus, the three, I bow respectfully.[7]
ye shes mkha' 'gro ma'i gsang tshig / 'gro rnams dag pa'i gnas su 'dren par byed pa/ /
The secret words of the Jñānaḍākinī lead beings to the pure states.[8]

bcom ldan 'das rdo rje 'chang gis rje btsun rdo rje rnal 'byor ma la gdams pa/ ji srid sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa dar ba de srid du 'gro don cher 'byung ba'i don du/ brgyud pa bcu gsum gyi bar du chig brgyud du bka' rgyas gdams pa/ / snyan brgyud yid bzhin nor bu zhes bya ba 'di rje btsun mas slob dpon tai lo pa la dngos su gdams/ tai lo pa la slob ma/ ka so ri pa/ ri ri pa/ grub thob brgyad rnams kyis o rgyan du mkha' 'gro ma la dngos su zhus pa'i chos de zhu byas pas/ /

The bhagavān Vajradhara gave instructions [directly] to the Jetsunma, Vajrayoginī.[9] For the sake of bringing great benefit to beings for as long as the Buddha’s teachings spread, the Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Aural Transmission—instructions sealed with a command to be a single transmission for thirteen transmissions—were given by the Jetsunma directly to the ācārya Tilopa.[10] Tilopa was requested by his disciples—Kasoripa, Riripa, and the eight siddhas—for that dharma, which he received directly from the Ḍākinī in Oḍḍiyāna.[11] He said:
dran pa brjed med nA ro pas/ / bcu gnyis par du nga brten byas/ / nga yi de nyid kho la yod/ / phyi rabs rten gyi gang zag rnams/ / rtogs par 'dod na nA ro brten/ /
Nāropa, whose memory has no lapses, has served me twelve times. The very thing of mine he has. Individuals of future generations who long for realization should rely on Nāropa.
gsung nas khong rnams la ma byin par/ nA ro pa gcig (481) pu la sbyin nas/ / bod kyi mar pa lung bstan te/ /
Having said that, he did not give these instructions to them.[12] {481} He gave them only to Nāropa[13] and made the following prophecy about Marpa of Tibet:
phul+la ha ri'i dgon pa ru/ / ma ti ma rig mun pa sol/ / snyan brgyud yid bzhin nor bu yis/ / ye shes snang bas khyab par gyis/ ces gsungs/
In the hermitage of Pullahari, dispel the darkness of Mati’s ignorance.[14] The Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Aural Transmission will cause the illumination of wisdom to spread.

nA ro paN chen nam dpal 'jigs med grags pa la slob ma A ka ra saM d+hi/ paN+Di ta shes rab ye shes/ ti phu la sogs mang du yod kyang ma gnang bar/ mar pa gcig pu la byin nas/ mi la ras pa bdag lung bstan pa/ /

Although great paṇḍita Nāropa, the glorious Abhayakīrti, had many disciples, such as Ākarasiddhi, Paṇḍita Prajñāsiṃha, and Tipupa, he did not bestow this teaching on them.[15] He gave it only to Marpa and made the following prophecy about Milarepa:
shar phyogs te los byin gyis brlabs/ / lho phyogs klu sgrub byin gyis brlabs/ / nub phyogs in dras byin gyis brlabs/ / byang phyogs nA ros byin gyis brlabs/ /
Tilopa blesses the East. Nāgārjuna blesses the South. Indra[bhūti] blesses the West. Nāropa blesses the North.
kha ba can ljongs byang phyogs na/ / thos pa dga' zhes bya ba yi/ / gdul bya snod ldan yod pas song / / ces gsungs so/ /
In the northern Snowy Land, there will appear one called Töpaga, a disciple who is a suitable recipient.

mar pa lo tsA la slob ma rngog chos rdor/ mar ba mgo yag mes chen po la sogs mang du yod kyang / mkha' 'gro'i snyan brgyud la yi ge med/ spel ba med gsung nas/ gzhan rnams la ma byin par kho bo gcig pu la gnang ba'o/ / de snga yan chad khrid kyi ngo bo la yi ge med par snyan brgyud zang ma yin pa la/ grod phug tu bcom ldan (482)'das ma'i zhal nas/ /

Although Marpa Lotsāwa had many disciples, such as Ngok Chödor, Marpa Golek, and Mai Tsönpo,[16] he said that what is “letterless in the Ḍākinī Aural Transmission” is not to be spread, and therefore he did not give it to others but bestowed it only on me. Up until now, since the essence of the explanations is “letterless,” the Aural Transmission has been direct. {482} In Drö Puk, the Bhagavatī said:[17]
mkha' 'gro gsang tshig nor bu de/ / rnal 'byor tsit+ta'i dkyil nas phyungs/ / badzra kI rti'i spyi bor zhog / 'od zer dga' bas 'thung bar 'gyur/ / ces lung bstan pa'i phyir dang / /
Draw the gem of the Ḍākinī’s secret verses from the middle of the yogin’s citta. Place it on the head of Vajrakīrti.[*13] He will drink its light rays with delight.

rdo rje grags pas yang dang yang du gsol ba btab pa'i phyir dang / las 'phro can gyi snod ldan rim par brgyud pa dang / khams gsum sems can ma lus pa drang ba'i don du/ mkha' 'gro'i bka' rgya bkrol nas bshad par bya'o/ /

That was given as a directive and as a supplication to be made repeatedly by Dorje Drakpa. For the sake of the successive transmissions involving suitable recipients with karmic continuity and guiding sentient beings of the three realms, with the command seal of the ḍākinīs having been loosened, I will give the following explanations.[18]
de'ang ye shes mkha' 'gro'i zhal nas snyan du brgyud pa 'di la gsum ste/ ston byed slob dpon gyi mtshan nyid dang / bstan pa slob ma'i mtshan nyid dang / bstan bya chos kyi gnas lugs so/ /

This Aural Transmission from the Jñānaḍākinī has three parts: (1) the characteristics of the ācāryas, who are the teachers; (2) the characteristics of the disciples, who are taught; and (3) the abiding state of the dharma, which is what is taught.
dang po
I. The Characteristics of the Ācāryas, Who Are the Teachers
['di] la drug ste
There are six characteristics for ācāryas:
lhag pa tshul khrims kyi bslab pa sdom pa gsum dang ldan pa/
1. The superior training in ethical conduct: possessing the three [types of] vows
ting nge 'dzin gyi bslab pa sems la rang dbang thob pa/
2. The superior training in samādhi: having achieved mastery of mind
shes rab kyi bslab pa sngags kyi 'jug sgo rtogs pa/
3. The superior training in prajñā: realization, which is the entryway to the Mantra[yāna]
byin rlabs 'byung ba'i gzhi brgyud pa dang ldan pa/
4. Being part of a lineage, which is the ground that is the source of blessings
brgyud pa de ldan gyi gdams ngag nyams su myong ba/
5. Being experienced in practicing the instructions associated with that lineage
thos bsam sde snod kyi 'jug tshul shes pas snyan brgyud kyi sgro 'dogs chod pa'o/ /
6. Cutting through misinterpretations about the Aural Transmission, having understood the way to enter the piṭakas through hearing and reflection
II.
II. The Characteristics of the Disciples, Who Are Taught
slob ma la lnga ste/
There are five characteristics for disciples:[19]
dkar po'i gzhi zad pa mo gsham gyi bu lta bu ma yin pa ni/ dad pa med na yon tan gyi gzhi med pas/
1. Disciples should not be devoid of the ground for virtuous qualities, like a child of a barren woman. If they have no faith, they have no ground for excellent qualities.
dad pa la gsum/
There are three types of faith:
dang ba'i dad pa yul khyad par can la drangs shing dad pa/
a. Inspired faith is to have faith in and be inspired by an exceptional object.[20]
'dod pa'i dad pa 'khor ba spong zhing mya ngan las 'das pa sgrub pa ste 'gro ba'i don bya bar 'dod pa/
b. Aspiring faith is the wish to be of benefit to beings through abandoning saṃsāra and achieving nirvāṇa.[21]
yid ches pa'i dad pa mi dge bas ngan song / dge bas mtho ris/ theg pa chen po gsang sngags nyams su blangs nas sangs rgyas par shes pa'o/ /
c. Trusting faith is to know that unvirtue results in the negative states, virtue in the higher states, and that practicing the Mahāyāna Secret Mantra brings buddhahood.
gnyis pa yon tan gyi rten du ma gyur pa rus sbal gyi spu lta bu ma yin pa ni/ dam tshig dang sdom pa med na yon tan skye ba'i rten med pas dam tshig dang sdom pa bsrung nus pa'o/ /

2. Disciples should not be without the supports for excellent qualities, like the hairs of a turtle. If they do not have the samayas and vows, they lack the supports for the excellent qualities; therefore, they must be able to protect their samayas and vows.

gsum pa chos brgyad kyi dbang du song ba bran lta bu ma (483)yin pa ni/ bde ba/ sdug bsngal ba/ bstod/ smad/ grags/ ma grags/ rnyed/ ma rnyed sogs mang po'i dbang du song na 'khor ba las mi thar bas/ des na chos brgyad kyi dbang du ma song bar brtson 'grus dang ldan pa'o/ /

3. Disciples should not be under the influence of the eight worldly values, as if they were their servant. {483} If they come under the sway of the many types of pleasure or suffering, praise or denigration, fame or disrepute, personal gain or loss, and so forth, they will not be liberated from saṃsāra. Therefore, they should apply themselves to not being influenced by the eight worldly values.[22]
bzhi pa theg pa chen po'i snod dang mi ldan pa rigs chad pa lta bu ma yin pa ni/ snying rje chen po dang / thos byung dang / bsam byung dang / sgom byung gi shes rab dang ldan pa'o/ /

4. Disciples should not be unable to be recipients for the Mahāyāna, like someone of the cut-off gotra. They should have great compassion and the prajñās arising from hearing, reflection, and meditation.
lnga pa smin grol gyi snod dang mi ldan pa sin+d+ha pa ma yin pa ni/ sngags kyi spyod pa blor mi shong bar skur pa btab na dmyal bar skye bas/ /sngags kyi lta spyod la yon tan du mthong ba'o/ /

5. Disciples should not be incapable of being recipients for maturation and liberation, like sendhapas.[23] If they denigrate Mantra conduct because it does not fit their understanding, they will be born in the hells.[24] They should see the Mantra view and conduct as excellent qualities.
bstan bya chos kyi gnas lugs
III. The Abiding State of the Dharma, Which Is What Is Taught

['di] la gsum ste/ phyi'i sgro 'dogs gcod pa sprul pa sku'i gdams pa brgyud pa yid bzhin nor bu/ nang nyams myong longs spyod rdzogs sku'i gdams pa smin lam yid bzhin nor bu/ gsang ba ngo sprod chos sku'i gdams pa grol lam yid bzhin nor bu'o/ /

This has three parts: (1) The Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Lineage, which are the external nirmāṇakāya instructions for severing misinterpretations;[25] (2) The Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Maturing Path, which are the inner saṃbhogakāya instructions for cultivating experiences;[26] and (3) The Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Liberating Path, which are the secret dharmakāya instructions, which point out.

'di la gsum ste/ bum dbang dang 'brel bar bsgom bya gtso bor bton pa thun mong yid bzhin nor bu/ spyi dang 'brel bar bsrung bya gtso bor bton pa dam tshig yid bzhin nor bu/ mchog dbang gsum dang 'brel bar de kho na nyid gtso bor ston pa gnas lugs yid bzhin nor bu'o/ /

[The Wish-Fulfilling Gems of the Liberating Path] has three sections: (1) The Shared Wish-Fulfilling Gems, which emphasize what is to be meditated upon in connection with the vase abhiṣeka;[27] (2) The Samaya Wish-Fulfilling Gems, which emphasize what is to be protected in connection with [the four abhiṣekas] in general;[28] and (3) The Abiding-State Wish-Fulfilling Gems, which emphasize suchness in connection with the three superior abhiṣekas.

gnas lugs yid bzhin nor bu la drug ste/ gsang dbang dang 'brel par rdzogs rim rtsa rlung gi gnas de gtso bor bton pa steng sgo rnam par grol ba'i chos drug shes rab ye shes kyi dbang dang 'brel pa mkha' 'gro'i gsang ba sgrogs pa 'og sgo bde ba chen po/ tshig dbang dang 'brel par sku gsum sems la ngo sprod pa phyag rgya chen po ye shes gsal byed/ lam blo nas gcod pa ngo sprod bar do'i gdams pa dang / gdams ngag spyi'i gegs sel ba dang / lam cig car ba bya spyod tshogs su bsgyur ba lam gyi (484) gdams ngag go /

The Abiding-State Wish-Fulfilling Gems are divided into the following six sections:[29] (1) the six dharmas, which liberate through the upper door, emphasize the points of the channels and winds and are the perfection process connected to the secret abhiṣeka;[30] (2) great bliss through the lower door is the Ḍākinī’s secret proclamation and is connected to the prajñājñāna abhiṣeka; (3) mahāmudrā, the illumination of wisdom, points out the three kāyas to be the mind and is connected to the word abhiṣeka;[31] (4) the instructions on the bardos point out how to arrive at the end of the path through recollection;[32] (5) dispelling hindrances are universal instructions; [33] and (6) the instructions on the path for those of an instantaneous path transform all activities into accumulations.[*14][34] {484}

{ thog mar las rgyu 'bras/ 'khor ba'i nyes dmigs/ 'chi ba mi rtag pa bsam pa/ tshogs rdzogs pa'i yan lag tu stobs kyis gang 'byor ba'i gser gyi maN+Dal 'bul/ bar chad sel zhing byin rlabs 'byung ba'i don du tshogs 'khor nges pa can bcu gnyis bskor/ zla ba drug tu khrid du bskyang bar bya'o/ mchan/ }

[*14] Interlinear note: First, contemplate karmic causes and results, the shortcomings of saṃsāra, and death and impermanence. As the branches for perfecting the accumulations, offer maṇḍalas of gold according to your means. For the sake of dispelling obstacles and as the source of blessings, perform gaṇacakras with the twelve certainties. Practice these instructions for six months.
dang po bum dbang dang 'brel ba bsgoms bya gtso bor bton pa thun mong yid bzhin nor bu
A. The Shared Wish-Fulfilling Gems, Which Emphasize What Is to Be Meditated Upon in Connection with the Vase Abhiṣeka
['di] la'ang gsum ste/ rgyal po chos nyid mi 'gyur ba/ blon po rigs gsum las byed dang / dmangs phal pa phrin las mthun sbyor ro/ /
This has three parts: (1) the sovereigns: unchanging dharmatā; (2) the ministers: three types of actions; and (3) the people: the conducive activities.[35]
dang po
1. The Sovereigns: Unchanging Dharmatā
['di] la gsum/ yab rgyal po lta bu'i sgrub thabs/ yum rgyal mo lta bu'i sgrub thabs/ sras rgyal phran lta bu'i sgrub thabs so/ /
This has three sections: (1) the sādhana of the king-like male consort, (2) the sādhana of the queenlike female consort, and (3) the sādhana of the prince-like son.[36]
de las 'dir yum gyi sgrub thabs gtso bor bton te/ lha mo gcig tu sgrub pa la rnal 'byor bcu las/
Among those, here the emphasis is on the sādhana of the female consort. There are the following ten yogas for the practice of the single goddess.[37]
dang po tshad med pa'i rnal 'byor ni/
1. The Yoga of Immeasurable Aspirations
gnas yid dang mthun par mthun rkyen bsgrub/ /rten bkram/ stan bde ba la 'dug ste/ skyabs su 'gro zhing tshad med pa bzhi bsgom/

The place should be one suitable for your mind, where you have the conditions conducive for practice. Set up representations [of body, speech, and mind]. Sit on a comfortable seat. Go for refuge and cultivate the four immeasurable aspirations.[38]
gnyis pa bla ma'i rnal 'byor sgom pa ni/
2. The Meditation on Guru Yoga

spyi bor pad+ma nyi zla'i gdan la/ rang gi rtsa ba'i bla ma sku gcer bu rus pa'i rgyan gyis brgyan/ / sku mdog mthing ga spyan phyogs bcur gzigs pa/ g.yas DA ma ru/ g.yon dril bu dkur bsten pa/ sku gzi mdangs dang ldan pa 'dzum zhing gar mdzad pa/ de la brgyud pa'i bla ma/ chos 'brel zhus tshad/ yi dam/ sangs rgyas/chos/ dge 'dun thams cad 'od dang 'od zer gyi tshul du bstim/ dpa' bo mkha' 'gro 'bum gyis bskor bar sgom/ phyi nang gsang ba'i mchod pa 'bul/ rtogs pa mchog tu gyur pa rgyud la skye bar byin gyis rlobs/ ces gsol ba rtse gcig tu btab/ de rjes bla ma 'od du zhu rang la thim/ phyag rgya chen po'i dbang bzhug go /

Imagine that on the top of your head, on lotus, sun, and moon seats, is your root guru, naked and adorned with bone ornaments. They are deep blue, gazing in all ten directions. They hold a ḍamaru in their right hand and rest a ghaṇṭā on their hip. Their body glows with radiance, and they are smiling and dancing. The lineage gurus, all those with whom you have a dharma connection, the yidams, buddhas, dharma, and saṅgha dissolve into them as light and light rays. Imagine your guru is surrounded by hundreds of thousands of heroes and ḍākinīs. Present them with outer, inner, and secret offerings. Make the one-pointed supplication, “Bless me that supreme realization arises in my mindstream.” After that, your guru melts into light and dissolves into you. Remain in the abhiṣeka of mahāmudrā.[39]
gsum pa lha sgom pa ni/
3. Deity Meditation

rang gi snying gi rtse mo gyen du bstan pa pad+ma dmar po 'dab (485) ma brgyad pa'i lte bar a las zla ba/ de'i steng du ba~M/ de las 'od 'phros/ lus phyi nang sbyangs/ yang 'od 'phros/ snod bcud 'od du zhu/

The tip of your heart faces upward. {485} There is a red eight-petaled lotus, in whose center, from a, a moon appears. Above that is vaṃ, from which light radiates, cleansing your body, inside and out. Again light radiates, causing the environment and its inhabitants to melt into light.

'od zer slar 'dus pa las/ bdag nyid rdo rje rnal 'byor ma sku mdog dmar mo/ g.yas gri gug g.yon thod pa khrag gis gang ba bsnams pa/ zhabs g.yas brkyang bas 'jigs byed sngon po'i rna ba mnan pa/ g.yon bskum pas dus mtshan ma dmar mo'i nu ma nas mnan pa/ rus pa'i rgyan drug mi mgo'i do shal/ thod skam lngas dbu brgyan pa/ spyan gsum mche ba gtsigs pa/ skra grol ba/ kha T+wAM ga 'bring po bsnams pa/ ma dang du khrod kyi dbus na snang la rang bzhin med pa/ 'du ba dang gshegs pa med pa/ ye shes kyi lus su yengs med du sgom/ mi gsal na bskyar zhing sgom/

The light rays gather back, and you appear as red Vajrayoginī. You are holding a hooked knife in your right hand and a skull cup filled with blood in your left. Your right leg is extended, pressing down on the ear of blue Bhairava, and your left is bent, trampling on the breast of Kālarātri. You have the six bone ornaments and a necklace of human heads. Five dried skulls adorn your head. You have three eyes, bared fangs, and loose hair. You hold an intermediate khaṭvāṃga. You appear in the middle of fire and charnel grounds and yet have no nature. You are without gathering and departing. Meditate on your wisdom body without distraction. If it is not clear, refresh it and meditate.[40]
bzhi pa 'jig rten gyi khams sbyangs pa ni/
4. Purifying the Worldly Realms
snying ga'i ba~M las 'od 'phros/ phyi snod la phog pas gzhal yas khang / nang bcud la phog pas skye 'gro pho thams cad bde mchog / mo thams cad rje btsun mar gyur par bsam/

Light radiates from the vaṃ in your heart. Imagine that as it strikes the external environment, that becomes a palace, and as it strikes the internal inhabitants, all male beings become Saṃvaras and all female beings become Jetsunmas.[41]
lnga pa dpa' bo dpa' mo bsdu ba ni/
5. Gathering the Heroes and Heroines
snying ga'i ba~M las 'od zer 'phros/ snod bcud kyi dpa' bo dpa' mo rnams la phog ste thams cad rang la thim par blta'o/ /
Light rays radiate from the vaṃ in your heart. It strikes the heroes and heroines of the environment and its inhabitants. See that they all dissolve into you.[42]
drug pa rlung rdo rje'i bzlas pa ni/
6. Vajra Repetition with the Breath
sna yi rtse mor thig le dkar dmar sran ma tsam rlung phar 'gro dus dkar po phar 'gro/ tshur 'jug dus dmar po tshur 'ong / res mos la sems gtad pas ye shes skye'o/

At the tip of your nose are white and red bindus, the size of beans. When your breath goes out, the white one goes out. When it comes back in, the red one comes in. By focusing your mind on those alternating, wisdom arises.[43]
bdun pa ngag rdo rje'i bzlas pa ni/
7. Vajra Repetition with Speech
thugs ka'i ba~M la sngags 'khor ba la sems gtad la/ nye snying ji srid du bzla'o/ /
Focus your mind on vaṃ surrounded by a mantra garland in your heart. Recite the quintessence mantra.[44]
brgyad pa rdzogs rim ni/
8. The Perfection Process

snying ga'i sa bon las 'od 'phros/ snod bcud 'od du zhu rang la thim/ rang yas 'dus mas 'dus/ zla ba la/ zla ba ba~M la/ ba~M zla tshes la/ zla tshes thig le la/ de nA da la/ nA da ring thung nas tsam/ phra sbom rta rnga brgyad gshags pa'i cha tsam/ mun khungs la glog 'khyugs pa tsam dmar khyem tsam la sems gtad/ de 'od du yal tser song ste dmigs pa ye dra med/ blos 'dzin med/ (486)shes pa bya bral du bzhag / bying na stod seng mgo dgye/ rig pa hur phyungs la phaT drag po gang ba/ rgod nam go phur/ sems 'phro na dbang dus dran par bya'o/

Light radiates from the seed syllable in your heart. The environment and its inhabitants melt into light and dissolve into you. You also dissolve from the top down and from the bottom up into the moon. The moon dissolves in the vaṃ, the vaṃ dissolves into its crescent, the crescent into the bindu, and that into the nāda. The nāda is simply [a horse’s hair] in length and a hundredth of a horse’s tail hair in width.[*15] It is like lightning in a dark enclosure—focus your mind on its red radiance.[45] That vanishes into light. Do not be distracted from the object of meditation. Do not grasp at it with your mind. {486} Leave your mind free of activities. If you feel dull, lift up your upper body and raise your head. Energize your awareness, and say phaṭ forcefully. If you are agitated, rub your head. If your mind scatters, recall the occasion of abhiṣeka.[46]
dgu pa bsre ba ro snyoms ni/
9. The Mixings and Equalizing Tastes
bsre ba dang ro snyoms gnyis po re re la'ang bzhi bzhi ste brgyad/
There are four mixings and four equalizing tastes, making eight.
dang po smin pa dbang dang bsre ba/ grol ba lam dang bsre ba/ bsrung bya dam tshig dang bsre ba/ thob bya 'bras bu dang bsre ba'o/ /

First, there are the mixings related to the maturating abhiṣekas, the mixings related to the liberating paths, the mixings related to the samayas (what are to be guarded), and the mixings related to the results (what are to be attained).
smin pa dbang dang bsre ba ni/ /
First, the mixings related to the maturating abhiṣekas.

bdag gi bskyed rdzogs bsgoms kyang / / smin pa dbang gi don ma bsgoms/ / grol ba lam yang ma bsgoms/ / bsrung bya dam tshig kyang ma bsrungs/ thob bya 'bras bu sku bzhi yang mi thob las che snyams na/ rang rje btsun ma'i spyi bor bla ma dang bcas pa gsal seng nge ba de bum dbang gi don yin/ bum dbang la'ang rnam pa gsal ba las gzhan bsgom rgyu med/

When you meditate on the generation and perfection processes, you may think that you have heavy karma and are not meditating on the ultimate point of the maturing abhiṣekas; are not meditating on the path of liberation; are not protecting the samayas, what are to be guarded; and do not attain the four kāyas, which are the result to be attained. If you think that way, [know that meditating] on yourself as the Jetsunma with your gurus on the top of your head, clearly and vividly, is the ultimate point of the vase abhiṣeka. The vase abhiṣeka is that there is nothing to meditate upon other than that clear manifestation [of the deity].
gsal ba do tsa na gsal ba rang gi sems su 'dug / sku mdog phyag mtshan rang rang gi ngo bos stong par 'dug pa gsang dbang gi don yin/ gsang dbang la ngo bo stong pa las gzhan bsgom rgyu med/

When there is clarity, the clarity is your own mind. The body [of the deity], their color, and their emblems are empty of any essence of their own. That is the ultimate point of the secret abhiṣeka. The secret abhiṣeka is that there is nothing to meditate upon other than the empty essence [of the deity].

rnam pa gsal ba ngo bo stong pa gnyis dbyer med du nyams su myong ba bde ba zag pa med pa ste shes rab ye shes kyi don yin/ dbang gsum pa la'ang nyams myong bde ba las gzhan bsgom rgyu med/ de ltar rnam pa gsal ba dang / ngo bo stong pa dang / nyams myong bde ba dang / skye 'gags gnas gsum dang bral ba de tshig dbang gi don yin la/

Experiencing the inseparability of the clear manifestation and the empty essence as undefiled bliss is the ultimate point of the prajñājñāna abhiṣeka. The third abhiṣeka is that there is nothing to meditate upon other than blissful experience. Thus, the clear manifestation, empty essence, blissful experience, and being free from arising, cessation, and abiding is the ultimate point of the word abhiṣeka.

dbang bzhi pa la'ang 'od gsal 'gro 'ong skye 'gag gnas gsum dang bral ba las gzhan sgom rgyu med/ de ltar bskyed rim bsgoms pas dbang bzhi rdzogs pa'i nyams len gcig 'byung ste/ bum dbang dma' ste mar ma shor/ /

The fourth abhiṣeka is that there is nothing to meditate upon other than luminosity free from coming or going, arising, ceasing, or abiding. Practicing the generation process in that way is the development of the single practice that perfects the four abhiṣekas. The lower vase abhiṣeka has not lapsed into being something low.

tshig dbang mtho ste yar ma shor/ / gsang dbang dang shes rab ye shes par tshigs su ma lus par bskyed rim sgom bdo tsan/ dbang bskur thob ba do bas (487) gcig shes kun la mkhas pa'i man ngag yin ces bde mchog gi yum rdo rje rnal 'byor ma des so/ /

The higher word abhiṣeka has not lapsed into being something elevated. The secret abhiṣeka and the prajñājñāna have not been left as things in between. When you cultivate the generation process, you receive the abhiṣekas. {487} Thus, these are the esoteric instructions called “knowing one and being skilled in all” taught by Vajrayoginī, the consort of Saṃvara.[47]
gnyis pa grol lam dang bsre ba
Second, the mixings related to the liberating paths.

['di] la bzhi ste/ bskyed rim grol ba'i lam/ / rdzogs rim grol ba'i lam/ zung 'jug grol ba'i lam/ phyag rgya chen po grol ba'i lam mo/ / rang rje btsun mar gsal seng nge ba de bskyed rim gyi lam yin/ bskyed rim la'ang rnam pa gsal ba las gzhan bsgom rgyu med/

This has four parts: (1) the liberating path of the generation process, (2) the liberating path of the perfection process, (3) the liberating path of unification, and (4) the liberating path of mahāmudrā. Visualizing yourself clearly and vividly as the Jetsunma is the path of the generation process. The generation process is that there is nothing to meditate upon other than the clear manifestation.

gsal dus na gsal ba ngo bos stong pa de rdzogs rim gyi lam yin/ rdzogs rim la'ang ngo bos stong pa las gzhan bsgom rgyu med/ nyams myong bde ba de zung 'jug gi lam yin/ zung 'jug la'ang nyams myong bde ba las gzhan bsgom rgyu med/

When there is clarity, clarity is empty of any essence. That is the path of the perfection process. The perfection process is that there is nothing to meditate upon other than the empty essence. The blissful experience is the path of unification. Unification is that there is nothing to meditate upon other than the blissful experience.

gsal stong bde ba dbyer med 'gro 'ong gnas gsum dang bral ba de phyag rgya chen po'i lam yin/ phyag rgya chen po la'ang 'od gsal 'gro 'ong gnas gsum dang bral ba las gzhan bsgom rgyu med/ des na bskyed rim byas pas zung 'jug gi lam rdzogs pa'i rnal 'byor gcig 'byung ngo / / jo bo la la phyag rgya chen po go bas bskyed rim la blo mi 'jug zer/ la la stong nyid sgom pa'i dus min zer/

Inseparable clarity, emptiness, and bliss, free from coming, going, or abiding, is the path of mahāmudrā. Mahāmudrā is that there is nothing to meditate upon other than luminosity free from coming, going, or abiding. Therefore, practicing the generation process gives rise to the single yoga that perfects the path of unification. Some masters say that since they understand mahāmudrā, they have no interest in the generation process. Others say that it is not the time to meditate on emptiness.

'dir bskyed rim lam dma' ste mar ma shor/ phyag rgya chen po mtho ste yar ma shor/ rdzogs rim dang zung 'jug bar tshigs su ma lus par bskyed rim bsgom bdo tsan lam bzhi bgrod bdo bas/ gcig shes kun la mkhas pa'i man ngag dam pa'o/ /

Here, the lower generation process has not lapsed into being something low. The higher mahāmudrā has not lapsed into being something elevated. The perfection process and unification have not been left as things in between. When you cultivate the generation process, you traverse the four paths. Thus, these are the sacred esoteric instructions for knowing one and being skilled in all.[48]
gsum pa dam tshig dang bsre ba
Third, the mixings related to the samayas.
