['di] la bzhi ste/ bum dbang gi dam tshig bskyed rim/ gsang dbang gi dam tshig rdzogs rim/ shes rab ye shes kyi dam tshig bde chen/ dbang bzhi pa'i dam tshig phyag rgya chen po'o/ / de ngo sprod na/ bdag nyid lhar gsal ba de bum dbang gi bsrung bya/ bum dbang gi dam tshig la'ang rnam pa gsal ba las gzhan bsgom rgyu med/ de bzhin du gong (488) bzhin 'gro'o/

This has four parts: (1) the samaya of the vase abhiṣeka is the generation process, (2) the samaya of the secret abhiṣeka is the perfection process, (3) the samaya of the prajñājñāna is great bliss, and (4) the samaya of the fourth abhiṣeka is mahāmudrā. These are introduced as follows: You appear clearly as the deity. That is what is to be guarded for the vase abhiṣeka. The samaya of the vase abhiṣeka is that there is nothing to meditate upon other than the clear manifestation. The other points are the same as above.[49] {488}
bzhi pa thob bya 'bras bu dang bsre ba
Fourth, the mixings related to the results, what are to be attained.

['di] la bzhi ste/ gzugs sku/ chos sku/ bde ba chen po'i sku/ ngo bo nyid kyi sku'o/ / de ngo sprod na rnam pa gsal ba la 'phel 'grib med par brtan pa zob pa de gzugs sku/ ngo bo stong la 'phel 'gril med par brtan pa thob pa de chos sku/ nyams myong bde ba la brtan pa thob pa de bde ba chen po'i sku/ 'od gsal 'gro 'ong med pa la brtan pa thob pa de ngo bo nyid kyi sku'o/ / ngo bo nyid kyi sku la'ang 'od gsal 'gro 'ong med pa las gzhan bsgom rgyu med/

This has four parts: (1) the form kāyas, (2) the dharmakāya, (3) the mahāsukhakāya, and (4) the svabhāvakāya. These are introduced as follows: When the clear manifestation is stabilized with no fluctuation, that is the form kāyas. When the empty essence is stabilized with no fluctuation, that is the dharmakāya. When the blissful experience is stabilized, that is the mahāsukhakāya. When luminosity is stabilized with no coming or going, that is the svabhāvakāya. The svabhāvakāya is that there is nothing to meditate upon other than luminosity with no coming or going.

bskyed rim bsgoms pas sku bzhi thob pa'i rnal 'byor pa gcig byung ste/ ngo bo nyid sku mtho ste yar mi gtong pa la sogs gong gis 'gre'o/ / 'di ni 'bras bu lam du byed pa gcig shes kun la mkhas pa'i man ngag yin ces sangs rgyas kyi yum des gsungs so/ / bsre ba go bas ro snyoms go bar 'gyur ro/ / de yan chad la khrid dus rnal 'byor re re la dmigs skor re re bya'o/ / myong ba ma skyes bar du bsgom par bya'o/ /

By cultivating the generation process, the single yoga that achieves the four kāyas develops. The higher svabhāvakāya has not been set off as something elevated. The other points are the same as above. These incorporate the results into the path. They are the esoteric instructions called “knowing one and being skilled in all” taught by the mother of the buddhas. Through understanding the mixings, you will understand the equalizing of tastes. Up to this point, when giving instructions, do one cycle of visualization for each yoga. Meditate until experiences arise.[50]
bcu pa gtor ma ni/
10. Tormas

nges bcas tshes bcur/ nges med rgyun du'o/ / sha chang zan chu dang bcas pa gtor snod gtsang mar bshams te/ yoM las rlung / ra~M las me/ ka~M las mi mgo'i sgyed pu gsum ka phyir bstan pa/ a las thod pa phyi dkar la nang dmar ba'i dbus su/ sha lnga bdud rtsi lngar bsams la/

[Tormas should be offered at] specified times, the tenth lunar days; and at unspecified times, continuously. In a clean torma container, arrange meat, beer, and [kneaded tsampa] dough with water. Imagine that from yaṃ comes wind; from raṃ, fire; and from kaṃs, a hearth of three human skulls facing outward. From a appears a skull cup, white on the outside and red on the inside. In its center are the five meats and five amṛtas.
oM AHhU~M dkar dmar mthing gsum/ lan gsum gyis rlung g.yos/ me sbar/ rdzas khol ba'i rlangs pas/ oM zhu nyes skyon dag AHzhu zag med kyi bdud rtsir gyur/ hU~M zhu dpag tu med pa 'phel bar bsam/

[Above that,] imagine oṃ āḥ hūṃ, white, red, and blue.[51] Three times, the wind stirs. The fire blazes. The steam of the boiling substances melts the oṃ, purifying the flaws and defects [of the torma]. Āḥ melts, transforming [the torma] into undefiled amṛta, and hūṃ melts, increasing it to something unimaginable.

'bar ba'i phyag rgyas pheM pheM brjod pas snying ga'i sa bon las 'od 'phros/ bla ma yi dam mkha' 'gro chos skyong thams cad mdun du byon/ rtsa sngags la ba liM btags pa lan bdun gyis 'bul ljags rdo rje'i sbu gu can gyis gsol bas mnyes par (489)bsam/ yi ge brgya pas bshags pa bya/ 'dod don la gsol ba gdab/ badzra muHsa gshegs par bya/ rgyas par gzhan du shes so/ / rgyal po chos nyid mi 'gyur ba'o/ /

Saying pheṃ pheṃ with the blazing mudrā, light radiates from the seed syllable at your heart. The gurus, yidams, ḍākinīs, and dharma protectors come in front. Offer [the torma while reciting] the root mantra with baliṃ added, seven times. Think that they receive it through their hollow vajra tongues and are delighted. {489} Make confessions with the hundred-syllable mantra, and supplicate for [the fulfillment of] your desired aims. With vajra muḥ, they depart. The details should be learned from other sources. This [completes] the sovereigns, unchanging dharmatā.[52]
blon po rigs gsum las byed
2. The Ministers: Three Types of Actions
['di] la gsum/ bla ma'i rnal 'byor/ bdag 'jug ting nge 'dzin gyi dbang bskur ba dang / yi ge brgya pa'i bzlas pa'o/ /
This has three sections: (1) guru yoga, (2) the self-entered samādhi abhiṣekas, and (3) recitation of the hundred-syllable mantra.
dang po bla ma'i rnal 'byor ni/
a. Guru Yoga

rang lhar gsal ba'i spyi bor pa~M las pad+ma'i sdong po 'dab ma stong dang ldan pa/ kha dog sna tshogs rim pa bdun dang ldan par bsam/ rang gi thugs ka nas 'od zer lcags kyu'i rnam pa lta bu 'phros/ bla ma yi dam dbyer med spyan drangs pad+ma'i dbus su bzhugs/ bla ma dang rang gi thugs ka nas 'od 'phros/ brgyud pa'i bla ma dang chos 'brel yod tshad spyan drangs/ pad+ma'i phyi rim la bzhugs/ de bzhin du yi dam rnams de'i phyi rim du spyan drangs/ dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas rnams de yi phyi rim la/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams de'i phyi rim la= dkon mchog gsum dang sku gsung thugs kyi rten rnams de'i phyi rim la= grub thob brgyad cu sogs rnal 'byor pho mo rnams spyan drangs/ de yi phyi rim la bzhugs/

Visualize yourself as the deity. Imagine that on the top of your head, from paṃ, appears a stemmed lotus with a thousand petals, multicolored with seven layers. Light rays, like iron hooks, radiate from your heart, inviting your guru, inseparable from the yidams, who comes to sit in the center of the lotus. Light radiates from your guru’s heart and your heart, inviting the lineage gurus and all those with whom you have a dharma connection, who come to sit on an outer layer of the lotus. Similarly, the yidams are invited to the next outer layer; the buddhas of the three times are invited to the next outer layer; the bodhisattvas are invited to the next outer layer; the three jewels and the representations of body, speech, and mind are invited to the next outer layer; and the yogins and yoginīs—the eighty siddhas and others—are invited and sit on the next outer layer.

de thams cad 'od kyi lus can/ nang ma bas phyi ma cung zad dma' ba/ zhal rtsa ba'i bla ma la bstan par bsam/ de dag la phyag bya/ phyi nang gsang gsum gyi mchod pa dang lus 'bul/ bla ma la sangs rgyas su bltas la mos gus chen pos rtse gcig tu gsol ba btab/ de rnams rim gyis rtsa ba'i bla ma la thim/ bla ma spyi bor thim pas/ snying gar mi bskyod pa'i rnam pa 'od zer dpag tu med pa 'phro bar bzhugs pas ma rig pa sangs dag de 'od du yal/ rjes gnas lugs kyi ngang la bzhag /

They all have bodies of light. The ones on the outside are slightly lower than those on the inside. They all face toward your root guru. Pay homage to them, present them with the outer, inner, and secret offerings, and offer your body. Supplicate them with great one-pointed devotion, seeing the gurus as buddhas. They gradually dissolve into your root guru. Your guru dissolves into the top of your head and resides in your heart in the form of Akṣobhya, radiating immeasurable amounts of light rays. This cleanses your ignorance. They then disappear into light. Next remain in the abiding state.

'di zab lam bla ma'i mos gus yin pas nyin mtshan du 'bad par bya'o/ / de ltar bsgoms pas bla ma'i (490)snang ba 'ba' zhig 'char rmi lam du chos zhu ba/ dbang bskur ba/ ka pA la bdud rtsis gang ba sbyin pa la sogs pa 'byung ba byin rlabs kyis chos sku thob pa'i rtags so/ /

This is the profound path of devotion to the gurus. Exert yourself in this day and night. {490} By meditating in this way, you will experience only the appearance of the guru. During your dreams, you will receive dharma teachings and abhiṣekas, be given kapālas filled with amṛta, and so on. These are signs of achieving the dharmakāya through blessings.
gnyis pa bdag 'jug gi ting nge 'dzin gyi dbang ni/
b. The Self-Entered Samādhi Abhiṣekas

skyabs 'gro sems bskyed dang ldan pas/ rang gi mdun du rin po che'i khri/ phyogs bzhir rgyal chen bzhi/ khri mig na glang chen brgyad/ mtshams bzhi nas seng ge bzhis btegs pa'i nyi zla pad+ma'am/ dar 'bol brtsegs pa'i steng na rtsa ba'i bla ma yab yum 'khor los sgyur ba'i/ ngo bo bla ma la rnam pa bde mchog yab yum dgyes pa'i zhal ras 'dzum pa'i mdangs dang ldan pa/ bdag la thugs kyi dgongs pas spyan gyis gzigs par bsam/ bla ma'i thugs ka nas 'od zer 'phros/ brgyud pa'i bla ma dang / yi dam lha tshogs/ sangs rgyas chos dang dge 'dun/ dpa' bo mkha' 'gro grangs med pa bla ma la bstim/ snyan brgyud pa la tha mal du sdod pa'i skabs gnyis te/ blon po rigs gsum las byed kyi bar mar ma gtogs lha ru gsal ba zhig dgos/

Take refuge and arouse bodhicitta. In front, imagine there is a jeweled throne, with the four great kings in the four directions. The sides of the throne are supported by eight elephants, and the corners by four lions. On top of a sun, moon, and lotus, or stacks of silk cushions, are your root gurus: male and female consorts in the form of cakravartins or in essence your gurus and in manifestation Saṃvara, male and female consorts. Imagine that glowing with delighted smiles, they gaze upon you with their minds’ attention. Light rays radiate from the gurus’ hearts, causing the lineage gurus, assemblies of yidam deities, buddhas, the dharma, the saṅgha, and heroes and ḍākinīs, countless in number, to dissolve into the gurus. In the Aural Transmission, there are two occasions when you remain in your ordinary form. During the three types of actions of the ministers, you must visualize yourself as the deity except during the middle one.

'dir rang tha mal du 'dug pas phyi nang gsang ba de kho na nyid kyi mchod pa/ lus longs spyod dang rang gi dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad ltos med du 'bul/ mos gus kyi gdung shugs bskyed la gsol ba thun mong ma yin pa yun ring du 'debs/ bla ma rin po ches bdag la bum pa'i dbang bskur du gsol ces pas/ bla ma yab yum kyi smin mtshams nas 'od zer kar po ye shes kyi bdud rtsi'i rang bzhin dkar na ra ra byung / rang gi smin mtshams su zhugs/ lus kyi dri ma dang sku'i dam tshig nyams chags sangs dag / lus shel ltar dag pa ste/ yi dam gyi skur gyur/ sku'i byin rlabs ma lus pa bdag gi lus la zhugs/ rig pa'i dbang lnga mtha' brten dang bcas pa thob par bsam/

Here, in your ordinary form, present outer, inner, secret, and suchness offerings. Offer your body, possessions, and all your roots of virtue with no concerns. Arouse your devotional longing and make extraordinary supplications for a long time. Saying, “Precious gurus, please bestow the vase abhiṣeka upon me,” imagine that from the point between the eyebrows of the gurus, male and female consorts, white light rays emerge as a white stream with the nature of wisdom amṛta. It enters the point between your eyebrows, purifying the stains of your body and cleansing your impaired and broken samayas of body. Your body is pure like a crystal and becomes the body of the yidam. All the blessings of body enter your body. Think that you have received the five abhiṣekas of awareness along with their conclusions. {491}

bla ma rin po ches bdag la (491)gsang ba'i dbang bskur ba stsal du gsol ces pas/ sbyor mtshams nas byang sems dkar dmar 'od dmar po dang bcas pa dmar na ra ra byung / rang gi lce thog tu babs/ ngag gi sgrib pa dang gsung gi nyams chag dag yi dam kyi sku snang la rang bzhin med par gyur/ gsung gi byin rlabs ma lus pa ngag la zhugs/ gsang ba'i dbang thob par bsam mo/ /

Saying, “Precious gurus, please bestow the secret abhiṣeka upon me,” imagine that from the place of union [of the male and female consorts] white and red bodhicittas with a red radiance emerge as a red stream. It falls to your tongue, purifying the obscurations of your speech and your impaired and broken samayas of speech. You become the body of the yidam: appearance with no nature. All the blessings of speech enter your speech. Think that you have received the secret abhiṣeka.

bla ma rin po ches bdag la shes rab ye shes kyi dbang bskur ba stsal du gsol/ yab yum gyi thugs ka nas 'od zer sngon po byung / snying gar zhugs/ yid kyi sgrib pa dang thugs kyi nyams chag dag / rang yi dam du gsal ba de bde stong gi ngang nas bde phril phril bar gyur/ thugs kyi byin rlabs ma lus pa yid la zhugs/ dbang gsum pa thob par bsam/

Saying, “Precious gurus, please bestow the prajñājñāna abhiṣeka upon me,” imagine that blue light rays emerge from the hearts of the male and female consorts. They enter your heart, purifying the obscurations of your mind and your impaired and broken samayas of mind. You appear clearly as the yidam and become vibrating bliss within a state of bliss-emptiness. All the blessings of mind enter your mind. Think that you have received the third abhiṣeka.

de rjes gsol ba btab pas/ gnas gsum gyi 'od zer sgo gsum du zhugs/ yab yum 'od du zhu/ rang la thims pa thugs sems gnyis med kyi ye shes kyi ngang la klod nas ji srid gnas pa de srid du bzhag / dbang bzhi pa thob/

Supplicating again, imagine that light rays from the three places of the male and female consorts enter your three doors. The male and female consorts melt into light and dissolve into you. Remain as long as you can within the expanse of wisdom, the nonduality of [your guru’s] mind and your mind. You have received the fourth abhiṣeka.

rjes bsngo bas rgyas 'deb/ bsre ba ro snyoms sbyar/ khrid dus dmigs skor ni/ dus rgyun du zhag re la lan re mi blang kha med do/ / de ltar byas pas dam tshig nyes ltung thams cad sbyong / dge sbyor gyi bogs thon/ rtogs pa khyad par can rgyud la skye/ bar do'i chags sdang rang grol du grol ba'o/ / ting nge 'dzin gyi dbang bskur ba'o/ /

Next, seal this with a dedication. Include the mixings and equalizing of tastes. When giving instructions, do one cycle of visualization. On a regular basis there is simply no way this cannot be done every day. Through doing this, the flaws and downfalls associated with your samayas are purified. Your spiritual practice is enhanced. Exceptional realizations arise in your mindstream. Attachments and aversions in the bardo will be self-liberated. You have received the samādhi abhiṣekas.[53]
gsum pa yi ge brgya pa'i bzlas pa ni/
c. Recitation of the Hundred-Syllable Mantra

sgrib gnyis ma sbyongs na tshogs gnyis mi rdzogs/ snam bu dri ma can la tshos bzang yang mi 'gos pa bzhin nyams sgrib can la gdams pa zab kyang rtogs pa mi skye bas/ de'i phyir na mtshan ma'i bsnyen pa sdig pa dag pa'i rtags ma byung gi bar ram/ grangs bsnyen 'bum tsho gsum/ dus bsnyen zla ba gcig gnas dben par smra bcad bya/ maN+Dal tshom bu dgu pa'o/ / (492) gtor ma bcas dbyar ma rul/ dgun ma 'khyags pa bya/

If you do not purify your two obscurations, you will not perfect the two accumulations. In the same way that a stained cloth cannot absorb even the best dye, those contaminated by impaired [samayas] will not give rise to realizations despite the profundity of the instructions. Therefore, the approach in terms of signs is that you practice until the signs of the purification of negative actions arise. The approach in terms of numbers is three hundred thousand. The approach in terms of time is one month. In an isolated place, maintain silence. Arrange nine piles on a maṇḍala. {492} Include a torma. Do not let that rot in the summer or freeze in the winter.

skyabs 'gro sems bskyed dang ldan pas/ swa b+hA bas sbyang / stong pa'i ngang las spyi bor pa~M las pad+ma/ a las zla ba'i steng du rdo rje sems dpa' sku mdog dkar po zhal gcig phyag gnyis pa rdo rje dang dril bu 'dzin pas yum la 'khyud pa/ yum rdo rje snyems ma sku mdog dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs can gri gug dang thod pa 'dzin pas yab la 'khyud la/ rin po che dang rus pa'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa/ zhabs phyed krung du bzhugs pa/ gnyis ka'i thugs kar zla ba'i steng du hU~M dang ba~M las yi ge brgya pa mu tig gi rdog po lta bu dkar ram me bas bskor bar bsam/

Take refuge and arouse bodhicitta. Cleanse with svabhāva. Within emptiness, on top of your head, from paṃ, appears a lotus. From a appears a moon, on top of which is seated Vajrasattva. He is white, with one face and two hands. Holding a vajra and ghaṇṭā, he embraces his consort. His consort, Vajragarvā, is white with a red glow. Holding a hooked knife and skull cup, she embraces her consort. They are adorned with ornaments of jewels and bones and are seated in a partial cross-legged position. In both their hearts are moons, on top of which are hūṃ or vaṃ, surrounded by the hundred syllables, like pearl beads, either white or fiery.

de yang ngo bo bla ma/ rnam pa rdo rje sems dpar bltas pa'i gnas gsum du oM AHhU~M bsam/ hU~M las 'od 'phros phyogs bcu'i bla ma yi dam sangs rgyas byang sems thams cad kyi thugs ka nas ye shes kyi bdud rtsi byung / rdo rje sems dpa'i hU~M dang yi ge brgya pa la thim/ sku'i nang thams cad gang / / zhabs g.yas pa'i sen dbrag nas cha'i them bu btang ba bzhin/ skya na ra ra tshangs bug nas zhugs lus kyi phyi nang thams cad bkrus/ nad gdon sdig sgrib nyams chags thams cad dud pa'am dri ma lta bu ba spu'i bu ga dang / gshang gci'i lam nas thon par bsam/ yi ge brgya pa bzla/ yang na bde mchog lhan skyes sku mdog dkar por bsam la/ he ru ka'i yig brgya bzla/ 'phro gcod dus mchod pa sna lnga dang gtor ma 'bul/

View them as being in essence your guru and in manifestation Vajrasattva. In their three places, imagine oṃ āḥ hūṃs. Light radiates from the hūṃs bringing wisdom amṛta from the hearts of the gurus, yidams, buddhas, and bodhisattvas of the ten directions, which dissolves into the hūṃ and hundred syllables of Vajrasattva. It fills their bodies and, from under the nails of his right toes, a white stream flows like beer from a spigot in a beer jug. It enters through your opening of Brahmā and cleanses your body, inside and out. Imagine that sickness, spirits, negative actions, obscurations, and impaired and broken [samayas] exit as smoke or filth through your pores, anus, and urethra. Recite the hundred syllables. Alternatively, imagine Saṃvara Sahaja, white in color, and recite the heruka hundred syllables. When you stop, present the five kinds of offerings and torma.

rdo rje sems dpa' he ru ka'i zhal nas rigs kyi bu khyod kyi sgrib pa dag go gsungs nas 'od du zhu nas spyi bor thim/ thugs sems gnyis med kyi ngang du bsngo ba bya/ bsre ba ro snyoms sbyar/ dus rgyun du thun gyi stod smad la bya/ khrid dus dmigs skor gcig dang chos thun re la nyi shu rtsa re bya/

Vajrasattva Heruka says, “Child of good family, your obscurations are purified,” melts into light, and dissolves into the top of your head. Rest in the state in which [your guru’s] mind and your mind are nondual. Dedicate. Include the mixings and equalizing of tastes. On a regular basis, do this at the beginning and end of sessions. When giving instructions, do one cycle of visualization, and with each dharma session, do it twenty-one times.
de ltar byas pas sgrib pa dag / dam tshig sor chud pa'i rtags rab zhal mthong / 'bring ting nge 'dzin skye/ mngon shes 'char (493)ba/ bla mas chos gsungs pa/ / dbang bskur ba la sogs 'byung / /

Through doing this, your obscurations are purified. The signs of restoring samayas are as follows: Those of highest abilities will see the face [of Vajrasattva]. {493} Those of intermediate abilities will give rise to samādhi, develop supercognitive abilities, experience their guru teaching the dharma, receive abhiṣekas, and so forth.

tha ma rmi lam khyad par can/ / 'ja' tshon skas la 'dzeg pa dang / / nyi zla shar dang ri mthor 'dzeg / mi nag khyi nag bsad pa dang / / rnag khrag 'dzag dang ngan skyugs 'thon/ / gos dkar gon dang gru gzings gtor/ / dge sbyor la yang ngang gis 'jug / 'jig rten chos la blo ldog pa/ / zhes sogs rtags rnams 'byung ngo / /

Those of normal abilities will have exceptional dreams, such as of climbing rainbow stairs, the sun and moon rising, climbing high mountains, slaying evil people and evil dogs, pus and blood oozing, vomiting foul substances, wearing white clothing, steering boats, naturally engaging in spiritual practices, and turning away from worldly values. Thus it is said. Those and other signs will arise.
yi ge brgya pa'i rnal 'byor /
[This completes] the yoga of the hundred syllables.[54] ithi
dmangs phal pa phrin las mthun sbyor
3. The People: The Conducive Activities

['di] la bdun/ bza' ba zas kyi rnal 'byor/ bgo ba gos kyi rnal 'byor/ nyal ba gnyid kyi rnal 'byor/ 'gro 'dug bskor ba'i rnal 'byor/ bkru ba khrus kyi rnal 'byor/ gsol 'debs maN+Dal gyi rnal 'byor/ tshogs gsog chos spyod kyi rnal 'byor ro/ /

This has seven parts: (1) the yoga of eating food; (2) the yoga of wearing clothes; (3) the yoga of sleeping; (4) the yoga of going, sitting, and circumambulating; (5) the yoga of bathing; (6) the yoga of supplications and maṇḍala offerings; and (7) the yoga of amassing the accumulations and dharma activities.
dang po bza' ba zas kyi rnal 'byor
a. The Yoga of Eating Food

['di] la gsum ste/ tha mas sems gsum sngon du song nas lhar gsal btab/ spyi bor bka' brgyud bla ma/ snying gar 'khor lo sdom pa/ yan lag tshigs la mkha' 'gro chos skyong srung ma ba spu'i bu gar rdo rje'i spun rnams dmigs te/ bza' btung gang yang rung ba rnams/ oM AHhU~M gis bdud rtsir bsgom la lag pa g.yon pas longs spyod/ de thams cad mnyes par bsam/ lhag ma la bdud rtsir rang la bstim la gzhan la sbyin no/ /

There are three approaches. Those of normal abilities begin with the threefold intention. Visualize yourself as a deity with the Kagyu gurus on top of your head; Cakrasaṃvara at your heart; the ḍākinīs, dharma protectors, and guardians in your limbs and joints; and your vajra siblings in your pores. Meditate that whatever food or drink you consume becomes amṛta by means of oṃ āḥ hūṃ. Partaking of it with your left hand, think that all those [gurus and deities] are pleased. Sprinkle the remainder on yourself as amṛta, and also give it to others.[55]
'bring gis lha ru bden 'dzin dang bral ba sgyu ma lta bu'i ngang du za/ rab chos nyid ngang nas ma bcos pa'i klong du rol lo/ / dper na zas gter dang 'dra ste/ zhim mi zhim gyi rtogs pa med pa'o/ /

Those of intermediate abilities eat while being a deity, free from any reification, like an illusion. Those of the highest abilities enjoy [food and drink] in an uncontrived expanse, within dharmatā. This is like, for example, a treasure trove of food—it has no notion of being delicious or not.

snyan brgyud kyi sgor zhugs nas zas kyi rnal 'byor ma chags par bya'o/ / de ltar rgyun du byas pas bza' btung thams cad tshogs 'khor du song / dpa' bo mkha' 'gro mnyes/ bar chad zhi/ mthun (494)rkyen phun sum tshogs pa 'grub/ byin rlabs myur ba'o/ //

Once you have entered the door of the Aural Transmission, you must practice the yoga of food consistently. By doing so on a regular basis, all food and drink becomes a gaṇacakra, the heroes and ḍākinīs are pleased, obstacles are pacified, excellent conducive circumstances are achieved, and blessings come swiftly.[56] {494} ithi
bgo ba gos kyi rnal 'byor ni/
b. The Yoga of Wearing Clothes

sems bskyed dang ldan pas/ gos rgyan ske rags zhwa l+h+wam la sogs pa gon tshad kyi dus su rang lhar gsal gdab/ na bza' dang rgyan phreng du gsal gdab la 'bul/ ngag tu oM spar+she AHhU~M zhes brjod/ gsar pa yin na rtsa sngags lan gsum bzlas nas btab pas byin rlabs 'byung / dang po nas lha la dmigs pas tshogs rdzogs/ gon dus lag pa g.yon pas sngon la gyon/ de ltar dus rgyun du bya/ gos gyon tshad byang chub kyi lam du 'gro'o/ / dar zab la sogs pa 'dod yon la longs spyod pa dang / ngo tsha dang khrel yod tshul khrims kyi gos dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ /

Having aroused bodhicitta, whenever you are wearing something, be it clothing, ornaments, belts, hats, boots, and so on, visualize yourself as a deity. Visualize [your clothing] as the garments and ornaments [of the deity] and offer them. With your speech, recite oṃ sparśe āḥ hūṃ. If it is something new, fold it while reciting the root mantra three times, thus consecrating it. To begin with, by visualizing a deity, you perfect the accumulations. When putting on clothes, start dressing with your left hand. Do that on a regular basis. Whatever clothing you wear will be part of the path to awakening. Your enjoyment of the sense pleasures, such as fine silks, will be the wearing of the clothes of integrity, consideration, and ethical conduct.[57]
nyal ba gnyid kyi rnal 'byor
c. The Yoga of Sleeping

['di] la gsum ste/ sems bskyed byas/ rab 'od gsal/ 'bring sgyu lus/ tha ma lha skur nyal ba'o/ / dang po 'od gsal du nyal ba la spros bcas spros med gnyis las/ spros bcas ni/ snod bcud dkyil 'khor du gsal gdab/ snod bcud la thim/ bcud kyi lha rnams rang la/ rang thugs ka'i ba~M la/ ba~M zla tshes la/ de nA da la/ de 'od du zhu/ rjes mi rtog pa'i ngang la nyal lo/ / spros med skad cig gis stong pa'i ngang du nyal lo/ /

There are three approaches. Arouse bodhicitta. Those of highest abilities sleep in luminosity, those of intermediate abilities as an illusory form, and those of normal abilities as the form of a deity. First, to sleep in luminosity, there are two styles: with elaborations and without elaborations. With elaborations is as follows: Visualize the environment and its inhabitants as a maṇḍala. The environment dissolves into its inhabitants. The deities, who are the inhabitants, dissolve into you. You dissolve into the vaṃ in your heart, the vaṃ into its crescent, that into nāda, and that melts into light. Then, go to sleep in a nonconceptual state. The unelaborate way is to fall asleep in a state of emptiness instantly.

'bring sgyu lus su nyal ba la/ spros bcas spros med gnyis las spros bcas ni/ snang ba thams cad rmi lam sgyu ma yin snyams pa'i ngang nas g.yas 'og tu phab la nyal/ spros med ni/ sgyu ma mi bden bzhin snang ba yin snyam du bsam la nyal/

Those of intermediate abilities fall asleep as an illusory form. This has two styles: with elaborations and without elaborations. With elaborations is as follows: Lying on your right side and thinking, “All appearances are dreams and illusions,” go to sleep. Without elaborations is to fall asleep contemplating the thought, “Illusions are not real, and yet they appear.”

tha ma lha skur nyal ba la/ spros bcas spros med gnyis las/ spros bcas ni/ rje btsun ma'i bskyed rim sgom pa'i ngang du nyal/ spros med ni/ skad cig gis lhar bltas te snang la rang bzhin med pa'i ngang du nyal/

Those of normal abilities go to sleep as the form of a deity. This is done in two ways: with elaborations and without elaborations. With elaborations is to fall asleep while meditating upon the generation process of the Jetsunma. Without elaborations is to see the deity in an instant and to go to sleep in a state where she appears but lacks any nature.
gnyid sad pa'i dus su DA ma ru'i sgras gnyid sad par bsam mo/ / (495) dang po 'od gsal lam gang rung la bzhag pa de'i ngang la bzhag / bsre ba ro snyoms rnal 'byor bdun char la sbyar bar bya'o/ /

When you wake up, think that the sound of ḍamarus is waking you up. {495} First, remain in the state of luminosity or whatever state you rest in. Apply the mixings and equalizing of tastes to all seven yogas.

'di dus rgyun du ma chag par bya/ khrid dus dmigs skor gcig / de ltar nyams su blangs pas mtshan mo gnyid pas kyang 'chi ba skyong / rmi lam gyis bar do sbyong / snga dro sad pas skye ba sbyong / gnyid kyis gti mug 'gags/ / rmi lam gyis 'dod chags 'gags/ / sad pas zhe sngags 'gas/ nyal tshad byang chub kyi lam du 'gro'o/ /

This [yoga of sleep] should be done on a regular basis [when you are falling asleep]. When giving instructions, do one cycle of visualization. By practicing in that way, sleeping at night is training for death. Dreaming is training for the bardos. Waking up in the morning is training for taking birth. Sleep stops bewilderment, dreams stop desire, and waking stops aggression. All your sleep will take you along the path to awakening.[58]
'gro 'dug bskor ba'i rnal 'byor ni/
d. The Yoga of Going, Sitting, and Circumambulating

sems bskyed bya/ ring ba lo zla nas/ thung ba chu len pa'i 'gro lam tshun thams cad du rkang pa g.yon pa sngon la dor te shes rab mtshan/ g.yas pa thabs/ lam zung 'jug mtshon nas/ / 'gro ba de o rgyan nam/ bla ma yi dam gyi drung du 'gro bar bsam ste/ tshur ldog dus kyang de bzhin no/ /

Arouse bodhicitta. During all your goings and comings—which, from the longest point of view, means years and months, or it means short periods, such as fetching water—think that putting your left foot down first symbolizes prajñā, that your right symbolizes method, and that the path symbolizes unification. When you are going somewhere, think that you are going to Oḍḍiyāna or into the presence of your gurus and yidams. When you are returning, do the same thing.

'di rgyun du 'gro 'ong byad tshad lam brjed par bya'o/ / de ltar byas pas 'khrul pa 'gro 'ong gi rnam rtog tha mal pa 'gags/ mtshan bltas bla ma'i spyan sngar phyin pa dang / zhal mthong ba la sogs 'byung / 'gro 'dug thams cad byang chub kyi lam du 'gro'o/ /

Do this on a regular basis whenever you are going and coming without forgetting. Doing so will stop your ordinary thoughts about confused goings and comings. You will see signs, such as going into your guru’s presence, seeing their face, and so on. All your goings and sitting will take you along the path to awakening.[59]
bkru ba khrus kyi rnal 'byor ni/
e. The Yoga of Bathing

sems bskyed bya/ rigs lnga yab yum sku mdog ser po gsal ba rus pa'i rgyan can/ g.yas rdo rje la sogs pa'i phyag mtshan so so/ / g.yon dril bu bsnams pa spyi bor byon/ mchod pa phul/ gsol ba btab pas yum rnams kyi phyag gi thod pa'i bdud rtsi'i rgyun lud pas sgo gsum gyi dri ma dag par bsams la yi ge brgya pa brjod cing khrus bya/ de nas rigs lnga mi bskyod pa la thim/ de rang la thim/ de nas g.yas mchog sbyin gyi phyag rgyas/ oM ba~M swA hA zhes chu sbyin byas nas/ rigs drug gi sgrib pa dag nas sdug bsngal dang (496)bral/ bde ba dang ldan par gyur cig ces brjod/ don yid la bsam/

Arouse bodhicitta. Visualize the five families [of buddhas], male and female consorts, yellow in color and with bone ornaments. They hold their own emblems, such as a vajra, in their right hands and ghaṇṭās in their left. They come to the top of your head. Present offerings and make supplications. Imagine that the amṛta within the skull cups held by the female consorts overflows and purifies the stains of your three doors. Recite the hundred syllables, and be bathed. Then, the five families dissolve into Akṣobhya, who dissolves into you. Next, make the mudrā of supreme generosity with your right hand and, saying oṃ vaṃ svāhā, make a gift of water. {496} Say, “Having purified the obscurations of the six classes of beings, may they be free from sufferings and be happy,” and contemplate that meaning.

chu khyor par cung zad blug ste/ oM AHhU~M brjod nas rang gis 'thung bas zhag gcig gi bsrung bar 'gyur/ de 'grub na nyin re bzhin dngos su bya/ ma grub na ting nge 'dzin bya'o/ / de ltar byas pas sdig sgrib nyams chags dag / mi gtsang ba mkhon grib la sogs pa sel/ nad gdon gyi bar chad mi 'byung / rig pa dwangs/ ting nge 'dzin gsal lo/ / khrus byas tshad byang chub kyi lam du 'gro'o/ /

Pour a small amount of water into your cupped hands. Saying oṃ āh hūṃ, drink that and you will be protected for one day. If you can, do it actually every day. If you cannot do that, do it through samādhi. Doing this will purify your negative actions, obscurations, and impaired and broken [samayas]. It will dispel uncleanliness, contamination through enmity, and so forth. Obstacles related to illnesses or spirits will not occur. Your awareness will be brilliant and your samādhi clear. All bathing you do will take you along the path to awakening.[60]
gsol 'debs maN+Dal gyi rnal 'byor
f. The Yoga of Supplications and Maṇḍala Offerings
['di] la gnyis te/ sgrub pa'i dang / mchod pa'i maN+Dal lo/ /
This has two parts: (1) the maṇḍala for practice and (2) the maṇḍala for offerings.
dang po ni
First, the maṇḍala for practice.
rgyu rin po che las byas pa/ 'byor na khru skor/ ma 'byor na sor bzhi yan chad kha khyer mtho ba/ yid du 'ong ba/ gas chag dang rdol bug med pa tshags byas la/ legs par phyis te/

It should be made of precious substances. If you have the means, it should be a cubit in circumference. If you cannot afford that, it should be at least four fingerbreadths in circumference and height. It should be pleasing. Check that it is without cracks or holes. Rub it well.

dkyil du srin lag g.yon pa bzhag la/ ngag tu oM badzra big+h+nA na ta kr-i ta AHhU~M/ zhes pas bgegs bsal/ oM badzra re khe AHhU~M/ brjod pas zhing khams rnams par dag pa rin po che las grub pa yangs shing rgya che bar bsam/ de'i dkyil du me tog gi tshom bu lag pa g.yas kyis bzhag pas/ seng ge'i khri nyi zla pad+ma'i gdan steng na hU~M ba~M las ngo bo bla ma/ rnam pa bde mchog yab yum du bsam mdun nas me tog phyogs g.yas bskor du/ mA~M lA~M pA~M tA~M/ bzhi bkod/ lha mo bzhi ru bsam/ de la mchod pa'i maN+Dal la sogs pa 'bul/ bla ma yi dam mkha' 'gro chos skyong sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis bdag la rtogs pa khyad par can rgyud la skye bar byin gyis brlab tu gsol ces gsol ba btab/ lha mo rnams bla ma la thim/ bla ma rang la thim/ rjes phyag rgya chen po'i ngang la bzhag / bsre ba ro snyoms sbyar/

In the middle, place your left ring finger, and saying oṃ vajra vighnāntakṛt āḥ hūṃ, dispel the obstructors. Saying oṃ vajrarekhe āh hūṃ, think that it becomes a pure land, vast and spacious, made of precious jewels. In the middle, with your right hand, place piles of flowers. Imagine a lion throne, on top of which are sun, moon, and lotus seats. Above those, from hūṃ and vaṃ, appear the essence of your guru in the manifestation of Saṃvara male and female consorts. In front of them, arrange flowers clockwise as the four: māṃ, lāṃ, pāṃ, and tāṃ. Imagine they are the four goddesses. Present offering maṇḍalas and so forth to them. Supplicate, “Gurus, yidams, ḍākinīs, dharma protectors, buddhas, and bodhisattvas: please bless me that exceptional realizations arise in my mindstream.” The goddesses dissolve into the gurus, and the gurus dissolve into you. Then rest in mahāmudrā. Include the mixings and equalizing of tastes.
me tog thad kar ma song nyan thos kyi pham ltung phog pas thu pa ma gud par bya/
Since if the flowers are not straight, you will commit the śrāvaka defeats and downfalls, do not make things worse.
gnyis pa mchod pa'i maN+Dal ni/
Second, the maṇḍala for offerings.

rgyu rin po che las byas pa ni gong dang 'dra/ gnyis (497) med na gong gi lha tshogs bar snang la btegs par dmigs te/ maN+Dal phyis la/ 'byung po me long gdong can gyi bar chad bsrung ste/ g.yon gyi srin lag gis lan gsum bskor la/ oM AHbig+h+nA na a nu g+hA ta hU~M phaT/ ces bgegs bskrad/ oM badzra b+hU mi AHhU~M/ ces pas gser gyi sa gzhi lag mthil ltar mnyam par gyur/ oM badzra su re khe AHhU~M ces pas rin po che'i lcags ris bskor bar bsam/ de nas lag pa g.yas kyis tshom bu g.yon bskor du bkod la/ bcu gcig gam/ bcu dgu'am/ sum cu so bdun la sogs pa bkod/ ngag tu brjod cing don bsam pa ni/

It should be made from precious substances, as above. {497} If you do not have two [maṇḍala plates], visualize that the above assembly of deities resides in the surrounding space. Rub the maṇḍala. To prevent the obstacles of the bhūta Ādarśamukha, circle three times with your left ring finger, and saying oṃ āḥ vighnān anughāta hūṃ phaṭ, dispel obstructors. Saying oṃ vajra bhūmi āḥ hūṃ, imagine that [the maṇḍala] becomes a golden ground, smooth like the palm of your hand. Saying oṃ varja surekhe āh hūṃ, imagine the surrounding precious iron mountains. Then, with your right hand, arrange the piles counterclockwise: arrange eleven, nineteen, thirty-seven, or the like. Verbally recite, and mentally contemplate, the following:

ri'i rgyal po ri rab/ shar lus 'phags po/ lho dzam+bu gling / nub ba glang spyod/ byang sgra mi snyan/ gling bzhi/ gling phran brgyad/ nyi ma/ zla ba/ 'khor lo rin po che/ nor bu rin po che/ btsun mo rin po che/ blon po rin po che/ glang po rin po che/ rta mchog rin po che/ dmag dpon rin po che/ bkra shis kyi gdugs dang / gser gyi nya dang / pad+ma dang / bum pa dang / dung dang / dpal be'u dang / rgyal mtshan dang / 'khor lo dang / gser gyi ri bdun/ rol pa'i mtsho bdun/ me tog gi skyed mo'i tshal/ lha mi'i dpal 'byor bdag pos yongs su ma bzung ba dang bcas pa thams cad ltos med du phul la/ bdag gi lus dang longs spyod dge tshogs bcas/ / bla ma rgyal ba sras bcas rnams la 'bul/ / thugs rjes 'gro ba'i don du bzhes nas kyang / / bdag gzhan smin cing grol bar mdzad du gsol/ ces brjod/

Mount Meru, the sovereign of mountains, the four continents—Pūrvavideha in the east, Jambudvīpa in the south, Aparagodānīya in the west, Uttarakuru in the north—the eight subcontinents, the sun, moon, the precious cakra, the precious jewel, the precious queen, the precious minister, the precious elephant, the precious supreme horse, the precious general, the auspicious parasol, the golden fish, a lotus, vase, conch, the glorious knot, victory banner, cakra, the seven golden mountains, the seven lakes for pleasure, the gardens of flowers, the wealth and enjoyments of gods, along with all the things that are not owned by anyone—I offer it all without any concerns. I offer my body, possessions, and accumulated virtue to the gurus, victors, and their sons and daughters. Having accepted it with compassion for the sake of all beings, please mature and liberate me and others.
khrid du dmigs skor gnyis bya/ chos thun re re la lan re 'bul/ sgrub pa'i dus su grangs med/ rgyun du nyi ma re la lan gsum ma chags par bya'o/ / dngos su ma 'byor na ting nge 'dzin gyis 'bul/

When giving instructions, do two cycles of visualization. Offer it once for each dharma session. During sādhana[pūjās], offer it countless times. On a regular basis, offer it three times every day, consistently. If you do not have any actual means, offer it through samādhi. {498}

de ltar byas pas rtags rmi lam du rin po che'i thang la phyin pa dang / rin po che (498)dang 'bru'i char babs pa dang / dpa' bo mkha' 'gros thod pa rdzas kyis bkang ba ster ba la sogs 'byung ngo / / dngos su 'khor dang dpal 'byor phun sum tshogs pa lo zlas 'grub/ gnas skabs su mtho ris kyi bde 'bras thob ting nge 'dzin khyad par can rgyud la skye/ / sangs rgyas pa'i dus su zhing khams dang mdzad pa rnam par dag pa 'byung / bsre ba ro snyoms sbyar ro/ /

Through doing this, there will arise signs such as having dreams of going to plains of jewels, of rains of jewels and grains falling, or being given skull cups filled with substances by heroes and ḍākinīs. In actuality, you will have an abundance of wealth and a retinue within a year or months. On a temporal basis, you will achieve the results of the happiness of the higher states, and exceptional samādhi will arise in your mindstream. When you are a buddha, buddha fields and pure activity will occur. Apply the mixings and equalizing of tastes.[61]
tshogs gsog chos spyod kyi rnal 'byor ni/
g. The Yoga of Amassing the Accumulations and Dharma Activities

skyabs 'gro sems bskyed sngon du 'gro bas/ mdun du dbus su rin po che sna bdun las grub pa'i khri bang rim bdun dang ldan pa yangs shing rgya che ba gcig bsam/ mdun du shel gyi khri/ g.yas su gser gyi khri/ rgyab tu bye ru'i khri dmar po/ g.yon du g.yu'i khri sngon po re re bsam/

Begin by taking refuge and arousing bodhicitta. In front of you, in the middle, imagine a throne made from the seven kinds of jewels with seven levels, vast and spacious. In front there is a crystal throne; to the right, a gold throne; behind, a red coral throne; and to the left, a blue turquoise throne.

rang gi thugs ka nas 'od 'phros/ bla ma bka' brgyud rnams byon/ khri dbus mar bzhugs/ yang 'od 'phros yi dam lha tshogs spyan drangs mdun du bzhugs/ yang 'od 'phros dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas dang / 'jig rten na bzhugs pa'i sku'i rten lugs su blugs pa/ ri mor bris pa/ 'bur du 'dod pa thams cad g.yas su bzhugs/ chos dkon mchog glegs bam la sogs rgyab tu bzhugs/ yang 'od 'phros/ dge 'dun dkon mchog grangs med pa snam sbyar chos gos gsol ba spyan drangs g.yon du bzhugs/ de dag gi mthar dpa' bo mkha' 'gro chos skyong dang rdo rje'i spun rnams kyis bskor bar dmigs la spyan drangs pa ni/ /

Light radiates from your heart. The Kagyu gurus come and sit on the middle throne. Again light radiates, inviting the assembly of yidam deities, who sit on the front throne. Again light radiates, and the buddhas of the three times and all the representations of [awakened] body residing in the world—those that are poured castings, those that are drawn as pictures, and those that are carved—sit on the right throne. The jewel of the dharma, such as the volumes of texts, sit on the rear throne. Again light radiates, inviting the limitless jewel of the saṅgha, who, wearing the saṃghāṭis and cīvaras, sit on the left throne. Outside of all of them, visualize that they are surrounded by heroes, ḍākinīs, dharma protectors, and vajra siblings. To invite them, say:
chos dbyings rnam dag gzhal yas nas/ / bla ma yi dam lha tshogs rnams/ / sngon gyi thugs dam brtser dgongs la/ / 'gro ba'i don du gnas 'dir gshegs/ /
From the palace of the pure dharmadhātu, gurus and assembly of yidam deities, consider your previous commitments and kindness, and for the sake of beings, please come here.
oM ma hA gu ru sarba ta thA ga ta shrI tsakra sam+b+ha ra badzra yo gi ni wI ra DA ki nI badzra A ral+li hoHdzaHhU~M ba~M hoHsa ma ya s+t+waM tri sh+ya hoH
oṃ mahāguru sarvatathāgata śrīcakrasambhara vajrayogini vīra ḍākinī vajra ārali hoḥ jaḥ hūṃ vaṃ hoḥ samayastvaṃ triśya hoḥ
mdzes shing yid 'ong gzhal yas khang / / rin chen sna tshogs seng ge'i khri/ / chu skyes nyi zla'i gdan steng du/ / dges shing brtan par bzhugs su gsol/ /
In a beautiful and pleasing palace, on a lion throne made of various jewels, on seats of a water-born, sun, and moon, please sit firmly with delight.
oM ma hA gu ru sarba ta thA ga ta shrI tsakra sam+b+ha ra badzra yo gI nI wi ra DA ki ni/
oṃ mahāguru sarvatathāgata śrīcakrasambhara vajrayogīnī vīra ḍākinī
de la phyi nang gsang ba de kho na nyid kyis mchod nas/
Having presented them with the outer, inner, secret, and suchness offerings, say:
pad+ma ka ma lA ya s+t+waM/
padma kamalāyastvaṃ {499}

de la phyi nang gsang ba de kho na nyid kyis (499)mchod pas sa gzhi bar snang thams cad gang bas lus longs spyod dang / nyams dang rtogs pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad ltos med du rim pa bzhin du phul bar dmigs la/ yan lag bdun pa 'bul ba ni/

Having presented them with the outer, inner, secret, and suchness offerings, the ground and surrounding space are completely filled. Visualize that you offer your body, possessions, experiences and realizations, and all your roots of virtue in sequence and with no concerns. Offer the sevenfold service:
chos sku spros bral ngang nyid las/ / sna tshogs gzugs kyi skur ston pa'i/ / bla ma rgyal ba sras bcas la/ / sgo gsum gus pas phyag 'tshal lo/ /
To the gurus, victors, and their sons and daughters, who display myriad form kāyas within the dharmakāya, freedom from elaborations, I respectfully pay homage with my three doors.
rab 'byams zhing khams thams cad na/ / me tog bdug spos mar me dri/ / zhal zas rol mo mchod pa'i tshogs/ / bla ma dkyil 'khor lha la 'bul/ /
To the gurus and deities of the maṇḍalas, I present collections of offerings: all the flowers, incense, lamps, scents, food, and music within the infinite pure realms.
'phan dang ba dan rgyal mtshan dang / / phye ma'i phur ma gdugs dang ni/ / bla bre dar dbyangs bkod pa'i tshogs/ / bla ma dkyil 'khor lha la 'bul/ /
To the gurus and deities of the maṇḍalas, I present collections of arrangements: pendants, flags, victory banners, incense powders, parasols, canopies, and silk ribbons.
rin chen snod mdzes gzhal yas khang / / rin chen gyis bkang mchod pa'i tshogs/ / ma lus blo yis blangs nas kyang / / bla ma dkyil 'khor lha la 'bul/ /
To the gurus and deities of the maṇḍalas, I present collections of offerings: beautiful jeweled vessels, and palaces, filled with jewels— all brought to mind.
kun 'byung sdug bsngal skyed byed pa'i/ / shes rab mig bral bdag lus 'di/ / bran g.yog bzhin du dmigs nas kyang / / bla ma dkyil 'khor lha la 'bul/ /
To the gurus and deities of the maṇḍalas, I offer my own body, visualized to be like a servant, even though it lacks the eye of wisdom and is a source of suffering.
sha lnga bdud rtsi lnga rnams ni/ / rigs lnga ye shes lnga yi dngos/ / dug lnga sel ba'i thabs mchog ni/ / bla ma dkyil 'khor lha la 'bul/ /
To the gurus and deities of the maṇḍalas, I offer the supreme methods for dispelling the five poisons: the five meats and five amṛtas, the substances of the five families and five wisdoms.
yab yum thabs shes gnyis su med/ / bde stong gnyis med rol nga yi/ / zag med bde chen mchod pa'i tshogs/ / bla ma dkyil 'khor lha la 'bul/ /

To the gurus and deities of the maṇḍalas, I present collections of offerings: the undefiled great bliss of the play of nondual bliss and emptiness, the nondual male and female consorts, method and prajñā.
bde dang gsal dang mi rtog pa/ / snang stong zung 'jug phyag rgya che/ / rang bzhin rnam dag mchod pa 'di/ / bla ma dkyil 'khor lha la 'bul/ /
To the gurus and deities of the maṇḍalas, I present this naturally pure offering: mahāmudrā, the unification of appearances and emptiness, bliss, clarity, and nonconceptuality.
sdig bgyis bgyid rtsal rjes yi rangs/ / phyin chad bgyid par 'gyur ba yi/ / chos 'gal nyes pa ci mchis pa/ / de ring nyid du bdag bshags so/ /
Today I confess any negativity I have done, am doing, request, or rejoice in, and any wrongdoings that contradict the dharma I may do in the future.
so so skye bo nyan rang dang / / byang sems sangs rgyas sras bcas kyi/ / dus gsum nyid du bgyis pa yi/ / dge la rjes su yid rang ngo / /
I rejoice in all virtue done throughout the three times by ordinary beings, śrāvakas, bodhisattvas, buddhas, and their sons and daughters.
bla ma rgyal ba sras bcas rnams/ / sems can kun (500)gyi don gyi phyir/ / chos kyi 'khor lo 'od 'bar ba/ / mun pa bsal phyir bskor du gsol/ /
dri med rgyal ba chos kyi ni/ / spyan can mang na chen po las/ / 'da' bar bzhed pa khyed rnams kyang / / 'gro ba'i don du rtag tu bzhugs/ /
I request all the flawless victors with the eyes of dharma, who are considering passing into great nirvāṇa, to remain continually for the sake of beings.
bdag gzhan kun gyi dus gsum du/ / bsags pa'i dge ba ji snyed des/ / bdag dang mtha' yas sems can rnams/ / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas myur thob shog
May I and all infinite sentient beings, through whatever virtue we have accumulated in the three times, either by ourselves or by others, swiftly attain complete buddhahood.
ces brjod/ de rjes sdom pa bzung / dbang blang ba la sogs pa yang bya/
After that, take the vows, receive the abhiṣekas, and so forth.
'di khrid dus dmigs skor gcig yin/ dus rgyun du nyin re la lan re ma chags par bya'o/ /
When giving instructions, do one cycle of visualization. On a regular basis, do this once every day, consistently.

de ltar byas pas sdig pa nyams chags 'dag / lha mi thams cad tshogs gnyis zung du rdzogs/ / skye ba nas skye ba 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po thob/ / mthar thug rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas thob par 'gyur ro/ /

Doing so will purify your negative actions and impaired and broken [samayas]; perfect the two accumulations of gods and humans; enable you, in birth after birth, to be a cakravartin; and finally to achieve complete buddhahood.[62]

bum dbang dang 'brel bskyed pa'i rim/ / thun mong yid bzhin nor bu 'di/ / bla ma mkha' 'gro'i gsung bzhin du/ / gnya' nang grod phug dgon pa ru/ / rdo rje rgyal mtshan brtse bas bkod/ / phyogs dus bde legs ldan gyur cig /

These Shared Wish-Fulfilling Gems, the generation processes connected to the vase abhiṣeka, were recorded according to the teachings of the guru and Ḍākinī at the hermitage of Drö Puk in Nyanang by Dorje Gyaltsen with love. May all directions and times be filled with goodness.[63]
rje mi la ras pas ras chung rdo rje grags pa la gtad pa rdzogs so// // //
This completes what the exalted Milarepa entrusted to Rechung Dorje Drakpa.
May there be virtue.
@#/ /bde mchog snyan brgyud kyi rdzogs rim steng sgo rnam par grol ba'i chos drug gi khrid yig bzhugs so// //
32. The Instruction Manual on the Six Dharmas, Which Liberate through the Upper Door. The Perfection Process of the Saṃvara Aural Transmission[1]
(502)@#/ /na mo gu ru de ba DA ki nI/ /
namo guru deva ḍākinī

gsang dbang dang 'brel ba steng sgo rnam par grol ba'i lam la drug ste/ / gtum mo bde drod rang 'bar lam gyi gzhung shing dang / / sgyu lus chos brgyad rang grol dang / / rmi lam 'khrul pa rang sangs dang / / 'od gsal ma rig mun bral dang / / 'pho ba gser 'gyur gyi rtsi dang / / grong 'jug sprul lpags 'dor byed do/ /

The path connected to the secret abhiṣeka, which liberates through the upper door, has six parts: (1) caṇḍālī: the main beam of the path of self-blazing bliss and heat; (2) illusory forms: the self-liberating of the eight worldly values; (3) dreams: the self-clarifying of delusion; (4) luminosity: freedom from the darkness of ignorance; (5) transference: the elixir for the transformation into gold; and (6) entering a body: shedding a snake’s skin.[5]
dang po
I. Caṇḍālī: The Main Beam of the Path of Self-Blazing Bliss and Heat
['di] la lnga ste/ gtum mo'i dbye ba dang / byed las dang / chos mtshungs dpe dang sbyar ba dang / rgyu mtshan dang / spar thabs so/ /
This has five parts: (1) classifications, (2) functions, (3) correlating examples and similar qualities, (4) reasons, and (5) methods for increasing caṇḍālī.[6]
dang po
A. Classifications
['di] la bzhi ste/ phyi dang / nang dang / gsang ba dang / de kho na nyid kyi gtum mo'o/ /
There are four classifications: (1) the outer, (2) inner, (3) secret, and (4) suchness caṇḍālīs.[7]
byed las ni/
B. Functions

phyi'i gtum mos gdon stong phrag brgyad cu 'joms/ nang gi gtum mos nad rigs bzhi brgya rtsa bzhi 'joms/ gsang ba'i gtum mos nyon mongs pa brgyad khri bzhi stong 'joms/ de kho na nyid kyi gtum mos rang la yod pa'i lhan skyes kyi ye shes ngo sprod pa'o/ /

Outer caṇḍālī conquers the eighty thousand kinds of spirits. Inner caṇḍālī overcomes the four hundred and four types of disease. Secret caṇḍālī subdues the eighty-four thousand mental afflictions. Suchness caṇḍālī points out the connate wisdom present within you.[8]
chos mtshungs dpe dang sbyar ba ni/
C. Correlating Examples and Similar Qualities

phyi'i gtum mo me dang chos mtshungs te/ me'i nang du shing gcig bskyur kyang sreg la/ brgya bsgyur kyang sreg / de bzhin du gdon gcig gnod kyang sreg la/ brgya (503) gnod kyang sreg go / nang gi gtum mo sman dang chos mtshungs te/ sman pa mkhas pas sman btang na nad sel ba bzhin gtum mo bsgoms pas nad sel ba'o/ / gsang ba'i gtum mo seng ge dang chos mtshungs te/ seng ges ri dwags thams cad zil gyis mnan pa bzhin du/ gtum mo bsgoms pas nyon mongs pa thams cad zil gyis mnan pa'o/ / de kho na nyid kyi gtum mo me long dang mtshungs te/ me long g.ya' dag pa la bltas na rang gi bzhin mthong ba bzhin du/ gtum mo bsgoms pas rang gi sangs rgyas kyi ye shes gsal lam me mthong nas a pa de ru 'dug pa la sngar ngo ma shes 'dug snyam pa cig 'byung ba'o/
rgyu mtshan ni/
D. Reasons

nges tshig yin te/ gtum bya ba ni spang bya 'joms pa la zer te/ dper na go mtshon thogs pa'i dpa' bo gcig gis sdar ma'i dmag dpung 'joms pa bzhin nyon mongs rnam rtog gdon bgegs 'joms pa la dpa' zhing gtum pas na gtum zhes bya/

The etymology[*1] [of the term caṇḍālī (Tib. tummo, gtum mo)] is as follows: “Fierce” (gtum) means that it destroys the objects to be abandoned. For example, a single courageous person wearing armor and wielding weapons can conquer a terrified army. Similarly, this is called “fierce” because it is courageous and fierce in conquering mental afflictions, thoughts, spirits, and obstructors.

mo zhes bya ba ni yon tan bskyed pa la zer te/ dper na dpal che ba'i bu mo mdzes ma cig la khye'u phun sum tshogs pa cig skyes na 'jig (504)rten gyi bde 'bras skyed pa bzhin mchog thun mong thams cad 'di las bskyed pas mo zhes bya'o/ /

Its feminine ending (mo) indicates that it generates excellent qualities. {504} An analogy is when an extraordinary woman gives birth to an exceptional child that brings happiness in the world as a result. Similarly, this is referred to with a feminine ending (mo) because it brings all supreme and common [results].
grangs nges ni/ /
Numerical certainty.

bzhir nges te de bas nyung na mi 'du ste/ phyi'i med na gdon mi sel/ nang gi med na nad mi sel/ gsang ba'i med na nyon mongs mi chom/ de kho na nyid med na ye shes mi 'phrod/ de bas mang na don med de/ gdon bzhi/ nad bzhi/ nyon mongs pa bzhi/ ye shes bzhi ngo 'phrod nas/ khur bor sangs rgyas pa yin te/ dper na chur thon pa la gru mi dgos pa bzhin/ gtum mo rang yang bsgom mi dgos so/ /

Caṇḍālī is definitely of four types. If there were less than that, it would not be complete. If its external mode is absent, spirits are not vanquished. If its internal form is not present, disease is not prevented. If its secret mode is absent, the mental afflictions will not be conquered. If its suchness is not included, wisdom is not met. It would also be pointless for there to be more than that. Having pacified spirits, diseases, and the mental afflictions, and having recognized wisdom, you discard your burdens and awaken. An analogy is once you get out of the water, you do not need a boat. Similarly, you do not need to cultivate caṇḍālī again.[10]
gtum mo'i sbar thabs
E. Methods for Increasing Caṇḍālī
['di] la gsum ste/ sbyor ba/ dngos gzhi/ rjes gsum mo/ /
This has three parts: (1) the preparation, (2) the main practices, and (3) the conclusion.
sbyor ba
1. The Preparation
['di] la gnad bzhi las/ gsol 'debs byin rlabs kyi gnad/ gegs sel bsnyen pa'i gnad/ mthun sbyor rkyen gyi gnad/ gsang ba dam tshig gi gnad do/ /

This has four vital points: (1) the vital point of supplication and blessings, (2) the vital point of the approach for dispelling hindrances, (3) the vital point of the conditions for the conducive preparations, and (4) the vital point of the secret samayas.
dang po ni/
a. The Vital Point of Supplication and Blessings

bla ma'i rnal 'byor bsgoms la 'dir snyan brgyud byin rlabs kyi lam/ byin rlabs mos gus gsol 'debs kyi lam yin pas gsol ba snying gi dkyil/ rkang gi khong / rus pa'i gding nas mchi ma phyung la/ bde drod ye shes kyi me sbar du gsol/ zhes gsol ba drag tu gdab bo/ /

Guru yoga meditation and, here, the Aural Transmission are a path of blessings. Blessings [rely on the path] of devotion, and [devotion relies on] the path of supplication. Therefore, from the center of your heart, the soles of your feet, the depths of your bones, and with tears, supplicate strongly, “May the fire of wisdom’s bliss and warmth blaze.”[11]
gnyis pa gegs sel bsnyen pa'i gnad la/
b. The Vital Point of the Approach for Dispelling Hindrances

gdon dang / nad dang / nyon mongs pa gsum gyis gegs byas nas gtum mo ngo sprod du mi ster bas bcom ldan 'das ma'i bsnyen pa sum 'bum bzhi khri btang / des gegs las grol nas byin rlabs kyis bde drod 'byung ngo / /

When spirits, sickness, and mental afflictions create hindrances, the pointing out of caṇḍālī cannot be bestowed. Therefore, do the approach of the Bhagavatī three hundred and forty thousand times. That will free you from hindrances, and the blessings will give rise to bliss and heat.[12]
gsum pa mthun sbyor rkyen gyi gnad
c. The Vital Point of the Conditions for the Conducive Preparations
['di] la bdun te/
This has seven parts.
dang po 'dug pa gnas kyi gnad ni
First: the vital points for the place to stay.
nyin mo skye bo'i 'du 'dzis dben/ mtshan mo dgra rkun gyi mel tshes dben/ 'cho ba dang chu shing bsgrub sla ba'o/ /

It should be isolated from the busyness of people during the day; isolated from the spies of your enemies and thieves during the night; and somewhere it is easy to get provisions, water, and fuel.[13]
gnyis pa mthun pa grogs kyi gnad ni/
Second: the vital points for harmonious friends.
dam tshig dang sdom pa srung ba/ lta spyod dang bla ma gcig pa'o/ /
These are those who keep their samaya and vows and who have the same view, conduct, and gurus. {505}
gsum pa bza' ba zas kyi gnad ni/ (505)
Third: the vital points for consuming food.
tshad pa shas che na bsil ba bsten/ grang ba shas che na drod bcud bsten/ rgyun du bcud can nyung ba dang / bdud rtsi lnga la'ang bsten par bya'o/

When it is excessively hot, eat cooling foods, and when it is excessively cold, eat warming, nourishing foods. On a regular basis, minimize your consummation of nourishing [or rich] foods and consume the five amṛtas.[14]
bzhi pa bgo ba gos kyi gnad ni/
Fourth: the vital points for wearing clothes.
dro yang gcer bu mi bya/ grang yang skyi chags mi bgo / mkha' 'gro mnyes byed ras dgos dang mi 'bral ba brtson 'grus kyi lcag yin pas bsgrub par bya/

Even when it is hot, do not go naked. Even when it is cold, do not wear skins. Not being separated from your cotton clothes, which please the ḍākinīs, is the whip of diligence, so practice [wearing only cotton clothing].[15]
lnga pa bde ba mal gyi gnad ni/
Fifth: the vital points for a comfortable seat.
mal sgom thag dang mnyam pa/ mgo sngas la mi 'jog pa'o/ /
Your seat is the same as your meditation belt. Do not put your head on a pillow.
drug pa mi 'bral ba pus 'khyud kyi gnad ni/
Sixth: the vital points of being inseparable from your meditation belt.
nyis bltabs la khru gang sor bzhi pa/ skyes pas rnal 'byor mar bsgoms la bstim/ bud med kyis he ru kar bsgom/ 'jug dus su yab yum khril gyis 'khril bar bsam/ 'gom yug mi gtang /

Folded in half, [the meditation belt] should be a cubit and four fingerbreadths. Men should meditate on it as the Yoginī and that she dissolves there. Women should meditate on it as the Heruka. When wearing it, think that you are held in the male or female consort’s embrace. Do not walk over it.[16]
bdun pa ngal dub med par spyod pa'i lam ni/
Seventh: the path of conduct without fatigue.
'gro 'dug las khur/ mchod rgyug / las ngal dub rdul thon pa mi bya/ ku co smra dgod rdo brdeg mi bya/
When going or sitting, carrying loads, or jumping about, do not tire yourself out or become sweaty. Do not chatter, laugh, or throw stones.[17]
bzhi pa gsang ba dam tshig gi gnad ni/
d. The Vital Point of the Secret Samayas
spyir snyan brgyud kyi gdams pa/ sgos snyan brgyud kyi dmigs pa/ 'khrul 'khor rlung gi gnad/ nyams myong du ba la sogs pa'i rtags rnams gsang ngo / /

Secrecy applies, in general, to the instructions of the Aural Transmission and, in particular, to the Aural Transmission’s meditation techniques, trulkhors, the vital points for the winds, and the signs of experiences, such as smoke.[18]
dngos gzhi
2. The Main Practices
['di] la gnad rnam pa lnga las/ nges pa dus kyi gnad dang / skyon bral lus kyi gnad dang / gnas pa rtsa'i gnad dang / g.yo ba rlung gi gnad dang / dmigs pa yul gyi gnad do/

This has five parts: (1) the vital points of the definite timing, (2) the vital points for the body free from flaws, (3) the vital points of the stationary channels, (4) the vital points of the moving winds, and (5) the vital points of the objects of meditation.[19]
dang po
a. The Vital Points of the Definite Timing
['di] la gnyis las/
This has two parts.
sgom pa dus kyi gnad ni/
i. The Vital Point of the Timing for Meditation

'grangs ches pa dang / ltog chas pa'i dus su bsgoms pa na/ rtsa 'chang ba dang / rlung khyer ba'i skyon yod pas mi bsgom/ nam phyed nas rlung 'dre rtsar shor nas 'dre snang 'byung bas mi bsgom/ rtog pa sna tshogs 'phro ba'i dus su sems kyi rgyal po sprul bar gnas pas de dus bsgom/ nam phyed 'das nas nam langs kyi bar bad kan cha'i (506)dus yin pas gtum mo'i me bsgoms pas 'byung ba snyoms/ / rtsa sbubs thams cad stong par yod pas rlung gis thig le rtsa nang du phul/ lus la khrems pas rtsa rlung byang chub sems su gyur pas bogs cher 'byung / rgyun du thun bzhir bsgom mo/ / khyad par gyi dus gnad zhal las shes/

If you meditate when you are very full or very hungry, you will have problems with your channels being constricted and your winds running [wild]. Do not meditate then. After midnight, the winds deviate into the spirit channels, causing the appearances of spirits. Do not meditate then either. When thoughts are proliferating, the “sovereign” of mind abides at the place of emanation, [that is, the navel]. That is the time for meditation.[20] {506} Since after midnight and until daybreak is the time of phlegm and water, meditating on the fire of caṇḍālī [during that period] will equalize the elements. Since the interiors of the channels are empty, the winds offer the bindus within the channels. By [bindus] spreading through the body, the channels and winds become bodhicitta and your practice is greatly enhanced. On a regular basis, meditate in four sessions. Learn the vital points of timing for special occasions from oral instructions.[21]
gnyis pa nyams myong dus kyi gnad
ii. The Vital Point of the Timing of Experiences
['di] la gsum ste/
This has three parts.
dang po gtum mo sdug bsngal gyi dus su sdug bsngal bzod par bya ba ni/
First, during the time of suffering with caṇḍālī, you must bear suffering.

rtsa zug rlung zug thig le'i zug dang / mgo dang ro stod na ba dang / 'khru skyug la sogs ci rigs pa 'byung / gtum mo sgom pa la ngal dub dang skyo ba'i nyams 'char/ des na sangs rgyas bsgrub pa'i don du gtum mo bsgom mi nus na/ ngan song gsum gyi sdug bsngal myong du ci tsug byed snyam du bsams la/ shi ma shi med par bsgom/

You may experience the pains of your channels, the pains of your winds, or the pains of your bindus. Your head and upper body may feel sick. Various things may occur, such as diarrhea or vomiting. When you meditate on caṇḍālī, you may experience fatigue or have feelings of sadness. Therefore, you should think, “If I am not able to meditate on caṇḍālī for the sake of achieving buddhahood, how will I manage with the sufferings of the three negative states?” Meditate relentlessly.

bar du btang snyoms kyi dus su sos dal spangs nas bsgom pa ni/ sngar gyi na tsha dang sdug bsngal rnams zhi/ bde drod bag tsam byung dus des chog snyam du sos dal du mi sdod par le lo med par brtson 'grus bskyed la drod de rgyu mtshan du byas la bsgom/

In the middle, during the time of equanimity, give up taking it easy and meditate. Your previous illnesses and sufferings will be pacified. When a modicum of bliss or heat arises, do not remain complacent, thinking, “This is enough.” Without being lazy, arouse your diligence and cultivate heat, making it continuous.

tha ma ngo 'phrod nas bde'i dus su yengs med du bsgom pa ni/ phyi ru drod mi 'dod kyang 'byung / nang du bde stong gi ting nge 'dzin skyes/ de la du ba la sogs pa'i rtags sna re tsam mthong dus des yid tshim nas ma bsgoms na/ yon tan gong ma la bar du gcod pa'i bdud zhugs pa yin pas yengs pa med par bsgom mo/

In the end, during the time of recognition and bliss, meditate without distractions. Externally, heat may arise even without you desiring it. Internally, the samādhi of bliss-emptiness arises. When you see a few signs, such as smoke, if you become satisfied with those and do not meditate, māras, who will obstruct your earlier excellent qualities, have arrived. Therefore, meditate without distractions.[22]
gnyis pa skyon bral lus kyi gnad ni/
b. The Vital Points for the Body Free from Flaws
lus gnad chos bdun dang ldan pa ste/
The vital points for the body are to have the following seven dharmas:
rkang pa rdo rje skyil krung byas pas drod shugs kyis skye ba yin/
1. Placing your legs in the vajra position will give rise to heat naturally.
lag pa gnyis lte 'og sor bzhir mnyam bzhag dam du byas pas rtsa kha bye/ bde ba skye/
2. Joining your hands firmly in equipoise four fingerbreadths below your navel will cause your channels to open and bliss to arise.
rgal tshigs drang por bsrangs pas rlung rang sar gnad du chud pa yin/
3. By straightening your spine, the winds will strike the vital points in their own places.
mgrin pa lcags kyu ltar bkug pas rba rlabs kyi rtsa non nas mi rtog pa skye ba yin/ (507)
4. Bending your neck like an iron hook presses down on the wave channels, giving rise to nonconceptuality. {507}
dpung pa rgod gshog ltar brkyangs pas rlung nad chung ba yin/
5. Extending your shoulders, like the wings of a vulture, lessens wind diseases.
mig sna rtser bltas pas dmigs pa gsal ba yin/
6. Gazing at the tip of your nose clarifies the object of meditation.
lus sems li ri ltar bsgrims pas drod myur bde ba skyed ba yin/
7. Tightening your body and mind, as if [making a rope of] liri, gives rise to heat quickly and bliss.[*2]

{li ri ni rtsa dras ma ste/ /de'i thag bzo pa dus grim por ma bsgrims par lhod na zhig 'gro ba ltar/ gtum mo bsgom pa'i skabs lus gnad dang dmigs gnad rtse gcig tu ma bsgrims na nyams len kha 'byams drod rtags skye ba'i dus mi yong bas shin tu bsgrim dgos pa'i don no/ / mchan/ }

[*2] Interlinear note: Liri is jute grass (rtsva dres ma). When making a rope of such [grasses], if it is not [properly] tightened so that it is taut and is thus [too] loose, it will disintegrate. Like that, when cultivating caṇḍālī, if you do not [properly] tighten the vital points for the body and the vital points of the meditation technique in a one-pointed way, your practice will just be empty chatter. Since the occasions for giving rise to the signs will not occur, it is necessary to be [properly] tightened.
'khrul 'khor 'di rnams la skyon 'di rnams bsal dgos te/ /
These trulkhors [that is, points for posture] are necessary to remove the following problems:
mgo bo rgus na tshig pa za/ /mig mi gsal/ gnyid che/ shes pa nyog
▶ If you bend your head, you will feel irritated, your eyes will not be clear, you will feel very sleepy, and your mind will feel cloudy.
ro stod dgyes pas shes pa 'phyo/ rtog pa 'phro/ ro stod gzer cing na/
▶ Leaning back will cause your mind to be flighty and thoughts to proliferate. You will have pain in your upper body and feel sick.
ro stod rgus pas shug ring 'byin/ nyams mi dga'/ snying rlung 'byung /
▶ Bending your torso will cause you to sigh, feel unhappy, and experience “heart-wind,” [that is, depression].
ro stod brgyangs nas na/ g.yas su yo na dmigs pa mi zin/ 'gro 'dod/ nor la gzan/
▶ When you stretch your torso, if you lean to the right, you will be unable to concentrate on the object of meditation, you will want to move around, and will crave wealth.
g.yon du yo na 'dod sred che/ tshe thung / 'khor mi 'du/ don mi 'grub/
▶ If you lean to the left, your cravings will increase, your life will be short, you will not gather a retinue, and will not achieve your aims.
tshang ra stan du bting na/ thig le 'dzag mkhal nad 'jug le lo che/ nyams ngan no/ /
▶ If you spread your buttocks on your mat, you will release bindus, develop kidney diseases, be very lazy, and have bad experiences.
des na rtag tu lus gnad bsrangs te 'dug par bya te/ de'ang rnam snang gi chos bdun no/
Therefore, you should always sit with a straight posture. Those are the seven dharmas of Vairocana.
yang na tsog bur rkang pa re mig ltar bsnol ba la lham sgrog ske rags 'ching pa nas sgom thag bsdams pas rlung zug chung / lus gnad dam/ drod skye ba myur ba yin/ gzhan snga ma bzhin no/

Alternatively, while in a crouch, cross your legs like lattice work. Hold your body with a meditation belt, binding it where your bootstraps and belt go. That will lessen the pains of the winds, bind the vital points for the body, and quickly give rise to heat. The other points are as above.
yang bol gong 'gal bu ltar brtsegs/ lag pa sgom thag ltar bsdam/ 'di yang drod myur ro/ /
Another posture is to stack your feet, one on top of the other, like stacked firewood. Your arms hold [your body,] like a meditation belt. This quickly [generates] heat.
gzhan yang gtum mo'i 'khrul 'khor bco brgyad la sogs pa rim gyis sbyang bar bya'o/ /
Furthermore, you should train sequentially in the eighteen caṇḍālī trulkhors and other trulkhors.[*3][23]
gsum pa gnas pa rtsa'i gnad ni/
c. The Vital Points of the Stationary Channels

lus la rtsa rgyas par phye na ba spu'i grangs dang mnyam/ de bsdu na nyi khri chig stong / de bsdu na stong phrag bdun cu rtsa gnyis/ de bsdu na rtsa (508)gsum 'khor lo bzhi/ de bsdu na d+hU di/ lA la/ rA sa gsum/ de bsdu na d+hU ti gcig pu la 'dus so/ /

When presented in detail, the channels in the body equal the number of body hairs. When condensed, they are twenty-one thousand. When those are condensed, they are seventy-two thousand. {508} Those are subsumed into three channels and four cakras. Those are subsumed into the avadhūti, lalanā, and rasanā. Those are subsumed into the one avadhūti.
rtsa gsum 'khor lo bzhi'i gnas tshul ni/
The abiding modes of the three channels and four cakras.

lus kyi khong drang por d+hU ti srog shing gi tshul du gnas te/ yar sna tshangs bug la zug pa pha las thob pa'i thig le dkar po'i dwangs ma ha~M mgo mthur du bstan pa la thug pa/ mar sne skyes pa'i gsang ba'i rdo rje yin pas thig le dkar po 'bab/ bud med kyi d+hU ti'i mar sne lte 'og sor bzhi nas mdud pa nyis sbrag yod pas thig le dkar po mi 'bab/ d+hU ti mtshan nyid bzhi ldan te/ pad+ma'i snal ma ltar phra ba/ {srab ba'i don min/} mchan/ chu shing gi sdong po ltar drang ba/ rgya skyegs kyi me tog ltar dmar ba/ til gyi mar me ltar gsal ba'o/ /

The avadhūti abides like a life-force pole straight up in the interior of the body. Its upper end extends to the opening of Brahmā where the quintessence of the white bindu, which is received from your father, resides as an upside-down haṃ. For men, its lower end is the vajra in their secret place and therefore is where the white bindus descend. The lower end of the avadhūti for women is from four fingerbreadths below the navel to the double knot, and therefore the white bindus do not descend there. The avadhūti has four characteristics: it is fine[*4] {[*4] This does not mean thin.} like lotus threads, straight like the trunk of a plantain tree, red like the flowers of a fig tree, and clear like a flame of sesame oil.

bsgom dus d+hU ti'i mar sna gsang gnas lte 'og sor bzhi na/ sum mdor/ chos 'byung gru gsum kha gyen du bstan pa'i nang na ma las thob pa'i thig le dmar po'i dwangs ma rtsa bya rog gdong can la a thung zug par bsgon/ ha~M gis bde ba bskyed/ a thung gi drod bskyed pa'o/ /

During meditation, in the lower end of the avadhūti, in the secret place, four fingerbreadths below the navel at the junction of the three channels, there is a triangular source of dharmas, facing upward. Within that is a short a, the quintessence of the red bindu received from your mother, residing in the Kākamukha channel. Meditate on that. The haṃ generates bliss, and the short a gives rise to heat.

rtsa g.yas rA sa na kha dog dmar la dkar ba'i mdangs can/ rtsa g.yon lA la nA dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs can/ gnyis ka'i yar sna sna bug gnyis su zug / smin mtshams nas ltag par 'khyogs nas d+hU ti'i nang gshibs pa g.yas pa'i mar sna skyes ba la lte 'og sor bzhi na mdud par yod pas thig le dmar po de man chad la mi 'bab/ bud med kyi mar sna bu snod chags pas rtsa g.yas pa'i rtsa sna pad+ma yin pas thig le dmar po dus la 'bab pa'o/ / pho mo gnyis ka'i rtsa g.yon nas dri chu 'bab pa'o/ /

The rasanā, the right channel, is red with a white glow. The lalanā, the left channel, is white with a red glow. Both their upper ends reach the nostrils. They go from the point between your eyebrows and curve to the nape of your neck, then they line up with the avadhūti. As for the lower end of the right one, in men the red bindus do not descend there since they have a knot four fingerbreadths below the navel. The lower end in women forms the womb, and since the end of the right channel is the lotus, the red bindus descend there at times. For both men and women, urine flows through the left channel.
byed las ni/
Functions.

rtsa g.yas pa nyi ma me'i rang bzhin zhe sdang skyed/ g.yon pa zla ba chu'i rang bzhin 'dod chags skyed/ dbu ma d+hU ti mun pa'i rang bzhin gti mug skyed/ bsgom dus d+hU ti mda' smyug tsam/ rtsa g.yas g.yon gro sog tsam mar sna lte 'og sor (509) bzhi ru d+hU ti la zug pa bsgom/

The right channel is of the nature of fire and the sun, and it gives rise to aggression. The left channel is of the nature of water and the moon, and it arouses desire. The madhyamā, the avadhūti, is of the nature of darkness and produces bewilderment.[*5] During meditation, the avadhūti is about [the width of] a bamboo arrow. The right and left channels are about [the width of] a straw of wheat. Their lower ends enter the avadhūti four fingerbreadths below the navel. {509}
'khor lo bzhi ni/
The four cakras.

lte ba sprul pa'i 'khor lo rtsa 'dab drug tu rtsa bzhi/ de la bsten nas bde drod bskyed/ snying ga chos kyi 'khor lo rtsa 'dab brgyad/ de la brten nas 'od gsal zin/ mgrin pa longs spyod kyi 'khor lo rtsa 'dab bcu drug / de la brten nas rmi lam 'byongs/ spyi bo bde chen gyi 'khor lo rtsa 'dab sum cu so gnyis/ de la brten nas zag med bskyed/ lte ba sprul sku'i sa bon rtsa yig a/ snying gar chos sku'i sa bon hU~M/ mgrin par longs sku'i sa bon oM/ spyi bor ngo bo nyid kyi sku thob pa'i sa bon ha~M ye nas gnas/ sgom dus su 'khor lo bzhi gdugs brtsegs pa'i nang ltar rtsa'i drwa mig shig ge ba/ rtsa rnams mi sgom pa'i dus su kha dog ser po/ sgom dus su dmar po/ dkyil na rtsa gsum gdugs kyi yu ba ltar yod par bsgom mo/ /

The nirmāṇacakra at the navel has sixty-four channel petals, based upon which bliss and heat are generated. The dharmacakra at the heart has eight channel petals, based upon which luminosity is recognized. The saṃbhogacakra at the throat has sixteen channel petals, based upon which dreams develop. The mahāsukhacakra at the head has thirty-two channel petals, based upon which undefiled [bliss] is produced.[24] The seed syllable for the nirmāṇakāya at the navel is the root letter a. The seed syllable for the dharmakāya at the heart is hūṃ. The seed syllable for the saṃbhogakāya at the throat is oṃ. The seed syllable for attaining the svabhāvakāya at the head is the primordially abiding haṃ. During meditation, the four cakras are like stacked umbrellas, inside of which the latticework of the channels is arranged. When not meditating, all the channels are yellow; during meditation, they are red. In the middle, the three channels are like the shaft of an umbrella.[*6][25]
bzhi pa g.yo ba rlung gi gnad
d. The Vital Points of the Moving Winds

['di] la gsum ste/ steng rang byung ye shes su sbar nas steng rlung gi las gcig ston/ 'og zag med bde chen du sbar nas 'og sgo'i bcu gcig ston par 'khor 'das rgyun gcod du sbar nas rtsa rlung gi chings gcig ston pa'o/ /

This has three parts: (1) the presentation of the action of the upper wind once there is self-arising wisdom blazing above, (2) the presentation of the elixir of the lower door once there is undefiled great bliss blazing below, and (3) the presentation of the binding of the root winds once there is the blazing that cuts the continuity of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa in between.[26]
dang po rlung sgom pa la rlung gi gnas tshul shes par bya ba ni/
i. The Presentation of the Action of the Upper Wind Once There Is Self-Arising Wisdom Blazing Above

mi rgan po dang / byis pa ma yin pa dar ma nad med pa la/ nyin zhag gcig la rlung 'byung 'jug gnas gsum gcig tu dril ba nyi khri chig stong drug brgya'o/ / de'ang 'byung ba lnga'i rlung gis phye na/ lnga po re re la stong phrag bzhi dang sum brgya nyi shu nyi shu rgyu/ de bsdu na rtsa ba'i rlung lnga/ yan lag gi rlung lnga ste bcu ru 'dus/ de srog rtsol gnyis su 'dus/ phyi ru rgyu ba rnam rtog skyed pas rtsol ba zhes bya/ nang du 'jug pa tshe dpal skyed pas srog ces bya'o/

First, to meditate on the winds, you must know the abiding modes of the winds. A young person who is not ill, someone who is neither elderly nor a child, experiences the cycle of emerging, entering, and abiding, [that is, exhalation, inhalation, and abiding] of breath 21,600 times in one day. If those are categorized as the winds of the five elements, each of the five move 4,320 times [a day]. Those are subsumed into the ten winds: the five root winds and the five secondary winds.[*7] Those are reduced to two aspects: life-force control (prāṇāyāma, srog rtsol). Since when [the breath] moves externally, it arouses thoughts, there is what is called “control” (rtsol). Since when [the breath] enters, it arouses longevity and glory, it is the life-force [wind] (srog).
steng rang byung ye shes su sngar nas steng rlung gi las cig ston/ ces pa ni/
It is said: Once self-arising wisdom blazes above, teach the action of the upper wind.[27]

thog mar yan lag dgus rlung skyon sbyang ste/ g.yas su gsum/ (510) g.yon du gsum/ dbus su gsum drag la ring bar 'bud/ nad gdon nyon mongs pa thams cad dud pa ltar thon par bsam/ rngub dus 'dzam bu'i gling gi tshe dang dpal thams cad 'od zer gyi tshul du 'dus nas rang la thim pas bkrag mdangs su gyur par bsam/

To begin with, cleanse the problems of breath with the nine branches. {510} Exhale three times on the right, three times on the left, and three times in the middle, forcefully and long. Think that all illnesses, spirits, and mental afflictions exit like smoke. As you inhale, think that all the longevity and glory in Jambudvīpa is gathered in the form of light rays and dissolves into you, causing you to become radiant.
[drag rlung]
Forceful breathing.

de nas drag rlung sbyang ba ni/ rlung byed pa gcig la bya ba khru gang tsam nas drag por rngub nas steng rlung chil gyis mnan pas/ lA la rA sa gnyis nas rgyu ma pus btab pa bzhin song nas rlung sems d+hU ti nang du khrog song bar dmigs la/ rlung ci tsam thub thub gzung / mi thub pa dang g.yas g.yon dbus dang gsum du brdig / rlung yang bskyar cing rngub la brtsegs par bya/ yang mgo dgug bya/ ro stod sing bya/ rlung chil te mnan no/ / de mi thub par 'dug snyam pa dang / ltag pa cung dgye tsam byas la/ sangs tser btang / rlung zhabs dwangs ma bag tsam yod pa la rngub nas yang sngar bzhin 'dzin pa'o/ / drag rlung de la zhag ci rigs sbyangs pas/ rtsa rgod rlung rgod thul nas drod ci rigs pa 'byung / de nas brtan par bya ba'i phyir/

Next, train in forceful breathing. For each action [or cycle] of breath, forcefully inhale [air] from about one cubit away. Press down the upper wind with some effort. Imagine it goes through the lalanā and rasanā as if they were inflated intestines [or balloons], and wind-mind whooshes into the avadhūti. Hold your breath as much as you can. [When you sense that] you cannot [hold it much more], pull up to the right, left, and middle.[28] Again inhale breath and stack up inhalations. Also bend your head, raise up your torso, and press down your breath with some effort. [When] you think, “Now I cannot [hold any longer],” arch the nape of your neck back slightly and release fully. The end of your breath has a bit of its quintessence: inhale that and hold again as before.
