By training in that forceful breathing for a few days, your wild channels and wild winds will be tamed and some degree of heat will arise.
[rlung sbyor ba bzhi ldan sbyang ba]
Breathing with the four yogic techniques.

rlung sbyor ba bzhi ldan sbyang ba ni/ rngub dang / dgang dang / gzhil dang / btang ba bzhi las/ dang po rngub pa ni/ rlung chung ba gcig rngub nas gnon/ de rjes dgang ba ni/ rlung drag po rngub nas thub thang gnon/ de nas gzhil ba ni/ mi thub pa 'dra ba dang / rlung cung zad se gol gtogs tsam gcig phyir btang nas de lhag thub thang du gnon/ btang ba ni/ de nas mi thub pa dang sangs rtser lhag ma ma lus par btang ngo / / gcig nor na bzhi char nor bas dran pa tu re bya/ goms nas dmigs pa la rtse gcig tu bya'o/

Then, in order to stabilize that, train in breathing with the four yogic techniques. The four are inhalation, filling, dispersing, and releasing. 1. First, inhalation: inhale a small amount of air and press it down. 2. Next, filling: having forcefully inhaled, press it down as much as you can. 3. Then, dispersing: when it seems you cannot [hold much longer], release a small amount of breath—about [the amount that you can release during] a finger snap—and press down the remainder as much as you can. 4. Releasing: then, when you cannot [hold any longer], release the remainder completely and fully. Since if you make a mistake with one, all four will be wrong, be mindful. Once you have become familiar, focus one-pointedly on the meditation technique.
['jam rlung]
Gentle breathing.

de nas 'jam rlung khug pa gsum ldan ni/ rngub pa sgra mi grags tsam du yun ring du rngub/ de rjes thub thang gnon/ mi thub pa dang ltag pa dgye tsam byas la sgra mi grags par sangs tshor btang / phyi ru gnas tshad gcig 'jog / 'di la nyin (511)mtshan du sbyang / mi sngon du yang mi tshor bar skyang / rlung sbyor de gsum la ci rigs par sbyang ngo / /

Next, train in the gentle breath for three cycles. The inhalation should be long and without sound. Then press down as much as you can. When you cannot [hold any more], arch the nape of your neck back slightly and release fully without any sound. Remain resting externally as long as you can. {511} Train in that day and night. When practicing in the presence of other people, they should be unaware [that you are doing so]. Train in any one of those three breath practices.[29]
gnyis pa
ii. The Presentation of the Elixir of the Lower Door Once There Is Undefiled Great Bliss Blazing Below

'og zag med bde chen du sbar nas 'og sgo'i bcu gcig ston/ ces pa ni/ steng rlung brdzangs drags nas rlung sems bshang gci'i lam du shor na/ 'khor ba rgyas/ mya ngan las 'das pa rgyun chad/ rlung sems d+hU tir tshud na/ mya ngan las 'das pa rgyas/ 'khor ba rgyun chad/ 'khor 'das gnyis kyi 'khrugs pa lte 'og sor bzhir byed pas/ steng rlung mnan pa'i rjes la srin po bskum/ shed sgrim/ thur sel gyen du 'then la lus cung zad bsgul rlung sbyor bum pa can bya'o/ /

It is said: Once undefiled great bliss blazes below, teach the elixir of the lower door.[30] When the upper winds have been forcefully expelled, if wind-mind is lost through the paths for feces and urine, saṃsāra will increase and nirvāṇa will be interrupted.[*8] If wind-mind enters the avadhūti, nirvāṇa will increase and saṃsāra will be interrupted. The disturbances of both saṃsāra and nirvāṇa occur four fingerbreadths below the navel. After the upper winds have been pressed down, contract the rakṣasa and vigorously tighten.[*9] Draw up the downward-expelling wind, shake your body slightly, and do vase breathing.[31]
[iii.]
iii. The Presentation of the Binding of the Root Winds Once There Is the Blazing That Cuts the Continuity of Saṃsāra and Nirvāṇa In Between

bar 'khor 'das rgyun gcod du sbar nas rtsa rlung gi chings gcig ston/ ces pa ni/ gsum ste/ lus 'khrul 'khor gyi gnad kyis bya ba las 'grul rgyun gcod/ ngag rlung sbyor gyi gnad kyis long gtam gyi 'grul rgyun gcod/ gsang ba yid dmigs pa rtse gcig gi gnad kyis rnam rtog 'grul rgyun gcod pa'o/ /

It is said: Once there is the blazing that cuts the continuity of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa in between, teach the binding of the root winds.[32] This has three points: 1. Cutting the continuity of the journey of karma and actions through the vital points of the trulkhors, [connected] to body. 2. Cutting the continuity of the journey of meaningless talk through the vital points of breath practices, [connected] to speech. 3. Cutting the continuity of the journey of thoughts through the vital point of one-pointed focus with the mind, the secret.[33]
lnga pa dmigs pa yul gyi gnad ni/
e. The Vital Points of the Objects of Meditation

rang gi lus phyi rje btsun ma'i sku/ nang stong ra phrum phus btab pa lta bu'i nang du rtsa gsum gyi 'dus pa dbu ma'i mar snar a thung zangs ma'i mo khab tsam/ yang na thig le dmar po cog sgong tsam/ de las me sor bzhi 'bar bar bsgom/ me de mtshan nyid bzhi ldan kha dog dmar ba/ reg bya tsha ba/ rtse mo rno ba/ 'jam zhing mnyen pa'o/ /

Externally, your body is the form of the Jetsunma, and internally, it is an empty enclosure, like an inflated placenta [or balloon]. Within it, at the lower end of the madhyamā where the three channels converge is a short a the size of a fine copper needle or a red bindu the size of a bird’s egg. From that, fire blazes up four fingerbreadths. That fire has four characteristics: it is red in color, hot to the touch, its tip is sharp, and it is soft and flexible.

de rjes sor brgyad/ de rjes snying ga / de nas 'bar 'dzag ni/ me rta rnga tsam d+hU ti'i nang nas yar song / tshangs bug gi ha~M la reg / de las thig le nyungs 'bru tsam tshad nas chos 'byung gi nang du babs pas bde phril bar bskyar cing bsgom/ chos 'byung thig les gang bar bsam mo/ /

Next, it becomes eight fingerbreadths high, then it reaches the heart. Then there is blazing and dripping as follows: The fire, which is like a horse’s tail hair, rises up within the avadhūti, touching the haṃ at the opening of Brahmā. From that, bindus the size of mustard seeds separate and flow down to the source of dharmas. Repeat and meditate until there is scintillating bliss. Imagine that the source of dharmas is filled with bindus.[*10]

de nas sum mdor gtum mo maN+Dali me'i 'khor lo shin tu dmar zhing tsha ba/ mgar gyi lcags sgong la zhun btang ba lta bu bsgom/ des bde drod gnyis ka (512) cher skye'o/ ha cang drod che bar 'dod na/ 'khor lo de las me sbar/ rtsa'i drwa mig rnams me lce nyug nyug byung bas/ snying ga man chad me ru 'bar ba la sems gtad de/ me de yang mtshan nyid bzhi ldan te/ rnam pa me/ ngo bo rnal 'byor ma/ rang bzhin ye shes/ nyams myong bde drod do/ /

Next, meditate that the cakra of caṇḍālī fire at the juncture of the three channels becomes very red and hot, like iron balls made by a blacksmith through smelting. That gives rise to much bliss and heat. {512} If you wish for a great deal of heat, fire will blaze from that cakra and flames will dance in the latticework of the channels. Concentrate on fire blazing up as far as your heart. That fire has four characteristics: its manifestation is fire, its essence is the Yoginī, its nature is wisdom, and its experience is bliss-heat.[34]
gsum pa
3. The Conclusion
rjes kyi gnad la bzhi ste/ sbyong ba thabs kyi gnad dang / bang chen rtags kyi gnad dang / rang grol phyag rgya chen po'i gnad dang / spyod lam shugs 'byung gi gnad do/ /

The vital points of the conclusion are four: the vital points of the methods for training, the vital points of the signs that are couriers, the vital points for self-liberating mahāmudrā, and the vital points for naturally occurring conduct.[35]
dang po
a. The Vital Points of the Methods for Training
['di] la phyi sbyong ba dang nang sbyong ba gnyis las/
This has two parts: (1) external training and (2) internal training.
phyi sbyong ba ni/
i. External Training

gtum mo bsgoms pas/ drod khol bur skyes na brtan/ dus gcig la skyes na mi brtan/ byin rlabs kyi drod skabs su ma bsgoms na'ang mi 'chor ba'o/ / gos gcig bsgyur gnyis bsgyur bya/ de rjes ther ma'ang ras la sbyang / drod chen grang bar bsgom/ rdul byung na bsku mnye byas rjes sran phyes dril phyis bya/ mthar gang la yang ras gos kyis chag pa 'byung / de tsam na gos kyi 'dun pa dang bral/ 'byung ba khyad du gsod pa'i grub thob ces bya ba zas su yang rlung zos pas chog pa 'byung /

When a small degree of heat arises through meditating on caṇḍālī, stabilize it. If it just arises once, it is not stable. The heat of blessings may sometimes not vanish even though you do not meditate. Change one set of clothing, cast off another set. Then, wool clothing can be exchanged for cotton clothing. If you have a lot of heat, meditate on cold. If sweat arises, massage yourself. Then rub powdered beans [on your body]. In the end, no matter what, you will wear cotton clothes. At that point, you will be free from any interest in clothing. [That is what it means to be] called “a siddha who is unconcerned about the elements.” As for food, eating the wind will suffice.[36]
nang sbyang ba ni/
ii. Internal Training

lus 'khrul 'khor phyi'i gtum mo li ri ltar grims par sbyang / ngag rlung gi sbyor ba nang gi gtum mo gzhu rgyud ltar grim par sbyang / sems me mtshan nyid bzhi ldan gsang ba'i gtum mo mda' 'phangs kyi 'ben ltar grims par sbyang / bde ba rgyas pa'i dus su spong sems brtan pa dang / nyams su len pa'i tshe thig le srung ba zhal las shes/ 'jam rlung rdo rje'i bzlas pa yig 'bru gsum la sbyang pa dang / 'byung ba lnga'i rlung sangs rgyas lnga la kha dog so sor sbyong ba'ang zhal las shes so/ /

Train, “tightening as if you [are making a rope of] liri,” using the outer caṇḍālī of physical trulkhors. Train, “tightening as if you [are making] a bow string,” using the internal caṇḍālī of the breath practices, [connected to] speech. Train, “tightening as if you are shooting an arrow at a target,” using the secret caṇḍālī of fire with the four characteristics, [connected to] mind. Learn how to stabilize your mind of renunciation when bliss increases and how to protect bindus in the context of practice from oral instructions. Learn how to train with gentle breathing and the three-syllable vajra repetition from oral instructions. Also learn to train with the winds of the five elements, the five buddhas, and their specific colors from oral instructions.[*11][37]
gnyis pa bang chen rtags kyi gnad ni/
b. The Vital Points of the Signs That Are Couriers
gtum mo bsgoms pas rtags bcu/ rdzu 'phrul bzhi/ 'du ba bzhi 'byung / rtags bcu ni thun mong lnga (513) dang khyad par gyi lnga'o/ /
Through meditating on caṇḍālī, ten signs, four magical powers, and four gatherings arise. {513} The ten signs consist of five ordinary ones and five special ones.
dang po ni/ rlung lnga zin pa'i rtags te
The first are the signs of holding the five winds.
dngos sam rmi lam dus rlung zin pas du ba dang /
▶ When you hold the earth wind, smoke will arise either actually or in dreams.
chu rlung zin pas smig rgyu dang /
▶ By holding the water wind, mirages will appear.
me rlung zin pas me khyer dang /
▶ By holding the fire wind, fireflies will occur.
rlung gi rlung gis mar me dang /
▶ Holding the wind wind, candle flames will appear.
nam mkha'i rlung gis sprin med pa'i nam mkha' lta bu 'byung ngo / /
▶ By holding the space wind, what resembles a cloudless sky will occur.
khyad par rlung lnga brtan pa'i rtags ni/
The special ones are the signs of stabilizing the five winds.
lte bar sa rlung brtan pas 'dug tshugs shing sa gzhi gser du mthong ngo / /zla zer lta bu dang thang chen po mthong /
▶ By stabilizing the earth wind at your navel, you will feel settled and will see the ground as yellow. You will see a great plain and something that resembles moonlight.
snying gar chu rlung brtan pas lus rdul/ snang ba chur mthong / nyi zer lta bu dang 'od dmar po mthong /
▶ By stabilizing the water wind at your heart, your body sweats and you see appearances as water. You will see red light and something that resembles sunlight.
mgrin par me rlung brtan pas drod che/ gos dang bral/ me chen po dang glog gi zer lta bu mthong /
▶ By stabilizing the fire wind at your throat, you will experience great heat and not need clothes. You will see a large fire and something that resembles lightning.
gsang gnas su rlung gi rlung brtan pas stobs che/ 'gro mgyogs rlung dang 'ja' tshon mthong /
▶ By stabilizing the wind wind at your secret place, you will experience great power and speed walking. You will see winds and rainbows.
spyi bor nam mkha'i rlung brtan pas lus bde/ mdangs dang ldan/ nyi zla bsres pa lta bu mthong /
▶ By stabilizing the space wind at your head, your body will be blissful and radiant. You will see something that resembles a blend of the sun and moon.

rlung sems dbu mar tshud pas rlung lnga'i kha dog 'ja' tshon 'od kyi skud pa lta bu sna sgor mthong / de bzhin gshegs pa'i zhing dang / rigs drug gi gnas mthong ba 'byung ste rlom sems med par byung rgyal du bskyang /

▶ When your wind-mind enters the madhyamā, you will see at your nostrils the colors of the five winds like threads of rainbow light. You will see the pure lands of the tathāgatas and the places of the six kinds of beings. Without any conceit, sustain [your experiences] however they come.
rdzu 'phrul bzhi la/
The four magical powers are as follows:
me rlung dbang du 'dus pas nyi ma bstod la gnon/
▶ Having subdued the fire wind, you can press the sun to your torso.
seng ge thur du tshud pas chu bo gyen la bzlog /
▶ By bringing the lion below, you can draw up and reverse the river.
rlung sems dbang du 'dus pa lta stangs kyis pha rol rengs/
▶ Having subdued wind-mind, you can paralyze others with your gaze.
rlung gi rlung dbang du 'dus pas bar snang du skyil krung 'cha' nus so/ /
▶ Having subdued the wind wind, you are able to sit cross-legged in space.
'du ba bzhi la/ rtsas nor 'du/ rlung gi mi 'du/ thig le mi ma yin/ cha mnyam gyi rlung ltas brtags pas dge mi dge shes/ rdzas dang zas 'du'o/ /

The four gatherings. The channels gather wealth. The winds gather humans. The bindus gather nonhumans. By examining the omens [when] the winds are equalized, you know virtue and unvirtue, and gather substances and food.[*12][38]
gsum pa rang grol phyag rgya chen po'i gnad
c. The Vital Points for Self-Liberating Mahāmudrā

['di] la gsum ste/ rtsa thams cad 'dres pas gsal ba rgyun gyis rtag pa ni/ da ltar gyi rtsa 'di rnams rnam smin gyi rtsa/ de'i nang na ye shes kyi rtsa kha dog dbyibs su ma grub pa bsgoms nas ngo 'phrod nus pa cig yod/ gtum mo bsgoms (514) pas rnam smin gyi rtsa dang ye shes kyi rtsa 'dres pas rnam pa gsal ba'i nyams rgyun du 'byung ba'o/ /

By mixing all the channels, clarity is permanent due to being continuous. The channels of our present state are channels of maturation. Within them, meditate on the wisdom channels, which do not exist with colors or shapes. They have the power [to bring] recognition. {514} By meditating on caṇḍālī, the channels of maturation and the wisdom channels mix, and experiences of clear manifestations arise continuously.

de bzhin du rlung thams cad 'dres pas mi rtog pa rgyun gyis rtag pa/ thig le thams cad 'dres pas bde ba rgyun gyis rtag pa rnams kyang shes par bya'o/ / gnas pa rtsal rten nas gsal ba ngos 'dzin pa/ g.yo ba rlung la brten nas mi rtog pa ngos 'dzin pa/ byang sems thig le la brten nas bde ba ngos 'dzin pa/ / rtsa gsal stong / bde gsal mi rtog pa gsum zung du chud pa rgyud la skyes pa de kho na nyid kyi gtum mo zhes bya/ phyag rgya chen po zhes bya'o/ /

Similarly, you should know that by mixing all the winds, nonconceptuality is permanent due to being continuous and that by mixing all the bindus, bliss is permanent due to being continuous. On the basis of the stationary channels, clarity is recognized. On the basis of the moving winds, nonconceptuality is recognized. On the basis of the bodhicitta bindus, bliss is recognized. The channels are clarity-emptiness. [The winds are awareness-emptiness or appearance-emptiness. The bindus are bliss-emptiness.] The arising in your mindstream of unified bliss, clarity, and nonconceptuality is called the suchness caṇḍālī. It is called mahāmudrā.[*13][39]
bzhi pa spyod pa shugs 'byung gi gnas
d. The Vital Points for Naturally Occurring Conduct
['di] la gnyis/ rlung gi sbyor ba dang / /spyod lam gyi bya ba'o/ /
This has two parts: (1) breath practices and (2) the activities of conduct.
dang po ni/
i. Breath Practices

grang na drod btsan thabs su dbabs pa ni/ lus kyi rgan po bzhi btsugs la gcud par bya/ mgo ri rab kyi bar du bcug la steng 'og rlung kha sbyor ba'o/ / 'gro na srog rtsol gnad du bsnun ba ni/ gling bzhi bsdus la srin po gcod/ dran pa'i rgyun de dang ma bral ba gnad che'o/ /

When you feel cold, exert yourself in the forceful methods of heat as follows: Plant the four old people of the body and work them. Insert your head as far as Meru. Unite the upper and lower winds. When going, penetrate the vital points of prāṇāyāma: contract the four continents and cut off the rakṣasa. It is vital that you do not let that be separate from the flow of mindfulness.[40]
spyod lam ni/
ii. The Activities of Conduct

rta mi zhon/ dung mi 'bud/ me dang nyi ma spang / thig le bsrung / tshwa ches pa dang / sga dang / sgog sngon dang / zwa dang / nya sha dang / sha rul dang / chang skyur dang / phye rul dang / gro phye dang / sran phye dang / chul 'khyag mi 'thung / nyin gnyid mi log /

Do not ride horses. Do not blow conches. Avoid fires and the sun. Protect your bindus. [Give up] excessive salt, ginger, green garlic, nettles, fish, spoiled meat, sour beer, rancid flour, wheat flour, and ground beans. Do not drink freezing water. Do not sleep during the day.

gzhan yang lus lha sku sgyu ma lta bu dang / ngag rlung rdo rje'i bzlas pa grag stong / sems stong nyid snying rje'i ting nge 'dzin dang mi 'bral bar bya'o/ / gtum mo bde drod rang 'bar gyi gdams ngag go /

Furthermore, do not let your body be separate from being the illusion-like deity body, your speech and winds be separate from vajra repetition and being empty sounds, and your mind be separate from the samādhi of emptiness and compassion. Those are the instructions for caṇḍālī, the self-blazing of bliss and heat.[41]
gnyis pa sgyu lus chos brgyad rang grol
II. Illusory Forms: The Self-Liberating of the Eight Worldly Values

['di] la bzhi ste/ gser 'gyur gyi rtsis dman pa mchog tu bsgyur ba dang / nyi zla'i 'od kyis ye shes ngo sprad pa dang / bstod smad kyis chos brgyad kyi rgya mdud grol ba dang / rjes grol zhing sgyu ma lam du khyer ba'o/ /

This has four parts: (1) the gold-creating elixir transforming something base into something supreme, (2) pointing out wisdom by means of the light of the sun and moon, (3) becoming free from the knots of the eight worldly values involving praise and blame, and (4) subsequent liberation and integrating illusions into the path. {515}
dang po ni/
A. The Gold-Creating Elixir Transforming Something Base into Something Supreme

dper na gser 'gyur gyi rtsi gser (515)srang gcig gis lcags srang stong gser du bsgyur nus pa bzhin/ sgyu lus bsgoms pas 'jig rten gyi snang ba bden cing rtag par 'dod pa thams cad mi bden zhing brdzun pa sbun gog tu bshig par byed pa yin te/ de la gsum/ yi dam gser 'gyur gyi rtsi dang / bla ma gser 'gyur gyi rtsi dang / snang ba gser 'gyur gyi rtsi'o/ /

For example, one measure of a golden elixir (one that creates gold) can transform a thousand measures of iron into gold. In the same way, by meditating on illusory forms, all assertions that worldly appearances are real and permanent are shattered, being unreal and false husks. This has three parts: (1) the gold-creating elixir of the yidam, (2) the gold-creating elixir of the guru, and (3) the gold-creating elixir of appearances.[42]
dang po ni/
1. The Gold-Creating Elixir of the Yidam
rang rje btsun mar bsgom/ sgyu ma rmi lam yin snyam du sems tur tur/ ngag tu thol thol brjod/ mig seb dang gnyid zam zi tshun chod sbyangs la bag chags 'dris nges rtag nges su bya/

Meditate upon yourself as being the Jetsunma. The thought, “This an illusion and dream,” flashes in your mind. You utter that spontaneously. Train in the midst of people and during the hypnagogic state. This should be your habitual pattern—what you are definitely familiar with, what manifests fully for you.
bla ma gser 'gyur gyi rtsi ni/
2. The Gold-Creating Elixir of the Guru
spyi bor bla ma dang bka' brgyud gsum/ rmi lam yin sgyu ma yin snyam du sngar bzhin sbyang /
Imagine your gurus and the Kagyu lineage on your head. As before, train in thinking, “This is a dream. This is an illusion.”
snang ba gser 'gyur gyi rtsi ni/
3. The Gold-Creating Elixir of Appearances

mig gis gzugs mthong tshad la gzugs su snang dus nas rang gi ngo bos stong / gzugs snang stong sgyu ma lta bu yin snyam du bsgom/ rna bas sgra thos tshad grags dus nas ngo bos stong pa grags stong sgyu ma lta bu yin/ sems la rnam rtog 'phros tshad rnam rtog tu gsal dus na ngo bos stong pas sems gsal stong sgyu ma lta bur bsgom zhing sbyang /

When your eyes see forms, whatever appears as forms are empty of any essence of their own. Meditate on the thought, “Forms are appearance-emptiness, like illusions.” When your ears hear sounds, those sounds are empty of an essence. They are sound-emptiness, like illusions. When your mind produces thoughts, all those vivid thoughts are empty of an essence. Meditate that mind is clarity-emptiness, like illusions. Train.[*14][43]
gnyis pa nyi zla'i 'od kyis ye shes ngo sprad pa
B. Pointing Out Wisdom by Means of the Light of the Sun and Moon
['di] la gsum/ 'pho 'gyur gyi dus la sbyang ba dang / nyi zla'i zer la ngo sprad pa dang / sgyu ma'i dpe bcu gnyis kyis mtshon te snang ba bden med du gtan la dbab pa'o/ /

This has three parts: (1) training for the time of transference, (2) pointing out in relationship to the light of the sun and moon, and (3) determining that appearances are unreal as demonstrated by the twelve examples of illusion.
dang po ni/
1. Training for the Time of Transference
skad cig gis rang rje btsun mar bsgoms la yul lnga gsal gdab/ mdun du rje btsun ma'i thang sku bkram la de la sems gtad/ sgyu ma yin rmi lam yin snyam du yid la bsgom zhing ngag tu'ang brjod/

Instantly meditate that you are the Jetsunma and visualize the five objects. Focus your mind on a tangka of the Jetsunma placed in front of you. With your mind, meditate on the thought, “This is an illusion, this is a dream,” and with your speech, say that.

de nas thang ga bsdus la yi dam bsgom/ phar bltas pas lha tshogs rnams snang tsam nas stong / stong tsam nas snang / snang stong sgyu ma rmi lam lta bur bsgom/ de la shes pa mi gnas na mdun gyi lha rang la bstim/ rang rje (516) btsun ma dbyer med du bzhag / de la skyon bla ma'i rnal 'byor gsal gdab/ bskyar cing bsgoms la/

Then, put away the tangka and meditate with your mind. When you look out, the assembly of deities are empty while they appear. They appear while they are empty. Meditate that they are appearance-emptiness, like illusions and dreams. If your mind does not rest on that, visualize that the deity in front dissolves into you. {516} Rest inseparable from the Jetsunma. If you tire of that, visualize guru yoga. Do that again and meditate.

ye shes mkha' 'gro sgyu ma'i sku/ sgyu ma stong pa'i ngo bo nyid/ stong nyid brjod du med par sprod/ sgyu lus 'byongs par byin gyis rlobs/ ces gsol ba gdab/ rgyas par byed na/ rdo rje 'chang chen sgyu ma'i sku/ ces brgyud pa la gsol ba gdab/ de thams cad sgyu ma yin pas stong pa/ stong pa yin pas skye med/ skye med yin pas spros bral/ spros bral yin pas chos sku yin snyam du thag rbad kyis bcad la/ de ga'i ngang la ying sing nge ye re tshugs tshad du bzhag /

The Jñānaḍākinī is an illusory form. Illusions are of the nature of emptiness. Emptiness is pointed out to be inexpressible. Supplicate with “Bless me to master illusory forms.” To do that extensively, supplicate the lineage, [beginning with,] “Great Vajradhara, kāya of illusion.” Since they all are illusions, they are empty. Being empty, they are unborn. Being unborn, they are free from elaborations. Since they are free from elaborations, they are the dharmakāya. Thinking in that way, be completely certain. Within that state, let your mind rest fully, vividly, crisply.[44]
gnyis pa nyi zla'i zer la ngo sprod pa ni/ /
2. Pointing Out in Relationship to the Light of the Sun and Moon

khang ba bla gab med pa'am/ yang na phyogs bzhir mun skar bzhi phug la phyag dar bya/ snga dro kha shar/ nyin phyed lho/ dgong mo nub tu blta/ shar gyi mun skar gyi/ thad du ral gri/ lhor me long / nub tu rgya bskyegs kyi khu ba/ byang du glegs bam bzhag / des cir snang bden med du 'char/ snang ba bun long 'gro ba'i rten 'brel lo/ /

[This is practiced] in a house with no curtains [on the windows], or in one in which four openings have been made in the four directions, and that has been swept clean. In the mornings, face east. At midday, face south. In the evenings, face west. Directly in the eastern opening, place a sword; in the south, a mirror; in the west, the sap of a fig tree; and in the north, a volume of dharma texts. Those will cause whatever appears to manifest as unreal. They create the auspicious connections for appearances to be nebulous.

yi dam ma rdo rje sems dpa'i thang ga gsar ba cig rgyab tu bkram/ sngar bzhin bla ma yi dam bsgoms la gsol ba gdab/ chu dang me long gi nang du lha sku shar ba la rig pa gtad/ skabs su lha sku la sogs pa chu dang me long nang du shar ba la brtag pa bzhi bya/ de yod nas 'char na bzung bas zin rgyu la mi zin/ med nas 'char na de'i nang du 'ong ba med par byung /

Place a new tangka of a yidam or Vajrasattva behind you. As before, meditate upon and supplicate the gurus and yidams. Direct your awareness to the form of the deity appearing in water or a mirror. Sometimes do a fourfold analysis of the deity’s form and so forth appearing in the water or mirror. If that arises due to being existent, it would be something that is graspable—but it cannot be grasped. If it arises due to being nonexistent, what arises in that [mirror or water] is nonexistent.

de'ang thang sku bris pa las thon nas der 'ongs pa'ang min/ lha sku glo bur du gzhan nas byung nas der thim pa'ang min/ de med bzhin rten 'brel 'tshogs pa'i rdzun snang tsam du shar bas/ de bzhin du 'khor 'das kyi chos dang da ltar gyi snang ba thams cad shes par bya/

Furthermore, [the reflection] does not come from the image drawn on the tangka and go there, [that is, into the mirror or water]. Nor is it that the deity’s form arises suddenly from somewhere else and dissolves there [in the water or mirror]. While it is nonexistent, it arises simply as a false appearance that is an interdependent collection. Know that all phenomena of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa and all present appearances are the same way.
thun bshol khar lha rang la bstim/ rang dang snang ba thams cad sgyu ma/ sgyu ma yin pas stong pa la sogs pa thams cad 'gre/ (517)
At the end of the session, the deity dissolves into you. You and all appearances are illusions. Being illusions, [you and all appearances] are empty and so forth, as stated above.[45] {517}
gsum pa sgyu ma'i dpe bcu gnyis kyi mtshon te snang ba bden med du gtan la 'bebs pa ni/
3. Determining That Appearances Are Unreal as Demonstrated by the Twelve Examples of Illusion

rgyu rkyen las grub pas sgyu ma/ g.yo ba dang bcas pas smig rgyu/ gnas dang longs spyod med bzhin du snang bas dri za'i grong khyer/ snang la rang bzhin med pas 'ja' tshon/ gsal la rdzogs pas me long gi gzugs/ kun la khyab pas chu zla/ rang yin pa gzhan du snang ba brag cha/ sems dang bcas pas rmi lam/ mi rtag cing myur bas glog / med bzhin snang bas mig yor/ gcig kyang du mar 'byung bas sprin/ gzugs sna tshogs pas sprul pa/ de rnams kyi don la res phar blta/ res tshur blta/ de rang la bltims la snga ma ltar bsgom par bya'o/ /

Since appearances are produced from causes and conditions, they are like illusions. Since they involve movements, they are like mirages. Since they appear while being free from remaining or being enjoyed, they are like cities of gandharvas. Since they appear but have no nature, they are like rainbows. Since they are vivid and complete, they are like forms in mirrors. Since they pervade everywhere, they are like the moon reflected in water. Since they are themselves but appear to others, they are like echoes. Since they involve the mind, they are like dreams. Since they are impermanent and swift, they are like lightning. Since they appear while not existing, they are like optical illusions. Since they are one but arise as many, they are like clouds. Since they have various forms, they are like emanations. Sometimes look out at the nature of those, sometimes look in. They dissolve into you and you meditate as before.[*15][46]
gsum pa bstod smad kyi chos brgyad kyi rgya mdud dgrol ba ni/
C. Becoming Free from the Knots of the Eight Worldly Values Involving Praise and Blame

lha sku bsdus la me long la rang gi gzugs 'char bar byas la/ rang gi ming nas bton la/ khyod pas pho grung ba/ btsun pa/ gtong phod che ba med la sogs pa byas kyang de la dga' ba med/ sdom nyams/ dam nyams la sogs pa byas kyang mi dga' ba med/ sgyu ma lta bu la dga' mi dga' yong ba med pa dngos su ro snyom ste/

Dissolve the form of the deity and let your own form appear in the mirror. Address [your reflection] with your name. Even though you say to it, “You are intelligent, honorable, charitable, and so forth,” it is not delighted. Even though you say to it, “You have impaired your vows and impaired your commitments,” it is not upset. What is illusion-like does not become pleased or displeased. You experience equal taste directly.

gzhan gyis bstod ra gtong gin 'dug na'ang de la dga' mi dga' mi bya de la brtag pa gnyis bya ste/ yon tan yod nas bstod na/ brjod pas lhag tu mi 'gro bas dga' bar mi rigs/ med pa la bstod na tshig stod phye 'thor la dga' bar mi rigs/

If someone else praises you, do not be pleased or upset by that. Apply a twofold analysis. If you are praised for having excellent qualities, someone saying that does not make you superior, and therefore it is inappropriate to be pleased. If you do not have such qualities but are praised, it is not appropriate to be pleased by empty words and flattery.
gzhan gyis smad ra btang na mi dga' ba mi bya/ de la brtag pa gnyis bya/ skyon de yod nas smad na/ yod pa brjod pa la mi dga' ba mi rigs/ med na tshig stong la mi dga' bar mi rigs so/ /

If someone else demeans you, do not be displeased. Use a twofold analysis. If you are demeaned for having those faults, it is not appropriate to be displeased that someone tells you that you have [faults]. If you do not have [those faults], it is not fitting to be displeased over empty words.

de bzhin du bde zhing skyid par snang na de la dga' bar mi bya/ de la brtag pa gsum bya/ lus bem po ro dang 'dra ste de la bde skyid ma grub/ ngag brag ca dang 'dra ste bde skyid ma grub/ sems nam mkha' dang 'dra ste bde skyid ma grub/ (518) ma grub pa la snang ba de sgyu ma/ sgyu ma la dga' bar mi bya'o/ /

Similarly, do not delight in pleasant and enjoyable appearances. Do a threefold analysis. Your body is like a corpse, inanimate matter. It does not exist as something pleasing. Your speech is like an echo. It does not exist as something pleasing. Your mind is like space. It does not exist as something pleasing. {518} What does not exist but appears is an illusion. Do not delight in illusions.
sdug pa'i snang ba byung na mi dga' ba mi bya/ de la brtag pa gsum bya/ lus bem por/ ngag brag ca/ sems nam mkha' 'dra bas sdug pa ma grub/ ma grub bzhin du sdug par snang ba sgyu ma'o/ /

If miserable appearances occur, do not be unhappy. Do a threefold analysis. Since your body is like inanimate matter, your speech is like an echo, and your mind is like space, the misery does not exist. While not existing, there is an appearance of something miserable. It is an illusion.

de bzhin du rnyed pa chen dga' bar mi rigs/ de la brtag pa gsum bya/ nor zang zing bden par ma grub bzhin snang ba mig 'phrul gyi nor dang 'dra bar dga' bar mi rigs/ phugs su 'tshengs mi nus la/ 'phral spyod dbang med pa rmi lam gyi nor bu'i gter rnyed pa dang 'dra bas dga' bar mi rigs/ de la zhen nas phung khrol thams cad 'byung / nong phyir srog kyang 'chor ba sbrang ma'i chi dang 'dra bar dga' bar mi rigs/ rnyed pa chung ba la mi dga' ba mi bya/ de la brtag pa gsum bya ba sngar bzhin no/ /

Similarly, it is not appropriate to delight in great gain. Use a threefold analysis. While wealth and material goods are not real, they appear, like magically displayed wealth. It makes no sense to delight in that. In the end, wealth cannot satisfy and, even in the moment, it does not have the power to be enjoyed. Since it is like finding treasures of gems in a dream, it does not make sense to delight in it. Being fixated on wealth brings all kinds of ruin. Do not lose your life for the sake of wealth, which is like honey. It is not fitting to delight in that. Do not be unhappy about [only making] small gains. Do the threefold analysis as before.

de bzhin du grags ma grags gnyis po gong gi bstod smad la dga' mi dga' mi rigs pa dang 'dra/ de ltar chos brgyad sgyu mar 'byongs/ chags sdang mi skye na bar dor mngal sgo khegs/ rgya mdud rang sar grol/

Similarly, treat fame or the lack of fame in the same way that you did above with praise and blame: it does not make sense to be either pleased or upset. In that way, train [in seeing that] the eight worldly values are illusions. If attachment or aggression do not arise, the door to the womb in the bardo is blocked. Your knots will be free on the spot.[*16][47]
bzhi pa rjes grol zhing sgyu ma lam du khyer ba ni/
D. Subsequent Liberation and Integrating Illusions into the Path

snang ba thams cad rigs lnga'i bdag nyid sgyu ma lta bur bltas te/ phung po lnga yab lnga/ 'byung ba lnga yum lnga/ phyogs yul/ dbang po yan lag / 'dod yon der 'dzin gyi rtog pa thams cad sku dang ye shes sgyu mar snang stong du blta bar bya/ sgyu ma lta bu'i ting nge 'dzin des phyag rgya thams cad la 'jug / dkyil 'khor thams cad bya/ 'dod yon thams cad spyad/ rgyan thams cad 'gags/ spyod pa thams cad bya/ gar dang rol mo smra rgod la sogs pa thams cad bya/ grub mtha' thams cad bsgyur/ lam thams cad bgrod do/ /

Seeing all appearances as the illusion-like embodiment of the five families, you will see that the five skandhas are the five male consorts, that the five elements are the five female consorts, and that the directions, objects, sense faculties, limbs, sense pleasures, all thoughts grasping at those are empty, appearing as illusions, as kāyas and wisdoms. That samādhi [in which everything is seen to be] illusion-like applies to all mudrās. It is used with all maṇḍalas, it is practiced with all sense pleasures, it joins with all ornaments, it is used with all conducts, and it is used with dance, music, laughter, and the like. It transforms all philosophical tenets. It traverses all paths.
ci'i phyir na thams cad sgyu ma'i rnam 'phrul yin par shes pa'i phyir/ nyes ltung gis mi gos so/ /
If you ask why that is, it is because [with that samādhi] you know everything to be an illusory display. Flaws and downfalls will not taint you. {519}

de ltar shes pas mchod rten dang / dge slong la sogs pa (519)la phyag mi bya ste/ de dag bem po'i gzugs brnyan ni sgyu ma'i rnam 'phrul yin pa'i phyir ro/ / kha ton dang / sngags bzla ba dang / srung 'khor bsgoms pa la sogs pa mi bya'o/ /

When you have that recognition, do not worship stūpas, bhikṣus, and the like, because those reflections of inanimate matter are illusory displays. Do not do such things as daily recitations, mantra repetitions, or meditations on protection cakras.
yang na phyag dang sngags bgrang ba la sogs pa thams cad sgyu ma'i ngang nas bya/
Alternatively, do such things as paying homage and counting mantras within a state of [recognizing all things to be] illusion-like.

de ltar 'khor 'das kyis chos thams cad bden med du shes nas sgyu ma lta bur 'char na/ sgyu lus kyi nyams shar ba'o/ / snang ba sems can thams cad dngos po dang mtshan mas ma gos par chos skur shar ba la zhen pa med na/ sgyu lus kyi rtogs pa shar ba'o/ /

When, by recognizing that the phenomena of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa are unreal, they arise as illusion-like, the experience of illusory forms has arisen. When appearances and sentient beings arise as dharmakāya—without being tainted by [being perceived] as [real] entities or characteristics—and you have no fixations to that, the realization of illusory forms has arisen.

rig gsum mgon po bsgoms pas gzhan gyi blo ngan sel/ me yi phyag rgyas 'jig rten sreg par byed pa de dus su 'byung / mnyam rjes med na tshe 'di la lus 'ja' lus dang / sems chos sku thob nas mchog thob pa'o/ /

By meditating on the protectors of the three families, you clear away the negative minds of others. The fire mudrā burns up the world. When that occurs, if there is no [distinction between] meditative equipoise and postmeditative attainment, in this life you will achieve a rainbow body physically and with your mind you will attain the dharmakāya. You achieve what is sublime.[*17]
sgyu lus chos brgyad rang grol gyi gdams ngag rdzogs so/ /
That completes the instructions on illusory forms, which self-liberate the eight worldly values.[48]
gsum pa rmi lam 'khrul pa rang sangs
III. Dreams: Self-Clarifying Delusion
['di] la bzhi ste/ dran pa'i lcags kyus bzung ba dang / brjed skul gyis sbyang ba dang / phrin las kyi mdzad pa sgyu mar byin gyis brlab pa dang / de kho na nyid bsgom pa'o/ /
This has four parts: (1) recognizing with the iron hook of mindfulness, (2) training through reminders, (3) consecrating activities as illusions, and (4) meditating on suchness.
dang po
A. Recognizing with the Iron Hook of Mindfulness
['di] la gsum/ yi dam dran pa'i lcags kyus gzung ba dang / bla ma dran pa'i lcags kyus gzung ba dang / snang ba dran pa'i lcags kyus bzung ba rnams sgyu lus gyi gser 'gyur rtsi dang 'dra'o/ /

This has three sections: (1) recognizing with the iron hook of mindfulness of the yidam, (2) recognizing with the iron hook of mindfulness of the guru, and (3) recognizing with the iron hook of mindfulness of appearances. They are similar to the gold-creating elixir of illusory forms.[49]
gnyis pa brjed skul gyis sbyang ba ni/
B. Training through Reminders

bla ma'i rnal 'byor bsgom/ rmi lam zin par gsol ba gdab/ nyin mo rmi lam ya mtshan can mang po yid kyis dmigs la/ de rnams rmi lam yin par 'dug / da ngas rmi lam gzung dgos snyam du dran 'dun brgya rtsa re tsam bya/ rmi lam sbyang pa mgrin par sbyang / 'dzin pa smin mtshams su 'dzin pas/ nyal khar bla ma snang ba mtha' yas kyi ngo bo mgrin par bsgom/

Practice guru yoga, and supplicate to recognize your dreams. Focus your mind during the day on having many marvelous dreams. Thinking, “They are dreams. Now I must recognize my dreams,” arouse your mindfulness and resolve a hundred times. To train in dreams, train at the throat. To recognize them, recognize at the point between your eyebrows. When lying down, meditate upon your guru, the essence of Amitābha, at your throat. {520}

phyi nang gsang (520) gsum gyi mchod pa phul/ gsol ba gdab/ mgo nub bde ba can du bstan pas gnas nges ngar byad/ gzhogs g.yas 'og tu phab/ seng ge'i nyal stabs byas pas rlung sems gnad du tshud nas lus des par byed/ 'dzin pa smin mtshams kyi bar thig le dkar po mu tig lta bu gcig la dran pa tu re bar gtad/ gnyid log pas sems nges par byed/

Present the outer, inner, and secret offerings, and supplicate. Your head should face west, toward Sukhāvatī. That establishes the place. Lying on your right side, in the position of a sleeping lion, engage the vital points of wind-mind. That establishes the body. For recognition, direct your awareness continuously to a white, pearl-like bindu at the point between your eyebrows and fall asleep. That establishes the mind.
rmi lam ma zin na don med yin snyam pa bya/ gnyid 'thum pa re bya/ skabs su rlung rtsol bag re bsgom/ gnyid sad res zhing thig le la rig pa gtad/ rmi lam rmi lam du shes na zin pa'o/ /

Think, “If I do not recognize my dreams, all this is meaningless.” Then let yourself fall asleep. At times, meditate using some breath practices. Each time you wake up, direct your awareness to the bindu. When you know dreams to be dreams, that is recognition.[*18][50]
gsum pa phrin las kyi mdzad pa sgyu mar byin gyis brlab pa
C. Consecrating Activities as Illusions
['di] la bzhi/ sprul pa dang / bsgyur ba dang / spel ba dang / lus kyi skar mda' gar 'dod du 'phang ba'o/ /
This has four parts: (1) emanating, (2) transforming, (3) increasing, and (4) sending the shooting star of your body wherever you desire.
dang po ni/
1. Emanating

rmi lam du dgra yis ded pa'am/ chu khyer ba'am/ g.yang la lhung la khad pa'am/ gzugs mi sdug pa la sogs pa byung na/ de la 'jig skrag gi snang ba 'char/ 'di rmi lam yin snyam du shes par byas la/ 'byung po la sogs pa rmi na de dar de'i gnyen por sprul nas 'dul ba zhal las shes/

When you have dreams of being pursued by your enemies, being swept away by water, being about to fall into a chasm, of unpleasant forms, and so forth, you will feel frightened. Recognize them, thinking, “These are dreams.” If you dream of bhūtas and the like, emanate the specific remedy for each one and tame them. Learn those from the oral instructions.[51]
gnyis pa bsgyur ba ni/
2. Transforming

rmi lam zin pa dang / gcig mang por bsgyur/ mang po gcig tu bsgyur/ gzugs chen po chung ngur bsgyur/ chung ngu chen por bsgyur/ dud 'gro mir/ mi lha ru/ / khang khyim rin po che'i gzhal yas khang du bsgyur/ rdzas dang mtshon cha rdo rje dril bu dang / po tir bsgyur/ chu dang / me dang / g.yangs sa thams cad la rmi lam yin pas 'jigs rgyu med snyam du mi phod pa la thog brdzis byas la mchong / sa chu ru bsgyur/ chu me ru bsgyur/ steng 'og brje/ / mdor na rmi lam gyi snang ba thams cad stobs bskyed la bsgyur bar bya'o/ /

Recognize your dreams to be dreams. Transform a single thing into many, and transform many things into one. Change a large form into a small one, and a small one into a large one. Transform animals into humans, humans into gods, and your home into a palace of precious jewels. Transform ordinary substances and weapons into vajras, ghaṇṭās, and volumes of dharma texts. Thinking, “These rivers, fires, and chasms are all a dream,” with no hesitation, trample on them and jump across. Change earth into water, and water into fire. Reverse up and down. In brief, be courageous with all dream appearances and transform them.[52]
gsum pa spel ba ni/
3. Increasing

dngos po gang snang gcig gnyis su spel/ gnyis bzhi/ bzhi brgyad/ brgyad (521)brgya'i bar nas dpag tu med par spel lo/ / sgyu ma mthar ma skyol na nyin nub brtag pa gnad che ste/ nyin mo rmi lam yin snyam nas g.yang la mchong na srog dang bral lo/ /

Whatever thing appears, if it is one, multiply it into two. Increase two to four, four to eight, and eight to a hundred. Multiply things to infinity. {521} In the end, if you are unable to take things to be illusions, the vital point is to examine, day and night, [how it is that things are illusions]. During the day when you think, “This is a dream,” if you were to jump into an abyss, you would die.[53]
bzhi pa lus kyi skar mda' gang 'dod du 'phang ba ni/
4. Sending the Shooting Star of Your Body Wherever You Desire

nyin par dran 'dun drag pos o rgyan/ 'og min/ mngon dga'/ rdo rje gdan la sogs pa bltar 'gro bsam pa bya/ rang gi mdun nam/ spyi bor yi dam dang bla ma dbyer med snang la rang bzhin med pa gcig bsgom/ de'i mgrin par pad+ma dmar po 'dab ma brgyad pa gcig bsam/ de'i lte bar oM/ 'dab ma bzhi la lA~M mA~M bA~M tA~M bsam/ yang na a nu ta ra hU~M bsam/

During the day, with strong mindfulness and resolve, imagine you will go to visit such places as Oḍḍiyāna, Akaniṣṭha, Abhirati, Vajrāsana [Bodh Gaya], and so on. Meditate that in front of yourself or on your head is the yidam inseparable from your guru, appearing yet without any nature. Imagine at their throat an eight-petaled red lotus. Imagine an oṃ in its middle and on its four petals lāṃ, māṃ, bāṃ, and tāṃ. Or imagine a nu ta ra hūṃ.

de nas rang rje btsun mar bsam/ rang dang mdun bskyed gnyis ka la mchod pa 'bul/ rang nyid mdun gyi lha'i mgrin par thim pa la/ yig 'bru lnga la re mos su rig pa hu re gtad/ gnyid du hrib rtsar 'gro dus rang las sems thon nas mdun bskyed kyi lhar sems zhugs pas cung zhig 'gul ba la rag pa gtad/ lus ma lan 'dug par bsam/ sprul pa'i yid lus des o rgyan la sogs par 'gro snyam pa'i dran 'dun gyi ngang nas gnyid log go /

Then imagine that you are the Jetsunma. Offerings are made to both the self visualization and the front visualization. Those dissolve into the throat of the deity in front and yourself. Focus your awareness continuously on the five seed syllables, one after the other. When you are about to fall asleep, your mind emerges from your body and enters the front visualized deity. Shake a little bit and focus your awareness. Imagine your body on your bed. Fall asleep in a state of mindfulness and resolve, thinking that your emanated mind-body goes to Oḍḍiyāna and so forth.

de nas rmi lam nang du rmi lam du 'dug snyam pa dang / skad cig la bya rgod la sogs pa'i sprul pa'i lus zung 'jug gi 'dab shog dang ldan pas 'phur nas phyin pas gang 'dod du phyin pa'i nyams 'byung ngo / /

Then, when you are dreaming, think, “This is a dream.” Instantly, you will have the experience of being in an emanated body, such as that of a vulture, with the wings of unification, flying off and going wherever you wish.
de la goms pas chu zla lta bu'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i zhal dngos su mthong nas chos nyan pa la sogs pa byed de/ mtshan mo'i rmi lam dang / nyin bar gyi sgyu lus la khyad med do/ /

Once you are accustomed to that, you may [dream of] seeing directly the faces of the tathāgatas, who are like moons reflected in water, and listening to the dharma. There is no difference between dreams at night and illusory forms during the day.
mi ma yin pa'i bar chad byung na rang gis kyang rdzu 'phrul sna tshogs bstan la gdul bar bya'o/ /
If you experience obstacles from nonhumans, display various miracles and subdue them yourself.
gzhan yang rmi lam gyi gegs bsal ba ni/ rmi lam mi zin pa'i rgyu bzhi/ rkyen bzhi'o/ /
Dispelling hindrances during dreams. There are four causes and four conditions for not recognizing dreams.
rgyu bzhi ni/ dam tshig nyams pa/ mos gus zhan pa/ mngon zhen che ba/ (522) grib kyis phog pa'o/ /
The four causes are: 1. impaired samayas, 2. weak devotion, 3. strong reification, and {522} 4. being contaminated.

sel thabs ni/ dang po la dbang bskur/ bshags pa bya/ dam tshig sdom pa gso'o/ / gnyis pa la mos gus drag po bya/ gsol ba gdab/ maN+Dal dbul/ bla ma ci mnyes la 'bad/ gsum pa la yo byad spong dag bya/ gang la'ang chags zhen spang / mi rtag pa bsgom/ bzhi pa la gcig pur bsdad/ sdig can dang / sdom med dang mi 'grogs/ ro gos dang mi gtsang ba la 'dzem/ yi ge brgya pa bzla'o/ /

The means for dispelling those are as follows: 1. Receive abhiṣekas, do confessions, and restore your samayas and vows. 2. Arouse strong devotion, make supplications, offer maṇḍalas, and apply yourself to pleasing the guru. 3. Give away everything you own, give up whatever you are attached to or fixated upon, and meditate on impermanence. 4. Stay alone, do not associate with those who are very negative and have no vows, avoid the clothing of corpses and what is unclean, and recite the hundred syllables.
rkyen bzhi ni/ sad 'byams/ 'khrul 'byams/ brjed 'byams/ rgyun 'byams so/ /
The four conditions are: 1. excessive wakefulness, 2. excessive delusion, 3. excessive forgetfulness, and 4. excessive continuity.
sad 'byams ni/ 'dzin 'phro la gnyid du ma song snyam pa dang / gnyid sad pa yin snyam nas 'dzin 'phro gcod pa dang / rmi lam ma zin par long med du sad pa'o/ /

Excessive wakefulness. [This occurs when] you think, “To sustain recognition, I will not go to sleep.” Thinking, “I will stay awake,” you are awake without a break, cutting off the continuity of your recognition and not recognizing your dreams.

de la 'dzin 'phro mi gcod par yang nas yang du gzung / gnyid long med par sad na/ gang gis lan brtags te sgra'i klag cor gyis sad na mi med sar nyal/ zin pa la dga' ches pas sad na sems klod/ las kyang bas sad na gtum mo bsgom pa'am/ gos mthug tu gtong /

[The remedy] for this is to recognize your dreams again and again, without severing the continuity of your recognition. If you wake up immediately, look for the reasons. If chatter is keeping you awake, sleep where there are no people. If being excited about recognizing dreams keeps you awake, relax your mind. If being cold keeps you awake, meditate on caṇḍālī or wrap yourself in thick clothing.

gnyis pa 'khrul 'byams ni/ rmi lam la rmi lam du ma shes par 'khrul pa 'ba' zhig pa'o/ / de la mos gus bskyed la gsol ba gdab/ snang ba thams cad rmi lam yin sgyu ma yin snyam pa'i dran 'dun drag po yang yang bya/

Excessive delusion. It is delusion alone that keeps you from recognizing dreams to be dreams. [The remedy] is to arouse devotion and supplicate. Again and again be mindful and arouse a strong resolve, thinking, “All appearances are dreams and illusions.”
gsum pa brjed 'byams ni 'dzin pa la sogs pa ma byung bar brjed pa'o/ / de la 'dzin sbyang dang gsal po rmi ba'i dran 'dun drag po bya/

Excessive forgetfulness. [This occurs when] you are forgetful, without any recognition or the like arising. [The remedy] for this is to be mindful and arouse the strong resolve to dream clearly and to train in recognition.
bzhi pa bsdug 'byams ni/ rmi lam ma byung ba'am/ byung yang ngos ma zin pa'o/ /
Excessive continuity. This is when dreams do not occur or you do not recognize them when they happen.[*19][54]
bzhi pa rmi lam gyi de kho na nyid bsgom pa ni/
D. Meditating on the Suchness of Dreams

rmi lam gyi snang ba thams cad sems kyi rnam 'phrul/ bzang ngan thams cad sgyu ma'i rtsal kha/ gzugs thams cad snang stong / sgra grags stong / sems (523)gdod ma nas skye 'gag gnas gsum dang bral ba/ rmi lam dang nyin bar gyi snang bar khyad med par bden med rang shar rang grol yin par sgyu ma lta bu yin pas stong pa la sogs pa'i ngang du gzhag par bya'o/ /

All dream appearances are displays of mind. Everything, good or bad, is an illusory display. All forms are appearance-emptiness. Sounds are sound-emptiness. [Thoughts are awareness-emptiness or bliss-emptiness.][55] {523} Mind is primordially free from arising, ceasing, or abiding. There is no difference between dreams and daytime appearances. They are unreal, self-arising and self-liberating. Since they are illusion-like, rest in a state of emptiness and so forth.[*20]
rmi lam 'khrul pa rang sangs gyi gdams ngag go /
Those are the instructions on dreams: self-clarifying delusion.[56]
bzhi pa 'od gsal ma rig mun bral
IV. Luminosity: Freedom from the Darkness of Ignorance

['di] la lnga ste/ lus gnad la brten nas sems mal du gzhug pa dang / lus gnad la brten nas sgom pa ngos gzung ba dang / ye shes pa'i spyan pas ma rig pa'i glang po gzung ba dang / ting nge 'dzin gyi ye shes ngo sprad pa dang / rjes spyod 'od gsal gyi bogs 'don pa'o/ /

This has five parts: (1) placing mind on its bed using the vital points of body, (2) identifying the meditation using the vital points of the locations, (3) restraining the elephant of ignorance with the eyes of wisdom, (4) pointing out wisdom through samādhi, and (5) subsequent practices for enhancing [the recognition of] luminosity.
dang po ni/
A. Placing Mind on Its Bed Using the Vital Points of Body

gnas dben par chu dron mos lus bkru/ de nas dri chus/ de nas chang gis/ de nas zhun chen nam/ med na mar gyis byug / de nas dri bzang gis byug / lus kyi bya ba spangs te dal bar bsdad/ thabs shes rab kyi zas bsten/ zhag gsum gnyid bsrung bar bya'o/ /

In an isolated place, wash your body with warm water. Then, rub it with urine, beer, great fat, or, if that is not available, butter. Then, rub it with scented water. Put aside physical activities and be at leisure. Enjoy the foods of method and prajñā. Keep yourself from sleeping for three days.[57]
gnyis pa yul gnad la brten nas sgom pa ngos gzung ba
B. Identifying the Meditation Using the Vital Points of the Locations
['di] la bzhi ste/ dus gnod/ yul gnad/ lus gnad/ dmigs pa'i gnad do/ /
This has four aspects: (1) the vital points of time, (2) the vital points of the locations, (3) the vital points of the body, and (4) the vital points of the object of meditation.
dus gnad ni/
1. The Vital Points of Time
nam smad nas nyi ma dros kyi bar dang / gnyid du song nas rmi lam ma byung gi bar rlung dbu mar 'jug pa'i dus so/ /
From the last part of the night until midmorning[*21] and from when you go to sleep until dreams arise are the times when the winds enter the madhyamā.
yul gnad ni/
2. The Vital Points of the Locations

'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po gling bzhi las mi 'da' ba bzhin/ rang gi rig pa 'di 'khor lo bzhi las mi 'da' ste/ tha mal gyi dus na lte bar gnas/ gnyid dus na snying ga / rmi lam gyi dus na mgrin pa/ snyoms 'jug dus na spyi bo na gnas so/ / des na yul snying ga chos kyi 'khor lor gnad du bsnan pa'o/ /

In the same way that the four continents are not beyond [the domain of] a cakravartin monarch, the four cakras are not beyond [the domain of] your own awareness. During the ordinary [daytime] period, it resides at the navel, during sleep at the heart, during dreams at the throat, and during sexual union at the head. Therefore, penetrate the location of the heart, the dharmacakra.
lus gnad ni/
3. The Vital Points for the Body
g.yas 'og tu phab/ g.yon bstod la seng ge'i nyal stabs sam/ tsog gnyid bya'o/ / shar mngon dga'i phyogs su mgo (524) bstan no/ /
Adopt the sleeping posture of a lion with your right side down and your left above. Or sleep in a crouching position. Your head should face toward the eastern direction of Abhirati. {524}
dmigs pa'i gnad ni/
4. The Vital Points of the Object of Meditation

snying gi rtse mo gyen la bstan pa'i nang du pad+ma sngon po 'dab ma brgyad pa'i lte ba la hU~M sngon po/ phyogs bzhi'i 'dab ma la mdun du a dkar po/ g.yas su nu ser po/ rgyab tu ta dmar po/ g.yon du ra ljang gu rnams gsal bar dmigs par bya'o/ /

The tip of your heart faces upward, where there is a blue eight-petaled lotus. Visualize clearly that in its center is a blue hūṃ and that on its petals in the four directions are a white a in front, a yellow nu to the right, a red ta to the rear, and a green ra to the left.[*22][58]
gsum pa ye shes kyi spyan pas ma rig pa'i glang po gzung ba ni/
C. Restraining the Elephant of Ignorance with the Eyes of Wisdom
bla ma ye shes spyan pa/ slob ma ma rig pa'i glang po'o/ / 'di la gnyis/ ba thag gser phur la glang po btags pa dang / rin chen tho bas ma rig pa'i gnyid sad pa'o/ /

The guru is the eyes of wisdom, and the disciple is the elephant of ignorance. This has two parts: (1) attaching the elephant to a golden stake with a gossamer thread and (2) being woken up from the sleep of ignorance by a jeweled hammer.
dang po ni/
1. [Attaching the Elephant]
ras bal gyi skud pa 'dom gang pa gcig slob ma'i skra la btags/ de bla ma'i srin lag la btags so/ /
Tie a cotton thread about a fathom long to the disciple’s hair and attach that to the guru’s ring finger.
rin chen thob ni/
2. The Jeweled Hammer

shing phra mo 'dom gang pa gcig gi rtse mo la ras kyi pho lto bskon pa gcig byas/ de nas sngon du bla ma la tshogs 'khor dbul/ bka' brgyud la gsol ba drag tu gdab/ bdag gi slob ma la 'od gsal zin par byin gyis rlobs bya/

Attach a soft tip to the end of a slender piece of wood, a fathom long. Then, begin by offering a gaṇacakra to the gurus. Make fervent supplications to the Kagyu lineage, saying, “Grant your blessings to my disciple to recognize luminosity.”

zhun chen gyi mar me mtshan thub gtong / sha chen gyis brgyan pa'i gtor ma gta' ru gzung / mkha' 'gro zas kyi phud kyis mchod/ slob mas mtshams gcad/ thig le bsrung / bla ma'i rnal 'byor byas la gsol ba gdab bo/ /

Set out a lamp of great fat capable of lasting a night. There should always be a torma adorned with great flesh. Offer a select portion of food to the ḍākinīs. Disciples should set the boundary [for their retreat], protect their bindus, do guru yoga, and make supplications.

de yang gnyid du 'gro ba dang 'chi ba tshul mthun pa yin pas/ 'byung ba bzhi thim pa'i 'gros ni/ dang po gnyid du 'gro dus sa chu la thim pas lus lci yor ba dang / shes pa nag thib ba dang / kha chu nar re 'ong / chu me la thim pas dpral ba tsha 'ub mig tshum cher te 'gro/ me rlung la thim pas sna su su sdur ba ngar ngar 'ong / rlung rnam shes la thim pas nyin mo'i rnam rtog 'gag / mtshan mo'i rmi lam ma byung ba'i bar der gnyid kyi 'od gsal stong pa mtha' dbus (525) med pa nam mkha' ltar ngos bzung med pa sa le seng nge ba gcig yong ba de ngos 'dzin pa'o/ /

Since the processes of going to sleep and dying are similar, the sequence of the dissolution of elements is as follows: First, when going to sleep, since earth dissolves into water, your body slumps with heaviness. Your mind is dark. Your saliva becomes thick. When water dissolves into fire, your forehead becomes very hot and your eyes begin to close. When fire dissolves into wind, you will start to snore heavily. When wind dissolves into consciousness, your daytime thoughts cease. {525} Before your nighttime dreams arise, there will be the empty luminosity of sleep, free from edge or center, like space. It is unidentifiable and yet vivid and vibrant. Recognize that.
de nas bla mas/ ngas de ltar skud pa 'then/ dbyug gus brgyud bya yi/ 'od gsal zin na zin 'phro gcig la bsgom/ ma zin na bskyor la sgoms la/ ral lan ma ster bya'o/ /

Then, the guru says, “I will pull on the string. I will connect to you with the stick. If you recognize luminosity, cultivate the continuity of your recognition. If you do not recognize, again meditate. Do not give me a reply.”

de yang zin na phyi rtags dbang po'i mdangs ya le yong / sdur pa mi 'ong / ma zin na ba thag gser phur 'then tsam bya/ rin chen tho ba thug thug bya'o/ / des gnyid mi sang / gdams pa gsal 'debs pa'o/ /

If you have recognition, the outer signs are that your sense facilities are radiant and you do not snore. If you do not have recognition, [the guru] will pull on the gossamer thread attached to the golden stake and nudge you with the jeweled hammer. This will not wake you up—it will clarify the instructions.[59]
bzhi pa ting nge 'dzin gyi ye shes ngo sprad pa ni/
D. Pointing Out Wisdom with Samādhi
gcig car ba gang zin du ngo sprad pa dang / rim gyis cho ga la brten nas nyams dang sbyar nas ngo sprad pa'o/ /
This has [two parts]: (1) the pointing out for the instantaneous type and (2) the pointing out for the gradual type, which uses a technique and is joined with experience.
dang po ni/
1. The Pointing Out for the Instantaneous Type
gcig car ba la nges med du 'od gsal zin pa 'byung bas de la yid ches bskyed par bya'o/ /
Since the recognition of luminosity arises unpredictably for the instantaneous type, they should arouse confidence.
rim gyis ba ngo sprad pa ni/
2. The Pointing Out for the Gradual Type

dang po gnyid log khar tha mal gyi dus su a la shes pa gtad pas yul rags pa'i rtog pa thim pas/ snang ba stong pa ngos gzung / gnyid hrib pa dang nu la gtad pas yul phra ba'i rtog pa thams cad thim/ mched pa dang shin tu stong pa/ de bas kyang cher hrib pa dang ta la gtad pas ches phra ba'i rtog pa thim pas/ thob pa dang stong pa chen po/ shin tu hrib pa'i dus su ra la gtad pas rtog pa thams cad thim pas nye bar thob pa dang thams cad stong pa'o/ / hrib kyis song ba'i dus su hU~M la gtad pas rang bzhin brgyad cu'i rtog pa thams cad thim pas 'od gsal chen po ngos gzung bar bya'o/ /

First, at the brink of falling asleep, during the ordinary state, focus your mind on a. When your thoughts of coarse objects dissolve, recognize illumination and emptiness. When you become sleepier and focus on nu, your thoughts of subtle objects dissolve. Recognize radiance and extreme emptiness. Then, when you become very sleepy and focus on ta, your very subtle thoughts dissolve. Recognize attainment and great emptiness. When you become extremely sleepy and focus on ra, all your thoughts dissolve. Recognize imminent attainment and total emptiness. When you have gone to sleep and focus on hūṃ, all eighty intrinsic thoughts dissolve. You recognize great luminosity.

yang na gnyid hrib pa'i dus du 'dod chags kyi rtog pa bzhi bcu 'gag /cher hrib pa'i dus su zhe sdang gi rtog pa sum cu rtsa gsum 'gag / shin tu hrib pa'i dus su gti mug gi rtog pa bdun 'gag nas 'od gsal chos sku'i don 'char ro/ / (526)

Alternatively, when you become sleepier, the forty thoughts associated with desire cease. When you become very sleepy, the thirty-three thoughts associated with aggression cease. When you become extremely sleepy, the seven thoughts associated with bewilderment cease. Then luminosity, the dharmakāya, arises. {526}
de nas gnyid sad pa dang / nyin mtshan gcig tu bsres nas rgyun chad med par bsgom par bya'o/ /'od gsal gyi gegs sel zhal las shes/
Next, blend waking up from sleep and the day and night, and meditate continuously.[*23] You should learn how to dispel the hindrances to luminosity from oral instructions.[60]
lnga pa rjes spyod 'od gsal gyi bogs 'don pa ni/
E. Subsequent Practices for Enhancing [the Recognition of] Luminosity
spros bcas spros med gnyis pas
This has two parts: (1) with elaborations and (2) without elaborations.
spros bcas ni/
1. With Elaborations

mdun gyi bar snang du hU~M sngon po bai DUr+Ya'i mdog can shin tu gsal ba rtog pas bar ma chod par bsgom/ de nas skye na hU~M rigs lnga'i rang bzhin tu zhabs kyu ha la thim/ ha mgo bo la/ mgo bo zla tshes la/ zla tshes thig le la/ thig le nA da la/ de 'od gsal du yal bas stong nyid mi rtog pa'i ngang du gzhag /

Meditate that in the space in front of you there is a blue hūṃ, the color of vaiḍūrya. Its vivid clarity is not interrupted by thoughts. Then, when you tire of that, the shapkyu of the hūṃ, which is of the nature of the five buddhas, dissolves into the ha. The ha dissolves into its head, its head into the crescent, the crescent into the bindu, the bindu into the nāda, and then that disappears into luminosity. Remain in nonconceptual emptiness.
de la skyon lha sku stong ra'i thugs kar hU~M sngon po bsgom/ de 'od du zhu/ stong ra'ang sngo nar gang / de je che la nam mkha' dang mnyam pa'i ngang du gzhag go /

When you tire of that, meditate on a blue hūṃ in the heart of a deity’s form, an empty enclosure. That melts into light. Blue light fills the empty enclosure and increases. Remain in a state that equals space.
spros med ni/
2. Without Elaborations

da ltar gyi snang ba sna tshogs 'di me long gi gzugs brnyan nam chu nang gi zla ba ltar snang tsam du zang kyi ngo bo la grub pa med par shes par byas la/ rjes thob la sngar gyi sgyu lus su langs la bya ba ci byed thams cad la 'jug par bya'o/ / de ltar brtson 'grus dang ldan pas dus la mi ltos par tshe 'di nyid dang 'chi khar sa bcu'i rtogs pa skye bar 'gyur ro/ /

Know that all the various present appearances are simply appearances, like reflections in a mirror or the moon reflected in water—they have no existent essence. During postmeditative attainment, arise as the previous illusory form and engage in all your activities. Those who possess diligence, without considering [the length of] time [that they have practiced], will give rise to the realizations of the ten bhūmis in this very lifetime or at the moment of death.[*24]
'od gsal ma rig mun bral gyi gdams ngag go /
Those are the instructions for luminosity: freedom from the darkness of ignorance.[61]
lnga pa 'pho ba gser 'gyur gyi rtsi'i gdams ngag ni/
V. Transference: The Elixir for the Transformation into Gold
sngar gyi de lta bus lam bgrod pa yin pa la/ gal lte dus kyi gtugs na 'pho ba bya ste/ de la gnyis/ thun mong dang / khyad par ro/ /
Those who have traversed the path presented above should do transference when they meet with the occasion [of death]. This has two parts: (1) the shared and (2) the special.
thun mong ni/
A. The Shared

ser sna sbyin par 'pho/ 'dod chags tshul khrims la/ zhe sdang bzod par/ le lo brtson 'grus su/ rnam g.yeng bsam gtan du/ gti mug shes rab tu/ rang 'dod gzhan don du/ rnam rtog bskyed rim du 'pho ba'o/ /

Avarice is transferred into generosity. Desire is transferred into ethical conduct. Aggression is transferred into patience. Laziness is transferred into diligence. Distraction is transferred into meditative concentration. Bewilderment is transferred into prajñā. Self concerns are transferred into altruism. Thoughts are transferred into the generation process.[62]
khyad par gyi 'pho ba
B. The Special Transference
['di] la gnyis/ yul gang du 'pho ba dang / thabs gang gis 'pho ba'o/ /
This has two parts: (1) the places to which we transfer and (2) the methods by which we transfer. {527}
1. The Places to Which We Transfer
yul gang du 'pho ba la (527)gsum/ spros med chos skur 'pho ba dang / spros bcas gzugs skur 'pho ba dang / /yid 'ong mkha' 'gro'i grong du 'pho ba'o/ /
There are three places to which we transfer: the dharmakāya without elaborations, the form kāyas with elaborations, and the pleasing residences of ḍākinīs.[63]
'pho thabs
2. The Methods by Which We Transfer
['di] la gsum/ rab 'od gsal du 'pho ba dang / 'bring sgyu lus su 'pho ba dang / tha ma bskyed rim gyis 'pho ba'o/ /

This has three parts: (1) transference into luminosity for the best, (2) transference into illusory forms for the intermediate, and (3) transference using the generation process for those of normal abilities.
dang po
a. Transference into Luminosity
['di] la gnyis/ rang bzhin gyi 'od gsal dang / bsam gtan gyi 'od gsal lo/ /
This has two sections: (1) transference into natural luminosity and (2) transference into the luminosity of meditative concentration.
rang bzhin gyi 'od gsal du 'pho ba ni/ /
i. Transference into Natural Luminosity

sems can thams cad la 'chi dus su phyi dbugs chad nas nang dbugs ma chad pa'i bar du 'od gsal 'char bas/ de ngos bzung la de'i steng du ma yengs par bzhag pas lam gyi 'od gsal dang gcig tu 'dres nas chos skur sangs rgyas pa'o/ / de la da lta gnyid kyi 'od gsal zin pa gcig dgos so/ /

All sentient beings experience luminosity when they die from [the moment] their external breath ceases until their internal breath ceases. By recognizing that and resting without distraction right with it, it is mixed with path luminosity. You will awaken as the dharmakāya. For that, you must recognize the luminosity of sleep now.
ii.
[ii. Transference into the Luminosity of Meditative Concentration]

de la goms pa chung na bsam gtan gyi 'od gsal du 'pho ba ni/ / 'chi khar lus gnad gang bde byed/ / skye med 'od gsal ngos gzung la/ de la skad cig kyang ma yengs par bya/ dbugs ring thung gi dus su ha byas pas shes pa dang nam mkha' bsre la btang / chos skur sangs rgyas pa'o/ /

When you are slightly familiar with that [luminosity], you can do transference into the luminosity of meditative concentration as follows: When you are dying, use the vital points of body that are comfortable. Recognize unborn luminosity and do not be distracted from that for even an instant. When your breath becomes shorter, say ha and mix your mind with space. You will awaken as the dharmakāya.[64]
gnyis pa sgyu lus su 'pho ba
b. Transference into Illusory Forms
['di] la gnyis te/ rang bzhin gyi sgyu lus dang / bsam bstan gyi sgyu lus so/ /
This has two parts: (1) transference into natural illusory forms and (2) transference into illusory forms of meditative concentration.
dang po ni/
i. Transference into Natural Illusory Forms
sngar sgyu lus la goms shing sbyangs pa de la/ ci ltar sbyangs pa'i dngos po thams cad sgyu mar shes pa'i ngang nas zhen pa dang chags pa spu tsam yang med par 'phos pas longs skur sangs rgya'o/ /

Previously, you became familiar with illusory forms and trained with them. Within a state of recognizing all the things you trained with as being illusions, do transference without even a speck of fixation or attachment. You will awaken as the saṃbhogakāya.
ii.
[ii. Transference into Illusory Forms of Meditative Concentration]

de la goms pa chung na/ bsam gtan gyi sgyu lus su 'pho ba ni/ lus tha mal du zhen pa'i gnyen por lha sku snang la rang bzhin med par bsgom/ ngag tha mal du zhen pa'i gnyen por A li kA li brjod/ sems tha mal du zhen pa'i gnyen por chos thams cad rang bzhin med par shes par bya/ gzugs snang stong / (528)sgra grags stong / rtog pa gsal stong / chos thams cad sgyu ma/ sgyu ma'i ngang nas 'dun pa drag po yang yang bya zhing rlung dang bstun nas 'phos pas longs sku sgyu ma lta bur sangs rgyas so/ /

When you are slightly familiar with that, you can do transference into the illusory forms of meditative concentration as follows: As the antidote for fixating upon your body as ordinary, meditate on it as the body of a deity, appearing yet without any nature. As a remedy for fixating on your speech as ordinary, recite ā li kā li. As the remedy for fixating on your mind as ordinary, recognize that all phenomena lack any nature. Forms are appearance-emptiness. {528} Sounds are sound-emptiness. Thoughts are clarity-emptiness. All phenomena are illusions. Within a state of [recognizing that all things are] illusions, repeatedly arouse a strong resolve. By transferring in conjunction with the winds, you will awaken as the illusion-like saṃbhogakāya.[65]
gsum pa bskyed rim gyis 'pho ba
c. Transference Using the Generation Process
['di] la gnyis te/ sbyangs te 'pho ba dang / btsan thabs su 'pho ba'o/ /
This has two parts: (1) transference through training and (2) transference through forceful means.
dang po
i. Transference through Training
['di] la gnyis te/ sbyang ba dang / 'pho ba'o/ /
This has two sections: (1) training and (2) transference.
dang po sbyang ba
A) Training
['di] la gnyis te/ dran pa'i spyan pas nyes pa'i skyon bsal ba dang / hU~M gi sang phrug gangs la 'phyo ba'o/ /
This has two components: (1) using the eyes of mindfulness to avoid the mistake of wrongdoing and (2) the lion cub of hūṃ leaping into snow.
dang po ni/
1) Using the Eyes of Mindfulness to Avoid the Mistake of Wrongdoing

bdag ring por mi thogs par 'chi dus 'di ga ltar du 'chi/ des na sems can gyi don du 'pho ba sbyang snyam du bsam/ de ma byas na dus min lha bsad pa'i nyes pa 'byung ngo / / rang rje btsun mar bskyed/ rtsa dbu ma mda' smyug tsam bsgom/ spyi bo'i tshangs bug k+Sha dmar nag gcig gis bkag par bsgom/ snying gar rlung sems 'dus pa'i ngo bo hU~M sngon po ba thag tsam btags par bsam/

Reflect on the thought, “Soon I will die—how will that be? I must train in transference for the benefit of sentient beings.” If you do not do that, the wrongdoing of killing the deity in an untimely manner may occur. Generate yourself as the Jetsunma. Meditate on your madhyamā channel, the size of a bamboo arrow. Meditate that your opening of Brahmā at the top of your head is closed by a single dark red kṣa. Think that at your heart there is a blue hūṃ, the essence that combines wind and mind, tethered by a gossamer thread.[66]
gnyis pa hU~M gi seng phrug gangs la 'phyo ba ni/ /
2) The Lion Cub of Hūṃ Leaping into Snow

steng gi nam mkha' la bla ma yi dam tha mi dad pa thugs kar pad+ma kha bye ba'i tshul du bsgom/ 'pho ba 'byongs par byin gyis rlobs/ / zhes gsol ba gdab/ rlung ro bus nas rlung nang du drag tu ring bar rngub/ steng rlung chil gyis mnan pas snying ga'i hU~M de mar song lte 'og gi a dang 'dres par bsam/ thur ser gcud/ srin po bskum/ rgyu zhabs nyongs byas la/ ngag tu hig ka hig byas nas drangs pas hU~M a ba d+hU ti'i nang na yar song bas spyi bo'i k+Sha la thug / thod pa ser ka shig shig rus pa theb gang dang / sha khrag dang bcas pa rgyangs thon nas bla ma'i thugs kar song /

Meditate that your guru, undifferentiated from the yidam, is above in space. At their heart is a blooming lotus. Supplicate them, saying, “Bless me to master transference.” Expel your stale breath, and draw a very long breath inside. Pressing down your upper wind with saliva, think that the hūṃ at your heart goes down and mixes with the a below your navel. Work the downward-expelling wind, contract the rakṣasa, and contract the lower part of your intestines. By drawing up as you say hik ka hik, the hūṃ moves upward in the avadhūti and touches the kṣa at your head. The fissure at the top of your skull splits open, and the hūṃ—with a small bit of bone and [some] flesh and blood—goes out and reaches the guru’s heart.
yang rlung rngub hU~M mar byung / srog gi rgyun ba thag lta bu la zhon nas snying gar thug tser babs par bsam/
Again, with an inhalation of breath, think that the hūṃ comes down. Riding the continuity of your life force, like a gossamer thread, it falls to your heart, just touching it.
de bzhin du rlung rtsol nyer gcig gam/ lnga bcu rtsa lnga tsam re sbyang / thun (529)bshol khar bla ma rang la bstims la sang sprug bya/ rjes gnas lugs kyi don la ji srid gnas par gzhag go /

Train in that way with the breath practices twenty-one or fifty-five times.[*25] {529} At the end of the session, the guru dissolves into you and you become a lion cub. Then, remain as long as you can in the abiding state.
tshad ma zin na ngos su 'pho bas tshong zin par bya'o/ /
If you have not gained proficiency, you will do so through the actual transference.
'byongs pa'i tshad ni/ /
The measure of mastery.

spyi gtsug rtse ba dang / g.ya' ba dang / dra ba dang / 'phrig pa dang / skrangs pa dang / khrag chu ser thon pa dang / shes pa phyed phyed pa dang / dbugs stod du 'tshangs pa dang / snying na kheng pa 'byung ngo / / de ltar byung ba dang sbyong 'phro bcad/ 'chi dus su blo gtad thub pas yid ches par bya'o/ /

The top of your head becomes pointed, is itchy, is warm, quivers, has a swelling, and blood and lymph flow. Your mind may feel fuzzy, your chest might feel “full” of breath, and your heart achy. When that happens, stop training. At the time of death, be confident in your ability to direct your mind.[67]
gnyis pa 'pho ba ni/
B) Transference

'chi ltas tshang ba dang / 'chi ltas brtag pa zhal las shes/ nam mkha' la bla ma yi dam gnyis med thugs gnyis su med pa'i ye shes bde ba chen po dang ldan pa'i thugs pad+ma 'dam ma brgyad pa kha bye ba'i tshul du bsams la/ snga ma ltar hU~M la rnam shes bsdus la/ spyi bo'i k+Sha gsal btab la 'og rlung gcud la thugs kar 'phos pas thugs gnyis su med pa'i ye shes dang / bdag gi shes pa dbyer med du 'dres pa dang /

You should learn all the death omens and how to discern the death omens from oral instructions. Imagine in space the guru and yidam nondual and that in their heart, nondual wisdom and great bliss, is a blooming eight-petaled lotus. As before, gather your consciousness into hūṃ. Visualize kṣa at your head. Work the lower wind, and send [the hūṃ] to [the yidam-guru’s] heart. Mix their mind of nondual wisdom and your mind inseparably.

phyir bskyed byas pas srog gi rgyun ba thag lta bu rbad kyis chad par bsams la/ rlung gcud pas lan gcig gis nges par 'pho ba'o/ /de dus bla ma'i grogs la sogs pas bde stong la gnas par gyis zhes bsgrag par bya'o/ /

Then, expanding outward, think that the continuity of your life force, like a gossamer thread, has been completely severed. By working the wind, you will definitely transfer in one time. At that time, your guru, friends, and others should tell you, “Rest in bliss-emptiness.”
rlung las mi nus na/ seng ge'i nyal stabs byas la gzhan snga ma dang 'dra'o/ /
If you are not able [to transfer] through [working] the wind, adopt the sleeping position of a lion. The rest is the same as before.[68]
gnyis pa btsan thabs su 'pho ba
ii. Transference through Forceful Means
['di] la gsum/ lus gnad la brten nas 'khor ba'i 'grul bcad pa dang / shel gyi 'ban btsug pa dang / ka hig gi mdas gang 'dod kyi gnas su 'phang ba'o/ /
This has three parts: (1) severing your journey in saṃsāra using the vital points of body, (2) setting up the crystal target, and (3) the arrow of ka hik sends you to your desired location.
dang po ni/
A) Severing Your Journey in Saṃsāra Using the Vital Points of Body

sems bskyed/ gsol ba gdab/ sgo dgu gang rung nas rnam shes thon nas de dang der skye ba sangs rgyas kyis kyang mi khegs pas/ 'khrul 'khor seng ge rnam grol 'di shin tu zab bo/ srin (530)zhal dmyal ba'i sgo yin pas rting bas bkag / 'og rlung bsdams/ bya kang dus 'gro'i sgo long mo gnyis kyi bar du btsir/ skyes dman la rtigs pas gdab/ 'brub khung yi dwags kyi sgo mthe'u chung gis dgag snom byed gnod sbyin gyi sgo srin lag gis dgag ma thub na g.yon nas gtang / lta byed mi'i sgo gung mos dgag / nyan byed lha'i sgo mthe bong gis dgag /

Arouse bodhicitta. Supplicate. Once your consciousness has departed through one of the nine doors, you will be born in the corresponding place. Even a buddha cannot stop that. The liberation of a lion trulkhor is very profound here.[*26] {530} Since the rakṣasa mouth is the door to the hells, block it with your heel. Restrain your lower wind. The “bird’s foot”[*27] is the door to the animal realm. Press it between both ankles. Women should press it with their heel. The incarceration box is the door to the hungry ghost realm. Block it with your little fingers. The agents of smell are the doors to the yakṣa state. Block them with your ring fingers, and when you cannot [hold your breath any longer], release it through the left. The agents of vision are the doors to the human state. Block them with your middle fingers. The agents of hearing are the doors to the god realm. Block them with your thumbs.[*28][69]
gnyis pa shel gyi 'ben gzug ba ni/
B) Setting Up the Crystal Target
bla ma yi dam gang gsal cig spyi bo ru 'dom gang tsam du bzhugs pa'i thugs pad+ma kha 'byed pa'i tshul du bsgom/
Visualize either your guru or yidam as seated a fathom above your head. Meditate that their heart is a blooming lotus.[70]
ka hig gi mdas gang 'dod du 'phang ba ni/
C) The Arrow of Ka Hik Sends You to Your Desired Location
thag pa'am dbyug pa la rgyab bkal/ khong du ka hig brjod/ shes pa shel gyi 'ben la 'phang / sbyor ba gcig gis nges par 'pho ba'o/ / gnyis dang gsum gyis mi 'pho mi srid do/ /

Use a rope or staff as a backrest. Internally say ka hik. Send your mind to the crystal target.[*29] One application will bring definite transference. It will be impossible not to transfer through two or three applications.[*30]
gnad bzhi zhal las shes/ ma bsgoms sangs rgyas 'pho ba gser 'gyur rtsi'i gdams ngag go /
The four vital points should be learned from oral instructions. Those are the instructions on transference, the elixir for the transformation into gold and awakening without meditating.[71]
drug pa grong 'jug sbrul lpags 'dor byed ni/ /
VI. Entering a Body: Shedding a Snake’s Skin

dper na sbrul de nam zla dbyar ngor pags pa rnying ba de dor nas gsar bu gcig 'byung ba ltar/ rang gi lam yongs su ma rdzogs shing rten dman par gyur na/ shes pa gzhan lus kyi rten grong du zhugs la don chen bsgrub par bya'o/ /

In the same way that when a snake sheds its old skin during the summer months, a new one appears, when you have not completed the path and have an inferior support, [that is, physical body], your mind should enter the body (the support) of another, and you will achieve your great aims.
'di la gsum ste/ 'jug bya yul gyi gnad kyis chad ldan du sbyang ba dang / 'jug byed rten gyi gnad kyis gar 'dod du 'phang ba dang / mthun rkyen grog kyi gnad kyis rnam shes gsal gdab ba'o/ /

This has three parts: (1) using the vital points of an object (what is to be entered) to train to be qualified, (2) using the vital points of the supports (the means for entering) to send you where you wish, and (3) using the vital points of friends (the conducive conditions) to clarify your consciousness.
dang po
A. Using the Vital Points of an Object (What Is to Be Entered) to Train to Be Qualified
